title: Characterization of Materials
reviews: A  hands on, extremely well designed course, which will get you up to speed with the most common techniques in materials characterization - Highly Recommended!
An excellent and informative class.
Easy class that is very informative.
Great course. Do it.
SEM, AFM, XRD, if you do not know them, you should take the course.
Strongly Recommend
Take it if you can.
Take notes as much as possible in the lab session. These notes are the most important thing when you want to operation the machine yourself.
Take the course
This class is a low stress introduction to various useful instruments.  It was interesting and informative.
This class is good and fills up quick, so register for it right away and then drop it later. The "I can just add it later" mentality is ignorant.
This is a nice informative course.  I think it is more valuable for students who are engaged in some sort of research in which these techniques directly apply.
very good course.  take it if you will ever need to using the instruments in the imaging facility.
descrip: A multidisciplinary course offering a practical introduction to techniques of imaging structure and compositional analysis of advanced materials. Focus on principles and applications of various characterization methods. Covered topics include AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, EDX/WDX, EELS, Confocal Microscopy, sample preparation and image processing, etc. Hands-on experience is emphasized.

title: Ecohydrology
descrip: A description of the hydrologic mechanisms that underlie ecological observations. The space-time dynamics of soil-plant-atmosphere is studied at different temporal and spatial scales. A review is done of the role of environmental fluctuations in the distribution of vegetation. Emphasis is made in the dynamics of soil moisture. The signatures revealing fractal structures in landscapes and vegetation are reviewed as result of self-organizing dynamics. Unifying concepts in the processes responsible for these signatures will be studied with examples from hydrology and ecology.

title: East Asian Humanities II: Tradition and Transformation
reviews: A good survey course on East Asian history as seen by various media (literature, film, etc.) An enjoyable EM.

Don't be fooled by the title of the course.  This is an EM, not an LA, so discussions will be focuses more on the macro aspect (meaning overall message of the reading as opposed to tiny details that might act as symbolism). This was the trap I fell into, I focused too much on the implications of syntax and imagery instead of thinking about what the readings meant for how Eastern Asians carried themselves.
If you are interested in East Asia, take this class.
It was a very interesting course and a great way to get to know the other professors in the EAS department.
TAKE IT

Take it!

And don't be afraid to ask if anything is unclear. The professors are very helpful.
This is a great choice for EAS majors. I think most students will find it more interesting than the alternative history sequence of courses.
descrip: This is the second half of a sequence introducing the humanities in East Asia. The course takes up early modern to modern periods, including the 20th century. Lectures are given by specialists in the departments of East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Art and Archaeology and Religious Studies. Lectures and classes are complemented by performances and films. The course is organized thematically rather than chronologically, and topics range from the early modern to the post-modern in the disciplines of literature, visual arts, music, philosophy and religion.

title: Food for Sociological Thought
descrip: If "you are what you eat," what are we? What do our food and eating habits reveal about identities, ethnicity, gender roles, sexuality, families, and sub-cultures? Flipping the direction of inquiry, where does our food come from? How do social institutions--from education to corporate markets to law to social movements--influence what and how we eat? This course examines food practices as sociological issues. We will read works by academics and journalists focusing on the politics that shape what is available for us to eat, how these institutions are being resisted, and current concerns about food production and consumption in the U.S.

title: Algebra
reviews: I predict a number of negative reviews of this course, but I'd take those with a grain of salt. The majority of the class stopped coming to class most days, and on any given day we would usually have 4-6 out of 15 people show up. If you actually came to class the pacing and material were understandable.
If you wish to learn take the course.
Perhaps read the material before coming to lecture? I am forced to wave my hands in despair to this question... If I had figured that out, I would have implemented this myself.
prereqs: MAT 202, MAT 204, or MAT 217 or permission of Instructor..
descrip: Algebra & Applications: To develop curiousity about algebraic structures by exploring examples that connect to higher mathematics and to applications in computer science, the natural sciences and electrical engineering. This is an undergrad course for sophomores and juniors The only prereq. is a solid understanding of linear algebra. There will be opportunities for a student to explore an advanced topic in great depth, possibly for a junior project.

title: Laboratory in Plasma Physics
reviews: Life will be far more enjoyable if you realize early on that the questions in the lab manuals are just suggestions, not requirements.
Take time to talk with Professor Cohen and learn about how to take advantage of the resources in the lab.  Learn how to work in groups and collaborate.
descrip: Develop skills, knowledge, and understanding of basic and advanced laboratory techniques used to measure the properties and behavior of plasmas. Representative experiments are: cold-cathode plasma formation and architecture; ambipolar diffusion in afterglow plasmas; Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and plasma density; period doubling and transitions to chaos in glow discharges; optical spectroscopy for species identification; microwave interferometry and cavity resonances for plasma density determination; and momentum generated by a plasma thruster.

title: Advanced Modern Greek
reviews: Be prepared for a wide range of ability in the classroom and just concentrate on improving your own language skills rather than trying to compare yourself to others in the class.

If you are interested in improving your Greek, take it! I can't make any extreme recommendations since we had a strange second half of the year, but I can say that if Dimitri is in charge, he's wonderful!

This class needs consistent dedication to be truly effective. Even if there aren't written assignments every night I advise reading through the textbook or internalizing class notes. The class is great, no matter what level your Greek is at. The small class size was really nice.
prereqs: HLS 105 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Advanced composition and oral practice aimed at developing idiomatic written and spoken style. Discussions entirely in Greek. Introduces students to contemporary Greek culture and literature through the study of works by Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Ritsos, and Anagnostakis, among others. Readings from articles on current Greek topics.

title: Introduction to Urban Studies
reviews: A great class with a manageable workload for anyone interested in urban topics.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in urban studies.  It's not a lot of work, but it's also worthwhile because you get a lot out of this course.
For weekly posts and the final paper, research relevant topics that interest you to get more out of the class.

Go to lecture and read all the readings. Not only are they stimulating and very interesting, but they help you understand important happenings in our world today. You definitely don't want to miss out.
I would strongly recommend this course if you're interested in cities and social problems in the world today.
If you are not interested in the architectural side of urban studies, don't take this
If you want to get a taste for urban studies, take this class! The weekly topics are an awesome mixture of contemporary urban issues.
It's a good course to take, take it with Christine (in the spring) especially if you're an architecture student.
Recommend
Shop it before you decide to stick with it. The course doesn't require much work.
Solid class.

The class was interesting but failed it's stated purpose: to introduce me to urban studies. I learned about a number of interesting places and situations but still know NOTHING about the basic thinkers and theories of this field. Some introduction.

This course was great because it brought up many relevant urban issues in a creative, media focused way that was very engaging. I would recommend taking this course, especially if you would like the chance to do a creative project for your final.

This is a great course if you're interested in urban studies. The work load really isn't that much at all, and you don't have to do all of each week's readings to get by in the course. However, lectures can be boring at times, making it difficult to get excited about the subject matter unless you really have an interest in urban studies.
This is a great course to take, you will learn about various problems within urban areas around the world.
great class
descrip: This course will examine different crises confronting cities in the 21st century. Topics will range from immigration, to terrorism, shrinking population, traffic congestion, pollution, energy crisis, housing needs, water wars, race riots, extreme weather conditions, war and urban operations. The range of cities will include Los Angles, New Orleans, Paris, Logos, Caracas, Havana, New York, Hong Kong, and Baghdad among others.

title: The Structure and Meaning of Words
reviews: Great Professor, also the sharp students in our class who could take out examples from their mental lexicons like change from their pockets, made our classes were exciting- led to lots of debates, discussions etc.
I would recommend the course.  It was a bit challenging so I might not recommend it as a first linguistics course, but otherwise it is a great and enjoyable class.
I would say only take this course if you're really interested in linguistics. It can be difficult to cope with, given the professor is kind of uninspiring, if not.
If you need an EC and you're willing to solve some puzzles on occasion, do it!

If you're curious about words, this class could be the most fun class you'll take. If you're curious about, for example, why "BIG kitchen door" and "big KITCHEN door" have different meanings and how to generalize this, you'll have a ball in this class. Be prepared for a bit of disorganization though.
It's not very difficult, and the subject matter is quite interesting!
Take it for a low-commitment EC. If you are PDFing you will have to do almost no work.
The course is slow and disorganized. Prof Williams is often vague and uninteresting.
some fun topics
descrip: The course will treat the structure of words and the structure of the overall lexicon for human languages. Topics included will be: the rules of word formation; the relation between syntax and the lexicon; the psychology of the lexicon, including an examination of studies of the storage and access of lexical items; the semantics of complex words; the phonology of word formation; lexical redundancy and the learning of the lexicon. Students will prepare one short class presentation on a topic in consultation with the instructor.

title: Readings in Japanese Religions - Buddhism in Medieval Japan
descrip: This seminar will introduce representative primary texts in classical Japanese and kanbun from the medieval Japanese Buddhist tradition. It will focus on introducing students to a range of genres, such as doctrinal writings, ritual manuals, temple and shrine origin legends, vernacular sermons, didactic tales, and personal letters. Some readings may be selected to accommodate the research interests of seminar participants. Attention will be given to grammar, vocabulary, genre, literary and philosophical issues, and research methods.

title: Contemporary East Asia
descrip: This course is an introduction to the societies, cultures, and politics of contemporary East Asia. The rise of East Asia has inspired Western observers to reflect on the ways in which capitalism, democracy, and modern social relationships can unfold in different ways, shaping the landscape of daily social life. East Asian societies have attempted to emphasize equality, shared values, and a strong state presence; at the same time, such values have come at significant cost in each case. The course focuses on China, Japan, and Korea (chiefly South Korea) and examines themes of economy, romance and family, authority, identity, and social ideals.

title: Topics in English History - Tudor and Stuart Britain
descrip: This seminar will cover English history and historiography from about 1485 to 1689. While Ireland and Scotland will not be fully treated, they will receive attention as well as they are indispensable to an understanding of events in England. While the course is primarily organized on a chronological basis, special attention will be given to social and economic issues, as well as gender. An attempt will be made to balance classic historiographical debates with emerging problems and concerns.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics
reviews: A relatively easy course that gives you a decent introduction to Microeconomics.
Be prepared for independent work.
Be prepared to learn a lot of the material on your own. Midterm is easy, final exam is much harder.

Decent for an introductory course, even if you're taking it just for interest or a distribution requirement. Remember your preceptor's office hours for sure, and don't forget the textbook is a big saving grace for this class.
Definitely do the reading, they are very helpful. Also, don't be afraid to go to office hours if you don't understand a topic, it can be very helpful.
Definitely take it. Not too hard or time consuming, but interesting topics.
Do the reading
Do the readings, go to class if you want an A, (otherwise you probably don't need to), have fun!
Don't take with Professor Willig.

ECO100 is an essential class that every student should take.  Economics principles and concepts are very useful in real life, so taking this class will help further your understanding of why things happen to work the way they do.  However, take this class during the fall semester.  I hear the professor who teaches during the fall is a better lecturer than the spring one.
From what I've heard, it's a better idea to take it in the fall.
Go to precept.

I feel like I learned the basics of Microeconomics, but I wished that i had taken it with Professor Rosen, who apparently teaches a much more engaging (and efficient) class. Professor Willig's class runs 90 minutes (and certainly doesn't need to). I PDF'd the course and I am very happy that I did. In order to get an A, you must get few-to-no questions wrong on the midterm and final. If you have a choice, take it with Rosen. Willig was fine, but not the best.

I hear that taking ECO 100 first semester is a useful thing to do, both because the professor teaching ECO 100 during fall semester has been doing it for longer and is better at explaining the material and because it is more helpful to get these basic concepts down as soon as possible.  If you take classes Spring semester, make sure to read the Mankiw book as it is really helpful and you can get a lot out of it.  Make sure you can apply the concepts you learn to all your problem sets and even understanding how to apply them in multiple contexts (Easier said than done, I know), because the problem sets are at times deceptively simple while midterms and finals are longer.  Go to precepts because the material covered truly is different from that covered in class, and go to office hours because there you can understand concepts that you will probably not understand the first time in precept.
I mean, if you pdf-ed this class it would be the easiest thing in the world
I really enjoyed it.
I would recommend taking Macro over this course.  You will learn a lot more and have a better experience.
I would recommend taking this course and really focussing during the lectures.  In doing so you can gain a deep understanding of microeconomics.
I would recommend that students taking this course seek one-on-one time with their preceptor to go over the problem sets, as the graders are not helpful.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in majoring in economics or have a general interest in economics. This class is not extremely challenging, and it goes over many important fundamental concepts in economics that any person who is going to major in economics should know and understand. This course is useful for everyone, and it has many applications in everyday life.
I've heard that micro is better in the fall, but I still enjoyed it in the spring. It gives you a good perspective of how economics influences decision making, and how firms react to market forces.
If you are passionate about economics, please do not take this class with Willig. The book is fine, but the lectures are unnecessarily long and boring, and the whole precept system is disorganized.
If you know nothing about microeconomics, definitely take it. I recommend the class only on the content.
If you need it, you need it. I don't know if I'd recommend this section over one with another professor, but Willig could certainly be worse.

If you want to go into economics, you need to take this course as an introduction. It's not a pain, like others are. But the material gets more interesting as the course progresses (especially with game theory and risk assessment).

If you're genuinely interested or think you would benefit, take it. Don't take it just because you're someone who already knows calculus and is looking to coast through a class you find easy.  Those people screw up the curve and annoy the people in their precept.

If you're interested in econ- definitely take this course. It's not a huge time investment, if you show up to lectures and precept, and pay attention, you'll do fine and won't necessarily have to read the book outside of class. Take advantage of office hours for precepts.
Important material to learn, but don't expect to be thrilled by the presentation

It is a fascinating course on an important part of society today. I would highly recommend taking this class, because you will learn vital aspects of economics that can prove to be helpful in future years, even if a career in economic is not prevalent.
It's an interesting class and the professor is very nice and passionate about economics.
It's an introductory course, not much more to say.  Willig probably wasn't the best person to get to teach 100, but overall no reason to not take this class so as to at least have a distribution.
It's definitely a helpful course to take if you'd like to do anything economics-related here. The grading is not too difficult, and the subject matter is genuinely interesting.
It's probably good to have an economics background regardless of your major.
Its ECO 100, if you are looking at econ, take it.

Lectures are not really too important to attend if you are following the readings in the book. I attended most lectures and found that 90% of the time that the same understanding could be reached in less time by just googling the topic or reading the book.

Precepts, however, are CRITICAL. You should always, always, always attend precept even though they don't take attendance.
Make sure you study well for the final and midterm. That's basically what you're graded on.
Micro is a necessary course and a good background for other material, just try to take it with a different professor
Micro is great!
Most, if not all students, should take some econ in my opinion. I think that micro was more practical than macro.
No- take Macro! Or take it with Harvey Rosen, but not with Willig!
Only if you have to for the major
Only take it if it is a requirement. If you want to take an economics class take macroeconomics. It is a much more relevant course.

Only take it if you need to or you're actually interested in microeconomics. If you are interested though, you'll learn a decent amount. From what I've heard, it's much better taught in the fall but the curve is harder.
Read the book and go to office hours
Read the textbook and do all problem sets.
Stay on top of the material week-by-week. If you get behind, it will definitely be hard to catch up.
Stay on top of the readings and go to office hours if needed! Economics is interesting and practical. Make sure you really understand the materials.
Stay on top of the work
Take it
Take it if you need an SA, it's always useful to know some microeconomic concepts.
Take it in the fall with Harvey Rosen!
Take it with Willig!
Take it, it's interesting
Take the course in the fall with a different professor.
Take this course with Harvey Rosen in the fall.
The class isn't hard, but take it during the fall if you can. Precepts can be helpful, but Willig's lectures are long-winded and relatively useless.
The content of the course is pretty interesting, but don't take it with this professor.  Lectures are totally unbearable.
The lectures were boring, but it's a good class on the whole. Not too much work, and the material is understandable.
The practice midterm and practice final exams are key to success on the actual midterm and final that you take
This class will certainly introduce you to some basic themes of economics. The workload is very manageable.

Unless you need it for a departmental, just don't bother. If you really want to learn about economics, macro is far more valuable. If you insist on taking micro, I hear that Professor Rosen is more interesting than Professor Willig.
Willig is hilarious.  You know you need to take econ.  If you're interested in micro, take it with willig
do the reading
dont take it
good class
good class to get the basic but hard to stay engaged during lectures
great if you're interested in econ.. highly recommend, definitely more so than macro
if you take this course with Professor Willig. You should not have a short attention span.
pay attention.  get things done
take with Rosen
descrip: This course presents fundamental analyses of the ways that households choose consumption and work, that incentives drive suppliers to utilize labor, technology and other inputs to produce goods and services and that a market economy harmonizes its sectors through the price system. Against this backdrop, the roles played by public goods, environmental impacts, income distribution, monopoly power, taxes, welfare programs and entrepreneurship are considered. The differing perspectives of market participants, public policy and academic economics are all exercised.

title: Seminar in Political Theory - Executive Power
descrip: This seminar examines an important conundrum associated with the theory of executive power. Political theorists have long recognized that as the laws cannot foresee every contingency, men and women must rule when necessity demands. However, entrusting men and women with such discretionary power is problematic because they might abuse it. We will study how prominent theorists of executive power, including Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke and Publius have attempted to solve this conundrum. Drawing on secondary literature as well as documentaries and news reports, we will also analyze the feasibility of their solutions in the modern world.

title: Social and Personality Development
prereqs: PSY 252 or 254 or 257.
descrip: Major issues in social and personality psychology examined from a developmental perspective, with emphasis on developmental processes and change. Data on children, adolescents and adults will be considered. Topics include: attachment, self-concept, self-esteem, achievement, gender roles, moral development, prosocial behavior, and aggression. Particular attention to role of culture.

title: Comparative Constitutionalism: U.S. and Canadian Structures
descrip: This course covers the basic constitutional design of American government, and compares this design to the Canadian constitution. The course materials are primarily Supreme Court cases; thus there is a heavy focus on the Supreme Court case-law method for analyzing constitutional law. The course includes an introduction to judicial review, congressional/parliamentary power, federalism, executive power, and rights. With each issue and doctrine covered in the course, comparisons will be made to Canadian constitutional law.

title: Race, Social Inequality, and Education
descrip: Education is becoming increasingly important for upward social mobility in the U.S. and abroad. Education has been linked to societal inequalities in health, income, and other life-chance measures. This course will focus on the role of education in both the production and amelioration of social inequality. Particular attention is given to racial achievement gaps. By engaging both quantitative and qualitative studies, you will acquire 1) knowledge of the historical trends and understanding of racial differences in achievement, and 2) a broad understanding of the current issues/debates in the literature.

title: Law, Psychoanalysis, and Ideas of Human Agency: The Ethics of Reading, III
descrip: This seminar will serve as an open-ended discussion of the many issues raised by the intersection of law and psychoanalysis as understandings of human action and motive. Readings include works by Freud, Camus, Shakespeare, Kafka, as well as various law cases.

title: Refugees, Immigrants, and Social Justice
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

classes.bldg: Carl A Fields Ctr for Equality

title: Starting, Building, and Operating an Architectural Practice - Business and Legal Issues in Architectural Practice
reviews: I advise other students participate and attend every class.
If you want to open your own practice, definitely its worth taking this course
descrip: Review and analysis of the dynamics and process inherent in starting, developing, managing and operating an architectural practice, including marketing, finance, human resources, project process, liability, insurance, and general management. Areas of particular emphasis include project accounting, public presentations, and the development of a business plan.

title: Chemistry, Structure, and Structure-Function Relations of Nucleic Acids
prereqs: General chemistry and one semester of organic chemistry. Open to juniors, seniors, graduate students in Molecular Biology, Chemistry, EEB, Physics and Chemical & Bioengineering. Others by permission of the instructor. Suitably prepared Freshman and Sophomores have often taken the course..
descrip: The chemistry and structure of mononucleotides, oligonucleotides, and polynucleotides and their helical complexes are presented as a basis for understanding and predicting the structures and structure-function relations of naturally occurring DNAs and RNAs. Functions to be considered include fidelity of DNA replication and transcription, mutagenic mechanisms, molecular evolution, roles and mechanisims of action of recently discovered small RNAs, and nature and organization of the genetic code.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: Bring tasty seminar food?
I enjoyed the seminars, would recommend attending on a regular basis
This course will broaden your horizon for sure.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-temperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Performance Projects in 20th and 21st Century Music
prereqs: Admission by interview/audition.
descrip: A performance course that concentrates on the unique techniques and repertory of the 20th century, as well as new works (including those written by undergraduate composers). Emphasis will be on works with text.

title: Seminar in European Cultural and Intellectual History: The 20th Century
descrip: This seminar will provide an introduction to recent theoretical debates and methodological approaches to 20th Century European intellectual and cultural history. Its central focus will be on the legacy of Marx, Nietzsche, and Weber for the debates on "enlightenment" and "counter-enlightenment" during the first half of the century. Among the thinkers we will be examining are: T.W. Adorno, Hannah Arendt, Walter Benjamin, Michel Foucault, Martin Heidegger, Georg Lukacs, and Carl Schmitt.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: The Sociology of Law
reviews: Be patient with it. There are important and interesting issues in the course, but they don't come out until after the midterm.
Definitely take this course. Professor is really knowledgeable and nice, a rare combination among top academicians.
Eh, probably wouldn't take it again.
Fun course, with a very manageable workload.
Good choice for an SA, great real world applications to the knowledge I gained in this course
Good class for second-semester seniors!
I recommend this course to anyone thinking about law school
I would take this course if you don't have a lot of other reading-intensive courses.
It's really interesting.  Be ready for a heavy reading load, but the readings are (mostly) worthwhile.
Not bad only having a take home midterm and final but it can be frustrating at times.

TAKE THIS CLASS! The material is fascinating and very well-presented. Professor Scheppele is clear and engaging; she really cares about students and will take time to make sure you are getting as much out of the class as you want. One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.
Take it if you have interest in law. Scheppele is a master in the field and in law so listen to her insights.
Take this class if you have an interest in law school. It is a great introduction to law.

Take this course if you are interested in law, its a great course for senior spring because it brings up a lot of real world issues you might not have ever gotten a chance to study in an academic context.
Take this course if you have any interest in possibly going to law school, or if you just want an interesting course that is taught very well.
The material is interesting, but a tad slow at times. Not too much work if you keep up with it.

This is mainly for the instructors: one of the reasons for the low attendance was the structure of the course (Here is a structuralist perspective on the matter)
1) Seniors looking to get a distribution requirement out of the way search for an easy class to PDF; this course has a midterm and final TAKE HOME for 80% of the grade. There is no "need" to study to get a C, thus many PDFers take the course. If you want greater attendance, have an exam
nearly everyone is taking it because they want to go to law school
try it out and see
descrip: Sociology has always been engaged in the study of law and, in this course, we will examine law with the tools of sociology. In Segment I, The Building Blocks of Social Life, we will explore the ways in which law provides a crucial basis for social organization at the micro-, mid-level, and macro- levels of society. We will also explore the relationship between legal norms and the moral commitments of societies and social elites. In Segment II: The Legal Organization of Social Sectors, the course takes up the legal construction of race, gender, and class, and explores the legal basis for the creation of crime, money, citizenship and terrorism.

title: The Civil Rights Movement
reviews: Definitely take this course for background on the Civil Rights Movement and to get the chance to learn from two awesome Professors.
Fascinating material, especially if you're interested in issues of race, social change, or 20th century US history.
Great Class. Be Prepared to do readings.
Great course!! Very informative and engaging
I recommend it.
I would encourage any student with an interest in twentieth-century U.S. history to take this course.

I would encourage them to go into the course with an open mind because perceptions of the Movement and certain figures that they have might be challenged or shown in different lights. I would also tell them to do as much of the readings as possible while listing any questions they may have because this will help in discussions.
If you don't take this class, you are a fool and are not smart enough to be a Princeton student.
This class is good if you want to learn about the Civil Rights Movement.  Try not to be intimidated during discussion.
absolutely not. unless, of course, you're PDFing it.
descrip: This interdisciplinary course examines the evolution of African American social and political mobilization from World War II through the 1970s. Through an analysis of historical scholarship, oral history, sermons, works of literature, film and music, it explores the various ways that African Americans articulated their political demands and affirmed their citizenship using the church, grassroots organizations, workers' rights, feminism, education, war, the federal bureaucracy, and the law as tools for political action. The course also considers the ways these movements have been remembered, memorialized, and appropriated in more recent times.

title: The Bible in Modern Political Thought
descrip: In this course we will discuss the Bible's status in modern political thought. The aim of the seminar is to explore the following issues: To what extent is the Bible admitted in modern political thought? What is authority of the Bible? What are the new ways of reading the Bible? Is reading and interpreting the Bible a political act? Can we speak about modern European political thought as independent of the Bible? Is the Bible a book for secular politics? We will discuss religious opposition to the Bible as a political authority.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Climate, Air Pollution, Toxics, and Water
prereqs: The course is required for students who wish to pursue the Environmental Studies certificate program; these students cannot enroll under the p/d/f option. This course will satisfy the core course requirement as well as one of the two required labs. Preference will be given to ENV concentrators..
descrip: This course will focus on environmental consequences of human activities and their interactions with natural systems. Beginning with underlying principles, we will consider the social, political, economic, scientific and technical dimensions of four areas of environmental concern: the atmosphere (atmospheric pollution, its sources and prevention); climate (climate and climate variability; models and public policy); toxics in the environment (pollutants, remediation and solutions); and water resources (watersheds, land use, climate effects, political issues).

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Primer on Psychology and Policy
descrip: A half-term course designed for MPP's to cover basic concepts and findings from psychology and their application in policy development. Topics include bounded rationality, group dynamics, memory, judgment and decision making biases, behavioral economics, public opinion, social determinants of behavior, attitudes, psychological assessment, and a psychological perspective on incentive structures, all of which have implications for the design of policies that affect individual citizens as well as for the functioning of organizations that determine policy.

title: Advanced Orbital Mechanics
descrip: An advanced course in orbital motion of earth satellites, interplanetary probes, and celestial mechanics. Topics include orbit specification, orbit determination, Lambert's problem, Hill's equations, intercept and rendezvous, air-drag and radiation pressure, lagrange points and three-body orbits, numerical methods, general perturbations and variation of parameters, earth-shape effects on orbits, Hamiltonian treatment of orbits, Lagrange's planetary equations, orbit resonances, and higher-order perturbation effects.

title: Human Genetics, Reproduction, and Public Policy
prereqs: There are no formal prerequisites, however, a knowledge of high school chemistry and modern biology will be assumed. Eight movies will be assigned for viewing outside of class..
descrip: Critical concepts in human genetics, evolution, reproductive behavior, embryology, and philosophy of science will be presented as a framework for understanding controversial human-affecting biotechnologies including embryonic stem cells, cloning, genetic selection, egg or womb vending, genetic engineering, and neuro-enhancement. Public perceptions and misperceptions of biotechnology will be explored through science fiction, movies, and popular music. Consideration will be given to competing political, religious, and ethical claims of authority in accepting, regulating, or rejecting each technology in the U.S. and other societies.

title: Special Topics in Contemporary Practice - Movement Improvisation for Dance and Theater
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of physical getting to know your classmates, and some bruises.  It's worth it.

Definitely, definitely take this class. You will learn things you most likely have never considered before; as cheesy as it may sound, I would even go so far as to say that this class changed my life. Truly wonderful.
TAKE IT IF IT IS OFFERED
Take the course, but only because of KJ.
definitely take it
descrip: The course, designed for creators and performers in dance and theater, provides a deep investigation of practices in movement improvisation. The course offers students techniques to engage in the development and performance of movement ideas. Students will study improvisation as a process of generating material through exploration and of gaining experiential knowledge through personal and group research. Contact Improvisation and the development of the ability to move fluidly off-balance in partnership with others will be a focus of the second half of the semester. Students will create many small studies over the term.

title: Studies of Orchestral Music - Orchestration and Instrumentation
reviews: Anyone who is serious about composition, particular for large groups of instruments, should make a point of working with Steve by the time they graduate.
If only for some of the cool opportunities to write music and have people play it, this should be taken.
If you are a composer, you should definitely take this class.

If you are interested in writing music, take this course in a heartbeat.  If you don't have a sincere interest in composition, it may not be the course for you--it's very much geared towards composers.
If you want to be a composer take this course.
Take it if you can.

This class is a must for music majors and aspiring composers.  Professor Mackey has a lot of experience in the material covered and has connections to many professional musicians, which through this course you can also have access to!
definitely take it, especially if Mackey is teaching it!
prereqs: Music 106 or Music 210 are prerequisites. Application in the form of a short paragraph describing your musical background and motivations for taking the course will help the instructor make the difficult decisions necessary to limit enrollment to a manageable 12..
descrip: An examination of the technical and expressive characteristics of the individual instruments of the orchestra and approaches to combining them. Participants will compose and arrange for guest instrumentalists and small ensembles, culminating in a short work for full orchestra. If possible, the Princeton University Orchestra will read/rehearse some or all of these final projects.

title: Topics in Science Technology and Environmental Policy - Biotechnology Policy
descrip: This course provides in-depth analysis of selected topics in biotechnology that are currently the focus of intense debate in the public and policy arenas. Topics include genetic modification of plants and animals, genetic testing in human populations, stem cells, cloning, and advanced reproductive technologies. Each topic is examined from the perspective of potential commercial applications, risk/benefit analysis, impact on individuals and society, the viewpoints of supporters and detractors, and the political response in the U.S. and other countries.

title: Digital Neurocomputing
reviews: It is a good graduate course for improving the skill of doing research. Please don't hesitate to discuss with Prof. Kung. He really likes to discuss with students.
Read the textbook! And don't hesitate to ask questions to Pr. Kung.

The course is very theoretical/mathematical and presents a lot of material quickly. To get the most out of the course, be ready to spend time on your own to learn the material. The final project is quite work intensive as it determines the entire grade for the course, but the workload when classes are in session is non-existent, useful if taking a heavy load otherwise.

You are fascinated by the wonderful Machine Learning world but you fear its complexity: then maybe that's because lots of people just don't know what they 're talking about! Professor Kung is really very good at teaching how all this stuff works, practically and theoretically, makes great slides and gives you his book for free! What else would you need? That's really great to master all these techniques and to use them for real (no homework, only one project to do suring the semester).
descrip: The course will cover machine learning techniques & applications. Machine learning techniques topics: a) adaptive techniques for feature selection & dimension reduction, b) unsupervised cluster discovery: K-means, SOFM, hierarchical clustering, c) supervised classifiers e.g. linear discriminant analysis (LDA), support vector machines, & d) kernel-based clustering/classification techniques. Genomic and multimedia applications will be explored.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Political Science
descrip: This seminar is concerned with the professional obligations of political science researchers. This course is designed to raise those concerns and develop in students an appreciation for the issues that they might confront as they do their work. Topics addressed includes the relationship of political science as an academic discipline to democratic politics and institutions, advocacy and objectivity in political science, plagiarism and academic misconduct, human subjects and fieldwork in research, institutional review boards, funding sources and intellectual integrity, collaboration, and mentoring.

title: General Computer Science
reviews: A great intro to computer science. If you are willing to put the time in, it is not terribly difficult for those who have never programmed before.
A working knowledge of a programming language is a very useful skill to have.
Any engineer should take this course. It's a good course to take. However, it might be a little too difficult for those who want to take it just out of mere curiosity.
Assignments are fun but lecture and precept are a waste of time.
Be aware of the time!
Be aware that a lot of people have programming experience coming into this course and it can be very intimidating in the first month or so, but it evens out for the most part.
Be engaged from the start!
Be prepared to work, don't get behind.
Be ready to read the textbook on regular basis.
Be sure to do practice exercises to reinforce the material in addition to programming the required code.

Begin assignments early enough so you don't get under pressure to finish.  Try to save extra time to explore with coding - you'll want to do it.  Skipping lecture is okay if and only if you understand all the material which will be presented there; review the lecture slides the night before (if they're up, which they almost always are) to be sure of this.

Oh, and GET KEITH VERTANEN AS YOUR PRECEPTOR.
COS 126 is exposure to computer science that every student should have.
Come into the course with a basic understanding of programming.

Computer Science assigments demand intense concentration and thought. Unlike a paper, you can't even try to B.S. a COS problem. It doesn't work. So if you enjoy solving difficult problems by unique methods, take this class, but only if you are willing and have the time that it requires (which is a lot).

Definitely give this course a chance.  You will enjoy it more if you start assignments early so you don't have to stress out if you run into trouble.  Go to office hours or computer lab if you need help.
Definitely recommend. Fun course and great intro to computer science!

Definitely take the class, especially if Kevin Wayne teaches it. If you don't have a background in computer science, it is a nice and easy starting point and if you have some basic knowledge, it helps you strengthen your roots.
Definitely take the course. Lots of work, but lots of fun!

Definitely take this class! It was really enlightening learning about programming. I didn't know anything before taking this course and I did well. If you put in the time (which you will probably want to since it's really interesting/fun to write your own programs) you'll definitely get rewarded!
Definitely take this class, even if it's not a requirement. It's a very good introduction to CS.
Definitely take this course if you can.
Definitely take this course. Everyone should have a background knowledge in computer science.
Definitely worth taking.  However, if you have never programmed before, this class will take a lot of time.  Always start the programming assignments early and use the lab TAs and your preceptor.

Depends on your reason for taking it. Many example programs revolve around application in the sciences (mainly physics). Sometimes fellow students complained about not being familiar with physics principles. I don't know why that mattered; they provide all the formulas you need anyways, but something to keep in mind :)
Do it.
Do the readings, start early, and this class won't be particularly difficult

Don't be intimidated by the fact that mostly engineers and science majors take this course; the programming assignments are fun, and although they make take a chunk of your weekend if you have no prior programming experience, totally doable and worthwhile.  With that said, if you choose to take this course, I would recommend focusing on the logic behind the programs, tracing how they work, how different components are organized, and what happens when things go wrong (improper input data, bugs, etc.). Such information makes up the written portion in the midterm and final exam, which together compose nearly 50 percent of your grade.

Don't take this course unless you are actually interested. While it might initially seem useful to have some background computer science knowledge, the class is fairly time intensive and not worth taking unless you are truly interested in computer programming and theory.

Don't take this unless you have to for the BSE requirement, or you are willing to devote an insane amount of time to really really learning the material- don't be fooled by success in other academic pursuits.  Programming, if it's new to you, is extremely challenging and time consuming, and you can't just slide by in this class.  Exams are also extremely difficult and poorly timed.

Don't worry if you have no programming experience--I didn't, and I thoroughly enjoyed this class! It can be hard at first, but you'll find it's really not bad at all--there are so many places to go for help.

Even if you don't plan to major in anything COS related, once you have ideas, can be creative and you enjoy using computers, definitely take this class.
Coding is ACTUALLY fun!
Even if you think you may never use computer science again, please take this course. If you will, ever, in your life, require a computer program, you absolutely must take this course.
Even if you're not interested in the sciences, this is a course everyone should take. In my opinion it is infinitely better than writing sem and arguably as useful.
Every students should take this class, whether for P/D/F or for grade, it is an eye-opening experience.
Excellent introduction to programming.

Fantastically taught course. A great and fun experience, definitely take it. Curve is pretty terrible because there are a lot of people who know computer science already, but you should be fine if you study hard or P/D/F.

For any AB students looking for a QR, definitely take this course. It's interesting, engaging, and overall very rewarding. I think everyone at Princeton ought to take this course. It's well taught (if the lecturer is Kevin Wayne).
Great class, you learn great stuff. Take it, even if it isn't a requirement. It's really time consuming, but definitely worth it. Start the programs early, and you don't need to do the reading.
Great course - it's not too hard, but provides a great base in programming.
Great course! Take it!
Great for whatever you need it to be.  Not too hard, but not a waste of time.
Great intro cos class! Take it!
Have fun with it.  If you view the course as a game rather than work, it is a lot more interesting.
I recommend it to everyone who wants an introduction to programming on the field of computer science.
I think everyone should take this course because it is a basic science.
I think you should take it if you're willing to put in some quality time programming.

I went into this course feeling quite scared that i would fail terribly and be unable to understand anything. But that is really not the case. It is best to go into the course with an open mind, a good attitude and ready to learn. Do the readings as early as possible and start the assignments early. 

It is a bit hard but it would be quite useful to do the recommended practice exercises.
I would advise the student to make sure that they have a thorough understanding of programming concepts.

I would certainly recommend this class to anybody, not just engineers - for you AB people it could be your QR.  My advice is to go to the lab TA sessions as much as possible if needed, they are incredibly helpful.  Also from what I've heard, Donna Gabai is a fantastic preceptor, so try to get her if you can.
I would definitely recommend this course. The class is a lot of fun, and it's amazing how much you will learn about programming in just one semester!

I would definitely say to take it, even if you aren't an engineer or CS major. The assignments are a lot of fun, the faculty are great, and learning to program is a practical skill to know. You might even discover an interest in CS!
I would recommend taking the course because it is very unique/different than other types of courses at Princeton. However, it is extremely time-consuming and requires a lot of focus and hard work.

I would recommend the course because of the practical applications that programming offers. I learned a lot of things about the intricacies of computers and their uses in the daily world. Overall, it's great knowledge to have even if you can't actually apply it and program.
I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn Java. Java is a very powerful programming language which can do many things.
If it's for a distribution requirement, note that the weekly assignments are only worth it if you're interested.
If the student has no experience with programming, I would advise her to take it PDF. I wish I had taken it PDF and wish that I hadn't had the illusions I did about doing well in this course.
If you are willing to work, you can learn a lot from this course.
If you have any interest at all in programming or animation or computers or are looking for an exciting and fun class, then you have to take this one.
If you have even the slightest feeling that you want to or ought to learn about computers, this class is a great introduction to many aspects of computer science.

If you have had previous programming experience as I had, then the class will be incredibly enjoyable while moderately challenging. If you have never tried programming before, you will probably be very frustrated at times and have to work a lot harder at it, but it will be worth it.

If you have the slightest desire or need to program, regardless of any lack of experience, you should take this course.  It is the perfect introductory course to programming.  I had experience in programming, and I saw beginners quickly surpass my programming skills in this course.  Even if your classmates have programmed before, as far as I can tell, this does not affect the grading curve to any appreciable extent.  They all learn new things in this course too, and by the end you'll be just as good as anyone who started with experience.

If you know lots of computer science, take 217 or 226. Don't be that guy who finishes half of the assignments during the first week of classes.

Also, don't buy the book.
If you want to learn how to REALLY use a computer, take this course and follow along closely.

If you're at all interested in computer science or programming, even if you've never programmed before, this is a great intro course to take. The material is interesting, and it's fun to put your knowledge to use in programming.

If you're interested in a science that will involve programming, this is a nice and easy place to start. If you go to lecture and stay ontop of the assignments(which isn't very hard), maybe dedicate ~(1-6) out-of-class hours a week.

If you've never programmed, don't let it stop you from taking the course.
If you're an engineer, you have to take it. Enjoy it.
If you're a science major and would like to work with computers, it's a very good idea to take it.
If you're not an engineer or a scientist but will probably work with computers, it's also a good idea to take it as it will provide excellent insight into the capabilities of computers.

It is a considerable time investment but it is a very rewarding class.  If you already have previous programming experience, even in similar languages, then COS 126 won't teach you much that you don't already know.  Otherwise, find someone who does and become good friends with them, since it will save a lot of time.

It is a good course to take if you have an interest in computers/technology because being able to program computers is a useful skill to have and this course is geared nicely towards students who have never programmed before (like me).
It is better to have cos experience, but be willing to put a lot of time into this course.
It is really hard if you have never programmed before. I suggest going to get all the help you can in the beginning of the course.

It is very well organized, and if you follow along in lecture with material you learned from the readings and seek help from TA's on assignments when you need it, the class will be very interesting and enjoyable.
It uses and teaches skills that are applicable in almost all fields.
It was a fun class, and you definitely don't need to be a math/science person to appreciate the class.
It you want to learn programming, then definitely take the course. Kevin Wayne is an excellent instructor! Also, make sure to start your assignments early since debugging can be a pain.
It's a course worth taking. Try to stay on top of the readings, and definitely ask for help when you need it - the support system is wonderful for this class.
It's a lot of work, but also kind of fun.
It's a must-take intro to cos with such interesting assignments.

It's hard if you don't know what you're doing especially since PEOPLE WHO ALREAD KNOW JAVA ARE IN THE COURSE. Which I find very unfair. They should be in a two hundred level course. But it's definitely worth it. You learn a lot.
It's tough, but so worth it.
It's useful material. Hopefully the class will improve by the time you take it.

Kevin Wayne is a fantastic lecturer, the assignments aren't too heavy a workload, and the subject material is made interesting. 

Take it, although be sure to do practice exams to prepare for the written assessments. That is absolutely imperative, in order to get a feel for the type of questions asked.
Know what you're getting into before you take it. It's a lot of time, but can be really rewarding.
Learn through programming!
Lots of work. Interesting though.
Make sure you get a good precept.
Make sure you keep up with the reading.
Make sure you study a lot on your own.
Make sure you understand aevery program. The material builds quickly and you want to make sure that you dont get lost because that will make the final very hard.
Most students take it for the engineering requirement, so be wary if you decided to take it as an introductory course. The material comes at you quickly, but is also worthwhile to learn.
My favorite course of the freshman engineering requirements but still a good course, despite its challenging nature.
Not only is it required for engineers, but I think this course should be taken by all for general knowledge in a world of computers.
Only take this course if you're a physics, engineering, or cos major.

Read the book thoroughly.  I managed to survive without having to but it would have saved me time from going to lab TAs and office hours if I had read it.  Otherwise, I strongly recommend taking this course.
Read the book.  I mean, really READ the book.  Go to lecture and pay attention.  Start assignments early and go to the teachers if you have trouble; they're really nice people, I promise!
Read the chapters ahead of precept.
Read the textbook, go the lectures and do the problem sets.
Reading the textbook on your own is very important and key to doing well.
Recommend if you like logical thinking.
Recommend only if you're interested in computers and programming.
Reserve sufficient time for the weekly projects.

Some people will tell you that this course is easy. If you've programmed hard core before, then they're probably right. But if you're like me and have only done the most basic of basic programming, then watch out. This course is really tough. They grade homework really harshly. The tests are designed to trick. There are a lot of other people who are brilliant at programming taking the course. They bribe you with extra credit to improve your grade, but it's not actually worth much. My advice is just to set aside enough time for this course and to be very, very careful for this class, because there are a lot of hidden hurdles here.
Start early on the assignments! The exams are hard but definitely doable.
Start programing assignments as soon as possible. Go to the TA help sessions in Friend.

Start your assignments early. Don't be afraid to ask for help. Go to all the precepts and lectures!! Not reading isn't the end of the world, but make sure to study your notes. Work hard and you'll do fine!
Start your programs before the night they are due, as often times debugging programs will require more than just a couple of hours to complete the program.

Super time consuming but interesting. challenging because of the varied levels of skills in the class. Realize you will be in class with people who are going to be Cos majors and/ or people who have programmed extensively before even if you are a complete novice to the subject.
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take COS
Take a computer science course before taking this one!!! So many people in the class have programmed before, so you're at a huge disadvantage if you haven't.
Take it
Take it but be prepared to spend lots of time on it.
Take it even if you're moderately interested. The programming assignments are engaging, and you might actually enjoy them.
Take it if you are prepared to put in the time every week
Take it if you do not care about your grade. It is really fun.
Take it if you have any interest.
Take it if you think it will interest you, but it will be slightly time consuming.
Take it if you want a nice intro level course to computer science but beware that the lecture portions of the exams will annoy the shit out of you since all they really do is nitpick.
Take it if you want to learn the basics of programming.
Take it no matter what you're majoring in!

Take it with Wayne!  He's a great lecturer.  Be prepared to make long time commitments for some assignments, and then feel lots of gratification when you finish them.  The assignments are basically logic puzzles, so if that sounds appealing, sign right up.
Take it!
Take it! Sometimes it is challenging, but finishing a program is always a rewarding accomplishment. Also, it teaches you skills that you will need in life!
Take it,
Take it, go to lecture and precept, invest time in learning the basics, and you should fly.
Take it, you'll be happy you did. The lab at Friend 017 is also really useful for help with debugging.
Take it, you'll learn a lot. Keep in mind that students of very different levels and backgrounds take this course.

Take it--programming is useful in just about any scientific field, and even if you aren't into math/science/engineering, it gives you some insights into how computers work.  Given that computers are involved in most aspects of our lives, that is (to me, at least) definitely something worth knowing.
Take it.
Take this class if you're so much as even a little bit interested.
Take this class, even if you don't have to. You won't regret it.

Take this class.  It is a requirement for all BSE students, but anybody with at least a slight interest in computers must take the class. The COS department is extremely organized, the faculty is famous, and the professors are accessible!
Take this class. If you're a numerically inclined, science-y person, you'll do fine and have fun. If you're not, you'll still learn A LOT of amazing things. Everyone should take this course.
Take this course if you foresee your major having any sort of connection to computer science (essentially any major). Computer science is another form of literacy today.

Take this course if you have some background in computer science because it will be a fun and easy course for you!

If you have not, unless it is a distribution requirement (eg BSE majors) or you are really interested in computer science, don't take it!
Take this course it is awesome
Take this course no matter your background in COS.
Take this course! A great QR, even if you have not had any experience with programming.
Take this course! The professors do a great job of helping students learn the topics and the assigments are interesting and fun.

Take this course, even if you don't necessarily want to study COS. It is worth every second you spend in class and you will come away having learned an extremely useful skill and a very solid understanding of computers.
Take this course.  It was actually pretty fun.  Just go to precepts, read the book, and ask questions and you'll be fine.  Also, do lots of practice tests for the exams.

Take this course. Don't even worry about grading-- this course will have a positive effect on your intelligence, regardless of your level of prior exposure. I'd never programmed before 126, and now I love it.
Take this course. This course is very informative and rewarding.
Take time to do the programming assignments!
Terrific course, learning useful things for sure
The course is fun, and even if you aren't a commuter tech there are a lot of resources available if you need help. I recommend the course.
The course teaches a lot of things you should know.
The material is good to know, and the lectures are great. I would definitely recommend this course for anyone with the slightest interest or curiosity.

The written portions of the tests are challenging and the programming exams are difficult to finish, but the course is very good overall. The class requires a decent amount of time so keep that in mind.
This course is worth taking if you have any amount of interest in computer science. The lectures are informative and the assignments are challenging and fun rather than overwhelming.
This course was really very useful and very interesting.  However, it is also very hard so I recommend taking it P/D/F or taking it during a semester in which you can focus mostly on this class.
This is a good class full of really useful material

This is a good class. It is very doable even with no programming experience because they treat the course as if no one has any experience. The assignments are actually kind of fun and the good thing is that they count for a good part of your grade unlike in other courses. And there is tons of help if you need it.
This is a great course to learn how to write computer programs and that it may be challenging at times, but getting through it is very rewarding.

This is a great course! Even if you don't need another QR take this class. It is amazing knowing how programming and computers work. For people who are taking the course, make sure you do well on the exams! Most students get about the same grades for the homework assignments, so exams is really where you distinguish yourself from the rest.
This is a great course, and not particularly difficult at all. Even if you are not mathematically inclined, it is an amazing all around introduction to computer science.

This is a great course.  It is very organized, and it is very easy to get help.  Even if you are not sure if you have an interest in COS, you should consider this course.  I did not have any interest when I took it and now I am considering getting a COS certificate.

This is a must-take course at Princeton! It is fascinating and teaches a necessary, useful skill.
Take it, even if it gets too hard and you have to drop it. Already the first couple weeks are life-changing!

This is a really good introductory course. It may be difficult if you haven't had previous experience with coding but it is definately rewarding in the end. Go to lectures and precepts - it makes it so much easier.
This is a very good course, even if you have never programmed or don't think you'd be interested in it.  It's a lot of work, but it's definitely worth it.
This was the best course I have taken all year, and is definitely worth taking regardless of major.
Try to do assignments ahead of time so you have time to work on the bonus problems.
Try to get somewhat familiar with Java before the course, as it will be a big help in the first couple of weeks.
Understand that this class will be difficult, but you will have much better understanding of how computers work.
Very hard exams and expect to spend a lot of time on homework. Interesting though.
Very well taught class. If you are into computing take this class!
You're probably taking this course because you have to, but don't worry, unlike physics, this course is good.

a great course, well organized and well staffed - just not my cup of tea. took quite a bit of time every week, esp since the subject matter was not my favorite, but rewarding nonetheless to have the finished product.
do it! but don't pdf it's not worth it
do lots of practice programs. you will only get better by practicing
good
start early on the psets so you know if you get stuck there is time to work it out
study the theory. it's a pain, but the exams do count for something... enjoy the programming, it's fun :)
take it
take it if you have general interest and seek help
try to get into Donna's precept. though I am sure the other ones are good too.
descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis. Two lectures, two precepts.

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
reviews: A very good course.  If you are interested in COS and want more after 126 then definitely take it.

As far as COS classes go, this is pretty dull material.  Well, maybe it isn't, but no effort is made to make it interesting.

Professor Sedgewick is a nice guy and is very knowledgeable about the material.  He organized the course incredibly well.

However, his lectures are boring.  He seems to have no regard for the students' level of engagement, and the relative dullness of the material.  He spends an equal amount of time on each topic, which is frustrating since easy topics take just as long to get through as the hard ones, for which not enough time is devoted.

He is pretty cocky about how much experience he has teaching the material, and about how well his book has sold.

The textbook is very well-organized, but not written clearly.
No one appreciated the fact that we were forced to go half the semester without a book, then buy it as soon as the new edition was released.

The programming assignments were usually interesting and had a cool end-product.

However, they were typically unrelated to what we were learning in lecture, other than a one-line call to an algorithm we might have learned.

Be careful with the weekly exercises, as they end up making a huge impact on your grade.  Definitely check them over for silly mistakes with other people beforehand.
Be prepared for a lot of competition from students and not a lot of help.
COS217 is a much better course. take this first so you don't get disappointed.

Definitely a course worth taking for anyone interested in computers. Particularly for non-COS majors who are still interested after 126, I would recommend this over 217 because the material is so much more applicable and tractable.
Do assignments early.
Do not expect anything interesting or creative.
Easier than cos 217, but harder than cos 126. The work is average.

I learned a great deal of information and strategy in this course.  It is the foundation for much of computer science study later on.  The grading in the course is not optimal because it is skewed by numerous brilliant cos people.
I would definitely recommend taking this class to both CS and non-CS majors alike because the algorithms introduced in the class would be useful for many different areas.
I would encourage students to take this course since it really expands their view on computer science.

I would recommend taking this course, even if you don't want to pursue the COS major or certificate, if you're interested in computer science and willing to study algorithms with a fair amount of rigor. Though the work is hard at times, and the material somewhat abstract, careful study pays off.
I would recommend this course if you have an interest in COS at all.
I would recommend this course to a student in any department with any substantial interest in computer science.
I'd recommend it to anyone.
If you took Cos126 this is an excellent follow up.

If you're considering this class, then definitely take it! Just get started on the assignments early because they take more time than the ones from 126, and go to precept if you don't understand things from lecture or the assignments.
Important material, but challenging class - useful to work with a partner.
Interesting class if its what you like
It's a decent course if you LOVED 126. I think it was organized well but I just personally didn't like the content.
It's not as fun as 126, but still a good class.
Keep up with the class or it is easy to get lost in the many algorithms covered
Make sure to start the programing assignments early. Get a good preceptor because it really helps.
Not a great senior spring class! Good otherwise -- sometimes just felt like there was needless busywork. Precepts were also unnecessary, generally.
Paying attention in COS 126 will get you through several weeks of this course
Put effort into the problem sets - they reappear on exams.
Read the textbook, skip lectures if you don't learn particularly well from them.

Spend time going through the actual algorithms, and fully understanding traces and stuff. Write your own programs for assignments. If you do these two, lectures/precepts can basically be considered superfluous...
Good material though. I liked learning about all these sweet tricks (maxflow, sorts, etc) in comp sci.
Start assignments early, do the reading before lectures
Stay on top of the material, go to office hours.
TAKE IT. Interesting assignments, grading isn't too bad...what's not to love? And it's COS. :)

Take 217 and 323 if you're going for the certificate program. The stuff covered is good to know, but it's really not worth spending an entire semester on it. Take it with Kevin Wayne if you really need to.
Take it for sure.
Take it if you are very interested in COS or the certificate, but not great as a general interest class like 126.

Take it if you have any interest in COS, it's very useful. The lectures are a little dry, but the book and slides make it very easy to understand. Put in the effort and you will be pleased with the results.

Take it if you like computer science. For me, it got very tedious as I felt very distant from both Sedgewick and my preceptor. I also am not a fan of the exam structure; I feel like I am better at computer science than my grade reflects, but maybe that's just arrogance on my part... In all, I did not especially enjoy the course, but that is not to say that a lot of people don't love it...
Take it if you need to.
Take it if you're going to be a COS major or getting the certificate.

Take it!  Taaaake iiiiit.

Then, make sure you get every lecture even if you don't attend.  It pays to go over it all before precept instead of right before the exercises are due.  Holes in your understanding are where they get you during tests.
Take it! It's a ton of fun and really interesting!
Take it! Lots of fun and they will MAKE YOU LEARN DATA STRUCTURES AND ALGORITHMS.
Take it!!!
Take it.  It's important if you're doing any sort of quantitative science/engineering.
Take it.  This is one of the best courses I have been in at Princeton.  Don't be intimidated by the size of lecture; they do an excellent job of personalizing the material and helping people out.
Take the class if you are interested in general computer science. Not too difficult. Easy exams.
Take this before COS 217!  The language is the same as COS 126; the material is closer; the books are by the same author.  I would have enjoyed both classes more had I taken them in this order.
Take this course and like all COS classes, the little mistakes add up.
The assignments are not bad.

The programming assignments look like they would fun, but you don't actually get to figure anything out for yourself or even implement algorithms from class; everything is given to you.  The lectures are also really boring.  Skip this class and go into something higher level if possible.

This course is a very easy step up from COS 126. The format is more or less the same. The concepts are mostly expansions of things touched on in 126, although a little less so in the second part of the semester, and the assignments are harder but not impossible by any stretch. Basically, it's fun and I would consider taking it even if you aren't going to major in cos.
This is a good course and a lot of useful material.
This is a good course, and relatively light in terms of workload. Definitely worth taking if you have time/interest, and you pretty much have to take it if you want to do any higher-level COS work.

This is a great course and I would definitely recommend anyone interested in problem solving though computing to take this class. The transition from COS 126 to this class was also fairly easy and smooth.
This is a solid course in algorithms. It's a good course to take if you are considering a COS major or the certificate.

This isn't a particularly difficult class, but it relies on the ability and effort to memorize the names of algorithms and what they do. Simply logically thinking about what the best method is to, say, sort a given data set is not sufficient to do well in this class (you have to know the proper name associated with that algorithm).
This was a good course for anyone interested in computer science, and I would recommend taking it.

Try to avoid this. The material is something you can learn on your own in the book without killing your GPA. The problem is more so with the graders than with Sedgewick himself but in the end I just felt like putting extra effort into an assignment would yield no additional result and stopped. Probably the worst COS class I have taken here yet.
You can do well if you learn the lecture slide material diligently. For exams, no need to think, just mechanically trace algorithms

You can learn a lot from this class if you put the necessary effort into it, but it's useless if you're just going to sleep through all the lectures.  You probably need to take it for a COS certificate or major, but you should also put effort into it or you'll just have wasted that time.
You learn a lot of useful algorithms in computer science which may be important later on
prereqs: COS 126 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: Comparative Political Economy
reviews: Convinced me to study political economy. Professor Vindigni is not the world?s best lecturer, but he is happy to answer questions.
Do all of the reading simply because it is interesting.

excellent workload for senior spring. professor is very laid-back, but very passionate about his subject. 
sit in the first class and you'll know if the class is for you.
prereqs: Elementary notions of micro- and macroeconomics; Elementary Calculus.
descrip: The focus of this course will be on the origins and economic impact of political institutions (e.g. Democracy vs. Autocracy, different types of Democracy). We shall argue that these are not "neutral", as different institutions allocate political power differently among social groups with conflicting goals, who then have naturally different preferences on them.
