Special attention shall be paid to the influence of international relations (and particularly international conflicts) on domestic institutions and policy outcomes. Occasionally, we will also make use of some simple formal models of political economy.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course devoted to scholarly writing intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every two to three weeks. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Problems in Greek and Roman Philosophy - Animals in Ancient Science and Medicine: Theories, Practices, Contexts
descrip: This seminar explores the role of animals in the development of ancient biology, medicine, and natural history. Among the central issues explored are the role of personal observation, animal experimentation, systematic dissection and vivisection of animals, and the relation between 'folk biology' and the development of a 'scientific' biology. The relation between animal sacrifice and a rule-based medical techne that regulates human consumption of animal products is also examined. The seminar also takes up different traditions of classifying animals and the diverse literary forms used to 'write the animal'.

title: Fundamentals of Engineering Statistics
reviews: A good intro stats class. Lectures were a bit boring, but the exams were fair.

A good, solid introduction to statistics, even for someone without any statistics background. The reading is not overwhelming, but I know that jumping into using the statistical software R without any coding background is challenging, especially since it is not introduced very well at all. But the lectures are engaging, and the material is important.
A lot of repetitive work on the problem sets, but you WILL learn if you do it all.

A surprisingly good course. Great instructor, great TA's. The software is not difficult to use, but as with any program, it will take some practice. Also, the textbook only costs $8. What more do you need?

DO NOT TAKE, unless absolutely necessary. Even if you have taken a stats course before there is too much work for it to be an easy course and it is too boring and repetitive for it to be intellectually stimulating or interesting.
Don't take this class unless it's required.

Don't take this course unless you want to be an ORFE major. The organization was bad. The problems sets were poorly built. If you can take probability and statistics in a department where they don't make you copy and paste R for half of the homework, do that. This is a pretty terrible course. Don't take it.
Go to precept. Easy to fall behind because the stuff starts out easy, but don't slip.
Go to precepts and go to lectures but don't read the textbook.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student if he/she needs to take a statistics course.
I would not recommend this course unless you need to take it or you like statistics.
I would only recommend this course for those who have to take it.
If you have to take it, take it.

If you need a statistics course, don't take this one. It is poorly organized and needs serious help before it will be worthwhile. Although it was a little bit engaging, there are other Princeton courses better than this one.
If you need statistics, take this course. Don't take it just for fun because the problem sets will demand you a lot of time and they are not even that good.
If you need stats, then take it.
If you took AP Stats, it's basically the same thing.
If you want a challenge and/or if you need to take a stats course. Tak this one. Don't attend the long tedious boring and sleep-inducing precepts. You'll leave more confused.

If you've taken any statistics before (AP, A-Level or IB), you'll find this class to be very boring; I only started learning new material in the last third of this class, and the rest was just review. I took this class because I'd heard it was supposedly the most theoretical intro statistics class available; I was extremely disappointed. There's very little derivation of results, as the results presented are very basic, and all you need to do is figure out which formulas/models to apply to given problems. If this class is not a requirement, don't take it; and if it is, be prepared to slog through the painfully long and yet conceptually very basic problem sets.

It's interesting and fairly relevant to life if you're doing anything with statistics. Professor Rigollet seems to have done a good job revamping the course to have a more real-world focus (eg, the use of R, the emphasis on problem-solving in the project, etc). I'd recommend taking it if you want to actually learn some statistics (as opposed to skating through a class like PSY 251)
Make sure that this isn't actually a lab course before considering taking this class.

NEVER, EVER take this course. I'm guessing that they will have to drastically improve it once they see the horrible ratings, but stay away if you can (if the course is being taught in R). 
Reasons -
For the first time, the bulk of the course consisted of programming in R. That's perfectly fine, and that means that we didn't have to spend hours on end trying to figure out inane differences between numbers by hand -- or that's what one would think. It turns out we spent probably more time than we would have spent doing that on our weekly problem sets. Our weekly problem sets/lab reports easily reached 20 pages in length each week, and we had a problem set *each week*. Even that would be understandable if each new problem actually helped us learn something new or broaden our understanding -- but the problems were basically EXACTLY the same thing, over and over and over and over again - till you got tired of typing and crashed.
This is Princeton, and we are not guinea pigs. Students here have a high opportunity cost of time and I feel the teaching staff failed to correctly assess the time required to do the weekly stuff.

Unless you hear of revolutionary changes occurring to the class, NEVER take it. You get to the cool stuff (regressions) only in the last week, and by that time you are so turned off that its not even cool anymore.
Not a good class. Pf. Rigollet is not very helpful and not very nice.
Only recommend if prepared for the workload.
Only take it if you have to, or you really want to learn R. Otherwise I would strongly recommend a different stats course.
Only to take it if they must. I would recommend eco 202 since this is a pretty challenging class.
Start problem sets early.
Start your problem sets early! They take a long time to complete, and trying to finish them on the last day is very annoying.
Study hard!
Take a different stats class.  Its really bad and not easy.  Problem sets take forever and its just over all really annoying.
Take it as opposed to any other stats class.
Take it!
Take it.  You'll get more out of it than the other stats courses.

Take the course if you have to. Not especially engaging and the problem sets require more work than is needed to understand the material. However, I understand they are trying to learn from their mistakes and fix the problem sets for next year? Hopefully that works out for future students.

Also, if you've taken AP Stat, you will learn close to nothing new. While it still took a decent amount of time per week, the course was by far the easiest I have taken so far at Princeton because I had learned 95% of what it covered in high school.

Take this class if you are considering ORF.  Besides that, be extremely careful choosing to take this class.  Obviously, if you took statistics in high school, you'll have a huge advantage over many students.  However, if you never took statistics, you need to put in more effort in this class, which already demands a lot of time for its weekly lab reports.
Take this class if you have to, or if you have a burning desire to learn statistical software.

Take this course if you need to. But know that many people have already taken stat before, which makes the curve tough; the assignments can be / will be tedious; and toolish ORFE majors abound. Personally, I think I should have taken ECO 202, but I also suspect that you learn more from ORF 245, even as an ECO major.
Taking the course concurrently with COS 126 would be extremely helpful. Having an understanding of computer concepts is very helpful to understand how to use the R language.
There are probably easier stats classes, and learning everything yourself would probably be more worthwhile.
This class is pretty average. Not super exciting, but not super useless either.
This class may not be a lot of fun, but it will without a doubt pay off when I want to use statistical analysis in other classes.
This is a great introductory ORFE class, but don't expect too much theory. Problem sets are very, very dry, but the material is still useful.
This is a new course and the HW take forever to complete. Tests are also fairly difficult. Take only if you need to learn it.
This year Prof. Rigollet completely changed the format of the course to include the program R and this caused some organization problems but overall this is a pretty easy class.
Very useful
dont take unless you have to, not particularly difficult but ridiculously time consuming
start the homework early every week!
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Politics of Campus Space, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Future of Nuclear Energy
descrip: Course explores current debates about nuclear energy and reviews the basic science and technology and current uses of nuclear energy, with particular emphasis on the economic aspects and arrangements to prevent its use for weapons purposes. Policy proposals to facilitate the safe and rapid global expansion of nuclear energy are analyzed.

title: Germany since 1806
reviews: Attending precept is very important.
Even if it is an overview, this is a compelling course.

If you're looking for a stimulating history course to fill your HA requirement, or you're a history or German major looking to buff up on German history, take this class. There is a lot of reading but the work is not too challenging. James is an excellent professor and makes the history of Germany very accessible. The content is also really unique, since the unification of a nation and its role in WW1 and WW2 makes for excellent history.
Pay close attention during lecture, and if you are interested in European history take the course, because it also gives information on other events in Europe.
Prepare to read a lot, but the mid-term and the final are pretty easy
Shop it to see if you like the lecture style.
Take it, take it, take it.  It's an obviously fascinating time period, you'll learn a lot, and you can't get better than Professor James.
Take this class if you have any slight interest in European history.  Many ties can be made between U.S. and German history.
This course has a lot of reading, but overall it is enjoyable and the paper topics are interesting and allow you to get creative.
Too disorganized for my taste
descrip: This course sets German history in a comparative context of international politics, demonstrating how nationalism and national unity emerged as responses to the European state system in the first half of the 19th century, how after 1871 German problems in turn affected the world, and finally why after 1945 Germany should be so prominent in super-power politics. It examines the origin of the German Revolution of 1989, and the place of Germany in the global order.

title: Aristotle and His Successors
reviews: A good intro class for those who know little about philosophy.
Do all the readings.
Don't skip lectures - they are very helpful in completing the exercises. Form a study group to go over the exercises. Stay on top of the reading and it is not hard to do well.
Excellent material and engaging professor who doesn't bore you to death, as is entirely capable while studying Aristotle.

If you are a philosophy major: take this course, as it covers very cool bits of ethics and the foundations of logic.
If not: take this course if you want to learn something about the foundations of (even modern) philosophy.  
Be prepared to do bi-weekly problem sets (that are usually not too difficult) and to do relatively little (although very dense) readings (possibly multiple times).  Great lectures, fantastic precepts.
If you like philosophy, it would be a great course.
It's a difficult class, especially if you have no prior experience with ancient Greek philosophy but it's very rewarding and interesting. Thus far, the best class I've taken at Princeton.
It's a great class to take.  I didn't think it was too difficult, but at the same time it teaches you some really good interesting stuff.
It's not the easiest class in the world, especially if you're looking to get an A, but you'll definately learn a lot about the material.

Its an interesting course, and honestly not too much work. The reading is generally short, and the assignments are nothing to get stressed out about. If you want to read a man who lived 2000 years ago and yet is probably 2000 times more creative, intelligent and influential than anyone you will ever meet, then take this course.

Professor Morison is an excellent instructor, and knows Aristotle very well.  You should definitely take this class if you have any interest at all in thinking about how the world works or how you should lead your life.

Strongly recommended.  The lectures are clear (and quite entertaining), the reading load is manageable, and the material is some of the most important work in philosophy.
There are weekly assignments (which are manageable).  Although they are graded and given a number, no letter or curve was ever given during the semester itself.
Take this course if you want to consider yourself an educated person.
This course was engaging, and refreshing. Take it if you are interested in learning about historical philosophy.
This is a good class. The professor is good and the material is interesting. If you go to lecture, you should be fine on all the assignments.
Tough course, but it really gives you a good basis for understanding Aristotle

Try and get into Professor Morrison's precepts.  He likes to call you out and ask questions/keep everyone engaged, but you learn a lot more from his precepts especially when it comes to having to complete the weekly assignments.

take it only if you enjoy aristotilian philosophy, because his style of philosophy is different than others and is far more nitty and gritty with the world.  this is not much of an ethics class, which i was not aware of.
descrip: We shall study Aristotle's contributions in logic, natural philosophy, metaphysics, and ethics, with emphasis on the ongoing philosophical interest of some of his central insights. We shall compare some of Aristotle's views with those of some of his successors, Hellenistic and beyond.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: The Experience of Modernity: A Survey of Modern Architecture in the West
descrip: An analysis of the emergence of modern architecture from the late nineteenth century to World War II, in light of new methodologies. It will focus not only on major monuments but also on issues of gender, class and ethnicity so as to cover the experience of modernity from a more pluralist point of view.

title: Enlightenment and Romanticism - Dreams of Modernity
descrip: What does it mean to be modern? And, upon what notions of progress and individuality do claims of modernity rest? Through the figure of the dreamer, and through the manner in which dreams in fiction police the boundary between rationality and imagination, this course investigates eighteenth- and nineteenth-century debates on stasis and change, future and past, agency and its failures in the Age of Revolutions. Topics include private and public distinction, architecture as cultural signifier, the abandoned Louvre, fetishism and animation, and the stakes of literary history in defining Enlightenment and Romanticism as dialectical movements.

title: The Origins of the Middle Ages
reviews: Make room in your schedule to devote to reading and preparation for this class - I wish I hadn't had other seminars this semester and I could focus on this one!
descrip: Reading and research on the transition of ancient into medieval society, religion, and culture are the focus of this course.

title: Kiswahili Novel
descrip: Although the novel is the youngest genre in the Swahili critical tradition, it has experienced some of the most revolutionary and innovative experimentations since it gained mainstream prominence in Swahili literature, mainly during the post-colonial/independence literary revolution. This course is a reading of the Kiswahili novel with a critical analysis of the socio-political and critical trends in the literary world that have influenced the writings of contemporary Swahili novelists. The colonial/independence and post independence experience in east Africa are some of the motifs that inform the course readings and class discourse.

title: Mathematics in Engineering II
reviews: A good class. McAlpine is a good teacher, but be prepared for exams that are much harder than anything you see on the problem sets.
I would say if you're interesting in differential equations, definitely take it, especially if you enjoy doing math problems that don't involve much theoretical basis or proving.

If you're looking at this class for MAE as opposed to, say, ORF 245, I'd say choose this one because it's way more interesting and it's actually applicable to other areas of engineering, like controls and stuff, but it is much more difficult.
Interesting stuff. Makes you feel engineering-math knowledgeable.
Only take this if you are really interested in the material.  I'm probably going to get a bad grade, but I'm glad I took it.
Probably not worth taking.
Study hard for the final, only thing that matters.
Take MAE 305 and MAT 317 instead.
Take MAT317.
Take it if you're interested in the topic
Take it. You learn a lot of useful stuff. However, getting a high grade can be difficult with all of the "brains" in the class.
This course is very useful; take it!
This course ties in nicely with MAE 433 and probably heat transfer as well.
This is an ok course, and you definitely need it for certain requirements. Otherwise, I wouldn't say it's really worth taking.
prereqs: MAE 305 or MAT 301 or MAE 303.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to partial differential equations, covering PDEs of relevant interest in engineering and science problems. The material covered includes: (i) Complex analysis, including complex functions and series, (ii) Fourier series, integrals, and transforms, (iii) Solutions of partial differential equations, (iv) Conformal mapping and Potential theory, and (v) Applications of all the above. The material will be covered in three weekly lectures, plus one weekly AI session. Grades will be determined from weekly homework assignments, the midterm and final exam.

title: Digital Photography
reviews: Be warned: most of it is a huge photoshop tutorial. Not for the feint at heart or those fairly drawn to the visual arts.
I wanted to become a better photographer, but this class was about art, not photography. too abstract. take if you are an artist, not if you are a photographer
I would definitely recommend this class to other students, especially if Demetrius is teaching in the future.

It's worthwhile to take only if you don't expect too much out of class time and simply want the motivation to work on creative photography projects. Also don't expect this to be a technical how-to course (i.e. one that teaches you how to operate a dSLR camera and become a pro at photo editing in Photoshop).
Really chill and laid-back class. The assignments can be fun. Overall not at all time consuming. Oliver's not a great teacher.
prereqs: Must have taken VIS 211 or 212 OR Instructor's permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar and lab which explores the aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital technology in relation to photography. The emphasis is on making the photographic print in the digital work space. Class will consist of both independent and collaborative projects.

title: Studies in the Classical Tradition - Between East and West: Europe and Greece, 18th-21st Centuries
prereqs: No knowledge of Greek, ancient or modern, necessary..
descrip: This course examines the links between constructions of Europe and the place of national cultures within the modern period. We will pay special attention to the peculiar relationship of Greece (ancient and modern) to Europe, since Greece exists on the edge of Europe as we think we know it. We will look at historical case studies, scholarly debates, and literary texts to get a handle on the question of how the tension between East and West plays out when located on that border.

title: Darwin in His Time and Ours
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Criticism and Theory - A Lover's Discourse
descrip: No one would ever have fallen in love unless he had first read about it, Rochefoucauld once remarked. Love and discourse go hand in hand. But while love is a central theme of Western literature, it remains critically under-theorized; the amorous text, it would seem, is an embarrassing text. This new course recovers love as a subject of serious philosophical consideration. Taking Roland Barthe's A Lover's Discourse as our touchstone, we will investigate how we think and write about different types of love, including platonic love, unrequited love, self love, jealous love, first love, and lost love.

title: The Logic of Ethnographic Methods (Half-Term)
descrip: This mini seminar, the second in a sequence on ethnographic methods, will address the central questions facing ethnographic research as it strives to be a part of social science. Among the issues we will consider are the roles of induction and deduction, generalizability, replicability, and linkages between micro and macro sociological units. Issues of ethnographic writing will also be addressed, particulalry techinques for making descriptions of interactions, people, groups, networks, settings, and interactions. This is a half term course and meets during the second half of the semester.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: A songwriting workshop. Participants share works-in-progress and discuss some of the issues contemporary songwriting, including: lyrics, the relation between words and text, the relative pull of simplicity and complexity, the role of the charismatic performer, singing vs. speaking, and transforming your musical limitations into virtues (c.f. Bob Dylan). Previous experience in songwriting not required. Beyond focusing on hands-on compositional issues, course analyzes other people's songs (from Handel to LCD Soundsystem) and interacting with occasional guest lecturers.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: I recommend the course - hopefully, it will keep on improving.  I learned a lot, and it was nice to have a combination of economic focus and practical applications of risk.
If you are considering working in the financial industry or studying financial economics, you have to take this course!
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 465.
descrip: This course will teach students about financial risk management through the lens of the recent financial crisis. Topics covered will include market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and systemic risk. Students will draw on their background in economics, finance, probability theory and statistics. The class will be in seminar format and active participation in the discussion is encouraged.

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: Do your absolute best to get into the class of Monserrat Bores if she's teaching.

I wish I could tell you not to take this class, but unfortunately, you probably have to. As for a language, taking Spanish is probably an easy way to get the requirement done and at least kind of learn a language that you will actually likely use someday, but as for the class itself, its not good. Poorly organized, poorly run, and a waste of everyone's time.
I would advise using a different textbook that has exercises with answers. I used one called The Ultimate Spanish Review and Practice by Gordan and Stillman. It was good preparation for the exams.
I would recommend that you take this class if you are trying to learn Spanish.
I would say take this course. Eventhough it is everyday instead of three days a week like 108, you have a chance to speak the language everyday and I imagine that I is a little easier than 108.

It's a great course. You'll definitely sharpen your Spanish speaking and writing skills in this class. Furthermore, the amount of work is not outrageous, just stay on top of the daily assignments and you'll be fine.
Make sure you go in to your instructor if you don't understand something. This class moves fast!
Spanish is probably not the best language to take at Princeton, particularly if you don't have to.

Spend a lot of time on the compositions and make sure that you reread them multiple times to catch most of your mistakes. Try and participate in class as much as you can, within reason, but please don't be a participation hog. The class atmosphere in my class felt very competitive which wasn't a great environment to practice a new language. Also, go to office hours if you can to get help on difficult grammar concepts.
Stay on top of the material early so that when there is a test or a quiz, you arent swamped with lots of vocabulary and grammar that you have neglected to look at for weeks.
Take it if you want to learn Spanish or are trying to fulfill your language requirement. It's a pretty easy class.
Take it! Monserrat is great; classes like these are the reason you chose Princeton.
Take this course.
Try to get in a class with Monserrat if she is teaching again.  She doesn't "refuse" to speak English and it makes learning the language a lot easier.
Work diligently and patiently at the material, do not be afraid to ask questions.
Work on grammar!!! Do the readings, participate in class and study hard.
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed for students who have successfully completed SPA 102 or SPA 103. An integrated approach to increase comprehension, oral and writing expression. Class activities reinforce language skills through aural/oral practice, grammar review, vocabulary acquisition, reading, editing compositions, oral presentations, and discussion of contemporary Spanish short stories, music and films.

title: Precolonial Africa
reviews: Difficult but terribly interesting. Makes you rethink everything you know about Africa - which for most, is almost nothing.
Do the readings because participation is a big deal for her. Don't get behind because there is a lot of it. Get to know the professor because her research is really interesting.

If interested in Africa, or learning interesting history that you probably know nothing about, I'd highly recommend this course. 
This class was very interesting and laid back. Do the readings.
If you're in anyway interested in Africa, you should take this course, and even if you're not, I'm sure you'll find something that sparks your interests/passion!
Take it!
descrip: This course explores the rich history of Africa before colonial occupation during the 19th C. It concentrates on people and civilizations indigenous to Africa, focusing on ancient civilizations as well as in the expanse of Islam and the Atlantic slave trade. Travelers' accounts, epic and archaeological evidence reveal the diversity of African culture.

title: Beginning Workshop in Musical Composition
reviews: Be ready to spend a lot of time outside of class creating and practicing for this course. It is an extremely rewarding class though, and getting to work with this professor-preceptor team is an amazing and unique opportunity.
Great class for anyone who has simple knowledge of music theory and a general interest in music.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in writing music (not any particular style, either, everyone was very open about any style of music - reading music not necessary, but helpful only in playing other people's pieces), but would caution to serious composers that, aside from the final project, it's hard to come up with something really, really substantial in the given time frames.
I would recommend this course to someone who has a musical background and is interested in learning about composition.
I would tell them to take this course if they have any musical background at all, because music does not even have to be formally written, as long as you're willing to be creative!

If you are at all interested in composition, take this class!  It's not going to be easy, and your grade will probably not be an A, but it's one of the most enjoyable classes I've taken at Princeton, and I've gotten much better at compositional skills since the beginning of the semester.
If you have some knowledge of music theory and are interested in composition, take it! (especially if 104 will be easy for you)

If you like writing music or are interested in learning how to write popular music, this course is a great introduction.  You will not necessarily learn how to notate music, but how to create a piece of performance art, which is very valuable.
Take this course only if you are interested in doing very self-directed compositional work.  There is plenty of help available, but you must take initiative.

Take this.  If you are experienced in composition, this will give you great feedback and a lot of new ideas, and if you aren't as experienced it does a great job of expanding your limits and encouraging experimentation and getting your compositions started.

Whether you play classical violin, jazz piano or indie rock, this class should push your abilities in composition assuming you haven't done a ton of it in the past.  Trying to fit instruments with which one is unaccustomed is an especially prominent challenge throughout the course.

You should have a fairly strong desire to consistently be writing your own songs and should also be prepared to work in groups most of the time. While ability to notate is not strictly necessary, it is helpful. I have absolutely no ability to write in proper form, however, and taught everything by ear. It worked out fine. Professor Lansky is incredibly nice and approachable.
prereqs: Some musical background..
descrip: A continuous cycle of creation, discussion, and response based on the creative activity of the students. Students will be encouraged to explore varied styles and techniques (for example, notated composition, multimedia music, and improvisation) and to perform their own works.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: High Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews:
As stated by others - make sure not to miss the final class - pretty legendary!

This is a great introduction to how technology actually makes it into the "real world" and how to start a company. Be prepared to dedicate 2 hours to read (interesting) material before every class. Also, take the accounting exam seriously and make sure you start learning the basics as soon as possible.
This is a great class- Princeton should offer more classes like this!
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: Amazing class and amazing teacher. By far, my favorite class this year in terms of engagement and the ability to truly explore my creative side.
Be prepared to learn how to draw on your own. I liked the course, but just because I could dedicate some time from my schedule to work on  my 'class', though I just did what i like
Definitely take if you love art and are willing to put in the time. Effort is valued even if you aren't necessarily skilled, so don't let that scare you off.
Great first art class for non artsy students.
I struggled with it personally, but you might like it.

I think it's a great class for learning how to draw, even if you're not an artist. I was one of the worst artists in my class, but I still saw improvement and enjoyed creating my own art pieces of various styles.
If you're decent at drawing, this class will be extremely laid back. Most of the topics are also really interesting and fun to try out.
It's not a blow-off class at all. Only take it if you are willing to put lots of time and effort into it. If you are willing, then you can get a lot out of it and it will be an enriching experience.
JUST TAKE THE COURSE. YOU WILL LOVE IT AND LEARN SO MUCH AT THE SAME TIME.

Note that it would take up quite a bit of time, both in studio sessions (5.5 hrs a week) and homework assignments(about 4 -5 hrs a week). Considering that it is also non-PDF, I'd not recommend it if one is just going for an LA. However, seeing myself draw something nice for the first time even though I didn't draw much in the past felt pretty good, so you might like it too.
Plan to spend more time than is required in the studio and on your homework/project
Put time and effort in, and you will be rewarded.  Try to really enjoy each assignment.  This course is great no matter what your skill level is if you're willing to put in effort.
Take it if you know you'll pour your heart into it. Otherwise don't complain about a bad grade.
Take it!
Take the course.
Take this class if you love to draw.  I would not recommend this class to someone who is not expecting to do much work.
The class is non-P/D/F, which I have an issue with, but the class itself is definitely worth taking.
You should take this course.
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink, oil stick, collage, string, wire and clay. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be completed at the end of the term.

title: U.S. Medical Research and Researchers: Preeminence, Problems, Policies
reviews: Do it!! It's at 8:30 in the morning, but with Professor Rosenberg and Professor Mahmoud teaching, you won't even realize it. They bounce off one another perfectly and keep the course engaging and insightful. Also, you'll learn a lot about the current status of the research enterprise and the relationship between academia, industry, and government.
Do well in preparing for your presentations.
Good course. Not much work, and as long as you participate and the professors generally like you, it's not hard to do well, granted you're willing to get up at 8:30 twice a week.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in the research enterprise in the country.

One of the few classes I've taken out of pure interest, and the only students who take it are those who are truly interested, which makes for a really great class well worth the time, work, and early mornings.
Take it!!
The workload isn't a lot. It is an 8.30 class. You must participate but you are in a seminar with Gods in the field of medical research.
prereqs: MOL 214/EEB 214 or MOL215/EEB215.
descrip: Medical research aims to improve and maintain human health. Accordingly, researchers employ such strategies as understanding biology, defining disease mechanisms, and developing ways to prevent, treat, or cure. Today, the U.S. is the preeminent global power in medical research through interactions among government, academia, and industry. This course will trace the evolution of this country's research enterprise, describe its diverse cultures, focus on its greatest achievements (and achievers), and identify a number of challenges confronting it currently. How the U.S. copes with these challenges will influence the future of world health.

title: Mathematical Analysis of Massive Data Sets
prereqs: Fourier analysis and PDEs (APC 350 / CEE 350 / MAT 350 or MAT 330); Probability theory (ORF 309 / EGR 309 / MAT 309).
descrip: This course will concern itself with the analysis of high dimensional data sets using spectral methods. There has been significant progress in the development of methods for dimensionality reduction of high dimensional data. We will discuss these methods and how to perform data analysis tasks such as clustering and classification, regression and out-of-sample extension of empirical functions, semi-supervised learning, and independent component analysis (ICA). We will emphasize applications to image and signal processing, structural biology, dynamical systems, text and document analysis, search and data mining, finance, and more.

title: Media Arabic II
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107or the equivalent..
descrip: This course is a continuation of ARA 303, Media Arabic, in which students will improve their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, and radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including the BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion of these subjects. Study will be arranged by subject matter.

title: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Theater
reviews: This class was like close-reading for theatre.  It taught me patience and to pay attention to every detail.  Really worthwhile.

This is not an acting class.  This is not a directing class.  This is not a playwriting class.  I felt like this class would be an excellent supplement to one of the above, as it equips you with out-of-the-box things to think about.  This class puts your performance creativity to the test, and is not for the faint of heart!
prereqs: Open to actors, dancers, composers, musicians, designers, directors, writers, and visual artists who are interested in working across their usual disciplinary borders..
descrip: Practicing thinking like a writer-who-thinks-like-an-actor-thinking-like-a-dancer-who-thinks-like-a-musician-thinking-like-a-painter-who-thinks-like-a-composer-who-directs. Exploring the Faust legend from all theatrical angles (words, music, movement, sculpture, design), we build a multi-dimensional theatrical logic over the course of the semester. We will explore, provoke, invent, and analyze the phenomenal, the poetic, the sententious, the informative, the confrontational, and the entertaining.

title: Senior Project
descrip: The senior project is a year long independent study intended for students who choose to work in teams of two or more. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Groups develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Groups develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Groups submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Mind, Body, and Bioethics in Japan and Beyond
reviews: As a small-sized seminar, the class is ideal for the type of person who likes to engage with the material in creative ways not usually allowed by the limited precept system of other courses. It means that you must be well-prepared every meeting. Since the readings are so interesting, you will actually look forward to doing them and finding interesting perspectives from which to analyze them in seminar.

Definitely take it if you want a fun/easy EM.  No need to PDF - extremely easy to get a good grade even if you're not really trying.  Be aware that you'll be approaching many of the topics from a feminist's point of view though.
I would recommend this class to any students interested in Japanese culture or medicine.
If you are interesting in the subject matter, you will probably like it. You will probably even like more topics than you anticipated.

We discuss interesting topics, the readings are engaging, and Professor Borovoy is a good discussion leader. It is not a huge time commitment, either, so it's good as a fourth class or a fifth class. However, not many anthro majors are in it, so discussion may not benefit from those within the discipline.
prereqs: One course in East Asian Studies or one course in cultural anthropology preferred..
descrip: The seminar will examine key concepts of the mind, the body, and the nature-culture distinction. We will study these issues in the context of Japanese beliefs about the good society, making connections between "lay culture," Japanese notions of social democracy, and "science culture." Topics include: styles of care for the mentally ill, the politics of disability, notions of human life and death, responses to bio-technology, the management of human materials (such as organs), cultural definitions of addiction and co-dependency, and the ethics of human enhancement.

title: Art and Science of Motorcycle Design
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Between Swords and Stones: Jerusalem, a History
descrip: For 3000 years the city that is holy to all three monotheistic religions has known little peace and tranquility and has been the site of wars, conquests and division. By drawing on historical, literary, religious and cinematic sources, this course will explore the history of Jerusalem from antiquity to the modern period. It will examine its place in the religious imagination of Jews, Muslims and Christians and trace the political history of a city that continues to be one of the most inflammable places on earth. The course will look at the conditions in today's 'united' Jerusalem and explore the different contingencies to bring peace to it.

title: African American Literature: Harlem Renaissance to Present
reviews: A must-take if you're interested in African American literature or want a small, comfortable seminar course!

Definitely take the course if you have interest in studying literature, even if you are not particularly interested in African-American literature. You learn about many themes that do not only apply to black American culture. Do not be intimidated by the close reading you have to do at first because this skill definitely improves the more you read and discuss in the course.
It helps if you've read some of the literature in other classes
Take It!
Take it! The literature covered is great and you will learn a lot.
Take this course! You won't regret it.
descrip: This course explores the relationship between cultural production and historical phenomena (such as the Great Migration, the Harlem Renaissance, and the Civil Rights Movement, for example) in 20th- and 21st-century African American literature. Additionally, we will consider the place of African American literature and cultural production in a global narrative that encompasses decolonization, multiculturalism and globalization. Primary texts include novels, short stories, poetry and video and performance art.

title: Gendered Identities in Contemporary Korea
descrip: This course explores gender and gendered identities as produced and performed in different disciplinary frameworks and historical contexts in contemporary Korea. The relationship between gender formation and 20th century Korean history will be examined through the study of both texts (popular, journalistic, and scholarly) and visual media (films, television shows, and magazines). We will analyze the construction of masculinity and femininity in specific institutions and cultural practices such as military service, the sex industry, and marriage, as well as sports, cinema, and popular culture.

title: Cinema and the Related Arts
descrip: Cinema has learned a great deal from modern literature, but literature owes even more to cinema. This course will consider a range of narrative films that reflect on the process of storytelling itself, each creating the effect of a labyrinth or mirror regression. The main focus will be the analysis of framing, editing, and dream sequences in avant-garde (Deren, Frampton), feminist (Akerman, Denis), psychological (Hitchcock, Cronenberg) or self-reflexive (Shutter Island) films. Readings will explore the metaphysics of narrative (Borges), fundamental film analysis (Propp), and recent developments in the theory of narrative (Zizek, Bellour).

title: Communication and the Arts - In Search of Enlightenment
descrip: What was the Enlightenment? This seminar aims to help its participants develop an answer to that question. We will examine the state of the art in scholarly answers and test them against a series of major primary sources that illuminate the contours of 17th and 18th century European debates about a wide range of important topics: biblical criticism, deism and natural theology, Pietism and the "cult of sensitivity," religious toleration and freedom of the press, commerce and its moral implications, Newtonianism, rights and representation, and revolution.

title: Sound Design
reviews:
As a sound designer, I couldn't pass this up.

I know most students aren't sound designers, but I think from a theater perspective, more students should take this.  Sounds gets the least attention out of all aspects of college theater.
Rob was very helpful and accessible; a very good introductory course.
Run, don't walk. Take it.
prereqs: Please visit the Theater Program website for application information..
descrip: An opportunity to explore what theatrical sound design is, how to look at a text from the point of view of sound, how to launch your creative process, and how to take the ideas based on that creative process and turn them into sounds to be used in a show. Students will also learn how to communicate their ideas, palate, and the arc of their design in a way that demonstrates to directors how they will fulfull the director's vision while embracing their own artistry and response to the text.

title: Law, Social Policy, and African American Women
reviews: Good for those who are interested in learning about intersections of law, race, and gender.
Take this class!
Take this course! Super interesting, thought provoking, and Prof. Perry is the best.
descrip: Journeying from enslavement and Jim Crow to the post-civil rights era, this course will learn how law and social policy have shaped, constrained, and been resisted by black women's experience and thought. Using a wide breadth of materials including legal scholarship, social science research, visual arts, and literature, we will also develop an understanding of how property, the body, and the structure and interpretation of domestic relations have been frameworks through which black female subjectivity in the United States was and is mediated.

title: Cold War in Popular Culture, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - Israeli Extremism and the Search for Peace
descrip: In 1995 Israel's prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, was assassinated at a peace rally by a religious student. Rabin's assassination helped derail the peace process; it also exposed deep currents of political extremism in Israel. This course explores the roots of Israeli political radicalism. It examines the impact of the Arab-Jewish conflict on Israeli politics and assesses the way the '67 War impacted political alignments in Israel. The course considers how political radicalism in Israel reacted to the peace efforts of the '90s and it looks at how in the 21st century, with the rise of fundamentalism globally, political radicalism impacts Israel.

title: Freud on the Psychology of Ordinary Mental Life
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: History and Theories of Architecture: 18th and 19th Centuries
prereqs: Undergraduates may enroll in this course by application only..
descrip: Acquaints students with the best that has been known and built between the years 1690 and 1870 and focuses on a series of designs and/or buildings in relation to distinct cultural and critical contexts. "Best" is defined by the ability to sustain historical and theoretical debate and to enact conceptual migrations across diverse fields of inquiry. Emphasizes the role of architecture in new institutional forms and the reconfiguration of urban, industrial, and pastoral landscapes. The emergence of historicism as an organizing theme prompts a self-critical attempt to undo the narrative continuities of the traditional architecture survey course.

title: Religious Encounters in the Colonial Atlantic World
descrip: The encounter of Europeans, Africans, and Native Americans in the world of the colonial Atlantic from the mid-fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries constituted "America." This course will examine the religious dimensions of the encounter of these different peoples across time and space.

title: Into the Woods! What Disney Didn't Tell You About Fairy Tales
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Life on Mars -- Or Maybe Not
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Public Leadership and Public Policy
reviews: I really enjoyed this course. Professor Scovronick was a bit intimidating at first, but he ended up being a great professor. The seminar format was perfect for the type of material that was covered. This course was extremely interesting, and I would recommend anyone to take this course.
descrip: This course will review key Presidential policy decisions on issues such as the Iraq wars, the Watergate tapes, the Voting Rights Act and the Cuban missile crisis, and will consider the ethical, legal, and operational frameworks for effective, responsible public leadership. Students will review relevant literature from history, psychology and politics, discuss the central policy issues in each case, and evaluate the decision-making process in view of these frameworks.

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is only open to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical and theoretical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing information and guidance on the proposal and dissertation writing process Seminar meets every two or three weeks throughout the year, providing a forum for dissertators to circulate work in progress for feedback and to discuss issues that arise in their work. Normally required of all post-generals students.

title: Surrealism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Social Issue Filmmaking
descrip: From "The Battle Of Algiers" to "Do The Right Thing," film has been used as a medium in which to explore social issues and conflict. This course will critically examine a selection of documentary and narrative films in order to compare their different approaches to representing social issues. We will also learn the essential aspects of social issue filmmaking (in both the documentary and narrative forms) and how journalistic research methods inform the process. Classes will include a short video project, script writing workshops, and lectures from guest speakers who work in the industry.

title: The Fantasy of The Middle Ages
prereqs: Open by application to the Class of 2003. Applications will be mailed out to all freshmen. They must be returned to 313A East Pyne by Wednesday, November 10..
descrip: See description in Freshman Seminars brochure.

title: Electrical Engineering Master's Project
descrip: Spring course number to be used by Master of Engineering students who will be doing a project in lieu of a course.

title: An Introduction to the Islamic Scholarly Tradition
descrip: The course offers a hands-on introduction to such basic genres of medieval scholarship as biography, history, tradition, and Koranic exegesis, taught through the intensive reading of texts, mostly in Arabic. The syllabus varies according to the interests of the students and the instructor.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: The Diversity of Brains
reviews: Ask questions to keep the tempo of the class up.
Do the readings in a timely manner and prepare the presentation and paper as early as possible.

I really liked this class. I looked forward to it every week. The student discussions are what makes or breaks a seminar class like this. It was really easy to participate. I don't think anyone felt like they had to have an ingenious insight in order to share. It felt more like a group of friends having an intellectual discussion. We challenged and built upon each others' opinions. I would definitely recommend this class. It fulfills both a NEU and a MOL requirement too!
Learn about some very cool brain systems (not a contradiction in terms, I promise). Discussion is only as fun as you make it, so come prepared and be good at debate.
Not the best course to fulfill the psychology neuro requirement, but probably much better coming from an EEB perspective.  A lot of really weird animals.
Really interesting stuff, you won't be bored.
Take it.
Take this course
Take this course! The topics are all very interesting and don't require extensive background knowledge. There's not too much work other than a presentation and the final paper.
This class is awesome.
This class is definitely worth taking. Professor Ghazanfar does a good job stimulating discussion, and the the workload is fair.
it's pretty good, asif is pretty chill and an easy grader, and you learn about weird animals.
sdfsf
prereqs: PSY 258 or PSY 259a,b.
descrip: The premise of this seminar is that an understanding of the neural basis of behavior can be gained by examining species-typical behaviors. Each animal species has evolved neural solutions to specific problems posed to them by their environment. The course will focus primarily on forebrain mechanisms in mammals, highlighting the unique environmental problems that a species must solve and the ways in which the brains of these animals implement their solutions. Some example model systems include prey capture by bats, monogamy and aggression in voles, and eye gaze processing by primates.

title: Seminar in Pedagogy
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all English Department PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton and scheduled to precept this semester. Seminar covers a range of topics including designing lesson plans; leading discussions; teaching writing and revision; grading; writing recommendations; lecturing; preparing syllabi; and managing students, faculty and time. Classroom observations, Blackboard postings, and teaching portfolios required.

title: Between Renaissance and Revolution: Baroque Art in Europe
reviews: I would recommend the course if you're interested in the subject and prepared to do a lot of reading and memorization. You can certainly get a lot out of it, but if it's not your thing you may find the class tedious.

I would recommend this course to anyone who needs it to fulfill a requirement in that time period, or who is very interested in the subject matter. You have to keep in mind that this course is quite a time commitment and focusses on a processing bulks and bulks of information, some of which might not be interestingly conveyed.
I would say the course is worth it if one wants to know more about the particular subject matter. The course probably won't win over someone who doesn't already have a knowledge of art history.

It was a good course but you need to stay up with your readings and read all of the readings, even if it only says "recommended." You should also have the slides printed out before class and you can take notes on them or on your computer so you know the names. This is because he jumps and sometimes does not say the name's of the works.

It's a good class, and you learn a lot. The readings are somewhat dry, and many of them are never discussed in class. Like many other instructors at Princeton, Kaufmann will demand your complete devotion and seek to penalize students who are not 100% committed to his course by testing material presented in weeks with sparse attendance. It's a little ridiculous, considering that JPs and senior theses are due in the spring semester. Apparently that's not a valid excuse.
Make sure you attend all the lectures!
Maybe try to get in the professor's precept?  Otherwise find a different course.
Take this course if you're looking for a good overview of the artwork of the 17th and 18th centuries, but be prepared for a lot of tedious memorization.

This is a wonderful course for both majors and non-majors. A good mix between in-depth art historical study, famous works of art, and lesser known works that hold an important place in the discipline.
i would recommend it
descrip: This course surveys painting and sculpture in Europe ca. 1580-1780. An examination of major artists and trends in their social, cultural and political settings. Close attention to works of art in lectures and in museums in Princeton and New York.

title: Beethoven
reviews: A great and relaxed way to learn more about Beethoven and his work.  More lectures should be like this: less worrying about having to note everything for an exam or memorize facts for a grade, more listening to a phenomenal (and entertaining) scholar speak extensively on his area of expertise.
Anyone who even has an ounce of interest in classical music should take this class.
Bring a coffee.  The listening during class was difficult for me personally, despite being interesting.
Definitely take it! Even if you don't feel entirely comfortable with music theory, this is a great way to dip your toes into music history in a really unique way.
Highly recommend to music majors.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.  I would also recommend taking any of Prof. Burnham's other courses.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is also important to do the readings and the listening assignments for each class. Overall this course was one of my favorite courses this semester.
If you can read music and love Beethoven, there's no better class in the world.  I don't care what they say in Vienna or Paris, this is the best!
Stay on top of listening assignments!
Take it because it's fun, so why not.
Take it!  Professor Burnham is a wonderful lecturer and you will not want to miss a class!
This is a fantastic class because Prof. Burnham is awesome. If you're interested at all in Beethoven or music, take it.
This is the best course! I wish I could take it again!
prereqs: Must have a year of theory (MUS 105/106)..
descrip: A survey of Beethoven's works in historical context. Questions of biography and influence will also be explored.

title: Energy for a Greenhouse-Constrained World
reviews: A comprehensive overview of sustainable energy, expert lectures from people at the top of their field, accessible professor and TA
Do the readings, they are 50% part of the class to get the best of it and get involve in your midterm paper.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in energy concerns.
I would only recommend this course if Professor Larson does not teach it.
It's a great course if you are interested in sustainable energy.
Take all the statistics presented in lectures and readings with a grain of salt.
Very informative
You can learn a good overview, but homeworks suck.
recommend it if you are interested in renewable energy
take it, but not with larson
prereqs: Freshman physics requirement. In addition, it is suggested that students have some coursework in thermodynamics or its equivalent but not required. Students from all departments of the University are welcome and are permitted in the course..
descrip: This course addresses, in technical detail, the challenge of changing the future global energy system to accommodate environmental constraints. Energy production strategies are emphasized, including renewable energy, solar, wind, nuclear fission and fusion, the capture and storage of fossil-fuel carbon, and energy storage strategies. Efficient energy use is also considered, as well as intersections of energy with economic development, international security, local environmental quality, and human behavior and values.

title: Elementary Chinese II
reviews: DEFINITELY TAKE CHINESE.
Definitely take Chinese.
Do not hesitate! Definitely take this course, you will not regret it. Your Chinese will be at an astoundingly high level at the end of the year, and you will be truly amazed at your level of fluency.
Excellent teaching, but very difficult language to learn.
Great class - definitely take it.
I think that other students taking this course should only take it if they really want to because it is very demanding.

If you are not passionate about learning Chinese, do not take this course.  There are things you could be doing that would better help you achieve your interests.  However, if you do feel strongly about learning Chinese, either for its aesthetic appeal, its political or economic utility, etc., and you feel you will be applying your knowledge in the future, the Chinese program at Princeton is very strong and I feel you are best off starting to learn the language here and now rather than waiting.
If you are willing to put a lot of time into this class, then go ahead. However, just know that this isn't a class you can take just to fulfill the requirement and not do any work for.
If you aren't willing to put in a lot of time, don't take Chinese! Otherwise, do, because it's very fun and an awesome thing to know.
If you put in the hours, you'll do fine.
If you want to take Chinese and are willing to do work consistently throughout the semester, the classes are incredible and the teachers are so happy to be teaching!
If you're not averse to challenging yourself, the is the course for you.

Keep up with the homework. Review your characters in the coming lesson before the week begins. Make flashcards over the weekend. Use the flashcards to refresh your memory of old characters from time to time. Put in the time and you'll see that it pays off! Go talk to the teachers - they're always willing to help.

Please take this course if you'd like to learn Chinese or if you just nee to fulfill your foreign language requirement. The teachers are amazing and dedicate so much time to our learning (Chinese tables are probably the language table that is most attended! And they are so fun and interesting). The work is definitely manageable and it is a fun experience overall. You'll make great friends in both your classmates and your teachers!!
Study hard and you will be rewarded.
Take Chinese! It's incredibly challenging and intense, but well worth the effort. The professors are amazing, and you'll notice a huge improvement from first semester to second semester.
Take it!  I think it gets a little easier to pick things up in 102 than it was in 101.  The class is fun.
Take it, do the work, stop complaining.
Take it.
Take it. Truly excellent course, excellent teaching, and a very novel learning experience.
Take this course or else you did not make the most of what Princeton has to offer.

Take this course!  The Chinese program at Princeton is unbelievable.  You learn an incredible amount in such a short time.  It is true that the course is very demanding, but it is definitely worth it.  Chinese 102 is not as difficult as Chinese 101 because you are already used to the structure of the class.  If you have a good grasp of what was learned in 101, 102 will not be much of an adjustment because it basically builds upon what was already learned.  The teachers are excellent and are always willing to practice Chinese with you.
The best kept secret at Princeton. It's a very easy course if you study 4 hours a week, you'll get an A.
The class is very demanding but the methodology used in this class definitely works in helping students learn Chinese.

This class is going to require a lot of work. If you just took this class, you wouldn't have to worry. But if you are an upperclassmen with other responsibilities and classes, know what you are getting yourself into.

Would strongly recommend if they are willing to spend the time learning the language.  I would also recommend that they get some preparation ahead of time (language tapes).  If not for this, it may have been hard for me to keep up at the beginning.

You do have to care.  Chinese pronunciation and characters are difficult, but if you want to learn them and are having trouble, there are so many resources at your disposal.  The Chinese teachers will go out of their way in multiple ways to help you if you ask, and sometimes if you don't.  Many people think this is a difficult course, but considering the amazing help from the teachers and the excellent course structure, I doubt that this is the hardest language at Princeton.  Though it's true there's a lot of work to do, the course makes learning Chinese much easier than it would otherwise be.
don't take this for fun, because it's not. it's fairly well-taught but the book's hilariously bad and ridden with typos.
perhaps the best Chinese curriculum in the US
prereqs: Chinese 101 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of Chinese 101. To develop basic competence in understanding, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese.

title: Introduction to Islam
descrip: This introductory course provides a thematic overview of Islamic beliefs, rituals and practices. We will study both majority Muslim societies and Muslim minority communities in the past and present. The course will highlight commonalities among Muslims but will also focus on historical, geographical and cultural diversities. Course materials include primary sources in translation, academic articles and books, feature and documentary films, fiction in translation, internet sites and power point presentations. Students will be required to participate in at least one of two possible field trips in the New York/New Jersey area.

title: Intermediate Persian II
reviews: Absolutely take this course! Professor Mahallati is simply amazing!
If you are interested in the Middle East, particularly Iran or Afghanistam, TAKE THIS COURSE!
If you have an interest in Persian, take it.
Take Persian! It's absolutely a challenge but the faculty are great and you learn so much about the culture in one of the most fascinating countries in the world.
Take this class. Nothing else needs to be said.
you get out as much as you put in.  if you treat the writing assignments seriously, you will really improve.
prereqs: PER 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The emphasis is on reading modern and classical prose, and writing modern prose. Classes are conducted mostly in Persian. Advanced grammar drills and translation exercises.

title: American Art and Culture: The 1960s
descrip: An examination of the dominant art movement of the 1960's, Pop Art, through its major figures (Warhol, Lichtenstein, Oldenberg, Wesselman, Indiana, and Segal), and the interrelationships with contemporary advertising, e.g., imagery of sex, automobile culture, cigarettes and food, art and signs. The course will look at parallels in other cultural expressions, such as fiction, journalism, rock music, and film, to explore some of the defining social and artistic concerns of a very turbulent decade.

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - Entrepreneurial New Product Development (NPD)
reviews: Definitely take it.  Maybe even take it more than once (since I think the professors are visiting professors, so each course is actually different).  This is one of the best classes I have ever taken at Princeton.
Do it.
Great, easy, fun course.
Highly recommended for born-entrepreneurs.
I would advise students to take the course if the opportunity arises.
If Dahan comes back FIND HIM.
Phenomenal course, take it, especially if it has nothing to do with your field of study or future goals.
TAKE IT!! You won't regret it!
Take it if you are looking for a relatively relaxed course that will introduce you to a few cool ideas and give you an introduction to what its like to create a product.
Take it!
Take it!  It's the best class.
Take it, it's a great use of your time at Princeton
Take this class! But choose your teams carefully...if someone ends up PDF'ing the class that can screw you over once the group project comes around.
Take this if you're looking for a fun and engaging course.
This class took me was outside my comfort zone but it was totally worth it.  Take the class.

This course has a generally lighter work-load when compared to other Princeton courses but provides a very stimulating framework to allow you to explore topics in more detail and expand your definition of "common sense".

This was an amazing course. I recommend it to anyone who has a slight interest in entrepreneurship or business.

The lectures were so well prepared and Dahan really tried hard always to keep us engaged and he almost always did. The material in the lectures were very practical and useful. The guest lecturers were also remarkable as well.
prereqs: None, other than interest in new product development and entrepreneurship. Basic concepts in probability, statistics and economics will be discussed..
descrip: Focus: We dive into the conception, innovation, and marketing of insanely great products and services. NPD processes must balance creativity, emotion, analysis, technology, and cost reduction. Great products may be thought of as a carefully orchestrated symphony of engineering characteristics, aesthetics, and emotional attributes. Design: We study multiple NPD methods, both qualitative and quantitative, and apply them to case studies and a course project competition.

title: Science and Gender
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Philosophy of Mathematics
descrip: Consideration of recent discussions of foundations of mathematics with special attention to the contrast between set-theoretic and category-theoretic approaches.

title: Topics in International Relations - The Global Jihad in Theory & Strategy
descrip: Course focuses on the historical and theological uniqueness of the movement of the Global Jihad in Islam, especially in comparison to other Islamic fundamentalist conceptions. Emphasis is on explaining the recent emergence of such a restorative and purist outlook only at the end of the 20th century; how it uses modernity and globalization in order to spread its radical notions, and why young Muslims are attracted to this conception. Reading for the course is based on original sources translated into English.

title: Introduction to African Studies
descrip: The course offers a unique opportunity to explore the past, present, and future of Africa in a truly multidisciplinary setting. A dozen of Princeton's distinguished faculty collaborate in an effort to shed light on both the huge potential of Africa and its peoples and the enormous challenges the continent faces. Topics include politics, economics, conservation, biodiversity, climate change, the environment, health and disease and written and oral literature.

title: Soil Mechanics
reviews: A lot of students end up falling asleep in class. But really, Prof. Popescu tries really hard so that everything understands the material.

Bearable. I don't see why anyone would take it if they aren't a civil engineer who has to. You'll learn, and at times there will be interesting concepts. But it is largely just a necessary subject to get to the cooler things like concrete.
Do not take it unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take this course unless you have to - it's pretty boring and tough to get through. Radu is really nice and willing to help, but not the best lecturerer.
Good class, not too much work, very straightforward material.
Only if you really like dirt.
Pay attention in lecture and definitely take notes.
Take this course if you need to- its interesting and you will learn a lot. The professor and TAs are all very helpful and willing to answer any questions you have.
The professor was approachable and explained concepts well, but the student needs to be prepared to work hard.
Unless you're really interested in soil dynamics or need it for a departmental requirement I would skip it.
descrip: General introduction to physical and engineering properties of soils. Soil classification and identification methods. Soil exploration, sampling, and in-situ testing techniques. Permeability, seepage, and consolidation phenomena. Bearing capacity. Stress Distributions and Settlements. Slope stability, Lateral Pressures.

title: Black Women and Spiritual Narrative
reviews: Take anything Prof. Best offers, especially a night seminar.  This course in particular has awesome readings and will hopefully attract great students.

Take this class or any other class by Prof. Best.  He is a fair grader, an engaging lecturer, a professor passionate in his area of study, and a genuinely nice man.  This class has been one of my best!
Take this! It raises great questions about gender, race and religion. Also, Prof. Best is one of the most consistently interesting and engaging professors I've worked with.
descrip: This course will analyze the narrative accounts of African American women since the 19th century. Drawing on the hypothesis that religious metaphor and symbolism have figured prominently in black women's writing (and writing about black women) across literary genres, we will explore the various ways black women have used their narratives not only to disclose the intimacies of their religious faith, but also to understand and to critique their social context. We will discuss the themes, institutions, and structures that have traditionally shaped black women's experiences, as well as the theologies black women have developed in response.

title: History of the Apocalypse, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: The Renaissance - Europe and Shakespeare
prereqs: None..
descrip: A course on literary relations in the early modern period, from the continent to Shakespeare. After some attention to theories of intertextuality, reading, translation, and influence, we will focus on several major European authors from antiquity and the Renaissance, particularly as they emerge in the astonishing industry of Elizabethan translation, e.g., Golding's Ovid, North's Plutarch, Harington's Ariosto, Holland's Livy, and Florio's Montaigne. We will consider these works in triangulation: the foreign original, the Elizabethan English version, the re-emergence of both in Shakespeare's plays.

title: Leadership
descrip: What do leaders actually do? What kinds of traits are important for successful leadership? How do followers influence the behavior of leaders? And what impact does exercising power have on your personality? The course draws from classical political theory (including Plato, Machiavelli, and Max Weber), current "leadership literature," and case studies of decision-making. Among the topics considered are expertise and collaboration, responsibility and accountability, women and leadership, and leadership in various kinds of organizations.

title: Introduction to Italy Today
reviews: Definitely take this class.
The class depends on who is in it. Do the homeworks at HOME so you don't have to read them line by line in class.
prereqs: ITA 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to familiarize the student with major features of contemporary Italy and its culture. Its purpose is to develop the student's ability to communicate effectively in present-day Italy. The course emphasizes Italian social, political, and economic institutions, doing so through the analysis of cultural and social differences between Italians and Americans in such everyday concerns as money, work and leisure. NOTE: no books will have to be purchased for this course since all reading materials will be available on Blackboard.

title: Urban Modernism and Its Discontents
reviews: Bruno is amazing, this course is incredible. A really intelligent and insightful way to look at problems of urbanism and modernism through a variety of perspectives.
Highly recommended, very interesting class.
TAKE THIS CLASS. DEUCES.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Do the readings and talk to Bruno - it will only go well. He is far more approachable than most other professors and far more knowledgeable than you can imagine.

The course is an incredible, provocative history of the development of urbanism, modernism, and the Lusophone world; and, almost regardless of your knowledge of any of the previous subjects, Bruno Carvalho is without question one of the best professors at Princeton.  Not to be missed.  Rearrange your entire schedule if you have to.
Treat it like a seminar- do the readings and participate in the discussions.
awesome course, awesome professor. take it!
make sure you space out the assignments and remember the blackboard posts
descrip: An overview of the cultures and histories of major cities in the Portuguese-speaking world, including Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, Brasilia, Lisbon and Luanda. This course explores some of the tensions between modernization projects and cultural production during the late 19th and 20th centuries, examining representations of the city in literature (poetry and prose), maps, film, painting, photography, and music. We will focus on topics like the favelas, Sao Paulo's urban explosion into a megalopolis, the architectural history of Brazil's modernist capital, and the potential consequences of Rio de Janeiro hosting the 2016 Olympics.

title: Sound, Music, and ... Physics
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
