descrip: This seminar course will introduce the students to recent developments in stochastic analysis as they relate to the mathematical models of pricing and hedging in incomplete markets.

title: Topics in Social Stratification (Half-Term) - Race and Schooling
descrip: Education is becoming increasingly important for upward social mobility in the U.S. and abroad and has been linked to societal inequalities in health, income, and other life-chance measures. This seminar engages both quantitative and qualitative studies and focuses on 1) the historical trends and understanding of racial/ethnic differences in achievement, and 2) the current issues/debates within the sociology of education literature. In addition to considering the relative underachievement of blacks and latino/as, this course also examines the academic success of Asian Americans and Asians living within the U.S.

title: Atmospheric Chemistry
descrip: Natural gas phase and heterogeneous chemistry in the troposphere and stratosphere, with a focus on elementary chemical kinetics; photolysis processes; oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen chemistry; transport of atmospheric trace species; tropospheric hydrocarbon chemistry and stratospheric halogen chemistry; stratospheric ozone destruction; local and regional air pollution, and chemistry-climate interactions are studied.

title: Greek Historians
prereqs: CLG 104 and CLG 108..
descrip: We will read selections from Herodotus' Histories, with an emphasis on Book 7. We will discuss the text from a broad perspective, examining it both as a work of history and as a work of literature. Particular attention will be paid to the relationship of historical writing to other forms of literature (both poetic and "scientific") as well as to oral tradition and oral storytelling. At the same time, the Histories will be explored as a major source for Greek and Persian history.

title: Biotech Plants and Animals: Frankenfood or Important Innovations?
prereqs: MOL and CHM intro courses recommended..
descrip: Biotechnology has given us the tools to manipulate both domestic plants and animals. Biotechnology may provide the means to allow crops to more rapidly adapt to changing health and environmental circumstances--including changes due to climate change--and to allow livestock to reduce their environmental impact. Case studies, and discussions with experts, will be used to evaluate these plants and animals created using biotechnology and advanced plant breeding techniques. We will also discuss the case against bioengineered foods and explore concerns over ethics, and adequate testing for their impact on human health and on the environment.

title: Special Topics in Molecular Biology - Molecular Biology of Skin
reviews: A great course, particularly for senior MOL students looking towards more biomedically-relevant fields; a fantastic primer to the skin, its biology, and skin pathologies.
Participate--you get as much as you put in!
prereqs: Intro Biochemistry (MOL345) or equivalent..
descrip: Structure-function relationships in health and disease. Topics include the development and regeneration of mammalian epidermal and dermal structures, inflammation and wound healing, cancer and aging. Pharmaceutical and cosmeceutical interactions will also be addressed.

title: Advanced Quantum Chemistry
reviews: If you are interested in quantum thing, it is a good course.
It is an extreme amount of work and is very, very difficult. Worth it, to be sure, but it should not be treated lightly.
Read the HW solutions well.

The course is well-suited for students with a strong background in quantum chemistry and advanced methods in mathematics. I would possibly recommend it to students who plan on focusing their research to topics in quantum chemistry.

This is a wonderful and perfect course if you are interested in the angular momentum theory (incluing angular momentum graph theory, the Wigner Eckart theory, spherical harmomic addtion theory), quatum dynamics, quantum scattering (Born Series, Partial wave analysis, inelastic scattering), and spectroscopy. I strongly recommend this course!
descrip: Selected advanced topics in quantum mechanics including: time-dependent quantum mechanics, angular momentum theory, scattering theory, and radiation-matter interactions.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - Arts and Cultural Policy in Contemporary Cuba
prereqs: This course will be offered in Cuba to participants in the Princeton program in Havana..
descrip: This course will address the creation, promotion and consumption of art and culture in Cuba--and will analyze the policy framework within which this takes place. It will examine the goals of the revolutionary government with respect to literacy and cultural democracy and will review how these objectives have been realized through changing circumstances since 1959. It will ask how cultural policy relates to diversity, emigration, tourism, the preservation of heritage, and the fraught histories of imperialism and nationalism.

title: Aircraft Design
reviews: Great course if you are considering aerospace track in MAE
If you have to get requirements done, take it. Probably much easier than space.
It's a good class, but since it's pretty much self motivated through the course of the semester, it is important to keep up with the work and not leave everything to the end

This course is very open-ended - whereas the previous semester's Aircraft Flight Dynamics consists of weekly assignments, this course essentially extends the final project for that prior course and devotes an entire semester to it, coming from the design perspective instead of analysis.  Students can research and implement any aspect of the aircraft in whatever detail they wish - we chose to ignore most of the interior organization details, save for the volume each component was expected to require.  Instead, we spent a significant amount of time working with CFD for the supersonic aircraft, which was very enjoyable.

If you're an aerospace engineer you have to take this anyway, but it should be less work than the weekly technical papers of last semester.

Very interesting!  Not easy but you get out of it what you put into it, particularly in regards to the final design project -- helps to stay on top of things early in the semester, even with other work, so as not to have an overwhelming amount to do before the final paper / presentation for the full design at the end of the semester
You get out of it what you put in.
You only take this course if you want to be a plane designer, and if you are the slight bit interested than this course will be a great option to take.
prereqs: MAE 321 and MAE 331 and MAE 335..
descrip: This course discusses methods for the design of aircraft. Topics in aerodynamics, and structural design are emphasized in the context of a design project. Students will be required to complete a design project to fulfill the requirements of this class.

title: Convex Analysis for Mathematical Finance
descrip: Tools from Convex Analysis are studied in the context of Mathematical Finance and economics, including the Hahn-Banach theorem, Legendre-Fenchel transforms, biconjugation theorem, subdifferentials, and duality. As a main application, translation invariant functions such as risk measures, no-arbitrage price bounds, good deal bounds, benefit functions and optimized certainty equivalents, are studied. Further applications include the Fundamental Theorem of Asset Pricing, hedging problems, capital/risk allocation and utility maximization.

title: Horace
reviews: Best course at Princeton. Don't miss it.

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. or any other course Prof. Feeney offers. Horace is a phenomenally interesting author, especially if you enjoy reading Augustan literature, or have taken a course on Greek lyric.  Also, Prof. Feeney is just brilliant and hilarious and a joy to learn from.
Take anything you can with Feeney.
Take it!  If not for Horace, do it for Prof. Feeney.

Take this course - it's a great combination of a fascinating poet and a good professor!  The work level is very reasonable and it's a fun class to be in.  One helpful prerequisite would be some background knowledge of Greek lyric, since so much of Horace's program is based on the adaptation of Greek meter & poetic content into an Augustan context.
prereqs: LAT 203 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Close reading of selected Odes of Horace, considering his poetic program and techniques, together with the contemporary Augustan context.

title: Genes, Health, and Society
reviews: Absolutely take it. Try the best you can to get Professor Rosenberg as your preceptor, he was amazing.
Definitely take this course, especially if you want to learn a little about science but are not a science genius.
Don't take it if you're interested in anythign but pure genetics
Dr. Rosenberg is a leader in his field.  Definitely take the opportunity to take a course with him.

GREAT textbook, like a novel. And the amount of readings wasn't overwhelming even though some were at a very scientific level.Very fair, logical and relevant tests.He is the MAN though when it comes to genes. He brought in GREAT patients.
Great course, not very difficult, very interesting

I think the decision on whether to take this course should be made considering what you want out of the class.  I liked the class even though it was not what I expected, but I don't know that most will.  If you are interested in discussing the social impacts of genetics then this is not your class.  If you have never taken a genetics class and want to learn the background to be conversational in genetics then this is your class.

I would say that if you are looking for an easy SA I would not take this course even if you are really interested in biology. You can find other couses especially if your other courses demand a lot. Also this courses would be perfect if it was pdf.

If you are interested in biology and need an SA, I would recommend this.  Also, I think it is an excellent course to obtain practical knowledge that will become increasingly more relevant throughout our lives, and in that vein, I would recommend the course to anybody who is at all concerned or curious about their genes.
If you're very interested in the material, I would recommend it. I would recommend against it if you're experienced in molecular biology, as the science in this class will bore you to tears.

If you're willing to spend the time learning all of the genetics at the college level, then this a great course. If not, another SA would probably be better. Also, the course is not PDF which makes it extremely difficult I thought. I mean the course was incredible most of the time. At times, the genetics became overwhelming and I though Professor Rosenberg could have been a little more respectful to student questions and opinions.

It depends on who you are. If you are not going to major in science, this is a very user-friendly course because it hardly goes into any of the detail one might find in MOL214 or even, I imagine, MOL101, based on what I've heard. If you're a senior familiar with the material trying to find a fluff class, this might work, but don't expect to do very well. To get high grades you're still going to have to go to the lectures and do the readings.
It's a great course, not too heavy but you can gain a lot out of it!

Know that it's a lot more heavily based in science than society, and know that if you know a fair amount of molecular biology/genetics type topics already, not much will be covered in that regard that would be new, only the specific diseases.  I guess it sort of depends on what you're looking for - if you're looking for a primer in genetics, then sure, take the course, but if not, I might say that it might not be worth your time.
Take it!
Take the Woody Woo class on genetics if you are interested in more than enzymes and chromosomal abnormalities.
Take this course! The material is very interesting.  This course takes a slightly different approach to biology than any other course on campus.
This class was interesting. Pretty easy if you've taken AP Bio.
This course deals more with the science of genetics and less with the ethical and social dimensions of the topic. If you have taken MOL 214 and AP Bio, much of the science will be review.
Wouldn't recommend it at all. If you want to learn very basic science and no societal implications, go take MOL101 and get your ST.
good

to do really well, you need to memorize every single detail of the lectures-- not because the material is super hard, but because you get no review material, dont review anything in precept, and because the exam questions are really ambiguous. Its not a hard course, though, so i would recommend it for an SA credit; if your not happy with getting a B though, PDF.
descrip: What should students know about their genes and genomics? Today, the field of Human Genetics is explored and debated like no other. To understand the medical applications and ethical implications of Human Genetics, one must grasp its scientific foundations. We will approach these topics using: lectures, textbook, journal and newspaper readings, precept discussions, and patient interviews. We will consider the following subjects: gene structure and function; the genetics and genomics of populations and of selected human disorders (cancer, mental illness, metabolic diseases); and clinical genetics (inheritance patterns, diagnosis, treatment).

title: Current Issues in Anthropology - The Anthropology of Performance
prereqs: Freshmen who are interested in this course may contact the instructor for permission to enroll..
descrip: This course explores performance as event, activity, object of study, and analytical framework. Students will explore the genealogy of performance in the study of culture, while also reading texts in theater and philosophy that assert particular understandings of what performance is, or should be. If humans are, as Victor Turner says, performing creatures, what do we mean by "performing"? What kinds of actions qualify as performances and how do different definitions of performance shift our insights? How does our own culturally situated understanding of performance influence how we perceive the actions and representations of others?

title: Seminar in Contemporary Art and Theory - Postwar German Art
descrip: A seminar on the art produced in Germany after 1945. Classes will be structured around the work of individual artists and the critical frameworks (cultural, theoretical, historical) that their works invoke. Artists to be discussed: Beuys, Polke, Richter, Knoebel, the Bechers, Genzken, Trockel, Struth, among others. Themes to be discussed: art and technics/technology, pedagogy, internationalism/nationalism, memory and trauma, the legacy of the avant-garde. Authors include: Appadurai, Butler, Luhmann, Stiegler, Siegert, Mumford, de Duve, Flusser, Blumenberg, Arendt, Fried.

title: Quantitative Analysis for Public Policy
descrip: The course is designed for students preparing to incorporate statistical analysis in their policy research. In the context of case studies, it will cover the principal methods of data analysis and applied statistics in social science and policy research, including multiple regression, analysis of variance and nonparametric methods. Students are expected to have some knowledge of basic probability and statistical concepts.

title: Chinese Poetry
reviews: At least skim the readings and try to pay attention to Professor Wang, she really knows her stuff.

If you like classical poetry, you should take this. But if you are interested in more modern stuff, this isn't a course for you. Also, it's mostly native speakers, so if you aren't one, either be really good or don't be intimidated.
If you're interested, definitely take it.
It's worth it to the readings and they can be interesting as well. Translations are also a key part of the class.
take it for an interesting, easy class. great professor
prereqs: 2 years of Chinese..
descrip: Close study of classical Chinese poetry from different historical periods; discussion of the art in the original, in English translation, and in its contemporary adaptation.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Basic)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Provides a thorough examination of statistical methods employed in public policy analysis, with a particular emphasis on regression methods which are frequently employed in research across the social sciences. This course emphasizes intuitive understanding of the central concepts, and develops in students the ability to choose and employ the appropriate tool for a particular research problem, and understand the limitations of the techniques. Prerequisite: 507b.

title: Christianity along the Silk Road
descrip: Syriac is a dialect of Aramaic very similar to the language spoken by Jesus in first-century Palestine. Aramaic-speaking Christians in the Near East soon adopted Syriac as their literary language; by the early fourteenth century, Syriac Christianity spread from the western Mediterranean to China. In this seminar we shall be exploring the origins of Syriac Christianity in the Near East and its spread along the Silk Road before 1500.

title: Linear Algebra and Multivariable Calculus for Economists
prereqs: MAT 104. Two terms of advanced placement may be substituted for MAT 104 prerequisite..
descrip: Systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, matrices, and determinants. Differential multivariable calculus. Constrained optimization, and the Kuhn-Tucker conditions.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: The class deals with what is still somewhat of a niche field, especially in the CBE department. Make sure you're interested in the intersection of physics and biology if you want to take this course.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: Japanese Popular Culture in the Age of Globalization
descrip: This course will examine elements of Japanese popular and visual culture both within Japan and in a global setting, especially its impact on America and the rest of Asia. With a focus on the effects of media representations on subjectivity in a late-capitalist world, we will devote particular attention to visual aspects such as manga, television, anime, and live-action cinema, but will include popular music and fiction as well.

title: Scientific Integrity in the Practice of Molecular Biology
reviews: Definitely take the course. What you get out of the course is absolutely proportional to what you put into the course.
For graduate students in Molecular Biology, this is a required course. At least there is pizza!
I mean they have to take it, so it doesn't really matter if I recommend it or not
I strongly recommend this course. It is recommendable even to take this course more than once.
It's helpful and you have to take it anyway.
Participation is key to enjoying the course.
They are required to take it.
descrip: This course satisfies the mandate of the National Institutes of Health for training of molecular biologists in the ethical practice of science. The nature of -- and response to -- personal "misconduct" will be a principle focus. Through case studies and class discussion, we will examine the societal framework for the public support of basic biomedical research, the rights and responsibilities of students and mentors in the conduct of that research, and the significance of intellectual property. We will also review regulations concerning research with human subjects and animals.

title: Quantitative Analysis II
descrip: This course builds upon POL 571 and introduces students to applied regression analysis in cross-section settings. It begins with the basic principles of statistical inference, and then covers various statistical techniques including linear regression, instrumental variables, structural equation models, maximum likelihood estimation, and discrete choice models. The materials are taught at the level of Hayashi's Econometrics, and Freedman's Statistical Methods. Prerequisite: POL 502 (or permission of instructor) and POL 571.

title: Topics in Energy Engineering, Economics and Policy
prereqs: No.
descrip: This course explores in-depth several important energy topics that integrate engineering, economics, and policy. It is designed for doctoral students in the natural sciences, engineering, and social sciences that have been exposed to a wide-range of energy topics, perhaps as part of a National Science Foundation Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship Program (IGERT), and are interested in investigating further some of those topics. Students will engage in computer modeling to understand and explore future global energy and environmental problems.

title: The Rise of Asian Capital Markets
reviews: Very good course. Professor is excellent, well prepared and informed, and also very eager to help his students.
highly recommend for students with interest in capital markets
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global equity financial markets and its implications, and frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, putting particular emphasis on concepts of economic development, domestic institutional reform, corporate governance, and public market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian equity markets. Course also explicitly considers the policy decisions faced by the US and Chinese governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: International Cooperation
prereqs: Professor Keohane is willing to consider undergraduates for Politics 558, but graduate students will have priority, and undergraduates will need to write a statement and, if he does not know them, undergo a brief interview before being formally admitted to the course. Admission of undergraduates is therefore conditional on consent of instructor..
descrip: The analysis, theoretical and empirical, of the generation, maintenance, and breakdown of international cooperation, and its consequences. Particular attention will be paid to issues of compliance. Policy areas to be studied include trade, arms control, warfare, environmental protection, and creditor-debtor relationships.

title: Policy Workshops
descrip: Policy workshops normally involve a group of six to twelve M.P.A. and M.P.P. students working on a specific policy problem under faculty supervision. Students frequently work with original source materials and data. Often the workshop produces a collective report or recommendation. The objective is for students to bring to bear the full range of skills emphasized in the curriculum.

title: Introduction to Bioengineering and Medical Devices
prereqs: SEAS first year requirements in physics and mathematics..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental concepts required for the design and function of implantable medical devices, including basic applications of materials, chemistry and biology to bone/implant systems. The class will discuss the interfaces between cells and the surfaces of synthetic biomaterials, and biosensors for disease detection. An introduction to bio-nanotechnology will also be presented. Classroom sessions will be complemented by lab demonstrations and seminars by outside lecturers.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Reactions and Mechanisms
reviews: Professor Schwartz taught us to think independently and logically: I learned both problem-solving skills and course material. Lectures are fun and interesting. There really is no reason NOT to take this class, since it's not all that time-consuming and required anyway. Prof. Schwartz knows everything and everyone in Inorganic Chemistry: this wealth of knowledge makes his lectures the best.
Definitely take this class for the inorganic requirement!!

Despite a lot of the hype, this course is really not very well taught. Schwartz is a really intelligent and entertaining professor, but the structure of the course is very disconnected and unorganized, so it makes very little sense how things fit together or even what you're supposed to be taking away from the course. For all intents and purposes, your grade is dependent solely on the final exam, for which you will not know how you will be graded because it's the only thing in the class Schwartz grades. Also you won't know if you're preparing effectively because there are no answers to any of the practice exams or problem sets. The material was fairly interesting at times, but this is far outweighed by the headache that the class structure and format causes everyone. I did not know a single person in the class who came out feeling like they understood the material well. This is either because we're all incompetent or the course was just that poorly taught - one of those seems more likely than the other. In short, don't take this class unless it really doesn't matter how you do in the class (ie you're a senior with grad school/a job already lined up).
Do it.
Don't get behind. Seek help early.

I feel like a learned a lot. The most important thing I gained from taking this course was greater confidence in my chemical intuition. Like orgo, you develop a feeling for how certain species like to react. I feel like I could look at an unfamiliar system now and at least make an educated guess at how it would react, even if I don't know all of the specifics.
If you are taking this class as a departmental, it is challenging but interesting.
Its a very unconventional class.  Show up ready to pay attention, or you'll find yourself severely unprepared.
Only take it if you are a chem major

This class is very good, but with one caveat. There is no textbook way of doing things. Partially because there is no textbook, but also because doing well in the class doesn't rely on simply knowing the knowledge or facts taught in class; instead, deductive reasoning and making judgement class was valued.
This class rules, take it.

This course is fine to fulfill the inorganic chemistry requirement for chemistry majors, or to give an introduction to the subject for people who are just interested in chemistry in general.  I don't think that the subject matter is terribly interesting, however, so you might consider taking a different class instead.
This is one of if not the best course in the chem department

eh, 407 is a lot easier, I probably would have taken 407 if I had had room for it last semester. If you do inorganic chemistry for your thesis, this course would definitely help (though I think very few undergrads actually do inorganic)
it's a good course
descrip: Structure-reactivity correlations for inorganic complexes will be emphasized. Ligand substitution and electron transfer processes will be presented. The course will highlight applications of inorganic and organometallic chemistry to areas of current interest to both organic and inorganic chemists. These areas will include organic synthesis, "redox" reactions, catalysis, and materials. Prior completion of a full year of organic chemistry is required for enrollment.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term) - Electrical Engineeering and Computer Science
prereqs: Course open to graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed sufficient research to begin writing an article for publication..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in electrical engineering and computer science who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One three-hour seminar.

title: The Islamic World from its Emergence to the Beginnings of Westernization
descrip: Begins with the formation of the traditional Islamic world in the seventh century and ends with the first signs of its transformation under Western impact in the 18th century. The core of the course is the history of state formation in the Middle East, but other regions and themes make significant appearances. The course can stand on its own or serve as background to the study of the modern Islamic world.

title: Global Environmental Issues
reviews: An excellent course, especially for engineers who are interested in environmental policy.
Don't take this class.

I have mixed feelings about recommending this class. The material is important to know to understand anthropogenic impacts on the earth and their implications for our future.  However, it was a ton of work: 
4 involved problem sets
a weekly discussion question on readings
over 100 pages of reading a week
2 longer oral presentations
an 8 page paper
a 16 page dean's date assignment
and a final...

oh and supposedly she cut out work from the class the year prior. I talked to one of those students and told them all that we were doing and the person told me that that was far more than they ever did. 

So take an ENV course and learn about how we're killing the earth, just don't take this one or probably another one with Mauzerall.
I think this class is very interesting and will provide the student with lots of knowledge on environmental issues. It was also harder than I expected.
I wouldn't recommend other engineering juniors taking this course during their junior year.  Perhaps senior year when you have fewer weekly problem set or lab classes.
Very informative. Every student should take some form of this class.
You should take it!
descrip: As the world population grows and becomes more industrialized, human impact on the global environment also increases. This course examines a set of global environmental issues such as climate change, ozone layer depletion, population growth, and depletion of global fisheries, as well as regional issues such as loss of biological diversity, deforestation and desertification, acid rain, and the pollution and overuse of fresh waters. It also provides an overview of the scientific basis for these problems and examines current and possible future policy responses. One three-hour seminar.

title: Caribbean Music from Contradanza to Reggae, Salsa and Beyond
descrip: Explores the history, aesthetics, and social significance of music in the English and Hispanic Caribbean from the late 18th C to the present day. Genres studied include those in the art, traditional, and popular realms (e.g., music of santeria, contradanza, son, salsa, nueva trova, bomba, bolero, merengue, bachata, ska, reggae, dancehall, dub, calypso and soca) in Cuba, Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, and Trinidad. We consider the social conditions that led to the birth and diffusion of these genres; their musical characteristics; and the interrelationships among the musical styles of the Caribbean.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: A good amount of work, but worthwhile and really interesting!

A lot of people feel that this is an "easy ST" course.  I, however, disagree.  I would recommend this class for anyone who is generally good at math and can pick up concepts quickly.  For students like myself, however, who have more difficulty with math, this course will be challenging but not impossible.  Communication with preceptors is extremely helpful and necessary.
A very easy ST and even enjoyable for people interested in Art and Architecture.
Absolutely take it. Best course at Princeton.
Bridges is easy and interesting. Its a great way to knock out an ST.
Could do an ST in an easier way. But the class is fine if you are marginally interested in the subject matter.

Definitely take this class. It may seem like a strange class to take for both engineers and AB students alike, but it integrates both perspectives very well and is one of the best classes I have taken here at Princeton.
Do all the reading!
Fantastic ST. Lab #5 was the best.

Focus less on very specific details and more on general ideas about evaluating bridges and structural artists. Practice the math and collaborate with classmates to split up making notes and flashcards for the midterm/final.
For an ST, this is the best one.
Go for it! This class is a Princeton tradition.
Go to lecture but you really don't need to do any reading.
Go to lecture.
Good class manageable amount of work
Good enough if you are looking to fulfill an ST.
Great ST option
Great for an easy ST
Great way to take the ST - only 4 lab reports!
I heard this class was a good ST course to fill the requirement.  It seemed like more work than was advertised.
I think if you're looking for an enjoyable ST and you like structures, you should definitely take this class. It's pretty laid back, its enjoyable, and you learn a lot about appreciating structures.
I took the fall bridges as an HA, and the spring as an ST, and I feel like the class in general is so much easier if you take it as an ST.
I would definitely recommend this course, especially to those who need an ST.
I would highly recommend this class to anyone who thinks they might be interested in architecture.

I would highly recommend this for anyone who just needs a science distribution or is at all interested in civil engineering.  The math is probably too easy for science people, but it's perfect for people who want a semi-interesting class to fulfill their requirements.
If you have taken physics and can do some basic memorization, this is an easy A.
If you need an easy lab, take this course.
It depends on what you want, really.  If you're like me and want an engaging course on civil engineering, steer elsewhere.  On the other hand, if you're a meathead who wants an easy grade, go for it.
It is a great lab class to take if you are not necessarily a science person but need to fulfill the lab requirement.
It's a good way to fulfill an ST requirement.  Take it.
Just know that there is a lot of math, so be warned if you aren't a math person at all. IMO lectures were really interesting, contrary to my expectations.
Learn the structural studies!

Make a PowerPoint of the structures as you go along with the course. Be warned, after the course you start looking at bridges differently. You start thinking about the forces at work and the aesthetics!
Not the easiest ST despite what people say
TAKE IT!
Take it
Take it -- it's probably the best ST
Take it for an easy lab.
Take it if you hav to
Take it if you need an ST
Take it if you need an ST! BUT DO THE WORK!!!!!
Take it! At the very least, it will help you gain an appreciation for the large-scale structures around you that you probably take for granted. It might even convince you to become an engineer...
Take it, it's pretty interesting and fun
Take the class, but don't buy all of the books.
Take the course seriously even if you think it won't be hard or else the midterm will shock you as it did to me.
Take this class! It's easy and a lot of fun!
Take this class, it's great!
Take this if you need a lab
Take this, it's a great class!
Taking a course you don't find interesting will feel like hard work no matter how little time you put into it.

This course is a great intro to structural art and is very clear. I would recommend this class to students who aren't necessarily amazing at math, but like working with numbers. It's a great mix of readings and math, which can be a nice way to break up your course load.
This is a great class to take if you are interested in structures, art, or architecture
Very interesting lab, if you take it just go to lab not lecture
a lot of busywork but very good.
don't take it.  harder than it seems for non-science people.  failed on all counts.  avoid.  take geology course instead, if you're looking for interesting, not-math-intense, science courses.
good st
its a great class to fulfill an ST
n/a
take it
take the course it's fun and intersting
take this class!! not because it's easy, because it's actually interesting.
very interesting and engaging course, good for those looking for an ST, lectures are similar to ARC203
whatever do what you go to do man.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through laboratory experiments students study the scientific basis for structural performance and thereby connect external forms to the internal forces in the major works of structural engineers. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Digital Communications and Networks
reviews: A solid introduction to information theory. It's essentially the probability, entropy, compression, and coding parts of ELE 201 in greater depth, and more theoretical. Professor Verdu is excellent, and worth taking a class with. I definitely recommend this class for all ELE majors who work with communications systems.

Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the homework assignments, which do not logically follow from the lecture slides. Exams require memorization of a large number of formulas that are easy to get mixed up. The course also assumes a background in probability. Great introduction to information theory if you are interested in the theory side. Absolutely no coverage of networks, so the course title is somewhat misleading.

If your interest learns in learning the various algorithms used in Digital Communications, this class is NOT for you. This course focuses mainly on proofs, and the lecture does a poor job of preparing you for the problem sets and examinations.
Tough class, make your choice. Doesn't take too much time though.
prereqs: ELE 301 and ORF 309 are prerequisites..
descrip: Historical overview of digital communications. Introductory information theory. Data compression. Error detection and correction code. Baseband transmission systems and optimum reception. Digital modulation and demodulation.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Trans-Atlantic Modernism
descrip: This course avoids the usual split of British modernism from American, modernist poetry from prose, in order to examine strains at once trans-Atlantic and trans-generic. Yet in looking at twelve of these authors, we will come to appreciate the mutual influences among poets and novelists, Brits and Yanks, as literature is reshaped by modernist innovations, among them: the turn from omniscience to marginalized voices; from formal coherence to fragmentary gestures; from predictable strategies to surprising demands upon the reader.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half Term) - The Development Challenge of HIV/AIDS
descrip: This seminar will review the origins of HIV, the multiple impacts of AIDS, the reasons for sustained global neglect, the foundations of effective prevention & treatment programs & the urgent need to improve monitoring & evaluation. Special attention will be given to the role of social factors in the epidemic. Course participants will examine the policy-making process related to global public goods & consider whether the world is better positioned to avert a resurgence of this pandemic or the emergence of the next threat.

title: Americans Abroad in Asia
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Portuguese II
reviews: Definitely
Take it!
Take this course!
prereqs: POR 101.
descrip: A continuation of POR 101. Students will continue to develop skills of oral/aural comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining further exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa. Students who successfully complete POR 102 will place into POR 109.

title: Directed Research
reviews: Be highly self-motivated.
This course is very useful for students who need to perform research work. It helps students to start the project in a logically planned structure.
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Seminar in Political Theory - Law, Politics, and Sexual Morality
descrip: The course will consider some of the key legal, political, and philosophical issues at the heart of contemporary debates about marriage, sexuality, and public morality.

title: Technology and Society
reviews: A good course for a lot of people.
Attend lectures. Make sure you understand the overall themes of the course so that you can apply it for the two projects in this course.
Come to precept prepared to actively discuss the topics from lectures.

Definitely consider taking this class! It does not have an overwhelming amount of work but is very relevant to many things in the modern world. I learned and retained more from this class than from others.

Definitely take this course if you want to be even slightly literate in the history of technology.  What you learn in this course will help to inform the decisions you are going to have to make in a world that is only becoming more and more integrated with technology, so taking this course is a great way to know what's going on.  Also not too much work, and very interesting.
Do all the reading and go to all the lectures
Great class. Learned a lot.
Great course
History majors should like this course for a change of pace - exams and projects instead of papers.
I would definitely recommend this course, especially if someone is an engineer interested in social implications.
I would highly recommend this course. Beware of the extensive time commitment required for the final website project if you don't have COS/programming background. Otherwise, a great course.
I would recommend students to take this course if they are more interested in the humanities than the sciences.

I would remind them that this is a class focused on covering a wide RANGE of issue rather than tackling any one issue in too much depth. So, in preparing for exams and making projects, they should focus on breadth of information rather than depth, although a balance between the two is ideal.

If you're interested by the interactions between science, politics, economics and society, if you feel that it could be interesting to learn more about these topics before to try to change the world or the society, if you don't want to be the "useful idiot" of capitalism, then this course is for you. Interesting, well-balanced, good precepts and fun projects to do (1 podcast and 1 website). Enjoy!
Interesting course
Strongly recommend for a PDF distribution requirement.  It's a fun and interesting class, but I'd definitely not want to put too much time into the work for it.
Take it if you are interested in the material. Good lectures, not a lot of work.

Take it! If you don't mind some history of various technologies (which I enjoyed a lot - the professor is like an encyclopedia of details!), you'll find yourself learning about a lot of new things, which are incredibly relevant to society today, and hence important. The exams are fair, and the projects are fun if you make them out to be that way! Great class, great professor. If technology is your thing, and you want to develop some other perspectives on it, take this class.
Take it, especially if you have a friend taking it with you so you can be partners for the midterm and final projects.
Take it- it's a great blend of modern, relevant topics.
Take it.

Take it. Not too hard, and you really learn a lot about technological innovations of the 21st century and the way they affect our society. The projects are not too hard, as long as you split the content according to the general themes of the course. If there's one thing to take from this class, it's that there's no clear solution to any problem that's presented. Make sure you make that clear in all projects and exams.
Take this class!

Take this class!

Reasonable workload and very engaging lectures especially with those from a science background

Take this class, especially because with touches of engineering, sociology, and history, it has something for everyone, and is well balanced between those interests, and not impossible to get through if you're not very good at one of those three components.

Take this course!  No papers, the projects are fun (a midterm podcast and a final website), the exams aren't too bad (and seniors don't have to take the midterm), the reading is pretty light, and most of all the material is SOOOO interesting. I approached this as an engineer, but I believe that the humanists and social scientists got just as much out of the class because it really explores the boundaries of the disciplines.  It takes engineering as a topic for historical and social study, and the results are great!  I learned a ton in this course and enjoyed it at the same time.
Our readings included the original Moore's Law paper, as well as a combination of technical and scholarly analysis of the concepts and case studies we used. Expect there to be at least one thing directly from current events that will come up in the course (for us it was normal accidents and the nuclear problems in Japan).  This is a great fifth class, but also a great class in general.  Lectures are amazing, precepts are good, and the material is pretty awesome. Take it!
This is a laid-back course that provides a good way to take care of a distribution requirement while still providing an opportunity to learn interesting and potentially useful information.
This is a very interesting class, with not too much work! The professor is an amazing lecturer!

This is certainly a good class for anyone who wants to learn about the problems that are inherent in technology, and how society interacts with technology and tries to overcome these problems.  The grading of the class can be arbitrary, which is dangerous in a class based on roughly 16 test questions and 2 media presentations.  However, if it is PDF'd, it would be a great course where you could learn alot.
Worth taking, even if you're not doing the certificate.

Would highly recommend this course. Subject matter is interesting and comprehensive; Class requires commitment to create the podcast/website, and a lot of material is covered in the exams, but other than that it does not take too much weekly time.
You cannot graduate from Princeton without taking a class with Prof. Gordin.
gordin is a great lecturer.  I didn't do anything else so that was fine.
descrip: Technology and society are unthinkable without each other - each provides the means and framework in which the other develops. To explore this dynamic, this course investigates a wide array of questions on the interaction between technology, society, politics, and economics, emphasizing the themes of innovation and maturation, systems and regulation, risk and failure, and ethics and expertise. Specific topics covered include nuclear power and waste, genetically-modified organisms, regulation of the internet, medical mistakes, intellectual property, the financial crisis of 2008, and the post-fossil-fuels economy.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Basic)
descrip: Introduction to the processes of economic growth and development. The course examines various theories of development; poverty and inequality measurement; and the role of markets for credit, labor and land, as well as education and health, in development. The role of public policy will be considered within each of these topics. The course may also cover topics such as foreign aid, commodity pricing, and tax policy. (Prerequisites: 511b; 512b can be taken concurrently.)

title: Independent Work with Design
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principle difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principles of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
descrip: A weekly seminar focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Russian II
reviews: Any course with Stas is worth taking, he is the best professor I have had at Princeton. He is great at explaining the material plus he's hilarious, great guy.
I recommend this class for those who want to improve their Russian!

Take Russian with Stas - one of the best professors you could have at Princeton. Incredibly dedicated, caring and understanding, and a fantastic language teacher, no questions asked. If you're considering whether or not to continue with Russian - this course is significantly more work than first year courses but if you put in the effort, you'll feel yourself making strides. Furthermore, the course is structured around a movie rather than simply grammar material in the textbook, and so lessons are consistently engaging. Take it!
if u like exotic languages and are good at them and are willing to devote a lot of time to the material, go for it.
prereqs: RUS105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continued presentation and review of grammar. Vocabulary thematically organized to include such topics as travel, city life, nature, hobbies, politics, etc. Training of all language skills in a cultural context. Vocabulary reinforced through reading of cultural texts.

title: History of Medicine and the Body
reviews: Again, HIS 395 is the best class I've taken at Princeton. Even if you aren't interested in history or in medicine, you will learn so much. Going to lecture was exciting and fun. Take this class if you can!

Be prepared to do a good amount of reading, though it's not essential to doing a good job in the course. Professor Guenther's lectures are interesting and stimulating. In particular, she debunks the idea that medicine was constantly moving forward and becoming more scientific without other factors such as culture influencing its progress. So DON'T fall into that trap like I did on the midterm. So don't stress about all the readings, but pay attention to the lectures and their themes.
Be ready to learn a lot about medicine and the body! This class is enjoyable, accessible, and interesting, so do the readings and be ready to participate in discussion.
Great HA, especially if you're interested in medicine.
Great HA. Take it if you're a premed. You'll learn a great deal about medicine and how it's far less scientific than we might think.
Have fun with the final project (an iMovie, podcast, or normal essay). Lectures were probably more important than the readings.
I would definitely recommend this course if you are at all interested. It's thought-provoking without being overwhelming. The material is fantastic and all ties together beautifully in the end.
If you need an HA distribution but you're worried you're not much of a history major, take this class. It's great
It's a great class and the last assignment is fun. What more could you ask for?
It's a great introduction to important history of medicine topics and will make you think about the ways historians think about medicine. It's a reasonable amount of work, too.
Take if you want a good understanding of how medicine got to where it is today. On exams, write fast and incorporate lots of detail. Do an iMovie if you can; it's a lot of fun.
Take it!
Take it, but only if you are seriously interested--it's a lot of reading!
Take this class and make sure you go to lectures an precepts, not because you need them to do well but because they are really interesting
The readings are important.

This course will teach you a surprising amount about who you are as a person. The lectures on ancient medicine are a little dull, but as soon as you get to colonial medicine it's super interesting. You can afford to skip 1-3 lectures, but not more after that.
This is definitely a pretty painless HA if that is all you are looking for, and the material is interesting without being too difficult to grasp.
Well taught history course
take it and work hard. and hippies are overrated
take this course but expect a lot of reading
descrip: This course covers key concepts and developments in the history of medicine from Ancient times to the present. We will explore ideas of health and disease in Antiquity, the rise of anatomy and dissection in the Renaissance, the fight against germs in the nineteenth century, and modern practices of health, life and death. Particular attention is paid to the ways in which changing medical views and practices were sustained by contemporary experience of the body. What did it mean to fall ill and get better? How did people understand their relationship to the environment? How could one prevent sickness by living a healthy life?

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. B.S.E. candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Topics in American Literature - American Jewish Writers
reviews: Great class, especially if you don't know much about Jewish American literature.
I enjoyed this course, and would definitely recommend to anyone interested in Judaic studies.
I really enjoyed this course.
I would definitely recommend other students take this course!
descrip: How did American Jewish writers manage to leave a mark both on American letters and on traditions of Jewish literature? And when were they "too Jewish" for American readers and "too American" for their fellow Jews? We'll address these questions while considering the historic sweep of American Jewish writing from the 18th to the 21st centuries. Texts include mostly fiction but also poems, essays, graphic novels and films. We will consider immigration and assimilation; bilingualism; city Jews; the holocaust from afar; women breaking and revising traditions; secularity and religious observance; and the role of Jews in multicultural America.

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: A decent course overall, sometimes interesting and often quite dry. If you are taking it, you probably have no choice. It is possible to get a good grade if you devote a lot of time and effort to the course. Start problem sets early because they tend to take a long time so you do not have to stress yourself out completely the night before trying to finish the whole thing. Go to Bill's office hours as often as possible. In lecture, it seemed as if most of the class this year eventually just gave up on following Thanos in lecture. Do not make the same mistake; be willing to stop him whenever he is going too fast through the material. The rest of the class will thank you for it.

Almost everyone who would consider taking this class is a CBE major, and you have to take it. For everyone else, this is a difficult but rewarding course, but only for people who are already interested in the topic
Be prepared to spend a lot of time working on the problem sets.
Cannot be avoided if you are in the department, and probably would not be taken by those outside the department. Still a great course.
DO NOT EVER TAKE IT WITH THANOS
DO THE READING AHEAD OF TIME so that you know what is going on in lecture, and start the problem sets VERY early.  Office hours are very useful, go to them.
Do not try to study alone, and absolutely go to office hours. Thermo is not intuitive, but learning in a group environment is very helpful to understanding the course material.
Don't be a Chemical Engineer.
Don't fall behind.
Don't take this class unless (1) it is a departmental requirement or (2) you feel like enduring 5 months of misery.
Go to office hours, always.
Great teacher, enthusiastic. Thermo is conceptually challenging, however.
HARD CLASS, go to office hours, esp the prof's if you can make it.
I absolutely loved this course.

If you are going to be a chem-e, thermo is a requirement...so don't be discouraged if you find thermo extremely difficult. True, the material is diffcult, but with a good amount of effort, it is doable.
If you're going to be ChemE, take it. If not, don't. Simple enough.
It was hard and you can't get around that. But I think for the material it covers in the time it does it is a good class.
It's a departmental requirement. I don;t know anyone taking it who didn;t need it.

It's hard but chemical engineering majors have to take it. If you are not but is genuinely interested, I have a friend who's not chem eng major that dropped by for a few lectures. Audit is a much better choice than taking the class.
It's not as bad as people make it out to be, but you have to be prepared to put in the effort.

Most people complain about this course, but I enjoyed it. Thanos is a nice guy overall and bubbly lecturer, but a little intimidating to approach for help. I survived by going to office hours (Bill Holloway is the best preceptor I have ever had) and working on problem sets well in advance with a set study group. Don't wait until 1 or 2 days before to start the work or you may not survive. I liked having the two quizzes instead of a midterm.
Start the problem sets early.
Study well for the quizzes and finals!
Study your ass off
This class can be challenging, but Professor P is a great professor from whom to be learning thermodynamics. So far out of my CBE classes, it has been the most interesting and enjoyable class.
This course is very difficult and quite frustrating at times. Reading the book and going to lecture is almost the same thing. If you don't have a good TA, then it'll be a long semester.
This is a requirement.
Tough but not unmanageable.

Tough, be prepared to spend a lot of time on problems sets. Get friends to work on problem sets with. GO TO OFFICE HOURS, everyone is extremely approachable. Tough but you'll come out of it feeling like you've really learned.
Well if you're taking this class, you kind of have to.  Read everything and do problems several times over.
prereqs: CHE 245/ CBE 245 and MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course focuses on basic principles governing the equilibrium behavior of macroscopic systems and their applications to materials and processes of interest in modern chemical engineering. In the first half of the course we introduce the fundamental concepts: energy conservation (First Law); temperature and entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials; equilibrium and stability; and the molecular basis of thermodynamics. These ideas are then applied to problems such as calculating the equilibrium composition of coexisting phases and reacting mixtures or analyzing the thermodynamic efficiency of cooling and power generation cycles.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Amazing course for anyone with the slightest inclination toward reading contemporary poetry and pushing their boundaries of writing a little. Class discussions of poetry books and workshops are great. Workload is not too heavy, consistent, and enjoyable. Take it!
Depends a lot on your professor, but most are really excellent and run a great workshop.
I would definitely recommend this course.

If you love poetry and have been writing for a while, this class will renew your experience of it, in ways that will give you a chance to grow as a writer. If you do not already love poetry, this class will make you adore it. Easily, the best class I have taken at Princeton thus far. Easily.
If you love poetry and want to start thinking about longer forms, take it!
Put time and insight into your poetry. This is a fun class, and its really what you put into it that allows you to get a lot out of it.
Susan is a great teacher and really responsive editor.
TAKE IT!!!
Take a creative writing course with Michael Dickman before you graduate!  It's a must-take.
Take it! Start working on ur writing early in the week, and space out the reading too so it isn't daunting the night before.
Take this course.  You surely will not regret it.
Take time and care to write poetry. Be honest but kind in your feedback. Enjoy your work and that of others.
see above
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two-200 level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Contemporary Dance: Advanced Technique and Choreography
reviews: Enjoy it!
If you love dancing, take this class!
Take it if you are interested
Take this course if you're interested in any kind of dance.

The studios are great. I can't say my choreographic ability improved very much from the beginning to the end with the choreography stuff (or even my understanding of how to choreograph), but my technique has gotten infinitely better.
Try to remember your choreography, because you will come back to it.  It's a great course.
prereqs: DAN 409 is designed for students with minimum of two or preferably three dance program courses from the following: DAN 309 and/or DAN 319 and/or DAN 419 and/or DAN 420, or the equivalent outside experience.
descrip: Advanced dance technique and choreography, with a focus on contemporary practices. In technique, students will be challenged to expand their movement range and increase their mastery of various styles in ways required by today's dance world. Students will examine concepts such as skeletal support, sequential movement, and momentum to emphasize ease and efficiency in motion. In choreography, students will work together on group objectives in movement-based laboratories focusing on collaboration and choreographic choice-making skills.

title: Beginning Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian II
prereqs: BCS 101.
descrip: A continuation of BCS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), concentrating on conversational practice, advanced grammar points, oral drilling, increased reading (BCS literature, folklore, and expository prose, including works chosen according to students' interests), and viewing films.

title: Playwriting II: Intermediate Playwriting
prereqs: THR 205 and Program Director's permission (interview is not required). Please visit the Theater Program website for application information..
descrip: A workshop devoted to ways of writing plays with the goal of producting the draft of a full length play by the end of the semester.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: Be prepared to work! You can't skim by in this class. You need to come with an open mind and know you are not perfect. The grading is not based off of your ability but rather on how you've grown and learned as an artist.
Definitely a course worth taking.  Martha is amazing, and the course is so much fun and at times relaxed.  But to do well, it does take time and going in for extra studio hours during the week.

Don't be shy during critiques. Even if you think what you have to say is stupid in comparison to all the profound things spewing out of other students' mouths, still say something. Your opinion matters.
Most fun I've ever had in a Princeton class
Start on the projects early! You don't want to be stuck in the studio the night before the due date.

TAKE IT. Don't miss this opportunity, especially if it's taught by Martha Friedman. It's going to be time consuming, especially if you get really into it (not that I can imagine there'll be someone who won't), but it's worth every second. Just make sure you take risks and push yourself so you make the most of it. It flies by before you know it.

Take it if you're ready to put a lot of work into this course.  I think being able to say "I built that" in the end is totally worth it, and the feeling of going to studio and getting away from studying is amazing.  But if you have no creativity, you may need to prepare to struggle.
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, concept, fabrication and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on sculpture and its consequences. Students will develop an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic facilities in woodworking, metalworking, carving and casting.

title: Form Finding of Structural Surfaces
reviews: For architecture students thinking of taking the class: extremely difficult to weave the rhythm of this class with the M.Arch work method and schedule. Nonetheless, the material covered in class is very interesting.

I would highly recommend this course. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the assignments, as each is like a mini project and several extend for quite some time. However, Prof. Adriaenssens knows her stuff, is passionate about her research, and really tries to get students working on a variety of different types of projects.
I would recommend this course.  You won't get exposure to the types of structures discussed in this class in other classes.  It is a very interesting course that I think will get better with time.
This course is very useful for (engineering) students who need to be familiar with the subject. It covered important topics in the subject.
prereqs: Open to all seniors even if not in CEE- Must get approval from Professor Adriaenssens. Open to all Architecture graduate students - Must get approval from Professor Adriaenssens..
descrip: The course looks at the most inventive structures and technologies, demonstrating their use of form finding techniques in creating complex curved surfaces. The first part introduces the topic of structural surfaces, tracing the ancient relationship between innovative design and construction technology and the evolution of surface structures. The second part familiarizes the student with membranes(systems, form finding techniques,materials and construction techniques) The third part focuses on rigid surfaces. The fourth part provides a deeper understanding of numerical form finding techniques.

title: Linguistics and Language Acquisition
reviews: Be prepared to learn lots of lingo!

I loved this course, but two of my friends who took it did not.  It all depends on how much you actually like language I believe.  If you find the idea of how people communicate something you're interested in, this class is fantastic, the work is just the right amount and the tests are an appropriate difficulty level (the midterm was relatively easy, and the final a little harder but not stressfully so)
I'd recommend taking the course - language acquisition is interesting and the results are not always what you would expect, as the quiz on the first day makes very clear.
If you're at all interested (or even if you aren't), it's a really interesting topic and Prof Goldberg explains everything in interesting ways.
Its a great course if you are interested in linguistics but have no background in it. It is not very time consuming and interesting.
Take it!  The course is wonderful!
Take this course. It is extremely interesting and you will learn a lot about language acquisition in children.

This class is great for people interested in psychology and language development. Professor Goldberg is incredibly kind and patient and really cares about the subject matter. If you put in the effort, you will do well in the class!

This is a solid course that will give you a firm grounding, based in experimental findings, in (first-)language acquisition. I would recommend it particularly strongly to students who have so far only been exposed to generative (or "Chomskyan") linguistics, since the most valuable aspect of the course for me was that it presented serious challenges to this "innatist" or "nativist" theory of language, in both the lectures and the readings, and I think far too many generatively trained linguists are unaware of the arguments on the other side of the debate.
Whether or not you've had experience with linguistics or psychology, you'll get a LOT out of this course. It's a great class size, too, so lots of personal attention. TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
descrip: We investigate the development of language from infancy to adulthood. The class examines naturalistic and experimental data concerning the acquisition of phonology, syntax semantics in light of current debates in linguistics and psycholinguistics.

title: The Medieval Period
reviews: Not as scary as it sounds. Enthusiastic professor.
Professor Cole is really interesting and engaging. If you're an English major who's shying away from the medieval period, don't! (Especially if you study it with Professor Cole!)
descrip: In this course we will study in detail several of the major authors from late medieval England, paying special attention to the practice of imitation, whereby one English author mimics another. The readings will be in Middle English but no previous experience is required. While this course is all about primary texts, secondary readings on the course topic will be made available from time to time.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Ask lots of questions and practice outside of class, otherwise it is difficult to improve.
Have an interest in Spanish language and culture.

Hopefully, you get a small class and a great teacher like Jorge who encourages everyone to speak in a casual environment. Study the book for the verbs with prepositions after them. Your writing will improve drastically if you want it to.
I highly recommend this course.  It is very stimulating and offers a very inviting classroom environment.
I recommend everyone take this course who's interested in Spanish

I thought I was interested in Spanish language and literature - unfortunately, I realized halfway through the semester that I wasn't nearly as committed as I thought I would be. Most of the difficulty in the course had to do with grammar, which I just didn't have the patience to handle. Only take it if you are sure your interest in the Spanish language will overcome the tedium of endless proofreading, and that you will be likely to take more Spanish classes in the future.

I would tell them to take it. Perhaps not at 9 AM like I did, but definitely to take it. In particular if they could take it with Prof. Mendez Seijas or Prof. Bruzos Moro, then I would think them to be crazy if they chose not to.
If any student is interested in languages and wants to continue improving their skills, they should take this course.
If you are motivated to improve your Spanish in a great atmosphere (but still work hard) then this is the course for you.
If you want to refresh or relearn spanish, take it!
Jorge is a wonderful professor! The homework is not mandatory on the due date, but should be done before the test.
Make sure you don't miss classes!  Similarly, try to keep up to date on all assignments; they pile up if procrastinated.  Reserve time to edit all written work.
Not an interesting class but necessary to proceed to what I hope are interesting classes.
Practice vocabulary often and do not slack in the beginning.
Study hard and engage in class.
TAKE IT
Take it with Alberto if he still teaches this course. But be prepared for the work.
Take it! Your speaking, reading, and writing skills will improve and you'll have fun along the way!
Take this class!
Take this course so that you can take 300-level Spanish courses in subsequent semesters, or even just to get more out of the Spanish language for everyday use with friends or while abroad, etc.

Take time to do the work! Alberto is a very good teacher who puts a lot of effort in to making things easier for his students. Please take advantage of this! Don't simply do the minimum and I guarantee your Spanish will improve in some sense.
There is a lot of grammar involved, but also a good mix of fun readings and assignments.
This is a great course, with great professors.  The grammar can get a little tedious, but you will improve your language skills.
You will love this course! If possible, take it with Jorge.
prereqs: SPA 107 or 108 or permission of instructor. Also open to students that placed out of the Spanish language requirement..
descrip: An advanced course in Spanish composition and conversation. Its main purpose is to increase the student's fluency and accuracy in spoken and written Spanish. Importance is also given to understanding elements of Hispanic literature and culture through literary texts, Hispanic periodicals, and films. (Please see note under "Other Information.")

title: Philosophy of Science
reviews: Any knowledge of science is a big plus for this class.  I took the class with no knowledge of science and felt at a huge disadvantage for the entire class.

I would definitely recommend it! If you're unsure, I would say go to the first lecture, talk to him at office hours if you can, and see what you think. I don't know if it's possible to PDF but that might be a good option.
If you are interested in philosophy, science, or the philosophy of science, I would highly recommend taking this course.
It's a great course if you enjoy epistemology and/or scientific methodology and ontology. A lot of fun. If you don't, you'll probably hate it.
Prof. Cloud knows what he's talking about but sometimes has a tendency to ramble. Much of the value of the course comes from the readings.

Professor Cloud is clearly a really smart guy, and his views are very interesting, but they're really weird and non-standard for analytic philosophy. Sometimes it's nice to have class that gives a straightforward discussion of the material instead of giving a discussion of the professor's own bizarre take on everything, so if you're looking for a standard analytic philosophy class this probably isn't the best.

The course is of interest to non-philosophers and should be required for philosophy majors (and it is, as part of the philosophy of science and logic requirement). Dan Cloud has done an outstanding job, exceeding my expectations on material covered, chose fantastic readings, and ran class discourse above and beyond expectations.
This is a very enlightening course and take it if you think you are serious about sciences.
descrip: What is science? What do scientists know, if anything? Are scientific theories supposed to be true? If not, why are they so useful? Many of these questions come up most acutely in sciences other than physics, so we will also discuss examples taken from biology and economics. Is there one scientific method, or many? How do the 'soft' sciences differ from the 'hard' ones, if they do? Points of view that have been influential among scientists - Weber, Popper, Kuhn - will be dealt with alongside more purely philosophical material from authors such as Goodman, Lewis, and Albert.

title: The Hedgehog and the Fox
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Image of the Jew in Russian Visual Culture and Literature
descrip: This course will focus on Russian Jewish visual and literary culture from the end of the 19th c. through the 20th. We will examine the ways in which it represented Jewish identity; reflected changing notions of selfhood and nationhood; and refracted anti-Semitic predispositions. Most of the course will unpack the impact of the Russian revolution and the transformatoin of a traditional, pious, and provincial Jewish ecosystem into an urban-dwelling, Russian-speaking secular society.

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: good
descrip: This course is an advanced pro-seminar that will examine the spatial histories and representational forms of the modern city. Students will read architectural, urban and theoretical texts and conduct individual research on how spatial theory affects the manner in which cities and architectural forms have been written about, envisioned and built.

title: Main Currents of Spanish Thought, 1848 to the Present - History and Memory in Contemporary Spanish Culture
descrip: The course will explore how the Spanish II Republic and the Civil War have been narrated, remembered and revised in historiography, prose fiction, poetry, film, journalism and other cultural venues throughout the decades and the generations. Special attention will be paid to the history of memory and to the "memorization" of history; to the politics of memory, but also to aspects of memory that challenge conventional political assumptions about history and memory.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
