descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research finding are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars.

title: Experimental Physics
reviews: Don't take it unless you absolutely have to. Even if you enjoy experimental physics, this isn't worth it.
Don't take this unless you have to.  It can be interesting once you take it, but it's more like making the best of a bad situation.
I hope they change the class to PDF only for the following generations of physics students.
If you're a physics major you have to take it. At least try to learn something about data and signal processing because physics majors don't usually touch that stuff.
If you're a physics major, you have to take it. If you're not, you wouldn't be taking it anyway.
Meet with the TA/Professor before starting. Don't be afraid to ask for help. Read lab manuals from many schools.
Take it if you need to, and start lab reports early.
This class made me want to be an experimental physicist.  However, be prepared to spend a LOT of time working on lab reports.
hard to imagine how to make an undergraduate lab class better
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent; PHY 208 or equivalent. Not recommended for sophomores..
descrip: Students work in small groups and perform four experiments and an electronics lab. The list of experiments to choose from includes muon decay, beta decay, optical pumping, Mossbauer effect, holography, positron annihilation, electron diffraction, single photon interference, Sagnac effect, bacterial motion, NMR, Coulomb's law, and the photoelectric effect. Weekly lectures will provide an overview of various experimental techniques and data analysis.

title: Computer Architecture
reviews: If possible, start the projects before you're born.
Take it!

This class helps you prepare for technical presentations without "teaching" it to you.  I can't speak for ELE, but since it is the only course of its kind in the COS department, I think it is essential for COS majors if you intend on being involved in scalable software and computer hardware projects in the future.  The only class that analysis parallelism with such rigor.
prereqs: Permission of Instructor or ELE 375 or (COS 471 or its equivalent). Seniors and graduate students may waive prerequisites with instructor's permission..
descrip: Modern computer processor, platform and infrastructure architectures. Instruction-set architecture and high-performance processor organization including pipelining, data and instruction parallelism. Cache, memory and storage architectures. Coherent multiprocessors. Interconnection and network infrastructures.

title: Major Russian Poets and Poetic Movements - Tsvetaeva and Akhmatova
descrip: The seminar is devoted to major writings of Marina Tsvetaeva and Anna Akhmatova. Close readings of their poetry and prose will serve as points of departure to discuss Russian modernism and issues relating to emigration, art and totalitarianism, gender, and the negotiation of novelty and tradition. The act of reading and how it both shapes and is shaped by the texts and their authors will be considered throughout the semester.

title: American Literary Traditions - The Rise of the Popular, 1790-1900
descrip: This seminar will examine American popular writing from the late eighteenth century through 1900. We will read representative examples from a variety of genres, including fiction, gift books, stage melodrama, dime novels, children's literature, self-help books, and religious tracts. We will also track important developments in U.S. publishing and the history of the book, and we will be particularly interested in the claims that various popular literary modes (gothic, sentiment, reform, seduction, adventure) make on readers and authors alike.

title: The Computational Universe
prereqs: This course is geared towards non-Computer Science concentrators, including social science and humanities majors. Students who have already taken COS 126 or any higher course in the Computer Sciences should not take this course. Limited enrollment; wait list will be maintained..
descrip: Computers have brought the world to our fingertips. We will try to understand at a basic level the science--old and new--underlying this new Computational Universe. Our quest takes us on a broad sweep of scientific knowledge and related technologies: propositional logic of the ancient Greeks (microprocessors); quantum mechanics (silicon chips); network and system phenomena (internet and search engines); computational intractability (secure encryption); and efficient algorithms (genomic sequencing). Ultimately, this study makes us look anew at ourselves--our genome; language; music; "knowledge"; and, above all, the mystery of our intelligence.

title: Medicine and Belief
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to the Evolution of Jazz Styles
reviews: Don't cram the listening assignments
Good class with a modest amount of work. Background knowledge helps. I realized I didn't have nearly as much as others in the class.
I recommend this class if you have not had a lot of experience with music, you will be able to follow it and learn a lot if you do the readings and listening assignments.
I think there are probably better ways to become acquainted with jazz.
I would tell them that is a really interesting class, and the listening assignments are really cool, especially at the beginning of the semester.
I'm not sure this class will be offered again, since Dr. LP was a visiting professor, but if you're ready for a musical jazz immersion and can handle the work, take it.
If you are interested in jazz but don't know much about its history, you will probably enjoy this course.
If you like jazz or just want to learn about if from scratch, this course will help. It's not always the most exciting, but it is informative and a decent amount of work.

PDF it unless you're a music major focusing in jazz, you're taking no other classes, or you know music really well. Worth taking if you're interested in jazz; not so much if you want an (easy) AAS class.

Pretty much everything about the course was not particularly remarkable either way.  Lectures weren't particularly great but they definitely weren't bad.  Easy PDF but seems like it's hard to get an A.

Take it if you're interested in jazz and don't know too much about how it evolved into what it is today. Do the listening, and most of the reading. Go to the lectures, they're really engaging. You'll need your notes from the lectures too, so make sure you take good notes.
Take it!  It doesn't matter if you know anything about jazz or music for that matter. It's just totally interesting.
Take it!!!

Take this class if you are interested in how jazz has grown to where it is today.  The readings are pretty helpful. Participate in precept, but not to the point where you are overbearing. Enjoy the music and learn from it.
This class is really amazing if you like jazz. You don't have to be able to play music, only appreciate it.
Would absolutely not recommend to other students, unless Prof. Pellegrinelli has some sort of epiphany as a lecturer or a different professor is teaching it.
descrip: This course seeks to stimulate an informed appreciation of American jazz within broad historical, social, and musical frames. Focusing on the time period from its so-called "birth" in New Orleans around 1900 to Ornette Coleman's infamous break with tonality heralded by the album Free Jazz in 1960, we will trace the evolution of jazz style and its cultural context.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew II
reviews: I really enjoyed this class but it took a lot of my time. It is 3 times a week and for each class we had assignments which took me 3-4 hours each so I spent around 10 hours a week for it. Other than that, it was an excellent class and I highly recommend it.
If you are interested in learning Biblical Hebrew, take this course.
If you finished the first course, definitely go on!

Professor Meshel is a brilliant scholar with unparalleled knowledge of ancient languages in general and biblical hebrew in particular. He is really good at explaining and did a wonderful job teaching the class.
prereqs: JDS 302 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament in its original language. During the semester, students will continue studying grammar and developing vocabulary. Upon completing the grammar textbook, students will read large passages from the Bible from all genres.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Institutions
reviews: A good class to take if you are interested in understand general finance better.
A great follow-up to 362. Basically how to apply concepts you learned in 362 outside of finance companies and your own private investment portfolio.
Absolutely necessary if you plan on going into finance. Don't even think about not taking this class. Yuliy is the best.
Easy material, so don't make mistakes on the exams!  Yuliy is really dedicated to teaching this stuff and making it relevant for us in the future.
Even if you are not getting a finance certificate, this course is worth taking.
Go to lecture and office hours if you are confused. The textbook is a good resource and the most important thing to know is not the formulas but the general concepts behind everything.
Go to lectures. It's not that hard of a class.
I would highly recommend this course for any students interested in business and finance.
I would recommend this course if you have any interest in mathematical economics.  It helped me learn about how economic concepts are applied in the "real world."

I would strongly recommend reading the book as a supplement to Yuliy's lectures, since sometimes they get a little dry/boring and it's hard to pay attention.  This class isn't really very hard from a conceptual point of view, but there's a lot of tools in there, so the curve isn't very forgiving (average for our midterm was 88/110).  Do your best to keep up with the material.  A lot of people stopped going to lecture, but I don't suggest this, since Yuliy walks you through some of the Excel parts that you'll have to do in the homework (sometimes it's literally the exact same question as in the problem set), so it's really in your best interest to go.  The class definitely got better as the semester went on, and hopefully by the next time he teaches it, it'll be as good as it was for us during the second half.
If you are going for the finance certificate, you have to take it, but it is pretty good.
If you have any interest in Finance, take this course!
If you have to take it, it won't be terrible, but I wouldn't have taken the class if it wasn't a requirement.
If you're interested in finance, a must to learn the basics of bonds, equity, and options.
It's a corporate finance class - very straightforward.
It's a great course if you are interested in corporate finance. I loved this course. I liked Prof. Sannikov and my preceptor. I have a feeling the other preceptors were good too.
Know the material and don't save the problem sets for the day before.

Mostly a repeat of content in ECO 362. Well-structured class but some of the psets can be extremely tedious and time-consuming (btw there are groupwork and random googling for figures involved). Don't take it unless you're in the finance cert program or you really want to be in IBD
Sannikov is awesome.  Take this class if you have any interest in corporate finance!
TAKE IT. Do not miss
Take if you want to go into banking. But, it's kind of a repeat of 362
Take it only to complete the finance cert reqs or if you want to do IBD after college.
Take this class, it's well worth it. You'll learn a lot about corporate finance.
Take this course. It is low-stress and easy. Also, it teaches very useful basic knowledge that everyone should have.

The course is good - it will teach you cool stuff. However, Professor Sannikov's lecture style may - may - get boring for a while, so you'll have to figure out yourself whether his style suits you well.

Not that hard to do well in if you study a few hours a week. Also, beware of the assignments - if even next time he has the experimental sort of assignments - they are fun but some can take a lot of time.

Overall though, take it only if you need to. If you just wanna get a taste of corporate finance, sit in on the first for weeks or audit it or something.

This is a good course if you are willing to teach yourself a lot of the concepts from reading the slides and textbook, and going to precepts. The course content is very useful if you are thinking of going into finance.
This is a great course that anyone who wants to enter the financial world should take.
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 362.
descrip: This course investigates the financing decisions of companies and financial institutions in the wider context of the workings of financial markets. Topics include capital budgeting, capital structure choice, risk management, liquidity, corporate governance, and the interactions between corporate finance and the workings of financial institutions and markets.

title: Elementary Persian II
reviews: Amineh is great. You will love her. Not a difficult class.
Any student who took PER 101 will already know how amazing Prof. Mahallati is and how enjoyable the class is and if he or she needs any additional convincing, he or she could only be insane.
Take this if you're interested in taking a nonwestern language or learning about Iranian culture.
prereqs: PER 101 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop the skills of understanding, speaking, reading and writing modern Persian. The classes are conducted mostly in Persian with emphasis on oral drills and conversations.

title: European Union
prereqs: Previous work in European politics, international relations, comparative politics and/or modern history is expected..
descrip: The European Union is an extraordinary political experiment. It has grown to a supranational polity composed of 27 member states governed by an ever-growing set of political institutions, and sharing common economic and social policies, a common foreign and security policy, and (for some members) an agreement abolishing border controls and a common currency. The course reviews the history of European integration in the post-war era, the EU's core institutions, the substance of major EU policies, and the key challenges facing the EU in the coming years. It also examines regional integration and cooperation in East Asia and other regions.

title: Humanistic Perspectives on the Arts - The Art of Deception: Aesthetics at the Perimeter of Truth
descrip: This course takes up the problem of truth and falsehood in the arts in a sustained way: we will sift the genealogy of current theoretical positions on this issue by means of close reading of classical and recent texts; we will investigate works of art (painting, sculpture, poetry, etc.) that engage these matters, with particular attention to contemporary gaming at the margins of the seemingly stable categories; we will weigh the political and critical implications of different postures in this large arena; we will experiment with new perspectives and practices.

title: Death and the Afterlife in Buddhist Cultures
descrip: In this seminar we will study Buddhist approaches to death, dying, and the afterlife in a variety of Buddhist cultures. Topics may include theories of ritual and anthropological studies of mortuary rites; Buddhist cosmology and the doctrine of karmic causality; Buddhism, the family, and rites for ancestors; Buddhist funerary and mortuary practices; tales of exemplary deaths; accounts of journeys to the hells and other postmortem realms; the placation of ghosts and revenants; and changes in contemporary Buddhist funerals. Continued in "Other Information."

title: Elliptic and Parabolic Partial Differential Equations
descrip: PDEs in Conformal Geometry: a contination from Fall 2010.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
prereqs: REL 521.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows.

title: Introduction to Architectural Design
reviews: A great course to show you what its really like to be a designing architect.
Come with positive attitude, and it'll be a great experience!

DO NOT take if you are not an ARC major.
If you ARE, then it's a fun course.
Excellent course, but very time consuming towards the end. The projects are very manageable as long as you do not wait until the last minute.

I would strongly recommend the course to those considering architecture. It's key to understanding the format of the studio and the factor that helps people to decide whether or not they're willing to put in the time required for the major. On the other hand, it is incredibly time consuming so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone wanting to take the class out of curiosity.
If you are interested in architecture take this course; however be aware that you have to complete a number of preliminary exercises before getting to the really interesting stuff.

If you are looking for a more hands-on LA and are willing to put in the time, definitely take the course. Even if you know you will not concentrate in architecture, this course will give you another way of looking at things that could be applied across many disciplines. If you are possibly interested in architecture and want to get a better feel for the field, definitely take the course. If you know you want to concentrate in archicture, well, then, you have to take it.
Loved the class.

Make sure you budget your time out effectively, don't go crazy on the first few assignments because they're nothing compared to the last couple, and beware of the cost of the course...the materials (mayline, drawing instruments) and close to $200) and the final project can get pretty expensive depending on the materials you decide to buy (I'd say try to be as frugal as possible).  I would only recommend this course if you have a serious interest in becoming an architect major
Only take it if you will be majoring in (or considering) architecture.
Only take the course if you are planning on joining the concentration, otherwise it is a lot of work simply for an LA distribution requirement.

Only take this course if you are a freshman or sophomore wanting to major in architecture (not as a junior because you think it would be fun!) My finals partner was a junior and definitely regretted taking it.  It's a lot of work, so stay on your toes.  It's worth it in the end to see your end result.
Take it
Take this class not expecting rigid architecture but conceptual mind-opening.
Take this course if you're committed to a really hard semester.
The course is quite time consuming but quite interesting if you want to concentrate in architecture.  Be prepared for late nights in the studio.
The course is very disorganized and there are a lot of hidden costs.  Once you get over the disorganization and obscurity in grading and evaluation, the course becomes enjoyable.

This class takes a lot out of you. You will spend a lot of time and a lot of money on this class. Be prepared for sleep deprivation in the last few weeks of the semester. Only take this class if you are really considering architecture or civ-arc. Overall, I really liked this class, but a lot of people drop it early on.
This course is an amazing first architecture course, but it's very intensive - especially in regards to time.

This is a fun course to take and a nice break from other classes as there are no papers, problem sets or reading involved. However, it is still a lot of work, so only take it if you're seriously considering architecture.
Work steadily and start your work early.

You have to take it if you're an ARC major. If you're thinking about ARC, this course will help you decide whether you have it or not. 

And if you're just looking for a difficult class that ensures you pull many all nighters, then take this, though I don't know why you would want to do that.
if you are not interested in architecture i would be careful. it is definitely for an artistic mind
prereqs: ARC 204 is a prerequisite for entry into the departmental concentration. Students will be expected to purchase materials in order to carry out various assignments..
descrip: The first in a series of design studios offered to students interested in majoring in architecture. The course will introduce architecture as an "impure'' plastic art, inseparable from a network of forces acting upon it. The student will be confronted with progressively complex exercises involving spatial relations in two dimensions, three dimensions, and time. The course will stress experimentation while providing an analytical and creative framework to develop an understanding of structure and materials as well as necessary skills in drawing and model making. Two three-hour studios with lectures included.

title: Contexts of Composition
descrip: Seminar considers the intersection of composition, performance and spectatorship from a wide range of viewpoints, ranging from theoretical notions of identity as a form of performance to the more nuts-and-bolts concerns of composer/performers. Course explores works that foreground the artificiality of performance (Judith Weir's operas), that emphasize the presence of the composer (Meredith Monk's performances); and that dismantle the narcissism of the stage (Yvonne' Rainer's pedestrian choreography), as well as others, including our own.

title: Issues in Environmental and Natural Resource Economics
prereqs: None. While this course is directed primarily at juniors and seniors majoring in economics, the theory and applications presented in the course will be developed from basic principles and should be accessible to non-economists..
descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resource allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurrence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the political economy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental and natural resource services. These concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollution of air, water and land to international issues such as global warming and sustainable development.

title: Problems in Greek History - Greek Historical Inscriptions
descrip: Greek inscriptions provide especially valuable information on the political life, institutions and social structures of Greek society. The aim of the course is to give an introduction to the use of epigraphic documents in historical research. The sessions will be devoted to the analysis of particular aspects of Greek society (e. g. relationships between city and country, king and city, Greeks and non-Greeks) on the basis of inscriptions from the Classical and Hellenistic periods.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
reviews: I would recommend this class for people who have started taking Hindi at Princeton because it is useful and will help you to improve your Hindi or at least keep it constant.  I would not recommend this class to people who already have some pre-existing knowledge of Hindi and are looking to improve the skills and become closer to fluent in the language.
I would say to take it if the student is very interesting in Hindi, but to be ready for a lot of confusing and headaches.

If students are interested in expanding their Hindi skills and their knowledge of Indian culture, this is an excellent course. Students should take advantage of Mekhala-ji's knowledge and her willingness to help and encourage them on an individual basis.
If you want to learn Hindi, take it.
If you want to learn Hindi, take this course.
It's a great class
prereqs: HIN105 or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: A continuation of the second year of intermediate Hindi language training, this course focuses on improving skills in the following areas: reading expository texts and extended narratives, writing descriptive informative texts of three to four pages, verbal communication on a range of topics, and expanding analytical understanding of the structure of the Hindi language. Special attention is paid to the cultural context of South Asia.

title: Forms of Literature - Three Dublin Writers
reviews: This is probably one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Really great readings, interesting as well as thought-provoking. Good class discussion as well.
Three hour English seminars can be daunting, but Colm does such a great job of making the material fun that it's worth it.
definitely take it!
descrip: Three writers born in Dublin between 1854 and 1906 sought to make literature new. In ways both playful and deeply innovative, they turned established systems of literary representation on their heads. All spent significant time away from Ireland, in London or Paris. All were deeply alert to the rhythms of the Gaelic language. All produced a body of letters that illuminate their work and the growth of their imaginations. They often wrote as though they were part of no tradition at all, but rather set out to destroy what they might have inherited. Together, their prose, drama, and poetry form a distinct lineage of Irish Modernism.

title: The Psychology of Decision Making and Judgment
reviews: After taking this class I've learned many interesting psychological effects that seem like they will be very relevant to my decision making in the future. It's an excellent class.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this course.
Definitely take this course. It is well-structured and you will never look at the world the same way again.
Do not hesitate to take this course. You will learn a lot from it.

Don't take it if you're a psych major, you've learned all of this in PSY 101 and 252 before. For non-psych people, 100% recommendation, you'll learn a lot of stuff useful for life and it's entertaining too.
Even if you think psychology is generally stupid (as I do), you'll still really enjoy this class.
Everyone, no matter their major, should take this class. The material is very interesting and can be applied to many different subjects.
Go to lecture and precept, do the readings, and stay on pace with the material (i.e. don't fall behind).
Good, but difficult.
Great course about how irrational humans are and ways to potentially overcome these flaws. Very interesting and useful for any major/any citizen of the world!
I didn't find the subject matter as interesting as I thought. Pick up a copy of Nudge and read it. If you want further information take the course; otherwise just enjoy the book.

I loved this course and would absolutely recommend it to almost anyone, regardless of whether it satisfies a requirement.  The material is incredibly interesting and although the grading isn't easy, it's worth taking the class.

I think that this course could be really good if the preceptor and administration issues were resolved.  However, even though I found the material interesting I found the class experience overall to be incredibly frustrating because of these issues.
I would strongly encourage people to take this class because just about everyone has fundamental fallacies in their every-day choices.

If you have to get an EC requirement fulfilled, consider this course. And if you're just interested in the way humans think, especially policymakers, also take it! The readings and discussions are fun.
If you want a deeper understanding of the process of human rationality, take this course.
It's a very interesting class, but there are a lot of assignments.
Keep a running list of terms.

Lectures and precepts make the course seem fairly easy, but the exams are a bit harder than one might think. It is a good course, however, if you are interested in the psychology of how we make decisions and how we should try and improve it.
Must take.
One of my favorites, even if I don't do as well
Shafir is fabulous!
TAKE IT. If you're interested in human behavior, how to influence it, and why we make certain decisions, take it.  There's also an interesting policy application to it.
Take it but prepare to be bored in precept
Take it!

Take it! An easy class with lots of interesting, but not-too-excessive reading. Just make sure to do the readings: Shafir's lectures get you 80% there, but the readings are critical for exams/completing your understanding of the material. A pretty easy class for math-ECO/ORF majors.
Take it! Its one of the few courses I feel can affect your life outside of an academic point of view.
Take it!!!
Take it.
Take the course regardless of what you're planning to do in your life.  It's bound to be useful!
Take this class!!! I guarantee you will learn so much about yourself and human behavior that will blow your mind!
Take this course as long as Shafir is teaching it.  It is interesting and relevant regardless of your discipline.
The class isn't too difficult but it is very thought-provoking and changes the way you view the world.
The lectures are good, the precepts hit or miss, the assignments and exams challenging and sometimes very particular about reading details. If the subject matter interests you, go for it.
This class has A LOT of reading! And you're expected to know author names on the exams...

This is a course that will open your eyes and really allow you to see how behavioral phenomena can have an impact on our daily lives.  It was really interesting and especially relevant to the issues we face today, not to mention an exciting and continually developing field.  I strongly recommend it.
This is a great course to take just for understanding yourself and decision-making in all contexts. It is a lot of fun and I also felt that I learned a lot as well.

This is one of the best classes at Princeton. It is extremely applicable to all areas of life, especially outside academics. It definitely makes one look at the world with a whole new perspective. A Must-Take! Be sure to avoid Melanie Thomas as a preceptor though.
Very interesting perspective on policy-making and human behavior...best EC course.
Will make you think a lot about how you think! lecture slides are good. may get somewhat repetitive in that he keeps on trying to persuade you people think irrationally. lots of material to learn.
You don't need to have taken PSY before to take this. Interesting, not a ton of work.
hated this class!
involves a lot of readings and work
it's not a hard class but it may be hard to get a good grade. interesting and worth taking nonetheless.
really cool but alot of work
prereqs: Introductory statistics for social science or equivalent..
descrip: An introduction to the logic and research findings underlying decision-making and judgment under uncertainty. The focus is on the contrast between the rational theory of judgment and choice, and the psychological principles that guide decision behavior, often producing biases and errors. Among other topics, we will consider legal, medical, and financial decision-making, poverty, well-being, and negotiation, along with the implications of the findings for the rational agent model typically assumed in economics, throughout the social sciences, and in policy making.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: I don't know what the experience was like for the more experienced actors, but if you haven't done much acting and you want to see what it's like and are up for a challenge, I definitely recommend this class.
I strongly recommend if you're wondering if you would like acting.
I would highly recommend taking this class with Tracy, no matter how much acting experience you have, and really enjoy and explore each class.

I'm sure this course varies by professor. I took it with Tracy and it was simply a great experience. I came in with a good deal of high school acting experience and learned a lot, but many people in the class came in without previous experience and they had improved just an amazing amount by the end of the semester. If you love acting, or even if you are just curious and want to try it out, I highly recommend this course. Come in with a good attitude, and I can practically guarantee it will be a great experience.

If you are interested at all, try it! 
It is great!
If you are interested in acting take this course.
If you have any interest at all in theater or performance, take this class. And DEFINITELY try to get Tracy Bersley if at all possible-- she's the best!

If you've had experience in a performative style of acting, be warned that this is not what the professor is looking for. If you're looking to play yourself a lot, go for it. If you'd rather learn how to play a character, this isn't the course for you.
It a very fun class. More active than your usually sit down lecture.
It's a fun class.  If you like theater you will probably like it and if you've never done theater before, it's a fun way to get involved.
Make sure you have time to meet with scene partners. Meeting after midnight isn't as fun as it would seem.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. Doesn't matter if you have a ton of experience or none at all, this class will make you think about what it means to be an actor and help you become a better actor overall!
Take it if your interested, but not for an easy course.

Theater 201 is a class with great promise, and the tutelage of a good professor would have made our syllabus shine. Professor Agins is no such good professor. Avoid her. Take the class, yes. But with anyone else.
Very fun and very helpful.  Everyone should take this class.
Yes.
You should take this class only if you like theater. It is unfair to the rest of the class to have students who don't take it seriously.
prereqs: No application needed; but must gain permission to enroll via the instructors. Please visit the Theater Program website for further information..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: Classical Historians and Their Philosophies of History
descrip: What philosophy of history belongs to Greek and Roman historians? How did the ancient historians themselves ask this question? Was their theory and practice as marked with change as has been European and American historiography since the 18th century? Finally, why has contemporary practice begun a turn back to classical narrative historiography? This course will cover major Greek and Roman historians, ancillary classical theory, and some pertinent contemporary philosophers of history.

title: Transformations of an Empire: Power, Religion, and the Arts of Medieval Rome
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Pictographic Modernity in the United States
descrip: The American visual landscape is replete with graphics dedicated to encouraging and detailing the reform of city, country, housing, farming, factory work and housework, health, and culture. This seminar will study the history of the tabulation of statistical data and its graphic representation in the form of pictographs, charts, diagrams, plans, maps, and other methods of illustration and inscription. Students will gain a thorough understanding of how graphical methods influenced policy makers as well as the perception of reforms in the minds of the American public.

title: Communicating Climate Change
reviews: Definitely worth taking if you're interested in this subject!
Do not take this course. If you are interested in the subject, find interesting and informative readings on your own (you will most certainly do a better job than the professors).
Extremely disorganized, but if you're comfortable being a bit of an autodidact and want a whirlwind tour of journalism's relationship to climate change, this is a good class for you.
Great course to get down basic understanding not only of climate change but also of how to craft a compelling story. Fun class, not very stressful, profs are great!

If you care about the environment and want a glimpse at the real world jobs of "climate change" people, this is the course to take. I had no experience with Final cut pro, but learned a lot and am very proud of what I created in this class.

It's a GREAT class for junior spring. You might make helpful connections for the future - it seems that their past students have done so. And you learn important things, such as how to create a piece so that the work becomes really easy for you, since you have done all the prep work and avoided most common mistakes. Also, I think the issue itself is super important.
It's fun. People are interesting. I didn't think I learned that much.

Not time consuming.  A handful of interesting readings.  If you want to learn how to make a podcast and video, this is a good time to give yourself a few hours to play around, but the course won't give you too much training besides your own initiative and what the Media Lab will teach you.
prereqs: Strong interest in communications and in the issues covered by the course; no previous coursework or experience necessary..
descrip: Climate change has the potential to wreak great havoc over the next century, threatening ecosystems, economies, and human lives. Scientists are putting enormous effort into trying to understand the causes, effects, and possible solutions to the climate-change problem. Yet the public still has only a vague idea of what climate science actually says, and much of that is badly distorted. The course will explore how to communicate to the public about climate change through print, web and video, in ways that are at once clear, compelling, and scientifically rigorous.

title: Screenwriting: Creating Visual and Emotional Unity
reviews: Ask Professor Lazaridi more questions and set up personal meetings. She is very open to meeting with students and has a wealth of knowledge.
Best class I've taken at Princeton.

I think this is a great class and Christina Lazaridi is a fantastic teacher. I love screenwriting after being introduced to it by her, and I think anyone else coming out of the class will love screenwriting too!

If you are interested in movies and/or writing this course is great.  The workload is also very different than standard papers or problemsets, which is a nice departure to a different way of doing things.

Of course I'd recommend it- easily the best CWR course in the department. The feedback in other courses don't remotely compare- there are answers here, clear and concise, easy to apply and understand, that will improve your writing and actually bring about a full understanding of the medium.
prereqs: Application through the Creative Writing Program. Prerequisite: Screenwriting I or Permission of the Instructor. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: This class will familiarize students with the complex use of metaphorical, emotional, and visual threads in screenplay writing. Analyzing examples of international, independent, and classical structures, students will be exposed to the rhythms and demands of the process of conceiving and writing a long form narrative film.

title: Purity and Sacrifice in Ancient Israel
descrip: The course will examine two interrelated topics in the study of ancient Israelite religion--purity and sacrifice--from a wide range of perspectives, including text-historical, archeological, anthropological, and cognitive. The course will try to answer such questions as: Is impurity evil? Are there universal patterns in ritual? And do rituals have meaning? Our primary sources will be the Hebrew Bible, the Qumran Scrolls, and early rabbinic literature. The value of comparative research in these fields will be demonstrated through the examination of texts on purity and sacrifice from the ancient Near East and from India.

title: Intermediate Swahili II
prereqs: Intermediate Swahili I (SWA 105 ) or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: The course aims at consolidating basic language skills learned in the previous elementary courses in enabling the learner perform daily communicative activities in Kiswahili with relative ease. The course content includes introduction to simple creative texts such as video, music, short stories, and visuals in newspapers and magazines that increase the learner's exposure to and appreciation for the cultural practices of the Swahili speakers.

title: Conflict and Terrorism in the Modern Middle East
descrip: The main aim of this course is to provide a thematic approach to the study of conflict and terrorism in the Middle East, with a critical inquiry over `what we think we know' about terrorism and conflict in the Middle East. To do that, the course will start of with an exposition of the competing theories on conflict and terrorism. Then, it will move on to the creation of the contemporary `conflict structures' in the Middle East during World War I. The class will then move onto case studies such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, examples of religious or secular terrorisms, and the modern manifestations of the Sunni-Shia conflict.

title: Fascism in Italian Cinema
prereqs: No knowledge of Italian is required to enroll..
descrip: This course, conducted in English, is a study of Fascist ideology through selected films from World War II to the present. Topics include: the concept of Fascist normality; Racial Laws; the role of women; and the opposition of the intellectual left. Films include: Bertolucci's "The Conformist", Fellini's "Amarcord", Rossellini's "Rome Open City", Rosi's "The Truce", and Benigni's "Life is Beautiful". The approach is interdisciplinary and combines the analysis of socio-historical themes with a cinematic reading of the films.

title: Animal Behavior
reviews:
1- Take detailed notes, especially on the examples. Gould does not repeat himself.
2- Make sure you know what topic all of the examples are for, because it's pretty easy to turn your brain off and just let everything go by.
A good way to get a feel for the subject of EEB.

Definitely.  If you take it, you'll be taking a very interesting course that will certainly give you a new perspective not only on the animal world but our place in it.  I feel like it's certainly something that everyone should consider taking because it helps us realize that we are not as special as we think we are, which is something I definitely think we need to realize.
Do the readings and go to lecture!
Don't take it unless you are INCREDIBLY interested. Boring. Will put you to sleep.
Fascinating subject matter, although the exams are very tough.
Good class, but not exactly easy.
I would recommend this course to other students.
If you  want to take a science requirement with no lab, this isn't a bad choice. If you're an EEB major you will probably enjoy this course.
If you attend lecture and do the readings, you will get a lot out of the course
It's a very good PDF class.
It's hard when the lecture slides are just 100  pictures of animals every lecture.
Know that you want to read about animals. Also know that you enjoy learning about the details of animals' lives.
Only take it if you like EEB. There are easier classes for distribution requirements.
Take it for a good quality STX.

Take it!  I took it PDF for an STX, and while there are definitely easier ones to fill this requirement, I think it was a great choice.  Lectures were so well-planned, accessible, and interesting (although a little long....), and I felt like I walked away with some great EEB knowledge!
Take it. Gould is a baller. You don't even need to study. If you do all the readings and take excellent notes, you'll have no trouble recalling the info for the exam.
Take the class!

Take this class!  You will laugh and learn a great deal.  Also, it's not work intensive, though I've noticed that some people in my precept dropped the class, maybe because they hadn't realized that they had to read scientific papers.
This course is fun and engaging and you should take it if you aren't great at math/science, because it doesn't require advanced technical knowledge.
This is a fun course for the most part.  Prof. Gould has a great dry wit that you should pay attention to if you're going to take this class.

This is a great class to take pass/fail. The lectures are entertaining and the material is really cool. If you're taking it for a grade, expect it to be harder then you imagined, because of the strict grading.
You have two choices: read before class, or pay attention to every single detail during lecture so you don't get lost.
good class, very interesting
take it if you are interested in topic
descrip: One of the fascinating challenges in biology is to understand the origins and organization of animal behavior. Ethology is the branch of biology concerned with the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. The course begins by examining the discovery of early ethologists of behavioral units or "programs", and relates these to our understanding of the nervous system. We look at how complex behaviors such as navigation, learning, and planning are organized. We study the social behavior of several species and end with an ethological analysis of our own species.

title: Optimization
reviews: Boring course, but problem sets are fairly easy.
Don't take it unless you have to.  It's boring and I don't feel like I walked away with any greater knowledge to tell the truth.

Don't take this class until absolutely necessary. Dr Art was great but the group project takes up a lot of time and the graders took a long time to return psets (and the quality of the precepts was not particularly high).
Don't take this unless you have to!
Especially with this professor, I would recommend taking this course because the information you learn is definitely useful and relevant in a number of fields.
Honestly, the subject material is absurdly boring.  There's no way around this.  If you don't have to take this class, you shouldn't.

I would say that if someone is interested in linear programming and likes doing applied math, then he/she should take this course.  However, I didn't feel as though I learned much about operations research in general.

I'd generally recommend the course, but it's not by any means the best I've taken here. Most people who take it do it if they have to, and it might not be the best purely general interest course to take.
If this class remains substantially similar, and isn't overhauled like 245 was to include a greater computer component, don't take this course unless you are required to.
If you are planning on taking this course make sure that the professor has taught the course before and has a good reputation.
If you pay attention in the lectures you can get a lot out of it, otherwise don't bother taking it unless you have to. It's worth it if you put the time in to understand it.

In most classes, if the professor sucks, you can ask the grad students for help. If the grad students are useless too, you can usually just learn from the book. In the case of this course, all three (the professor, grad students, and textbook) were horrible. The professor read off of powerpoint slides and was bad at explaining what he was doing, the TAs only graded about 1/3 of the homework so there was basically no feedback to know how you were doing, and the textbook wasn't very clear either (don't believe me -- look at the reviews on Amazon).  Future students won't have to worry about having the same professor though; he was a visiting professor and won't be here next term. If you don't have to take this class, don't take it.
It's OK. Keep up with the work.
It's not the most interesting class I've taken but it has some quite important uses.
Obviously you have to take this class if you're an ORF major. Even if you're not, I would consider taking it because it is completely new material that you won't learn on your own.
Probably a useful course to take if you are in the field, but otherwise you have better options for interesting courses
Same as above.
Take it if you have to for your department or certificate.
Take it with this professor only if you have to.  Wait for Vanderbei or a Princeton professor to teach it.
Take the course if you need to.
This course depends much on who teaches the course. The course material has great potential to be interesting but the professor could make it very interesting or very boring.

We had a visiting professor, so these reviews won't be applicable anyway. The subject matter is interesting, but can be tedious at times. If you like optimization, though, the techniques learned in this class are really interesting.
don't take it if you don't have to.
extremely boring. only take if necessary.
read the book
prereqs: MAT 202 or MAT 204. Basic computer programming knowledge suggested..
descrip: Optimization of deterministic systems, focusing on linear programming. Model formulations, the simplex method, sensitivity analysis, duality theory, network models, nonlinear programming. Applications to a variety of problems in optimal allocation of resources, transportation systems, and finance.

title: Epidemiology
reviews: A pretty good class. Not too much math/stats; there's more of a focus on the other aspects of epidemiology.
Definitely take it - it teaches you how to critically read other academic work although it doesn't quite prepare you enough to design your own study.
Definitely take it.
Do all the textbook readings and practice problems. For the case studies, pick reputable journals and articles that are very cookie cutter.
Good class, Prof Amon is great!
I really hope students take advantage of this course. Amon is a wonderful lecturer.
If you have to take it, go for it. It's not awful and has its highlights.
If you're GHP, you have to take it. Hopefully, you'll be really interested in it. I wasn't, so I might drop the certificate.
There were great guest speakers, the assignments were helpful, the tests were fair, and the readings were interesting.
prereqs: Completion of an approved basic statistics course (e.g., ECO 202, EEB/MOL 355, ORF 245, POL 345, PSY 251 or SOC 301), or completion of an advanced statistics course (e.g., ECO 302, ECO 312, ORF 405, SOC 404, WWS 332)..
descrip: This required course for GHP students focuses on the distribution and determinants of disease. Diverse methodological approaches for measuring health status, disease occurrence, and the association between risk factors and health outcomes will be presented via classic and contemporary studies of chronic and infectious illness and disease outbreaks. Emphasis on: causal inference, study design and sampling, bias and confounding, the generalizability of research, health policy and research ethics.

title: Financial Crises
reviews: Certainly worth taking if interested in financial crises.
If you want to learn about financial crisis, this is the course to take and learn it from an excellent Professor.
Shop it.
descrip: The use economic theory and empirical evidence to study the causes of financial crises and the effectiveness of policy responses to them. Particular attention given to some of the major economic and financial crises of the past century and to the crisis that began in August 2007.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty member.

title: Introductory Logic
reviews: A class for people who like proofs and puzzle-like symbol manipulations.
A good class, but beware if you're a random humanities person who doesn't need this - this class is full of math majors who get perfects on everything.
A good course to take for a distributional requirement. do it.
A great class to take if you are interested in logic. Highly recommend if Professor Dasgupta is teaching.

Almost everybody who takes this class will be good at logical thinking, so don't think you're at an advantage because you are. If you're really focused on grades, you will be frustrated by the nitpicky marks that will be taken off on assignments and exams.
Definitely take this course if you're looking for an EC to fulfill and are somewhat quantitative.
Do not take this.
Do the reading!
Easy and fun course to take if you are interested in or want to learn more about logic and proofs
Expect to be not challenged. Would recommend intermediate logic for more mathematically inclined individuals.
For the exams, do practice questions and read the answers for the past graded problem sets.
Good introduction to logic
Great course, indirectly helps with proof writing if you're into math, and fulfills an EC requirement. I'd recommend it.
Great course.

I think that Professor Dasgupta was a great lecturer and that his test were more than fair, but that the concepts of the class were very hit or miss and if you were doing poorly it was very hard to get a better grade.  Also, the material of the class did not really seem to have much application, and might have been better suited for math rather than philosophy.

I would not recommend this course.  The material is largely uninteresting.  While the material is not hard to grasp, this makes the curve unforgiving.  A few stupid mistakes will cost you a good grade even if you understand the material well.  There is little room for error.  Professor Dasgupta is a good lecturer and presents the material clearly and in an engaging way, but overall it's not enough to make the material interesting.
I would strongly recommend taking this course if you are a prospective philosophy major, or if you just have an interest in logic in general.
If you are a humanities person do not take this class! It is very difficult and involved a lot of proofs.
If you need an EC or you are interested in logic, and if Shamik is teaching the course, then it is totally worth it.

If you want to take a really fascinating EC, I'd recommend a religion class or a philosophy class with readings and papers (like 203) instead of this one. But if you like playing with math problems, proofs or logic puzzles and you just want to do that then take this class.

If you're in math or CS, you'll find it a breeze. If you're an engineer or in a quantitative discipline, you'll still find it pretty easy. If you don't have much exposure to symbolic logic otherwise, you might find it pretty tough. In terms of how interesting it is, I think this really varies by person -- I knew learning about logic would be fun for me, so I enjoyed it, and it's definitely applicable in real life in that you might more quickly be able to strip arguments down to their logical essence. But some people just find it a bore and don't really find it applicable. Maybe read a wiki article on it beforehand to see how you feel about the topic. Also, Shamik is a really great lecturer -- very clear, very friendly. He went out of his way to answer all questions and provide us with as many resources as students asked for. Fantastic professor.

If you're seriously interested in studying logic, this class if a good way to do it. Even if you're just remotely interested you might want to take it. BUT, if you are just looking to fill a distribution requirement, there are a number of EC's that will give you a better experience.

It definitely seemed like more of a COS class presented in PHI form than pure PHI; it was interesting to learn PL and SL, but at times I couldn't help but wonder exactly what relevance such knowledge would have.
It is worth taking if you are interested in abstract thinking; the work for this class asked you to go into depth but it is a very manageable workload.
It's a fairly easy class, with a few interesting logical ideas sprinkled throughout. Take it if you're looking for an easy EC.
It's a fun course! Especially for those who haven't taken math in a while and miss that kind of thought.
It's a good class for distribution requirements.
It's a good class for the EC requirement, especially if you believe in your analytical abilities.
It's a good introduction to logical thinking
It's a somewhat boring course that does have some interesting elements to it. But you could probably learn in a few hours everything that was covered in one semester.

It's very tough for an intro class and I'm surprised that it's designated as an EC and not a QR.  If you're interested in mathematical proofs and theories applied to other subjects you should take this course.

Keep in mind this is NOT the course it used to be--Professor Dasgupta is a new teacher, and the material is much more difficult than it was in previous semesters.

For me, it was a nice EC, especially since I'm interested in MAT and COS and I like logic.

Be careful with the problem sets, as you can lose valuable points for silly mistakes.

Lecture was absolutely useless, but I learned a lot through the textbook and my precept.
Material can be self-taught, but it's easier to just go to lecture.

Much better than I expected. Interesting stuff, homework = fun puzzles to solve, and very manageable workload. I've heard the professor for this class in past years has been horrible, so I feel pretty damn lucky to have taken it with Shamik, who is easily one of the best professors I've had here.
Pay very close attention second semester when the class gets very hard.
Read the textbook and do lots of practice problems.
See above.
Take if you want a lighter than usual workload but still want to learn something pretty usable.
Take it for an EC if you're mathematically-inclined.
Take it for the EC. Not only that it will fulfill a requirement on your transcript, but it might actually induce you a passion for Logic.
Take it if you have trouble developing logical arguments and/or want to know how the underlying logic works behind COS, MAT, etc.
Take it only if 1) you're a math science type and want a very easy class or 2) if you want practice thinking in a math science type of way.
Take it, but don't miss lecture.
Take it, it's a good way to do an EC if you're a quantitative person.
Take it, its fun, not too much work and the professor is great
Take it, not terribly exciting or practical, but interesting.
Take it.
Take this class if formal logic interests you and if you're willing to put in the time to truly understand the material.
Take this class!  It is like a mathematics class from an English perspective.
The course covers interesting, introductory material to logic well.  It helps to give a nice way of thinking about reasoning.
The material is interesting but the course needs to be restructured.
This class does what it says in its course description-- introduces students to logic.  It is pretty basic, and should be quite easy for anyone who has experienced mathematical constructs.

This class should be mandatory for all students and really should be called introduction to thinking. If you have any sort of math background it will be trivial. If not, you might struggle a bit, but learning how to think in this way will be invaluable both in future classes here and in the real world after graduation.
This course is a good distribution requirement. Only 5 problem sets, and they are not too long. As long as you don't neglect this class, you will be fine. Do the ungraded problem sets!

This course is fairly interesting and not too difficult if you keep up with the material and practice the problems weekly. The grading reflects this: you don't have too many assignments, so just do well on the few problem sets and two exams and you're set. They even drop the lowest graded problem set.

This is a great class. It is very systematic, like a science class, but it has more applications to social sciences than many science classes. The emphasis on problem sets over exams will make your life easier as long as you are conscientious.
This is a nice way one can get their EC requirement. There isn't a lot of work as there are only 5 graded problem sets the whole semester. Quite nice. Dr. Dasgupta is also an awesome lecturer.

To do well in the course, completing the ungraded problem sets for practice is extremely helpful.

Otherwise, I would want to suggest future students to ask what is motivating them to study logic before taking this course as sometimes the course material has a tendency to feel removed from real life at times.
Too much grade deflation.
Unless you are extremely good at math-based learning, don't take the class.  I don't see it helping me in the future by any means, as I previously thought it might.
if you're a quantitative person, this class will be very easy. you may have already seen many of the concepts before in math/computer science, and others will be fairly intuitive.
its hard. REALLY hard.
really changed the way you think/your mind work. definitely take it (i think it should be a core requirement almost)
descrip: Logic is the study of the principles of valid reasoning. This course provides an introduction to symbolic logic, which studies the principles of valid reasoning from an abstract point of view -- paying attention to the form of valid arguments rather than their subject matter. We will cover the basic concepts and principles of symbolic logic: validity, logical truth, truth-functional and quantificational inference, formal languages and formal systems, axiomatic and deductive proof procedures.

title: Planetary Systems: Their Diversity and Evolution
prereqs: GEO 207, GEO 255, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Examines the diversity of recently discovered planetary systems in terms of fundamental physical and chemical processes and what this diversity implies about the origin and evolution of our own planetary system. Topics include: the formation and dynamics of planets and satellites, planetary migration, the evolution of planetary interiors, surfaces and atmospheres, the occurrence of water and organics, and the habitability of planets and planetary systems. Recent discoveries from planetary missions and extrasolar planet observations are emphasized.

title: Cityscapes
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Applied Federalism in an Age of Limits: Case of NJ
descrip: This seminar uses the recent experience of NJ state government to examine federalism's impact on state governance. Topics include K-12 and higher education; health care; energy and the environment; transportation and infrastructure; and the state budget. Students focus on the interplay between state and federal funding sources and regulatory structures, and disparities between and within states in the provision of social services. Course material is primary-source intensive, with a focus on the years 2006-2010.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture II
reviews: Be prepared to study traditional Chinese characters (hanja) if you want to learn higher-level Korean vocabulary.
Definitely take this class if you want to improve your korean language skills.
Do not underestimate the amount of work that goes into this class. It is definitely worth the effort, but be willing to work hard.
Great class! Did NOT feel like 3 hours and the professor makes each class a fun experience. Would recommend to anyone wanting to sharpen their Korean reading/speaking/writing skills.
You have to go to the language table/go to individual sessions/just speak Korean in general if you want to survive as a non-native speaker. But if you want it, it's there and a lot of fun.
prereqs: KOR 401 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion of Korean thoughts and issues in contemporary Korea. Readings drawn from a variety of cultural and historical topics. Class discussions will be conducted in Korean.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of science and engineering who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Relativistic Quantum Theory II
reviews: Learning something about QFT before taking this course, it is a bit suffering to come up with basic knowledge as long as learn advanced topics.
You had better learned functional integral before taking this course.
strongly recommended if you want to do high energy, condense matter, or other theoretical physics. This course is a good step towards a deeper level of physical cultivation.
descrip: Renormalization group, non-abelian gauge theory, the Standard Model, selected topics in Quantum Field Theory.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Some Serious Business.  This is the is, and not the ought, of research ethics in the US.  Good for getting an idea of what you will have to navigate if you continue as a researcher.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies? requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Bridges
prereqs: CEE 366 or CEE 361.
descrip: The design of bridges is considered from the conceptual phase up to the final design phase. The following issues are addressed in this course: types of bridges, design codes, computer modeling of bridges, seismic analysis and design, seismic retrofit design, inspection, maintenance and rehabilitation of bridges, movable bridges, bridge aerodynamics, organization of a typical engineering firm, marketing for engineering work. Several computer codes are used in this course.

title: Islamic Family Law
reviews: If you are interested in the field. TAKE THIS COURSE. Modarressi is a great professor. The class is manageable also!

Take this class if you'd like to improve your knowledge about how family law works in islam. Don't be afraid to take this class if you've never taken the general islamic law class, as the first half of the class goes over the basic structure of islamic law and is a bit repetitive for students who have already taken islamic law classes before.
some fore-knowledge of Islam would be helpful, but its not necessary, which is nice
very good introduction to the basics of islamic jurisprudence and family law!
descrip: This course examines the oulines of Islamic family law in gender issues, sexual ethics, family structure, family planning, marriage and divorce, parenthood, child guardianship and custody, etc. The course starts with a general survey of Islamic legal system: its history and developments, structure and spirit, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to terms with the challenge of time.

title: Modern Physics I: Condensed-Matter Physics
reviews: Good for a broad overview of condensed matter physics. Not terribly difficult, but requires at least a couple hours work per week.
I recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in condensed matter.
I strongly recommend taking any course taught by Prof. Petta.

If you'd like to take an intro / survey course in condensed matter, this is the course to take. You absolutely won't go wrong with Professor Petta teaching it - he's an incredibly clear lecturer who helps motivate each topic and helps you keep track of where you're going, really interested in the material and effective and transmitting this enthusiasm, gives you tons of little insights including current work in the field, which keeps you excited, and also really concerned about students being interested in the material and seeing the exciting research and phenomena in the field (hence the final presentations). He's also always helpful and patient with office hours etc. Great class, great professor.
If you're interested in the subject and prepared to work hard, definitely take it.
This is a dense and super rewarding introductory course.

This is a really great course, as taught by Professor Petta. His enthusiasm for the subject comes across clearly and his lectures are always well-prepared and delivered. The material covered is very interesting and even quite exciting towards the end. A great introductory course to solid state physics.

This was a fantastic course and really useful to any physics major, even if you're not planning into going into condensed matter. If you're a junior, it's the first time you'll actually apply all that hard-earned quantum mechanics, E&M and Statistical Mechanics in one place and to real systems. It's a great course to test yourself in, and there are fewer students than the average class, so it's great to really engage with a class and a professor. Prof. Petta is especially good at involving his students in every way and always helpful and available. He's also a hands-on, practicing condensed matter experimentalist, does this stuff day to day and can therefore answer questions before you've said them.
prereqs: PHY 208 and PHY 301 and PHY 305..
descrip: This survey course applies concepts from quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to the properties of electrons in solids. Topics include phonons and lattice dynamics, electronic band structure, the tight-binding approximation, origin of exchange and magnetism, spin waves, Ginzburg Landau theory of phase transitions, and the BCS theory of superconductivity.

title: Gauge Theory and Low Dimensional Topology
descrip: Khovanov homology (a continuation from Fall 2010)

title: Introduction to Financial Mathematics
reviews: Attend lecture and definitely ask the professor or preceptors for help.
Coulon is excellent, so if he's teaching it, go for it.
Do not take unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take it before taking 309. Life would be much easier and you'll have a way better grasp if you had taken 309 before
HIGHLY RECOMMEND, Prof. Coulon is an excellent professor
Hard class. Not as good as ORF 309.
Hard work, but worthwhile.
Highly recommended.

I seriously recommend this class if you are interested in trading as a career in the future. It is a great intro class that still touches on several advanced concepts that can be applied to the work field.
Should consider this course because it is interesting. Learn the material diligently because it gets harder as the semester goes on.
Take it! The material is stuff you really want to know especially if you're thinking of going in to finance. Professor Coulon makes it even better.
Take the class if you are interested in applications of ORF 309 materials. Not very time consuming or difficult either.
This course is really good but also very difficult. Stay on top of things. I didn't and I hope I'll be able to understand the course by the final.
This is a good course even for ORF majors who are not interested in finance; it exceeded my expectations.
This is a good course to take if you want to get a good introduction to financial math.
This is a great course if you want an introduction to financial mathematics. It definitely requires a lot of time commitment.
Too much math but organized.
Very difficult course with a lot of material.
You learn a lot. Take it if programming doesn't put you off.
computationally intensive. put your math pants on.
great intro to financial math class - learn all the buzz words!!
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 104 and ORF 309 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course introduces the pricing and hedging of options and other derivative securities. The main focus is on the binomial tree and the Black-Scholes models for equity markets. Other topics include credit risk, energy markets and stochastic volatility

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term) - Molecular Sciences
prereqs: Course open to graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed sufficient research to begin writing an article for publication..
descrip: Writing workshop for students who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One three-hour seminar.

title: Computer Graphics
reviews: Awesome course. You will be very satisfied with what you can do at the end of this course!
Be prepared for workload, otherwise very enjoyable experience.
Definitely a class you should take. Loved it and found it very interesting. Assignments take a while but there are only a few. Exams are tough but the curve deals with that well.
GREAT CLASS! take it without question

Great course for learning and really worth it; just be prepared to do a whole lot of work ... and it may be best if you don't care about grading too much and are just taking this out of personal interest.

Great, great, great course, BUT only if you have the time for it. It is known as the work equivalent of two classes, and that's reputation is well-earned. The assignments/concepts aren't hard to understand, but they take a lot of time to code and especially debug. Everyone does well (>100% average on last two assignments), so if you can't put in the sheer hours, you're at a disadvantage. In short, you'll love the class, but be prepared for a time commitment.
If you are confident in your mastery of the skills taught by COS217, and you are capable of time management, this is a very good and rewarding course.
If you can't devote 20-30 hours a week on this course, then don't take it. If you can, the problem sets are great and you feel like your resulting projects are worth the time you put in.
NO!
TAKE IT
TAKE IT but realize it's a lot of programming, lots of "here's an algorithm, now implement it but considering all the little nitty gritty things our psuedocode left out."
TAKE ITTTTTTTTTT
Take the class, go to lecture, and make sure to start the assignments as early as you can.
Take the course - the assignments include writing a fairly significant amount of code, but plenty of time is given and the code is divided up into many smaller parts.

Take this class - it is a good introduction and exploration of computer graphics material.  Just be prepared to spend time on the assignments.  
The final project took up almost all of my reading period, so make sure you plan for it.

The material in this course is very interesting and Syzmon does a great job of explaining it. Always seemed very intuitive to me. 
The assignments have some interesting parts but tend to be very long and have alot of not so interesting parts to implement. Perhaps one of the heaviest workloads I've ever seen for a class: heavier than any MAT or COS classes I've taken.
Exams reflect material well and aren't too hard. Final project (make a video game) is alot of fun, but did not feel we were given enough time.
Took a lot from the material learned, but also spent a very large part of my free time working on this class. I feel this class may be more suited to hardcore programmers than people interested in the math and concepts of graphics.
This course was very interesting and, in my opinion, a must-take for anyone planning on majoring in COS. It's a *lot* of work though so don't take it if you're pressed for time and/or weak.
This is a difficult class. Be prepared to spend a LOT of time on assignments. Start them very early.
Time consuming, but sort of worth it in the end.
Time intensive, but very interesting and satisfying when you get your programs to work.
this is not the class to take if you have a life, friends, other classes, any form of extracurriculars, a job, and/or a desire to sleep
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Introduction to computer graphics. Topics include image synthesis, 3D modeling, image processing and animation. Encourage hands-on experience.

title: Intercellular Signaling and Signal Transduction
descrip: Explores the interactions of cells with their surroundings at a molecular and cell biological level. It begins with an introduction to a number of basic signal transduction pathways, a characterization of their respective receptors and the molecular pathways that communicate between the cell surface and the nucleus. Discusses how signaling establishes axes of cell polarity and cell fate decisions. Addresses the cell's response to nutritional cues and other extracellular signals that influence cell growth, cell division and cell physiology. Experimental data and modelling approaches will be discussed.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
reviews: Always worth the hour to sit in since you never know what you're going to find out. The speakers are often very engaging.
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: Special Studies in Renaissance Drama - Marlowe and the Literature of Atheism
descrip: A seminar on the dramatic oeuvre of Marlowe, in the context of the many biographical, social, religious, and political questions raised by his brief career. The class will read Marlowe chiefly as a playwright whose life and work aroused suspicions of "atheism" among his contemporaries. The course will explore the question of what atheism means in pervasively Christian society, and how the paranoid representation of this perhaps imaginary figure supports the development of Marlowe's theatrical innovations.

title: Seminar in 17th-Century French Literature - Le Merveilleux sous Louis XIV
descrip: This seminar will explore the various modalities and functions of the marvelous in the "classical age" (1650-1700). What is the place of the extraordinary, the supernatural and the fabulous in a strictly ordered and increasingly rationalistic world?
