How can literature and art astonish, enchant and transport while following the rules of reason and verisimilitude? Readings will range from mythological spectacles to fairy tales, considered with relation to the critical debates about the merveilleux and the sublime, the Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes, and the discourse of absolute monarchy.

title: Science, Technology, and Society: South Asian Perspectives
descrip: Science, Technology, and Society (STS) is an interdisciplinary field that explores the social and historical shaping of science and technology. This course provides an introduction to STS with special focus on South Asia. We will consider questions such as: Is Bangalore simply an Indian version of Silicon Valley? Does outsourcing truly result in a 'flattening' of the world? What issues result from virtual migration and body shopping? What is the role of national identity in constructs of Hindu or Islamic science? How do South Asian electronic cultures relate to pirate modernity? Does cell phone culture vary globally?

title: The Problem of Meaning: Contemporary Perspectives
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Language and Style
reviews: Great course, great professor!
Take this class.

This course takes a lot of personal initiative, and a good understanging of Italian grammar is a plus.  Weinapple is a great teacher, and if you put the effort in, you should thoroughly enjoy this class.
This is a fantastic course. The work load is sufficient but not too much.
Una classe molto piacevole! Take it if you have the opportunity!
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level Italian course or instructor's permission..
descrip: We will concentrate on the textual analysis of literary texts from the beginning of Italian literature to the present. An intensive grammatical, syntactical, and rhetorical analysis of every piece will be conducted through class discussion. Students will be asked to prepare oral presentations on the authors studied, and to write short papers on each text.

title: War and Society in the Modern World
descrip: The interrelationship of war and society from the 18th century to the nuclear age. Emphasis on the causes, conduct, and consequences of war. Particular attention is given to the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, American Civil War, World War I, and World War II.

title: Architecture and the Visual Arts
reviews: AWESOME CLASS! Spyros is an amazing lecturer. You'll learn a lot and really grasp the material.

Attend all lectures, because they are very interesting and stimulating! I noticed not many students would come to lecture, but I always looked forward to the lectures and thought they were very beneficial to my understanding of the material.
Good Course if you need extra time because of independent work
I really like lecture, not sure what to tell you about precept though...
I would advise other students to take this course.
I would definitely take it. It was inspiring and interesting. If you are interested in architecture and/or the visual arts this course is a must!
I would say if you're interested in art or architecture, or if you aren't sure, please consider taking this course. It gives a great insight to architecture/art from a variety of different ways.
Please do take this course if you're slightly curious abouts arts and architecture. You'd love it!
Take this course
Take this course if you are interested in the topic.
This class is not a lot of work and it gives an new perspective on art and architecture.

This is a good class to take to fulfill a distribution requirement for architecture. It is much more laid back than a lot of architecture classes and the material is very abstract. That being said, it allows for a lot of creative thinking that can be applied to many other subjects. I recommend it!
This is definitely an interesting class for those interested in art and architecture.
Very good course, but it does assume some background knowledge on architecture and arts, but you can still do fine without it, I think.
Very nice and interesting course, definitely take it if interested in architecture.
highly enjoyable and interesting to consider not only architecture but how architecture relates to the visual arts and your every day environment
take it for a fun LA
descrip: This course will explore the relationships between architectural discourse and the visual arts from the historical avant-garde to the present. Architectural discourse will be considered here as the intersection of diverse systems of representation: buildings, projects, drawings, but also architectural theory and criticism, exhibitions, photographs, professional magazines and the popular press. The visual arts will be seen to include not only painting and sculpture, but also photography, cinema, fashion, advertisement and television.

title: Topics in Science Technology and Environmental Policy - Conservation of Endangered Species and Ecosystems
descrip: This course examines the ways in which science has influenced public policy with respect to both endangered species and ecosystems. Important case studies from different regions of the United States are examined in detail, emphasizing the key scientific studies and how they affected decision-making. Topics include the northern spotted owl and the Clinton Administration's Northwest forest plan, the reintroduction of the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park, and the conservation of endangered species on private lands.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: This second half of a two-semester proseminar for first year graduate students in anthropology continues the exploration of major theoretical currents that inform the discipline. This second semester will focus on the relation between theories of human action, consciousness, and disciplinary practices such as fieldwork, participant observation, translation, sense-making, and interpretation. Theorists or theories will often be paired with the reading of an ethnographic account inspired by them.

title: Intermediate Video and Film Production
prereqs: VIS 261 or 262 and instructor's permission. APPLICATION INFORMATION: For students who have taken VIS 261 or VIS 262; there is no interview required; you will apply to state your interest in the course. For those who have not had VIS 261 or 262, please apply and contact Professor Su Friedrich to set up an interview. Please visit the Visual Arts Program website for application information..
descrip: A second level workshop in digital media production. Students complete several videos and view short films and videos each week outside of class. The spring 2011 course will focus on the questions raised when working with music, whether it's hip hop, a Bach concerto or the Ramayana monkey chant. How does it interact with narrative, when can it function as the main audio element, how does the emotion in music affect the emotion in an image, when do lyrics matter, does one always have to edit to the beat, how do we transcend music video cliches, and how and why does music diminish, enhance or otherwise affect our experience of moving images?

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Bodies in Cultural Landscapes
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences II
reviews: Just take it.
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. This is the second of two core geosciences graduate courses.

title: East Asia since 1800
reviews:
-take this if you are interested in modern East Asia
-do all the readings. they are interesting
A very interesting class that has great teachers to lecture!
Always make notes on the course packet articles to use in essays and on exams.
Definitely take it if you have any interest in East Asia.
Do the readings!!

Fantastic class, absolutely recommend it if you're looking for an HA that's not too demanding and/or if you have an interest in East Asia.  I already knew a lot of the things that we discussed in the course from World History, but it was interesting to look at them from the East Asian nations.  This class is fairly straightforward, so there's really nothing super special that should be noted, although I do recommend going to lecture and bringing a laptop since that way you will be able to take down detailed notes on the actual historical context.  I studied off the lecture notes for the midterm and ended up receiving an A just because they were so detailed.  On exams you'll be tested primarily on the history and not so much on the primary sources - that's mostly a precept thing.  But overall, a very good and straightforward class.
Great general history course.

I was quite disappointed about this course and would have taken a course that was specifically about one country if I could choose again. The materials covered may be good for people with no previous backgrounds, but they are almost like summaries you can look up by yourself.
I will recommend taking that for an introduction to modern East Asian
I would recommend the course.
I would strongly recommend taking this course even though it is not easy.
Only take it if your interested in the material or enjoy History.
Stay on top of the paper assignments.
Sure, if you want. There are probably more interesting classes you can take though.
Take it seriously and you will do amazingly well.

Take it! This was a great course, and helped me learn so much about recent Asian history, which is obviously so important in today's world. The workload is not too overwhelming, and Garon is a great lecturer.
Take this class if you want to know a little bit about the big events in East Asia in the last 200 years. If you're looking to get really specific and in detail, pick a different class.
The readings are reasonable and very interesting (although the Pequod is a bit horrifyingly huge at first) and the lectures are good. It's very good if you need to cover an HA.
This class is good if you have time to read and discuss.

This course is a great introductory history course for those interested in East Asia. You really go in-depth. The readings are interesting for the most part since they're mostly personal accounts. The professors are great lecturers. The papers are not too hard.
This is a good introduction to East Asian history but if you are only interested in the history of one of these countries, it may be too broad in scope.

Very reading intensive, not a big workload in terms of papers, but it can be a whole lot of info you're taking in at once sometimes. Satisfying course though if you've got an initial interest in it. If history is not your thing, you can go either way with this course.
When studying for exams, look for themes and connections between the countries.
Writing style is important for all assignments and exams. Be prepared to read and participate. Lectures are engaging.
Yes
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern East Asia. We will examine the inter-related histories of China, Japan, and Korea since 1800 and their relationships with the wider world. Major topics include: trade and cultural exchanges, reform and revolutions, war, colonialism, imperialism, and Cold War geopolitics.

title: Survey of Selected Works of Twentieth-Century Architects
reviews: Entertaining and pretty chill course. Kipnis is such an interesting charater that one should take this course just to have the chance to listen to him every week.
If you've heard anything about Jeff Kipnis, then you will know whether or not you personally want to take this course.  I highly recommend it.
It is very worthwhile if you are engaged.
Take this class.  It will expand your thinking about architecture in interesting ways.
This class, while unusual, is completely worth the time.
Well, you just have to take a Kipnis class.
kipnis is always interesting
descrip: This course is intended to expose the students to a range of major works, built and unbuilt, of architecture from 1950 to the present. This course will focus on these particular buildings as they open themselves to a textual analysis. These analyses are intended to open up issues such as criticality, autonomy and singularity as they begin to evolve in architectural building (as opposed to texts) in the last half of the 20th century. This course will concentrate on individual buildings not architects. Each analysis will be accompanied by an illustrated presentation and selected readings.

title: Foundations of Political Economy
descrip: Course focuses on modeling the interaction of politics and economics, with applications to a variety of substantive areas. Topics include: poltics of taxation and redistribution; governmental structure, political economy of constitutional arrangements, development, and growth. Familiarity with microeconomic theory and POL 575 or the equivalent are prerequisites.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Averting the US Fiscal Crisis
descrip: With the federal budget recording unprecedented deficits and rapidly escalating debt, a US fiscal crisis may be near. This course will begin with a brief review of the facts and politics of the current budget situation. The focus will then be on evaluating the most significant proposals, from across the political spectrum, to bring the budget closer to balance, including whatever emerges in the forthcoming (Dec 2010) report of the President's bipartisan Fiscal Commission.

title: Advanced German
reviews: Don't be afraid to participate.

I urge you to keep Jamie Rankin's goal of the book close to heart- you must do a lot of independent work to really learn the language. Look up words independently, and develop your own personal lexicon. It is one thing to do well on vocabulary tests and essays and another to really learn the language!
If you're already taking German, go ahead and finish it out for the distribution, but I haven't been terribly impressed with Princeton's German department.

If you're interested in learning German, this is the way to go. A decent amount of work, but you'll really improve. Tons of opportunity to speak in class. Probably one of the less demanding languages with which to fill the requirement too.
It was good. Take it.
if you need a refresher, this is a stress-free, enjoyable course that should refine your german skills
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor. Classes conducted in German..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using film, digital media, and literary texts as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: A very different class from any other at Princeton, but be prepared to set your own agenda even if you don't really know what needs to get done.
As an engineer, this was an awesome class that gave me insight into a real-world design problem. The class was a great experience.

I was on the team designing a power system for disaster relief, so your mileage may vary. In our case, second semester was mostly student-driven with all kinds of integration across disciplines, so if you're not good at working on a team, this is not be the course for you. Additionally, I would warn CBE majors against expecting anything even remotely relevant to the courses they've taken thus far. Nonetheless, the course has taught me a lot, and I suggest that anyone tired of book learning give this course a spin.

Take EPICS if you want the chance to apply your classroom learning in a hands-on way. It was one of my favorite classes at Princeton and definitely my favorite engineering class. You get to build things that matter and become very close to your classmates and professors. Join the Haiti team!
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The American Political System
descrip: An examination of political institutions and the study of political institutions focused on the United States. Provides an overview of the various problems for which institutional solutions are sought (e.g., problems involving collective action, delegation, and social choice) as well as a detailed assessment of some of the scholarly literature that investigates political institutions. We will cover executive, judicial, and legislative politics, but the course may focus more heavily on legislative institutions and politics given the instructor's expertise.

title: Athens and Jerusalem: Philosophical, Theological, and Political Implications
descrip: This course explores the meanings and implications of claims that "Athens" and "Jerusalem" constitute the two poles of Western Civilization. Focusing on classical and pre-modern philosophical, literary, and religious texts, the first part of the course considers the history of the distinction between Athens and Jerusalem for understanding different conceptions of reason, revelation, justice, evil, and free will. The second part of the course turns to modern political appropriations of "Athens and Jerusalem" in arguments about the meanings of modernity, social justice, multiculturalism and higher education, and definitions of the "West."

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Domestic Policy
descrip: Examines a series of major issues of policy designed to illustrate and develop skills in particularly important applications of microeconomics. Topics will include education and training, the minimum wage, mandated benefits, affirmative action, the theory of public goods and externalities, and the basic theory of taxation. Prerequisite: 511b.

title: Expanding British History 1700-1830: Nations, States and Empires
descrip: This reading course situates 18th and early 19th century British and Irish history in a broader European and global setting. It addresses issues of war and competing nationalisms; Britain's role as a European power, in an Atlantic community; as a constitutional model; and the changing domestic and international impact of the British Empire.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Modern China
reviews: It is a course I would like to recommend to anyone who is interested in modern Chinese history.
descrip: This seminar introduces students to major historiographical and methodological issues in twentieth-century Chinese history, with emphasis on the Republican period. Topics reflect theoretical debates and empirical questions, including: nationalism and citizenship, urban life, gender and sexuality, the Communist revolution, early PRC history.

title: Fourier Analysis on Euclidean Spaces
descrip: Two topics will be dealt with: Several developments in the theory of singular integrals. Also, the application of oscillatory integrals to generalized Radon-transforms and to existence theorems for some non-linear Schrodinger equations.

title: Field Ecohydrology
reviews: Great class. Highly recommend it.
I recommend having some background in Matlab before starting this course! It is necessary for the first assignment, and would be helpful for the others.
Take this course, but take it seriously. It starts moving fast so the more engaged you are from the get go the better it will go for you. Don't be afraid to ask questions!
prereqs: MAT 201.
descrip: This three-week course, offered as part of a four-course study abroad semester, takes place at Princeton University's Mpala Research Centre in central Kenya. The course will provide an introduction to the principles of hydrological sciences through the development and application of instrumentation for characterizing surface/subsurface hydrological dynamics in field settings. Lectures and field activities will address the theory of operation, design, and implementation of methods used to quantify hydrological patterns and processes.

title: Oil, Energy and The Middle East
descrip: An overview of the issues surrounding global energy supplies, oil's unique economic properties, and its role in shaping the political economy of the Middle East and U.S. strategic interests in the region. We will begin by discussing the basic science and availability of energy sources, the state of technology, the functioning of energy markets, the challenges of coping with global climate change and the key role of the oil reserves in the Middle East. The second part of the course will focus on the history of oil in the Middle East and its impact on societies in the region.

title: Introduction to Black Queer Studies: Queer Aesthetics in the Black Diaspora
descrip: This interdisciplinary course explores over two decades of work produced by and about black queer subjects throughout the circum-Atlantic world. While providing an introduction to various artists and intellectuals of the black queer diaspora, this seminar examines the distinct socio-cultural, historical, and geographical contexts in which "black queerness" as a concept is embraced or contested. We will use the prism of artistry to highlight the dynamic relationship between Black Diaspora and Queer Studies.

title: Secession, Civil War, and the Constitution
descrip: Examines the Constitutional issues raised by the American Civil War, beginning with nullification and secession, and surveying the presidential war powers, emancipation, confiscation, war crimes, international law, and the contrasting constitutions of the U.S. and Confederate states.

title: The Universe
reviews: A great and eye-opening class, but be prepared to work hard.
A relatively painless way of doing your QR.  There are a number of very cool moments that let you contemplate the awesomeness of the universe, if that's your thing.

As an engineer, I still found the problem sets really annoying. They take forever to do. It's not difficult, but it takes a while to explain everything in FULL sentences. It seems stupid sometimes because it's just stoichiometry, but somehow I have to explain unit conversions in words? 

The lectures aren't that great (most people stopped going), and I think that if you're just looking for a fun, easy class, taking a psychology/philosophy course would be better. Although I took this class because I didn't want to write papers, in retrospect maybe it was better to just take a course with 2 short papers instead of one with several time-consuming problem sets.
Definitely take this class.
Depends on if you're looking for a good easy class.
Do it!
Do not take it.
Do you REALLY like stars? Do you like math? If yes and yes, then perhaps this course is for you. Otherwise, don't be fooled by people suggesting it's an easy way out of a QR. It really isn't.
Don't take it because it is easy but it is interesting.
Easy course for those familiar with algebra.

Final word, the course material is too easy (no calc, formulas given, etc) to have a good curve, so the solution is to nickel and dime you to death with ridiculous point reductions.

If you are an absolute retard with math, but love writing paragraphs about 2 lines of computation, then take this class. Otherwise, there are more meaningful was to get a B

Go to class, especially in the first half because it's really interesting and not everything is covered in the notes provided

work on p-sets early so you can get help from TAs if needed

Go to office hours if you don't know what you're doing. I can tell you if you don't know what you're doing, you need to get help. Lectures are interesting, but your class attendance will not be reflected in your homework grades necessarily.
Good class for understanding more about the universe and the solar system.
Great class.
I would consider it a moral failure to allow a humanities friend to take this course without doing everything humanly possible to warn them about it.

I would recommend this class if you are looking for an easy QR, or if you're like me, a senior who needs to take a class that doesn't invovle much effort.  However, this isn't to say that the subject matter isn't interesting.  It is!  So really it has that and the fact that it's easy going for it.

I would recommend this class-- its interesting and fun, and an easy way to take care of the QR credit if your not big on math. The professors were great overall, and the fact that there are three lecture series is interesting.
If you are naturally talented in physics, you will do fine. If you don't like physics in the least, this class is not for you.

If you know some physics/math, this course will be pretty easy for you, although not 100% intuitive. However, with just a little bit of work (about 5 hours/problem set), you should be able to get above 95 on psets, and do pretty well on miterms. You shouldn't waste this easy course for PDF.

If you need a QR and have ANY interest in astronomy, this is a great class to take. If you do take the course, make sure you get a book. Although you don't technically need it, the book can be very helpful if you get stuck on problem sets.
If you need an easy QR, sure take it.

If you need to take a QR and aren't great at math this is fine. The lectures are awful and the problem sets and exams are harder than I expected them to be. This is an extremely easy PDF and relatively easy if you are taking it for a grade. I still wouldn't take it, because it is intensely boring.
If you're looking for an "easy" QR, this isn't it. It's not geared towards students who don't enjoy physics, but otherwise, the theory behind everything is fascinating.
If you're not gonna take it p/d/f or your not gonna be an astrophysicists, don't take it
If you've taken some physics in high school, this course will be manageable. Do the problem sets early, and with a friend.
Interesting material, not hard if you have had any math or science before.
It is not as easy as it used to be

It's good stuff to know, and works well as a QR if you need to get one out of the way anyway, but the lectures can be fairly long.  The problem sets are more difficult than I expected.  I'd recommend it, but it's by no means the best course I've taken at Princeton.
It's ok if you need a QR, but you will hate all the higher-math and engineering kids who should be in a higher level and will kill the exam curve
Light work load, often interesting lectures
Much tougher than anticipated. Problem sets took  a fair amount of time and the exams were in no way easy.
Not a good QA, not as interesting as it sounds and the problem sets are very difficult.
Not as easy as everyone says.
Not exactly stars for stoners, but if you have an engineering friend that you can work on problems sets with, you'll be fine.
Problem sets are super easy if you're an engineer. I'd recommend it if you're looking for an easy class
Read the lecture notes to learn the non-quantitative stuff. If you're an engineering, it'll be so easy.

Really easy.  The problem sets take longer than expected because you have to perform the same calculations over and over and show a bunch of work, but that is to be expected in a class like this.  The professors post all the lectures online, which means class attendance is very much optional.  The material is interesting, as descriptive science often is, but lectures are incredibly slow (so read the lecture notes instead!).
Take it for a QR, not stars for stoners like advertised but be prepared to study and spend a good amount of time on the problem sets
Take it if you are interested in astronomy.
Take it please.
The course is OK. There are better QRs out there, and it is NOT that easy.
This class is often called "Stars for Stoners" amongst undergraduates, but it is much harder than the name would imply. Be wary, especially if you struggle with math and the sciences.

This course may have a reputation for being "easy" but the work is actually quite rigorous if you want an A. HW help sessions are extremely useful for completing assignments, which in my experience took around 5-6 hours w/o assistance.

This is a great course if you are interested in the creation of the universe and learning about space.   It is not a heavy workload so even for those with little math or science experience this class is a nice break.
This is a perfect class to take if you just want to take up a class slot.

This is not a good class to take to fulfill a requirement as problem sets are not explained in class.  Always go for extra help.  The professors are all very interesting and nice. Most TAs are willing to help.
This is not an easy cake-walk class, and do not take it for credit expecting an easy A.  It is probably a good PDF class if you are generally interested and I wish now that I had PDFd.
Very hard math for a non math concentrated student
Very interesting material. Professor Spitkovsky is the best.
While not as easy as some may think, if you have any scientific background getting an A should not be a problem.

Worth taking. Technically the material covered in this course is the only important thing you can learn at Princeton since it shows how insignificant your life is compared to the Cosmos. I'm taking it on PDF which makes it less stressful since the median on the HW's is a 95. But its relatively easy to get into the A range if you study a lot for the midterm since there is a wide distribution of grades on the tests.
be good at math
might as well
perhaps not a class to take for a requirement as it does require some interest

the problem sets are impossible to access for people without quantitative backgrounds and the lectures/review sessions don't do a good job to prepare you for them. there are no precepts, so it's very difficult to learn the material through the course itself. Unfortunately, the class is also filled with many science/math people trying to get an easy A, so it throws off the course curve. The midterm is too long for the allotted time, so many people fail miserable. I would STRONGLY recommend against taking this course to satisfy a QR.
prereqs: This course is intended for humanities and social science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This specially designed course targets the frontier of modern astrophysics. Subjects include the planets of our solar system, the birth, life, and death of stars; the search for extrasolar planets and extraterrestrial life; the zoo of galaxies from dwarfs to giants, from starbursts to quasars; dark matter and the large-scale structure of the universe; Einstein's special and general theory of relativity, black holes, neutron stars, and big bang cosmology. This course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. High school physics would be useful.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Seminar in Sustainable Development
prereqs: Calculus at least at the level of MAT 104, familiarity with statistical inference and regression (at least one of ECO 202, ECO 302, ECO 312, ECO313, MAT 310, EGR 245), microeconomics at least at the level of ECO 100..
descrip: This course will use economic theory and statistical methods to analyze the environmental problems of the developing world. We will discuss the meaning of sustainability, the relation between population, poverty, and the environment, social norms and common property resource governance both local and global, the impact of international trade on the environment, the implications of climate change for development, the design of climate policy, environmental rat races, how to achieve international cooperation on environmental issues, and policies for regulating pollution in the developing world.

title: Stars and Star Formation
reviews: I would definitely recommend taking this course -- I hope Jill continues to teach it!

Like most astro departmentals, this is a more interesting and laid-back course than your average physics course.  There's no reason not to take it as an astro major, and as a physics major it would be a cool topic to learn on the side.
Make sure to attend lecture.
The lectures lead to a much-improved understanding of star formation. The problem sets are interesting, although not always directly related to the questions posed in lecture.
descrip: Stars form by the gravitational collapse of interstellar gas clouds, and as they evolve, return some of their gas to the interstellar medium, altering its physical state and chemical composition. This course discusses the properties and evolution of the gaseous and stellar components of a galaxy: the theory and observations of star formation; stellar structure; the production of energy by nucleosynthesis; stellar evolution; stellar end states; and the interpretation of observations of the diffuse and dense interstellar medium. We will discuss how major telescopes and space missions might tackle these problems.

title: Intermediate Turkish II
reviews: I would recommend students keep up with the steady stream of assignments or else they might get overwhelmed. It's a good pace, but could be easy to fall behind.

If you have had any contact with Turkish before, or are just interested in taking a less commonly taught language - DO IT!!! It's a great language, and it's taught in an excellent manner - you'll have fun and learn about lots of other things (culture, literature, politics, history) at the same time. Prof Gilson has developed an excellent language pedagogical style, and you'll find yourself being pushed at a good pace to develop all aspects of your linguistics skills. Most of all, she just really wants you to learn the language, and you'll benefit immensely from her enthusiasm and never-ending patience in this regard.
Make sure that you understand everything you read, and consistently ask questions.
prereqs: TUR 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To enable students to communicate in Modern Turkish, and to read Turkish (current events, editorials, literature and academic writings) with some speed and accuracy.

title: 20th-Century French Narrative Prose - Albert Camus: Writing in Motion
descrip: We will examine the works and figure of Albert Camus - to redefine them. Through the study of his most acclaimed narratives, plays, essays, but also his more obscure juvenilia, notebooks, and up to his last, unfinished novel, we will see what confirms the canonical (sometimes sanctified) dimension of Camus, and what challenges it. Looking at his critical reception and his own assessments, we will assess his greatest accomplishments, his shortcomings and even (self-proclaimed) failures. Always in between, eternally moving, we will reconsider Camus as concerned as much by politics as he was by poetics.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: Study of selected passages from various genres of Syriac literature. Knowledge of Syriac is required.

title: Advanced Comparative Political Economy
descrip: A broad introduction to the state of the art of the research in formal comparative political economy (CPE), in which the topic of the economic role and of the economic origin of political institutions is perhaps the most central. A number of models are viewed in detail, discussing their substantive results and how the models can improve our understanding of important questions of comparative political economy.

title: Senior Thesis with Design
descrip: Similar to 442 with the principle difference that the thesis must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior thesis with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Witnessing War
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Financial Management in the Corporate and Public Sectors
descrip: Designed to introduce graduate students in public and international affairs to certain principals and analytic tools widely used in the financial management of organizations, privately or publicly owned. Course is based on the premise that future civil servants should be familiar with this subject matter, either because they may be involved in the financial management of public agencies, or negotiate financial contracts with the private sector, or regulate financial management in the private sector.

title: Architectural Sculpture and Sacred Space in Greece
descrip: Recent studies have examined Greek architectural sculpture through the lens of socio-political relations. This course will evaluate how and when (if ever) the sculpture assumes such an allegorical character. It will seek in particular to discover an approach that can integrate architectural sculpture more coherently into the materiality of sacred space. The seminar will address the issues of space and landscape; religious ritual; votive dedications; temple decoration and ornamentation; and agency. It will then turn to several case studies from the late Archaic and Classical periods.

title: Integrated Building Studios
reviews: Go for it.
Take the course.
descrip: Integrated design studios approach architecture from a synthetic perspective. Considerations of structure, environmental technology, building materials and systems, exterior envelope, and site design are integrated directly into the design process through the participation of technical faculty and outside advisors in critiques and reviews. Projects are developed to a high level of detail. At least one course is required for professional M.Arch. students.

title: Southeast Asia's Global History
reviews: Definitely take this course.  It's one of the best I have taken at Princeton.
I would highly recommend students interested in Southeast Asia to take this course.
If I were to take this course again, I would strongly consider meeting with Prof. Laffan often. He is very approachable and is totally willing to clarify any uncertainties in the material.
If you have even a slight interest in the area, definitely take it. Laffan is the man.

It is an excellent course for anyone interested in the region. It requires work but is not excessively challenging. It gave me a strong appreciation for a part of the world I had known very little about prior to the course.
Take it.
descrip: This course aims to provide an introduction to Southeast Asia and its prominent place in global history through a series of encounters in time; from Marco Polo in Sumatra to the latest events in such buzzing cities as Bangkok, Jakarta and Hanoi. For the early modern period we will read various primary sources, before turning to consider a series of diverse colonial impacts across the region (European, American and Asian), and then the mechanisms underpinning the formation of some of the most vibrant, and sometimes turbulent, countries on the world stage.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Accounting
reviews: Don't expect to learn much from this course.
I would not recommend this class.
Most students have to take it. It takes a while to adjust to the speaking volume, pace, and accent of the teacher, but otherwise its fine.
get some accounting background before would be better
descrip: Major topics in modern corporate finance. We will study investment policy (investment decision rules, project valuation, cost of capital) and financial policy (mostly capital structure decisions). Additional topics (private equity, bankruptcy and reorganization, merger and acquisitions) will be covered if time permits.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Nonlinear Models
reviews: This course requires a lot of time, but the professors really do care about you learning and are patient when they know you are trying but have trouble understanding something. Ask questions if you don't understand!
descrip: This is half of the second-year sequence in econometrics methodology (ECO 513 is the other). The course covers nonlinear statistical models for the analysis of cross-sectional and panel data. It is intended both for students specializing in econometric theory and for students interested in applying statistical methods to statistical data. Approximately half of the course is devoted to development of the large-sample theory for nonlinear estimation procedures, while the other half concentrates on application of the methods to various econometric models.

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: Arabic is both a great program and a supportive student community. I would highly recommend this course.

Do not take Arabic--it's a beautiful language, so important to learn, such a rich body of literature and writing, but the program at Princeton needs so much improvement I feel like I have wasted two years of classes by studying Arabic.

Don't be discouraged by the poor quality of the lower level Arabic classes--upper level teachers are supposed to be much better. Just be cautious about which teachers you have and base your decision on your desire to learn the language rather than on the teacher. I'm very much looking forward to having Hisham next fall.
If you are interested in Arabic, I am certain this class is right for you.
It really helps you learn Fusha but doesn't teach you to speak well. take colloquial for that.
My advice is to take Arabic courses with Tarek Elsayed, never with George Hatke.
Study vocabulary on your own often; class does not give you enough practice with the vocab.
Take 2nd year Arabic abroad during the summer unless a better professor comes!
Take if you are willing to put in a lot of time.  Don't expect to improve much unless you take a lot on outside of class.
Take it with Tarek; you'll learn a lot and be entertained.
Take it!
Tarek is excellent at helping you learn to speak the language

Well, you've made it this far, so you kind of have to finish... Your Arabic will get better just by virtue of spending another semester on it, but it will be a terrible experience, and you won't get much out of classes or drill.
prereqs: ARA 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Study of Arabic grammar and syntax, and use of the language in functional contexts. Reading of extra material from articles, newspapers, short stories. Discussions are held in the Arabic language to enhance the students' speaking skills.

title: Elementary Modern Greek II
prereqs: HLS 101 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: To provide the basis for acquiring a command of written and spoken Modern Greek.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - Grand Strategy
prereqs: Some knowledge of U.S. European, and/or Asian history is essential, though there are no prerequisite courses..
descrip: Military strategy was defined by Clausewitz as the use of battle to achieve the objectives of war. Grand strategy is broader, encompassing the attempted use by political leaders of financial, economic, and diplomatic, as well as military, power to achieve their objectives in peacetime and in war. This seminar will examine the theory and practice of grand strategy both to illuminate how relations among city-states, empires, kingdoms and nation states have evolved over the centuries and also to identify some common challenges that have confronted all who seek to make and execute grand strategy, from Pericles to Barack Obama.

title: Social Structure in Africa: Responses to Socio-Political and Economic Forces Since Independence
reviews: Definitely take this class.  Very informative, nice professor, and interesting topics.

Don't take this. The discussions and readings are really boring, and you just focus on tiny snapshots of the issues without any context. Whether or not you have a background in Africa, you won't learn much. If you're interested in Africa, try Politics in Africa instead.
Recommended if pursuing a certificate in African studies or if you just want to get a better sense of some issues in Africa in a seminar setting.

The work is manageable, the professor is knowledgeable, the papers are quite reasonable, and the breadth of topics is astounding and fascinating!  I would recommend it to anyone with interest in Africa, whether or not he or she has had experience there.

This class is certainly accessible to people with or without a background in Africa, but it is definitely helpful to have some sort of historical or political understanding--although, this can be said for any class, I suppose.
This class was not too much work and gives a good overview of African studies.
This course is very interesting as long as you do the readings.  The entire class hinges on how well you understood the readings, and, although they are long, they are very well selected.
prereqs: No previous knowledge of Africa is required..
descrip: The seminar addresses structural consequences and responses that African nations and communities developed upon their insertion into global political and economic practice. Africa's character before modern nationhood forms the backdrop to discussions of the development and utilization of social, political and economic strategies for continued participation in global political and economic intercourse. Themes include traditional and contemporary political structures; religious practice and the church; global economic interactions; African interstate relations; governance and regime change; wars and displacement; and women in society.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
prereqs: High school math will be used extensively..
descrip: Introduction to strategic issues in politics. After a brief introduction to game theory, we will look in depth at voting, collective action, deliberation, and deterrence.

title: Intermediate Chinese II
reviews: Be prepared to devote a lot of time to this class. The teachers are great though and you will really learn the language.
CHI 107 is a well-organized and well-taught course. The workload is manageable if you are willing to invest some time in it every day and stay on top of the grammar and vocabulary.
DO NOT DO IT UNLESS YOU ARE BASICALLY FLUENT IN CHINESE

Definitely take this course.  Princeton's Chinese language department is the best in the country, and my own experiences have proved it.  Taking Chinese in Princeton will develop your speaking, writing, and reading skills, and you learn more about China's culture and current development.  Most importantly, the instructing team is amazing and you get to know some of your teachers really well.

Do NOT take Chinese unless you are willing to put in a lot of grunt work. It'll pay off if you're diligent, but it isn't painless. Balancing with other obligations can be difficult with restricted schedule flexibility.
Fun class! Just make sure you can devote some time to it. =)
Hao hao xue xi, tian tian xiang shang!
Make sure you have enough time in your schedule and the interest...but if you have both, then there's no better place to learn chinese then here!
TAKE THIS CLASS!!! The professors are wonderful!
Take it if you are interested in continuing the study of Chinese. It's about what you'd expect if you've taken first-year here, otherwise, it's going to seem pretty intense at first.

The Chinese Program at Princeton University is one of the best in the world, due to the structure and the high quality of the instructors. I highly recommend all this program has to offer its students.

The course is very time consuming but that comes along with trying to learn the Chinese language. The hard work does pay off, though, if you ask for help when you need it and put effort into your learning.
This course is a lot of work, with classes and homework assignments almost every day. However, it is totally worth it if you are committed to greatly improving your Chinese language skills.

This course takes a consistent level of preparation and effort every week, and it can be demanding (especially towards the end of the semester) to keep up with the vocabulary and the grammar patterns. However, as long as you put in the effort, your Chinese skills will improve dramatically.
You have to take it....
You know if you want to take this
definitely take it, but be aware that there is a substantial amount of work and time that is associated with it. however, it is definitely manageable.
difficult class but fun and useful
prereqs: CHI 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Continuing the intensive study of modern spoken and written Chinese, this course shifts the emphasis to the reading of modern cultural and social issues.

title: Quantitative Analysis IV
descrip: An introduction to the basic analytical and computational tools of applied Bayesian statistics. Methods covered include multi-level models, mixture modeling, Bayesian model averaging, and models for missing data and causal inference; computational tools taught include the EM algorithm and the Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms. Goal of the course is to enable students to build and implement their own model in order to answer a particular research question. Course may be of interest to those in disciplines outside of political science who need to learn the basics of applied Bayesian statistics.

title: Conspiracy Theories as a Cultural Practice
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Macroeconomics
reviews: "I guess you have no choice if you're an econ major."
Absolutely terrible Professor. Structure of class was boring, and we barely talked about relevant macro theories.
By the time you take this class, you'll probably have a different professor. But if you can, take 301. You'll learn more.
Don't take it unless you're an economics major.
Don't take this course unless you have to.
Go to lectures and do the readings and the course becomes pretty straightforward. If you understand graphs well, you'll be fine.
Go to lectures, go to precepts, very manageable!

I didn't enjoy this class because of the professor, but she's only visiting so you should be in the clear in the future. The book was the most helpful part of preparing for exams. Of course, if you are doing non-math track Econ as a major, you don't have much of a choice regardless.
I enjoyed this class.
I would consider taking ECO 311...
I would not recommend this class to someone unless they need to take it or are really interested in economics.
If a different professor is teaching it then it is probably worth taking, but if this professor ever teaches it again you need to STAY AWAY and take it a different semester.

If you're considering doing any sort of higher level economics, you've got to take it, so...  But if you're just interested in learning about macroeconomics, then this isn't the course for you.  101 Macro covered real-world applications much more often (instead of always abstract problems here).
Interesting subject matter, but depends entirely on the instructor
It is a good class to take if you want a macroecon perspective. And if you are not an econ major (like me), I suggest taking this class over eco101.
Just make sure to understand concepts.  You don't have to attend all lectures and do all the readings, but it's important to understand concepts and put them into practice in this course.
Lectures aren't necessary. Just know the book readings.
Material is interesting and I would take it again as long as there was a different professor.
Most of you are taking this because you have to anyway. It's always a visiting lecturer so it's hit or miss. Good luck.
Nothing special about this course, but nonetheless a good course
Only take it if you a) are majoring in Econ, b) really like Econ. The lectures are not spectacular, but if you read the book and understand the problem sets you should be okay.
Pretty typical for a general economics course - I probably wouldn't have stuck with it if it weren't a departmental, though, since the material isn't particularly involved yet.
Read the book and do practice problems.
Read the textbook and do the practice problems from the textbook.
Sucks that you have to deal with this bucket of nonsense.
Take it for the departmental but also because the materials covered are relevant and interesting
Take it only if you have to.
Take this course if you have a keen interest in economics or need to for departmental reasons.
Take this course if you want a fun and painless macro course.
Take time on the problem sets.

This is a good class if you need Macro or if you want to have a good economics base. The class isn't curved, however, and the tests are hard, so if you don't need it, I would recommend another economics class.
Tough grading curve. Useful, but only take if you really like ECO and are pretty good unless it is required.
Yan Bai pretty much goes according to the textbook with exams involving more critical thinking than what you see in problem sets and lectures.
You have to take it.
You learn a bit and don't work too much.
You need to check psets with one or two people to make sure you're doing things right. Helps with the learning process too.
You'll have a different professor so this field is irrelevant.
if you need to take it, take it. if you're doing it out of general interest or because you feel like you should take an economics class, take the eco100 or eco101.
never take the class with this professor
pretty good class
read the book
solid course. not too exciting, but well taught.
take it!
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: This course covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. We will focus on the determination of macroeconomic variables -- such as output, employment, price, and the interest rate -- in the short, medium, and long run, and we will address a number of policy issues. We will discuss several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Contemporary Society, Politics, and Culture
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: Through literature, film, historical documents, and journalism, this course surveys issues and events in German politics, society, and culture from the fall of the Third Reich to the end of the twentieth century. Topics include: the aftermath of WWII (Stunde Null); the founding of both German Republics; the economic miracle (Wirtschaftswunder, Gastarbeiter); the legacy of National Socialism; attempts to define a new Germany; the student revolts; and reunification. In addition to providing an introduction to post-war Germany, this course aims to facilitate advanced competence in written and oral German.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Chemical Dynamics and Thermodynamics
reviews: Thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and chemical kinetics. AWESOME quantitative treatment, important if you want to go to grad school. Even if her lecture style is lacking, Wang's lectures present all the material in a nice, logical manner, making it easy to understand.

CHM 406 is not to be taken lightly: to do well will require sustained and concerted effort throughout the semester. However, you will come away with a deeper appreciation for the fundamentals of thermodynamics, which will be immeasurably useful in your future chemistry endeavors.

I took CHE thermodynamics before this class, so a good deal of it was familiar. To someone who hasn't taken thermodynamics before, this class is not a particularly gentle introduction. All the same, Professor Wang is a great teacher, and makes the subject matter very comprehensible. If you don't like calculus and slightly tedious differentials, this class may not be for you; but for me it helped flesh out my understanding beyond the fairly superficial treatment of thermodynamics I received previously.
Think twice before taking this course with Wang. She still has a ways to improve before being a capable teacher.
prereqs: MAT 201 or equivalent. Some knowledge of thermodynamics is useful..
descrip: This course is an introduction to statistical thermodynamics, kinetics, and molecular reaction dynamics. Following a review of classical thermodynamics, the statistical mechanics of molecular systems is developed. Discussions of transport properties, chemical kinetics, and reaction dynamics form the rest of the course.

title: American Religious History Workshop
prereqs: REL 523.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Topics in American Literature - The Supernatural in American Literature
reviews: Consider not taking the course, unless you have no other options for the American Foundation class. Especially don't take this course if you're a freshman considering majoring in English. It might turn you off from the department, but most English classes aren't like this.
I really enjoyed it. I would take it.
If you are interested in American religious texts and early American literature, its a really great course.
If you like early American literature and the supernatural, go for it.
Strongly recommend for English majors
Take this class!  Professor Rivett is so nice!
Take this class.  Professor Rivett is great!
descrip: The 1692 Salem witch trials defied rational explanation. How does one reconcile invisible specters flitting through the night or inflicting harm on young girls with religious orthodoxy and scientific modernity? Beginning with the crisis exposed by Salem, this course charts how a supernatural domain of sleepwalking, ghosts, and transcendence persists throughout American literary history. We read novels about Salem alongside the more general appearance of supernatural phenomena in slave narratives, Native American prophecies, and ghost stories. Oscillating between spirit and matter, the supernatural interrogates what haunts America.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Intermediate)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth. This intermediate version will assume familiarity and comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. Seminar aims at assisting students in their research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. Meets for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Rituals, Songs, and Stories: Balkan and East European Oral Traditions
descrip: This course explores oral traditions and oral literary genres (in English translation) of the Balkan and East European world, both past and present. Topics include traditional rituals (life-cycle and seasonal) and the music and song associated with them, contemporary forms of traditional and popular culture, and oral traditional narrative: prose (folktale and legend) and poetry (epic and ballad). Discussion and analysis will focus on the roles and meanings of Balkan and East European oral traditions as forms of expressive culture.

title: The Great Recession: Causes, Consequences, and Remedies
reviews: A good course.  Worth taking (though perhaps not at 9 AM).
Definitely take the course. Don't miss lectures and take really good notes.
Definitely take this course, you will learn alot about the recession as well as how to prevent future ones. Do attend lectures and read your notes!
Do the readings. Go to lecture. Certainly go to precepts.
I would advise students to attend all of Professor Krueger's lectures, as they were all fascinating, and I would have regretted missing any of them.

If (and whenever) Krueger teaches a course, and you are remotely interested in the topic, TAKE IT. He's a  SUPER smart (   cute) guy who is just great at what he does. Lectures were amazing and something I looked forward to - even though they were 9 AM, I was never tempted to sleep through them (I kicked myself the couple of times I inadvertently did). Great at explaining stuff, very knowledgeable, super sharp, and super boss. His anecdotes (and pictures) from the white house were great too. If this is taught again, TAKE IT! You won't regret it - YOU WILL LOVE IT. The course wasn't a ton of work - although you do have a dean's date paper, the weekly assignments are very manageable and the precepts are fun (at least if you have a good preceptor). TAKE IT!!!
Informative course to learn about the recent financial crisis
It's a good class to take if you want a survey of exactly what happened in 2008 and 2009.
It's a very good course to understand what happened in during the financial crisis.
Must-take if you're interested in the recent financial crisis.
Not bad...but probably not as good as you're hoping.
TAKE IT.
Take it
Take it if you are macro person.
Take it take it take it! Krueger's simply awesome. If you can, get Gonzalo's precept, because he's a boss.
Take it!
Take it! Do the readings, even if they are long and difficult--there is a wealth of information in them. And go to every lecture and precept, they are fascinating.
Take it, great class and relatively easy class that non-econ/woody woo majors can take

Take it, hands down! It was one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Professor Krueger is absolutely fantastic and you'll really learn all about how our economy got into the mess it did. A truly terrific course. Midterm, problem sets, and final paper were all fair, thought-provoking, and well-designed. Precepts had great discussion, too.
Take the class. Pay good attention and take notes, not sure how grading is yet, since a lot of grade was determined from exam and paper.
Take this class.  You will learn so much about our country just by going to lectures.

Take this course! Especially if Krueger is teaching it. It is not a technical econ-course by any means, and it is so informative about where we are today and what has been happening in the recent years.

This is a great and extremely relevant class. It's a departmental elective, so it isn't very challenging. Professor Krueger is a great lecturer, and the preceptors all really know their stuff, and can relate it in an interesting way.

This is a great course. Professor Krueger is a wonderful lecturer and the material is engaging. This course is more about policies and the history of the recent financial crisis, so don't expect there to be too many (or any) mathematical models.
This is a really good course if you don't know much about the Great Recession and want to learn.
This is not your typical econ course - it's more history and policy than theory and modeling. Professor Krueger is a great teacher and this is a great opportunity to learn from him.
Very good course.  My preceptor was the only disappointing component, and he is graduating.
Very good course. The professor is very knowledgeable.
Very good to understand what happened in our economy and very interesting.
Worth waking up at 9am to take!
take it! ratings might be low this year cos it's the first time but it will def improve
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101 and ECO 202.
descrip: This course covers topics related to the current economy and current economic policy. The course will begin by reviewing the causes of the recession that began in December 2007. It will concentrate on consumer behavior, financial markets, unemployment, and the housing sector. The role of public policies in contributing to the economic crisis and in ending the crisis will be explored. The state of the recovery will be assessed and monitored. The course will also consider current economic policy priorities.

title: Music in the Renaissance
reviews: It is a great course, and you learn a lot about historiography through the lens of Renaissance music. You also learn how to differentiate between subtly different types of music, which is awesome. If you are interested in those topics, you will enjoy it!
It's a great opportunity to learn of music from an era we typically hear so little about.
Take it if you like music and history.
This course is really fantastic and  great way for people to engage with this music, whether they are a seasoned musician or new to the field.

You do not need to be a music major to take and benefit from this course.  A general knowledge of reading music is, however, helpful.  You would have a large learning curve if you did not have any previous knowledge of music.  However, this is not a musical analysis or composition course, it is a history of music class.
descrip: General historical survey of European Art Music in the period 1400-1600, covering such composers as Dufay, Ockeghem, Josquin, Byrd, Palestrina, Lasso, etc.

title: Comparative Physiology
reviews: Attend the lectures because you learned a lot and dont want to miss the material. Also, make sure you practice locating structure in lab before you take the exams.
Best class I've taken so far at Princeton. Definitely take it if you're premed. You get to pet a rhino.
Definitely take this class!  The lectures are fun, the labs are fun, and the professor is amazing!
Dissections are interesting/cool. Enjoy the trip to Great Adventure Safari! You don't really need to do any reading.
I don't think that anyone involved in the course this year will be involved next year, but this was an excellent class and it has a great record over the years.
I would take this class without any reservations.  It was wonderful, and my only complaint was that it was too simple at times.
If it's still being offered, TAKE IT! It isn't too much work, the lab is amazing. Really interesting stuff, too.
If offered, take it! Dissections are fun and you learn so much about how exactly the bodies of animals look and function.
If you can memorize things to some extent, this class will be fun, though you can't slack on the lab material.
It's not bad, though a bit basic.  Though, with Cassandra leaving, it may be different.
My advice: do not take this course.  If you are interested in the evolution of animal forms, find a book about it.  You will learn much more than you ever would by taking this class.
Show up for lecture because there is a lot of material the professor adds that isn't necessarily on the slides.
Take this class

You probably don't need to do the readings - I didn't, and I did fine. Pay attention and take notes during the movies. Find a good lab partner, and do the labs thoroughly - they're actually a lot of fun.
loved it!
there'll be a different professor next year
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: This course explores the mechanisms of animal function in the contexts of evolution, ecology and behavior. We will cover the physiological bases of osmoregulation, circulation, gas exchange, digestion, energetics, motility, and neural and hormonal control of these and other processes in a variety of vertebrate and invertebrate animals, thereby revealing general principles of animal physiology as well as specific physiological adaptations to differing environments.

title: Topics in Anthropology - Anthropology of Labor
descrip: This course focuses on how labor shapes identity and citizenship; gender and sexuality; global networks of power, inequality and displacement; and bodily commodification. We will examine various kinds of work--agricultural, industrial and post-industrial, immigrant and migrant, sex and service--in numerous sites. Our readings will move from historical debates about unpaid and unrecognized work to the question of labor as transnational, flexible and affective. As we scrutinize work in a comparative and cross-cultural context, we'll seek to interrogate how the question of what we "do" is intricately intertwined with who we are.

title: Philosophy of Language
descrip: Conditionals. Both indicative and counterfactual conditionals are examined, with a view to exploring a unified account of those two categories. The relationship of conditionals to modality, epistemic and metaphysical, is an important theme. Readings from both linguistics and philosophy. Some recent joint work (unpublished) by Hawthorne and Dorr figures prominently.

title: Seminar in Information Sciences and Systems
descrip: This is a forum of graduate students, staff, and distinguished outside speakers presenting their recent research in signal processing, communication and information theory, decision and control, and systems theory. Attendance by ISS students is required.

title: Cultural & Ethnographic Perspectives in the Sociology of Work
descrip: This course focuses on the experience, organization, and meaning of work in modern industrial societies. Wage labor and wage labor relations, rather than managerial functions, are the main foci of interest with an appreciation and examination of the `bottom-up` everyday experiences and informal cultures of the workplace--so bringing alive and filling out sometimes too wooden economic models. The course offers the opportunity for careful study of some of the founding classical positions in the study of work, but will also focus discussion on classic and more recent ethnographic texts portraying work relations and cultures.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Racial Politics in the U.S.
reviews: Even with the limitations of the course that came from the teaching style, I would consider talking others to take this course. It allows for more of an opportunity to understand how social science and research methods can be applied to a topic usually seen as very subjective or one dimensional. Also provides views of both sides which is very unique.
Excellent course, very engaging seminar where you don't find yourself watching the clock. It would be helpful to have a strong knowledge of American politics
Lots of reading, get started on the paper early, and participate a lot. Good class, great professor.
descrip: This course investigates the politics of race in the U. S. with particular attention to the political status of African Americans. We will cover topics including the meaning of race, the civil rights movement and collective action, gender, class and regional differences, racial prejudice, racial identity, and various public policy issues such as residential segregation and political representation. The focus will be on student participation and student research projects involving direct observation and rigorous qualitative analysis, or analysis of quantitative data.

title: Theory of Games
reviews: Absolutely take it.
Good course but a decent understanding of math (especially linear algebra) will really help.
If you want to take a picture of John F. Nash Jr, this is the class to take. He actually lectured us for 40 minutes!

If you're looking for a math class on game theory that's interesting and not too much work, this is a great class to take! You'll learn about many of the important fundamentals and interesting applications in a very effective and concise manner.
Take It!

Take the class if you are interested in game theory for a slightly mathematical point of view. It is a good introduction. However, if you are looking for a proof-intensive class, this class is not it.
This is the nicest and most interesting 300-level Math-course out there.
This was a great class, well worth taking if you are at all interested in game theory.
take it. interesting subject matter
prereqs: A course in linear algebra or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The mathematical concept of a game is an abstraction which encompasses conflict-cooperation situations in which strategy (not just chance) plays a role. Central topics of the theory and some of its applications will be discussed. Introductory aspects of algorithmic game theory will be covered, if time permits.

title: Politics after Communism
descrip: This course focuses on the political and economic reform processes in the countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union since the collapse of communism. The course is not intended to provide a full survey of events in this particularly tumultuous time in post-communist history. Rather, we will focus on some of the more important aspects of the simultaneous political, economic and social transformations, emphasizing some key themes that emerge in the social science academic literature on the subject.

title: Topics In Earth History - A Tropical Perspective on Ice Ages
descrip: A Tropical Perspective on Ice Ages - explores why the sensitivity of the Earth's climate to Milankovitch forcing has increased dramatically over the past 3 millions years as is evident in records of two separate but related phenomena: the waxing and waning of glaciers in high latitudes; and the rise and fall of sea surface temperatures in the equatorial Pacific Ocean. What are the feedback's that increased climate sensitivity over the past 3 million years? What are the implications for future climate changes?

title: Condensed Matter/Many-Body Physics
reviews: Take it if you want to know advanced condensed matter.
This is possibly the best graduate-level course you can find in Princeton.. If you are at least slightly interested in condensed matter theory, take it.
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Discusses the main tools of econometric analysis, and the way in which they are applied to a range of problems in social science. Emphasis is on using techniques, and on understanding and critically assessing others' use of them. There is a great deal of practical work on the computer using a range of data from around the world. Topics include regression analysis, with a focus on regression as a tool for analyzing non-experimental data, discrete choice, and an introduction to time-series analysis. There are applications from macroeconomics, policy evaluation, and economic development. Prerequisite: grounding in topics covered in 507c.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Biophysics
descrip: An attempt to bring principles of physics to bear on the most complex systems of all: biological systems. Course begins with a discussion of whether physics can tell us if something is, in fact, alive, then considers the physical principles that govern the constituent molecules of biological systems-and their emergent properties. From DNA and proteins, course moves on to evolution and how it is physically possible for a species to genetically adapt to its environment quickly enough to survive. Finally, how the conscious mind can emerge from a network is considered.

title: The Hebrew Poetry of Medieval Spain
prereqs: HEB 302 or equivalent.
descrip: Covers the rise of the golden age of Hebrew poetry in Muslim Spain; the Arabic literary background; lyrical, liturgical, and contemplative verse by great poets of the 11th and 13th centuries (Shmuel ha-Nagid, Ibn Gabirol, Judah Halevi, Todros Abulafia, etc.); and narratives in rhymed prose. Two weeks will be devoted to developments outside Spain: the 12th and 13th century martyrdom poems from France and the Rhineland, and, in conclusion, the adoption of Romance forms, especially the sonnet, in the Hebrew poetry of Italy.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Health Reform Implementation
