descrip: President Obama signed comprehensive health reform into law on March 23, 2010. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is an unprecedented joint federal-state initiative, with provisions to expand health insurance coverage, control health care costs, and improve the health care delivery system. This course will focus on the critical implementation period leading up to 2014. We will examine the federal regulatory process, the role that states will play in the expansion of Medicaid and operation of health insurance exchanges, the implications for the federal-state relationship, legal challenges, and Congressional oversight efforts

title: Analysis in Several Variables
reviews: Don't take it unless you know you want to be a math major.
It's a great class, but will take up quite a bit of time. Take care to give yourself a lot of time to do the problem sets, especially the midterm and final problem sets.
It's a nice course, but you could be better off taking departmentals right away.
Professor Gunning is a very nice teacher, but the material is tough. If I were to choose again, I would go for 203.

Take MAT 215, 217 instead. Well, I haven't taken any higher-level math courses yet, but it seems those two would be much more applicable than this class, which doesn't really give you insight as to what is going on with the material. You could learn some basic computation on your own and be pretty much as well off as before.

Take it if you want to be a math major. You have to know these things and be assured that if you skip the class and read on your own you won't be as thorough. I took it even though I personally hated computations, against my purely abstract inclination, but I know it will prove to be very useful.

There is no reason to take this class if you aren't planning on majoring in math or maybe physics. If you are a math major, you should take it simply for the challenge and for the material, even though it's basically a requirement.
This is a must if you are a math major, or if you are just interested in abstract mathematics. You will learn a lot and leave very comfortable with the material.

Well, if you're a math major then you have to take this anyway, but it's certainly a fairly worthwhile class in any case.  The material at first is pretty boring, and then confusing once you get to differential forms, but still perfectly manageable, and it's all very important for all sorts of other math.  Lectures tend to get spent doing pretty detailed proofs step by step, which is kind of nice but all in Gunning's notes (which we used as a textbook, and which are very solid in that regard), so it can be easy to zone out and not pay attention.

Daniel Shenfeld, our pseudo-TA/grader/whatever was extremely good at giving some intuition, usually geometric, behind the various things that we did in class.  Those classes were very valuable, and usually gave you something to think about, especially once we got into the differential forms part of the class.

My only caution would be that if you're taking it to hope to get a better understanding of multivariable calculus, that might not be exactly what you get.  More rigorous, certainly, but the intuition is really all in the geometry; unfortunately this is more or less requisite background to get into any differential geometry anyway.

The problem sets were often interesting, occasionally very infuriating with long calculations, but those were rare enough that it was tolerable, hopefully the problems in the notes will get revised sometime.
prereqs: MAT 215 and 217.
descrip: Rigorous introduction to calculus in several variables.

title: Controversies in Health Policy: Historical Perspectives
descrip: Examines historical pathways in shaping recent health policies. Among the topics examined: Medicare's history, failed Clinton reforms, and 2010 health legislation as case studies of diverse pathways toward reform; Ritalin as insight into FDA policy, direct-to-consumer drug advertising, and prescription practices; recent vaccine debates which sit at the intersection of science, consumer beliefs, economics, and state health policy; and physician-assisted suicide in medicine, law, and the courts. Emphasis on analyzing role of government, political ideology, consumers, industry, scientists, and regulatory interests in health policy formation.

title: Advanced Japanese II
reviews: Advanced level Japanese is difficult but rewarding.
I would say that he or she should take it. It was much more fun than 301 and probably than 305 will be. All around fabulous. You learn a lot and have a lot of fun doing it.

I would strongly recommend this class, if only for the curriculum. Since Spirited Away was the focus of the curriculum, I always looked forward to readings and had no trouble remembering the reading's content.
Participate a lot in class!
There's a lot of regular work, so keep up or work ahead if you can, and try not to cram for anything.
descrip: The course is designed to further students proficiency in four skills aiming at ACTFL-ETS advanced level. Reading materials include the Japanese anime "Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away)" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Topics in International Relations - Protection Against Weapons of Mass Destruction
descrip: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the only significant security threats to the U.S. and its allies have been from nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. Historically, the US focus has oscillated between protection via nonproliferation and disarmament agreements, and via civil and missile defense. The course assesses the threats, both approaches to protection, and linkages made between policies on WMD and perceptions of "conventional" military threats.

title: Experimental Methods I
reviews: Use Orcad from the beginning, because he'll make you use it by the end anyway.
descrip: A laboratory course that focuses on basic electronics techniques, digital electronics, and data acquisition and analysis. Topics include introduction to digital and analog electronics, digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion, microcomputer sampling, and data analysis. There are four laboratory hours and two lecture hours per week. There is one project.

title: Combinatorial Mathematics
prereqs: MAT 323 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: 307 introduces students to Combinatorics, a fundamental mathematical discipline as well as an essential component of many mathematical areas. While in the past many of the basic combinatorial results were obtained by ingenuity and detailed reasoning, modern theory has grown out of this early stage and relies on deep, well-developed tools. The course covers over a dozen virtually independent topics including Ramsey Theory, Turan Theorem and Extremal Graph Theory, Probabilistic Arguments, Algebraic Methods and Spectral Techniques, chosen to illustrate several such techniques. This is a fun course, showcasing the gems of modern Combinatorics.

title: Introductory Video and Film Production
reviews: A great course for anyone just generally interested in film and video, theoretically, practically, or otherwise.
Be sincere and invest yourself in the class, you can BS your way through the class but it really isn't worth your time. If you're interested in film though, definitely take the course.
I'd recommend this course if you're willing to dedicate several hours to each project.  Dedicating a large portion of time to the course is the best way to get the most out of it.
If you are interested in film, especially avant garde film, you should check this class out.
If you have an interest for film, this is definitely a course to take.
Take this class. It is a fun way to learn about the creative process that goes into making movies.
take it!
prereqs: By application/interview and instructor's permission. Please see the Visual Arts Program website page for specific application/interview information..
descrip: A film/video course introducing the techniques of shooting and editing digital video. Works of film/video art are analyzed in order to explore the development of, and innovations in, cinematic language. Production is oriented toward film/video as a visual art, including narrative, documentary, and experimental genres. Several short video projects produced during the semester.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Geometric Modeling and Analysis
reviews: I would strongly recommend engaging in the discussions, because the more people speak, the more beneficial the class turns out.
prereqs: COS 426 or equivalent.
descrip: We will study algorithms for geometric analysis of 3D shapes. Focus will be on recent methods for matching, registering, recognizing, chassifying, clustering, and understanding 3D data. Coursework will include reading/presenting research papers and executing a single course project in each student's own area of interest.

title: Topics in Modern South Asia - Subaltern Studies
reviews: I would certainly recommend this course to specialists, both within the history department and to those who are, like myself, interested in the theory's role in other disciplines.
descrip: This course explores special topics in modern South Asian history. The precise topic varies from year to year.

title: Ornament Past and Present
descrip: This course has three aims: close encounters with some of the world's major traditions of ornament, close examination of issues that arise in the study of ornament and its history, and the cultivation of skills for writing about ornament. One troublesome issue is simply the problem of defining "ornament" (or "decoration"): is this anything more than a catch-all category for arts traditionally excluded from "the fine arts"? Themes for discussion include plant, animal, and geometrical ornament; space constraints as a stimulus to invention; and the relations between ornament and architecture.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
descrip: A weekly workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion.

title: Advanced Korean II
reviews: It is a very challenging and helpful course with a lot of interesting topics covered, and the professor is awesome. She cares about her students and will go out of her way to make sure that they understand the material.
prereqs: KOR 301 or placement test..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 301. Continued development of proficiency in speaking and reading through class discussion and short readings. Vocabulary learning and discourse skills are emphasized.

title: The McGraw Seminar in Writing - The Journalism of Outsiders
reviews: An absolutely fantastic journalism course--Professor Hull is incredible at teaching her craft and giving detailed feedback. This class is entirely Professor dependent, so check the name out before enrolling.
Definitely take this course! Best journalism class at Princeton (maybe even best class in general)

For students reading these evaluations in the midst of deciding whether or not to take JRN 441, I can only express my most profound sympathy and my deepest sorrow. You will not have the opportunity to take this course with Professor Anne Hull - you have missed the opportunity for the greatest experience at Princeton. I'm sorry.
Great Class. Journalism is a fun thing to try and becoming a better writer is always amazing. If these things are interesting to you, I would really recommend it.

I'm not sure if Professor Hull is teaching the class again, or plans to in the future, but all I can say is that I feel fortunate to have had her as a teacher and hope that her class is representative of the journalism seminars in general. If that is the case, I would HIGHLY recommend that students apply for and take journalism seminars.
If Prof Hull is around Princeton again, take the class...
If she ever comes back to teach again, I would highly recommend her class.
If you ever see a course with Anne Hull's name on it, take it. Immediately register for it, even if it means dropping a departmental.

If you want to be challenged and are interested in feature writing, take this course. If you want to have an easy semester with a fluffy writing course, don't!

The assignments take many hours, but are incredibly rewarding and mirror real world journalism.  The editing is intense and you'll learn a lot from it. 

If you have the time to devote, I would strongly recommend this course for those who want to write in a feature style (even if they haven't done so before). There is a lot of room for people with different levels of experience and different skill sets.

Professor Hull is the best teacher I've ever had at Princeton, and she isn't even a full time teacher. She really cares about her students and she makes sure we are all engaged. I would recommend Professor Hull to anybody and everybody.
Take as many journalism classes as you are able. Get on the streets. Look inside yourself. Write stories. Find your own voice.
This class was amazing. Anyone would love it. We all did.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: This course focuses on journalism that seeks to explain or understand the human condition of outsiders--individuals who experience a psychological, economic, or social sense of separateness. These might include a soldier coming home from war or a gay teenager living in the Bible belt. We will cover elements of journalism ranging from story conception and fact gathering to synthesis and writing. Assignments and discussion will revolve around reporting, writing, and readings.

title: Topics in Literary and Cultural Theory - Film Theory/Theory Film
descrip: A survey of classical and contemporary film theoretical texts and debates that will examine, among others, issues of narration, medium specificity, realism, photogenie, suture, montage, film language, and apparatus theory. Close readings of texts by filmmakers (Deren, Bresson, Pasolini, Brakhage) and theorists (Lukacs, Panofsky, Munsterberg, Kracauer, Balazs, Eisenstein, Vertov, Bazin, Benjamin, Cavell, Metz, and Deleuze) will be confronted with what could be called theoretical films ranging from Eisenstein's project to film Das Kapital, essay films by Marker and Farocki, and Debord's film of his theoretical opus La Societe du Spectacle.

title: Computational Geometry
reviews: Chazelle is great. If you like algorithms you should take this class.
I didn't care for it.
I'd suggest taking the course if you are strong on theory, but if not, then the problem sets are very hard.

If you're going to take this course, make sure you have the mathematical maturity to do so. If you think algebraically, as I do, expect no introduction to geometric patterns of thought.

If you're a grad student and just want compentency, take another course.;
Only take it if you're very comfortable with proofs and algorithmic analysis of all sorts. Sure, Chazelle's a captivating lecturer, but if you're looking for a second theory requirement, beware?.
Really a wonderful course
Take it if you can handle the problem sets.
Take this course if you need a theory. It's better than 340 (especially if Charikar is teaching it), Chazelle is great and the work isn't too hard. 4 problem sets and a really easy final project.
Take this course.

This class is extremely hard, but I would definitely recommend it.  It will make you a much better thinker and problem solver.  If you take it, try to balance it out in your schedule because you'll want as much time to think about the problems in a non-stressful way (*at least* 7 days solid for every set to live and breathe the problems).  Also, Chazelle is an amazing lecturer.  Try to go to all of his lectures, even if they aren't "necessary."  You'll learn some amazing stuff.
prereqs: COS 226 and COS 341..
descrip: This course introduces the basic concepts of geometric computing, illustrating the importance of this field for a variety of applications areas, such as computer graphics, solid modeling, robotics, database, pattern recognition, and statistical analysis. Algorithms are presented and analyzed for a large number of geometric problems, and an array of fundamental techniques are discussed (e.g., convex hulls, Voronoi diagrams, intersection problems, multidimensional searching).

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Mechanical Design
reviews: Robots are cool, but be prepared to spend lots of time outside of your designated lab time in order to meet deadlines.

This semester, pretty much all of the work for this class was the robot. Building a robot is kind of fun, and pretty much all the class made more or less successful robots, but I didn't really feel like like I learned much about engineering in this class. There was next to no formal guidance for most of the project. Lectures were pretty useless in giving any sort of relevant practical information; Prof. Nosenchuck is a very longwinded lecturer who spends a long time repeating himself or talking about unimportant details. That said, the course was not all that intellectually challenging. Just make sure you get an early start on deadlines, and don't be afraid of asking Glenn for advice (he's got a lot of experience). You do get to do a lot of machining for this project (it did improve my machining skills), and a sizeable portion of the project was coding the robot in C, for those who enjoy that. Take this class if you have to or want to, but it did not feel very inspiring for this aspiring engineer.
Worth it. Great learning experience.
prereqs: MAE 321 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course builds on the technical foundations established in MAE 321, and extends the scope to include a range of advanced mechanism design. Students, working in teams, will be challenged to design and fabricate a robotic system that will draw upon multidisciplinary engineering elements. The robot will be used to facilitate common daily tasks. The selected tasks vary each year. CAD, CAE, and CAM will be utilized in the design/simulation/prototype process. Labs are designed to reinforce and expand CAD and CAE skills. A final public competition will be held among the design teams. Judges from relevant industries will be present.

title: Ancient Judaism from Alexander to the Rise of Islam
reviews: If you are interested then definitely take it.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the development of ancient Judaism during the eventful millennium plus from the establishment of the Torah as the constitution of the Jewish people in the fifth century BCE--an event that some have seen as marking the transition from biblical religion to Judaism--to the completion of the other great canonical Jewish document, the Babylonian Talmud, in perhaps the sixth century BCE. The weekly lecture and assigned readings will provide historical context, but the focus of the course will be on primary texts that reflect the major developments in ancient Judaism, to be treated during a two-hour precept.

title: Books and Their Readers
reviews: Definitely consider taking this course. Professor Grafton is incredibly knowledgeable. The reading isn't too heavy and usually quite fascinating. Just be prepared that you are going to have to write a substantial research paper at the end.
Definitely take it!
If you are interested in the subject or want to take only one ECS course, I would highly recommend it.
Take anything that Professor Grafton teaches. Come armed with a few Monty Python quotes handy.

Take this course, regardless of your academic background! Do be warned that the reading list is often heavy and intense, but your perseverance will be rewarded by great seminar discussions and a chance to study with the encyclopedic and wonderful Professor Grafton.

take it.
take it.
take it.
take it.
prereqs: Sign up by e-mail: mjreilly@princeton.edu or stop by the ECS office, 207 Scheide Caldwell House. ECS students will be given priority. Class limited to 15 students..
descrip: This course will offer an intensive introduction to the history of the making, distribution and reading of books in the West, from ancient Greece to modern America. By examining a series of case studies, we will see how writers, producers, and readers of books have interacted, and how the conditions of production and consumption have changed over time.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part II
descrip: Study and evaluation of mechanical and electrical system applications for different building types, including air conditioning, electrical, plumbing and telecommunications. Emphasis on design integration with architecture and structure within the construction process including sustainable design and energy conservation. Introduction to vertical transportation, life safety systems, and intelligent buildings. Emphasis on a conceptual approach using case studies and field trips.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Promoting Foreign Investment in Developing Countries
descrip: This course will first examine the link between development and foreign direct investment, then review policies and practices designed to promote investment in least developed countries, primarily in Africa. Focus will be on identifying the most effective strategies for governments, multilateral development banks, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector.

title: Mathematical Models in the Study of Politics
reviews: Don't worry so much about learning the lecture materials and definitions. This course is about problem solving, so just work really hard on the problem sets.
Excellent course. Would recommend to any politics major. Though you get all the course slides, GO TO LECTURE.  Ramsay is an awesome professor.
Go to office hours for advice on solving the problem sets...book doesn't really help
I would tell another student to take this course, but explain that the problem sets are often very difficult and confusing.

If you are not an IR concentrator in the politics department, do not take this class as your Quant Analysis requirement. This class is not very useful to someone interested in non-IR political science. Wish i had taken stats.
If you like game theory and want to apply it to some other context besides economics, you should definitely take the course.
Interesting material; great professor. Osborne reading recommended, Dixit reading not necessary, lecture MANDATORY!  Get ready to change the way you perceive others and the world!
It is a tough class but you will learn a lot.

It's a demanding class, but very enjoyable and rewarding if you like puzzles and games. I'd recommend you start problem sets a couple days in advance and work with other students, because they can be tricky at first, but they're oddly satisfying at the same time because of the fact that you're solving puzzles.
It's not very hard, it's just a method that you need to learn. Also, don't try to rely too much on the book. A lot of the questions can be solved with common sense.
Learned a lot! Take it!
Other courses are much better: ECO 308 for example
Take it--if you know math even a little bit, it will be an easy course.
Take it.
Take this course if you have an interest in the material, applications of game theory to politics.
Take this course if you're interested in learning about game theory at all.  The math is not too difficult, and it's very interesting.

This class was hard for me. I'm new to game theory and if you are looking for a painless class to satisfy any non-necessary requirement think twice before you take it. Overall, the class is fair and teaches you a whole new way of thinking about political actions, but be ready to be confused, it's tough.
great if you're a science/math type who wants some exposure to POL
descrip: An introduction to the use of formal game-theoretic models in the study of politics. Applications include: voting, legislative institutions, party formulation, and international relations. Familiarity with mathematical reasoning is helpful.

title: Philosophy and the Modern Mind
descrip: A historical introduction to philosophy since 1600, emphasizing close reading of classic texts, but including some attention to the scientific, religious, political, literary, and other context.

title: Politics of Campus Space, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: History of African American Families
reviews: Great class.
I recommend this course for students looking to learn about construction, evolution, and perception of the black family over time.

Take this class or just take a course taught by Professor Hunter if this class isn't available.  I didn't enjoy most of my classes at Princeton; I found them repetitive and drab, but this course was a welcomed break from the norm. It shows that professor is actually intelligent, so you don't feel like you're doing a bunch of mindless work just for a grade.
The class covers a lot of important material and should be mandatory for every Princeton student.
descrip: This course covers the history of African-American families. It traces the development of family life, meanings, values, and institutions from the period of slavery up to recent times. The course engages long-standing and current debates about black families in the scholarship across disciplines and in the society at large. The course will look at the diversity of black family arrangements and the way these have changed over time and adapted to internal and external challenges and demands. It will also situate the history of black families within a broader cross-cultural context.

title: Topics in International Relations - Terrorism, Civil War & Non-State Threats
descrip: This seminar is devoted to understanding (1) forms of political violence other than interstate war and (2) how policy makers can (and sometimes cannot) take action to ameliorate the threat from non-state violence. Course requires careful reading of 1-2 policy statements and 2-3 moderately technical articles each week on topics including: terrorism, the causes of civil war, the duration and cessation of civil war, the transition from violence to democracy, violence and social order, economic development and violence, the institutional structure of insurgent organizations, government violence and expropriation, revolution, and ethnic violence.

title: Representations of History
prereqs: Prerequisite: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine three crucial moments in French history and culture: the rise to power of Louis XIV, the French Revolution, and the Vichy regime during the German Occupation. Through the reading of archives, memoirs, historical accounts, and novels, we will consider representations of three distinct regimes and the crises they created or meant to resolve. In addition, we will see films such as Rossellini's [The Rise to Power of Louis XIV], Hollywood's interpretation of [A Tale of Two Cities], and Claude Chabrol's dark account of occupied France, [Histoire de femmes].

title: Elementary Swahili II
reviews: If you are interested in East Africa, this class is awesome!

Mahiri is a really great professor.  He's super nice, and very approachable.  He makes you feel comfortable, even when your Swahili speaking skill aren't as strong yet.  If you take the class you should definitely go to Dar es Saalam over the summer to continue the Swahili track. I'm going this summer and I can't wait!
Mahiri is fantastic! You learn a lot in a very fun way!
Study after class what you learned that day.
Swahili is a great language and Mwalimu has an odd but enjoyable sense of humor. Swahili may not help you around America, but its cool to say you know Swahili.
Swahili is more fun than other languages courses.
Take this class, and make friends with your classmates, and plan to go to Tanzania!
Take this class. Get out of Spanish and all those other boring languages. Going to Africa is almost a guarantee in this class.
Try it.  You might be surprised.
Very interesting course.
you won't regret taking it--just make sure you are willing to speak in class
prereqs: Only those who have taken Elementary Swahili I (SWA 101) should enroll..
descrip: Continuation of SWA 101. Emphasis is on increasing proficiency in reading and listening comprehension, speaking, and writing activities in Swahili. Cultural contexts of the East African societies where Swahili is spoken are incorporated in classroom activities in order to enhance communication and cultural proficiency.

title: Critical Trespasses: Theorizing Political and Intellectual Borders
descrip: This seminar structures an encounter with theoretical writings about nation, subjectivity, power and culture, which are assembled for their relevance to "East Asia." The collection is not meant to be comprehensive, but is intended to facilitate discussion of work that has shaped and revised active intellectual traditions. It starts with reflection on "area studies" as an academic discipline and move to considerations of national identity and nationalism. It proceeds to a study of power through psychoanalysis and "neo-Marxism." Finally, it turns to practices - writing, media, technology - that embody and inflect these conceptual formations.

title: Approaches to the Study of Religion
descrip: In this course we will read the representative "classics" in the study of religion. We will see that "religion" has been approached in a number of different ways, and that these different approaches are relatively recent because, in some significant respects, the notion of "religion" is no older than its study in the "West." This modern western concept then is the subject of this course. The course is not an introduction to "world religions" nor is it a methods course. Students are invited to think critically about religion as a subject of academic inquiry.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research
descrip: Examination of issues in the responsible conduct of scientific research, including the definition of scientific misconduct, mentoring, authorship, peer review, grant practices, use of humans and of animals as subjects, ownership of data, and conflict of interest. Class will consist primarily of the discussion of cases. Required of all first-year graduate students in the Department of Psychology. Open to other graduate students.

title: Topics in Drama - The Musical Theatre of Stephen Sondheim
descrip: This seminar examines the musicals of Stephen Sondheim from page to stage. Focusing on a different musical each week from Gypsy (1959) to Road Show (2009), we will ask, How do musical theatre's elements of music, lyrics, script, dance, and design cohere in Sondheim's musicals? We will explore influences on his art, both personal and cultural, his collaborators, and the historical and theatrical context. We will read scripts, listen to music, watch taped and live performances, research production and reception histories, and read popular and scholarly criticism.

title: Beginner's Latin Continued: Basic Prose
reviews: Be ready to switch sections aggressively during the first week, since the preceptor really makes or breaks this course.
I would recommend it to students who have not taken a Latin course before.
I would tell him to keep up on vocab and make sure he does all the reading on time.
If one already took LAT 101, there's really no reason not to continue onto LAT 102.

If you have any intention of going on to study higher levels of Latin, it is imperative that you keep up with the foundational vocabulary presented in this course.  Michelle is a capable and accessible instructor, and you will learn.
If you've taken Latin 101 and enjoyed it, you will definitely enjoy this one.  Princeton has a really excellent latin program.
It's a great introduction to Latin, and also just short of required if you've already taken 101.

Latin is a very fun and rewarding language to learn, especially for history buffs. You don't have to be a Classics major to take Latin, but if you enjoy history and would like to learn how many modern languages developed, this is the language to take. It's also a great way to increase vocabulary as so many words come from Latin.
Lots of work and difficult material, but you learn a lot.
Take it as a continuation of lation 101, preparing you for reading actual latin.  make sure you have a good teacher
Take it.  It is good if you are trying to learn the language.
Take the course.
Take the course. Hope you don't get a silly graduate student for an instructor.
This is a complicated course.  Review material every day.  Only take if you possess strong language skills.
Unless you've had prior experience - take another language. Or become an engineer.
prereqs: LAT 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continues Latin grammar from LAT 101. The second half of the semester will be devoted to reading continuous Latin poetry and prose.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Business Strategy in the Public Sphere
descrip: Course analyzes the behavior of private businesses when operating in the public sphere. We first study how businesses respond to non-governmental challenges to their market behavior such as pressure from private activists and negative media coverage. We then analyze the strategies that businesses pursue to actively influence the political institutions - legislatures, bureaucracies, and courts - that set the 'rules of the game' under which businesses compete. Course is taught using a combination of case studies and theoretical frameworks that examine how business managers approach nonmarket challenges.

title: Accounting for Taste
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Religions of China
reviews: A good EM and not too hard.
Be wary of who the lecturer is; sit in on a lecture or two before you decide for certain you want to take the class. Also, get to know your preceptor.
Definitely take this even if you aren't familiar with China or religion. It's just a great class for being an educated, worldly person!

I think this is a great class to take to fulfill the EM requirement. It is interesting, and it doesn't require you to have a background knowledge of Chinese culture/religion, or even a background in religion.
I would recommend this course for anyone looking to learn a lot about china and fulfill an EM. The lectures are at 9am, however, which is a deterrent.
If Jolyon will be a preceptor, definitely take this course.
If Professor Teiser or Jolyon is involved, then I would recommend taking this class.  Regardless, it is a great way to fulfill the Ethics requirement with a course that is actually interesting.
If you are interested in religion in general or Chinese history/culture in particular, you will find this class very enjoyable and thought-provoking!
Interesting - good choice for EM distribution.

It's an easy-going, chill class and a good way to get rid of an EM. At times the readings aren't the most interesting, but everything is easily understood. Precept was very relaxed. Try to get Teiser as your preceptor (from what I hear he's a lot more lenient of a grader than the TA).
It's an enjoyable EM and an east class to PDF
It's not a bad course... not too much work, interesting material and good way to get an EM.
Lecture is mind-numbingly boring, but you don't have to go because it has nothing to do with the readings. If you want an easy PDF of an EM, take this as it requires minimal work
Take it.  No matter what your persuasions academically, it is an interesting and engaging course.

This course is a great introduction to Asian religions and/or to Chinese culture. I strongly recommend taking it! Stephen Teiser is a great professor and Jolyon Thomas a great preceptor. There is a lot of reading and most of it is a bit obscure but it's important to do the reading because then it all makes a lot more sense when the professor talks about it in class and when you are discussing it in precept. All the readings are important ? they are not only relevant but most will introduce an important idea to the course.
Apart from the readings there really isn't much work to do in this class. Show up to the lectures (you'll want to!) and to precept and you'll do fine.
This course is one of the best classes I've taken here at Princeton. Definitely take it if you're even a little interested in Chinese religion or Chinese culture in general.

This is a nice, painless way to fulfill an EM.  It isn't work-intensive (2 papers   2 memorization-based quizzes that you can prepare for in 30 min).  As with most humanities classes, the material is unsubstantial and kind of irrelevant, but it is fun, fluffy, and interesting.  A great class to PDF.
Unless you love (or think you will love) China or Chinese religion do not take this course because you will be bored.
Worth taking. The professor understands that religion isn't everyone's #1 priority, but doesn't try to overcompensate for it. The workload is very manageable and usually interesting stuff
great
take if interested
take it and work hard
prereqs: Open to students who have not taken prior courses in Religion or Chinese studies..
descrip: A thematic introduction to the history of Chinese religion. Topics include cosmology, ancestors, gods, mythology, ethics, shamanism, divination, gender, and mortuary ritual. Readings drawn from a wide range of sources, including sacred scriptures, philosophical texts, popular literature, and modern ethnography.

title: Advanced Arabic I
reviews: Always bring your dictionary.
Heba is a great instructor, very knowledgable and VERY passionate and committed to what she does.
I truly do recommend this class
descrip: Readings from modern Arabic works; systematic study of syntax; speaking and composition. Main text book Al Kitaab part II.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop II
reviews: I think everyone enjoyed this course.  Give it a try.

If you want to improve your ability to engage with a wide range of Arabic texts, this is the class for you.  If you want a traditional language class, or to improve your spoken Arabic, you should consider looking elsewhere.
Prepare the translations carefully ahead of time, noting the voweling.
Take this course when they change the format.
Take this course! It will be challenging but very rewarding.
The professor is definitely the best in the department.  But he is really disorganized and although this is not usually a problem, at the end of the semester it can make life really painful.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 401 or the instructor's permission..
descrip: Classical Arabic sciences of grammar, morphology, and rhetoric, supplemented by expository writing and poetry from classical scholars and literary figures. Emphasis on translation from Arabic and on memorization and oral recitation of texts.

title: Ocean, Atmosphere, and Climate
reviews: Attend the lectures and don't be afraid to ask questions.
Do your work.  That's all your really need to do to do well in this course.

Go to office hours if you need help, not even just with the problem set. Use the study guides with questions. Review the lecture slides to make sure you understand the material even just from the pictures and diagrams.
I think that this is a good course to take if you're interested in the ocean or in the field of Geosciences.  There are a lot of people looking to fulfill their ST requirement though.
I would definitely recommend this as a great intro to geosciences class.
If you like this topic I would recommend it, but otherwise I would not.
Just take it.
Not extremely difficult, not extremely easy.

This course is a lot more work than you would expect, and is quite difficult now after the university made changes to it. However, if you are interested in oceanography, the course is worth taking because do learn a lot about what is actually being studied in the field. Do not take this course looking for an easy ST.

While I have certainly learned a lot, I would advise thinking long and hard just how much the topic fascinates you before signing up. Only the most enthralled with the subject will not mind the excessive time commitment and number of assignments that the course involves. That said, lectures were interesting on the whole and the field trip was fun!
dont take to fulfill st
prereqs: High School biology, chemistry and calculus..
descrip: An introduction to the ocean, atmosphere, and climate from the perspective of oceanography. Covers coastal processes including waves, beaches, tides and ecosystems; open ocean processes including atmospheric circulation and its impact on the surface ocean, the wind driven circulation, and surface ocean ecosystems; and the abyssal ocean including circulation, the cycling of chemicals, and ocean sediments and what they tell us about the climate history of the earth. The final part of the course will cover humans and the earth system, including a discussion of ocean resources and climate change.

title: Order and Chaos in Eighteenth-Century European Art
descrip: This seminar looks at order and chaos as organizing principles for an exploration of 18th century European art. Drawing on primary texts, the course focuses on key figures in British, French, and Italian art to understand their relationship to fundamental Enlightenment discourses concerning the ordering of knowledge and society at a time of dramatic social, economic, and political change. The course will draw heavily on period literary sources, and on both key individual creative artists and wider social contexts.

title: Normative Ethics
reviews: A fairly easy way whereby the EC may be fulfilled, but also thought-provoking and engaging
Ask your preceptor to meet with you before writing your papers.  This is a great way to hash out ideas.
Do the readings! Take a stance!
Do the readings. Attend all the lectures and precepts. Participate! Start your essays early and sketch outlines ahead of time.

Extremely interesting subject matter, you treat two subjects like abortion, patriotism, friendship, murder, etc a week, which is fast paced but also keeps it interesting. The readings show the whole spectrum and are usually 3-6 pages per reading. The course is not too hard. I basically didn't go to lecture, did 30 minutes of reading a week and just went to precept. Although I never took a philosophy course before I am averaging an A, I feel like I have learned a lot and my opinion on a lot of the subjects has changed. I strongly recommend this course, it's easy, interesting, doesn't take to much time, but you still learn a lot!
Gil Harman is not a great lecturer, but the material is pretty interesting. Not a lot of work required.
Harman is terrible.  Run away.
I recommend taking this class if you're interested in ethical questions that are prevalent in today's society

I wish I had PDF-ed successfully, since grading was rather stringent. It's a good class, but if you're looking for a light workload, there are other philosophy classes that don't have three papers, a midterm, and a final.

I would highly recommend taking this course. It will definitely challenge most of your beliefs and is great for any sort of interest in philosophy. I would not be afraid to PDF it--that's a mistake I made (not PDFing the course). The grading is somewhat random on the paper and the midterm (and I can only assume the same will be true for the final).
I would recommend this class more strongly to those with little philosophical background than to those looking for a high level course in the subject.
I'm not sure whether this is the best course to PDF, but if you are at all interested in philosophy it would be enjoyable. Otherwise it could be frustrating.
If you are interested in ethics, this is a good course to take.

If you are interested in topics that affect our world every day (abortion, women's rights, etc), this is definitely a class for you. It brings up arguments that you may have not thought about and makes you evaluate your own beliefs. Even if you're just looking for an EM, it's a great class to take.

If you have taken some philosophy before and are interested in taking it to a practical, ethical level, then this is a great course to take. Just be warned that once people start getting passionate about important moral issues sometimes they tend to listen more to their deeply ingrained preconceptions than to reasoned arguments.
If you really haven't thought much about these issues, then it might be worthwhile, but honestly you can read the subject materials on your own - you're not going to get anything out of lectures.
Lectures are boring but readings are great, and workload is completely reasonable.  Good class to PDF.

PHI 319 is a good course - you discuss a lot of interesting moral issues as well as philosophers' theories. Although you can certainly get by in class and precept without doing the readings, you should still do them because they're quite interesting.
Readings are interesting, lectures are dry
Recommend 100%.

Stay on top of the readings throughout the semester, perhaps reading an article each day.  They are worth the read, even if you completely disagree with them; you'll at least have to think about why you disagree with them.  It is certainly one of the best ways to satisfy this distribution requirement.
Take a different class. It was easy (until the final), though, if that's what you're looking for.
Take it to grapple with the issues.
Take it to learn the most important positions on many moral issues.
Take this if you are interested in discussing ethical issues!
The grading is harsh, material is interesting, and the lectures are alright.
The workload is relatively light, so keep up with it. Go to class and take notes because the final will cover almost exclusively the content of lecture.
Think about taking an ethical theory class first.  The first few weeks were spent on theory, but then theory was pushed aside.  I was not quite ready for the normative focus.
This is a pretty easy class to get a B in, but if you really want to be engaged in a class, take another.
This is a solid moral philosophy class. The readings are very entertaining and elucidating. I'd recommend it for all interested - from beginners to philosophy lovers.
This was an ok class to get an EM out of the way, but I would look into other classes.
do the readings and try really hard on the papers
if you want to take a basic philosophy class that isn't extremely challenging, take this class.
it was a good class with interesting papers.
you don't always have to do all the readings. It's more important to read some and think a lot. Choose a side and argue it in precept and in papers, you'll learn more this way.
descrip: We will discuss a variety of moral issues including patriotism, war, terrorism, capital punishment, abortion, euthanasia, justice, civil disobedience, liberty, freedom of speech, equality, affirmative action, love and friendship, marriage and the family.

title: Elementary Hebrew II
reviews: I was behind in my language requirement and already taking upper level courses my sophomore year so choosing Hebrew was the perfect choice since it wasn't too much work and I could really put enough focus into my other classes. The language requirement, in my opinion, is a little unfair since we are not allowed to PDF so if you're not great with languages and don't want to take French or Spanish where everyone in 101 or 102 has already taken a few years of the language and it just padding their GPA take Hebrew. The teacher is good and the workload not overbearing.
If you are interested in learning Hebrew at a relaxed pace with a lot of help along the way then I would take this course.

If you want to learn Hebrew, you definitely can do so in this course. Because the course isn't very demanding, you'll have to be motivated at least partly by your own interest and desire to learn and retain the material. For optimum learning, ask plenty of questions, and in particular, try to speak Hebrew in class and with the professor as much as possible.
To do the homework on time and participate in class.
prereqs: HEB 101 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of HEB 101 focusing on the structure, the grammar and vocabulary of the Hebrew language. We'll be reading easy texts from Israeli newspapers, from our textbooks. We'll be writing more compositions and be giving presentations about various topics in Hebrew.

title: Narratives of Rebellion: The Revolts of 1857 in Colonial India
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: The English Revolution
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: PLS105.
descrip: The class will provide an introduction to Polish poetry, together with developing students' vocabulary and conversation skills. Its goal is to expand students' literary knowledge as well as language abilities. The course will be conducted in Polish and English, with the readings mostly in Polish. Responses written in Polish will aim to augment the reading with active production in the language.

title: International Political Theory
descrip: The seminar will be devoted to the recent literature on various aspects of global justice. The main themes may include global distributive justice (Rawls's The Law of Peoples and subsequent literature); justice and global governance institutions; international legitimacy and democracy; and human rights. Open to undergraduates only with instructor?s permission.

title: Differential Geometry
descrip: Differential geometry is at the basis of modern physical theories, not only of general relativity, Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation, but also of the gauge theories of electromagnetic and nuclear interactions. The aim of the course is to develop a working knowledge of the fundamental concept of differential geometry and of their physical realizations.

title: Hydrology
reviews: Don't fall behind
Don't get stuck on the nitty gritty of the material, but instead try to gain a conceptual understanding of the material that will allow you to apply it beyond the scope of the course
Highly recommended for anyone interested in the field of hydrology and flood analysis.
I don't really see any reason to take this course if you're not a CEE who has to, but for those who have to it will be better than you expect.
Only take this course if it's a departmental. Not too bad-- sometimes it's interesting. Need to go to lectures to get equations.
Stay on top of problem sets.
descrip: Analysis of fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, streamflow and groundwater flow.

title: Science and Technology of Nuclear Energy: Fission and Fusion
reviews: As long as you have a background in the sciences (and a little bit of calculus), I would suggest this course.
Be aware of this course, it is very hard. The requirements say that you need calculus, which is true. But if that's all you've had physics-wise, I think you will have a very hard time.
Great class but be prepared to be challenged.
I would recommend being a Junior as this is one of the hardest courses I have taken at Princeton.

If you have a strong background in math and physics and are familiar with MATLAB, you can do well in this course. If you are interested in learning about something very unique and relevant, you will enjoy this course. Prof. Glaser's lectures are great and Prof. Goldston is very approachable to explain things you didn't understand from his lectures.

Nuclear energy is so important nowadays that any student who plans to work in the energy field should have taken this class to be able to understand articles about it or discussions with scientifics later on. I also recommand it to anybody who has an interest on the topic.
Stay away if you value your time enough that you'd rather spend it not beating your head against math until it yields. Not nearly as qualitative as I had expected when signing up.

Take it if you need to take it for something. If you don't, it's a decent amount of work for not that much payoff. If subsequent years are similar to this year, you'll understand fission and still question fusion. Maybe this will change. If you're taking it as a physics departmental, it is still probably one of the easier choices.
some parts have a lot of math, but still a good class
prereqs: PHY 101-102 or 103-104 or 107-109, MAT 201 or 203, or EGR 191-194. Thermodynamics background strongly recommended or permission of instructor..
descrip: Concern about climate change is creating the potential for a renaissance of nuclear fission power. The international ITER fusion experiment is being built to demonstrate the scientific and technological feasibility of fusion. This course will introduce the science and technology of fission and fusion. We will also cover societal risks, such as nuclear weapons proliferation, and societal benefits, such as reduced CO2 emissions.

title: Design of Large-scale Structures: Bridges
descrip: The design of bridges is considered from the conceptual phase up to the final design phase. The following issues are addressed in this course: types of bridges, design codes, computer modeling of bridges, seismic analysis and design, seismic retrofit design, inspection, maintenance and rehabilitation of bridges, movable bridges, bridge aerodynamics, organization of a typical engineering firm, marketing for engineering work. Several computer codes are used in this course.

title: Master of Engineering Independent Project II
descrip: Continuation of MAE 513. Directed study for Master of Engineering students. The topic is proposed by the student and must be approved by the student's research advisor and have received approval from the MAE Graduate Committee.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: If you are fairly comfortable in Spanish and are a graduating senior or grad student who cannot devote a lot of time to Portuguese but think basic proficiency would be helpful for your career, doing research, or traveling, this course is excellent!
It is possible to learn a great amount of Portuguese with this class, but you have to keep up with the material.

The course is wonderful, a breather among my other courses.  It's understandable that you may have to dedicate more time to your other classes, but this is a uniquely convenient opportunity to learn Portuguese, so don't waste it by not doing the work!
The only advice I would give to a student who is considering this course is, budget your time well. This course will take up a bulk of your time to get everything done and study properly.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
descrip: This course is an introduction to modern sociological theory from mid-twentieth century onwards. It will begin with notions of philosophy of science concerning the nature of concepts and theory and continue with selective review of major currents of contemporary social thought. Throughout, the emphasis will be on those ideas that can guide fruitful empirical research rather than on abstract perspectives.

title: Ethics and Economics
reviews:
1. Take precise notes. Leonard speaks slowly enough that you will be able to do this.
2. Chew gum or drink Powerade from late meal if you need to stay awake.
3. Really--follow rules 1 and 2.
4. Remember that this stuff is pretty interesting.
A good course in ethics.  Builds on intro micro (ECO 100).  Good capstone course in economics, as it draws from so many different fields (micro, behavioral, etc.).
Beware of the subjective grading for subjective answers.
Definitely take this course.  Leonard is a fantastic professor.  Only class I've taken and attended every lecture.
Easy course for a PDF. Interesting lectures.
Good course to PDF; doesn't require too much thinking.
Great class, easy PDF. Take it!
Great class.  Assignments are fair as long as you pay attention in lecture and take copious notes.
I would highly recommend it
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in economics.
I would recommend this course to an economics major and also a non-economics major.
I would take this course - Professor Leonard is a good lecturer, and the material is interesting.
If you are interested in ethics, economics, or policy, this class is a must. It will introduce you to an interesting and systematic way of seeing things.
If you have any interest in economic policy making or general ethics, take this class. Even if you don't, if you want to take a perfectly taught and organized class - look to Professor Leonard.
If you need an EM, and are somewhat interested in Econ, you might as well take it.
It's a good class. But to do well, start the assignments early. Go to office hours.

Leonard is a fantastic lecturer. A really great course to PDF -- the grading feels rather unpredictable unfortunately, but when PDFing it you won't care. You learn a lot in this course about how to relate economic principles to ethics and morality, and just how intertwined the two are (despite what other economics courses often purport). I really think it'll make a difference in how you view the world and what you choose to support -- it's the only course at Princeton that's done that for me, really (but then again I'm an engineer so I don't get exposed to life-changing topics too often unfortunately).
Professor Leonard is a cool, laid back guy. The course is interesting and pretty low stress. I would definitely recommend it as an ECO departmental.
Professor Leonard is an excellent professor, and the class is very interesting. Just be wary of the assignments.
START EARLY ON THE TAKE-HOME ASSIGNMENTS! They will ALWAYS take three times as long as you think they will! And go to all the lectures!!
TAKE IT
Take it for a distributional. It's really not too engaging.
Take it or Law and Economics. Attending class and paying close attention is far more important than doing all the readings.
Take it!  Professor Leonard is a good lecturer, and it's a lot of work every two weeks with very little in between.

Take it! Especially if you enjoy economics or, as the name says, are curious as to how economics relates to ethics. It is a pretty good amount of work but you will definitely learn a lot if you devote some energy to it. Professor Leonard is very intelligent but also very down-to-earth.
Take it, if you are prepared to do a lot of work every 2-ish weeks.
Take this if you are interested in the subject matter and you are okay with maybe not doing that well for no reason.
Take this if you are looking for more theoretical economic perspectives.
The lectures are really good - just go to them and take good notes and that's all you need.
This is a great course! It doesn't take too much time, and Professor Leonard is an excellent lecturer. Make sure you go to all the lectures and write down everything he says!
prereqs: ECO 100.
descrip: Introduction to ethical issues in market exchange, and in laws that regulate it. How ethical commitments evolve, and influence cooperation. The moral dimension of low wages, price discrimination, distribution of resources, trade in inalienable property, and the separation of choice and consequence. As time permits, the influence of economic ideas on moral reasoning.

title: Seminar. 19th-Century European Art
descrip: Rethinking Aestheticism: This course seeks to recover the intensity and strangeness of the art and artwriting associated with Aestheticism in Britain, c.1860-1900. Long a byword for frivolity and excess, British Aestheticism, centered on the re-imagination of bodily experience and the life of the senses, has emerged as a crucial episode in the development of modernism. Figures considered will include Ruskin, Swinburne, Pater, Rossetti, Morris, Whistler, Burne-Jones, and others. Topics will include the intersection of art with utopian politics; practices of sexual dissidence; theories of the decorative; and the impact of Darwin on the arts.

title: Ottoman Diplomatics: Paleography and Diplomatic Documents
descrip: An introduction to Ottoman paleography and diplomatics. The documents will be in divani and rika scripts.

title: Knowledge and Travel
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Techniques of Conducting
reviews: Definitely take this course! It will be a lot of fun! But don't expect to get an easy LA or something; although it is a P/D/F class, I ended up putting more time and effort into it than a regular graded class.
Fantastic.

Gabriel is an incredible conductor. If you're a musician and you get the chance to take this course, do it. Don't worry about the "keyboard proficiency" requirement, it probably doesn't matter any more.
Good course, you learn a lot with a small amount of actual conducting.

Such a good course! Every week there is one day of discussion of readings and, sometimes, various exercises, and one day of conducting lab - when each student conducts the others and Gabriel and the other students provide critiques and guidance. Both are helpful, but the second especially so - and it manages to be both really helpful, with a lot of useful critiques given, and a very safe environment despite all the mutual criticism. If you want to really get a lot out of this course, though, you'll need to really make time to practice conducting much as you would practice an instrument.
Take it.  It's great and Gabriel is a really wonderful instructor.
Take this course if you are interested!!!  You will LOVE it.
The best course ever! If Gabriel is teaching it, you won't regret it. As long as you're really interested in learning how to conduct, apply!
Wonderful course, definitely take it, just be prepared to put in a number of hours practicing and doing readings. As of now, offered every other year in the Spring (odd years).
Working with Gabriel is an enlightening and inspiring experience. Everything is done really well and I would highly recommend it.
the class is a little too big but fantastic.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of instructor. Some background in music theory. Basic keyboard facility. Membership of either glee club or chamber choir for the semester in question. Contact Gabriel Crouch to schedule an interview..
descrip: This course will focus on: 1) the development of competency in choral conducting technique 2) verbal and non-verbal communication in rehearsal 3) the study of choral repertoire of various styles and genres, emphasizing analysis and interpretation and 4) the development of good rehearsal strategies.

title: Dynamical Systems
descrip: TBA

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: Be prepared because this class is a lot of work and time in the studio, but because you invest so much time, you get so much more out of the course

I think this class will definitely help art students of any level improve. I do think that it requires a good amount of time and effort, but I think that it is worth it. I would recommend this class to any student.

If you want to be in the certificate program or program 2, definitely take this course. It'll help you refine your technical skills and you'll get some great paintings out of it. If you haven't painted before, no worries, you'll learn quickly and Professor Jermusyk is very helpful.
If you're not really interested in painting, you probably don't want to take this.  But if you are a beginner and want to try it out I would highly recommend!

Pay attention to the professor who is teaching your painting class and know what kind of experience you want. Jermusyk is very traditional, while other are more modern. Enjoy the class, and take risks! I wish I had. Just try some new things and don't stress too much. Have fun with your painting, but also know that we were expected to spend 6 hours painting outside of class time per week, which proved to be a lot, considering 6 hours never really seemed to be enough anyway to get what needed to be done finished.
Take this class out of interest! Learning to make my own canvas frame and stretching canvases was one of the most satisfying things I have learned at Princeton.
amazing course, relaxing, but it is hard and there is alot of extra work outside the class periods, also class periods are long, can get draining
dont leave your painting for the night before.
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and interaction with light.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I can fully recommend the studio. Jesse has been helpful and supportive of my ideas. He was really open for experimentation.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: The Origins of Rome: Livy and Vergil
reviews: Good course, but LAT 203 is probably be a better choice, especially since Rose will no longer be teaching 108.
I would strongly recommend this course
Keep up with the translation assigned each night, find a good dictionary, and make a vocabulary list.
Make sure not to get behind on the readings, and ask about grammar or other questions as they come up.
Rose is great but she graded somewhat harshly.

Take this course if you like Latin. Odds are, if you need to take 108 anyway, you will take this course. But still - it moves at a good pace, the material is fun and worth reading, and it all stays interesting. Work hard.
do it. do it
prereqs: LAT 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read selections from Livy and Vergil, the masters of prose and poetry respectively in the period of Augustus. Our objectives are: to develop the ability to read Latin with greater ease and enjoyment; to improve sight-reading skills; to experience the artistry of Latin prose and poetry; and to examine some of the questions associated with the Romans' interpretation of their history.

title: Politics and Religion
descrip: In this highly interdisciplinary course where we draw on political and social theory, comparative politics and constitutional law we address three concerns: first, how can politics be protected from religion, and how can religion be protected from politics? Second, do certain types of politics depend on religious sources, in particular might liberal democracy actually `live off religious feelings and intuitions in ways that liberal theorists do not acknowledge? If so, does even the liberal state need a `civil religion of some sort? Finally, does secularism need to be rethought more fundamentally in a supposedly `postsecular age?

title: Symplectic Dynamics
prereqs: Some basic exposure to elliptic PDEs, differential geometry, and symplectic geometry..
descrip: Symplectic geometry and the theory of dynamical systems have a nontrivial common core around Hamiltonian dynamics. It seems natural to try to bring ideas from these seemingly different fields together. A good starting point are questions concerned with the dynamics of area-preserving disk maps. A basic tool, which will be developed, is the theory of pseudoholomorphic curves. The study of area-preserving disk maps will be accomplished by studying suitable almost complex four manifolds. This graduate course should lead up to some interesting PhD topics, just in time with the program on "Symplectic Dynamics" at the IAS in 2011/2012.

title: Transformation of the Ancient World: Byzantium 500-1200
reviews: As someone looking for an interesting history course (or a new look at Byzantium, since we didn't spend too much time on the art and religious sides that normally get all the attention, I'd highly recommend it.

I took the class when there was low enough enrollment that there would be only one precept, and rather than schedule it, Prof. Haldon just extended the lecture for half an hour each day. This was a very bad idea, since only about half the time did he present enough material to go into the extra time. Some days people had questions and his responses would be informative and take up the time, but mostly we just ended early. He never referred to the reading since there wasn't a precept where that was the only thing on the agenda. So don't buy the pequod if he runs the class like this again. 

The take-home final was really long.

It's a great history course with a very approachable and friendly professor. Professor Haldon is passionate about the topic and shares that passion with his students. The readings are not too bad and the midterm and final are very manageable.
Take it! But don't do all the readings. Pick and choose what you think might be relevant.
This is a good course, with a good professor. However, if you don't enjoy lectures, this is probably not be for you.
descrip: This course introduces the history and culture of Byzantium, with some material on the medieval European world to the West and the Islamic states to the East. We will focus on the development of Byzantine society and economy, on how the state worked, and how Byzantium related to its neighbors to both the West and the East. Why did the eastern Roman empire survive the barbarian invasions of the fifth and sixth centuries? How was the state ruled and by whom? How did it deal with the powerful Islamic states to the East? How and why did the Byzantines arouse the hostility and suspicion of the medieval West and the papacy?

title: Introductory Seismology
prereqs: PHY 104 and MAE 305 (can be taken concurrently), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Fundamentals of seismology and seismic wave propagation. Introduction to acoustic and elastic wave propagation concepts, observational methods, and inferences that can be drawn from seismic data about the deep planetary structure of the Earth, as well as about the occurrence of oil and gas deposits in the crust. Offered every other year.

title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Thermodynamics and Kinetics
reviews: Be sure you can learn from a book
Ben is a great preceptor!
Do a lot of practice problems before the exams.  They help.
Don't take it. for your own sanity.
Go over the powerpoint slides; seek out Prof. Kelly and Ben one on one.
I hear it's better than quantum.

It's a good intro class to thermodynamics. Nothing too difficult or mathematically involved (in fact, Kelly specifically tells us to just ignore a lot of the proofs in the book). I personally put a lot of time and effort into this class because I was not sure how to approach a more quantitatively based class, but looking back I would probably say that my effort was probably excessive. If you can comfortably do the problem sets (and also pick out a couple more problems from the end of the chapters), then you're in good shape for exams. Ben's a great TA, so if he's still around next year take advantage of his office hours.
Take thermo from another department if you can. This class may be one of those "necessary" evils of the Chemistry department. Don't take it senior year as a science major. You will hate it to death.
Take this class, unless you have better things to do.
Take this course if you are interested in physical chemistry
Take this if you need it as a departmental-no reason to take it if not.

Textbook is not the greatest

Tests are comprehensive and cover most lecture slides

This is a big time commitment.  The material is just as dense as Quantum but it is slightly more approachable and taught much better (Kelly vs Soos). If you find yourself out of time, it is a sad but true fact that you can do decently merely by plug-and-chugging equations you don't really understand.

This is an easy class, do not worry. However, it is also really really boring and involves a lot of inane and trivial busy-work in the form of problem sets that are long but unchallenging. Exams are roughly the same - averages are typically around 80. Basically, this class is like a high school class. If that floats your premed boat, then you'll be happy. Otherwise it's mostly a waste of time.

Understanding of thermodynamics is central to having a good scientific intuition about many physical and chemical phenomenon. I would recommend this course to students who want to have a general understanding of thermodynamics.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 and MAT 104, or CHM 215, or permission of instructor. Course is open to freshmen who have completed CHM 215..
descrip: At the center of this course is the recognition of Gibbs Free Energy as a fundamental quantity describing physical processes. From this, we will develop concepts of thermodynamics and kinetics, and illustrate them with examples from chemistry.

title: Topics in Development - Policy Implications of Globalization
descrip: Explores the historical background of globalization including previous examples of this phenomenon. Proceeds with an overview of competing contemporary theories of the causes and consequences of globalization. Discusses the types of data required for analysis of the policy implications of globalization and how these can be utilized. Emphasis on the use of transactional data using network analysis. Students will use primary sources and databases in discussions of policy areas including trade, migration, security, media, etc. No formal training in statistics, database management, or networks required.

title: Solid-State Physics II
prereqs: ELE 441 or PHY 405.
descrip: Electronic structure of solids. Electron dynamics and transport. Semiconductors and impurity states. Surfaces. Dielectric properties of insulators. Electron-electron, electron-phonon, and phonon-phonon interactions. Anharmonic effects in crystals. Magnetism. Superconductivity.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - American Religion to 1865
descrip: This readings seminar offers a broad survey of the scholarship on American religion to 1865. We read a combination of "classics" in the field alongside more recent literature that suggests where the field might be heading. We engage with texts that speak to specific cases and themes in early American religious thought and practice, and also with scholarly attempts to synthesize the material into a coherent whole.

title: American Constitutional Development
descrip: Explore questions of order and change in American constitutional doctrine and institutional relations and powers across time. Students will consider diverse theories of constitutional and institutional change, including those drawn from comparative politics. Emphasis will be on the relationship between paths of constitutional development and both conventions of legal and constitutional reasoning, and political, economic, social, and intellectual currents, settlements, and crises.

title: The Wireless Revolution: Telecommunications for the 21st Century
prereqs: MAT 103 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: This is an interdisciplinary course addressing technological, regulatory, economic and social issues arising in the rapidly developing field of wireless communications and computing. The course is intended to introduce students to a major technological trend that will be a significant force in worldwide commercial and social development throughout the 21st Century.

title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Stochastic Hydrology
reviews: If any student is interested in data analysis related to climate, he or she should consider taking this course.
If you are interested in environmental and geoscience statistics, this is a good class.
prereqs: Basic background in probability and statistics. Computer programming skills. MATLAB Skills or better..
descrip: Use of probability and statistics for hydrologic mideling and analysis. This methods- based course will include: probability models, including the L- Moment parameter estimation method; estimating bivariate distributions using copulas, time series analysis, spatial data analysis using kriging, as well as principle components ( empirical orthogonal functions, EOF), Monte Carlo simulation and hydrologic forecasting. The course will involve readings from the stochastic hydrology literature and hands on computer analysis and simulation.

title: Ethics of Honor and Competition, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Electronic Circuits for Biomedical Application
reviews: An introductory course on analog, IC design should be compulsory for any self-respecting electrical engineer. This course fulfills this objective, while providing a stimulating and enjoyable environment.
Have a good background in electronics before taking this course, it will challenge you.

I have taken many advanced circuits courses previously and still managed to gain a lot out of this class, especially fundamental intuitive understanding of circuits. This is a course that covers a wide range of circuits coupled with some very interesting case-studies into biomedical applications and the constraints of low-power design. 

Basic circuit simulation is taught using Cadence, which is also a very worthwhile component of this course. 

Lecturer is outstanding (you will not notice when he goes 20 minutes over time....) and always made time for us outside class time whenever we had convoluted questions.

Highly recommended.
If you want to learn about small signal circuit analysis and are willing to work hard, definitely take this.
Take it if you have interests in circuits.
Take it!
prereqs: ELE 203, ELE 208, ELE341 (recommended, exceptions by instructor's permission).
descrip: Start by analyzing biological systems to understand the origins of some of the signals that they present. Develop circuit models of these systems to determine what instrumentation circuits are required at the interface so that the signals can be reliably acquired. Study analog circuit topologies based on MOSFETs for low-noise instrumentation and processing of the signals. Study digital topologies based on MOSFETs for extensive computations on the biological signals. Analyze the trade-offs between the analog and digital topologies. Emphasis is on design and analysis using circuit simulators.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A good beginning course.  Be prepared for criticism, and try not to get too attached to your work.
