An easy 4th or 5th course. Not too much work, but you don't get too much out of it either. Toibin is a really nice, smart and interesting dude, but perhaps not the best teacher. He's leaving anyhow, so find out about your professor before you sign up.
DO the readings on time so you'll have better discussions in class.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take this course if you are remotely interested in writing. It is a lot of fun and can really help you.
Don't be afraid to be blunt and specific when leaving comments on classmates' work. The more critical you are, the more helpful you will be to their improvement.
I think that the very nature of the course guarantees an enjoyable and productive semester.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone interested in seriously improving their creative writing.

I would definitely recommend taking this course, even if you have no prior creative writing experience. It was such a nice break from all of my other classes, and I felt like I really got a lot out of it.

I would definitely recommend this class to any student who is interested in pursuing a Creative writing major or certificate. Professor Moore is great, and the assignment load is definitely doable. I would even recommend taking this class as a fifth class if students need to fulfill other distribution requirements, as the course load is definitely manageable with five classes.
I would definitely take it if you have any interest in creative writing.

I'd recommend that everyone take a creative writing course sometime--not just for the class experience, even though it's great--but because it's something that enhances your own life and changes how you look at the world. I think it matters less who precisely you take the course with, than just having the chance to embrace your creative impulses and take yourself more seriously as a writer.
If you have an interest in creative writing, I definitely recommend taking any fiction writing course. The program is great.
If you like creative writing, this class is great to take!
If you want someone who will kindly but honestly critique your work, Edmund White's creative writing is the way to go.
If you want to write, write!  And then get people to read your stories and give you feedback.  This class is a great way to get comments from other writers.
If you're at all interested in creative writing, you should go for it.

If you're looking for a relaxed atmosphere with constructive- but not overly aggressive criticism, I highly recommend Professor White. It won't be a stressful experience- but you'll still gain really helpful feedback. Take a class with him!

If you're looking to learn some basics about creative writing and want to try your hand at it in a somewhat serious way, take this class.  Consumes very little of your time, little pressure involved, etc.  The old adage "you get out of it what you put into it" is actually quite true with this class; you can ride it out as an easy P/D/F, or learn a fair bit with some effort.
Make sure you start your short stories with enough time to develop them. Don't rush. You only deprive yourself of beneficial feedback and practice when you don't leave yourself enough time.
Maybe try it with a different professor. I've heard about how other classes are structured, and it seems like intro fiction classes are hit or miss, depending on who's teaching.
One of the best classes I've taken in my 4 years here...

Take Creative Writing if you're interested in writing! You will get out of the course what you put in, but also put thought into the professor you sign up for, as it determines the course 100%. I think Professor Moore would be a good choice if you just want a low-pressure course, but perhaps not the best choice if you're serious about writing.
Take it.
Take this course, and write a little everyday.
This class is taught through realist lens, so take this class if you are looking to explore that style.  Always try to envision pieces in a particular place and time.  It's a helpful intro class.
This is a great class! Anyone interested in creative writing should take it.
This is a great way to force yourself to write more, but it's only fair to take the class seriously and really work hard on your stories, since other people will have to read them.
Wonderful opportunity!!!
definitely take this course if you have any interest in creative writing!
keep in mind that this professor has a strong journalistic background. i feel this definitely influences his view of how creative writing should be done.
take it if you're looking for a very easy class
take it with Lee
take it! White is the best!
take it! everyone should have to take a creative writing course at some point.
take this course with prof. moore
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Energy, Environment and Development
descrip: An interdisciplinary introduction to debates about energy, environment, and development. Some of the questions to be addressed are: Should one posit quantitative or qualitative limits to economic growth? What kinds of social change might be desirable or necessary to achieve a sustainable future? What role does energy play in improving the well-being of the poor and how does one ensure that this function is "optimized"? What are the roles for technology and consumption reduction in climate mitigation? How can we reduce pollution, environmental degradation, and human hardship due to the use of bio-fuels in cooking?

title: Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Materials
reviews: Chemistry kids should not even bother registering for this class. They all dropped it after they saw the first homework assignment because they don't like math.

Due to the time consuming nature of the course, I would not recommend it as a general elective requirement.  This course is very good for those who work in the area of materials research, however, including both experimental and theoretical research.
Recommend to engineer students who are interested in theoretical area of materials, but not chemistry students who care more about experiments.
descrip: Thermodynamics and kinetics applicable to phase changes and processing in materials. Physical and mathematical descriptions of phase equilibrium, nucleation and growth, phase separation, coarsening, and diffusion in solids.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics

title: Luso-Brazilian Seminar - Writing and Urban Life
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar explores different writers' representations of urban experience, and how the development of cities has been shaped by writing. Issues to be approached will include the impact of new media (i.e., photography, phonography, film) and urban transformations on literary imaginaries and city life; the interface between literacy, orality and visual cultures (including cartography and architecture); relationships between fiction writing and social history; intersections between modernity and city planning.

title: Martyrdom: Self, Suffering, and Community in early Christianity and Beyond
descrip: This course examines the theory and practice of martyrdom in Western Religious traditions. We begin by closely studying the development of the martyrological paradigm in early Christianity and how martyrdom participated in the culture of the Greco-Roman and Jewish Mediterranean world. We will address issues as intimate as the body and as public as spectacles and the communal definition. In the end we will trace how martyrdom is deployed and functions in modern culture in various phenomena, such as the "Columbine martyrs," "martyrdom operations" (suicide bombers), political martyrdom, and modern notions of holy war.

title: Topics in Latin American Modernity - Workshop on Contemporary Literature and Arts
prereqs: Fluency in Spanish (reading and speaking)..
descrip: Meet the writers! We will study the work of several young, cutting-edge writers and artists from Latin America. Five of them will travel to Princeton and meet with seminar students. Discussion will focus on the relation between literature and politics, and the impact of globalization and other 21st century developments on culture.

title: Social Interaction and Influence
prereqs: PSY 252 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course reviews psychological theories and research on how individuals are shaped by the groups and social situations in which they find themselves. We examine how, when, why, and by whom people are influenced, as well as the conditions under which they are impervious to influence. Topics include the social self, hypnosis, imitation, conformity, compliance, obedience, social etiquette, and social learning.

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy seminar as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 402. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy seminars students work in groups first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Theory of Detection and Estimation
reviews: If you haven't had previous experience with linear discrete-time dynamical systems, find a way to get some background early in the class.
You could learn lots of thing in this course.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental theoretical principles of signal processing related to detection and estimation. The level of this course is suitable for research students in communications, control, signal processing, and related areas.

title: Land Use Policy and Planning
descrip: Examines theory and practice of land use policy and planning in the US. Explores concepts of sprawl and smart growth, then examines land use plan making, law, and regulation. Analyzes land use programs and issues at diverse levels of government, including state smart growth programs, regional agencies, fair share and inclusionary housing programs, open space conservation, and big city planning and redevelopment. Also analyzes the roles and interactions of executive agencies, courts, experts, advocates, property owners, profit-oriented and nonprofit developers, and citizens in land use issues.

title: Modern Quantum Devices: Physics and Applications
descrip: This is an entry level graduate course concentrated on physical foundations of modern quantum electronic devices that have sprung up in the last decade and will become the mainstay of electronic and photonic systems. Understanding of functionality of these devices calls for a deeper comprehension of the underlying quantum theories. Examples of the topics covered: nano-lasers, plasmonics, graphene electronics and micromechanics, single electron transistors, and other topics selected by the students. The course will include students? presentations on topics of their choice.

title: Topics in Modern Astronomy
reviews: 204 is one of the better classes that I've taken at Princeton. Burrows is amazing, as is the course material. That having been said, it's a very challenging course. I got an A in physics 103 and took MAT 215 concurrently with this class, but still managed to get stressed out due to the difficulty of lectures. I ended up PDFing to spend more time on my MAT 215 problem sets, but I probably would have ended up with a B  if I had continued to apply myself fully. Most students in the class are physics majors, so the curve is harsh. I strongly recommend it as a PDF though!

Definitely take this course if you're a physics major, but don't be afraid to take this course if you're just interested in the subject matter. It's probably much more difficult than AST203, but I think this is the only way to get a stronger background.
Don't take it: the textbook is terrible, the homework problems are unclear, and the lectures are scattered.
If the student is interested and willing to work hard for their grade, then I would strongly recommend.
If you are interested in astrophysics, cosmology, astronomy, or the universe, definitely take this class because it is a great survey of all of the above.
Take the course, but just don't hold your expectations too high.

Take this course, but be able to grapple with a new form of lecture. Not everything is black and white in this course. You have make some broad assumptions and ramp up your creativity in Physics concepts. It's extremely interesting, though, and Adam Burrows is a tremendous teacher.
The amount of hand waving in derivations and the overly qualitative nature of the course will be extremely frustrating to most students with significant physics and math backgrounds.
This course covers a lot of material, so if you are interested in learning about astro as a whole, take this course.

This is a great course, not only for astro majors, but for any science major, especially physics majors (like me).  I took this course because I felt that I knew little about space or astronomy in general, and this course did a great deal to fill in gaps in my knowledge.  It's an elegant subject area, and it has many links with other diverse areas of physics, like quantum mechanics and general relativity.  I think the material presented in this course is important for any physics majors to know.  (As a side note, try to take it with Burrows if possible.  He is a great teacher.  I heard negative reviews about whoever taught it last year...)
prereqs: PHY 103 or 105 and MAT 104 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course will provide a broad overview to modern astronomy and astrophysics for students in the sciences. Topics include historical developments; overview of the solar system; the structure and evolution of stars; supernovae, neutron stars and black holes; formation, structure and evolution of galaxies; cosmology and the early universe; and life in the universe.

title: Intellectual History of Europe since 1880
reviews: TAKE IT.
The reading load is not very heavy, but it is important to do it carefully.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Modern Intellectual History. It will examine the period from 1880-1960 focusing on several main trends and key figures. Late nineteenth century authors like Nietzsche, Weber, and Freud will be examined against the backdrop of the classical social theories of Marx and Mill. The era of totalitarianism after World War I will be examined with particular attention to Communism, Nazism (Carl Schmitt), and the debates over humanism and existentialism. The course will conclude with discussions of thinkers during the Cold War including, Raphael Lemkin, Jean-Paul Sartre, Albert Camus, and Hannah Arendt.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - International Political Economy of East Asia
descrip: This course examines conditions that support open markets and economic growth with a focus on the East Asian experience. How have the countries of East Asia responded to the constraints and opportunities of the world economy? The path to export-led rapid growth in Japan, Korea, China, and Southeast Asia will be compared to assess the "East Asian Miracle" and the role of state-led industrial policy. The 1990s in which Japan's growth stalled and the region went through a major financial crisis will be discussed to determine policy lessons. What implications does China's emergence as economic powerhouse hold for the region and global economy?

title: Religion in American Society
reviews: Do it!
I would advise any student with an interest in religion - or even one just looking to fulfill a distribution requirement - to take this course.
I would recommend it.
I would recommend taking this class.

If you are interested in religious studies or even other disciplines in the humanities, I would definitely recommend this course. It is a lot of reading, but if you start the works a little before or when they are assigned, it is usually not too difficult to keep up in the course.
Interesting course!
Interesting topic with correlation into other fields, art, history, music... etc. so enjoy it.

It's a great course for freshmen because the workload is manageable and the exams are just like high school.  A course that deals specifically with one aspect of religion in America would probably be a better choice if one wants an introduction to religion in American society.
Know that it feels more like an HA than an SA.  There's a moderate amount of reading but not too much work otherwise.

Pay careful attention to everything that Professor Gin is saying, write everything down, and, as easy as the homework can seem, contemplate the readings as much as possible.  If you have to miss a class, get the notes from someone.

Put simply, do not take this class. 
There's little knowledge to gain, and certainly no rewarding feeling of enrichment for having completed it.
Take it.
This course contains content any American, or International student for that matter, should know.
descrip: A broad survey of religion in American society from the colonial era to the present. Emphasis on religious encounter and conflict; the relationship between religious change and broader social and political currents; religious innovations and transformations; immigrant religions; secularization, resurgence, and pluralism. Mix of primary and secondary source readings.

title: Topics in Development - Politics and Development in India
descrip: This course is a graduate level survey of themes in the study of politics and political economy of development in India. The following themes will help organize the course: How does one make sense of democracy in a poor, multi-ethnic setting? How has democratic politics shaped and been shaped by a society divided along numerous lines such as caste, class, and linguistic and religious identities? And how well has India's democratic state fared in promoting economic development, both growth and equity? Regional diversities within India will also be surveyed.

title: Lab in Conservation of Art
descrip: This course examines how environmental factors (acid, rain, ice, salts, and biota) damage sculpture and monuments made of stone and masonry, paintings on wood, and sculptures in bronze. We examine campus buildings that illustrate each type of damage and visit the Cloisters Museum to learn how those medieval buildings are protected. Lectures on structure and properties of materials and mechanisms of attack. Labs include quantifying water movement through stone, damage from freezing and salts, strength of mortars, protective effects of sealants and consolidants, effect of moisture on wood.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced Italian
reviews: Absolutely take this course with Teardo if you are interested in Italian or need to fulfill your language distribution requirement, or if you just want to have a fun class. Assignments are graded very fairly and Teardo goes over test material beforehand. Engaging class conversations that were light-hearted but also useful since conversations were nearly always in italian.
DO IT AND YOUR LIFE WILL BE BETTER
Definitely take this and try to get into Sara's section!
Especially if Sara Teardo is teaching it, definitely take it! It is really fun and engaging, and all of us become really close friends because of this course.

I absolutely loved this course. There are not many classes which could remain interesting and stimulating for an hour and a half every day, but this was always my favorite part of the day. Both Weinapple and Spinazzi are wonderful instructors--very knowledgeable, nice, fun, etc. You're able to become very close with them and the rest of the class after spending so much time together, and my knowledge and familiarity with the language increased tremendously. Just be ready to do the necessary work every day.
I would recommend the course without reservation.

If you are taking Italian, take 1027. I think it is worth a little extra work. You really learn a lot in the semester, but it's not overwhelming. I wasn't particularly great in ITA 101, but forcing myself to take this class was a great decision and really improved my Italian. Plus, Weinapple and Spinazzi are great, super entertainin!

If you have a commitment and desire to learn the Italian language quickly, then you'd be stupid not to take this course.  Be prepared to do an extensive amount of daily work, but also be prepared to learn the language much quicker than you thought was possible.
If you want to learn Italian, no reason not to.
It's a wonderful course to take, and worth the extra time per day to get through 2 semesters worth.

Take 1027! The workload is manageable and the speed is great, especially if you want to challenge yourself a little more than 101/102. The teachers are great, so don't worry about things just sort of flying over your head--the teachers really look out for you.
There is nothing one can regret from taking this course.
its a fantastic course, bur definitely more work.
prereqs: ITA 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Italian 102-7 is an intensive double credit course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Reading comprehension and oral proficiency as well as reading skills and grammatical accuracy will be developed through various activities. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be familiarized with various cultural aspects of Italy through readings, cultural videos, and films.

title: Proteomics in Biological Sciences
prereqs: MOL 345 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course will highlight the various contributions of mass spectrometry-based proteomics to various life science fields. Areas covered will include fundamentals of mass spectrometry, protein identification and quantification, characterization of post-translational modifications and protein interactions. This course will include discussions on the present state of proteomic research, with special emphasis on characterizing protein assemblies and applications to virology, signal transduction pathways and epigenetic networks.

title: Advanced Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A really good class if you like a healthy amount of theory behind linear algebra. This class, more so than 203, gave me some exposure to writing proofs, since I had none in high school, and made me seriously consider becoming a math major. If you don't have much experience writing proofs but are interested in doing so, 204 is a nice gentle introduction because of the abstract nature of the material covered.
Do a lot of practice problems by yourself.
Do all the reading on the text book. It will help the exam.

Do not take this course unless you consider yourself outstanding at math. Even if you were great in 203, you may find this to be extremely challenging. The hw will take up a lot of your time, and the exams will be painful no matter how hard you study. Take 202 unless you're really looking for pain and angst.
Find out who is teaching it and whether they can teach. It will be critical to your understanding of the subject and ability to succeed in the class.
Go to class.  I wish I did more.
I think taking this class was a good choice over 202, because the style of thinking was just more practical
I would recommend this course to those learning linear algebra.
I would say to only take this course if you are very strong in math. It can be really difficult and the material can be very abstract and difficult to visualize and understand.

I'm not sure if 202 is any better or worse. Just make sure you have a good instructor. Unfortunately quality instructors are apparently very hard to come by in the lower levels of the math department...

If Yichio Tian is teaching, take it in a heartbeat. He is a wonderfully kind and funny professor, who knows more about his subject than any lecturer I've had. Don't skip classes...the book is very ineffectual.
If you have to choose between 204 and 202, go for 204.  It's much better.

It's an excellent course, especially with Professor Tian (I can't speak for the others). Keep up with the work and definitely get a study group if you feel like you're falling behind. This material is extremely cumulative.
It's not hard if you study it well; be alert, take notes, study.
Make a study group, read the book closely and study hard off of past exams.
Read the textbook before going to class to get an overview, even if the explanations are bad.
Take 217. It is harder but it is worth it.

Take class with Yichao Tian if possible; I heard that Reichart's students barely understood anything.
Spend time understanding all the concepts on each pset. Everything taught is based on previous concepts, so falling behind 1 week means you're dead the next.
Take this if you really need to see derivations and proofs and good reasoning to appreciate a subject. I came out of 204 with a solid understanding of linear algebra.
Take it if you like math. Otherwise, take 202.
Take it!  It was an interesting class, which I liked much better than MAT 203.
Take it.

The course can't decide if it wants to be pure or applied. You get some of both, but neither part is really fleshed out. However, you don't have much choice if you need to take linear algebra and want something more intense than 202 but can't dedicate the time to 217.

This class was really hard, so only go for it if you have an interest in the theoretical parts of math.  It did lead to a better understanding of the material, but proofs are hard and are something totally different from pure application.
This class will move quickly. Much more proof based than 203, so beware if you do not like / are not good at proofs.

This course requires a fair amount of dedication, and the abstract aspects of the course might be a little difficult at first, but there are very interesting applications of the theoretical material, especially in the latter half of the course.

This is a good course and people have told me that it is better taught than 202 (although it is much harder).  Make sure you have Yichao as your lecturer.  He can go through material really quickly sometimes, but he lays out the material very methodologically.  Go to review sessions, lectures, and work on problem sets in groups.

This is a pretty good class for those who are interested in math beyond simply calculating. It's not that theoretical, but it gives you a good look at where a lot of the material used in MAT 202 comes from.
definitely take it if you want something more challenging and in depth than 202, but easier than 217.
go to office hours if possible
descrip: This is the linear algebra part of the MAT 203-204 sequence, which is somewhat more theoretical than the 201-202 sequence.

title: The Art of Science, the Science of Art
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This lab course complements NEU 502A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include electrophysiological recording, functional magnetic resonance imaging, psychophysics, and computational modeling. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: AVOID at all costs.
Another textbook would be a great reference tool.
Any other statistics class has got to be better than this. Do not do it.

Be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own. Go to office hours. Devout devote a fair amount of time to doing the problem sets because they may take a while to figure out (but they aren't unreasonable).
Choose another stats course.

DO NOT take this class unless you absolutely have to. It was probably the worst class I have taken at Princeton. The lectures were awful, the homework just required you to memorize buttons on a computer program and the textbook was unreadable. Absolutely avoid this class if possible.
Do not take this class unless you have to.
Do not take this course unless the textbook has been changed.

Do not take this course unless you absolutely have to. It is not good AND there's a research requirement if it's your first or second psych class. If you're not a psych or politics major, take a really easy QR and pdf it instead.
Don't buy the textbook; it is a waste of money
Don't ever do it.
Don't take it unless you must.
Don't take it.
Don't take it. Don't freaking take it. Unless the textbook changes.
Don't take this class if you can avoid it. If you have to take it, go to every lecture, read everything twice, get a good preceptor and pray that you pass.
Don't take this class if you don't want to be a Psychology major.
Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to
Dont take it
Easy stats class
Great practical applications.
I chose a stats course based on what would fit in my schedule. It sufficed.
I think that Professor Conway is great--he is very good at explaining things if you e-mail him or attend office hours. Also, I admire his passion for statistics.
I would definitely attend every single lecture as well as the professor's office hours if you can make them.
I would recommend asking any questions and studying hard for the exams.
I would recommend this course to other students.
I would strongly advise meeting with the professor and with the preceptors if you do not understand the material, and just to make sure that you do.
I'd recommend it only if you have to take it for a requirement and are choosing between some courses.

If students need to take a statistics course, this would be the one to take. The professor is willing to help as much as possible. However, if students do not need to take this course, do not even bother.

If you do not need this class for a department, I wouldn't take it.  The material is very dry and the examinations are difficult without completely devoting your time to understanding every relationship in course concepts and comprehending the incredibly difficult graduate level textbook.
If you need a stats course, take it with Professor Conway and Tim.  Reasonable work load, and it's useful/easy to learn SPSS.
If you need a stats course, take this one!
If you need a stats course, this is still probably one of the easier ones.  Problem sets never took more than 30 minutes because you basically learn how to answer them in labs.
If you need it for the prereq you have no choice but to take it and get through it. Wouldn't take it just for fun.
If you need to take it, then take it.  If not, then take something else.  The PSY parts of it seemed interesting
If you put in the work to understand the main points, after a certain point the rest of it becomes really easy.
It's a good way of learning introductory statistics that's trying to move away from its reputation as an easy course.
It's not too difficult if you keep up with the material. Make sure to ask questions as they come up, so that you don't fall behind.

It's probably the easiest of the stats classes (so I've heard) but I and my friends taking the class often commiserate because we usually feel pretty lost as to what's happening, which is unsettling. Conway is a good lecturer and genuinely wants us to learn, but he could be slightly more organized in his lectures.
It's really hard, but it's a really important class if you want to do any kind of psychology/anthropology/sociology research. Andy is a stellar professor.
Look for another stats book to clarify the material; the assigned textbook is not helpful.
Only take it if you're going to be a psych major.
Only take this if you have to for the psychology major
PSY251 was not that great this semester, but I feel that the instructors were aware of it to a degree that next year's course will be many times better.
Pay attention to lectures and labs. Make sure you know the concepts. If it is the same as this year, don't buy the book and beware of disorganization.
Take if you need to, probably the best stats class to take
Take it for an easy statistics class, but I hope the readings are remedied by then.
Take it if its a pre-req to your dept.
Take this class if you're looking for the easiest statistics course.
Take this course if you need the distribution requirement.
Take this if you want a broad overview of how statistics is applied to psychology.  Be prepared to do a lot of work outside lectures and labs if you really want to understand the material though.
The book is useless and not even worth reading. Go to lecture and lab to learn everything you need to know.
There is some important, useful information in here, but I did not especially enjoy this class, although I'm glad I now know some basics.
This class is boring. Don't take it unless you have to. I wish I had just taught the material to myself.
This class was extremely difficult if you were not a psychology major. All of the tests were difficult and the textbook made no sense. I wish I had dropped the class.

This course is actually a great introduction to statistical analysis for psychology. The only thing is you can get easily behind because things may seem easy- stay on top of the reading and most importantly ASK QUESTIONS.
This course is excellent for those who aren't huge on math.  It is not easy, but it is a lighter load than some of my other courses and could serve well as a 5th course if needed.
This course is not about the fundamentals/basics of statistics. It teaches you how to do Psych research ie. how to read and understand output from SPSS.
This course is not an easy A by any means.  Be prepared for stress.
This course only really made sense if you had a basic understanding of stats...if you haven't taken high school stats, it would be really hard to get through.

When you see that this course is titled "Linear Algebra" you might think that this course is easy. I certainly did. But don't be fooled by its deceivingly simple name. Linear Algebra is not about solving for an unknown variable in x   1 = 2. I mean, it's based on a similar concept, but it's different. Think about solving for an unknown vector instead. Not so bad? Well, now imagine that the vector in is one dimension, two dimension, three dimension, four dimension, five dimensions. Suddenly you can't visualize it any more. Then add the kernel, a complex contraption that requires you to find vectors perpendicular to other vectors, and everything becomes a jumbled mess. And that's only the tip of the iceberg. The exams ask you ridiculously hard true or false questions and ask you to do mini-proofs - justifications for all of your answers - and you have to provide very good explanations or you lose points. The midterms and finals are also ridiculously hard. They teach you a simple concept in class, they go two or three levels deeper on the exam and expect you to solve it. I guess the equivalent would be if somebody taught you the pythagorean theorem, but then on the test asked you to prove it. My advice is to go through ALL the midterm and final problems. The book is pretty useless as their examples are pretty elementary. But if you go thorugh all the problems you can get more practice for what the real tests are like.

prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 or permission of Instructor..
descrip: Euclidean spaces, vector spaces, systems of linear equations, matrices and linear transformations, determinants, orthogonality, Eigen values and applications to systems of differential equations, symmetric matrices and Quadratic forms.

title: Communism and Beyond: China and Russia
reviews: Great course if you're interested in Russia or China. It provides a really interesting perspective that you won't get out of a HIS class and Prof. Kaple is terrific!

I already knew a good bit about Russia, and I really didn't learn much about Russia from taking this class.  I learned about China, mainly because I knew very little about China to begin with.  It was a lot more like a history class than a sociology class; I wasn't sure what was really sociological about it until the final week when we read about the theory stuff, in a completely divorced setting from the subject material of the course.
Prof. Kaple is a very nice lady, though.
I would recommend this class with the caveat that it is much more historically based than sociologically based.

If taken just as a matter of general interest it is alot of work, the lectures adn subject matter is very interesting but the weekly responses and mid term/ final are not easy and it will definitely add to your course load
If you're looking for historical sociology, take it.  If you're looking for sociology or history, look somewhere else.
TAke it!
Take it if you're into political history
Take the course if you have any interest at all in China and Russia.
Yes I would recommend it to students interested in the topics.
You will love this class.
descrip: This course focuses on the communist experiment in the Soviet Union and China. The first half of the course presents the political, social and economic histories that characterize the USSR's and China's particular path to communism. The second half of the course focuses on the consequences of communism by examining each country's demographics, environment, social structures and so on.

title: Structural Geology
reviews: General Douglas MacArthur once said, "Build me a son, O Lord, who will be strong enough to know when he is weak, and brave enough to face himself when he is afraid, one who will be proud and unbending in honest defeat, and humble and gentle in victory."   I think he was talking about me during and after this class.

If it is being taught by Maloof, think twice about taking this course.  Although you will learn a great deal you will have to make a big sacrifice in your life to do well. This includes regular all-nighters high stress loss of appetite. Take this only if you are interested in hard rock geology and even then think twice.
It is an excellent course, but not for the faint of heart.  As always, Prof. Maloof's expectations are very high.  Don't get caught up in the BS and you'll do fine.
It's a great course, but be prepared for it to take over your life.  Seriously - plan your schedule accordingly.

This class is engaging and interesting, but be warned. You probably should not take it if you are not a Geoscience major. This course is not for the faint of heart. There is difficult and there is Adam & Blair difficult. Adam & Blair difficult involves a workload you cannot possibly begin to imagine. This class will push you to the BRINK OF CATASTROPHIC FAILURE. You will brush Mohr's envelope and see if you are strong enough to avoid fracturing and shattering into a million pieces. I hope you come out alive on the other side.

This class is still being built, so advice I give you now might not apply very well in a few years when you're taking the course. But know this: The problem sets for this course are long and are probably only going to get more difficult. They're really satisfying to finish, but unless you want to spend upwards of 12 hours each week working on the problem sets, I'd advise against the class. But if you're willing to devote a lot of time to an awesome subject with great instructors, the work you put into this will be returned tenfold.
prereqs: One semester of college-level calculus, one semester of college-level physics, and one semester of college level geoscience are required. Open to freshman with permission of instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the physics and geometry of brittle and ductile deformation in Earth's crust. Deformation is considered at scales from atomic to continental, in the context of mountain building, rifting, and the origin of topography.

title: Simulation and Modeling of Fluid Flows
reviews: It is very helpful to take APC 523 before taking this course.
very specific class recommended for those in the field, need solid background
descrip: In most problems of interest in engineering, flow is governed by a set of non-linear partial differential equations (conservation laws), often on geometrically complicated domains, and a solution can only be computed numerically. This course presents the fundamental underpinnings of Computational Fluid Dynamics. Both finite-difference/finite-volume and finite element techniques are illustrated, with emphasis on the compressible flow regime. Advanced techniques for shock capturing are developed, and both explicit and implicit integration schemes are discussed.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: "Strong background in chemistry and physics" means AP physics, chemistry, and biology, and an intro college course in physics as well.  You better have wonderful note-taking skills and be willing to go all-out for this class!  I'm still reeling from it, but if you can handle it, it's the best intro science course, and you'll have a competitive edge on all the other freshmen, especially if you can't take higher level courses to begin with.  Beware, though - a lot of people in this course shouldn't be in intro courses at all, and are just in it for the interesting lectures!
Be ready for the workload.
Be warned! This is just as intense as first semester, don't let anybody tell you otherwise!
Do it!
Don't do it if your not going into science for sure, it's not worth it.  Don't do it if you don't like labs, that's at least 60% of the course.  Don't do it if you're not going to do the work.

I still think ISC is the most interesting (though not the easiest!) introduction to natural science. Though be forewarned: it is a lot of work, and you'll probably gain most if you already know some of the stuff (not necessarily meaning familiar with any of it, just that you've had some exposure to the ideas.)
I think this course shows you a lot about the things that scientists, both experimentalists and theoreticians, have to think about when doing their work.

This will give you credit for computer science and the satisfaction of completing one of Princeton's most intense freshmen course sequences. If you do not have a strong background in physics or vector calculus, you should be prepared to work hard to keep up.

If you took the first semester, stick with it. Second semester, you have a better idea of what to expect and what is expected of you, which I felt makes things much more manageable. The material is also taught in a slightly more traditional way, with more use of textbooks.
If you're into how the sciences all go together, this is the class for you.  If you survived the first semester of ISC, STICK WITH IT!

It is a useful course if you are interested in research, or science as a process. If you are strictly interested in learning physics or chemistry separately, it may be more useful to take the introductory courses. The course is geared in such a way that it really teaches a way of thinking and problem solving.
Make sure you keep up with the readings and ask questions if you have them.  Go to the problem set sessions and take advantage of other students.
Only take this course if you love science and are willing to work REALLY hard. It's the kind of course you are really glad to have taken, but getting through it can be tough.
Read in advance. Look at teachers' notes, not the textbooks.
Rough, but Worth it.
See 234

Lab reports will take ~15 hours every 2 weeks, psets will take ~6 hours every week.

descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. Botstein (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); E. Carter (MAE).

reviews: Don't. Unless you like Alan Mann's disorganized teaching style.
Get involved and speak up!
Great class, very interesting lectures, material is relevant outside of the class room.  Take this class.

Take this course if you need something with an easier workload, but that still provides interesting and engaging material. You will not be swamped with work, but will be eager to do the work you do have.

This class has a lot of potential. The syllabus will make it seem like you will cover a wide range of interesting topics. Unfortunately, it seems that Mann's own interests in food are limited to a few things (nutrition, gatherer-hunters, etc.) and so you never make it to some of the more interesting stuff about food (at least not more than on a surface level). Don't take it if the class size is huge-- it turns into a 3-hour lecture with painfully forced breaks for discussion. There is, however, almost no work for the class (it's not really necessary to do the readings), so if you PDF, it's only a paper and a presentation. Be warned that you don't get any feedback on how you are doing until the final grade.
This class is extremely interesting with a manageable workload. Just make sure you understand the components of your grade before signing up.
This was a fun course.  Lots of reading, but very relevant and personal.
it's information worth learning, but don;t bother with the class
descrip: Foodways is a biocultural exploration of human food consumption. Readings and discussions will focus on both the biological and socio-cultural aspects of what humans eat and the ways human cultures conceptualize food and its consumption. Topics include the nutritional needs of humans, the differences between diet and cuisine, which foods taste good and why some foods taste disgusting, the evolution of human diet, how cultures define what is and what is not food, the symbolism associated with various kinds of food, and how cultures distinguish foods that are suitable for some members of the society and not others.

title: Moby-Dick Unbound
prereqs: Applications are available outside the American Studies Program office, 42 McCosh Hall, and on the AMS website: http://www.princeton.edu/ams/undergraduate_program/seminars_1/ Preference will be for students enrolled in the American Studies certificate program, but students from all departments are welcome to apply. APPLICATION DEADLINE : 12:00 NOON, FRIDAY, DECEMBER 3..
descrip: This seminar undertakes a close reading of Moby-Dick (1851), often acclaimed as the greatest American novel. Why was this story of a tragic sea voyage so neglected in its day, and so celebrated by later generations? To explore its twin lines of action--Ahab's drive to kill a white whale versus Ishmael's quest to know it--we use the methods of history, literature, art, religion, economics, philosophy, and ecology. Of special interest are the ways Melville anticipates recent environmental thought, depicts a globalized culture, and dramatizes the national struggle to reconcile faith and fact, race and justice.

title: Elementary Arabic II
reviews: Ask to get extra help to practice speaking.
Be prepared for a lot of work but you will learn a great deal.
Be prepared for having homework every night as this class meets daily, but overall it's not that much work and its truly very rewarding.
Be prepared to study daily.

Be prepared to work. Arabic is by no means an easy language to pick up--there is a LOT of memorization of vocabulary!!! The work load is definitely manageable if you have good time management skills, but you should be prepared to study every night.
Definitely take it, and make sure you keep up with memorizing verbs and vocabulary. It's easy to fall behind.

Do not take this class. It is the most disappointing experience I have ever had in a Princeton classroom. The Arabic department, largely because of the unprofessional department head, Nancy Coffin, is corrupt and tyrannical. I would publicly advocate for the removal of Nancy Coffin from this University because I feel that the way she handled my situation besmirches the University's name and prestige. Despite my love for the language and my sincere desire to pursue my learning of Arabic, I will not be taking the language next year due to the way I was treated by the head of the department.
Excellent course in all aspects. Arabic isn't an easy language, but ARA 102 is an enjoyable course that further develops and enhances your arabic ability.

I only recommend taking this course if you have a strong and practical interest in studying Arabic. I took this course just because of my curiosity and ended up hating the language. This is not a language you want to dislike and spend a year studying.
I thought ARA 102 was a lot more fun and interesting than ARA 101.  You've already learned the alphabet, so you get to learn more useful parts of the language.  Take it with Bell!
I would strongly recommend the course so long as you are truly interested in learning Arabic - it's a lot of work, but by the end of the year, you'll make a lot of progress.

If you're at all interested in taking Arabic -- DO IT! The professor's are amazing, especially Bell, and you will learn a ton and actually come out of the first year being able to hold up a conversation, even if limited in vocab, for more than 5 minutes.
If you're interested in Arabic, and don't mind getting up for 9 am class, then this is as good a section as any.
If you're interested in Arabic, you can definitely learn a lot from this class.
If you're looking to pick up another language, I would stay away from Arabic.

It is an intense course and grading is relatively harsh, so do not take this course if you are looking for a grade boost.  However, if you love languages or are interested in the Middle East this class will be rewarding.
Professor Bell is the best; taking the course with him is fantastic.
Review everyday; cramming just won't work with a language, especially with Arabic
Spend a lot of time learning vocab and practice a lot! Time spent will yield rewards.
Take it! It's a regular amount of work, but if you keep up, the class is not hard, and Greg is the best teacher

Take this course if you are at all interested in Arabic, or even to fulfill the language requirement if you are up to the challenge.  This course is generally pretty demanding, but the time and effort really pays off in the end.
This is your basic language course. Arabic is difficult. Take it if you want to learn it, but don't expect it to be easy.
Try to stay on top of the vocab!
Yes.
prereqs: ARA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course continues the study of Modern Standard Arabic commenced in Arabic 101. Emphasis is placed on grammatical analysis; writing and reading of increasingly longer, unvocalized texts; further vocabulary acquisition, and continued practice in listening and speaking Modern Standard Arabic.

title: Culture, Power, and Inequality
descrip: This course focuses on the relationship between three core sociological concepts: culture, power, and inequality. Culture denotes the expressive traditions, creations, and ways of life of a group of people. Power pertains to the capacity to exert influence. We will approach questions of inequality through the lens of class, which emphasizes how people fit into social and economic hierarchies. This course explores the ways in which these concepts are related, specifically, the role culture and power play in the formation of class boundaries, musical tastes, fashion, the development of cities, and other topics.

title: The Age of Discoveries: Early Modern Europe, 1450-1789
reviews: DO THE READING!  And do it well; that's the way to do well in the class.
Great new take on things you probably skimmed over in AP European History in high school - a new perspective on familiar concepts. Definitely take it!
Have a strong knowledge of European history to really appreciate the course.
I would not take this class again.  The subject matter is incredibly interesting, but the structure of the class makes it boring and frustrating.

I would recommend this course, especially for prospective history majors or anyone who has never taken a history class before, because it does a great job at leading you through the process of historical thinking and writing. It is also very interesting material and presents important figures and events in a new and interesting light.
Take it if you are interested in European political thought and the Scientific Revolution!
Take this course if you are interested in the subject.  Probably not a great class to PDF.
The problems with the readings made this class less than enjoyable for me.
There is a lot of dense reading. I wouldn't take this if you aren't interested in history.
descrip: The early modern period in European history is often referred to as the "Age of Discovery" because of European encounters with the New World. In fact, the period witnessed multiple discoveries: not just of different parts of the globe, but of ancient texts and learning; of the laws of the physical universe; of the science of politics; of nations (as objects of knowledge and as political actors); and of the idea of secular progress. This course will provide an introduction to the period, from the Renaissance to the eve of the French Revolution, introducing students to key texts and themes of the period.

title: Anthropological Approaches to Arab Society and Culture
descrip: This course will concern how society, culture, and law affect one another in the context of contemporary Arabic-speaking societies. Using anthropological theories to "read between the lines" of the contemporary and historical record, the course will consider such topics as: the nature of the self, the meaning of time in Arab culture and history, the forms of family and political organization, changes in the legal status of women, and the development of democratic institutions. Minority groups, Muslim-Jewish relations, challenges to orthodoxy, and the roles of art and memory will also be connected to changing patterns of social life.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - The Arab-Israeli Conflict
descrip: The course examines the history and dynamics of the struggle between the Jewish and Palestinian national movements for sovereignty and control over territory each claims as its historic homeland. The course will review the inter-state dimension; the competition between national movements; wars and their aftermath; and diplomatic efforts to achieve peace.

title: Roman History - Problems and Methods
descrip: A seminar that introduces graduate students to current methods and debates in Roman history and historiography. Provides a chronological overview of the history of Rome and her expanding empire from early times (8th century BC) to the end of the Severan era (AD 235), accompanied by the study of a wide variety of ancient sources, including texts, inscriptions, coins, material culture, art, and archaeology, and the methods commonly used by modern historians to analyze them. Students acquire the basic tools needed to do research in Roman history.

title: Analysis IV: Special Topics in Analysis
prereqs: Advanced calculus and general topology, or real analysis..
descrip: Math 433 this year is intended as an introduction to the theory of dynamical systems. A considerable portion of the course will be devoted to hyperbolicity, beginning with the existance of stable and unstable manifolds and normal form theorems for hyperbolic fixed points, followed by the study of globally hyperbolic (Anosov) diffeomorphisms and flows. Time permitting, other classical topics will be discussed briefly.

title: Topics in Paleoecology, Paleoclimatology, and Paleoceanography - Biotic Effects of Volcanism and Impacts
descrip: Investigation of paleoenvironments and biotic effects associated with Cretaceous and oceanic anoxic events and large igneous provinces.

title: Empire and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Seminars
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; fourth-year students for 596; and fifth-year students for 597. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Masterworks of European Literature
reviews: I strongly recommend this course. Just try to do the readings ahead of time if you can, like in the summer if you're taking the course in the fall or something.  Otherwise I can almost guarantee you won't have time to finish all the books, and they're worth reading.
I would recommend this course for anyone considering literature as a possible major.

If you have any interest in literature, take this course. Professor Wood is absolutely awesome, and having the chance to discuss things with him in precepts was so much fun, as well as quite interesting.
It's a great course if will actually commit to doing the readings thoroughly. Otherwise, it's pretty pointless.
It's an interesting array of books to read and Professor Wood guides you to a special understanding of them.
This has been my one of my favourite classes at Princeton so far.
Try something new, take this course.
descrip: In the 16th century European literature embarks on a remarkable double journey that is still in progress: into the darkest corners of the mind and the far places of the earth. Through close readings of a number of major works we shall explore this quest for knowledge of the self and of others, paying especial attention to Europe's encounters with the Americas and the Near East. The real and the imaginary are never exactly the same but they do sometimes change places.

title: Socio-Cultural Issues in Modern Spain: 1800 to the present
prereqs: SPA 207 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course explores the cultural, social, economic, and political history of modern Spain from the early 19th century to the present. It discusses the role of war, memory, collective identity, citizenship and utopia, as they appeared in Spanish film, literature, and the visual arts.

title: Architects in Quest of the Ideal City
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: Although you won't get Mrs. Harmon because she's leaving, the French department is amazing and if you're interested in the language it's a great one to learn at Princeton. I could easily get by in France after just two semesters
Don't fall behind on your homework. It might not be checked, but it is useful.

I am entirely the wrong person to ask about this class, as I was taking it with the singular intention of finishing my requirement. I remain entirely neural -- if you must take it, then you will and I can have no sway on you. If you are interested in taking it then you are interested in learning French, and this is the course appropriate for your level. In that case, once again, you have little option beyond either taking this class or abandoning the study of the language. My opinion should play no factor in the decision.

I would take the course for the content--it was interesting and over the course of the semester, you notice an improvement in your language ability. I would not, however, recommend taking the course with Professor Anne Aubert.
If you want to challenge yourself to get better at French, take the class.

If you've got to do it, you've got to, there's no changing that. But it was a good class and definitely helpful for learning french grammar and pronunciation. Less of a focus on vocab, which was good for me.
If your Professor will understand your situation as a grad student, then you will be rewarded for taking the course.

Its a good course. If you're taking it, it's probably for a language requirement or because you want to learn French; in both of these cases there's no reason to try to persuade or dissuade you from taking it.
Just for this professor, I recommend against.
Nothing in particular- I would recommend it.
Study HARD for the tests. They are very difficult, especially with respects to minutia such as prepositions.
Take it if you have to fulfill your language requirement, but avoid Professor Aubert.
The reviews I read complained about the homework. I do not agree. The assignments were very interesting and did not take that much time.
Yes, your French will certainly improve from this course. You will not gain much, however, if you do all of the work at the last minute.
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: Continued presentation and review of grammar. Development of an active command of spoken and written French through class discussion and compositions. Acquisition of reading skills through progressively longer readings.

title: Water in the Atmosphere
prereqs: Background in atmospheric/oceanic sciences..
descrip: Despite the paramount importance of atmospheric water vapour for climate, our understanding of the processes that regulate its distribution and changes within a changing climate remains incomplete. This course analyses observations and discusses theoretical approaches, both basic concepts and novel ideas, to the problem. Course is for graduate students with a background in atmospheric and/or oceanic sciences, and students are encouraged to provide contributions from their own research experiences that are related to the course topic.

title: Energy and Form
descrip: This course will familiarize participants with the basic theories and practices of ecological design in architecture. It will promote professional practices that foster environmentally sound design decision-making and achieve beneficial social and economic outcomes. It will investigate how designing within the matrix of natural systems and processes can enhance both the experiential and poetic dimensions of architecture.

title: Research Seminar in Comparative Studies
descrip: Theme of comparative and interactive civilizations. Primary coverage of China, Japan, Russia, or Korea as well as comparisons with the West. Attention to: national identities, great power identities, strategies of regionalism, principles of social order. Opportunities for individualized readings, as each student chooses an independent focus.

title: Theatrical Design
prereqs: This course is by open enrollment..
descrip: An exploration of the various aspects of Theatrical Design: lighting, set design, costuming. Emphasis will depend to some degree on the instructor's area of interest and/or student interest. Studio projects will be designed to coincide with other theater and dance courses and currently scheduled productions. Critical discussion will explore the relationship between dramatic texts and design ideas. The Spring 2011 class will focus on costume design.

title: Women and Film
descrip: This course will explore the role of women filmmakers in European cinema from World War II to the present. We will examine the way film artists (directors, editors, set designers, etc.) have identified with the visual image specific to the art of cinema and national cultures. It will include Varda, Cavani, Wertmuller, Potter, Campion, and Holland among others. Emphasis on cinematic, socio-ideological perspectives on the role of women in film.

title: Introduction to Logic Design
reviews: All in all the course is worth taking even if you are not a CS or ELE major. Malik is a great lecturer, the TAs are really helpful and the material is not very hard, but still very interesting. The course starts from scratch and builds up, so you are going to understand everything as long as you pay attention during lectures and do all the work for the class.

As a COS major, this course was a mistake for me. The course is not difficult, but still required a surprising amount of work, and the tediousness required for so little reward was not worth it. I had no previous digital circuit experience, but what I did learn from this course could probably have been compressed into about two weeks. Do not take this course unless you are absolutely required to. If you can, find a better text on the subject, read it on your own, and skip ahead to the computer architecture courses.

Ask and answer questions in class!  If you find it difficult to stay focused during 1.5 hour classes, then consider chewing gum (but speaking up will also keep you alert).

Start PUnC early--it can be very stressful, though it does make for a good bonding experience.
Be aware of the workload and the boring parts you have to sit through before getting to interesting material.
Definitely take this course.  I can't imagine an individual who won't be interested by this material.
Do not procrastinate on labs, particularly the final project.

Don't take it as a CS departmental. I thought I would like it - and I did like the theory behind it - but the programming in Verilog, although manageable after a few painful sessions, just wasn't for me.
The lectures are great, and Professor Malik is amazing. Having said that, the problem sets can sometimes turn out to be unreasonably long and complex, and the labs are a *huge* time sink - make sure you're prepared for that.  You will have to spend a lot of time on the labs - and the reason that this point is important is that these labs can take away a LOT of time from your other courses. Labs were okay - I thought Simon was the most fun once I got it to work. The final processor lab was very time consuming and imho could be/should be made simpler. Also, labs count for just 20% of the grade, even though you spend hours on them every week - that needs to be looked into.
Good class to take if your looking to satisfy the systems requirement for CS.
Good course - Malik is a good guy. His midterm and final test your problem-solving skills more than anything, though.
Good course, very slow pace, too much work.

Great course. Malik is a great lecturer, though at times he proceeds pretty slowly. Attending lectures is a must as the slides don't have all the material you may need. Labs are annoying (Verilog is an interesting language to be sure) but only take on average, about 3 hours.
Great course. Very interesting material, and very well taught.

I highly recommend it, especially to students who aren't engineers. I think this is a wonderful class for non-engineers to understand what engineering is, instead of taking engineering classes that are geared toward  humanities students.
I really did not learn very much in this class, but I had to spend a significant amount of time on it.
I really enjoyed this class - it's well-taught and the material is really interesting.
I recommend this course even for people outside of cos and ele - you learn a lot.

I would definitely recommend this course if you are a COS major, have any interest in the logic circuits used in computer processors, or if you just need an ST course but don't want to do a lot of formal lab write-ups or meet for 3 hours a day.

I would definitely recommend this course to others, especially if they are ELE or CS majors because I feel as though the way of thinking that we developed was very systematic and will be useful in many avenues in the future.

I would recommend this course for anyone who is interested in lower level/systems computer science or ELE.  I would advise that they pay attention in lecture, because that is where I learned most of the material
It covers some cool applications, like how a processor or RAM is built. Overall, I think this is a great engineering class and it does a great job explaining logic circuits.

Sharad Malik is a fantastic professor; unlike some others at this school, he's focused on quality teaching and making sure that you're able to learn meaningfully and learn well. For COS majors, this is a great departmental: it starts at the basics of Boolean logic and transistors, and works all the way up to the level of assembly language and programmable processors as covered in 217. It provides a good perspective on computing technology, the lab assignments are interesting, and most importantly, it's taught fantastically well.
Take it if you're at all interested.
Take it.  Designing the processor at the end of the course is one of the coolest things, especially if you've taken COS 217 already, or just have general interest in ELE or COS.
Take it. The material is interesting and good to know in life. Arnab is the man; get to know him.

Take this course if you are at all interested in hardware design. The lab component is challenging, but the TA's are incredibly helpful and you get to work on it on your own time. The course is tough, but very interesting. The satisfaction of designing your own processor by the end of the class is awesome.
Take this course, but be engaged and really try to follow lecture so you can participate to get the most out of the course

This is a great course taught by a great professor who really cares about both the material and the students. One of the best I have taken at Princeton so far. Of particular note is how I felt I was getting a grade I deserved unlike with some other classes.
This is a great course with a reasonable workload.

This is my most favorite class at Princeton so far! If you like understanding how computers work, and thinking logically, this is the class for you. Definitely take this class if you are CS or ELE, and I would even recommend it to any other majors! Arnab is the best TA at Princeton, hands down!
Very satisfying and well-taught course. Start as early as you can on the labs - they take a lot of time!
Yes!
You should obviously take it if you're an EE major, but even other majors can get a lot out of it too.
best class ever.
definitely take it if you're at all interested in the subject, even if you're not an ELE/COS major. malik is a great lecturer.
take it
this is a very time consuming class. if you want to take it, be ready for that.
descrip: Introduction to the basic concepts in logic design that form the basis of computation and communication circuits. Logic gates and memeory elements. Timing methodologies. Finite state systems. Programmable logic. Basic computer organization.

title: Race, Ethnicity, and Nationalism in Latin America
descrip: Examines a wide range of issues regarding race, ethnicity and nationalism in Latin America. We will explore the basic sociological, political and cultural concepts of nation, race and ethnicity, emphasizing how they are used in the region. Race and ethnicity have taken on special meanings in Latin America that are disctinct from other regions. Much of the course will focus on how that came about and how race is manifested. We will emphasize comparisons to the U.S. as well as across countries within Latin America. The course will cover populations of African and indigenous origins.

title: Seminar on Education
prereqs: Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Senior Seminar, taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402), is designed for those preparing to teach in public or private elementary and/or secondary schools. Course content includes: the development of learning goals and rubrics for assessment, the study of national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, the examination of current literature and research on teaching and learning, the discussion and evaluation of each student's performance as practice teachers, and the use of research to measure the effectiveness of the teaching/learning process.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: Be sure that you have a lot more experience than the course description expects. Many of the students have a lot more control of the language than they let on in the beginning.
I highly recommend taking this class with Prof. Rachel Hart. She's the best.

I've had six different language professors here at Princeton for three different languages, and I can say Rachel Hart is DAMN GOOD at her job. It's not a lot of work, and if you enjoy learning French then there's no better way to go.
If you've taken French before.

It is crucial to make yourself go over vocab and grammar every day. People say it over and over, but it's really the only way to learn a language. No matter how good the course/professor is this really the only way to feel accomplished at the end of the semester.
Make sure you have some French basics before taking and don't feel uncomfortable about trying to speak in class.
Take it for fun!  Be prepared to do work, but don't stress out too much about the workload.

This is a great class for someone who has taken a little French or has not practiced it in a long time. Although the schedule seems a little burdensome at first, it is actually very easy to comply with and the constancy of the classes adds to the learning of the language.
This is a great course for those who have taken French before and need a review.
excellent.  this course was manageable for anyone willing to put in the work, and definitely rewarding for a language learner.
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test. Permission of Placement Officer required..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Approaches to Ballet: Technique and Repertory
reviews: Definitely worth it, but be prepared because it it is a large time commitment. Also, make sure that you really want to do a lot of ballet.
If you love ballet or are curious about it, take this course.
Take this course if you love ballet. I plan on taking it every spring.

This class really helps you learn and Tina and the other guest instructors are very welcoming and incredibly helpful.  Don't be intimidated from taking this wonderful class because you think you wouldn't be able to keep up!
This course does require a strong ballet background. You should be prepared to put in a lot of time, especially class time for this course.
prereqs: Application by Interview only. Interviews will be held on Monday November 8th and 15th from 1:30-2:00 in Room 209 at 185 Nassau Street..
descrip: Studio course in ballet technique and repertory for Adv/Int dancers. The course consists of a pre-professional ballet class and selections of classical, neo-classical and contemporary ballet repertory. The course will focus on three different choreographers: Jerome Robbins, Frederick Ashton, Karole Armitage. Students will be coached by internationally known guest artists, including Robert La Fosse, Hilary Cartwright, Karole Armitage, to master and understand the diverse styles of each piece of repertory learned. Readings and viewings of live and taped performances will further students' knowledge of major trends in 20th Century ballet.

title: Slavery: Ancient and Modern
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Film Noir
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors if they have already taken COS 398. B.S.E candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Witnessing War
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Studies in 19th-Century Literature and Culture - Aphorists and Aphorisms
descrip: Aphoristic collections occupy a prominent place in the canon of German literature. One could argue that there were in fact two "Golden Ages" of the aphorism genre. In the first, around 1800, writers such as Lichtenberg, Goethe, or Klinger took an old tradition to a new height. In the second, around 1900, Nietzsche, Kafka, and Kraus wrote world literature in the form of German aphorism. The seminar will be organized as a historical and systematic survey of the genre within German literary history. Close readings will be informed by excursions into the poetics and theory of the aphorism.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop
prereqs: Arabic 302 or the equivalent..
descrip: Advanced readings in modern Arabic literature. Major emphasis on syntax and the accurate understanding of authentic material. Also some readings for overall understanding, with discussion in Arabic.

title: Advanced Analysis of Environmental Systems
reviews: Do not get scared off by the word "quantitative" in the course title. The professors would adjust the level of quantitative skills required in the course so that everybody would not have a lot of difficulty understanding the materials in class.
I would say this class presents a great way to cover a wide variety of topics in environmental systems with a really interesting quantitative analysis part.
Take it!
This class is small, which is nice, and you get to actually talk to two of the smartest professors on Princeton's campus, which is pretty cool.
prereqs: Prerequisites: Mathematics equivalent to MAT 104 or instructor's permission; and Chemistry equivalent to CHM 202 or instructor's permission; and Biology equivalent to EEB 211 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Humans are increasingly affecting environmental systems throughout the world. This course uses quantitative analysis to examine three of today's most pressing issues: energy, water, and food. Each issue is examined from perspectives of natural and engineered ecosystems that depend on complex interactions among physical, chemical, and biological processes.
