The course is an introduction for students in the natural sciences and engineering pursuing an advanced program in environmental studies. We emphasize quantitative analyses with applications to a wide range of systems, and the design of engineered solutions to major environmental problems.

title: Seminar in Global Health and Health Policy
reviews: EXCELLENT! Definitely take it
Great class.  Really interesting and relaxed atmosphere.
Highly recommend this class to anyone interested in health policy.
I strongly recommend this course for whoever is interested in global health and policy.
Take it!
Take this course
Take this course!!! Come prepared to express your opinion in class!!

Take this course. One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. It is entirely discussion based and all the topics are very interesting. Both professors are extremely knowledgeable and guide and supplement the conversations very efficiently. No exams, no papers, and light reading for every week. Have to give one big presentation one time during the semester and lead conversation a few times. Easy course and you will learn a lot.
The guest speakers are a nice feature of this course.
This class is not only for seniors in the GHP program or Woody Woo.  It's accessible, awesome, and gives you perspective on important things that you might not otherwise have perspective on
take it!
prereqs: GHP 351/WWS 491 Critical Perspectives on Global Health and Health Policy, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar will examine four major topics in global health. Potential topics include: the importance of patents in healthcare; AIDS in America; synthetic biology and biosafety; vaccine safety; the business of biology; the state of US healthcare; healthcare in emerging economies; and drug discovery and development.

title: Contemporary Practices in Photography
prereqs: Introductory Photography or Digital Photography or equivalent experience..
descrip: This is a project driven course for the intermediate or advanced studio student. This course explores the variety of ways contemporary artists have used photography since the 1950s, including but not limited to, documentary, conceptual, alternative processes and experimental methods, installation, narrative, collage, serial images, and appropriation.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology
descrip: A selected topic in anthropology is studied; the particular choice varies from year to year.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Beginner's German II
reviews: A very efficient way of preparing for the reading proficiency test, while also allowing you to improve your general language skills, and being highly enjoyable.
An effective way of developing basic skills in German.

Continue your German studies with German 102, even if you are not taking it for a language requirement. It becomes more fun when you see that you are actually improving in both reading and speaking German. However, you really should dedicate a good amount of time to it in your studies if you are hoping to see major improvement.
Great class! John Benjamin is fun, nice, creative, musical, and an awesome teacher!
I really enjoyed my experiences in first-year German.
I would definitely recommend the course. The only catch for grad students is that the 4.45 time slot generates a lot of conflicts with lectures and departmental events.
I would recommend keeping up with the homework, since it is what allows one to come to class ready to practice speaking the language. Otherwise, the course is very straightforward and well-managed.

If you've taken German 101, you know how excellent the Princeton German Department is. Take this class, it will be similar to 101 with a little more writing, or take 1025 if you can handle the challenge.

It definitely goes slower than 101, which is a huge plus, but they do expect A LOT out of you. although there is very little homework, you do really need to study, or else you will suffer terribly in class.
Keep up with the vocabulary and grammar so as not to fall behind.
Much easier than German 101 since you already have a base for the language.
Practice the vocabularies often. Engage in class, and use the online Vocabulary software on Blackboard.
Recommended for graduate students looking to gain a reading knowledge of German. Not as much speaking practice for those interested in speaking German.
The German department is fantastic. All the classes are extremely organized so you know exactly what to study to get good grades on the tests. You will do well if you put the effort in.

This isn't a class that one could strongly recommend against, simply because it is a required step in the sequence of learning German at Princeton. I do think that a student should consider the teaching styles of all the possible instructors of the course and consider what he/she is interested to get out of the course.
While grammar is extremely important, don't forget to effectively learn the vocabulary for each chapter.
You should definitely take German. The professors are fun and offer all the help possible so you can learn the language.
it depends on if you want to learn german or not.
take german!
take it.
prereqs: GER 101 or permission of instructor. About 12 students per section. Normally no credit is given for GER 101 unless followed by 102..
descrip: Continues the goals of GER 101, focusing on increased communicative proficiency (oral and written), effective reading strategies, and listening skills. Emphasis on functional language tasks: learning to request, persuade, ask for help, express opinions, agree and disagree, negotiate conversations, and gain perspective on German culture through readings,discussion, and film. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich, GER 105-G, June, 2011. The afternoon section , intended for graduate students, follows the basic syllabus with added emphasis on reading skills.

title: Ecology and Conservation of African Landscapes
prereqs: Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya.
descrip: Only six percent of Africa's land area (containing a fraction of its biodiversity) is protected, and these areas are rarely large enough to sustain wildlife populations. Mostly, wildlife must share land with people also facing survival challenges. This course will explore how wildlife and people interact in Kenya, where new approaches to conservation are being developed. Lectures will cover the ecology of tropical grasslands and first principles underlying conservation and management of these landscapes. Field trips and projects will examine the dynamics between human actions and biodiversity conservation.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Revitalization of America's Cities
descrip: Seminar focuses on the evolution and revitalization of America's cities. Course concentrates on the public policy and real-world dynamics that help explain the origins, fortunes and fate of cities; examines the lifecycle of cities and their neighborhoods, the forces that drove their decline, the policies and players that have spearheaded their revival, the reasons why some communities have yet to recover, the public policy conflicts and community tensions that arise when revitalization and gentrification get traction, and the potentially transformative impact of the recent economic meltdown.

title: Vertebrate Tropical Ecology
prereqs: Enrollment limited to EEB juniors only and they must be enrolled in the Tropical Ecology Program in Panama..
descrip: This field course will address the life history characteristics of tropical vertebrates and the physiological traits that underlie those. Students will learn how tropical life histories differ from those in the temperate zone and will use eco-physiological techniques while conducting experiments and observations at a Smithsonian Institute field station. In particular, students will trap wild vertebrates, conduct baseline behavioral and physiological measurements, attach radio transmitters to individuals and monitor them over time in the forest. Students will then analyze the data and write a scientific manuscript.

title: General Physics II
reviews: A class that you will simply have to endure if you are an engineer. Rothman and Calaprice are two of the better preceptors. Prepare a LOT for the exams; they are much more difficult than the quizzes and really test your understanding of the material.
A good intro to E&M. The exams are fair, and the homework assignments aren't too bad.

As a pre-med student who had the option of taking 101/102, I would still recommend taking this course if one is confident of their physics and/or calculus skills. Yes, it requires a lot of work, but it was a good challenge, and I learned a lot.

Be prepared to work a lot on the material. If you're an engineer, then you don't have much of a choice, but if you're someone who is simply interested, then I recommend PDFing the class. It is simply to great of a strain on time.
Be ready for a decent amount of work, but the course is a pretty good introduction to E&M.
Better than Physics 103.

Considering physics? First ask yourself these questions:

Is your IQ over 300?
Do you have 16 hours a day to dedicate to a subject?
Did you get a 5 on AP Physics B and C no sweat?

If you answered yes to any of those questions (preferably not the last, that one isn't likely to save you) then take physics, otherwise do yourself a favor and buy the books for this class, but don't actually take the class.
Develop a study group with other people. Also, the textbook is very helpful.
Do not take it if you don't have to or if you don't like physics. This course if very difficult
Do not take it unless you need to.
Do not take unless it is required for engineering.

Do the assigned reading for the upcoming week on Sunday so you can start Wednesday webassign early.  Start Monday webassign on Thursday so you can ask your preceptor questions on Friday.  Attempt all problems on your own at least three times before asking for help.
Do the problem sets conscientiously. Go to office hours if you need more help.
Doesn't matter. Who takes it has to take it.

Don't expect much from this course. It's mostly based on feeding the students formulas with a flavor of concepts. I understand that mostly engineers take this course as a requirement and consequently are not entirely interested in physics - I personally am not one - but I have talked to other engineers and even they are disappointed at how little effort is put on teaching students the actual concepts, which is actually the most important part of the field of physics - concepts. If you want to actually understand what's behind the formulas, you would have to do a substantial amount of research of your own. Understandably, this is PHY104 and not PHY106. However, a little more effort in this area would definitely be a plus. So if you're at all interested in truly learning, expect disappointment. It's doable, though, don't worry. While the teaching is mostly formula-based, the quizes and problems are along the same vein, as well.
As a side note, after taking this course, I am thoroughly convinced that I am going to major in physics: If I like the material IN SPITE OF the course itself, it's a sure sign that I should probably choose physics as my concentration, which I have now happily done. If you find yourself feeling the same way, you could take the same route!
Don't get behind on your work. Also, if you don't have to take this class as a requirement, I would seriously consider the amount of weekly work when deciding to take this class.
Don't take it if you don't have to.

Don't take it if you don't have to. Take 106 or nothing at all. It's monotonous and will kill any appreciation for physics you may have. (I had the best preceptor in terms of doing well in the course and I still disliked this course). No one wants to be there; it's not intellectually stimulating. Just say no.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you need to.
Don't take it.
Don't take physics unless you have to.
Don't take this class unless you are an engineer and are in fact required to take it.
Don't take this class unless you need to.
Don't take this course unless absolutely required!!!
Don't take this course unless you have to. If you have to, just budget in a ton of time for this course. Stay on top of the work, plan ahead, and form study groups. Good luck.
Don't take this course unless you need it as a requirement, or unless you're really interested in the material. I found it challenging.
For many, this class isn't really an option; it's required.  Not much you can do to avoid it.  Just try to find a good preceptor whose office hours you can attend, and grind through labs.
Get Jones as a preceptor.
Go to precepts.  Do the readings.  And make sure to ask questions.
Hard to avoid, but worth taking.

I don't think anyone takes physics here for a lark. This course has much more work due per week than 103 (two webassigns   a written challenge problem   written prelab   a weekly quiz during lecture). 
Calaprice's office hours are amazing! Go to them at least once a week. They will help you much more than lecture or precept (especially if you tend to fall asleep in lecture and/or precept because of a busy schedule). If your preceptor has office hours, go to those also. But definitely attend Calaprice's.
I really like this course, both because I had a great preceptor and because of the material. However, I wouldn't take it unless I had to.

I thoroughly hated this course. It is quite some work and the people in charge were stupid enough to concentrate all that work over two days. The lectures were just really bad, Calaprice really has no idea what he is doing. Having a quiz each weak sucked, it came with so much unnecessary pressure and stress. The midterm was not anything like the older midterms or challenge problems, but they couldn't seem to care less. This is by far the worst course I have taken at Princeton and it has made me hate physics.
I would not recommend taking this course unless you have to. If you can take Physics 101/102 instead, I think that would be a better choice.
I would say take this if you like physics.
I wouldn't necessarily recommend this course to students unless it was required. It is a lot of work, but it will definitely prepare students for future courses regarding the subject matter.
If a student can place out of the course with AP credit, I would recommend that they do that.
If you are curious about the physical world but aren't up for phy106, I would recommend this.
If you aren't a BSE, I probably wouldn't take it because it will become your life
If you can not take it, don't. If you feel like you can handle 106 do that instead.

If you don't have to take it (and you would have had to take 103/105 first anyway), don't take it.  It's a huge time investment with weekly quizzes, two official problem sets per week, a third prelab set with the actual lab as well.  The hours spent studying in this class versus the grade you get compared to other classes is almost laughable.  If you do take it, it can be rewarding and instructive, even if your grade says otherwise.

If you don't have to take this class, don't. It's poorly taught and poorly managed. Some of the professors are good, and you'll want to try to get those if you have to take it. You have to go to lecture, because they give weekly quizzes, but you'll end up studying for the quiz while the professor talks about stuff that you'll go over in class in greater detail the next day. If you have to take it, though, just make sure you get a good instructor, and you won't be doomed.
If you don't need this for a requirement, I really wouldn't suggest it. Unless you PDF it maybe. A lot of work.
If you don't need to take it for your major but just have a general interest in physics, take 102.
If you have taken AP Physics C, seriously consider taking 106. I really should have; this course was really just a review for me.

If you have to take this class, make sure to read the textbook as that helps a lot. Attend precepts because they are three times a week. If you don't have to, consider something else because it sucks up a lot of your time.
If you like physics, take it but don't expect to love it.
If you love physics, take PHY 106.  If you're an engineer, you have to take it.  Otherwise, don't bother.
If you need to take it its not so bad. otherwise dont put yourself through all the work.
If you take these course make sure you are interested in physics because it does require a lot of work. If you have to take this class, have fun.
If you want a cursory understanding of elementary physics, this is the course for you.
If you want to do physics, take 106. If not, this is a perfectly good class, and it is A LOT less time consuming that 106.

If you're interested in the material, I would consider taking the class, but overall it's pretty tedious and time consuming, not to mention competitive because of its nature as a required engineering course.
If you've got to do it, do it.
Interesting and highly recommended
It helps to work through problem sets with a group of friends to bounce ideas off of.
It is interesting but be prepared for a TON of weekly work.
It is quite hard.

It's a good course. Make sure to go to your preceptor's office hour, and spend sufficient time every week learning all of the concepts. For exams, the only way to prepare is to do past papers, because the problem sets are no where near as hard as exam questions.
It's a good physics class for non physics majors.
It's a lot of work and not much fun.
It's a lot of work. be prepared

It's a well taught and well organized class. It's a bit of work, and you spend a lot of time per week in the classroom and in the lab as opposed to other classes. I would only recommend it to someone who really likes the material or needs to fulfill an engineering requirement since the P/D/F option isn't available. Overall, it's a good course. It's much harder than Physics 103 though, so don't get caught off guard by that like I did.
Its tough, very tough. But if you stick with it, its a fascinating course.
Keep up with the work.
Make sure you stay ahead in the material being taught.
Most of the people only take it because it's a requirement but I think it's also really interesting.

My best advice would be to study with friends. I got through the class by working through all the homework with friends who could explain things that I didn't understand. Only take it if you are an engineer or you like physics, because otherwise you'll probably hate it.
Not necessarily a 'fun' course to take unless you particularly like physics.

Office hours with Professor Calaprice are the best!  He'll put you on the spot to work out a problem, which can be intimidating, but explaining a concept to your peers is one of the best ways to reinforce what you've learned.
Only take it if it's a requirement.
Only take it if you have to.
Only take it if you need to. You will save yourself a lot of time and stress by not taking it.
Only take this course if you are interested in E and M or if you need it for a requirement.
Only take this course if you have time for it.
Only take this course if you have to or are really interested in physics, it is very difficult! Go to office hours starting at the beginning of the semester and don't wait until the end to get help.
Overall, not that bad.  Invest in another book as well or go to the library and find a book with more challenging problems, because that is what will be expected of you on the midterm and final.
Phy 104 is a good course for those who are interested in physics. However, they should be prepared for really hard work and keep in my mind that this course is much harder than Phy 103.
Start assignments early and read the chapters each week.  Go to office hours.
Stay on top of the material and make sure you understand all the derivations!

Stay on top of the material, especially if you haven't had prior EM experience. ASK QUESTIONS if you get confused or behind, and make sure you understand the concepts as you go along. Do the Webassigns and problems, and understand them as you go. McGraw is a great resource as well. Good luck.

Take 104 as a departmental, not just for a distribution requirement or for fun (unless you're REALLY excited about physics, in which case it'll probably be a departmental anyway). For a physics class, though, it's as good as it gets; I've learned a lot this semester.
Take if you are really interested and want a deep understanding.
Take it if it's a requirement or if you're generally interested in physics, but if you just need to fill a distribution requirement I'd look for an easier course. This course takes a lot of time.
Take it if you have to, but avoid it if you don't. The class is poorly taught and the professors don't seem to care about the students at all.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you have to; if you're looking for a review of physics, just look at a book for a little while instead.
Take it if you like physics (or if you need to obviously). Keep up.

Take it if you need it for a requirement. I don't know why you would take ti just for fun. It is on a very specific topic of physics and not of much interest to non physics, geoscience or engineering majors. That being said, its quite easy to get a decent grade in it if you put the time and effort in.
Take it if you need to. If you do not, make sure you have a strong reason why you are taking it.
Take it if you want to learn EM but don't want to put in the time for PHY 106.
Take it only if it's mandatory. Don't put yourself through the hell of lab and quizzes.
Take it only if you have to. Be prepared for exams that are extremely hard, since the homework and quizzes give no indication of this.
Take it only if your preceptor will be Valerie Halyo.
Take it!
Take only if it is a requirement.
Take only if you must, if you really love calc/physics, or if you have way too much time that you want to get rid of.
Take this for BSE, not for any other reason.
Take this only if you have to
The course is tough, with weekly quizzes two web assign problem sets and a challenge problem. I would recommend if you are genuinely interesting in physics.

The course moves quite fast, so make sure you keep up with the readings. The weekly quizzes help with staying on track though. Also, WebAssign makes it seem like only getting the right answer is important. Knowing HOW to get the answer is even more important though.
The weekly quizzes kind of force you to keep up, but make sure you really understand the concepts and not just the equations, or else you'll get burned on exams.
There is a lot of work for this course! Multiple problem sets a week are assigned but they do a good job at explaining everything and I found it very interesting.

This class is like any other large science class--full of those who will do very well, those who will do adequately and those who won't do well, but Professor Calaprice and Groth put it together marvelously, so you'll have stories to come out of with with.
This class is very hard and takes a lot of time.  Do not take for fun.  You'll learn a lot of physics though.
This course demands a lot of time and attention.  It is quite challenging.  Find a group to study together with.

This course is a lot more work than PHY 103, but I would say it's also much better taught and the labs are more relevant. I would point out that the webassign problems are also much more involved - actual calculus! - but more satisfying in my opinion.

This course is not amazingly hard, and the material covered is really interesting. If you like electricity and magnetism and need a lab, it's a must! Going to lectures would not be really necessary, but they have the iclicker questions and the quizes... but reading the book is a must.

This course's material is very interesting and useful, and many of the instructors are very good, so the course is certainly decent and doable, but unless you are required to take this course or are very interested in the material, do not put yourself through it.  There is a lot of work involved, including labs and problem sets that, while short, can be somewhat frustrating.  Also, make sure you get a preceptor whose teaching style matches your learning style, as most of your understanding of the material will be the result of attending precept.
This is a good physics course for people who want a little more understanding than "here's an equation and here's where you use it" and aren't as hardcore about physics as the physics majors.

This is a terrible course.  Do not take it unless you absolutely have to.  This class is only doable if you go in with a strong physics background.  The instruction for this class sucks.  There is a lot of seemingly useless, time-consuming work.
This is a terrible course. I know a lot of people who dropped BSE because of it
This is obviously a requirement.
Whatever I was doing in the course was not working, so I honestly don't know what advice I could give other students.
While physics may be a challenging subject, this course is rewarding and will help you learn the material.
Would definitely recommend this! Personally loved physics - the subject is soo interesting to me - but also, I feel like I gained a better understanding of the world around me as well. Great course!!
You get to see a big magnet!
You probably have no choice. I'm sorry.
You will do fine in the course once you understand the fundamental properties of electricity and magnetism.
You'll probably just take this class if it's a requirement and you have to take it. I don't recommend it otherwise. Make sure you spend time on the problem sets.

You're only taking this if you need to, nobody takes this course as an elective.  It's a lot of work, I recommend working with your friends as much as possible.  Also, go to Calaprice's office hours, he is really helpful.  And the labs suck, you're just going to have to deal with it.  Luckily you will never have to compile any sort of lab report.
better than 103! but still, come on why would you take physics if you dont have to
good course, I'd recommend it if your interested in physics, even if you don't need it as a requirement
its interesting if you like phyics. if you dont like physics and calculus, dont take it.
take it.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This calculus-based course is primarily geared to students majoring in engineering and physics, but is also well suited to majors in other sciences. The goal of the course is to develop an understanding of the fundamental laws of physics, in particular, electricity and magnetism, with applications to electronics and optics.

title: The Holocaust in Personal Testimonies: Historiography and Literature
descrip: Many authors claim that, as the Holocaust is the traumatic experience of the twentieth century, it is extremely difficult to grasp, comprehend and portray. This seminar will investigate ways in which these difficulties manifest themselves in various kinds of personal writings. It will cover analysis of statements by witnesses (both of child age and adult), and texts of poets, prose writers and historians. We will read the works of T. Adorno, J. Andrzejewski, H. Arendt, Paul Celan, Anne Frank, S. Friedlander, Raul Hilberg, C. Milosz, M. Sebastian, and others.

title: Innovating Across Technology, Business, and Marketplaces
reviews: Excellent course to learn how technology influences managerial decisions at the executive level, including in the early stages of a start-up. Make sure you are comfortable writing mini-essays of 500 words every week. The guest lectures were invaluable.
Get in early, if it survives its infancy, this course will fill up fast.
Highly recommended if this course is offered again.
I'm sure in the following years JP will add more structure to the course and improve it. Overall it's an interesting course if you like the startup world.

Strongly recommended not only to those who want to start a startup or become a CTO, but also to any creative individual who cares about innovation in technology. The best about this course are the people: valuable anecdotes and personal stories by Prof. JP (presented in a unique style), TA (Muneeb) who is passionate about the course & technology & innovation; last, but not least - incredible guest speakers (top in their field, CEOs, etc.): we had Tom Siebel (Siebel Systems), Naveen Selvadurai (Foursquare), Greg Papadoupoulos (Sun), Fred Wilson (Union Square Ventures), Meg Whitman (eBay). One in a lifetime experience, for sure!
Take the course, JP is amazing and his guest speakers are top notch.
The course was interesting overall. Some of the assignments were pointless, but the professor is trying hard to improve the course, so it'll probably be even better next year.
This course is pretty much one of a kind at Princeton-- definitely take it if you are interested in or inclined towards entrepreneurship.

This is hands down the best course I have taken at Princeton. JP Singh was amazing, the TA Muneeb was incredibly helpful and had interesting experiences. This was the first year they attempted to teach a course like this, so it will only get better in term.
easy class, not much work, interesting topics, not very well thought out, though
prereqs: COS 217 or COS 226 or equivalent..
descrip: This course introduces engineering students to the types of issues that are tackled by leading and innovative Chief Technology Officers: the technical visionaries and/or managers at companies who innovate at the boundaries of technology, business, and marketplaces by understanding all of these areas deeply. These individuals are true partners to the business leaders of the organization, not merely implementers of business goals. The focus will be on software technologies and businesses based on them. To use specific contexts, we will emphasize two complementary areas as examples: businesses based on cloud computing and on marketplaces.

title: Advanced Hebrew Language and Style II
reviews: If you enjoy a relaxed environment in which you can discuss key components of Israeli culture and identity in Hebrew, then take this class. Don't expect to come out and jump on to the Israeli street speed-talking, but your Hebrew will inevitably improve if you participate and take it seriously.
Take it!
descrip: Readings in Hebrew culture, exploring the underlying tensions in identity among Israeli Jews: tensions in religious identity (ie. Ashkenazim versus Sephardim/Ultra Orthodox (Chareidim) versus Secularists), political identity, age/generational identity, and personal identity. We will analyze these issues within the context of contemporary short stories, modern poetry, newspaper articles, and cinema/theater.

title: Readings in Classic Chinese Short Stories
reviews:
1- Summarize the stories somewhere. Details can fly out of your head pretty quickly after a week, but you'll have to be able to remember them for the weekly essay.
2- If you want to improve your speaking level, do weekly gebietanhuas and keep looking over the new phrases that you learn.
3- Listen to the way that everyone speaks, and mimic their patterns. It's a good way to go.

If you don't already know the language pretty well, you might want to take more Chinese first; if you have a decent grasp, though, this is an excellent LA to take.  The only thing is that you don't really have any idea what your grade will be until you get your grades in the end.
If you have interest in the material.
Only if you're truly dedicated to learning chinese.
Study the vocab and use them in precept and essays, but the usage shouldn't be forced.
Take it.
Take the course, but expect to do a lot of regular writing, which is pretty demanding.
There are many international students who take this course, so realize that you'd have to work hard for a good grade.  The content is very interesting, though.
descrip: Focuses on reading and discussing selections from Feng Menglong's Sanyan, the most popular and well-known collection of Classic Chinese short stories published in the late sixteenth century. One class, two hours of discussion, conducted in Chinese. Prerequisite: three or more years of modern Chinese, or instructor's permission.

title: Pentecostalism as a Global Religion
descrip: Pentecostalism is the fastest growing religious movement in the world, spreading especially in Africa, Asia, and the Americas, having a major impact on the religious, social, and economic practices in those regions. This course looks into the religious and cultural sources of the movement from its birth in Los Angeles in 1906, focusing on such distinctive features as healing, expressive bodily worship, "speaking in tongues," and its special appeal to people on the margins of society.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: A great deal of work but a really good overview of macro.
A must-take if you are interested in serious macroeconomics.
Depends on who will teach and what, but this course is a milestone in your graduate education.

Do not take a course with Kehoe.  He will make you crazy with his disorganization.

Take anything taught by Professor Rogerson.  He is amazing.
Excellent choice if interested in macroeconomics.
Great lecturers if you're interested in macro.
Highly recommended if it is taught by these professors.
I would recommend this class, especially if Prof. Rogerson is teaching it.
I would recommend this course to other students and recommend they devote a significant amount of time to doing the outside readings in addition to the required coursework.
If you want to do macro then you must. Take 503 before and be prepared for tons of papers and long psets.
Take this class if you want to be able to intelligently discuss macroeconomic issues.
descrip: This course is the second term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include classical and Keynesian theories of cyclical fluctuations; the determination of employment and real wages; credit markets and financial stability; and stabilization policy.

title: Truth of Memoir, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
reviews:
A good introduction to the field: I feel like I retained a lot of what I learnt. Lectures are sometimes a little slow-paced but the slides are pretty good. Exams and homeworks are pretty interesting but not too challenging. 
Overall, a good return in material learnt relative to time spent on the class: would definitely recommend.
Fairly simple course with interesting material.
Feel free to take it. You'll learn a lot if you do the homework properly; they're definitely the priority.
I would take it as a COS departmental.
If you are a theory minded COS student, this is a good way to eliminate an Applications track course.

If you wanted to know how a search engine worked, this is the class for you. The course project is really open ended and lets you explore what you like. The course load is also manageable and doesn't involve programming (except for possibly the final project).
Take a different applications course.

The subject matter for this course is a little dry, and lectures aren't all that necessary. However, the final project is very rewarding. The problem sets can be challenging, work on them with a partner.
This course gives a good overview of the topic of information retrieval.
This is a fairly easy class with an interesting topic.
fun! take!
prereqs: COS 226.
descrip: This course examines the methods used to search for information in large digital collections (e.g. Google) and how digital content is gathered by search engines. We study classic techniques of indexing documents and searching text and also new algorithms that exploit properties of the Web (e.g. links) and other digital collections, including multimedia collections. Techniques include those for relevance and ranking of documents, exploiting user history, and information clustering. We also examine systems aspects of search technology: how distributed computing and storage are used to make information delivery efficient.

title: Laboratory in Molecular Biology
reviews: As I have mentioned, the TA's gave me the most help on writing lab reports, so I think it's important to communicate and set up appointments with them a few weeks before the lab report is due. As with all lab courses, it's important to keep a well-written notebook and to make sure you know exactly what you're going to be doing in the lab session in advance.

Core lab was fun.  Only tough part were the 2 lab reports:  strongly suggest starting as early as you can.  Don't take workshops too seriously; they don't really help.  Professor Tanny is a great resource; ask her if you have any questions at all and you'll be fine.
Do as much as you can on your lab report drafts when you have the chance.  It really helps when you are editing your draft and not just writing.
Don't be scared of core lab, it's really not too bad. Do the draft workshops, start your papers early, ask questions, and you'll be fine.
Don't take it unless you need it.

I don't think there is any advice I could give as to how to improve in this class.  I believe that the only determinant for grades in this class is luck.  It all depends on who is grading your reports and whether they agree with your writing and what you put in the lab report.
I would recommend if you like working in the lab.
If you have to take it, take it. If you don't, don't. (Seriously, you could learn most of this stuff in a real lab and have more fun doing it).
If you're in it, you're probably MOL, and if you're MOL, you have to take it at some point. It could be tougher, so be thankful.
If you're taking it, it's likely because you have to.
It's a great course, and also a MOL requirement.
It's a lot of work -- like writing sem for MOL, there's stuff due every week -- but it gives you good training, especially if you've never written a scientific paper before.
Just push through...rite of passage for MOL majors
Most likely, you are taking it because you need it, but all the instructors, t.a.s and laboratory assistants are some of the best faculty to take this class with!
Obviously don't take it if you don't have to.

Only take it if you have to or intend to do molecular biology research. The labs are pretty useful in giving you experience with various techniques and materials. Do EXACTLY as you are instructed for the lab reports, and clarify EVERYTHING. Follow the guideline in the manual and the rubric to the letter. Don't be afraid of being repetitive or detailed in your report; they are not nearly as condensed as real papers.
Relatively painless in comparison to core labs in other departments.
Take the course. Do the writing drafts. Don't wait till the last minute to  do the paper.

This is a really great course.  The lab reports are a lot of work, but you can do well if you put in the time.  Also, for people that might not be so great at exams (like me), I really enjoyed that we didn't have to take exams.  I finally felt like I controlled my own fate in a class through working hard on the lab reports rather than having to rely on doing well on two difficult exams to do well.

This is possibly one of the most interesting courses in the MOL department, and a valuable experience.  I learned more about how to write a scientific paper in this course than I did in either of the fall Junior Tutorials.  If there's any way to take this course before/at the same time as the first JPs, I highly recommend it.
Even if this wasn't required for MOL majors, every MOL major should take it.

Work hard on the first lab report as well as the second lab report. Ask questions to a lot of TA's because every TA has a different opinion on what's to be included. It's better to be safe than sorry so always include more than less.
Work on your lab report as you go. Label and date all the samples you keep so you know what they are later!
You have to take it anyway...be sure to start early on the lab reports, they're deceptively long.

You're probably taking this class for a departmental, but it's one of the better science core labs. Lab reports are graded harshly though, and it can get annoying because one lab TA might tell you one thing, another will tell you something else, but you don't know who's going to end up grading yours.

read the lab manual multiple times before lab for the concept (not necessarily the actual procedure)--it will make the experiment and each step make sense and help for the lab report to understand the "big picture"
prereqs: MOL 342 (or permission). This course is required for Molecular Biology Majors..
descrip: The major objective of the course is to introduce students to a variety of tools required to conduct independent research in the field of molecular biology. While completing original research, students will employ a number of techniques that are used by molecular biologists, molecular geneticists, and biochemists. Upon completion of the course, students should have gained an understanding of how, when and why certain techniques and skills are used in a research setting. In addition, students will learn to write a research report modeled on the scientific literature.

title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
reviews: Best class ever. Make sure you attend lectures because the notes are often difficult to understand.
Do not underestimate it, be willing to put a lot of time into the class (~7/8 per week). Do not take unless you have experience with upper level Physics/Math/CS courses.
Don't expect more than 3 weeks of Quantum Algorithms.
Fun class.  Be prepared to stretch your brain in strange new directions.  Also, make sure you have a basic understanding of linear algebra.
Good introductory course even if you don't already know QM.
If you have any interested in physics, electrical engineering, or computer science, take this class.  It's not a lot of work and you learn a lot.

If you've ever heard the term "Quantum Computing" thrown around, and want to learn more about it, you should take this course. The problem sets aren't the typical mindless long problems from classes, and Professor Houck keeps the lectures interesting.

Really interesting. You learn a whole bunch of techniques and ways of tackling problems that become possible with the unique constraints of quantum mechanics. It's not terribly difficult, but is very deep.
Take it if Houck is teaching.
Take it!

This class is very interesting and Professor Houck is great. It's not an easy class, especially after the midterm, and the class is full of ELE, COS, PHY, and MAT geniuses, so if you're an average student like me, I recommend PDFing the course.
This course is up there with the best courses I've taken ever

This is a really interesting class - in one semester, you get to the point where you're talking about stuff that's happened in quantum computing the past 5 years.  You get a really good overview of the field.  The work level is not too intense, and it doesn't presume a lot of background in math, physics, ele, or computer science.

This is a very good course. It has a small amount of homework. Houck is really cool and gives good lectures, although they go pretty fast (although he will stop and explain things more if you ask). This year we went over things like surface codes.
take it!
prereqs: A previous quantum mechanics course will not be required. Requires sophomore linear algebra at the level of MAT 202, 204, 217 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course will introduce the matrix form of quantum mechanics and discuss the concepts underlying the theory of quantum information. Some of the important algorithms will be discussed, as well as physical systems which have been suggested for quantum computing.

title: Early Japanese History
descrip: The Worlds of the Tale of Heike and Chushingura. Using the two classical warrior tales, the Tale of Heike and Chushingura, as central texts, the course will explore the social, political, and cultural developments of Japan from the late 12th to 18th centuries. Themes include the flowering of court culture and emergence of warrior power, development of Buddhism and Confucian ethics, the city and structure of Heian (Kyoto) and Edo (Tokyo), and the culture that flourished therein. Aims to help students better understand the historical background of the works and to illuminate the historical context in which they were produced and appreciated.

title: Random Measures and Levy Processes
prereqs: Prerequisite: Measure theoretic probability theory, ORF 526.
descrip: Poisson random measures, additive measures, Poisson-Dirichlet processes, self-exciting point processes; Levy processes, Ito-Levy characterization; subordination, subordinators, and stable processes.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Management of Public Organizations
descrip: Course equips students with knowledge of management and leadership concepts to perform successfully and responsibly in public organizations. Course begins with a discussion of the nature of public administration and moves to concepts of organizational theory, organizational structure, administrative reforms, and decision-making mechanisms. Course also examines the people side of government organizations as well as management and leadership roles within organizations. Recent management innovations in the federal government will be discussed and considered.

title: Intermediate Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian II
descrip: A continuation of BCS 105. Advanced-level class with emphasis on oral and written communication; reading literary texts of interest to students; films

title: Bioethics and Public Policy
descrip: Focuses on the relationship between selected issues in bioethics and their implications for public policy. Issues include the ethical responsibilities of doctor and patient to each other; the ethics of research with human subjects; the ethics of death and dying; the ethics of reproduction; eugenics; access to health care; the role of bioethics committees; and animal experimentation. Considers the history of cultural attitudes towards these matters, the contemporary policies designed to deal with them, and the landmark court cases that have focused on bioethics.

title: Seminar in Medieval French Literature - Humans, Animals, and the Medieval Text
descrip: Medieval thought, Augustinian or Aristotelian, officially separates human beings from (other) animals. But medieval beliefs and practices-in commerce, religion, blazonry, horsemanship, genealogy, law, and mythology-trouble their separation. Texts of all kinds reflect this category disturbance, often highly imaginatively as in tales of talking or companion or criminal animals, or of metamorphoses such as werewolves. Copied in books made from the skins of some animals, and read to audiences wearing the furs of others, the scene of medieval reading questions the human-animal divide which language supposedly inaugurates.

title: Integrated Engineering Science Laboratory
reviews: Be prepared to spend a sizable portion of your study time writing the lab reports for this course.

Don't save lab reports for the night before, because they take a while and if you are confused you will be screwed.  Also, really get on Mike's case about getting your materials and machines for the independent work (actually, that's a general rule with MAE).
Don't start writing the labs the night before.
Great help during lab, not very good feedback on lab report grading
I would never consider taking this course without the department requirement it is mostly busy work
I wouldn't recommend this course unless it's required, due to the time needed for the lab reports/labs, but it was still very interesting.

It's a requirement for MAEs, and I really wouldn't recommend it for students in other majors. Though I found fluids much more interesting than thermo in the fall, this course was still one of the most painful parts of MAE. Labs were fun, and rarely took all 3 hours, and aligned nicely with Fluids lecture. But grading was a nightmare. It was unfair, arbitrary, and inconsistent. The TAs really didn't care at all (I don't think they even read the reports half the time, only skimmed them and slapped a grade on). Mike's really awesome though, and you can definitely feel free to be honest with him about any problems you run into, so that's a (probably the only) plus. Get through it, MAE is worth it.
Plan on spending a lot of time doing the labs!!

You're probably taking it because you have to, so you're screwed anyway - just deal with it.  Either accept the fact that you'll have to pull an all-nighter every week or bust your butt to get your lab report done before the night before.  But don't worry - it doesn't really matter if you spend one or six hours on the lab report - you'll probably just get an 85 no matter what.
manage your time writing up lab reports.
requirement
you really cant take this unless your an MAE and then its required so good luck and have fun
prereqs: MAT 104, MAT 202 (may be taken concurrently), MAE 222 (must be taken concurrently). Laboratory report grades from MAE 221 fall semester will be incorporated into final grade of MAE 224.
descrip: Students will conduct a series of prepared experiments throughout the year that will culminate in an independent project of the students' design involving fluid mechanics, thermodynamics and data acquisition tools. Preliminary experiments focus on pressure and Bernoulli's equation. Concepts learned will be applied in subsequent labs involving expanding flows and lift and drag measurements. Experiments will include internal and external viscous flows. Digital electronics including combinatorial and sequential logic, analog-to-digital conversion, digital-to-analog conversion, digital telemetry. Coupled oscillators will be covered.

title: Photonics and Light Wave Communications
reviews: Because Prof. Prucnal tries to make it as accessible as possible to anyone with any background, I would recommend anyone take it as long as they had interest in the topic.
Great class, great professor, take it.

The material is dry if you're not interested in optical fiber or communications systems, but if you are, it's a great engineering course. You actually learn how real fiber systems are implemented and how to design them, rather than just deriving theorems. As any ELE major knows, Professor Prucnal is an excellent teacher.
This is a very good course.  It is challenging, but if you have any curiosity about optics and communication systems, I think this is a perfect class for all levels.
descrip: Introduction to fiber optic communication systems. Optical transmitters and receivers. System design and performance. Multi-channel lightwave systems. Optical amplifiers. Dispersion compensation.

title: Structural Solid State Chemistry
prereqs: General chemistry or Advanced Placement; one course in thermodynamics..
descrip: Survey of the principles of the structure and properties of non-molecular solids. Space group symmetry, structure determination by x-ray, and neutron diffraction. Introduction to electron microscopy. Important structure types in metals and oxides. Pauling Rules, solid solutions, nonstoichiometry, and defect chemistry.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews: A great and usually small class that mixes lots of grammatical learning with a good novel and fun classroom activities.
Be ready to be flexible but just go with the flow and have fun. As long as you participate in class and do the reading you will learn, even when you don't realize it!
Great course!  So much fun and you learn the language so quickly.  If you don't already love the language and lusophone culture you're going to.

I recommend this class if you are really motivated to learn Portuguese. The professor is very kind and approachable, and the course is worth taking if you can let the frustrations with overall structure slide.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the Portuguese language. This course is very interesting and requires that all students participate. In one semester, students will greatly improve their writing, reading, and speaking skills in Portuguese.
If you want to learn a new language, this is the one to chose!
If you want to really become basically proficient in Portuguese, take 108 and 109 and you're there.
If you're looking to study abroad or do the Portuguese certificate, try to take this course with Megwen. In any case, though, it will be a fun stepping-stone to the higher-level Portuguese courses.
Stay on top of your assignments, and always pay attention to Luis's emails. They are full of helpful information.
Take it! Luis does a great job. The course goes at a nice pace that forces you to do some work every day, but it's never painful. One of my favorite courses.
Take it, no hesitation.
Take it. Don't hesitate for a second. You might not enjoy every second of it, but you'll be glad to have added this class to your schedule.
This is a course that takes a break from conventional language courses.
Try to take it with Megwen instead.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Junior Seminars
reviews: I think this course will be particularly appealing for students interested in urban history. As that is not really my topic of interest, it was a bit laborious at times. But I thought Prof. Mintzker did a good job of trying to make the material appealing, and I thought the overall instruction was very helpful in my independent work.
Take this class with Yair!! I might be biased, but he's one of the best this university has to offer. For a 1st JP adviser, he was EXACTLY what I needed.
prereqs: Compulsory course for departmental majors in the fall of their junior year. Students interested in taking this course must contact History's Undergraduate Administrator (etta@princeton.edu)..
descrip: A special section of HIS 400 for junior majors returning from study abroad and for sophomores intending to major in History and to spend the fall term or year abroad. Normally required of all juniors in the fall term, the seminar serves to introduce majors to the tools, methods and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This seminar will concentrate on readings of European urban history in the early modern period (1500-1800).

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Authoritarianism
reviews: As long as you're willing to work, take this class.
Follow the instructions and you should be golden.
I loved this class. Be warned - the workload is RIDICULOUSLY heavy. But you learn a lot. Soooo take it if you're really interested in the material! You'll have fun.
It's really interesting and you'll learn a lot.
Meh.

TAKE THIS. You have to be really interested in the subject and willing to do somewhat more work than usual, but if you are interested enough it's really worth it. 
Make sure to pick a regime that interests you for the research, since you're dealing with it all semester, but if you have a good one the research can be really interesting.

The seminar requires a significant time commitment and engagement, but I am very happy that I stuck with it because now I feel very confident with the material. It was especially gratifying to see how the course helped me to understand the current events going on around the world.
descrip: At the end of the Cold War democracy appeared to sweep across the globe. However, new democracies have fallen to military coups, leaders remain president for life in spite of multiparty elections, and China is a rising power under single-party rule. In this class, we will explore how various dictators are able to hold onto power, how and when democratization occurs, and the consequences of authoritarian rule. In addition to learning about examples of each type of authoritarian regime (e.g., personalist, military, single-party, and hegemonic party), students will research a dictator of their choosing for the final research project.

title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
reviews: A class with a lot of premeds in it is usually a bad choice, not because they are good at science but because of the attitude the bring towards learning.  I would pass.
A very comprehensive introduction to Mol Bio. The tests can be tough so be ready to put some time in on the details but it's very interesting so totally worth it.
All memorization.
Anyone who enjoys the natural sciences should take this course.
Ask questions when you're confused.  If you're not a premed, be prepared to deal with a lot of competitive premeds.  If you are premed, also be prepared to be in a very competitive environment.
Attend all lectures, do the readings, and go in with a god heart knowing that it will be challenging, but believing that you can do it through Christ who strengthens us!
Be prepared to do a lot of studying, but it's a good class.
Be prepared to study hard!
Be ready to study a lot of details
Consider your options.

Definitely only take it if you are willing to dedicate many hours a week to reviewing the topics. If you are debating don't take it because you have to put your whole heart into the course. Definitely seek help if you need it because there are many resources available especially your lab TA. If you need one, definitely get a tutor!!! They are the best.

Despite Gavis and Rose's weaker lectures, this course is worth taking for the later modules and for the overview of interesting biological concepts that are essential for later study in the subject, or just for knowledge of the workings of the world in general.
Do not take this class unless you are pre-med or an engineer.
Do not take this class unless you have no other choice.
Do not take this course.
Do not take this is if you're just looking for an ST. It is serious material

Do not take this unless it is required for your major or if you want to be pre-med. It is an extremely hard course that demands as much of your spare time as you can devote to it. Be prepared to work hard and still not necessarily do very well in the class.
Do not take unless you have to. That's all.
Don't be intimidated by AP bio kids.  Go to lecture as fully awake as possible, but go nonetheless.
Don't do the textbook reading before lecture.

Don't take it unless you have to, though I'd imagine that the vast majority of students who do take it are required to take it for various reasons. There are definitely better ST to go to for lecture quality and the intra-class competition was really intense due to the large number of students forced to be there.
Don't take it unless you have to.  It's interesting material, but they seem to assume you have prior biology experience.
Don't take it unless you have to. Some parts were very interesting although others were painfully detailed. Lots of work
Enjoy yourself in labs.  If you're constantly looking at the clock, you miss all the fun of it.
Fun class!
GO TO LECTURE!
GOOD
Get ready to memorize!
Go to lecture in order to understand the material.  Go to office hours to do well on lab reports.  Leave yourself enough time to study.
Go to lecture.
Good class, but be ready to be trampled by hundreds of over-eager pre-med freshman.  Consider PDFing if it's just for general interest.
Good class, good labs. Study a lot for the exams because they are specific and difficult
Good course. There are interesting topics covered in this class. I enjoyed the special topics modules.
Great course! AP/advanced biology in high school definitely helps, but an
Great introductory class, but I would shy away from it if you are only interested in fulfilling an ST (unless you're happy PDFing)

I loved this course. Although you may want to avoid it if you aren't scientifically inclined (it will involve a lot of studying), I do think it is an excellent course for anyone with a slight interest in biology. It's an excellent survey of the molecular biology department (we were taught by 4 different professors over the course fo the semester). This was an 8:30AM class and I was almost never falling asleep. I was usually excited to go to class, and it's pretty impressive to be excited about anything that early in the morning.
I recommend taking this course for interest as well as for general knowledge.

I think it is a pretty good introduction to the basics of molecular and cell biology. All the stereotypes about it being a really difficult and competitive course are false in my opinion. If you put in the amount of time and effort needed for you to understand the material well (only you can be the arbiter of how much genuine preparation you need), then you will be rewarded in the results of this class. The material is really interesting. The labs could be a little more interesting. Overall positive experience. Not stressful at all.
I think this class gives a good foundation of molecular biology and is useful to anyone who wants a background in this area.
I would advise other students to go to the professors' office hours, go to the review sessions, and do the readings.
I would advise taking this course if you are pre-med if not then you have to be very interested in the topic, otherwise you should take MOL 101.
I would not recommend this class to anyone who did not require it as a pre-req, and I would suggest those that do consider 215 instead.
I would recommend going to all lectures.

I would recommend that students attend all lectures, even though the class is early. The slides are really helpful, but sometimes without context, it is really easy to get lost. I understood the material so much better that related to the lectures. I attended.

I would recommend this to any premedical students who need it or any other concentrators. If you have a general interest in biology you'll probably like this, but otherwise it's probably an unnecessarily difficult class for an introductory course.
I would recommend this to any student considering a molecular biology major to see if they really enjoy biology.
I would recommend you not take this course PDF.
I would say be prepared to learn a lot of the material on your own.
I would tell them to take MOL 215 in the fall.
I would warn other the students that there is a lot of material, but if you put in enough study time and attend review sessions/office hours, the work will pay off!
If a student is interested in Biochemistry or Biology this is a useful course. Otherwise, it is too detailed to be of any use.

If a student is not sure he or she is interested in biology, this is a good "tester" course to take. It is not too intense, nor is it too light. After this course, it was pretty clear to me whether or not I'd like to continue with biology, and I'm guessing something similar will happen to other students as well.

If you are interested in molecular biology and would like to learn, generally, about molecular biology, take this course.  It is difficult and requires lots of studying; there are also many pre-meds in the class who "need" to do well for medical school.  So, if you are looking for an easy and interesting science, do not take this course.

If you are taking MOL 214, you are probably taking it as a prerequisite for a biology major or medical school.  Try to enjoy the class.  Don't get hung up on all of the little details as this will drive you crazy.  You will miss some questions on the exams if you don't memorize the esoteric elements but you will get the gist and that will serve you well in the course.  Go to every lecture, you will be tested on them all and it is difficult to gather information from the lecture slides.
If you do not have the stamina to absorb incredibly vast amounts of information in a small amount of time then don't take this course.
If you enjoy memorizing a lot of material instead of focusing on concepts then you will be fine.
If you need to take an introductory biology class, or you just want to take one, I'd recommend this one.

If you take this course, go to the review sessions and ask questions immediately if you don't understand a part of the material, since the amount of material you will have to learn with inevitabely pile up, and you might not have a chance to get back to it until right before the exam (which may be rather stressful)!

If you're just looking for an ST take Mol 101 with Prof Bassler. She is very lively and engaging and makes the material interesting. If you need to take 214 for the requirement, then take the initiative to engage with the lecturer and ask questions, rather than just sit there

If you're majoring in MOL, you have two options: MOL215 or this course, MOL214. MOL214 is painful. There's nothing to gauge your performance besides two exams, followed by a final. If Gavis is teaching again, strongly consider taking MOL215. She is to be avoided.
It is a required class, be smart in your studying.
It is very focused on the laboratory side of biology.
It was an interesting course and I would definitely recommend it to all students, regardless of major.
It's a decent feeler course for molecular biology
It's a fine class - good ST.
It's an awesome course with wonderful, pertinent labs.

It's not a terrible course so take it if mol bio is something that is remotely interesting to you and you need to fulfill your ST requirement.  The labs are pretty chill and the write-ups aren't bad at all.  Gavis isn't the best lecturer so that's a bummer in terms of the class especially since you have to get up at 8:30 in the morning to go.
It's tough but it is really interesting so go for it.
Just because you already learned some of this in high school does not mean you know it. Do the work.
Just like any other bio class, memorization is key.

Keep up with the material from the start.  If you take it, you better be really interested in this material, or you better develop a deep interest in it.  Otherwise it's hard to get motivated to study all the molecular material.
Lectures are okay, but I would try to stay awake for all of them.  Study a lot for the exams!

Lots of rote memorization, if you intend to do well in the class. Having to memorize dozens of biological processes on the molecular level will be time consuming, so make sure to start studying well before each exam.

MOL 214 is a really great course.  It is full of pre-meds and Mol majors, but if you are not a science person it is still very engaging.  I am definitely not a science person, and it was probably one of my favorite courses of the semester.  There is a lot of material to learn, but overall it's all very interesting.  If you're looking for an easy ST, don't take this course. But if you're interested at all in the material, I definitely recommend it.
MOL214 is the best introductory science class I've taken

Make study guides in advance, and study throughout the semester. I know you should do this in every class, but especially for this. THIS IS NOT A REGURGITATION CLASS LIKE HIGH SCHOOL BIO. You actually have to THINK. I mean it!!! I got a lot out of this course, but I don't recommend it to someone who doesn't need to take it because it is a lot of work to do well.
Make sure to clarify subjects that you don't understand early in the class because much of it relates to each other.
Make sure to go over lecture slides briefly before lecture, and study them more thoroughly a few days after lecture.  The lectures for which I did this are the ones I understood best come exam time.
Make sure you are prepared to devote a lot of time to this class.
Make sure you understand the gist of every lecture slide.  If you try to figure all of it out right before finals, you'll be overwhelmed.
Maybe take 215?
Motivation to go to lecture drops significantly halfway through the semester. Go anyway.
Not as good as it used to be. Wait for Shenk to teach it again.
ONLY TAKE IF YOU ARE PREMED OR MOL BIO MAJOR!!!!
Only take if you are pre-med. Do everything possible to attend the weekly review sessions.
Only take it if you have to. The exams are all about memorization so start studying early. If it's the same as this year, don't buy the textbook. It was a waste of money and time.
Only take this class if you are considering a future concentration in molbio or are pre-med.

Only take this course if you enjoy "memorizing" material. 
Go to lectures and write down everything the professor says. 
The readings are not necessary. What is covered in the lectures is far more important. 
There is not a lot of reading in the course, so if you don't want a heavily reading based course this is perfect.
Don't be intimadated if you did not take AP bio in high school like most of the class will have. Honestly, it does not matter.The professors make it seem like you are at a disadvantage if you haven't taken AP bio but don't pay attention to them.
Only take this course if you have to -- tests are difficult and there is a lot of work necessary to complete labs and study for exams.
Only take this course if you know you want to major in MOL/if it is a prerequisite or a requirement.  If you do take it, be ready to memorize a lot of information.
Only take this course if you really need to do so. There are a lot of pre-meds that make the course stressful, and the material is difficult
Only take this if you have to.

Please don't take this course if you don't need to and have no background in biology. I had to take this course being pre-med, but had no background in biology except for a basic biology class freshman year of high school. Thus, this course was very challenging for me. Spend time each week going over the lecture slides and LEARNING the material (oh, how I wish I had done this!). Studying for exams will be very painful if you let everything pile up.

Prepare to spend a lot of time on this class to do well in it. Everybody in this class is pretty much pre-med, so it will already be tough. There is a lot of reading, so keep up with the lectures. Lecture notes are more important than the actual textbook readings.
Reading isn't worth it.  All the info is in the lectures.
Should try to learn the material during lectures, otherwise you will waste more time sloughing through the textbook.
Stay well organized and keep up with the material

Study the lecture slides, take good notes, read the topics on the discussion board. 

That last point is probably the best way to study for tests because you'll realize that you have WAY more questions than you think you did.
Study the material throughout the semester!
Study.  A lot.  A little at a time, but a lot overall.
Take MOL 215 instead.
Take MOL 215!!! And don't take it if you don't have to...
Take it for premed and it is not too difficult. The class just requires memorization and covers a lot of different types of material that are not always really connected.
Take it if you have to, but don't fall behind.
Take it if you have to. The course drags on and on, and the lectures at 8:30 make everything worse. Watch out: the midterm exams are very long and Rose's questions are very difficult.
Take it if you must or if you are very interested in bio.
Take it if you must. I wouldn't really take it for general interest, though.
Take it if you're looking for a tough ST.
Take it only if you know you can learn in the morning, otherwise you wont get as much out of the lectures as you could be.

Take it! But keep up-to-speed with lectures.
tHe timing SUCKS. you will want to fall asleep. that's ok though because the powerpoints have it all pretty much.
Take only if you really like bio or if you have to
Take the course.
Take this class if you are interested in mol bio, but unsure if you want to major in it.

Take this class if you need to for your major, but be ready to put in the work. It is not easy if you plan on waiting last minute to study for exams. I did that and almost went CRAZY. So please give yourself plenty of time to process the information before exams and chill the day before the exam. It is not that exams are hard, it is just that you have to put in the time to study for them and do that way beforehand. The class is truly intereting for science people, but is filled with details so again, study the material regularly.  If you are not a science major and just want to fulfill your ST, consider other, easier classes. Labs were easy but pointless for me. Good luck!
Take this class!
Take this course if you are interested in biology.

Take this course if you are interested in molecular biology: it's definitely a lot more enjoyable if you enjoy the subject material. It's well-organized and you get to learn about some really neat stuff.
Take this course if you want to be a MOL Bio major because you have to. If you do not have interest in Mol BIo, you won't like it. I am interested in mol bio and did not find it very stimulating.
The advice I would give is do all the readings.

There's a lot of material, so to enjoy it, you have to spread out the material over a lot of time. Go to all of the review sessions, and most importantly, try to challenge the material to undetstand it better. I think that alone helped me most on tests.
This class can be found interesting by those of all academic interests.
This class is a difficult ST, so I would recommend that you take a different one. It requires a lot of time and effort.
This course is hard and challenging because of the sheer amount of information that you have to learn and memorize, but I do think that the teachers teach the material as well as they can.
This course is not as bad as everyone says. The labs are great and the material is interesting.
This is a great class if you enjoy cell biology. If you don't the details that you are required to know for this class maybe a bit much and may seem pointless.

This is a great introduction to Molecular and Cell Biology, if you want to be a MOL major or otherwise. There is A LOT of material to learn and memorize that is covered in class, so definitely do not fall behind on the readings. Read the lecture notes primarily!! And use them as a guidance for reading the book, although spend much more time understanding the lecture notes than what is written in the book because you will get tested on the lecture notes. If you cannot deal with memorization, you may opt out of MOL 214 and instead take MOL 215, which is more quantitative. However, I find that memorizing and really getting to understand the fundamental material in the course is essential; the exams are not really a regurgitation of the lecture notes, but make you think about the material you have just learned and makes you apply it to experiments and problems they present to you. Also, if Prof. Bassler is still going to do the Microbiology section of the course, one word: ENJOY.
This is a memorization-heavy course. The information is generally interesting, but be prepared to spend a lot of time studying the material. DO NOT TAKE THIS WITH ORGO.
This is a reasonable class, but don't expect to be blown away.

This will definitely give you a great basic understanding of concepts and lab techniques involved in Molecular Biology. The beginning seems deceptively similar to AP Biology if you've taken it, but it soon becomes a lot more detailed. Attending lectures is extremely important, especially for Rose. Take good notes during lecture, because those are the best study materials. The reading isn't that important, but if you don't attend lecture, you'll have to do a lot more of it.
Try to make it out of bed to go to the lectures because they are really engaging!

Try to study as you go along, although I'm sure that probably won't happen. Go to office hours. Maybe not review sessions, but definitely ask Ms. Thieringer questions or something. Also, studying in groups is extremely helpful so you can talk over the material. Remember that you and your classmates are all in this together.
Unless you're pre-med/MOL/EEB and love waking up early, don't take this.
Usually if you're taking this class you don't have a choice...
Work hard.

You're gonna have to take this for pre-med, EEB, or chemE requirements, although if you're chemE, you might as well take MOL 215 since you're an engineer already. Otherwise, if you're a MOL major and taking this as a pre-req, then you probably already enjoy molecular biology and I have nothing to say to you, except that this is the easiest of your departmentals. Taking this for the ST requirement is just dumb.
be prepared to study a lot, but it's definitely manageable
go to every lecture because that provides the only information you need to know and without lecture, powerpoints and slides make no sense
good course to take if you don't know what MOL is like, but majority of kids are premed in the class so be prepared for lots of people, lots of studying, and lectures that aren't the most helpful.
keep up on reading and studying.  i would only recommend to majors or premed
learn the details
only take it as a pre-req.
only take it if it's a requirement or you have time to waste because its time consuming. but if you put in the time you'll do well. don't take with three other heavy courses and a JP.
take it only if you really have to
take this course if you're interested in molecular biology but be willing to put in the time going to office hours and studying.
prereqs: Open to undergraduate students only. Graduate students and auditors must have permission of instructor..
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology, are examined in an experimental context. During the second half of the semester, topics-based sections will be taught by different faculty members in the following areas: cell biology, virology, neuroscience, microbiology and development. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: Suburban Dreams and Nightmares
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Tourist
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: HARD but worth it
If you made it this far, keep going.
If you're willing to make the necessary time commitment, this is a very fulfilling and helpful course.
If you've made it this far you might as well keep going.
My Chinese improved much more during 404 than during 403.  Don't stop at 403 just because that's all the certificate requires.
This is challenging and work intensive class--a "must take" if you are interested in improving Mandarin language skils
You probably don't have another option for Chinese, but even if you did I would recommend this one!
prereqs: CHI 403 or instructor's permission..
