descrip: A continuation of 403. Reading and discussion of scholarly writings in the fields of Chinese literature and modern Chinese intellectual history. A weekly written assignment will be required. Prerequisite: 403, or instructor's permission.

title: Theory and Practice of Arabic to English Translation
prereqs: Minimum of two years of study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course trains students in the practice of translating of Arabic texts from a wide variety of genres into English. Attention will be given to both theoretical and practical problems of translation for research and professional ends.

title: Advanced French
reviews: But you have to work quite hard and to practice a lot
Do take the time, if not to do the assigned problems, to make sure you know the various exceptions to the grammar rules and learn how to use the constructions.
Fun course, and you'll improve your spoken French a lot.
Generally people don't have to much of a choice about taking this.
Go to class and force yourself to do the grammar.  It will help you do well on the tests
Great readings, great movies. Be prepared for a lot of grammar, though.
I mean, you need to take the class in order to finish the language requirement, so... I guess there is no choice here.

I was initially hesitant to take this course, worried that my French wasn't good enough, but FRE 108 isn't bad at all. You start the grammar lessons from the very beginning (present tense, imperative, etc.) so there's time to catch up, and in class, you get as much as you put in.

I would highly recommend taking this course if, in addition to language instruction, you would like an introduction to some works of French literature and film.  I found the course very beneficial to my French.
I would recommend this course to someone interested in furthering their education in French.
I would say that it's a lot of work, but your french will definitely improve if you take this class!

I would strongly recommend Madame Ambrogelly and French 108. I feel that it prepares you well for higher level French courses and you will receive some degree of fluency without a doubt, if not a good grasp on many of the structures and grammar of the language. Going to class and doing the assigned homework is a must, your work in this class will help you to greatly improve your French...and you will have some fun along the way too!
I would suggest that students be prepared to spend a great deal of time reviewing for the class. I believe that each class requires upwards of two hours of preparation.

I would tell them to do the homeworks the day they are assigned so you keep up with the grammar, and also not to worry if you don't understand the readings right away, just pay attention and go to class.
If you would like to continue learning French, I would take this course.

It will help your french language skills and you'll be a lot more comfortable with reading in french. Make sure you do the grammar exercises and feel free to approach the Professor if you need help with anything! Madame Ambrogelly is incredibly warm and welcoming.
Loved this course. My favorite class of the semester. I especially loved the way Valerie taught the course. Extremely personable, friendly, and approachable. I will certainly miss this class.
Make sure to study well before the exams, and do your best work on the compositions.
Not the greatest course, but good for improving your French.

Read the grammar book and do the exercises - that is how you will improve and perform well on the tests. Make your essays the best that they can be for the first draft. Write them several days ahead so that you can look back on them with fresh eyes. Be creative. Ask the teacher questions.

Read the grammar textbook!  It's the best way to be prepared for the exam and for class.  It isn't necessary to do every reading or to do the textbook exercises, because exercises are done in class.  Definitely try to take FRE108 with Anne Ambrogelly.
Stay on top of readings and movies and participate a lot in discussion...that is the best way to get a good grade and learn the language well.
Take it and have fun. The grading sucks but I guess...I dunno, it's a great class nonetheless.
Take it if you want to keep up with your French.
Take this course if you need a requirement or are interested in learning about extremely interesting topics in French culture alongside of language.
The tests were very tricky for me. You have to start studying WELL in advance in order to get the grades that you want.
You might be surprised at the high level of thinking that is required for this course
take it! painless and really relaxed, i looked forward to this class.
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 takes you on a tour of France, across regions and through history. From Les Fables by La Fontaine to L'Avare by Moliere, and incorporating recent articles and films, the course will draw on a variety of materials to acquaint you with France's cultural diversity and contemporary debates. Through literature, newspaper articles and films, we will explore different regions and cities of France (La Provence, la Bretagne et Paris), their changing cultures and the contemporary issues they face. We will look at the importance of Paris in the construction of a national identity, and the regional developments of the past few decades.

title: Introduction to the History of Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
reviews: A decent course if you want to learn something about art. The class does lack narrative because every lecture is taught by someone else, and you have to memorize like crazy for the midterm and final. But you do learn something.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE
Definitely go to class and read the lecture notes!
Definitely take it if you want to know more about art. It is more time consuming than expected but still a good class. I feel significantly more about art, but I also started knowing nothing.
Do it
Final and midterm are not easy, but the rest of the class is.
Go to lecture.

I liked it. It was pretty interesting, and its only hard if you don't go to class and pay attention. If you do that and actually put in some time to study, and study smart (i.e. lecture notes and slides), its not bad. Its what I expected, and as a p/d/f it was great. I didn't read at all and will do just fine.
I recommend taking this course pass/fail if you are fulfilling a LA requirement.  Being under less pressure to perform enables you to truly appreciate the art.
I would advise students to study throughout the semester if they do not have prior knowledge of art history.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone who would like to have a general knowledge of art.
I would not recommend this course to you if you are not good at memorizing.
If you have little background in art, this class is a good way to improve your knowledge.
If you have no prior knowledge of art and need an LA, it's worth considering this course.
If you want to take this as an LA, I think there are better options.  This course is interesting, but you need to be more passionate about it than I was.
Interesting course. Don't try to memorize everything the night before.
It's a great class to gain a general knowledge of art history.  Lots of memorization, but you learn a lot in a short period of time.  Makes going to art museums a lot more interesting.
It's really what you'd expect. Take it if you want to learn more about art.
Memorize paintings
Really great class, but LOTS of memorization. Totally doable if you spend the time on it though. The class teaches what you need to know about art that will come up in conversation.
Start studying ahead of time
Study for the exams early on.
TAKE IT. A great PDF if you're a senior and looking for something that will allow you to work on thesis, but also allow you get invested in the course once you've handed in your thesis.
TAKE THIS COURSE!
Take it with a professor other than Heuer if possible.
Take it! Everyone should know and understand art

Take it, don't go to lecture, start memorizing the images from the beginning of the semester, and do one reading per week and I guarantee an A. I think I approached the course the wrong way. I tried to learn the concepts all semester rather than focusing on the images. Bad decision.
Take it. It's not a lot of work if you take it on a P/D/F basis.
Take it. Keep up with readings, particularly those from the textbook. Don't skip lecture.

The identifications are difficult to keep up with so you seriously should start trying to learn the artworks early on, rather than cramming 200 pieces the day before the exam like most others. Reading the textbook is helpful, especially since only pieces from the book are on the tests, and I say do pay attention in lecture and precept because the artwork on the tests are usually those that were also talked about in class.

This course is a great overview of art, especially for those who have never studied (or appreciated) fine art in the past. It is a great learning opportunity, and even memorizing all the paintings isn't so bad because many are famous works you'll want to remember for general knowledge.
This course is amazing and generally interesting. I would be careful not to think of this as an easy course, as the midterm and final requires a lot of studying and memorization.
This is a decent course to pdf - although you will have to memorize for the exams. There isn't much work though.
This is a great class for anyone interested in an introductory art course, however I would recommend taking ART 100 first.

This is a survey course, but it is very enjoyable and it is great if you are unsure of what you are interested in, exactly. I would recommend it (unless you are sure of what you want to study in art history, then this class might not be worthwhile)
This is an interesting course with good material. I learned a lot and it's not too much work.
This is not an easy class. I would actually recommend taking a class that is geared more toward your specific interest. If you do take this class, your preceptor is a wonderful resource.
Unless you truly enjoy art, it will be a long semester.
Very great class if you have some passing interest in art history. Stuff everyone should know.
midterms and finals require a TON of memorizing, so be prepared for that.
descrip: An introduction to selected periods and works of art and architecture from the Renaissance to the present as well as an introduction to the discipline of art history. Two lectures, one preceptorial.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Financial Markets and Public Policy
descrip: Examines financial markets from both a theoretical and policy perspective. Topics include modern portfolio theory, financial asset pricing theories such as the Capital Asset Pricing Model, the Arbitrage Pricing Theory and derivative security pricing theories; key issues in corporate finance such as capital budgeting, capital structure and corporate governance. While modern finance is one of the more technically demanding areas of economics, course imparts the important concepts without a high level of mathematical rigor; the case format is used extensively. Prereq: 511c/instructor's permission.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: The Portrait
descrip: The portrait is one of the oldest and most widespread representations of the human subject. In this seminar we will focus on problems of form and social context as well as philosophical quandaries regarding representation of the subject. The types of portraits considered will be drawn from a variety of cultural contexts, both Western and non-Western. There are no prerequisites per se but students are expected to bring their expertise in (foreign) language and interpretation to bear on course materials. The course is open to graduate students in Comparative Literature and related departments.

title: Race and Public Policy
reviews: DEFINITELY take this course.  This man is a genius, and you will learn things in this class that will be more important in your daily interactions with the world than you will in any other class.
Definitely recommend the class. Professor Massey is great!!!!
I would strongly recommend taking this course.
IMportant subject! Take it!
If you are at all interested in policy, history, and why this country is the way it is then take this class!
Keep your dean's date schedule in mind but awesome lectures - worth the 20 page paper!
Prepare to take a lot of notes, but at the same time learn a lot. Also, prepare for the 20 page paper early in the course.
TAKE IT!
Take it if you're interested in race issues
Take it! As much work as you want to put in--very end-heavy.
Take it, this class is awesome. Not too much work, not a ton of reading, awesome lectures.
Take this course!

Take this course, but be prepared to work and read a lot. The lectures are incredible, the readings are interesting, and the material is extremely captivating. The course will change the way you few race relations in the United States and abroad, and will be beneficial in everyday life for anyone who puts in work and attention to the material.
There is a lot of reading for this course.

This class will make you think about many US policies in a different way. The lectures are sometimes dry and consist of Professor Massey often lecturing the readings, but the material is fascinating, so I would recommend the class.
This is a good class to take.  The Professor does a good job in lecture, the preceptor was very good and the tests were fair.
This is a must-take course!
i recommend this course if you are interested in how race proliferates in America, and are interested in politics
take it, but be aware of the 20 page doozy of a final paper
descrip: Analyzes the historical construction of race as a concept in American society, how and why this concept was institutionalized publicly and privately in various arenas of U.S. public life at different historical junctures, and the progress that has been made in dismantling racialized institutions since the civil rights era.

title: Inquisition, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Gandhi: The Making of the Mahatma
reviews: Good class, not impossible work load, definitely easier if you've had some experience with South Asian history, but not a reason not to take the class.
Take this whether or not you are interested in the subject matter.  Even if you have no interest in Gandhi, you will after the first seminar.
descrip: The seminar examines Gandhi's political life extending from his campaign for the rights of Indians in South Africa to his leading role in the struggle for Indian independence from British rule. In doing so, it focuses on those historical processes that turned M. K. Gandhi into a major 20th-century figure -- the Mahatma. Issues relating to imperialism and nationalism form the context in which the seminar looks at Gandhi's life and seeks to understand Gandhi's thoughts on the modern nation, community, religious state, and sexuality.

title: Race and Medicine
reviews: A LOT OF READING AND WORK.

Great class. Be prepared to use your mind and think about real life. Because of the subject matter, this course shouldn't be about getting a good grade, but more about engaging with the material and having a critical perspective. It is a challenging course, there will be many things said or that you may read that are jarring. But I think you will come out with a better understanding of the fact that the world is much bigger, complex, and unfair than Princeton.
I would discourage them from taking this course.
If you're not a pre-med, I'd shy away.  I feel like the premeds in this class got a lot more out of it than I did.  Otherwise, go ahead.
It is very easy to get behind in the readings but paying attention and being active during seminar is easy given the engaging topic of the course.
It's a lot of work! Keep up with the many hundreds of pages of reading..
It's really difficult to keep up with the readings and sometimes the assignments are unclear, so if you don't need to take this class for a grade, it might be a good class to PDF.
Make sure you know the professor's expectations on assignments beforehand.

Please do not take this course if you are only going to be sitting around and playing video games or shopping online. The professor is outstanding but is too nice to actually do something about the lack of engagement and disrespect that students subtly show by wasting their time in the classroom. Also, the seminar class often feels more like a lecture class.
Take it. It's an easy class if you write well.
Take the course with an open mind in health disparities.  You will learn a lot.
The readings are important for the midterm, but unimportant after that.
The title of the course drew me in but I regret taking this course. I would recommend taking another ANT with Biehl or Mann.

There are generally two types of students in this class: those who are PDFing it, and those who are trying to seriously engage with it.  If you aren't in that category, you may not get very much out of the experience.  

PDFing the class is an excellent option who wants exposure to the the subject without having to work very hard.
prereqs: None.
descrip: In 1998, then-President Clinton set a national goal that by the year 2010 race, ethnic, and gender disparities in six disease categories would be eliminated. While the agenda, called Healthy People 2010, was a noble effort, many of the goals were not met. This course examines what went wrong. For a final project, students will be asked to propose their own solutions for eliminating health disparities.

title: Compiling Techniques
reviews: A good class if you're interested in implementing your own compiler or interpreter.

Definitely at least write down what Prof August is writing on his slides because those notes won't be available later. Especially in the second half of the course it will make reviewing it for the final a much easier task. Also make use of the finals and midterms provided since they offer problems that are at least similar to those that you'll see on the final. Also, if you don't know ML, get familiar with it quickly.
Don't take it if you can avoid it. Very, very boring. ML is a terrible language to program in.

If this course is taught by David August, you might want to avoid it.  He doesn't seem to be terribly interested in teaching the course, but rather only in his research, and thus he isn't very helpful.

The book for compiler design isn't helpful on some covered topics like typing rules or on some SSA features like node splitting--both of which were critical to know.

ML is hard to get to fully understand without any assistance and while the rest of the class seems to already have been exposed to it, so one should be wary of the workload demands this course has and the disadvantages it presents with seemingly no aids.
If you are looking for a challenging class, take 320.  It isn't the greatest COS class, but you'll learn something, and it's the only exposure you'll get to functional programming.
If you have trouble thinking about what a computer does when you write out certain instructions, this class will help you be a better programmer.
If you want to see how a compiler works (and make one), then take it. I wouldn't do this one just to get the systems requirement for COS.
Learn functional programming paradigms and you'll do so much better.
Only take this course if you expect to have a specific interest in compilers, and be prepared to drop it and have a backup, if it isn't what you expect.

TAKE IT IF YOU LOVE COMPILERS LIKE ME, be aware that you will have to do much of the leg work (reading, learning ML, drilling the lectures into your sub-sub-sub-sub-cortex, etc.) yourself, though, so find a few friends and make a study group.

Good companion course to 441 (Programming Languages).

The programming assignments are mostly good, and it's a great introduction to Standard ML if you haven't been exposed already. The lectures cover a lot of material that you won't get to implement in your own compiler, so the exams are deceptively difficult.
You make a compiler.
if you're genuinely interested in compilers, take it. otherwise, there are probably more interesting/useful systems courses.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Understand the design and construction of compilers. Concepts include syntax analysis, semantics, code generation, optimization and run-time systems. Translation of imperative languages (such as C), functional languages (such as ML), and object-oriented languages (such as Java) will be studied. Students will implement a complete compiler for a small language.

title: Pre-Columbian Peoples of Tropical America and Their Environments
reviews: Avoid taking a class from Andrew Ugan
I have no idea what this course will be next year ... if it's as much paleobiology as this was, push to have it considered a departmental.
I recommend this course if Anthony Coates and Aaron O'Dea are teaching it. If Andrew Ugan is teaching, I would suggest PDFing the class and finding other things to do during class time.

I strongly recommend the geology part of the course but not the anthropology part of the course. The work isn't very much or very hard, but it's all due at the same time so work ahead, especially if Andrew decides to take away your work day again.

The first half of the course is fantastic!  Anthony is at first slightly confusing, but he makes sure to explain complicated topics several times so don't worry if you don't get it the first time around.

This course probably won't be the same in the future, since Princeton had to make some last-minute changes due to our original professor's illness.. So it's hard to recommend anything to you! The Panama field semester is great though. Definitely do it if you love biology!

You have to take this course if you go to Panama. You can't take this course if you don't.

Hopefully Andrew will not be teaching the archaeology section again.
prereqs: Prerequisites: 211, and 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring Semester in tropical ecology program in Panama..
descrip: The pre-European history of Amerind cultures and their associated environments in the New World tropics will be studied. Topics to be covered include the people of tropical America; development of hunting/gathering and agricultural economies; neotropical climate and vegetation history; and the art, symbolism, and social organization of native Americans. Field and laboratory experiences will incorporate methods and problems in field archaeology, paleoenthnobotany and paleoecology, and archaeozoology.

title: Advanced Multivariable Calculus
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time on math.
Give it a shot. It's a really interesing class, but it does take a lot of work. If after two weeks you think it's still too hard, it's easy to drop down to 201.
I would not take this course unless you have taken multivariable calculus before. If you are not familiar with the concepts already, this course will be frustrating.
If you're at all interested in math, take it!
Review sessions are essential
This course moves very quickly through the topics of multivariable calculus. Therefore, it might be helpful if you have seen some of the concepts before.
This is a hard class for anyone without previous exposure to multivariable calculus. Do take it if you are prepared to put in hard hours of work ...and try to get into Kai-Wen Lan's section!
This is a solid course. If you want to have a strong background in mathematics, whatever your major is, this is a good course to take.
prereqs: MAT 104 (or AP placement credit).
descrip: This course is an introduction to multivariable calculus and its applications. Its goal is to cover the fundamental results of Vector Calculus known as Green's, Stokes' and Gauss' theorems, and to show how to use them to solve problems. We attempt to explain the theory behind the techniques so that "WHY" they work is understood. The level of rigor is midway between MAT 201 and 218. The course is designed for science and engineering students with a good mathematical aptitude and for mathematicians with applied math interests.

title: Topics in Discrete Mathematics - Induced Subgraphs
descrip: A general introduction to the theory of induced subgraphs (a continuation from Fall 2010).

title: God of Many Faces: Comparative Perspectives on Migration and Religion
reviews: Do the reading and prepare for precept
Don't take this class.
Eh. Not that great.

Everyone should take a course with PFK.  She's an awesome personality and will make you think, but don't expect a typical framework for the course.  You're very much responsible for your own learning experience.
Go to lecture.
I recommend this course to students who can accept the fact that Professor Fernandez-Kelly has a very unique and refreshing way of teaching.
I would not recommend taking this course unless you are absolutely sure the study of religion interests you or you need to for distribution.
If you like PFK's teaching style, take it
If you like the subject matter and PFK you should take the course. For people just looking for a random course to take this one might not be for you.
If you want a super easy PDF where you put in minimal work, go for it.  Otherwise, avoid this class at all costs.
Interesting and relatively light workload.

It is a great SA to take and PFK is a wonderful and very caring professor. She is dynamic and tries to present the information with as least bias as possible, but still presenting important issues in the world today. One can get involved as much as one wants to. I would recommend the course to others.
Love it, take it!
Take it if you like the professor, if you're a major, if you are interested in the topic. Don't take it if you don't like courses that are too subjective or sometimes go off-topic.

Take this class if you want to take an interesting SA with a very light workload. However, the class may not be rewarding if you are looking for a course that is really engaging, so make sure you're interested in the material.
There is a lot of reading, but there are not many assignments.  It is not a killer class, but it is not an extremely stimulating class either.
This course is not much work and interesting.
This is a really interesting course with a manageable work load. I would highly recommend it.
Very interesting do the readings and you will love it
You have to do all the readings and start the take-homes early.
fairly easy and not much work, not entirely boring
good
take it
descrip: Immigrants often experience discrimination in areas of destination. Religion can strengthen their sense of worth, particularly when the circumstances surrounding departure from the country of origin are traumatic, as with exiles and refugees. We take a comparative approach and use examples from the United States, Asia, Europe, and Latin America. The course broaches questions such as: how does religion transform (and how is it transformed by) the immigrant experience? When is religion used to combat stereotypes? Are there differences between the way men and women or dominant groups and racial minorities understand religion?

title: Seminar in Modern Spanish-American Literature - The Mask of the State:Mimesis and the Political
reviews: Do take it. If you are interesting either in Latin American literature or in learning about theory and literary criticism, the course is very helpful. The professor is extremely knowledgeable and welcomes people from other departments in a very generous way.

This is one of the best courses I have ever taken. Prof. Nouzeilles is just amazing, and given that XIX Lat. Am. literature is one of her areas of expertise, you will learn a lot. This was a truly enriching experience for me, and I would highly recommend taking this course to anyone interested in Latin American culture.
descrip: This seminar explores the role of mimesis in political representation and state formation in Latin America, focusing on some of its most powerful and enduring symbolic articulations in the massive legal, literary, and scientific archive it generated during the nineteenth century-a long and turbulent century, characterized by revolutions, mass political mobilization, subaltern uprisings, utopian thinking,and sweeping modernization. Taking into account Taussig's work on mimesis and alterity, we will study how the modern political produces spaces of equality and of extreme differentiation.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Human Security and Development
descrip: Publication of the Human Security Report in 2005 marks the emergence of human security as a more formal operational policy framework, but it remains an essentially contested concept. Course explores the ethical, analytical, policy, and operational dimensions of several approaches to human security. Particular areas of focus include: the "responsibility to protect," HIV/AIDS, and failed states. Requirements include: the presentation of the readings for one session, participation in a formal debate, and a 12-15 page paper.

title: The Brain: A User's Guide
reviews: Don't get behind on the readings.
Don't take it.
Eh. Think carefully about why you are taking it.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture and do all the reading
Good class if you are interested. Don't expect anything too advanced though.

Great introduction to psychology, biological psychology, and neuroscience, aimed at non-concentrators. Opened my eyes to alot of new and interesting things, really enjoyed it alot and I think I look at life a little differently and appreciate my brain and its complexity more as a result
I do not recommend this course.
I recommend it for a solid understanding of the brain and for a interesting class for EC distribution.
I recommend this class. Make sure you do the textbook reading and I also recommend attending lecture and precept.
I would encourage you to take this course, but beware of the exams. They are challenging and you must be prepared to spend a significant amount of time preparing for them. Lots of memorization!

I would recommend taking this class because it is interesting and the work during the semester is minimum.  BUT beware the midterm and final because even though Prof. Jacobs said there would not be any "details" on the exam I thought they actually asked detailed an in depth questions.

I would recommend taking this course. If you do, try to pay attention in lecture and precept, and you should do fine. For the midterm, however, don't be fooled by the fact that it's multiple choice, there are a lot of hard questions from the book and lecture, so study hard!
I would recommend this course. It changed the view I had about our world in general. Not kidding. Best course I had for fun so far. And it is pretty easy to get an A.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student.  It is an interesting way to fulfill a distribution requirement.
If you pay attention and do your readings, you should be fine.

If you're a psych major, it's definitely easier than the other neuroscience classes. It's probably not going to stimulate you intellectually too much. Also, everyone's grades for the midterm were sent out in an excel spreadsheet to everyone in the class, which was kind of odd. I noticed that the person who did best on the midterm indicated that he rarely went to class. So it's possible to not go to lecture and do ok. Overall, it's an ok class.

Interesting material and a great way to find out more about neuroscience. However, don't believe that you'll be able to just focus on the main concepts and big ideas in the class--even though Professor Jacobs says you don't have to memorize tiny details, you do.
Interesting material, but boring lectures and precepts. The precept assigned reading is amazing, so definitely do it.
Only to take if one was desperate.
Take it if you don't want to take PSY 258, or if you need an EC, because it's pretty interesting.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject matter
Take this course if you're not really interested in neuro, but want to see what it's all about (or need to take some to major in PSY)
Take this course!  Do the readings, especially for precept.  If you give this course the time it calls for, you will learn many applicable concepts.
The class is fun but fear the exams!
The class is very interesting and I feel that what I have learned in the class is very relevant to my life and is not too much in the "neuroscience realm"

The material is very interesting, and if you're like me, it'll change the way you think about many things about life. I would recommend taking it, but the exams are very memory intensive, so I would recommend keeping up with the readings during the course of the semester. Professor Jacobs is a very good lecturer, and it is obvious he cares about the quality of the course.
This is a fun and interesting course. Take it!
This is a great course for anyone interested in how the human brain works. It will broaden your knowledge about the mind mechanisms and emotions by treating lots of interesting topics!
This was not a bad course overall. The work load was manageable as a fifth course fulfilling a distribution.
Unless you want hell, don't take it!
Very easy.
Very interesting course, I would definitely take it again, and I might take more neuroscience if I can fit it in.
Very interesting subject, tests are tough, its hard course for distribution requirement but worth taking for educational and learning purposes

Very interesting, but you can't PDF, so if you are incredibly concerned with grades (like a lot of people here) you should understand that you will have to put some work into this class. However, if you just want to learn about an incredible subject, definitely take the course. That's what college should be about, and that's why I took the course.
You will get a lot out of this class if you do the readings and go to the lectures, which actually shouldn't be that much trouble since both are very interesting.
do the readings
it would be a good class if it could be pdf'd.
descrip: The course provides a basic introduction to neuroscience, especially as it impacts upon practical issues: mental disease, drugs, neurological disorders, development, learning, memory, etc. It is intended for students who are not planning to concentrate in the life sciences. It is hoped that some students may get stimulated by this course and decide to concentrate in aspects of psychology, biology, philosophy, or engineering as they relate to mind and brain.

title: Critiques of Violence
reviews:
This is a very philosophical "Think-course" which opens your eyes for the hidden violence and injustice in the world. Even though the question " What is violence?" can't be answered, the course is very useful in getting closer to an answer.
Take this course if you are interested in philosophy.
This was a good class. Professor Nesbitt is a new professor and very interested in listening to his students.
prereqs: 200-level French class or permission of Instructor..
descrip: What is violence? Visible and invisible, legitimate and illegitimate, the course will examine a selection of critiques of this ubiquitous phenomenon. Topics to include revolutionary violence in France and Haiti, the critique of colonial violence from Montaigne to Fanon and Ouologuem, and the Sartre-Merleau-Ponty-Camus debate over Soviet violence and the Algerian war. Critical writings to include Robespierre, Louverture, Benjamin, Sartre, Arendt, Foucault, Zizek, Badiou. Films will also be included.

title: Seminar in Normative Ethics
reviews: Definitely take the class.
I would highly recommend this class, or any class with Professor Appiah!
Take it, do all of the readings thoroughly, make appointments (yes, more than one) to talk with Appiah and enhance your knowledge. Do not take it if you aren't going to do the readings.

This course is not for students who need to be perpetually pushed to find reasons to engage.  You either need to be predisposed to find interesting the topics at hand (identity, race, racism, etc.), or you will have to be willing to put the effort behind engaging with the professor, texts, assignments, etc.  Once that effort is made, it is incredibly rewarding.
appiah is a wonderful teacher.
descrip: This course aims to show how the reasonable resolution of normative issues can depend on scientific and metaphysical truths as well as on ethical or moral ones. We will examine a series of interconnected questions about the ideas of race and racism. So we will ask: What, if anything, are races? What significance do they have for political and moral life? What is racism? What's wrong with it? What does our consideration of all these questions teach us about if and when we may - or must - use differences in "race" as a basis for differential treatment in private and in public life?

title: Cultural Freedoms: Hate Speech, Blasphemy, and Pornography
descrip: Freedom of expression is always limited, both by the harm that may be said to occur if unbridled and by the constraints of the dominant culture. Using such topics as hate speech on campus, the cultural defense plea, the Mapplethorpe exhibit, the Supreme Court opinions on pornography, and the Salman Rushdie affair, we will ask how civility relates to free speech, how codes may channel expression without oppression, and how cultural difference can relate to shared values and orientations.

title: Topics in Popular Music - Issues in Global Popular Music
descrip: Examines the issues involved when popular musics interact with the global media industry, the global flow of people, and the formation of local identities. We examine structures of power, as exemplified by the media industry and a country's geopolitical position. We consider how musical cultures form and how musical scenes are translated in various locales. Topics discussed include cultural imperialism, hybridism, exoticism, politics, subcultures, diaspora, and gender. Each topic is paired with case studies drawn from around the world, including Graceland, Yellow Magic Orchestra, Cuban nueva trova, punk, the Asian Underground.

title: Topics in Organic Chemistry - Methods for Complex Organic Synthesis
reviews: Good course.  Worth taking.
Great course, take it if you are interested in organic chemistry.
I would strongly advise a student to take this course if they were interested in organic chemistry.
If you are interested in organic synthesis, you will not disappointed the class. Excellent class.
Start working on the final project about a month before it is due.
descrip: An in-depth discussion of transition metal-catalyzed reactions commonly used in modern organic synthesis (e.g. cross coupling, olefin metathesis, asymmetric hydrogenation, etc.). Emphasis will be placed on the topic of selectivity (chemo-, regio-, and stereo-) and its mechanistic basis. The historical development, scope, and limitations of the methods are discussed. A prior course in organometallic chemistry (CHM 521) is recommended.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Course offers a broad treatment of macroeconomic theory and policy issues, using the formal methods of modern macroeconomics. Topics will include long-run growth and development, labor, consumption, savings and investment decisions, the role of expectations, short-run fluctuations and stabilization policy, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rates. The course is advanced, so that: (i) having had some introductory course in macroeconomics is a prerequisite, and an intermediate-level one is best; (ii) the course requires a solid command of microeconomic theory (511 c or d) and good comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Theories of International Politics
descrip: History of international relations theory, current debates, and applications to problems of international security and political economy.

title: Gore and Glory: Early Heroic Literature
prereqs: No prior knowledge of classical or medieval literature is assumed..
descrip: This course introduces major ancient and medieval heroic texts, texts that tell the deeds of men larger than life, the incursions of gods and monsters into this human world, and the awe and suffering of mortals whose fortunes depend on how all of this heroically-proportioned battle plays out. Reading chronologically, we will compare formal elements that heroic narratives share and build a repertoire of literary features. We will consider how culture and history shape a text's specificity, examining across these texts the evolving ethos and capacity of the warrior, the hero's relation to his people, and the bearing of women on heroic lives.

title: Independent Work
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical, experimental, and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include systems and cognitive neuroscience, perception and attention, learning and behavior, memory, executive function/decision-making, motor control and sequential actions. Diseases of the nervous system are considered. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: International Trade II
reviews: Although the course involves a lot of reading and is very demanding, I strongly recommend it.
That's an excellent field, professors are involved, you get to learn a lot (very demanding though !).
descrip: A continuation of ECO 551, with emphasis on current research issues. Topics vary from year to year.

title: Social Movements and Contentious Politics
descrip: Explores the study of social movements as well as other forms of unconventional collective action aimed at achieving or preventing social and political change (riots, demonstrations, strikes, terrorist movements, etc.). After examining various approaches to the field, we will investigate a number of issues of abiding concern within the field: repertoires, violence, repression, and the transnational dimensions of mobilization. Finally, we will turn to empirical applications in the study of revolutions, democratization, and nationalism.

title: Introduction to Augustan Literature
reviews: A good 200-level Latin class.
Depends on the prof and the readings, I guess. Not the best, not the worst.
I would recommend this class because of the friendly atmosphere, individual focus, developing of ability to read and understand the language, and knowledge of historical context gained.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in classics. It is a good way to cover more latin at a reasonable pace.
If you simply want an LA, just know that there are far easier LA's than this. As long as you have a genuine interest in Latin, however, definitely take this course.

It's worth shopping. Grammar is more important than you think it is. Keep up with the readings and do your translations on time and you'll be fine. Start thinking about the term paper well in advance.
Maybe read a little background about Augustan culture before taking the class.
Take it! Livy and Ovid are great, manageable authors to read. Professor Shaw is an amazing resource on Augustan history and literature. This is a fun, laid-back, and enjoyable Latin course.

This course is a great class to gauge your interest in continuing the study of Latin. Reading Ovid has helped me immensely with my translating ability and Professor Shaw is extremely knowledgeable about the works (being the Historian he is.
prereqs: LAT 108 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: A reading course in Augustan prose and poetry. The chief objectives are (1) to develop an ability to read and to appreciate Latin literature; (2) to become familiar with some of the literary themes of the age; and (3) to learn about the social and cultural world of Augustan Rome.

title: Algebraic Methods in Topology
descrip: We continue investigation of problems in finite groups acting on finite dimensional spaces. We begin with an account of Rim's Theorem on the relation of cohomological triviality and projectivity for modules, using Tate cohomology. We then apply these results to construction of examples with many intersting and unusual properties, particularly for actions on products of spheres. Later, we consider the problem of the free p-rank of symmetry of products of spheres, and try to extend Carlsson's theorem to some new cases.

title: France Today: Culture, Politics, and Society
reviews: Do the readings, watch the movies..it's really not too much work, so prepare for it! And be engaged in the class discussion!

I would recommend this course as taught by Professor Sagnier, because I think the material and style of the course is helpful for understanding French culture and improving language. I would recommend it specifically with Sagnier because I think she brought life to the course and the material, and taking a class with her was a very positive experience for me.
Keep up with your work and really try to get the most out of this class.
Take any class with Professor Sagnier - you will not regret it!
Take this class if you plan to pursue French at Princeton in any capacity. Professor Sagnier will MAKE you passionate.
Take this class! The progress that you can make throughout the semester is amazing and extremely rewarding. Professor Sagnier made every class interesting and exciting!
prereqs: FRE 108 or equivalent; FRE 207 recommended..
descrip: This course is designed to develop students' linguistic skills and broaden their knowledge of contemporary French society. Discussions and essays will cover a wide range of topics drawn from economic, political, social and cultural aspects of France and the francophone world. Current affairs will be discussed in class on a regular basis. The course will provide intensive language practice and students will improve their communication skills by completing a research project, to be presented orally and in writing, on a topic of their choice. Course material include readings, videos, films, francophone television and web-based activities.

title: Senior Project
descrip: Students conduct a one-semester project. Topics chosen by students with approval of the faculty. A written report is required at the end of the term.

title: Readings in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: Topics vary according to students' interest. Some possible topics: poety, narrative prose, "adab," historiography, ethical and political texts.

title: The Gothic Tradition
reviews: A lot of reading, but well worth it!
Be ready for a lot of reading.  The finals make sure you have done a majority of the reading, so keep up

Coming from an engineer who thought he'd hate taking an English course: it was absolutely fantastic. Alliston's lectures are interesting, the readings are badass, and the precepts are some of the best I've had at Princeton. Most importantly, I left with a much greater appreciation for the Gothic, a typically neglected literary genre, as well as of literature as a whole. If you're willing to put in a bit of effort, you'll get a lot in return. P.S. Ella Brians was a great preceptor, if you're lucky enough to get her!
Do the reading!
Don't.
I would take it for the reading list. And it's not a very hard class.

If you enjoy reading about the supernatural and are curious about the history behind the blockbuster modern gothics that have recently exploded in popularity in books and film, this class is definitely worth checking out. The first half of the semester can be a bit trying at times, but struggle through to the second half because The Monk, Frankenstein, and Dracula are definitely worth the wait.
If you love reading, you will love this course!
If you're looking for an interesting English class, don't take this one. Wouldn't recommend unless you absolutely have to.
It would depend on the size of the class and whether they get a good preceptor.
It's a fun course, a lot of reading but you can get away with not doing all of it.
Lots of reading, but most of it is super fun.
Participate in precept - it's fun. I would say do about six readings each semester to prepare you for the exams, but read those carefully.  That way you can add real insight to discussion.
Read ahead of time and pay attention in lecture, because the exam depends on established concepts and ideas moreso than your own!
Take it!
Take the class if you are interested in the subject or want something easy.
Take this class! You do have to work and it is quite the opposite of "book club," but it's worth it if you love literature!
Take this class.  The readings are terrific, the lectures are great, and there is a lot to talk about in precept.  It is a very well-organized class.

There's a lot of reading some weeks, but this is an interesting course that'll leave you with a good understanding of the Gothic tradition and how it ties into all sorts of literary traditions we still see today. I learned a lot from this class.
This is a fun course to try. If you lament the fact that you no longer have time to read for fun, this course will give you plenty of excuses to do so.
definitely definitely take it! fun, exciting, so spot on with what it's teaching, and supremely rewarding.

if you're a psych major, the readings in this course are interesting in that they relate a lot to freudian psych (a branch/discipline which current psyc researchers tend to dismiss these days). it was nice to get a feel for how freudian ideas are still applied outside the lab, in literary analysis.
descrip: The purpose of this course is to analyze and understand the cultural meanings of the Gothic mode through a study of its characteristic elements, its historical, aesthetic, and political origins in eighteenth-century English and German culture and thought, its development across Western national traditions, and its persistence in contemporary culture, including film, electronic media, clothing, social behavior, and belief systems, as well as literature. Films, artifacts, web sites and electronic publications will supplement readings.

title: Ancient Magic in Theory and Practice
descrip: The course will examine a broad spectrum of artifacts crafted and written by practitioners-magicians in the Late Antique Mediterranean. Starting with Greek Magical Papyri and amulets, we shall discover the esoteric world of secret signs and language, and the magical use of plants and animals. We shall try to reconstruct and explain a number of magical rituals described in papyri and amulets, learning our abilities and limitations in understanding those for whom the magic was real.

title: Natural Disasters
reviews: Attendance is mandatory and there's a lot of work for the pre-labs and labs so for a class to fulfill requirements and PDF it can be a little bit a little stressful.
Clicker points count so go to class sometimes.
DO IT! Its a class that doesn't require much prep outside of the labs, and its easy to put on the backburner during midterms and crunch times, then easy to catch back up on later on.
Definitely recommended if students need a lab requirement to fulfill and have a heavy workload.

Definitely something easy to PDF for an ST requirement, but the class is something you still have to exert effort in. Labs aren't great but lectures aren't too painful even if you hate science, and labs could still definitely be worse.
Do the readings
Do the readings.
Do you like science?
Especially for students who want an interesting, hands-on course to fulfill the ST requirement, I would say that this course is a great choice.

For those who are interested in these powerful phenomena, the natural disasters that shape our world so profoundly and force us to respond accordingly, or if you're simply looking for a solid ST, this class is definitely worth considering.
Go to lecture
Good way to fulfill the ST requirement.  There is more work than you may think because of the lab reports.  The material is rather interesting.  Put the work in and you can get an A.
I would recommend this class for students who are interested in natural disasters or Geology in general. I would also recommend it for students that are in need of an ST.
I would recommend this class if you intend not to put effort in getting knowledge and skills in the field. I would recommend that such a class be P/D/F'ed.
I would recommend this course because of the interesting subject matter and the more or less light work load
I would recommend this course for people that aren't really big on math and science and need to fill their distribution requirements. It's challenging but not too much so
I would recommend this for students looking for an interesting way to fulfill their ST requirement.
If you need to fulfill the ST requirement, take this.
If you need to take a lab class, this would be good if your strength isn't math. Especially if you are interested in stuff like earthquakes, hurricanes, and global warming.
If you're not good at any other STs and you want to learn about natural disasters take the class. Don't take it if you are looking for a blow off.
It's a good 5th course and a good way to satisfy an ST requirement, but don't take it if you're interested in another area of science.
It's good to take as a distributional requirement. If you genuinely like geology, don't take the class.
Learn how to write lab reports quickly and follow along with the slides
Lectures > Readings. Being an attentive listener in class is probably better than reading the whole book.
Listen and lecture, go to class because there are clickers for attendance, and do the lab reports on time.
Not a terrible course to take if you want an ST.
Only take it if you are interested in the material.  Do not take it if you only want to fulfill the ST requirement.
Only take this if you are serious about the acquisition of knowledge on natural disasters or if you are good at science classes.
Take it if you need it--you'll knock out an ST, and you may actually learn something
Take it!
Take it.
Take this class for sure, but have some coffee beforehand. Every day.
Take this course if you're interested in earth studies!
This course was very interesting and good for someone not particularly looking to continue science.
This is a good course to take if you are not a science person.
Yes, good ST.
You must take this course!
take it, easy
take this course only if you want to lose brain cells
descrip: An introduction to natural (and some society-induced) hazards and the importance of public understanding of the issues related to them. Emphasis is on the geological processes that underlie the hazards, with some discussion of relevant policy issues. Principal topics: Earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunami, hurricanes, floods, meteorite impacts, global warming. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: Metaphysics - Hyperintensional Metaphysics
descrip: Course covers selected issues in contemporary metaphysics. Possible topics include the role of hyperintensional notions in metaphysical research and the metaphysical role of individuals.

title: Combustion
reviews: Get his textbook.  It's a must.  I also feel that Glassman's combustion text would be a good supplement.
I particularly recommand it to students who took the class of energy conversion : transportation MAE427 because the approach is completely different.
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.

title: The Dramatic Expression of the Golden Age
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of the major forms of Spanish drama of the Golden Age, including plays by Lope de Vega, Tirso de Molina, and Calderon. Emphasis on the development of the theater in relation to the rise of the absolutist state, the Counter Reformation, and the impact of the Inquisition on Spanish society.

title: The Making of the Ottoman Balkans, 1350-1500: Conquest, Settlement and Infrastructural Development
descrip: The Ottoman Empire is traditionally viewed through a paradigm which stresses its Islamic character. In keeping with this assessment, its advances into southeastern Europe from the mid-14th century onward are usually portrayed as stemming from a desire to expand the frontiers of the Islamic East at the expense of the Christian West. This course will present an alternative explanation, one focusing on the extent to which the early Ottomans absorbed the peoples, practices, and nobilities of the pre-existing Christian peoples of the Balkans.

title: Complex Organization (Half-Term)
descrip: An introduction to the study of complex organizations. Course goals are (1) to familiarize you with recent organizational scholarship; and (2) to help you apply critical insights from this research to empirical analyses involving organizations. The course considers a range of issues: Why and how are organizations created? Why do organizations fail? What explains the variety (or lack thereof) among organizational forms, processes, and goals? Who benefits from organizational activities? How do environments influence organizations? What is the broader role of organizations in modern society?

title: Advanced Economic Theory II
reviews: Good course
descrip: Topics vary from year to year. See 511.

title: Milton
reviews: Excellent introduction to Milton
I wish I could recommend this course, but I can't say that I do.

I would recommend this class to other students, even to those who are not English majors. This course was very thought-provoking and challenging as it involves a lot of detailed reading. Prior knowledge of Milton's works/the classics is advantageous for discussion in precept.
If you're satisfying a distribution requirement, consider a course with (a lot) more than one author. If you love Milton, take it.
It's a solid introduction to Milton, but don't expect to be blown away.
Nigel Smith is wonderful and the course material is interesting.
Take this course.  Every student should read Paradise Lost.
Very interesting course, but very harshly graded.
descrip: We will explore John Milton's entire career, largely as poet, but also as prose writer and thinker: a lifelong effort to unite the aims of intellectual, political and literary experimentation. In doing so Milton made himself the most influential non-dramatic poet in the English language. We will spend much time with Paradise Lost, regarded by many as the greatest non-dramatic poem in English or any modern language; we will encounter Milton's profound, extensive learning and his startling innovations with words, and in ideas of personal, domestic and communal liberty.

title: Econometric Theory II
reviews: A bit boring at times, but need to sit through it.
A must-take if you are interested in serious econometrics.
Crucial to learn advanced tools in econometrics.
Good class to take with either professor.  Learn theory (70%) and tools (30%).

Good for learning about time series and applied metrics techniques. If you want to do research you have to take this. Brush up on Stochastic Limit Theory if you want to be rigorous and coding if you want to be more applied.
Great class. I'd recommend it to anyone seriously interested in econometrics.

I recommend this course to other students and recommend that students that take the course invest in understanding how to apply the concepts learned empirically since it is helpful for both research and in developing intuition.
If you want to do empirical research in economics then you should take it. Lectures are very good and a lot of material is covered.
Recommend this course.
Take it. It's hard, but with really interesting, important results.
descrip: This course begins with extensions of the linear model in several directions: (1) pre-determined but not exogenous regressors; (2) heteroskedasticity and serial correlation; (3) classical GLS; (4) instrumental variables and generalized method of movements estimators. Applications include simultaneous equation models, VARS and panel data. Estimation and inference in non-linear models are discussed. Applications include nonlinear least squares, discrete dependent variables (probit, logit, etc.), problems of censoring, truncation and sample selection, and models for duration data.

title: Reading Medieval Culture
reviews: Stay on top of the readings!
Take it.
prereqs: None..
descrip: Medieval culture, literature and literary theory, as well as Modern critical debates currently being staged, highlight the diversity of cultural production in the European Middle Ages. This course explores such topics as Medieval textuality and reading, text and image, subjectivity and spirituality, premodern sex and gender, and myths and realities of Medieval nation-building.

title: The Philosophy of Plato
descrip: Seminar aims to reconstruct and evaluate the theory of human good is presented and argued for in Plato's Philebus.

title: Gilded Age and Progressive-Era United States, 1877-1920
reviews: Attend all classes. The information for the exam is in the lectures not the books.
Generally would recommend it, and would strongly recommend it if Dr. Young is still precepting!
Gilded Age history is a pretty niche interest, so while I'd recommend it to a student with specific interest in the time period, I'd hesitate to recommend it as a general history course.
Great history class.  Good to focus on a specific period in depth, good practice for later history courses

I would strongly recommend this class to any history majors or anyone with an interest in U.S. history. I would also recommend to any student in general, as long as they know that a good amount of work/preparation is necessary to get the most out of the class. (This is a class that you have to put a lot in to get a lot out.)
If you're interested in the time period, I'd take it. Professor Rix is engaging and helpful and the exams are incredibly fair.
Kind of dry, but a great topic.

Professor Rix can be a little dry, but otherwise, this is an amazing course. Precept is really interesting. All the readings are fascinating. This class has a great syllabus. The lectures are very interesting too. They are an essential and worthwhile part of class. Go to all of them or else you will feel thrown off come exam time.
TAKE IT!
The readings were interesting and integral to understanding the material.
descrip: This course introduces students to major themes in the history of the emergence of modern American society and government. It covers 1877-1920, paying particular attention to such crucial post-Civil War developments as the modern business corporation and changing labor conditions; the transformative effects of industrialization, urbanization, immigration, and internal migration; the unsettling of traditional gender and racial arrangements; the origins of modern democracy and liberalism in labor organization, Populism and Progressivism; and U.S. participation in global politics through its colonial ventures and World War I.

title: Macroeconomics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews:
0 Do you truly need to learn these concepts? It's more satisfying than only graphical stuff, but it's far from a walk in the park. If you do want to,
1 Take notes however you need to (typing or writing) to get all of the equations down properly.
2 Ask if there can be lecture notes, they are incredibly useful.
3 If you have to read the book, read summaries before everything else; otherwise, you (read I) lose track of what you're supposed to be learning.

A course made challenging by having only 5 problem sets with no repetition of ideas, and a disorganized lecturer, although the ideas of the course are very interesting and should not be too difficult.
Best (and easiest) of the 310, 311, 312 sequence.  Benjamin Moll is the man.
Good for people who know math, as economics without math is vague and it is difficult to develop insight.
Great course; I strongly recommend it if Moll is teaching.
I recommend this class, but then they might change prof. again next semester, so my comments might not apply.
If you like Macroeconomics you might like this course. If you don't you'll have a hard time, even if you're good at math, as intuition plays a very important role.
If you like econ and know math, take this over 301
It's going to be all about the problem sets.  Know how to do what the lecturer does.
Moll won't be teaching it next year so this is irrelevant
Only take it if you have to or if you really like math and are interested in macroeconomic models.
Professor Moll makes this class much better than its reputation. It's really interesting; take it instead of 310 if you're only doing one.

Strongly suggest taking this course, especially if Ben is teaching.  You won't learn anything that you didn't already know if you take ECO 301, and that's a huge waste of time.  The math is not forbidding by any means as long as you know how to take Lagrangians and aren't afraid of algebra that can get a bit messy sometimes.  Go to lecture - I cannot stress this point enough. Ben walks you through EVERYTHING you need to know in lecture, and does so in a very organized, concise, and elegant way.  Trying to teach yourself the material is a nightmare, but by going to lecture you will save yourself a lot of time and suffering, especially since the problem sets are very similar to what he does in class.  If you've done ECO310 and/or ECO 312, you will be more than fine - I actually found this class to be more straightforward than either one of these.
Take It
The class is not hard if you have a strong math background. The material is pretty interesting.
This class is definitely easier than ECO 310, and if you enjoyed that class at all, you should take this course for a similar mathematical treatment of macro.
You can take it.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 and MAT 200 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course examines the determinants of long-run economic growth, short-run business cycle fluctuations, and the conduct of monetary and fiscal policy. The first part of the course develops a framework for the analysis of households' consumption and savings behavior and firms' production decisions, and uses that to analyze long-run growth and financial crises. The second part of the course extends that analysis to examine business cycle fluctuations, including inflation, unemployment. Current issues in macroeconomic and financial policy are discussed throughout.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: Attend lectures and precepts. Ask questions if you don't understand something.
Do not take this class unless you like linguistics for some reason.
Go to lecture.
Go to precept - it really helps to do examples as a group and if Vrinda is your preceptor, you're in great hands.
Go to the lectures.
I didn't particularly enjoy this course or the subject matter.

I think that everyone should take this course while they're here. Understanding the structure and properties of human language increases one's grasp of native and foreign tongues. I would highly recommend the course to any student, regardless of his or her concentration.
I would recommend that they take the class PDF if they are not all that interested in the material. I really enjoyed the material though.
I would recommend this course to those students interested in a language-based distribution requirement. It may not be for everyone though.
If you are at all interested in linguistics, give this class a shot. I enjoyed it.
If you are interested in linguistics it is a very interesting subject!
If you are looking for an EC, this is a good one.
If you want to learn about ling, take it. if you have no interest in it, and are simply trying to fulfill a dist. requirement, don't.
If you work you can get an A, but unless you know you are really interested in the material don't take it - work harder in a class that you will actually learn in and enjoy.
If you're into linguistics, go for it, but there are probably other more interesting ECs to take for the distribution requirement.

It is really cool to think about languages in a way that is entirely different from what I've experienced before.  I *think* I'm glad I took it, but the stress of trying to self-teach using a sometimes-wrong text was not great.
It took a while to get into the class, but after midterms, it started to grow on me.  The concepts can be frustrating at times, but they're not difficult.
It's a good class that doesn't require much work. Take it for a distribution requirement.
It's an interesting course for your EC, if it's not in-field.
Lectures are boring, subject matter is fine, grading is fair. It's an EC, probably not the worst way to get one.

Linguistics is clearly a very complicated subject.  Be sure to attend lectures and to read the textbook closely.  If neither of these things helps, precepts and office hours are your friends!  

If you're just in need of an EC, I would recommend logic or a philosophy class instead...!
Only take this class if you want a view of language that is both very technical and very removed from language as it will ever be practically useful.
Take it. It's really easy and you might end up loving linguistics!

Take the course only if you are actually interested in linguistics. Freidin is a really nice guy and he is great at communicating by email. Even if he is not the best at it, he is always willing to help.

Take this course if you have any interest in linguistics, but be aware that you do need to pay close attention to lectures to fully understand what's going on.  Freidin is not the worst lecturer ever, but he's also not the easiest to follow.
Take this if you actually have an interest in the subject of linguistics or think you will, and you might like this class. Otherwise, it would be insufferably boring.
The class is a good EC to take, and it gives one a good overview of the field of linguistics.
The material is interesting, and not overly challenging. Pay attention in the lectures and go to precepts. Not reading will not hurt you.

This course has some really interesting material, but it has a different kind of organization and if it unsettles you to have things come up at the last second, then this may not be the course for you. If not, then this course is pretty great.

This course seems to give a decent introduction to some areas of linguistics, particularly syntax. Freidin is a poor lecturer, though, and the class often felt disorganized and frantic. It's a fairly light load.
Work hard, ask questions, and pay attention in lecture. Also, read the notes he makes for you. They're very, very helpful!
You don't need to read the book. Get Vrinda as a preceptor.
do not take. ever.
dont take this class. ever.
descrip: Introduction to the major areas, problems and techniques of modern linguistics, providing an overview of what is known about human language: its unique nature, structure, universality and diversity.

title: Theory of Algorithms
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work; you need to sit down and understand the material, then just think about the problems for a few days, and finally write down your answers at some point.  Definitely leave time to sleep on your answers; they'll become much more clear that way!

Be prepared for some sleepless nights and pay attention to the lectures as much as you can. Also, learn to use Google to help find papers and other lectures about topics that appear in the problem sets.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the problem sets.
Do not take this class.

Even though the material was inherently very interesting, the course is probably not worth taking.  Prof. Tarjan is brilliant and definitely tries to make this a good course, but he is not the most engaging lecturer.
If computer science interests you, and if you think you know some algorithms, definitely take the course.
If you are really interested in and good at algorithm, or you just want to take a course offered by a Turing Award recipient, you may take it. Although the content is hard, the examination is not.
Keep up with readings, start problem sets early.
Only take this if you are a COS Theory person.
Start the homework sets early; don't pass up opportunities to collaborate; don't pass up extra credit opportunities; Google Scholar is your friend.
Take it!

Take this course if you are already familiar with or have taken a more basic algorithm class. Be ready to spend a lot of time on the problem sets. The recommended textbook is sometimes better organized and more helpful than the lecture slides.
Take this course, but be prepared to work.

Take this if you enjoy theory. It's not every day that you get to take a course with a leader in the field. Problem sets are not too bad and very interesting. Lectures are great if you enjoy the material. I wish I could take it again.
The contents of this course are critical to all areas of computer science, and hence students should definitely take this course.

The material is sometimes interesting but the lectures are consistently monotonous. If you absolutely must take the course, know that the book is completely unnecessary, problem sets vary substantially in difficulty (so start early), and the lecture slides are sufficient enough to make the lectures themselves an optional (don't do it!) affair.
Think twice, and maybe thrice.
This course gives excellent exposure to the topic of analysis of algorithms and design of new algorithms.
This course needs some basic backgrounds of algorithm, and is not a low-level course.
This is really a challenging course and please be prepared that it will be very time consuming if one is determined to learn this course well fully.
Unless you absolutely love algorithms and are willing to put in a huge amount of time outside of class to learn the material on your own, I think this class will frustrate and disappoint you.
Very hard class, and a lot of work, but do take it if you are looking for a challenge.
prereqs: COS 226 and 340, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Design and analysis of efficient data structures and algorithms. General techniques for building and analyzing algorithms. Introduction to NP-completeness.

title: International News - Reporting from Abroad
reviews: - Bernstein sadly won't be teaching it again, so I can't vouch for any other teachers in the future. But if it's anything like the course we had this semester, then by all means, TAKE IT!! This was my favorite course this spring by far.

If you're in any way interested in, or intrigued by journalism--not necessarily meaning you want to be a journalist, but even if you wonder what foreign correspondents do and why foreign reporting is the way it is--take the course. It'll really open your horizons.
[Disclaimer: Your experience may vary depending on who's teaching.]
If you're interested in learning how to write news articles, as journalist would, this course if useful.
Take it! Though this one won't necessarily be offered again in this exact iteration, take the journalism seminars!
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: How foreign reporters get it right, when they do, and why they sometimes get it wrong. Students will write their own "news stories" about events abroad, past and present. We aren't abroad, but we will collect information, in part through documentary research but also by doing what reporters do, which is to question experts. Students will practice writing succinct, accessible journalistic essays and learn about current events, fairly recent history, and the way journalists work.

title: Diffuse Matter in Space
reviews: For graduate student in astrophysics, this is a requirement so there is not much choice here. But it is a good course and I would recommend taking it.
ISM is a really worthy taking course. Reading is important part in the lecture.
If you're planning to do any serious research in astrophysics, this course covers much of the necessary background material to help you understand what's going on.
It's a great course and very important in the field of astrophysics. It's totally worth taking it.
The readings are both useful intellectually and essential for success in the course. You will undoubtedly learn a lot from the course as a lot of effort has been put into its structure and material.
This is a very important class. I think it should actually be the first we take when starting the graduate program.
descrip: Subject of course is the astrophysics of the interstellar medium: theory and observations of the gas, dust, plasma, energetic particles, magnetic field, and electromagnetic radiation in interstellar space. Emphasis will be on theory, including elements of: fluid dynamics; excitation of atoms, molecules and ions; radiative processes; radiative transfer; simple interstellar chemistry; and physical properties of dust grains.The theory will be applied to phenomena including; interstellar clouds (both diffuse atomic clouds and dense molecular clouds); HII regions; shock waves; supernova remnants; cosmic rays; interstellar dust; and star formation.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences IV
reviews: A lot of work, but great class
Difficult, very bio but also quantitative

Don't take unless you want to get a PhD in Bio, have worked in a Bio lab before, and have significant experience with genomics.  Otherwise it will be assumed that you know a lot more than you do and you will have to either read 300 pages of science textbooks to catch up, or you'll have no idea what is going on.
I would take it in a heartbeat.
If you like biology and don't expect it to be as mathy as first year.
If you like science and math and are willing to work hard, take integrated.  It'll set you up for pretty much any science career.  Go to problem sessions and precepts!  They're worth it.
If you took 235 then don't stop now.  It is a great course.
If you took first semester, why stop now?

If you took freshman year ISC, and are interested in biology, then definitely take this course.  Heck, if you didn't take first year ISC, but have taken all the prerequisites and are interested in biology, take this course!
