If you've already made it through three semesters of Integrated (or even if you're weird and joined in second year), it's really worth it to finish it off. You learn really cool stuff from the masters, and you already know what to expect.
If you've taken 231-5, not taking 236 wouldn't make much sense.
Integrated science is an amazing curriculum.
Take it!!
Take it, you fools. Why would you quit now?

This class is challenging, but well worth the time and effort that it demands, as it provides the foundations for a wide variety of scientific pursuits through the presentation of quantitative methods and ways of thinking.

This course appeals to a very specific set of people, but for those with the right set of interests I highly recommend taking this. The course trains you to think like a scientist better than most of the courses at Princeton, which focus on treating you like a student, and this is a very valuable skill. Also, the faculty is amazing.
This course is interesting and not too grueling. Definitely take it if you you like the idea of biology with some math thrown in.

You need to take this is you are a second year integrated student, as it will complete the biochemistry and genetics backbone of your coverage of QCB. But as usual with integrated, and especially for this semester, you will need to do a lot of independent reading and study to stay up to par, which will be really tough if you don't love the material.
prereqs: Students are expected to have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 235..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics, and evolution. This is the second course in the year-long multidisciplinary integrated science sequence. Five faculty will be involved over the year: D. Botstein, M. Llinas, E. Wieschaus (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM), L. Kruglyak (EEB).

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: It's a great course, especially if you are looking for a more hands-on
Take it! It will be a good way to see how engineering can be applied in the real world.
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Diplomacy and Security in Northeast Asia
descrip: Course examines the major diplomatic and security issues affecting relations among the major powers in Northeast Asia and the evolution of current U.S. policy towards China, Korea, and Japan. Reviews the U.S. alliance system in the region and discuss the major challenges facing these alliances. Particular emphasis is placed on examining the implications of China's rise for U.S. policy. Finally, the course will devote special attention to the challenge posed to regional peace and stability by North Korea and its nuclear ambitions.

title: Homer
reviews: I would recommend it because the material is great, and if you're going to do Classics then you should probably have this level of Greek behind you.
If you like Greek, take it! Homer is very interesting
Learn vocabulary all the time. It will be the only way to gain speed and skill in reading Homer.

Take this course if you want to learn about Homeric Greek.  If you want to talk about Homer as a literary work, you might be better off looking elsewhere, since the focus on reading Greek doesn't leave much time for talking about the text.
This is a ton of work.  Much more work than 105, but for some reason this year it was even tougher than 213.  There are presentations. It acts like a 200-level class.
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: To learn to read Homer with pleasure. In addition to providing an introduction to Homeric dialect, oral poetry, and meter, we will discuss literary technique, epic's historical background, and Homer's role in the development of Greek thought.

title: Special Studies in Modernism - Exilic Time
descrip: Exile by definition entails a wrenching relocation in space, but exile also can disarrange, by fracturing, the sense of time. This course will examine the double time of exilic life, what Nabokov in [Pnin] calls physical time and spiritual time. Physical time accentuates the pangs of inhabiting a present so radically different from the familiar but quickly receding past. Spiritual time is more mobile and more creative; it can recall a vanished world back into existence and even project a future return. We will explore the theme of exilic time from Conrad's [Under Western Eyes] and Joyce's [Ulysses] to Sebald's [Austerlitz].

title: Atmospheric and Oceanic Wave Dynamics
descrip: Observational evidence of atmospheric and oceanic waves; laboratory simulation. Surface and internal gravity waves; dispersion characteristics; kinetic energy spectrum; critical layer; forced resonance; instabilities. Planetary waves: scale analysis; physical description of planetary wave propagation; reflections; normal modes in a closed basin. Large-scale barclinic and barotropic instabilities. Eady and Charney models for barclinic instability, and energy transfer.

title: Topics in the Intellectual History of Modern and Contemporary Spain - On Heroes and Urban Legends in Spain
prereqs: At least one SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission..
descrip: Using Spanish context as a case study, this course analyzes how literature shapes everyday life and how narrations play a central role in the configuration of a society. Films, novels, short stories, popular tales and other kind of narratives will be studied from a narratologic and cultural perspective, focusing on two paradigms: heroes' tales and urban legends. Violence and power, collective memories and ghosts, democracy and fictions are among selected topics.

title: Immigration Debates in the United States
prereqs: This is a combined public policy and writing course. Interest in testing different styles of journalism writing and in honing a non-fiction writing style is essential..
descrip: This course will examine the current national debate over immigration, studying the historical context and the social impact of immigration to the United States since 1990, primarily from Latin America and the Caribbean; as well as the evolution of policy. This is a writing course in which we will read and practice different journalism styles for reporting this contentious issue, from the neutral news voice to the blog blast.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Surviving Good Governance: Public Administration after the Reforms
reviews: I would say to take this course if you have a very keen interest in public reforms, but to not expect to get a historical perspective on the specific reforms.
It will at times be a little boring, but Ferraro is amazingly knowledgeable and an authority on the topic. Grading not particularly hard, and definitely good times to be had.
Really enjoyed it. The lectures can be a bit slow at times but it is overall a great class, with a great professor and interesting materials.
Take the course, because there is none other that deals with this particular and very interesting subject at Princeton.
descrip: This seminar introduces students to the main issues in state and public administration reform carried out in Latin America over the last 15 years. The three main points to be discussed are Classical Weberianism, New Public Management, and Neo-Weberianism. The seminar will present a critical review of each, both in theory and implementation. In addition, the seminar has the practical goal of providing students with the capacity not only to understand, but also to reproduce and further elaborate arguments for and against each of the main reform models, generally and in specific cases of application.

title: Forms of Literature - American Elegy
reviews: Do all of the readings and come to class with ideas that you really want to discuss.
It is a very personal, at times difficult, but always moving course.
Take anything Diana Fuss teaches.

Take it if you like reading poems. Professor Fuss is great. The workload is manageable - i.e. not Princetonian, which is also great. This also satisfied two distribution requirements, I think, a nice plus.
This course is amazing. The subject matter seems odd but it's super interesting.
it is challenging yet very much rewarding.
descrip: This course explores the evolution and significance of the American elegy, from the antebellum to the postwar periods. We will read both personal and public elegies, moving from deathbed to hospital bed, home front to battlefield, bourgeois parlor to rural woods. Beginning with 17th c. Puritan elegy and ending with late 20th c. family elegy, we will cover a range of periods and poems in between, including national elegy, Indian elegy, child elegy, African American elegy, Civil War elegy, World War elegy, lynch elegy, and AIDS elegy.

title: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer
reviews: Dedicate considerable time to the project.
Do your homework and study hard.
Heat and mass transfer is an important subject for all engineers to take. It is a difficult course, but well worth it.
It's a lot of work, but provides a solid background in heat and mass transfer fundamentals.
Most students who take this course don't have a choice to take it or even a choice of when to take it, but it was a good class.
N/A
Not an easy one.
students should be fairly confident with the math techniques they learned in first semester (cbe502)
descrip: A survey of modeling and solutions methods for processes involving heat and mass transfer. Topics will include convective and difffusive transport, conservation equations, scaling principles and approximation techniques, forced convection, multi-component energy and mass transfer as well as buoyancy and turbulent driven transport.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Given that this is an unavoidable requirement, you may as well enjoy your time in it.
focus on reading and understanding the case studies
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: The Rise of Asian Capital Markets
reviews: A good class to PDF/audit. JCdS is extremely knowledgeable, and you'll absorb a ton just sitting in his lectures.
Definitely take this course: professor is great, and you'll learn a lot about financial markets!
Great class! But be prepared to participate to get the most out of it.

I really liked the class. Prof. JC de Swaan is a good teacher and it will be very interesting for people interested in finance in Asia. Prof. is very knowledgeable. I found the readings to be very interesting as well. However, remember that 30% of your grade depends on class participation.
I think this course will prove to be very interesting and engaging for anyone passionate or curious about Asian capital markets.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in Asia, the markets, and finance. It would be extremely interesting to students from other subjects as well.
TAKE THIS COURSE
Take it!
take it!
prereqs: For those who are unable to register because the course is full, please contact Professor De Swaan directly - jdeswaan@princeton.edu. Sophomores need special permission from instructor to enroll..
descrip: This course will explore the increasing weight of Asia in global equity financial markets and its implications. It will frame the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, putting particular emphasis on concepts of economic development, domestic institutional reform, corporate governance, and public market investments. Discussions will combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian equity markets. It will also explicitly consider the policy decisions faced by the US and Chinese governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: Topics in Contemporary Italian Civilization - Pirandello's Generic Transformation: From Short Story to Theater
reviews: I would encourage a student to take this class only if the group of students taking it are motivated.
If you are interested at all in Pirandello, or even in Italian literature and drama, you have to take this course.
If you are interested in the Italian language, taking Pirandello with Frassica is the best thing any student could do.
prereqs: 200-level Italian course or permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course is intended to provide an introduction to Pirandello, concentrating on his evolution from short-story writer to dramatist. Special attention will be given to those cases in which Pirandello transformed one of his own stories into a play. We will also consider the ways in which the dramatist gives additional psychological depth to the characters that appear in his short stories. In addition, we will examine how Pirandello's plays are also miniature psychodramas that reenact the dramatist's own obsessions.

title: An Introduction to Engineering
reviews: Definitely take if you are in engineering, even if you already know your major.

For any engineering students looking for a good 5th class or looking to explore in more depth some subject areas that would not be seen until further in their Princeton careers, I would strongly recommend taking this course.

Here's the deal: this class is sort of a double-edged sword. On the one hand, the lectures can go into the seriously boring. On the other hand, the labs are usually fun and relaxed. If you are very confused about which department of engineering to go into, I'd consider taking it - it worked for me (unfortunately by giving me the distinct impression that all the other departments were incredibly boring). If you have a pretty strong conviction about what to do, then don't take this class; you can find better things to do with your time.
I would strongly recommend this course to someone who is unsure what engineering is really like.
If you have any curiosity about any field in engineering, take this course. It fills no requirements and will take an elective spot but it is a great 5th class.
If you think you want to be an engineer, take this course.
It's an easy course and it's fun to be with other engineers.
It's quite a good fifth course, but don't expect it to change your life. I left lectures with new perspective, but never new understanding.

Take the course, especially if you are not sure what type of engineering you are interested in! The labs provide you with an example of what you would be doing in class, while guest lecturers brought in also give you an idea of what types of jobs people in that concentration go on to have.

Take this class if you want an easy fifth class that's kind of fun and interesting.  You do learn some things that I think are pretty important for any engineer to learn (things that you probably should just know as an engineer or person).
Take this course if you are undecided between the different engineering majors! Or if you want an easy PDF class!
Take this course, you won't regret it.
Take this course. It's a great way to work a break into your schedule and still get 5 courses in, and the Mech E labs are fun.

There is absolutely no reason why you shouldn't take this course.  Yes, it takes up a good amount of class time, but there is no homework and I actually learned more in this course than in several other courses because they teach you about something new and interesting (and actually applicable) each class.
dont take it, unless you really need the 5th easy course as BSE
prereqs: Open to BSE freshmen.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the various disciplines of engineering. It is a project-based sequence (Energy Conversion and the Environment, Robotic Remote Sensing, and Wireless Image & Video Transmission) that covers engineering disciplines and their relationship to the principles of physics and mathematics.

title: Secrets and Confessions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Geometry and Architectural Representation
reviews: I loved this class. When we weren't drawing, the lectures were really interesting.
If you want to prepare yourself for a successful architecture career/major at this school, definitely take this class to help build your level of visual and representational understanding.
Take this before you take Arch 204

This class is a great introduction to both broad architectural concepts and the practicalities of drawing and representation. Professor Young is an engaging lecturer and is incredibly helpful in critiquing your work. However, this class is heavily geared towards students planning to be architecture majors, so be careful if you are taking it for general interest - you will pull multiple all nighters working on drawings.
This class is amazing. Take it. If you're an architecture major, then definitely take it. Professor Young is one of the best lecturers and one of the most brilliant professors I've had at Princeton.
This course provides the basic tools necessary to perform basic drafting, and is not a survey of architectural styles.
the work takes a lot of time, but it is worth it.
prereqs: This course is designed primarily for freshman and sophomores who are interested in gaining introductory experience in design and drawing. This course will help prepare students for ARC 204 and upper-level studios..
descrip: This course sets out two goals: the first is to understand the theories and techniques of geometry in architectural representation; the second is to develop the student's drawing sensibilities through 5 thematic drawing projects engaging both digital and manual techniques. Each new theme will be introduced through a lecture, tutorial, and discussion including a number of specific readings related to the topic at hand. The second class will be an individual desk crit to discuss the development of each drawing project. The third class will consist of a group pin-up review of each drawing experiment.

title: Seminar in Musicology - The Pluralities of Modernism: Vienna 1890-1920
descrip: Examines currents of musical modernism in Vienna, including those outside the traditional canon of the "Second Viennese School". Course surveys the broad spectrum of musical innovations and analyzes their relationship to important challenges of modernity, including revolutions in recording, film, and communications technology, new conceptions of time, rising ethnic and religious tensions, and gender and sexual politics, and how these momentous transformations affected notions of form, phrase structure, orchestration, performance practice, and genre.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
reviews: Be prepared to work, the class encourages independence but without hard work and focus in each lecture it may be less rewarding.
If you're interested in learning about cancer pathology, this is a great course to take.
It doesn't matter if you don't have a background in cancer biology. Preparing yourself with a broad mind and reading about both basic and clinic cancer research would be helpful.
Really laid-back course, nobody really does the readings haha...
Take it--you won't regret it!
Take it.

Take this class if you want to learn some general information about molecular pathways in cancer.  You will be exposed to a lot of material but luckily you will not be forced to memorize it all since there is very little assessment in the course.
descrip: We will explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We will review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We will discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We will investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We will explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Financial Econometrics
reviews:
Be prepared to learn everything by yourself, and not learning much. 

Expect to spend hours on homeworks that are completely pointless and useless.
Compulsory class. Very redundant with other classes
Extremely hard course for people with limited background.
Recommended.
Take this course!! It's very interesting.

They probably have to take it as a requirement, in which case well they just have to do it and beware for all the mistakes they'll come across...
If they're just looking for a statistics/econometrics class, I'd suggest they look for sth more interesting.
This class is very time-consuming due to awkward homework.
This class was required, and I would perhaps not have taken it if it wasn't. However, it was a good class, and since I had to take it, I am glad that it was taught as it was.
need some basic stat background and finance background
who cares you have no choice
descrip: Econometric and statistical methods as applied to finance. Topics include: Overview of Statistical Methods; Predictability of asset returns; Discrete time volatility models; Efficient Portfolio and CAPM; Multifactor Pricing Models; Intertemporal Equilibrium and Stochastic Discount Models; Expectation and present value relation; Simulation methods for financial derivatives; Econometrics of financial derivatives; Forecast and Management of Market Risks; Multivariate time series in finance; Nonparametric methods in financial econometrics

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Topics in Algebra
prereqs: MAT322 or MAT323.
descrip: The study of local fields and its application ot Galois theory. Continuation of algebra, with emphasis on advanced topics in Galois theory.

title: Special Topics in the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine - Art, Science, and Technology
descrip: How have the visual arts and the sciences interacted in the modern period? In what ways have those interactions served to define and defy boundaries between empirical investigation and expressive creativity? Where is the most significant contemporary work in this area, and to what extent is this work informed by or indifferent to historical tradition? In this seminar we will take up these questions and others through a course of readings in primary and secondary sources from the Renaissance to the present day.

title: Topology
reviews: Anyone who has any interest in math at all MUST TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!
Definitely take topology at some point, preferably with Szabo.
I would recommend, but I would take Algebra before taking this class. It should be a prerequisite. Also, the final is really long and hard.

If you're a math major, you absolutely must take this class - Szabo is  ridiculously good at explaining topological concepts and making sure there are enough examples that everything gets through to you.  He tries very hard to not get bogged down in the longer proofs, and instead actually give you the machinery of topology and explain how to use it.  

Munkres is also a great book and there are a lot of solid problems to work on, although the lectures are so good that reading it isn't exactly necessary to understand the material.  On the other hand, it's nice to have it there as a reference for the proofs that we didn't do entirely in class, and there are some neat little chapters throughout (proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, Baire category theorem, etc).

Take it with Szabo if at all possible, it's hard not to be inspired by the elegance of this material in his presentation.
It's a fine class for learning topology.
Take it!
Take it. Szabo is a really good lecturer and the material is interesting.

This is a very interesting course and Prof. Szabo is an excellent lecturer -- he is able to clarify the ideas presented in the book quite well.  He is fond of using pictures rather than getting mired in tedious details, which is a good thing if you want to have a real understanding of the subject.  However, I suggest you study algebra before the second half of the semester.
This is an amazing class. Every math major should take this class, and even if you aren't majoring in math and you just enjoy math, you should take this class.

Topology is a really interesting field and this course provides a great intro, no previous knowledge required.  Professor Szabo is quite possibly the chillest professor at Princeton.  And the problem sets are really easy, so it's a good course to take alongside a harder math class.
prereqs: MAT 202, 204, or 218 or permission of the instructor.
descrip: An introduction to point set topology, the fundamental group, covering spaces, methods of calculation and applications.

title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
reviews: As long as you have experience coding, you will absolutely enjoy this class.
Consider computer science as a requirement for taking this class.
Great, fun course!! Push your musical boundaries and experience the cutting edge of electronic music!

It's a lot of fun. The requirement that you don't need programming experience beforehand is perhaps ok but taking COS 126 before this would really help. I was fine with the code, but in general some programming experience would help many students.
Solid course, interesting introduction to electronic music. Can get a bit slow at times depending on your background.
Some of the most fun you will have in a computer science class at Princeton. Take it.
Take Cos 126, then take this class.
Take it if you're interested in the subject and sound, and willing to take on the programming challenge.
The coding is harder than you think it will be. But performing is fun.
This course is great for any student that is interested in computer science, music, and their intersection. The material is interesting, and there is a lot of opportunity for individual creativity.
Very fun class.  Easier than most departmentals for COS majors, but harder for those without programming experience.
prereqs: Instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music in the context of the Princeton Laptop Orchestra (PLOrk). The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.

title: Introduction to Clinical Neuropsychology: Case Studies in Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: Definitely take it if you have a neuro background! We also had people who took it who didn't, but as someone who does have a neuro background, it make me very very interested in everything we did in the class. Prof Kastner's great and the topics are very interesting.
Don't be scared by the name - there's a lot of interesting stuff here.
I would definitely recommend this class, especially for pre-meds in the neuro certificate program.

Take this class if you intend to go to med school or grad school for clinical psychology. Don't expect to be taught much directly by the professor since every class is dedicated to three hour long student presentations.
Take this course, especially if you want to study clinical psychology.
do the readings, speak up, awesome course!
no comment
prereqs: An introductory neuroscience course, such as NEU/PSY 258 or NEU/PSY 259ab, or instructor's permission. Aimed at students with an interest in clinical psychology, pre-meds, and Neuroscience Program students with an interest in clinical applications..
descrip: Much of what we know about the brain systems underlying perception, attention, memory, and language was first derived from patients with brain lesions or other brain pathology. This course provides an introduction to major syndromes in clinical neuropsychology such as object agnosia (deficits in object recognition), amnesia, visuospatial hemineglect (attention deficits), aphasia (language deficits), and others through careful analysis of clinical cases and their underlying pathology.

title: Cities and Suburbs in American History
reviews: Ask questions when something is not clear, and expect to do a lot of reading.
Good way to take care of your US History requirement.

Great course for history majors or anyone interested in public policy, urban studies, or American stories in general! If you put in the time to do the readings and go to lectures, you will get a lot of out this class.
I definitely learned.
I enjoyed this class and Professor Isenberg is wonderful!
I highly recommend taking the course. Stay up on the readings and you will really enjoy it.
If you are really interested in the topic then you should take it. If not, there are other history classes that might be a little easier to follow and more fun than this course.

If you ever get a chance to have Karam Nachar as your preceptor, do it. He's awesome. Wait until the professor has had more teaching experience to take this course at Princeton. Don't take it in 2011-12. Maybe in 2012-13.
If you're interested it was a fine course.
This is a good course for anyone interested in urban history or getting an urban studies certificate.
This is an interesting class that gives students a different perspective fro which to view the development of cities throughout American history. Just be prepared for a large amount of reading.
Would not recommend course.
descrip: From the colonial era to the present, this course weaves together a comprehensive history of American cities and suburbs, cutting across social life, politics, economics, culture, and the built environment. Topics include urban planning and design, public and private spaces, social experience, urban investment and disinvestment, the metropolitan economy, politics and policy, arts and culture, city leadership, and the participation of ordinary people in shaping urban and suburban life.

title: Independent Research Project
prereqs: Students MUST sign up in room 121 during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member. Open to sophomores and juniors.

title: The Tragic, The Comic, and The Political
descrip: No Description Available

title: Film Noir
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Persian Reading II: Modern Persian Prose
prereqs: PER 107 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course focuses on modern Persian prose. It is the continuation of 302, and is designed to improve the student's proficiency in the reading and comprehension of Persian texts. The emphasis is on reading, understanding, and translating modern prose. The class is conducted in Persian.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
reviews:
1. Find a way to use that tiny desk to take good notes.
2. Eighty minutes was a little longer than I was ready for, no matter what I told myself. Bring gum.
Do all the practice midterms and finals for preparation. Reading the book will not be enough. Go to all lectures.
Don't go to class if you already know some stats
Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to
Don't take unless you want to become an economics major and are absolutely sure of that.
Go to class, listen carefully, and enjoy!
Go to lectures. Even if you know everything, his tests are purely based off what he goes over in lectures so you will know what to study for and what tricks to look out for.
I guess going to lecture is helpful, but he makes the exams much harder than they need to be considering the subject material. Just be prepared for that.
I recommend this class if you want to take a stats class, have to fulfill the Econ pre-reqs, or just want to take a class that is math-based but not really math.

I would advise other students to pay attention and attend all lectures and to read as you along. Don't decide to try to understand everything at the end, it will not work. One concept feeds off another so it is really important to understand everything as the lectures progress.
I would advise them to do the readings and go to lecture and make sure they really understand the concepts and equations.

I would highly recommend it for students who need a statistics course and don't mind a fair amount of math. However, it is somewhat difficult and probably more math-intensive than most other stat classes.
I would make sure to read the textbook, and exposure to statistics beforehand could be helpful.
I would recommend either another statistics class or taking an equivalent summer course at another college.
I would recommend this course for anyone who wants to learn methods of statistical analysis.
I wouldn't take this course unless you need to.  If you do, try to get some outside one on one help because the book, lecture, and precepts may not be enough.
If this course is very difficult for you, you probably shouldn't major in economics.
If you are a prospective Econ major take it because you have to.

If you don't have a relatively strong math background and don't need to take a statistics class, you probably shouldn't take ECO202.  BUT, if you have decent math skills, Professor Mueller takes an arguably boring subject and makes it exciting for students who want to learn statistics, and tolerable for those who are required to take the class.
If you like math, it's an interesting course. There is no economics involved whatsoever. If you haven't done statistics it's a good introduction.

If you like statistics, this class is not very hard and doesn't require much time. It is not the most interesting class though, and many of the potentially interesting situations in which the material could be used are ignored.
If you need to take it as a pre-req, do so. If you are thinking of taking it just to become acquainted with stats, don't underestimate the difficulty of the class.
If you want to major in econ you have to take it
If you want to take a stats course, this is absolutely the one to take!
Keep up on the work from the beginning and the course will be pretty straightforward. Professor Mueller is great and he makes the course fun.
Make sure to do all of the practice test
Not too hard a course. Complete the readings before lecture, since they'll give you a broad background for understanding general concepts.
Only take if required

Only, and only if you are an econ major and you need this for a distribution requirement should you take this class. Otherwise, don't waste your time -- you're better off buying a book online and working through it yourself.
Pretty easy stat course, not work intensive at all.  I'd take it again.
Pretty straightforward course. Problem set and exam questions are fair.

Professor Mueller is highly entertaining. I found this class challenging, but the stuff you learn will definitely be useful. 

Make sure you study early for the final!!
Really great class!
Statistics is a dull subject if you aren't mathematically inclined, but Professor Muller does his best to make class entertaining and you'll come out of ECO 202 knowing a lot about the subject.
Stay on top of the work and don't fall behind otherwise this course will become impossible.  Work with other students and figure out problems you are having quickly.
Take it
Take it even if you don't need to for the computational concepts that everyone should know.
Take it if you are an Econ major, but otherwise probably don't bother.
Take it if you have no experience with statistics. If you've been through AP stat, go ahead and take ORF 245 or 300 level ORF/MAT classes instead.
Take it, because you have to as an ECON major. But don't fret, because it's a good learning experience.
Take it, especially if Professor Mueller is teaching it.  Even if you don't want to be an econ major it is worth it.
Take it. You will feel like you learned.
Take this class if it is required.
Take this if you want to understand Econ ideas and not just memorize how to do problems!
Take this over the other Stats classes because the teacher is great!
Take this, the professor goes over the material well.

The class is easy and gives you a good introduction to statistics. The problem sets are few and easy, the lectures are quite good and entertaining, the tests are at most moderate in difficulty and the curve is decent.
The class is tough and going to hurt your GPA, but it's required and it is helpful for economics so you'll need to take it.
Things get progressively more challenging. It will get you where you need to be.
This class presents information that is good to know in life, but it is not the most exciting class.
This course is definitely a lot of work, but you get a lot out of it.
This is a tough stats class.

This is a very good course for every student, as it is applicable/insightful for every field.
This is a must-take course at Princeton.
This is overall a very good statistics course. Professor Mueller's lectures are generally engaging, and he's accessible and cares about his students.
do not take it. its terrible. muller is terrible
do the problem sets
dont do it if you dont have to.
easy stats course, i would recommend orf245 if you like math (i regret not taking orf245 instead)
go to lectures. the book only tells you so much.
only take it if it's required
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101 and MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to probability and statistical methods for empirical work in economics. Probability, random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and hypotheses testing, introduction to the regression model. Economic applications are emphasized.

title: Religious Authority in Modern Islam
descrip: How far reaching is the "fragmentation" of religious authority in modern Islam? How have traditional religious scholars sought to rearticulate their authority in conditions of radical change? On what basis do "new religious intellectuals" make their claims to authority? How has the state shaped structures of religious authority? What is peculiar to modern Islam so far as conceptions of and contestations over religious authority are concerned? These are among the questions this seminar seeks to examine.

title: Linguistic Semantics
reviews: Do it! Not too much work but a very cool discussion based class.

It's a good course and you learn a lot. My two main criticisms are: (1) there's no written outline, or PowerPoint slides, to go along with the lecture, which means that if you lose focus for a bit it can be somewhat hard to regain it and know what's going on; (2) the main textbook, while very clear and interesting, jumps straight into the mechanics of doing formal semantics with relatively little immediate theoretical justification for the approach taken. Things do eventually pretty much get explained, and after spending a little over half the class on the textbook we read some papers covering aspects of language the approach we had learned about could not, by itself, fully explain, so this is kind of a minor quibble about the way things were ordered.

This is an excellent course. In the first part, we built up, using the Heim & Kratzer textbook, (part of) a formal theory of semantics that represents natural-language meaning by means of an algebraic formalism using functions. In the second part of the course, we examined other aspects of natural-language meaning besides literal truth-conditional meaning, such as Gricean reasoning, vagueness, and quantifier domain restriction. As usual, Prof. Williams presented the material in a very interesting way, and he is very kind, helpful, approachable, and eager to clarify any doubts you may have. (Of course, before taking this course, you should at least suspect that you'll be interested in the material?it's probably not for absolutely everyone.) Note: the philosophy-of-language papers in the second half of the course can seriously take a while to read and understand adequately, and are different from "mainstream" linguistics papers, so make sure to set aside enough time for them.
You should take this course if you are good at logic, philosophy and math. Otherwise, it might be a bit hard.
prereqs: LIN 213 or Permission Of Instructor. LIN 213 or equivalent preparation in syntax required..
descrip: An introduction to central issues and leading theories of linguistic semantics for natural languages. Analysis of specific linguistic phenomena (including: anaphora, quantification, and tenses) will be used to illustrate the interaction of syntax and semantics, the relation between language and the world, and the role of linguistic meaning in communication and understanding.

title: Analysis I: Fourier Series and Partial Differential Equations
reviews: If you are interested in mathematics, take this class. Fourier analysis is a cool subject with cool applications!
It's a great course. Professor Stein does a really good job at teaching it. It's also quite intense.
It's not an easy course, but it's worth taking if you have any interest in analysis.
Read ahead of time!
Really enjoyed this course, by far my favorite of the semester.
Stein is amazing! If you can take a class with him, you should!
Strongly recommend.
Take this course if Stein is teaching it, and if you are interested in this kind of math.
The class taught by Stein is very well run. Take it if you have any interest in analysis.

This is a very well-taught and interesting course that I would recommend to anyone with an interest in mathematics, and to anyone without an interest in mathematics. The former group will enjoy it, and the latter will gain an interest in mathematics by taking the course.
This is an excellent course that combines pure and applied mathematics.

This was a great course - the level of rigor versus application seemed to be just right, perhaps between 215 and 203. Stein is a great teacher who doesn't go too fast and is great at explaining the concepts. I don't know if he'll be teaching it in the future though.

Try to take the course with Professor Stein, if he is still teaching it. Read the textbook regularly and keep up with lectures, and you will have no problems. Also start on problem sets early if possible and go to problem sessions because some of the problems need special tricks that may not really be possible to figure out if you have not seen them before.
if you think you might enjoy it, take it.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or consent of instructor..
descrip: Basic facts about Fourier series, Fourier transforms, and applications to the classical partial differential equations will be covered. Also Fast Fourier Transforms, finite Fourier series, Dirichlet characters, and applications to properties of primes.

title: Introduction to High-Energy Physics
reviews: Langacker's probably better than Tully, but not by a lot. In any case, expect to supplement this course if you really want to understand the concepts.
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest. Course also covers concepts in experimental tools and techniques.

title: Modern Worlds of Islam
descrip: A survey of political, intellectual, social and cultural worlds of Islam, with emphasis on the Middle East and North Africa, from the 18th century up to the present. The course covers a range of topics: the rise and spread of Islam; the establishment and expansion of Islamic civilization; imperial state formation and governance; transformations of Islamic societies, cultures and legal traditions; intellectual currents and religious practice; colonialism and imperialism; the rise of nation-states; nationalism and other political ideologies; and cultural politics in the context of globalization.

title: Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Beware of the end of term presentation. Know your topic inside and out because Professor Loo will ask thoughtful questions one after another until she exhausts either your knowledge or hers on the subject. Usually, it will be you who comes up short and it's not fun.
Go to office hours.
I took this instead of MAE 324 because it didn't fit in my schedule. I really regret this. MSE 301 assumes you have a chem background. The class is basically memorized a lot of unrelated facts.
I would recommend this to students who are interested in more atomic materials properties.
If you're not an engineer, be prepared to be up against a room full of them. Be prepared to have coffee. Be prepared to go to office hours. Be prepared to be confused.
Take it if you are interested in chemistry.
Take it to see if you're interested in MSE or not.
Take it!

This is a well taught and well organized course. Professor Loo is very nice and easy to talk to if you need some extra help. The only downside is that because it covers many different areas, it doesn't go into too much depth on any one subject. But I still thought the material was pretty interesting.

When she tells you that you don't have to memorize anything for the exams, that is not true. It isn't a huge amount, but be forewarned and consider the type of stuff you would have to have memorized to do the practice exams.
prereqs: Calculus, physics and chemistry. Course will expect some level of organic chemistry; students to carry out some basic derivation of equations. Freshmen should speak with course instructor for approval to enroll..
descrip: An introduction to the structure and properties of important current and future materials, including metals, semiconductors and polymers. Emphasis will be placed on the phase behavior and processing of materials, and how structure in these materials impact their macroscopic physical, electrical, and thermal properties.

title: Advanced Research Methods
prereqs: SOC 300.
descrip: Designed as an extension of SOC 300, this course will be of particular help to students interested in questions of research design. Students will gain greater proficiency in deploying data, in using case studies more effectively in their research, and in writing up the results of a research study.

title: Imagining Other Worlds
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in engineering, community service, or engineering education!!
Great class to take.
really nice, fun course, you get to work with your hands and complete fun projects. pizza parties!
very good class
prereqs: EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: African Development and Globalization
descrip: Africa today represents less than 2% of the world's GDP. The legacy of colonial rule has undoubtedly contributed to a slowdown in the international competitiveness of Africa. However, there are internal factors as well. Today, many countries are progressively shifting from a US-EU-Africa paradigm, to one that includes a larger proportion of alternative investors from the Middle-East, India, and China. This seminar will focus on: the effect of the legacy of complex political intricacies and the ways in which Africa engages the world; and how African countries face and anticipate the challenges of globalization.

title: Principles of Macromolecular Structure: Protein Folding, Structure and Design
reviews: A great course for someone who wants a concise overview of the whole field.
Good survey of of principles in macromolecular structure. Challenging but not over your head.

Honestly, this is a really good class for both people who are going to be doing a lot of research in the area as well as those with a general interest. Both types of people can gain a lot from the class. And Prof. Hecht is a really engaging and nice professor to take a class with.
I strongly recommend this course, it is one of my favorite courses I have taken at Princeton.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning more about proteins and de novo protein design.  In addition to being very interesting, this course was also laid back and relatively stress-free.  You won't regret taking it.
If you are interested in proteins, this the best course you can take.  It is both well-designed and highly interesting.
If you want to do anything related to proteins i.e. protein folding or protein design, take this course.
It's a very good course. I recommend you have a try at the first few classes.
No advice, it's a pretty straight forward class.
One of the best classes at Princeton.
Studying is important - it's a pretty self-motivated class setup.
Take It!
Take it if you are awesome and love biochemistry and chemistry
Take it if you have interest in protein structure.  The scope of the course is not very broad, but the discussion is very in depth.
Take it!
Take this! One of the best classes I've ever taken at Princeton. Hecht is smart but clear and funny, as well as tests and grades very fairly. I could not ask for more.

This class was pretty easy. As long as you do all the reading and stay awake, it is hard to do poorly in it. It was also pretty interesting, and I'll admit I learned a lot about protein biology that I did not know before.

This is probably one of my favorite classes at Princeton. The class was taught in a way such that it was about understanding and not memorizing. I learned a great amount of information on proteins and had fun doing so.
You really hit on a lot of issues surrounding protein folding, and you will be sure to learn a lot about this topic.
great course
descrip: This course will be taught from the scientific literature. We will begin the semester with several classic papers on protein folding. As the semester progresses, we will read about protein structure, stability, and folding pathways. The latter part of the semester will focus on recent papers describing new research aimed toward the construction of novel proteins from "scratch." These papers will cover topics ranging from evolution in vitro to computational and rational design. The course will end by discussing the possibility of creating artificial proteomes in the laboratory, and further steps toward synthetic biology.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, examination, or other evidence of accomplishment will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: Take it seriously.  Read all the papers carefully and come to class prepared.  Especially if you want to pass the general.
descrip: Macro implications of micro imperfections. The "cleansing" effect of recessions and the impact of allocative versus aggregate shocks. Recent models of consumption and empirical tests of risk-sharing. How the distribution of income or wealth affects aggregate growth and fluctuations. Role of imperfect credit markets, distributional conflict and political economy. Endogenous, skill-biased, technological change and human capital accumulation; implications for growth and social mobility.

title: Film as Medium
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy
descrip: Methods for empirical and theoretical analysis of markets composed of productive enterprises and their customers are studied. Analyses are applied to modern market structures and practices, and public policy towards them. Topics include the roles of technology and information, the structure of firms, modes of interfirm competition, determination of price, quality, and R & D investment, and criteria for government intervention.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
reviews: Excellent course - definitely take it.
I mean, it's required for certificate students...But don't think it's just gonna be a course just for fun like I was told..
I would definitely take it if you love performing.
If you are serious about chamber music and are willing to commit outside hours to rehearsal, then absolutely take this class.
If you can, take this!!
If you need an LA, take it! It is definitely a lot of work and you will definitely be challenged a lot, but you emerge out of it not only a better chamber musician but also a better musician.
If you're at all interested in a performance course, this is the one to take.  Make the most of it!
If you're considering auditioning for this class, do it. It's well worth it!
It is hard -- working closely with 3 other people, as one will with a quartet, is a very different experience from the usual class one takes at Princeton, but I think a worthwhile one.
TAKE THIS CLASS, it's awesome.
The Brentano Quartet is amazing. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! It's so much fun! (Though make sure your group is going to be dedicated, otherwise it can get really frustrating...)
The coaching sessions are superb.

This class is a great way to learn about and develop your chamber music skills, and the best way to take advantage of it is to rehearse a lot outside of the class to really internalize the instructor's advice.  I strongly recommend it but wouldn't recommend it to someone who is looking for an easy 5th class because that person will not ultimately benefit.
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions will be held on Tuesday, November 16, 2010, 6:00 - 9:00 p.m. in Room 105, Woolworth Center. Only complete groups may audition. No exceptions will be made for students abroad or absent for any other reason. Students will be allowed to receive credit for the course twice and to audit the course only once. (Signup sheet is on the Bulletin Board near Room 101 Woolworth.) Contact Gregory D. Smith (609) 258-6078 or gsmith@princeton.edu for further details..
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Latin American Neobaroques: Literature, Philosophy, Politics.
descrip: Departing from a brief review of central concepts about the "barroco de Indias," this course explores the idea of the neobaroque (up to the neobarroso) in Latin America as an aesthetic, historical, political, and philosophical idea; themes include poetics, desire, fetish, coloniality, empire, and philosophies of history. Authors may include Carpentier, Lezama Lima, Haroldo de Campos, Cabrera Infante, Sarduy, Perlongher, Irlemar Chiampi, Benjamin, Lacan, Deleuze, Marx. Readings in Spanish, English, Portuguese.

title: Sociology of Religion (Half-Term)
descrip: The seminar is devoted to discussing selected readings in the Sociology of Religion. Topics include religious practice, discourse and values, selves, communities, gender, race, pluralism, and markets.

title: Born in the U.S.A.: Culture and Reproduction in Modern America
reviews: Definitely take this course, you learn more than any other class on campus and it is super engaging and fun.

Don't be afraid to speak up in class, even if you don't think you have the most informed voice. I was really intimidated by my classmates' experience speaking on similar issues around campus and I let it silence me but I do think I would have been able to contribute more if I hadn't been so afraid.

I strongly recommend this class to every Princeton student. Reproduction is a vital part to living. It is frightening that WOM 420 is one of the few classes at Princeton that discusses childbirth, menstruation, contraception, etc. It is important for students to think about such important topics in an academic setting. Professor Armstrong is a wonderful teacher with a strong syllabus.
If they are interested in the subject material, I would definitely recommend it.
Take it! But go into it sociologically or else you will get overwhelmed by the sheer amount of  biological and historical context.
Take this class.  Professor Armstrong will make it great!
Take this course, if you are engaged in the readings and discussions you will love it
This class is excellent. Be prepared to express your opinion in class. Do your assignments early. Don't not hand in things late. Enjoy!
This is a very interesting course that requires a lot of participation and an interest in the topic.
it is a great course to take as the science requirement for the GSS certificate or just for fun.
take it! it's great! also, you don't have to do all of the readings.
prereqs: A prior course in sociology or anthropology will be helpful, but is not required..
descrip: Reproduction is a basic biological process, as well as a fundamental one for all societies. While the biology of human reproduction is universal across time and place, cultural norms and social institutions powerfully inflect and shape the experience of pregnancy and childbirth in every society. This course investigates the history and sociology of reproduction, focusing on the contemporary United States, but with an eye towards other societies for comparison. How, why, and for whom does birth matter? How do reproductive practices reflect gender, race, and class? The course examines the culture, politics, and economics of reproduction.

title: Topics in International Relations - Secularism, Religion and Politics
descrip: The enduring presence of religion is one of the most intriguing characteristics of modern politics. A range of factors including the pluralization of societies, questioning of Enlightenment assumptions about religion and secularism, and a sense of urgency among policymakers in a post-9/11 world have set in motion a re-evaluation of long-standing research programs based on the assumption that religion is easily defined and will decline or disappear. This seminar on secularism, religion, and the politics of modernity is part of this re-evaluation.

title: Readings in Chinese Literature
descrip: Genre and Tradition in Early Medieval China: An analysis of the formation and canonization of the Chinese literary tradition from the perspective of the origin and development of genre classification. In addition to the major works of genre taxonomies (Wenxuan, Wenxin diaolong, lost anthologies, library catalogues), readings include early medieval essays, letters, poems, prefaces, etc. that implicitly or explicitly reveal the distinction of genres in the practice of literary writing, criticism, and history. Functional knowledge of classical and modern Chinese is required.

title: Portuguese in Context: Studies in Language and Style
reviews: If you are interested in Portuguese, this is a good bridge from 100 to 300 level course work. Megwen is wonderful and the material is, for the most part, interesting.
Portuguese is really fun at Princeton, lots of new Brazil options too that are opened up if you have Portuguese language.
do it!
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: German Intellectual History - German Concepts of "Bildung" and Science
reviews: This may seem like it is an obscure topic in Germany, but it is a part of all of the classic authors. I would encourage not just those interested in German intellectual history, but also literature majors to take part in this class.
descrip: This seminar will study representative German texts (1750 to 2010) that deal with 'self-formation' and 'self-cultivation' ('Bildung'). These concepts not only formulate educational ideals and ideas about schooling and educational institutions but also function as articulations of individuality and its place in society, about specialization and division of labour, vocations and professions, culture and cultural sciences, and about the freedom and political activities of educated citizens. The seminar will focus on this diagnostic quality of concepts of 'self-formation' for understanding problems of the development of German society.

title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Aizenman is a pretty good physics teacher, but you do have to appreciate that he sometimes approaches things from a mathematical point of view. After all though, quantum mechanics is a lot of math.
Aizenman means well but he is terrible at lecturing. Just read the book.
Aizenman's lectures were often hard to follow so it might help to read the textbook beforehand
Aizenmann is not the greatest lecturer.
Be prepared for the fairly intense workload (though less than 205!)
Be prepared to learn everything on your own.
Definitely take this course if you want an introduction to quantum, or even if you just like physics.

Don't take it if you're a math major who doesn't know much about Physics, but interested in quantum mechanics. You'd be better off reading a book. Take it if you're a Physics major, or if you don't know much math.
Griffith's treatment of Dirac's notation left some of us quite confused. I'd recommend Shankar for that.
If the course is structured differently, then take it for sure.  Regardless of the quality of the course, quantum is something everyone should learn about so take the course anyway.
If they took 207 before, this is even more amzing.

If you are a physics major, you basically have to take this course. If not, you have a choice, but make sure when you sit in on the first few lectures that you have a good sense of how the professor teaches and if he conveys information in an understandable way to you. If this is not the case, the lectures will basically be a waste and you will be teaching yourself the material, so be aware of that. That said, you do learn the fundamentals of quantum mechanics in this course.

If you are a physics major, you have to take this course whether you like it or not.  Quantum mechanics is a very interesting subject, so I recommend taking it whether or not you are a physics major.  Nevertheless, I must warn you that Aizenman was not the best of teachers (brilliant physicist, just didn't teach well).  I always hear views to the contrary from MAT 317 students, who say he is excellent as a math teacher, but I think most in PHY 208 would agree that he is not a great physics teacher.  Hopefully, someone else will be teaching this next year.  If so, definitely take it.  Still take it if Aizenman is teaching it, but be prepared to learn mostly from the book, not lectures.
If you have an interest in the subject and are prepared to do a lot of work on your own, it's worth it.
If you take it with Aizenman, you will be learning out of the book (which happens to be very good). Take it if you need to, or if you have a very strong interest in QM.
If you're physics, you have to take this; not many others take this course 'just for fun', I think.
Make sure you do the readings.  Lectures are optional.

Overall, I enjoyed this course, mostly because I found the material more exciting than in any other physics course I had taken. Lectures with Aizenman tended to be quite disorganized, though I think he genuinely did care about students being engaged. The textbook (Griffiths), however, was accessible and engaging. If you are taking this course, you are probably planning to be a physics/astro major and don't have much choice, so do your best to enjoy. But be warned - Aizenman seems to curve more harshly than most professors in the physics department, so getting a C is far from inconceivable if you don't work hard.

Quantum Mechanics is a fascinating subject, but if you take it with Aizenman, be prepared to get a pretty low grade...he curved the average on the midterm exam to a C . He's also not a very good lecturer, but the book (Griffiths) is pretty good, so you can just learn from that.

Since it is a required course, you need to take it. It is much easier than 205. The problem sets are doable and are more meaningful. The book is great, though the lectures are at times hard to understand. If you are going to take it, definitely read the book.
Take it if you are interested in physics at all. Quantum Mechanics is a really fascinating subject and is quite elegantly formulated. Really great subject
Take it if you are interested in quantum mechanics
Take it if you're interested in pursuing physics or astrophysics.

Take it, but don't expect a revolution in thought...if you want to be BLOWN AWAY by the SHEER BEAUTY and MYSTERIOUS POWER of the UNIVERSE then you should have learned about quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics in INTEGRATED SCIENCE!!!
Take the class if you are interested in QM.
Take this course if you are interested to know real quantum mechanics!
The concluding material from the last two chapters was most interesting, so if you make it through the rest of the course, the end is worth it.

The material in Quantum Mechanics is very, very interesting. It involves a lot of math, though (as with all Physics). If there's a good lecturer, this will probably be an excellent class. The textbook, Griffiths, is amazingly good.
This is a good introduction into quantum mechanics.

Well, as it's required for physics majors, they don't have much choice about it. As for the others, I feel that it's not the best course if you just want to learn about QM--probably a more theoretical course would serve them better.
You would learn the bare bones of quantum mechanics pretty well.
would recommend for students who wish to learn more about fundamental physics
prereqs: MAT 204 or MAT 217 and PHY 205 or PHY 207. If PHY 104, PHY 106, or ISC 234 have not been completed, one of them must be taken concurrently..
descrip: This is the Physics Department's introductory quantum mechanics course. Its intent is to present the subject in a fashion that will allow both mastery of its conceptual basis and techniques and appreciation of the excitement inherent in looking at the world in a profoundly new way. Topics to be covered include: state functions and the probability interpretation, the Schroedinger equation, uncertainty principle, the eigenvalue problem, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and the hydrogen atom.

title: Neuroscience and Everyday Life
reviews: Absolutely take the class, I couldn't recommend it more highly.
Definitely take this class!

Definitely take this course if you are a non-science major searching for an engaging ST. It is a challenge at times because there is a lot material BUT all the TAs are helpful and there are so many resources. I found that I have really learned so much that has carried out into my daily life. Also, Professor Wang is amazing!

Do the readings, if not for your performance in the class, then because they're super interesting. Get to know the teachers and lab instructors - they're super smart and have really interesting perspectives. Get the meat of your lab reports done early; that way, if you have questions you will have time to ask questions.
Helps you understand so much in every day life.
I would encourage him/her to take it.
I would not recommend as a distribution requirement filler. It is a good class but if you're looking for a light workload in the sciences and are not a science type, it's not the class for you.
I would recommend gong to lab with a very good idea of what you are doing because  it can otherwise be frustrating.
I would say absolutely take this class. Best class I've taken at Princeton so far.
If you are a humanities student in need of an ST, or even if you just have an interest in neuroscience but are intimidated by the upper level classes, it's a great course.
If you are considering this course as a humanities major, I would recommend it because it is requires no background knowledge.
If you are looking for a general introduction to neuroscience, this is a great choice of course. The professors and lab instructors are top notch, and the material is highly relevant.

If you area humanities major looking for an easy ST, this is a good course to take. The lectures can be almost intolerably boring at times, but on the whole the course material is interesting and easy to understand.

If you chose to take this course and find yourself thinking that it's way too mechanical and that's not what you signed up for, stick with it. The lectures, labs, materials only get better as time goes by. And in the end, you'll be glad you took in a little science too.
It is not too difficult and a good ST if you need the distribution requirement.  It is also interesting as an introduction to the subject of neuroscience.
Make sure to go to every lecture. Don't be afraid to ask questions about the labs.

Make sure you ask questions if you don't understand something.  Know that while this is a very interesting class, it is not an easy PDF because there is a lot of work weekly and studying for exams takes a long time.
Pay attention in lecture, and read over Wang's notes (he posts them on Blackboard!!) before exams.  Exams are easy, and this is easily the most interesting class I've taken at Princeton.
TAKE IT! Cannot emphasize this enough. You will learn a lot about yourself and others as humans! Super interesting and fun as well.
Take it pass/fail!
Take it!
Take it!!! even if you are BSE try to get in this class
Take it, and go to lectures. They are the best part of the course.
Take this course! It is fun, interesting, engaging, and a super-easy way to get an ST under your belt.

Take this course.  You will find yourself reading material because you want to, not because you have to.  Come to every class so as not to miss the opportunity to enjoy Professor Wang's fabulous lectures.  If you are curious, then you will succeed and walk away from this class with a better understanding of the world around you.
This class could be interesting to anyone, and most people found it pretty easy.  Personally, I'm very bad at science so just PDF-ed it, but found it fascinating and am glad to have taken the course.
This is a great ST for social science / humanities students.
relatively easy course, probably one of the easier you'll find at Princeton. definitely interesting and so worth the time.
descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-science majors with classical and modern neuroscience. Lectures will give an overview at levels ranging from molecular signaling to cognitive science with a focus on the neuroscience of everyday life, from the general (love, memory, and personality) to the particular (jet lag, autism, and weight loss). The laboratory will offer hands-on experience in recording signals from single neurons, examining neural structures, and analysis of whole-brain functional brain imaging data.

title: Sociology of Gender
descrip: How does gender structure social relations? Which social processes create and reinforce gender difference and inequality? This course approaches these questions by introducing the sociological understanding of gender as a multilevel social structure. It then uses this theoretical framework to consider how gender, which often hides behind the "common sense" routine of daily life, structures individual identities, social interactions, social institutions (e.g. the workplace, the family, the state), social networks, and violence. It concludes with a discussion of the implications of sociological research for the future of gender inequality.

title: Introduction to Statistics for Biology
prereqs: MAT 104, or equivalent, or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to statistical models, methods, and concepts with a particular focus on applications in biology. Real data sets will be analyzed using a statistical software package in order to gain an understanding of how statistics is used in practice. Topics to be covered include probability, experimental design, point estimation, hypothesis testing, Bayesian statistics, and the application of these topics to modern biological studies.

title: Economic Experience in Cultural Context: The Anthropology of Wealth, Needs, and Wants
reviews: I would highly recommend this course as it really opens you up to thinking about economics from an entirely different frame of reference.

Take the course with an open mind. You will enter with preconceived notions of what constitutes a gift, what constitutes culture, etc. and many of them will be challenged. Allow yourself to be proven wrong and you will learn a lot more than you ever expected.
great class
descrip: This course explores the social and cultural contexts of economic experience in the US and around the world. It considers how the consumption, production, and circulation of goods--today and in times past--become invested with personal and collective meanings. It pays special attention to symbolic and political dimensions of work, property (material, intellectual, and cultural), wealth, and "taste" (i.e., needs and wants). Additionally, course participants do a bit of anthropological fieldwork by learning to draw everyday experiences systematically into conversation with more familiar academic sources.

title: Shooting the Enemy in Non-Fiction Cinema
prereqs: Taught in English, but some materials may be only available in Portuguese or Spanish. Knowledge of these languages is helpful, but not required..
descrip: Among the questions that define the nature of nonfiction film, one of the principal ones is the question of responsibility towards those one wants to film. Documentaries about the "enemy" or the "adversary" constitute the most extreme manifestation of this problem, and can therefore be seen as the most radical testing ground for nonfiction film. This seminar will explore the dilemmas faced by documentary filmmakers who choose to represent the enemy, be it a war enemy, a class antagonist, a political opponent, a social monster, a dictator, a torturer, or an ambivalent friend.

title: European Politics and Society in the 20th Century
reviews: A little too much repetition in each lecture and precept, but the material is pretty compelling.

Although it is definitely possible to do quite well without doing all the readings, I would suggest that the student be prepared to do quite a bit of weekly reading; otherwise, the lectures seem a bit shallow.

Definitely take it if you are interested, but be warned this is a very fast-paced course! If you want depth in a certain topic that is covered in the course (and nothing else), stay clear - and look out for a topic-specific course. You must be prepared to take one step back from the close examination, whether political or historical, that you've been used to - it's not only about rote memorization of dates etc., but ALL about comparing trends, understanding the origins and trajectories of predominant ideologies, political thoughts, and developments of the major political systems of the era. If you're up for it, then by all means, take it! You're in with a great, caring professor and lots of intellectually stimulating reading! :)
Don't take this course unless you need it for EPS - even with that, think about it. It's really a waste of time if you know a lot about Europe already. really.
I would not recommend taking this course unless one is planning to pursue the Contemporary European Politics and Society certificate.
I would recommend that he/she does all the readings.
I would suggest taking this class only if no other reading heavy courses are in the same semester.
I would suggest this course only to someone with a background in this material.

On balance, the course is worth taking. The main upside is that you learn a ton through the readings, if not almost entirely through them. The lectures vary a great deal in quality; Prof. Mueller's are often the best organized and most stimulating. Don't expect too much from the precept discussions, though. Contentwise, there are some gaps to be mindful of; the 68-era protest movements, for example, are not addressed at all, while some readings are a bit one-sided in perspective.
Precept was very useful.
Strongly recommend for those interested in European politics and society.
Take it.
Take the course if and only if you would want to do the readings.
Take this seriously, otherwise you will fail.
This is a great way to begin the certificate program and an interesting course.
really take note of what the events and theories represent theoretically; the exam is more theoretic than about specific events.
descrip: The course aims to cover the critical developments of twentieth-century Europe and the consolidation of democracy in European countries. It will deal with the legacy of the two world wars, Nazism, Stalinism, the Cold War, the legacy of colonialism and decolonization, the birth and development of the European Community, the development of the welfare state, the problems confronting the European Union (immigration, enlargement, political institutions, military role), and the varieties of democratic institutions in Europe.

title: Optimal Control and Estimation
reviews: Much of this class is geared towards making you an effective researcher. As such problems are not as well defined as you are used to. I'm sure this is very frustrating for younger students. Very large commitment for a first-year student because it requires a lot of time to do well and understand the material.
