very complete specific class, needed for any control major
descrip: An introduction to stochastic optimal control theory and application. It reviews mathematical foundations and explores parametric optimization, conditions for optimality, constraints and singular control, numerical optimization, and neighboring-optimal solutions. Least-squares estimates, propagation of state estimates and uncertainty, and optimal filters and predictors; optimal control in the presence of uncertainty; certainty equivalence and the linear-quadratic-Gaussian regulator problem; frequency-domain solutions for linear multivariable systems; and robustness of closed-loop control are all studied.

title: Advanced Programming Techniques
reviews: A must if you want to go into technology/programming in your career. A very practical/interesting class in general.
Choose your project group members carefully.  Make sure you have a lot of time to devote to this course.
Classes were boring and the assignments were easy. Final project was fun though.
Come in with a plan for your group project, and with people you want to do it with. But don't be overly ambitious! Know the potential issues with the technologies you want to use beforehand.
Definitely take this course, and be sure to start thinking ahead of time about the project.

I found the course to be a bit dry at times, but I'd imagine someone who hasn't had much programming exposure before would really benefit from this course.  It could be a little boring if you've seen a lot of the stuff already though, but in that case I might still take it to work on a really interesting final project.  Also Dondero was an impressive and super nice lecturer, as was to be expected.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn how to program in the real world.  The final project is one of the best experiences I've had at Princeton, and I learned so much throughout the semester.  It's important to have a good group to do the project with, so it's not a bad idea to sign up for the class with a few friends so that you can work together.
If you have survived 217 and 226, do take 333, it's a lot of fun!
If you're a COS major thinking at all about working in industry, you've got to take 333, but be sure to have your project group formed beforehand.
Moral of the story-Dondero is an awesome teacher.
Pick a good team.

Probably a good course to take. You learn a bit about a loooot of different stuff; you get practice developing a somewhat substantial project with a group of people; it's interesting and probably useful. Just one thing: ALL of the coding is collaborative. If you like this, great; if not (like me), it can be frustrating, though learning to adapt to this is important too.
Start project early!
Take it and really use it to explore your creative side.  Awesome class if you're even remotely interested in entrepreneurship.
Take it, and make sure you like coding, because the team project is an endless coding session.
Take it.  Also, although I'm sure Kernighan was good, I'd still request Dondero.  While 217 may be his domain, I feel 333 should become his new thing.
Take it.  Everyone that can should take this class.  Don't worry if Kernighan isn't teaching it; Dondero is just as good.
Take the class with friends, and don't choose a project that requires a large user base.

The best way to get a systems course done for more theory based people. It can be fairly interesting and is certainly useful for real life. Latter lectures can sometimes not be interesting or relevant but attendance is mandatory.
The final project is a lot (A LOT) of work, but if you're truly interested, you will love this course.

The project is a great experience. Princeton CS tends toward the theoretical side, so if you want something a bit more "real," this course is an absolute must. Invest yourself deeply in the project and you'll get a ton out of it. Lectures weren't too useful, but mandatory. Also be careful who you work with for the project -- be very wary of non-CS majors (honestly, they don't your knoweldge of coding or, more importantly, your passion for it), and be wary of students that haven't done 226 and 217 ahead of this course.

This is an excellent course.  At the end of it I really felt like I had some understanding of what it would be like to pursue computer science in the real world.  Some people were hesitant about taking this course without a group of friends, but I took it knowing nobody else in the class and by the end had gotten close to a group of students I hadn't known before.  I good experience.
This is important: FIND GOOD ASSIGNMENT PARTNERS.
Well-taught if a bit sporadic - worth taking for the experience with languages and the group project.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term) - Environmental and Material Sciences
prereqs: Course open to graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed sufficient reseach to begin writing an article for publication..
descrip: Writing workshop for students who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One three-hour seminar.

title: Analytical Methods in Algebraic Geometry
descrip: A continuation from Fall 2010.

title: Economics of Crime and Crime Control
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 and MAT 102 or MAT 103.
descrip: Covers the economic analysis of crime and the criminal justice system, including criminal behavior, law enforcement, crime prevention, sentencing, capital punishment, organized crime, and the war on drugs. The primary goal of the course is to develop economic thinking to gain insight into the behavior of the key actors (potential offenders, potential victims, and the many parts of the enforcement system) that determine crime outcomes. The last third of the course analyzes and evaluates policies to prevent or reduce crime.

title: Problems in Latin Literature - Seneca "Moral Epistles"
descrip: The seminar will address the literary, philosophical, and political dimensions of Seneca's "Moral Epistles", which were written near the end of his life after his withdrawal from Nero's court.

title: Domestic Politics
descrip: An introduction to the political analysis of policy making in the American setting. The course includes theoretical and empirical analyses of political institutions, including executives, legislatures, and bureaucracies. It also examines the political environment in which these institutions operate, with special attention given to the role of public opinion, interest groups, and elections.

title: Environmental Law and Moot Court
reviews: Helpful as a first introduction to environmental law.
If you are interested in law or environmental policy, this is a fun and interesting course.
Take the class. Readings are not too difficult. Written work is enjoyable. Overall an interesting class with a very good professor.

The course book "Introduction to Advocacy" was the most helpful book about how to conduct legal research and write legal documents I have ever found. If I had had this book in Constitutional Interpretations I would have done well. It very clearly explains how legal writing and research should be done, which I found lacking in other pre-law style classes at Princeton.
descrip: Examining the relationship between law and environmental policy, this course focuses on cases that have established policy principles. The first half of the seminar will be conducted using the Socratic method. The second half will allow students to reargue either the plaintiff or defendant position in a key case, which will be decided by the classroom jury.

title: Topics in Contemporary Architecture & Urbanism - Politics of the Building Envelope
prereqs: The methodology of research will be aimed to find resonances between envelope qualities, organisations and performances and political concerns. It will require the capacity of drawing and measuring as crucial tools for architectural theory, in an attempt to merge theory and technology. The seminar will be structured into 12 sessions, grouped in 6 weeks, with two sessions per week in which a series of case studies, will be collectively discussed through texts and drawings..
descrip: Seminar explores the building envelope as the intersection between environmental, iconographic and territorial concerns. As the limit between inside/outside, natural/artificial, private/public, the building envelope is a key political subject. By analyzing the building envelope, the course identifies a ground on which to re-empower the discipline as a transformative force in the reorganization of the contemporary ecologies of power.

title: Cyber Security
reviews: Although I did not find the lectures engaging, it was good to attend them to understand technical language employed in literature we had to read to do the final project
Don't procrastinate.
Easy class
For a non-ELE major, this course is more enjoyable if PDFed. Grading seems somewhat idiosyncratic. That said, for me it was a more appealing option than any other STX's.
Go for it - very interesting if you are interested in learning about cyber security. Its an intro level thing and not too technically detailed and theres no computer programming involved.
It's a decent class to PDF for an STX (or STN now, or whatever).  But don't expect to be ridiculously easy or interesting.
Its good for both BSE and AB students. It is not hard and the course work load is very reasonable.
Take the course, stick it out, and go to lecture.  It makes the homework and exams a piece of cake.  If you're interested, you can make it work.

This is an interesting and not too difficult course, and if you go to lecture and pay attention, it does not require much further studying and you can get a lot out of the class in terms of new information. (Suited for non-technical people)

Try to stay away, as it's not too easy for a non-ELE non-COS type. It's not too bad for a PDF, although I feel like you might get a lot more from other courses. Do the readings before lecture, although Prof Lee doesn't give a reading list, so you're pretty much on your own navigating through the two books to try to find where the material comes from.
prereqs: No prior security knowledge required. COS109/EGR109 or equivalent..
descrip: This course surveys the technology underlying secure transactions and safe interactions in a public Internet and wireless world. Topics include cyber security needs such as confidentiality, integrity, availability, access control, authorization, authentication, non-repudiation, trust, privacy and anonymity. Case studies are selected from e-commerce, denial of service attacks, viruses and worms, spam, e-voting, digital rights management, and cyber-terrorism. Related policy, social and economic issues are also discussed.

title: Senior Thesis - Resubmission
descrip: No description available

title: Research Seminar
reviews: Do research early on so you have comprehensive results to discuss at the end of this course.
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course will be 25% oral presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Violent Politics
reviews: Best course I've taken at Princeton.
Do the readings, and don't be too afraid of the cold calls - it's really not that bad. If you've taken any IR classes, you'll have a foundation for this class (there's a little bit of overlap).

Don't take it. Not worth your time - the lectures suck, the readings are too specific or overlap with too many other politics courses, and the midterm and final are graded really hard despite the overall lack of rigor in the rest of the course. Definitely don't take it.
Final was difficult
I bet in 2-3 years this course will be really good and so i would recommend it then.
I highly recommend to anyone interested not only in political violence, but in social studies in general.
I learned some interesting things in this course, but it has a lot of room for improvement.

If the small changes (I suggested) are made, then I would strong recommend. For now, I am more neutral given how hard the exams have been relative to time-limit and the other small challenges. Potential to be a great course though!
Interesting class if you're willing to do the work. Be prepared for what you're getting yourself into.

It can be a lot of work (reading-wise) but the course is really interesting, Shapiro's a great lecturer, and I feel like I learned a lot about research design and thinking that I wish I knew before I started by thesis.  If you're interested in violent politics/war/security TAKE THIS COURSE.
It's challenging but I found it really enjoyable.
Take it, but realize that its something of an oppressive regime that you can't use violent means against.
Take the class if you have any interest in politics, but be prepared to do work.

This class is fascinating, but be warned--there is a ridiculous amount of reading and the exams are insanely hard. Oh, and you get randomly called on in lecture, so you have to be there and have done the reading. That said, if you are prepared to do the work and not too attached to getting an A on the exams, you should take this class. The material is extremely interesting, and lectures are GREAT--Professor Shapiro is a very informative and fun lecturer, and you even get to watch clips from movies like The Princess Bride.
This class just needs a lot of restructuring. Not very organized, and not very undergraduate-friendly.

This class will teach you everything you want to know about political violence, but you better be willing to work for it. This is a hard class. Do the readings and take notes on them every week, same with lecture, and you'll be okay. But before you enroll make sure you're willing to devote the time.
if you interested in the material go for it. this is one of the best-designed politics classes ive taken.
prereqs: Freshman and sophomores may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: Governments have tremendous power over our lives and thus the competition over who controls them is always intense and often violent. This course will study various ways in which violence is used to political ends. The larger goal of the course is to understand the sources of violence in political competition and the conditions under which political disputes can be peacefully resolved. Specific forms of violence to be covered include assassination, civil war, ethnic conflict, insurgency, revolution, riots, terrorism, and war.

title: Econometric Applications
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of work
Class really worth taking--problem sets will take you a while, but you'll find yourself learning a lot of materials APPLICABLE to JP/Thesis research
Good course. Too bad you can't PDF it (so stressful). Helps so much with Junior paper (and potentially senior thesis).

I would say that there are two reasons to take any econometrics course. One is to practice the empirical methods and another is to understand why methods are used and what the flaws may be. I think that the second purpose requires practicing the empirical methods and this class will give you the opportunity to do that but you wil have to put some of your own work in as well. As the assignments don't always ask about the why, you have to be somewhat self motivated to read the textbook and understand why you are doing what you are doing.

If you're in the econ department, take this course. I know it gets a bad rap as useless from some people, but those people are the ones that dropped out after two weeks because the assignments are too long when we're still doing review. If you stick it out, it's worth your while and you'll become very competent at stata.
Take this course. It is a lot of work, but should not be optional for anyone interested in using statistics to answer tough questions about the world.

The grading in this course is harsh, there is a lot of work, and there isn't much feedback. This course will force you to analyze data and practice with STATA, but other than that you probably won't learn much.

This is the hardest class in the economics department that I've taken thus far (the other courses being the math-track core). Competition is cutthroat as generally the best students in the economics department self-select into this small class. As Dr. Watson insisted that each assignment be graded on a curve with a mean of 7, students had to go beyond the requirements of the problem set to get top marks.
This having been said, the problem sets were very good. They forced us to think critically about the data and the mathematical models,  and helped us to develop solid stata-programming skills. I really learned a lot from this class and feel that every economics major should be required to take it--in fact, making this course a requirement would help to combat the self-selection problem that makes it unnecessarily difficult in the first place. 
My only real qualm with this course is that the lectures for the first half of the semester were relatively boring as the syllabus required professor Watson to re-teach us what we had learned in ECO 312/302. The second half of the class was much better, as we moved on to new material.

Tough to get a good grade when everyone answers everything correctly. Make one mistake and you get penalized harshly as a result. Everyone in the class seemed to be so good at Stata/econometrics. 28 people dropped down to 20 by the middle of the course - the bottom 8 people left, but still only 35% A's were given. You will learn a lot though - I spent less time on my JP second semester than I did on a single 313 problem set because the analysis was so much easier for my JP.
Very, very useful class.
Work hard and you'll get so much out of the class.
watson not teaching it next year so irrelevant
prereqs: ECO 302 or ECO 312. Additional prerequisite: Calculus.
descrip: This course provides hands-on experience in the art and science of econometric analysis designed to help students to acquire and master the skills necessary to carry out their own empirical research in economics. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable economic models, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. A range of applications will be presented and discussed in class and on problem sets.

title: Integrated Building Systems
reviews: Don't take this during your thesis semester.
descrip: An introduction to building systems and the methods of construction used to realize design in built form. First half of the course will be an overview of the primary systems, materials and principals used in construction of buildings and the fabrication of elements, through lectures and accompanying lab sessions. The second half will be an explanation of the means by which information is communicated from designers to fabricators, current standards in the practice of architecture, and practice's relation to changes in methods of fabrication and project delivery.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Do it! Especially now that the homework and tests and being assigned at a reasonable level.
I think that this was a great course!  I would highly recommend it to any who are interested in learning Chinese at a high level.
I would only recommend this course for students who are serious about learning Chinese at a very high level.
prereqs: CHI 405 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Continued reading and discussion of scholarly writings on modern Chinese literature. This course also exposes students to the social issues China has faced in recent years, while discussing various aspects of contemporary Chinese society.

title: Oil to Ozone: Chemistry of the Environment
reviews: Do the readings! Remember that there is a difference between short-term memory and long-term memory. You need the former for in-class questions and the latter for the midterm.

I loved this class. Morel is hilarious and it isn't too much work. You learn a lot about basic environmental chemistry, which is interesting because many of the ideas are applicable to modern life (i.e. concepts such as global warming). The class is made up of mostly Chem majors and ChemE's but it's not super technical and the problem sets aren't too bad at all.
It's a great class!  Not too difficult, but a great introduction into environmental science.
it's a good course
take it for senior spring.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or equivalent. (Consult instructor.).
descrip: The chemical background of environmental issues. Topics include energy and fuels, greenhouse effect, ozone, air pollution, food production, pesticides, metals pollution, carcinogens and anti-oxidants.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Human Rights and the Rule of Law
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Computational Neuroscience
reviews: Definitely take, unless you don't have a strong grasp of modelling/differential equations.
Great for both computer scientists and biologists; really interesting course
It is a lot of work. The professor holds a high expectation of performance, be ready to put in a significant amount of work.
Take the class if you are interested in the subject and have at least a modest background in computation.

The actual math required for this class, which is not what's listed on the SCORE page, is dynamical systems analysis.  Either learn this on your own or maybe from MOL410 (I didn't take that class) before taking this course. Don't expect the professor (if it's Brody) to respond to your emails in a timely manner, or to be sympathetic to the fact that his poor email etiquette inconveniences you.

This course was very interesting. I did not have a good idea of what "computational neuroscience" was when I first signed up for the course. It is an interesting and quickly-growing field that tries to model certain activity patterns observed/predicted in neuroscience.

This is a great class, whether you are a neuroscientist, a biologist, a computer scientist, an electrical engineer, a mathematician or whatever. Class consists of presenting one paper for one class during the semester and then listening to other student's presentations. In the process you learn a lot about some of the seminal papers in computational neuroscience. Carlos is one of the best lecturers at Princeton. In general the course isn't hard but some fairly simple programming in MATLAB is required. Highly recommend. 5 stars. Would take again.
Very cool and modern material but it requires a broad range of mathematical concepts and there's no hand holding
prereqs: MOL 410 or basic linear algebra, probability, ordinary differential equations, and some programming experience, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Introduction to the biophysics of nerve cells and synapses, and the mathematics of neural networks. How can networks of neurons compute? How do we model and analyze data from neuroscientific experiments? Data from experiments running at Princeton will be used as examples (e.g., blowfly visual system, hippocampal slice, rodent prefrontal cortex). Each topic will have a lecture and a computer laboratory component.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Random Processes
descrip: (1) Wiener measure. (2) Stochastic differential equations. (3) Markov diffusion processes. (4) Linear theory of stationary processes. (5) Ergodicity, mixing, central limit theorem of processes, Gibbs random field. If time permits, the theory of products of random matrices and PDE with random coefficients will be discussed.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: A lot of work, but doable if you get involved with the material.

Although the precepts were great, the lectures and tests and quizzes were just so miserable that I don't think I can give this class a high score. The saving grace of this class is that the material is really interesting. And maybe Professor Niv will have learned from her mistakes by the time you take this class...
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it with this professor.
Don't take this class for fun, it's too much work if it's not a requirement.

Don't take this course unless a) you are pursuing the neuroscience certificate or b) there is a change in professor. If you end up taking the class with Professor Niv prepare for the lectures to be disorganized and for her to cover almost nothing. The onus will be on you to pick up HER slack and teach almost everything to yourself from the book. And she actually says that you will be responsible for all that is not covered in class. Whatever she doesn't cover (which is her own fault) she will let you figure out for yourself while she just moves on to the next topic.
I don't know what I gained or learned from this class. Take it, if you must for the neuroscience certificate. Just read the book and look over the lecture slides.
I personally did not enjoy this course as much as NEU258, but I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in neuroscience.

I really liked neuroscience up until I took this class. I think Yael Niv is an amazing teacher, and very helpful. I just thought that the quizzes were pretty unfair. Also, the amount of time outside class that we were expected to be "participating" was unfair. Besides going to lecture, precept, and studying for quizzes, tests, and precept quizzes we were expected to write questions and post responses to our classmates on a website. While it may seem like not a big deal, I felt a lot of pressure in doing this. I felt like my answers/questions would be judged by my classmates and so was hesitant to take part. MOST importantly, the questions asked during lecture (encouraged by the professor) were EXTREMELY distracting to the flow of the class. The questions were mostly irrelevant, and definitely unnecessary. I would have much rather heard the whole lecture from the professor than have to listen to classmates try to get participation points by coming up with meaningless questions.
I would definitely recommend this course to someone specifically interested in neuroscience. I would make sure they know it is completely different from NEU258

I would recommend this class for those pursuing the certificate. For people who are simply interested, they might enjoy this class, but I don't think it is significantly better than other neuro classes offered here.

If interested in neuroscience then take 258, since you might get a little lost in this one without the anatomical knowledge. Psych majors should be able to get by without 258, but may need to do outside readings. Not the most interesting option for this dept. category, but it was alright.
If you gotta take it, you gotta take it, but the course has some major problems.
Interesting and not super tough even if you haven't taken NEU 258.
It's a good class. Also, I'm not sure how she will approach "lecture participation"...
It's a very interesting EC. Well-taught, and likely to improve (I took it Prof. Niv's first year teaching it).
It's interesting.
Make sure you go to lecture and do the reading and you'll be fine.
Only take it if you want to get the Neuro certificate.
Take it if you're interested.
Take this course if you're interested in cognitive neuroscience, but be prepared for the lecture format: it's "interactive" and may not cover everything that's important.
The exams were a bit too easy.
There is a lot of little work to do in this class, mainly due to the precept responses and the quizzes.  It is open book midterm/final which is nice but the quizzes were not well designed.
This class helps understand cognitive neuroscience of every day life - it is very interesting and useful.
This course interesting and a great class to take after you get some of the basics from 258.
Try to participate as much as you can.
Yael Niv is a really great instructor - much better than the previous professor who taught this course from what I hear.
sdfs
very helpful as a foundational course for anybody interested in neuroscience
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention and selective perception, systems for short- and long-term memory, language, cerebral lateralization, motor control, executive functions of the frontal lobe, cognitive development and plasticity. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed.

title: Inventing Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Olmec Art
reviews: Definitely take this class if you're interested in the law and politics of art material distribution, Mesoamerican culture, or ancient art in general. Be ready to talk and participate.
Great course, definitely take it.
Great way to be involved with museum's collection.
I would hesitate to take this course if you are considering enrolling in it outside the confines of your department. But, if you want to talk to Professor Just about awesome/random stuff, take it!

I would recommend that you have some background in art history or archaeology, as one student who did not found adapting to the style of thinking and working used in the class very difficult.  Otherwise, if you are interested in the subject, I highly recommend it.

This course requires a lot of self-motivation and instruction when it comes to readings and scholarly work on the objects studied. That being said, it is an incredible opportunity to work with objects not on display at the museum.
We do not have many ancient American material culture courses in Princeton, and this is one of the few that could provide you this training.
prereqs: ART 267/LAS 267 or ART 268/LAS 268, or permission of the instructor. Spanish literacy preferred..
descrip: This course explores the ancient culture known today as Olmec, which flourished from 1500-600 B.C. Renowned for its monumental sculpture, fine pottery, and delicate jade carvings, many aspects of the Olmec remain enigmatic. In this course, we will delve deeply into what is and is not known about the Olmec, with a heavy focus on visual culture both as explanans and as explanandum. The course will include intensive study of original works of art, both in the collections at Princeton and in other area collections. Issues of authenticity, quality, and provenance related to these works will also be considered.

title: Environmental History
descrip: The course examines the processes of environmental change and the causes and effects of change. Class readings expose participants to different models and approaches to the study of environmental change. The class readings draw from different historical periods and different parts of the world, including Europe, Africa, the Americas, and Asia. The course critically assesses the paradigms and models underlying the analysis and description of environmental change and explores alternative ways of understanding and narrating environmental change.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
reviews: Definitely recommend, great course.
Do the readings!!!

Great Politics course.  Made me want to specialize in comparative politics as a Politics major.  Professor Roberts is an entertaining lecturer and Yanilda runs a great precept.  Do the work and you will be happy.
If one desires a demanding class with constant independent and group work, and a steady stream of information, then this is the perfect class to acquire a breadth of knowledge.

If you are looking for a good introduction to politics, this class is a great one to take. I would recommend, however, taking 220 or 210 first - these are more conventional and specific classes. That being said, 230 covered a lot of interesting and different material that encompassed a lot of varied topics in one course. Personally I really enjoyed it and would recommend it to any student.

If you're interested in democracy versus authoritarianism, democratic transitions, and voting and electoral systems, take this class. It doesn't move from country to country, but rather moves topically, like "Social Cleavages" or "The Modern State." If you're interested in a specific country though, I would just skip to a higher level politics class. To be honest, this intro class isn't really a great intro--I would just jump right into higher-level politics classes if you're interested in this kind of stuff.
It is an okay class if you want to learn more about comparative politics.

Love, love, love this class! I was thinking about concentrating in Politics before this course, and now I'm certain that I'm going to. The subject matter is really interesting, Roberts is a cool guy and a neat lecturer without being in-your-face, and Yanilda is a really engaging preceptor. If you're thinking of concentrating in Politics but aren't 100 percent sure, take this course!

Please, listen to me, take this class. I thought I was going to pdf this for an SA, and I ended up loving it so much that now I'm considering being a POL major. It is such a politics class about real world things that are going on, but there are also bits of game theory and logic and rigorous thinking that were delightful but not too hard(coming from a science major).It is very broad, it covers many ideas without going too deep, but this was enjoyable. There is a bit of busy work, but you'll learn to deal, it's not too bad. All in all, it was a significantly easy class. Take it.
Take it if you need it or have a definite interest in comparative politics (or want to know exactly what comparative politics is).
Take it.

Take the course if you are genuinely interested in the material.  Don't take it just for a politics class or something like that.  It is not an easy class but if you are interested in comparative politics, particularly in democratization and political development, it is great.
Take this course if Professor Roberts is teaching it.
Take this course if you are at all interested in politics- the things I learned in it are very interesting and useful.
Take this course if you're interested in specifically comparative politics, though there are more intereting politics courses out there if you don't know.
Take this course.
There are probably better comparative politics classes you could take, but this class does give you a solid foundation in theory... just be prepared to work pretty hard.
This class was interesting but it was a lot of work. Weekly blackboard posts, weekly research assignments AND weekly problem sets. It was a lot. But the material was interesting and relevant.

Very interesting subject matter. Professor Roberts was quite engaging and interesting. The course curriculum was not exactly what I was expecting when I came in (a survey of different countries). Instead, it discussed several themes (e.g. poverty, democratization, electoral systems) across different countries. Still, this was a bit intriguing, so I decided to remain in the class (unlike several people who dropped the first week).
go to lectures and you will do fine in the course.
descrip: This course surveys institutions of government and explores the role of government in economic and social affairs in developing as well as advanced industrial countries. The course also provides an introduction to the comparative method.

title: Theoretical Ecology
reviews: I would have enjoyed if I took this course as a freshman or sophomore. It was very simple but still quite a bit of (busy) work. For a quantitative MOL or ISC junior/senior, effort to usefulness ratio is too high. If you are MOL and looking to fulfill your EEB requirement, take another EEB class, perhaps one that focuses on reading papers.
If you are comfortable with math, take the class early on (freshman or sophomore year). As it stands, the course is fairly easy, albeit it covers some very interesting phenomena.
Not a great class to take senior spring, unless you have a strong background in calculus. Ties a lot of concepts in ecology together, but it is a very demanding course.
prereqs: There is no limit on graduate enrollment..
descrip: Current and classical theoretical issues in ecology and evolutionary biology. Emphasis will be on theories and concepts and on mathematical approaches. Topics will include population and community ecology, immunology and epidemiology, population genetics and evolutionary theory.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese II
reviews: Honestly if you don't know Chinese there will be a ton of work awaiting there, but I would not say Kanji takes a great portion of this class. IF you have an interest, it would not be bad to try sitting in this course.
Take it to be positively surprised!
the class is fairly different from 2nd and 3rd year. emphasis is on reading, so people with a kanji background will do well in this class. still, take it! it's great :)
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, writing, speaking and listening.

title: Sociological Theory
reviews: Best presentation of sociological theory throughout my entire Princeton career
Go to lecture and do the readings afterwards.  But seriously, go to lecture.
I would highly recommend this professor; maybe not so much the course for every one, but Camic is awesome.
I would recommend this class to fulfill a requirement. The professor and preceptor were very helpful.
If Camic teaches this again, jump on it.
If you're in soc, you'll have to take it.
If you're in the SOC dept, you must take this class. Otherwise, I'm not sure I would recommend it to just anyone.

If you're interested in learning something about these three sociologists, it's a good class, but if you're interesting in doing more than just memorizing a particular reading of their theories, you might be a bit disappointed.
It is probably best to start outlining the beliefs of the different theorists early on and start making the comparisons otherwise it can get very overwhelming as the tests near.
N/A
Not something I would normally take, but Camic is great and it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be.  It's a requirement, so you don't have too much of a choice, but don't dread it too much.
Only take this if you're a SOC major because the material is pretty dry but Camic does a great job of conveying it.
Required course, not that bad, but not that interesting.

Sadly, Professor Camic is not from Princeton, otherwise I would recommend you take his classes.  SOC 302 is required for all soc majors and could be interesting if you're trying to decide if soc is for you (altho lots of soc students find theory boring).
Social theory is always dry, not very interesting, and difficult to understand, but Professor Camic explains it fairly well.
Take it for a departmental, but otherwise make sure you're interested in the topic.
The course isnt necessarily the most enticing or enjoyable, but if you must take it (as a soc major) be sure to get Erin as a preceptor!

Took for departmental. Professor Camic is a good professor and explains things really clearly. I would advise paying attention during lecture, having questions for lecture and precept ready, and going to office hours.
camic is awesome and erin is an awesome teacher
camic was a great lecturer...made the material engaging
take it
prereqs: Soc 101.
descrip: This course seeks to provide a thorough understanding of the ideas of the three "classical" social thinkers whose work has been foundational for sociological analysis: Emile Durkheim, Karl Marx, and Max Weber. Class sessions will explore each thinker's major concepts, the larger arguments that he builds from the concepts, and the distinctive manner in which he proposes analyzing the social world.

title: Germany in the 19th and 20th Centuries
descrip: Discussions of the major controversies in the interpretation of modern German history. Was there a Jacobin movement in Germany? Did Germany follow a "peculiar path to modernity"? Other topics include 1848 as a social movement, the bases of German nationalism, Wilhelmine rule and the outbreak of war in 1914, the depression and the collapse of the Weimar Republic, the nature of the Nazi electorate and of the Nazi state, the Cold War and the division of Germany, Germany as "two states and one nation", and problems arising out of re-unification.

title: Topics in Music from 1400 to 1600 - Renaissance Music
descrip: Source studies, palaeography, textual criticism, mensual notation in music from the 14th to 16th centuries.

title: Reading Literature: Drama
reviews: Good class but beware if you're not a drama buff.
I really enjoyed this course.  If you are looking for an English class definitely consider this one.
I would definitely recommend this course because of the subject material and the professors.

If you are interested in theater or dramatic literature, and are interested in opening your mind to the many big-picture ways in which famous plays comment on life, society, the human condition, etc. TAKE THIS CLASS!! Great fun and a perfectly reasonable amount of work.
If you need/want to take an English course and you want something you'd enjoy, go for it. It's a good class and not too reading-heavy (unlike the rest of the English classes).
Only take this course if you are legitimately interested in English; don't try to use it as a cop out of an LA requirement, it certainly isn't.
Read all the plays, see all the plays, and listen to Bob in lecture. The plays are great and Bob is really knowledgeable.
Start exercises and papers early! Talk to Professor Sandberg if you have questions. Sketch outlines and plan ahead. Read everything on time!
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it if you like drama; don't take precept with the lecturer.
Take it if you're an English major only.
descrip: This course is designed to teach students how to read plays as literature written for performance. Key assumptions are that every act of reading is an act of interpretation, that a good reader of dramatic literature engages in an activity nearly identical to that of a good director or actor or designer, and that a reader might learn from theater practitioners how to make critical choices based on close reading and a knowledge of theatre history.

title: Saints and Sinners: Women and the Church in Colonial Spanish America
descrip: An introductory exploration of women's experience of and participation in the Catholic Church and colonial Christianity in Spanish America. Through primary sources, secondary readings, lectures, and discussion, we will look at women's roles in the processes of conquest and colonization; how conversion and religious change affected gender ideologies and gender relations within indigenous communities; women's daily encounters with the church and participation in devotional culture; and the ways women's complex relationships with the colonial church was shaped by race and social status.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in Chinese thought, including examination of some broad interpretations of intellectual development of China. A reading knowledge of Chinese or Japanese is required for the study of selected problems areas through seminar discussion, oral reports, and research papers.

title: Poetics - Poetry and Poetics of the Eighteenth-Century
descrip: A seminar in the poetry and poetics of the 18th century. We will give particular focus to the transformation at mid-century away from neoclassicism, asking questions about the figure of the poet in the culture, the situation of a "minor" poetry, the rise of poetic individualism and theories of the imagination, and the relation between poetry and the visual arts.

title: Seminar on Selected Topics in International Security and Qualitative Methods
descrip: The seminar focuses on selected topics in international security that have not been sufficiently covered in other courses and seminars offered by the department. These include topics such as power, military effectiveness, signaling and interstate communication, beliefs and emotions, the role of reputation etc. Each session, the group will discuss the evolution in a particular body of literature in the field, while placing the emphasis on issues such as conceptualization and measurement of key variables, case selection criteria, research strategy and execution.

title: Studies in Chinese Religions - Popular Religion
descrip: Critical examination of enduring and recent scholarship on popular Chinese religion, modernity, and ethnography. Designed for graduate students preparing general examinations or other work in Chinese religion.

title: Physics of the Universe - Introduction to Theoretical Cosmology
reviews: If you're interested in cosmology, this is an essential course to take.
This is an excellent class. It is very specific in terms of the contents. I would recommend taking it if you are interested to work in cosmology and extragalactic astrophysics.

This is an excellent course to take, taught by two pioneers in the field.  It presents an excellent opportunity to learn a great deal about cosmology, if you are willing to put in the time outside of class to supplement the material gone over in lecture and the assignments.  It also helps to have a strong background in QFT, GR and some Cosmology.
To get the most out of this course you'll want to have some background coming in, but if you're interested in the subject I'd definitely recommend it.
descrip: The second semester of a survey of fundamental concepts in cosmology, designed for students who have taken a basic introduction (Physics 563, Astro 522, Astro 401 or equivalent). Course spans the leading issues in contemporary cosmology including inflation, the cyclic universe, baryogenesis, dark matter and dark energy, emphasizes the connections between cosmology and particle/string physics, and discusses the origin and evolution of inhomogeneities, their effects on the cosmic microwave background and large scale structure.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: Definitely take it
Edmund White is an eminent literary voice with a plethora of wisdom that a young writer would be wise to discover and absorb.
Edmund White is my favorite of the CWR professors I've had.

I definitely learned some things about writing fiction from Professor White. He's so well-read and experienced (and funny). The only drawback is the lack of feedback, which you'll probably get more in CRL's class.
Sheila Kohler is lovely (and very helpful).
Take it! he's a hilarious professor.
Take it, especially if you enjoy creative writing!
Take this course!
Take time editing other students' work (making lots of comments) and reading everyone's comments on your own.
Yes, yes, yes.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two-200 level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: The Ionian Shore
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Topics in Hispanic Culture (Europe and America) - Women Writers of Spain and Latin America
prereqs: A 300-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: Close readings of female-authored works ranging from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. A series of oral reports on normative and moralistic texts will enable us to contrast the ways in which women saw themselves with the ways in which they were seen by men.

title: Intellectual History of China from the Ninth to the 19th Century
reviews: Don't worry if you haven't had an EAS course before.  It might seem scary given the course number, but it's really fun and there's no need to go in knowing a lot about EAS or Chinese intellectual history.  You'll still get a lot out of it.

I thought this was a good course, both for those students interested in Eastern history and those interested in history more broadly. I would not suggest it for non-intellectual history majors, but I found the philosophy particularly engaging. I think it is a good general Eastern history or philosophy course.
Take if you have a good attention span and like dense philosophy.
Take it if you have an interest in the subject matter. A background in Chinese history is not necessary, but it may be useful.

This sort of very-small and intimate seminar defines the essence of why Princeton is a supposedly "better" institution than all or almost all other universities and colleges in the United States. At the same time, there is no intimidation and no pretentiousness on the esteemed Professor's part as well; rather, Professor Peterson embodies the extremely talented but highly approachable and accessible instructor that every student wishes for in all sorts of classes. Professor Peterson is a world expert and is down-to-earth and the intimate small size of the engaging seminar and stimulating discussions are all reasons why this class is highly recommended.
prereqs: A prior course in East Asian Studies is desirable but not required..
descrip: The course centers on the changing role of the intellectual elite -- how they were recruited, their relationship to holders of powers, their attitudes toward the past and their cultural heritage. The aim of the course is to provide a clearer understanding of the burdens and privileges of intellectuals in Chinese society.

title: Beginner's Greek: Attic Prose
reviews: Definitely take it- go Greek or go home.
I would strongly recommend this course.
Take it, and hope you get Professor Ford.
prereqs: CLG 101 or Permission Of Instructor. Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year short selections of Attic prose will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: For engineers looking for a deeper understanding of the problems they may encounter in their engineering projects, as well as for social scientists and humanities students looking for a broader understanding of technical processes, from proposal to design to implementation, this class is unlike any other.
This is a great class with hands-on experience. You should definitely take it if you want to take part in hands-on projects. You can start any project on your own, and you get funding for it too.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Roman Literature: Selected Author or Authors - Seneca
reviews: Kaster is wonderful. If you're the type of student who falls behind on work when you can get away with not doing it, though, you should be wary. It'll be really hard to catch up come quiz/test time.
Kaster runs a very tight class--he's extremely organized, and definitely notices if you're not prepared. One of the best language professors I've had in Classics here.
This is a great course. Just be prepared to read a lot of Latin.
prereqs: LAT 108 or higher or permission of instructor based on equivalent preparation..
descrip: Nero's tutor and advisor, Seneca, also wrote the only surviving Latin tragedies - strange, violent works whose impact on the development of European drama surpassed even Greek tragedy's - as well as compelling philosophical treatises. This course offers an introduction to both sides of Seneca's literary output and will pay particular attention to the social and political context in which these works were produced.

title: Indigenous Peoples and the Law in the United States and Canada
descrip: This course will survey U.S. and Canadian law governing the relationship between the federal and state/provincial governments and Indian Nations, and will focus on the constitutional, statutory and jurisprudential rules of US Federal Indian law. Topics to be addressed include: the history of federal-tribal relations; the origin and scope of federal power over Indian affairs; the source and scope of tribal powers recognized under federal law; the limits of state authority in Indian country; and contemporary Indian policy. The course will be comparative in nature, with frequent reference to Canadian law.

title: Dance Performance Theory and Cultural Studies - Cultural Politics of Moving Bodies
descrip: This course will expose students to the most recent developments in dance studies. While engaging with a variety of dance forms from different cultures, students will explore analytical strategies and familiarize themselves with the methodologies used by dance scholars in their interpretations of bodies in motion. They will examine how social theories inform the understanding of dance and, vice versa, how the analysis of dance contributes to the development of social theories. Topics to be covered include: dance as a product of culture, as a social form of expression, as cultural identity, and as political power.

title: Scientific Computation in Astrophysics
descrip: A broad introduction to scientific computation using examples drawn from astrophysics. From computer science, practical topics including processor architecture, parallel systems, structured programming, and scientific visualization will be presented in tutorial style. Basic principles of numerical analysis, including sources of error, stability, and convergence of algorithms. The theory and implementation of techniques for linear and nonlinear systems of equations, ordinary and partial differential equations will be demonstrated with problems in stellar structure and evolution, stellar and galactic dynamics, and cosmology.

title: Conceptions of the Sensory
descrip: In-depth discussion and analysis of conceptions of the sensory in writings by philosophers, poets, art critics and theorists, and artists, from the early modern to contemporary periods. We will investigate the ways in which the sensory is understood as the necessary basis for conceptual thinking of diverse kinds, including systematic and dialectical philosophy (Kant and Hegel), sign theory (Saussure), imaginative and figural writing, and theory and practice of the plastic arts (Rilke, Mallarme, Adorno, Greenberg, Serra, Stella, Scully, Buchloh, Warhol, among others).

title: Other Worlds: Science Fiction and Discourses of Alterity
descrip: The development of science fiction as a literary genre is deeply connected to colonialist and anthropological projects that sought to document contact with so-called primitive cultures. Students will examine writers such as Wells, LeGuin, and Delany within this historical framework, with emphasis on how science fiction writers used concepts of exploration, discovery, expansion, and civilization to critique oppression and imagine transformations of the world in which they write.

title: Modern Political Theory
reviews: Beware of the readings, and make sure you know what political writing entails before you turn in your first paper! Go to office hours if you can make them, because the preceptors and professor are all very open to meeting with you.
Decent course.
Do the readings & don't fall behind. Go to lectures. Decide on an essay topic early, so you can at least be thinking about it while you procrastinate.
Do the readings on your own, and forget about lecture.

I thoroughly enjoyed this course. Professor Wenar was a wonderful lecturer and preceptor. This is the type of course that depends a lot on the professor for whether it is interesting or horribly dry, and he did a great job of presenting things in a clear and stimulating way. The material itself was interesting as well though, so I would recommend taking it regardless.
I would encourage students to take advantage of office hours and discuss ideas and questions!

I would recommend this course if you are interested in politics, especially as a major. It gives you a good idea of political theory and a nice foundation. The papers are interesting and not horrible. Also the final isn't too daunting.

I would suggest that the student speak up in lecture and precept as often as possible, because it is very easy to get confused by the concepts. It really helps to get to know the professor even if you do not happen to be in his precept.
If you have the time for lots of reading and want to have this foundation in important thinkers, take it. If you're looking for an interesting course to PDF, take it. But don't assume it'll be easy!
If you're even the slightest bit interested in the topic, I would recommend this course to you. Was interesting, and not too difficult.
It was very interesting, and Prof. Wenar's lectures are definitely worth going to.
It's a really good course
Its not a bad EM, and for pol classes light on reading and writing. I'd say worth it to get the theoretical grounding for later classes.

Strongly recommended, for political theory concentrators, POL majors in general, and anyone looking for a good course.  
I took it with a visiting professor, but the works (Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Mill, Marx, and Rawls plus Hume and Bentham) are some of the greatest in political theory, so you likely can't go wrong.
Surely something to consider for an introduction to political theory.
Take it!

Take the class, especially if Professor Wenar is still teaching it. He worked extensively with the most influential political philosopher in recent memory (Rawls), so his understanding of all things modern political theory is second to none, and he presents it in a way that is accessible to all.

Take the course if you have a legitimate interest in political theory. You will the most out of the class by doing the readings and really trying to understand what the authors are saying. Modern political theory is a subject matter that should be understood by many people, so that they may understand its influence on today's political society. 

The professor is a visiting lecturer, so he probably won't be around the next time they offer the course. Just hope you have an engaging professor.
Take this (or intro to political theory or the just society) before graduating.
Take this class!
Take this course if you're interested in politics, philosophy, want to read some foundational type sources, or simply want to get the distribution requirement. Do it.
This course is very thought-provoking and interesting. The theorists this course covers are definitely worth studying.
Unless you are dying to commit yourself to reading these books (which I recommend) but don't need to get that much out of the lecture, don't take it.
Use google to help clarify concepts
an excellent intro to pol theory.
descrip: A study and critique of the philosophical foundations of modern democratic liberalism based on a close reading and analysis of texts by Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Mill, Marx and Rawls.

title: Analysis and Number Theory
descrip: The general analytic theory of L-functions. Analytic continuation, zeros, magnitude, and related issues are studied. The emphasis of the course is on applications to problems in number theory automorphic forms and mathematical physics.

title: Elementary Korean II
reviews: Don't worry about Korean being to hard - it's a very straightforward and fun language.  It simply has a different vibe and attitude to it than western languages like English or French.
If you are at all considering Korean, then you won't find a teacher more enthusiastic for Korean or better taught material.
If you liked 101 you'll like 102.

If you want to learn Korean than of course... you should probably take this class. If you want to learn any language than pick Korean because Korean culture is interesting, Korean class is good, plus its always fun
If you're looking at this, you're probably sold on the subject. The teachers are amazing. Take this course.

If you're looking for a fun language, absolutely take this class. You will get along well with the teachers, learn a lot, and have a lot of fun. Korean is not as intimidating as people think--the characters you see are actually a phonetic alphabet.
It's really fun and effective at teaching you the language.
Take it ASAP!
Take it~ Teachers are awesome, language is awesome, culture is awesome! Why wouldn't you take it?
Take the class! The Korean teachers are extremely nice and go to great lengths to help you improve.
The course is fun, interesting, and not hard if you put in the effort and cram for the quizzes if you have to.
This class is a lot of fun and the professors are friendly and helpful. A good way to fulfill your language requirement, or just to take for fun.
You should definitely take it, it's a lot of fun. Even though some days there is a lot of homework, it usually isn't too much.
yes
prereqs: KOR 101 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 101. Continued develoment of proficiency in basic communication. Students who complete KOR 102 with excellence may be recommended for KOR 301.

title: Introduction to English Literature: 14th to 18th Century
reviews: A good overview of the literature of this period.  If you don't like reading epic poems and are not interested in English as a field, you might want to skip this class; otherwise, it's a solid class that will get you read up on a few of the 'must-read' literary classics.

Although English majors are required to take the course, I would still recommend it to other students. I would tell them to not be intimidated by the difficulty of the material, and to allow yourself sometime to not rush through the works. Maybe take the course when you do not have other courses that requiring a lot of reading.
Be sure to plan enough time to do all the readings.
Do not take this course unless you want to be an English major. If you're looking for an LA, look elsewhere.
Do not take unless you are an English major.
Don't take it unless you're an English major. It was not an enjoyable course.

ENG 200 has a heavy workload, and you won't always feel like doing the readings, but do your best and it'll be worthwhile. Though it's an intro course, this class isn't really representative of others in the department. If you're not thinking of majoring in English, there are other, more fun and creative courses to consider.

Good course. If you do not like English do not take this course. If you only enjoy the modern novel, do not take this class. I'm sure that there are more exciting English classes with easier to understand reading material to be offered at Princeton. But your enjoyment of the class will depend also on your preceptor. If you get Beatrice Sanford, be happy!

I would definitely recommend this class to perspective English majors as it introduces you to some landmark texts and inspiring writers.  I would also recommend that any student taking this class in the future makes a point to attend the lectures.  They help!

I would not recommend this course to anyone. The lectures were slow and tedious, and the precept (at least mine) was incredibly boring. No one felt compelled to engage in this precept, and the hour and 50 minutes was torturous.
I would say that this class is great for English majors or prospective concentrators, but that it does not have widespread appeal as much as other classes might.
I wouldn't recommend it to someone just looking to take an English class, but as a departmental, it's a great course.

I wouldn't recommend taking the course unless you have to, or unless you do have a huge interest in the texts.  The reading can be a bit overwhelming and Nigel Smith who gives the majority of the lectures is pretty mediocre. Likable maybe, but uninformative.
If you seek more structure in an English class, this is nicely guided and gives you a glimpse of a lot of different texts that speak amongst each other.
If you're an English major, you have to take it. But if you're not, it's a great way to educate yourself on the most important authors of the 14th-18th centuries.

If you're not planning on majoring in English or aren't in love with 14th to 18th century English literature, but have a general interest in the disciple, I would recommend another, smaller course in the department.
It depends on why the student is considering it. If he/she wants a distribution requirement, I think there are more interesting English classes available.
It is a lot of reading; I can't stress enough how much reading it is and it is also quite dense. On the other hand, Cole and Smith are great and it's a prereq for the English department.
It's a departmental prerequisite, and it is difficult to treat it any other way. Unless you know you love the material, there are far better and far more interesting English courses out there.
It's a great survey course for masterworks in English Literature.

It's worth taking if only for Paradise Lost, but you may struggle through some of the more tedious 'gems' of literary history to get there.  It's not for everyone, but if you enjoy old British literature and middle English, by all means, take this.
Its annoying, but the English dep. is worth it.
Just make detailed notes as you read and try to work on analysis assignments ahead of time.
Lectures might not seem that useful but the final at least this year depended heavily on the perspectives presented in lecture, so you might as well go.

ONLY take this course if you are an English major.  Period.  I am not an English major and was just looking for an interesting way to get one of my LA distribution requirements out of the way.  This was NOT the right course for that.  I have had to take a bunch of other intro courses to satisfy other distribution requirements, and I have to say that this is the one that I have gotten the least out of.  Readings were manageable, I suppose, but there was a very low education to labor ratio.  If you are an English major, you have to take this course, so just deal with it.  If you are not an English major, just take a music class as an LA.
Only if you have to.
Only really recommend it for a departmental. Other than that there are better literature courses you can take.

Only take it as a departmental.  Take better English courses first, preferably 300-levels, to get a feel for the department, or this course will probably make you (like me) want to run and never look back.

The readings take 2-4 times longer to read than modern novels, so 150 pages a week feels more like 400.

Don't have high expectations for the course, although precepts are very good.
Only take it if it's the only LA course that fits in your schedule.
Only take this class if you 1) really like English or 2) Really like lots of reading, particularly medieval/renaissance literature.
Read the books before hand.
Recommend to all my friends

Required for English majors, but if you are not an English major I would only recommend the course if you're interested in British literature. Otherwise, readings may seem difficult or dense at times.
Take this class if you really love English and are considering an English major. It's a little work-intensive if you just want to fulfill a requirement.
Take this course! It gives you an opportunity to engage with some brilliant texts and the lectures and precepts are fantastic!

The final exam requires a pretty impressive recall of minute passages from some of the large works you will read, and they are not even plot-specific for the most part.  Take careful note of passages emphasized in lecture and review them before your final.
This is a great class if you're looking for a taste of all the greats; Milton, Shakespeare, Chaucer, etc.  Be prepared to move through a lot very quickly though!

This is a really fun course, and a great introduction to British literature. The readings can be a lot--quite frankly, I never finished some of them--but they're definitely worth the effort. Both professors are very good and provide an interesting contrast: Professor Cole, tall, bearded, and straightforward, starts the year with Medieval literature and ends it with Fielding, while Professor Smith, smaller, British, and more meandering in his lecture style, does the middle lectures on Renaissance and Enlightenment literature. Definitely recommended!

This was the first English class I had taken at Princeton, and I really loved it. It is a great introduction into the department and the works that we study are classics that everyone should study at some point in their college career. I recommend taking this course!
Unless you're entering the department, there are much better classes to take.
don't take it unless you have to

if it's required, you have to take it (obviously). If you are interested in these materials, you'll enjoy the class a lot because lectures and precepts are just fine. Otherwise, take something else...
prereqs: First-year students welcome. English 200 is a prerequisite for entrance into the Department of English..
descrip: An introduction to the leading figures of earlier English Literature (Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Milton, Pope, and Swift), to literary history as a mode of inquiry, and to the analysis of the way literature makes meaning shaping the way human beings think about themselves and each other with respect to art, artfulness, beauty, romance, desire, liberty and agency, God, the mind, sex, death. We will consider how authors create literature in dialogue with their predecessors, and in relation to contemporary circumstances. We will focus on the qualities of literary brilliance that have made this canon so revered and so influential.

title: Organic Chemistry II: Foundations of Chemical Reactivity and Synthesis
reviews: Best class I have taken at Princeton.  Many people dread taking organic chemistry, but the combination of Prof. Sorensen, Prof. Gingrich, and Keith Reber make the experience enjoyable.  You will be glad you took the course.
Challenging course. You will learn how to make illegal street drugs, which makes such a science-heavy course feel rewarding and practical. But strap down
Challenging.  But in a weird way, fun.
Definitely take Sorenson over Simmelhack. His lectures are way more interesting, and he writes out the notes and puts them on blackboard which makes things so much easier to follow

Do not take Semmelhack's section. I will repeat that again, do not take semmelhack's section. If you want to do well in Orgo, understand the material for the MCAT or for being a Chem major, definitely take this section. Sorensen is a fantastic lecturer. Do not let the graded psets shy you away, they really force you to learn the material and not fall behind. This course doesn't have to be the 3 headed monster it's made out to be, do the sensible thing and take this section.
Do not take this class unless you have ample time to devote to it, because it could be enjoyable, but not with as a fourth technical class.
Do not wait until the last minute to do lab reports.

Don't fall behind on the material. It is very easy to forgot to look over the notes or simply let the material fly over you during the lectures as you focus on the pretty colors of the chalk on the board. Always think critically and continuously go over the material, especially with practice problems and exams.
Don't take it unless you are required to. This isn't one of those classes you just take for fun.
Don't take it unless you need to.
Don't underestimate orgo. Go to lecture, always.

Don't you dare take this unless you have to for premed (even still, I'd advise you take it over the summer and save the thirty grey hairs that you'll develop after this class), or are some sort of Chemistry genius.  This class will not only bring your GPA down because of it's ridiculous difficulty, but it will bring down your grades in every single other class because it will take so much of your time in order to simply pass the class that you will be forced to blow off all of your other school work.  Also, be ready to sacrifice basically any and all social interactions during the week leading up to the exam.
Expect the unexpected and be ready for little tricks in exam questions.
Fuck Orgo.
Good luck. It's organic chemistry. But Sorenson is great; he's super excited about his subject and hopes that you will be too.
I know you don't exist, but if you want to take organic chemistry for fun, you'll probably enjoy it.

I would recommend the class, but be prepared for a lot of hard work.  Orgo kind of ruled my life this year, and even with all the studying my grade was just so-so.  Orgo can sort of be a subject where you either have it or you don't.  But getting a tutor and going to office hours helps.  Do practice problems!  And def go for Sorensen over Semmelhack.  Sorensen is an awesome prof that you shouldn't miss out on.
I would tell him to take Sorensen's section and make sure to stay on top of the lecture notes.
If you are a pre med athlete take it somewhere else
If you are interested in chemistry.
If you didn't like 1st semester, you will most likely enjoy the set up for this class much better.
If you don't need organic chemistry, I don't recommend taking it. Otherwise, I do prefer Professor Sorensen's teaching over Professor Semmelhack.

If you found the mechanisms and last third of first semester Orgo interesting, definitely take second semester orgo. It's more of the same, but I found the problem/puzzle-solving nature of Orgo to be quite enjoyable. Overall, I liked Sorensen's style of running the class better than Semmelhack's style, but I found myself more engaged in Semmelhack's lectures for some reason. Sorensen's notes are much more helpful than the textbook.
If you like organic chemistry, take this course.
If you look for beauty in organic chemistry, you'll find it in Professor Sorensen's class! If you want to be more inspired, I strongly recommend taking organic chemistry with Professor Sorensen.
It is a tough course, but probably my favorite science course at Princeton thus far.
It is hard to cram for this class so study early for midterms and finals. Don't be afraid to ask Sorensen or Keith questions; they are helpful and nice.
It's not for everyone, but if you have any interest in the chemical sciences, take it. It's a well taught and organized class.
It's not that bad. You'll survive
Just get it over with.
Keep up with the work (DO NOT LET MATERIAL ACCUMULATE) and you will be fine and learn tons.
Keith Reber is an amazing preceptor, and if you have the chance to be in his precept, definitely do it.
Lectures are for fun; typed notes are where learning happens. Master material early - makes learning much easier
Make sure you can devote some time to this class.
Most people taking it have to, either for departmentals or pre med, but it is worth taking if you enjoy chemistry
No one will help you if you don't find help yourself. No one will warn you if you slip behind during the semester. But you've taken CHM303, I guess you know that.
Note: exams are closed book (unlike 303), but exams ask less unexpected detail (predicting stereochem).

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.  The course was student-friendly.

the only thing I'd suggest is... maybe using 3D models when describing stereochemistry?  I'm personally pretty bad at visualizing things, so this might have been an extra help.
Only take it if you must
Only take this course if you have no choice or if you're a chem major.

PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE!!! Past a certain point, you will have to do a lot of mechanisms and some synthesis problems, and if you don't know the material well, you won't be able to do it very easily.  Make sense of the mechanisms, don't let yourself fall behind and not know the early concepts, because it will just make your life more difficult later.  Everything made more sense to me when I reviewed everything before the final, but if you keep up it might make sense all the way through.  Go to precept and office hours if you need.  Precepts are quite helpful and I'd imagine office hours are too.  Don't wait until the last minute to start problem sets, they may take a lot longer than they look.
STUDY, STUDY, STUDY. And then study some more. Get extra help.
Sorensen IS THE BEST PROFESSOR EVER! He is very lively, enthusiastic, and makes Orgo very interesting.
Sorensen and Keith are seriously amazing. I would recommend this over Semmelhack's any day.
Sorensen is a wonderful professor who is very passionate about teaching. It is a challenging class, so do lots of problems!
Stay on top of the material as much as possible
Stay on top of the notes and attend all the lectures.
Students complain, but the grade you receive in this class is, for the most part, reflective of how much time you put into it.

Study the lecture notes, it's where most of the exam material comes from, and pay attention to the problem sets, it's not uncommon at all for very similar problems to appear on exams. Be sure to keep up with the material.
Study, study! Great professors can't help you remember things.
TAKE THIS OVER SEMMELHACK!
