Take 304 with Sorensen. He loves his students and works for them to understand the material like no other. Reber does the same thing. Sorensen's notes for this class are extremely on-point for this class and teach you everything you need to know.
Take it but PDF if you don't do well on the first test.

Take this class only if you have the time and dedication. If you know you'll have a busy semester, make sure you're really sure you can handle it and that you really love orgo and are willing to put the time into it. The class is tough and you need to be willing to devote yourself to it. That being said, Sorensen and his colleagues are pretty good.
Take this class over Semmelhack's version any day.
Take time on it

The course is actually a really good course once you stop complaining that it is in fact Organic Chemistry. Yes, it's hard, but very doable, and with the right attitude it's actually quite interesting and enjoyable.
This class is a great class. Though I certainly would not recommend taking it for fun as it is still rather challenging.

This class is completely manageable if you just keep up and put in the time and effort. If you are pre-med, this class might just seem awful, but if you genuinely like chemistry, I think you will like this class.

This is a well-done class. It is challenging but not impossible, and it is really interesting. If you like puzzles and critical thinking, you will enjoy this. Read the notes thoroughly, go to lecture, and do practice problems.
Transcribe the notes into your own words to help prepare for the exam. Go to lecture and precept.
Unnecessarily hard
You will die if you are not brilliant and/or willing to dedicate all of your time. Take this ONLY if you have to.
run.  class is sooo hard
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303..
descrip: This course begins by discussing the chemical consequences of conjugation and the Diels-Alder reaction. After a coverage of aromaticity and the chemistry of benzene, we then move into the heart of the course: the nature and reactivity of the carbonyl group, a subject that is central to both mainstream organic chemistry and biochemistry. Throughout this course, an effort will be made to demystify the art of chemical synthesis. This course is appropriate for chemistry majors, premedical students, and other students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Advanced Studies in Acting: Scene Study and Style
prereqs: THR 201 or THR 301 or THR 311 OR any class in Dance. Please visit the Theater Program website for application information. THR 401 can be taken up to three times, with the permission of the Program Director, as long as the instructor or the subject matter is different..
descrip: This course will focus on scenework from the contemporary American repetoire, including plays (by Lisa Kron, David Greenspan, David Henry Hwang, Tanya Barfield and Nenna Beeber) whose world premieres were directed by the instructor.

title: Music and Madness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Algorithm Design
reviews: A student taking this course needs to be able to stomach a good amount of mathematics, but otherwise it's a course filled with a lot of intuition and creative ideas.
An excellent review of approximation algorithms. I learned many tools.
Great course. Take it if you love learning advanced aspects of algorithmic analysis and design. I found the power of the described techniques absolutely incredible.
Take it!
This course is an opportunity to learn a lot, but there is also much reading and hard problems to work on although not so many. It is a hard course.
Try to have at least solid notions on flow algorithms, tree algorithms, dynamic programming, and some basic knowledge of probabilities (expectations, variance, Markov inequalities, etc.)
descrip: Advanced methods of algorithmic design and analysis: data structures, network flows, and linear programming. Solution of linear programs: Karmarkar and Ellipsoid algorithms. Probabilistic techniques. A selection of topics from on-line computation, approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems, number theoretic algorithms, geometric algorithms, and parallel computation.

title: Dante's "Purgatorio" and "Paradiso"
prereqs: HUM 216-217, ITA 303, ITA 220, FRS 111 (Dante's Inferno), or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is a continuation of ITA 303 and provides an occasion for close collaborative study of the final "cantiche" of the "Commedia". Half the semester will be devoted to the "Purgatorio", half to the "Paradiso". "Vita Nuova" will be read over Break.

title: 19th-Century Master Novelists - Tolstoy
descrip: A close reading of War and Peace (in Russian) along side short fictions, classics in Russian criticism, a sampling of diaries and letters, and ideological - philosophical context. Good reading knowledge of Russian required.. Coordinated with COM 415.

title: Intensive Intermediate Chinese
reviews: A tough course but very rewarding; undoubtedly essential in any introductory Chinese education.
Awesome class. PERIOD.

Chinese has a very specific structure to its weeks--go through at least one or two weeks, see if you like it and then decide whether to add or drop. Make sure you get a good teacher. It's vital. You won't find a friendlier language department, but make sure you know what you're getting yourself into. Your Chinese will definitely improve.
Definitely a huge commitment, there will be work every day and quizzes every Friday.  But, my Chinese no doubt improved dramatically after a year
If you are prepared to spend 20  hours every week on Chinese, take this course!
If you want to learn Chinese, then definitely take CHI 108. It's a lot of work, but the teachers are awesome and class is a lot of fun!
It's a lot of work, but very rewarding and fun.
Make sure to dedicate time to it, and you'll feel very rewarded
Make sure you have the time necessary to devote to Chinese. It's a time commitment.
Take it if you want to learn Chinese! Be prepared to work very hard or to accept an average grade (in the long run, this is okay if you end up learning a language you keep for a lifetime).
Though it requires a lot of hard work, the knowledge of Chinese you gain in the end will be very rewarding.
You will do as much work for this class as two classes, but you will have a lot of fun and a very good experience.
do it
take it, but be prepared to work harder than in 103 as the material and tests get more difficult
prereqs: CHI 103 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: An intensive course covering 105 and 107 in one semester for students who have finished 103 which covers 101 and 102. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills and the analysis of grammar. After 108, students are ready for third year courses.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 301 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of CHI 301. Reading in Qin and Han philosophical and historical texts and essays written from Tang to Qing.

title: Topics in Medieval Art, Architecture, and Theory: Concepts for the Depiction of God
descrip: Discusses the conditions of image making and theory in the Middle Ages. The course will focus on how to represent God in the visual arts, introducing iconographic concepts and their reception. Single image-types will be analyzed on the basis of sociological and intellectual history and from different historiographic view points. Discussions of selected readings will raise questions and suggest approaches to the iconographic material. Issues covered in this course are: institutionalizing Christianity in Late Antiquity, the idea of authenticity for various types of icons, iconoclasm, the image of God in Scholasticism, and allegory.

title: American Politics and Democratic Theory
prereqs: At least one prior course in American politics..
descrip: This is a course on American politics viewed from the perspective of democratic theory. We will begin with recent political events that raise perennial issues, and then proceed to the history of the American party system. The course material is primarily historical and theoretical.

title: Morality in America
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - International Migration and Public Policy
descrip: This course examines the theoretical models put forth to account for international migration, reviews the empirical evidence on hypotheses derived from these theories in different world regions, develops a synthetic framework for understanding immigration in the contemporary world, and uses this framework to analyze immigration policies in the United States and other migrant-receiving nations.

title: Philosophy of Art
reviews: An absolute must.
An enjoyable, thought-provoking class with interesting lectures.
Come in with an open mind.  If you're willing to have a lot of your assumptions challenged and deal with some uncomfortable concepts, you'll get a lot out of it, provided you actually do the reading.
Definitely take this course. It will not let you down.
Do it.
Even if you are only remotely interested in the topics of the course, I'd recommend considering it.
I strongly recommend students take a course with Nehamas. He's a wonderful speaker and this course had very interesting reading material.
If you are interested in art at all, this is a great class!
If you have a strong interest in the topic and are comfortable investigating without conclusions, you will really enjoy Nehamas and the structure of the course.
If you know a lot about philosophy and art, you will love it! If not, you will be lost and confused.
Interesting class but could move slower and cover less material to allow for more analysis.
It was a very interesting PDF course.
It's probably the best survey course you can take at Princeton
Prof. Nehamas' lectures were fantastic.
Take it if you need an LA, are interested in aesthetics, or want to hear some great lectures.
Take it!

This is an interesting course, especially if you have a background in a particular art form (art, music, poetry, etc.). Prof. Nehamas is wonderful! It was a great course to cap off my academic experience at Princeton.

This is definitely a good course to take, if you enjoy both art and philosophy (that seems a bit obvious...). It is not very difficult and at times very interesting. If anything, Nehemas is at least a very engaging lecturer.
This is one of the classes for which you came to Princeton.
Though not as good as Nietzsche, this is still a strong course taught by a great professor. His ideas, more than anything are worth taking the class for.
do the readings. Go talk to Nehemas- he's awesome.
eat well but not too much before lectures.
good la requirement
intriguing course, not too much work.
solid course- definitely do the reading to get the most out of it
descrip: Ethics, Aesthetics and the Arts: Ever since Plato's REPUBLIC, the arts have been the target of ethical criticisms. We will examine these criticisms, discuss whether the aesthetics status of art renders it immune to them, and consider in detail the case --not of the fine but-- of the popular arts, in particular, television, which gives such criticisms an unexpected immediacy and leads to many of the most important problems of aesthetics.

title: Topics in Literature and Ethics - Reading Ethically, Reading Aesthetically
descrip: A study of the role that moral education should play in literary study, with examples drawn from American fiction, photography, and film. The possibility of an "ethics of reading" will be tested through various questions: Are there limits to what should be represented (sexual explicitness, violence)? Should offensive depictions of race, or class, or gender be challenged? What is lost through an "inauthentic" voice, or through paraphrase, or through an imposed cultural style?

title: Applied Quantitative Analysis
reviews: Classes build on one another so don't get behind early on in the course.
If you are enthusiastic about learning statistics, this class is definitely worthwhile.
Take it only if you are interested in statistics
prereqs: POL 345, or ECO 300, or ECO 303..
descrip: This course provides working knowledge of data analysis using regression models. Topics include multiple regression techniques, probit and logit models for discrete outcomes, and panel data analysis. Students will learn how to build regression models to answer substantive questions, how to draw statistical inference for regression coefficients, and how to overcome situations when the basic model assumptions are violated by observational data. Coursework will involve using R to analyze real data sets.

title: Accounting for Taste
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture
reviews: Awesome reading, dry lecture. Only take if you are interested in Chinese society and culture.
I would strongly recommend the course.  Professor really knows what he's talking about and it gives an excellent overview to the current social trends in China.

If you're really interested in China and want to do a lot of interesting readings, then take this class. The lectures, however, might bother you at first because it is hard to understand Prof Zhang. You get used to it though.
This class has much potential, but Prof. Zhang's thick accent and inflexibility make the class dull and boring. The exams are designed to stump you. Do not take this class with Prof Zhang.
Unless you really like the topic, don't take this.  It's difficulty is on par with a Woody Wu class.
do the readings I wish we didn't have to ALL of them bc there were too many but it seems like some random things were pulled from the readings for the midterm. Recommend, with caution.
descrip: This course offers an overview of contemporary China, focusing on its transformation from Maoist socialism to the current Chinese society. It outlines Maoist socialism, and explores the changes since the late 1970s, giving special attention to tensions in this transformation: the tension between decentralized social life and the sovereignty of the post--Mao state; between the memories of Maoist socialism and current cultural politics; between the loss and reinvention of traditions; between the increasing mobility and social re-stratification; and between China's change and the existing theories about the way a society changes.

title: Advanced Topics in Structural Biology - Neuro-developmental Disorders from a Molecular Point of View
descrip: A critical discussion of biological structures pertinent to understanding neurodevelopmental diseases. Crystal structures of ion channels, synaptic scaffolds, receptors, chromatin remodeling complexes, and kinases will be analyzed in the context of recent genetic findings on the causes of autism, fragile-X syndrome, and Rett's syndrome. A systems biology approach will be taken to bridge the gap between behavioral phenotypes, as studied with mouse models, and gene expression profiles. The principles of x-ray crystallography will be taught as needed to follow journal articles under discussion.

title: International Economics
descrip: Survey course in international economics for non-specialists. The first half covers microeconomic topics such as trade theory and policy, multilateral trade negotiations and regional economic integration. The second half addresses macroeconomic topics such as current account imbalances, exchange rates, and international financial crises. The course stresses concepts and real-world applications rather than formal models. Prerequisite: 511b and 512b (concurrently).

title: Philosophy of Language
prereqs: Course open to freshmen..
descrip: An introduction to selected topics in the philosophy of language, including Frege's puzzle, Russell's Theory of Descriptions, the arguments of Kripke's "Naming and Necessity", propositional attitudes, conditionals, and Grice's pragmatics.

title: Spreading the Wealth
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Translation Workshop: Spanish to English
reviews: Fun, interesting seminar that teaches you Spanish/English translation through firsthand experience. We had interesting, famous guests come to our seminars: Eliot Weinberger, among others! Professor Allen's accounts of her own experiences, as well as individual meetings (schedule to meet with her frequently!! So helpful!) will quickly develop your skills as a translator.
A remarkable opportunity to have your work critiqued and refined by one of the best Spanish-to-English translators working today.  Really, don't pass this chance up.
Anyone interested in Spanish and English literature (or any kind of writing) should enjoy this a lot, especially with Professor Allen's teaching.

Awesome course.  If you're interested in not just learning translation theory but really getting your feet wet trying it yourself, take the course. Prof Allen also does a great job of contextualizing translation and showing how much the work matters in the exchange of ideas and words across languages. She made it so much more than a purely academic exercise.u
Be aware she's not very available, or at least had over booked herself when I took the class. But if you're interested in learning about translation she's a master and also a great teacher.
Boring but easy.
If you are interested in translation as a practice you should take it.
If you have taken Spanish at Princeton (or otherwise can read at a reasonable level) and have any interest in translation, you're a fool not to take this course.
Take this course if you want to develop your translation skills.
Take this course with Professor Allen!  You will learn so much more with her than you ever thought possible.
Take this if you want to have other students workshop your translations and vice-versa.
esther won't be teaching it again, so I can't judge.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Reading knowledge of Spanish..
descrip: This course is an initiation into the inspiring complexities of literary translation. We will begin with a series of translation exercises; students will post, analyze and critique their own work and that of classmates on a blog. Each student will then select an author and work to be translated as the central project for the class, and embark on the process of researching, contextualizing, locating intertexts, and revising successive drafts to produce an effective translation. Each class will be accompanied by readings in translation theory and practice and guest speakers will provide additional perspective.

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy II
descrip: Advanced topics in monetary economics, with an emphasis on open economies. Money demand and currency substitution; price-level and exchange-rate determination under alternative monetary policy rules; real effects of monetary disturbances; exchange-rate policy and macroeconomic stability; welfare consequences of inflation and exchange-rate stabilization; advantages and disadvantages of monetary union.

title: French Renaissance Literature and Culture
prereqs: Prerequisite: prior 200-level French course..
descrip: A glimpse into the world of Renaissance France and the period's rich diversity of cultural expression. Through fiction, poetry, essays, treatises, emblems, and images, this course explores the relationships among literary creation, political events, religious movements, artistic innovations and scientific discoveries. Readings may include the works of Rabelais, Marguerite de Navarre, Ronsard, Louise Labe, Jean de Lery, Montaigne, and d'Aubigne.

title: Topics in Mathematical Modeling - Mathematical Neuroscience
reviews: This course is great for people who are interested in mathematical modeling and/or neuroscience.
descrip: The course draws problems from the sciences and engineering for which mathematical models have been developed and analyzed in order to describe, understand and predict natural and man-made phenomena. Topics will range across the physical sciences and biology, including cognitive science and neurobiology. Model building strategies: analytical and computational methods; the manner in which applications motivate mathematical developments.

title: Leo Tolstoy, War and Peace, and the Tasks of Literature
reviews: Absolutely take if it is offered.  You have to commit time to it, but it will be so rewarding.
Awesome. The workload is fair, not strenuous, and you will find that you genuinely enjoy the readings and class discussions.

CE and Anna are wonderful, do the reading - it's very fun, start your final paper early - you'll have so many ideas that are brought up from the course that it's hard to narrow them down into a single essay.
Definitely a must take for anyone interested in Russian literature or even literature in general.
Definitely take it!  I would take it twice if they'd let me!
EXCELLENT. A superb class for anyone, in any department, with any background.

Everyone should read War and Peace at some point, and you might as well do it with one of the most respected Tolstoy scholars in the world! The reading load (250-300 pages per week) is a tad heavy, but it is most definitely manageable with a little planning. The overall workload was also quite reasonable: five written critiques (one page each) spaced throughout the semester, three spot quizzes (three questions each; if you did the readings, these are a breeze), and one ten-page final paper. Anna Berman was an amazing preceptor for this course, and I only hope someone with her passion for the subject matter will take be precepting next time around. All in all, TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
If you have the time available to dedicate to War and Peace and you have even the slightest interest in Tolstoy or Russian literature, take it.
If you're even remotely interested in Tolstoy, or Russian literature, or literature in general, TAKE THIS COURSE.
It's a lot of reading, so you have to want to read a lot.  If you want to read Tolstoy, this course will definitely help you understand it.
One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton!
Possibly the best class I have ever taken in my life
TAKE IT
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT.
Take it i you're willing to engage with the texts seriously, it's not worth doing halfheartedly
Take it!! There is a lot of reading involved but it was completely worth it. Best class I have had in Princeton. I highly recommend this class and any class taught by Emerson.
Take it- this is an amazing course that takes you through the best book of all time War and Peace and the enigmatic author behind it. The second best course I have taken at Princeton.
Take it.
Take this class whenever it's offered! It's a rare chance to delve into an amazingly rich literary world, but gives you total freedom to set the tone and topic of class discussion.
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not required. Graduate students taking the course under SLA 511 must have excellent reading knowledge of Russian, and will meet Tuesday afternoons in lieu of the Wednesday session..
descrip: An introduction to Tolstoy through his select short fiction and/or drama, critical essays, and all of [War and Peace] in the context of various theories of the novel. Our thesis--which is open to debate--is that Tolstoy's radical ideas on narrative have their counterpart in his radical ideas on history and the self, which, taken together, offer a coherent view of the human condition at odds with most Russian writers and philosophers of his time.

title: Writing histories of the modern Middle East: trends, topics, problems
descrip: This seminar introduces graduate students to a range of trends, topics, and problems that are currently shaping research of the modern Middle East. We will mainly read recently published books that are helping to define their respective fields, but also re-read a few by now classical interventions. The key objective is to help graduate students to both appreciate and criticize contemporary research; to understand the roots various debates as well as the sometimes hidden connections and parallels between them; and to develop a sense of how their future doctoral dissertations fit into, and/or may help re-shape, ongoing debates in their field.

title: Topics in Early Chinese Art and Archaeology
descrip: The origin and early functions of writing in comparative perspective, with special attention to Mesopotamian, Egyptian, and Chinese writing systems, but some mention also of the New World (Maya hieroglyphic; Inka khipu).

title: International Relations of the Middle East: Policies, Issues and Debates
descrip: Addresses complexities of the Middle East. Focuses on both major players' individual foreign policies and wider regional structural forces that determine them. Starts with historical overview of Middle East--how states were created from a collapsing Ottoman Empire and how Cold War superpower rivalry affected states' foreign policy traditions. Next, structural influences--political economy of oil, globalization and identity; also analyze foreign policies of region key players. Concludes with recent debates regarding regional reconfigurations, Iranian nuclear program, Turkey's new ambition, and Iraq war aftermath.

title: American Families in Comparative Perspective
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Genetics of Multicellular Organisms
reviews: Definitely take this course.
Great course to take if you are interested in challenging yourself.
Heavy on development, not a deterrent should something to keep in mind.

I would strongly recommend any student interested in genetics, even if he or she will deal primarily in prokaryotic systems, to take this course.  The issue of diploid systems is highly enlightening, and perhaps allow for extrapolations to polyploid systems.
If a student is interested in developmental genetics and/or considering working in a developmental genetics lab, this is an excellent course to take. I loved it.
It is definitely a good course to take if you are interested in working with model organisms or just want a brief idea of how genetics of these organisms work.
Take it
Take this course if you have a great interest in developmental biology, and make sure you have enough background.

This is a good genetics course, especially if you will be working in development.  However, it assumes that you have had some genetics in the past and it helps to have taken an development course as well.
take it
prereqs: Undergraduates need permission of instructor.
descrip: Course presents the genetic tools and logical framework currently used research in developmental biology, neurobiology and quantitative biology of multicellular organisms. Lecture topics and reading material focus on primary literature describing genetic approaches used in model organisms such as Drosophila, C. elegans, mouse and zebrafish. Techniques are presented in a context emphasizing basic biological phenomena and include mutagenesis, production and analysis of genetic mosaics, production of transgenics, ES cells, knock-in technologies and cell type specific expression gene expression.

title: Race and the American Legal Process: Emancipation to the Voting Rights Act
descrip: This course examines the dynamic and often conflicted relationships between African American struggles for inclusion, and the legislative, administrative, and judicial decision-making responding to or rejecting those struggles from Reconstruction to the passage of the Voting Rights Act. In tracing these relationships we will cover issues such as property, criminal law, suffrage, education, and immigration, with a focus on the following theoretical frameworks: equal protection, due process, civic participation and engagement, and political recognition.

title: Introduction to African-American Intellectual Tradition
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar introduces graduate students from many departments to the African-American intellectual tradition. The perspective concentrates on African-America and the African Diaspora, with attention to issues of class and gender as well as race. A broad set of topics, including race, racism, religion, and slavery are discussed. The course presupposes a familiarity with issues in African-American studies.

title: Seminar in Golden-Age Literature - Contingent Ethnographies in Early Modern Spain
descrip: The nature, definitions, and politics of ethnicity -and ethnography-in the history and fiction of Early Modern Spain reveal intricate and shifting parameters. A variety of texts from the Old World and the New, read in conjunction with such theorists as Agamben, Taussig and Ricoeur, and critics including Gonzalez Echevarria, Mignolo and Pratt serve as the focus of discussions. Readings include works by Inca Garcilaso, Guaman Poma, Antonio de Guevara, Antonio de Torquemada, Miguel de Luna, Lope de Vega and Cervantes.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: Definitely keep up with problem sets. Work in groups and start earlier in the week, so you are prepared with questions to ask in office hours. Even though there is a lot more math than the 100-level econ courses, all of it is pretty accessible and intuitive. If you have any questions at all, definitely reach out to the TAs and professor. Prof. Pesendorfer is very approachable and does a thorough job of clearing your confusions.
Definitely take it with Prof Pesendorfer! Will understand many interesting aspects of abstract econ!
Do the problem sets carefully, and pay attention to the concepts.
Don't bother buying Varian and precepts aren't necessary if you read the online solutions.
Don't take it unless you need to. There are plenty of other more interesting finance courses out there.
Fantastic foundation course for econ, I loved it. Obviously it's required for most of the kids who take it, but there's no doubt I would have taken it even if I ducked into Woody Woo
For engineers, this course is more of problem solving and less of theories. So those people might find this course interesting.
From everything I have heard, this version of the course was much easier than other semesters.
Go to Rohit!

I took this course because I thought the material would be interesting, and it was. However, it wasn't really worth it. I would not recommend this to anyone who isn't an Econ major or doing the Finance Certificate, mainly because it is easier to learn the interesting parts of econ by yourself without wasting time with this course

I would recommend this class if Professor Pesendorfer is teaching it. However I can't vouch for other professors, since I have heard bad things about this course from people who took it while it was taught by other professors.
I would strongly recommend taking this course WHEN IT IS TAUGHT BY WOLFGANG PESENDORFER.

If Pesendorfer's teaching it, take it. He actually wants you to understand the material so you won't be the lost the whole semester, and he tries his best to make things as intuitive during lecture. If you go to lecture, you don't really have to do much else.
If you don't like econ, don't take it. It can be a lot of work. The curve is good though.
If you have taken required math courses, go for this course!

If you have to take this course, take it, you'll survive.  Otherwise, I see very little reason to want to take this course, since it is so not-applied and very tool-based for preparation for other economics classes.
If you like a math-econ course, take this course.
If you're into economics, this class is a must.
It's a fun class and really easy!!
It's a good course to take if you are an econ major or interested in the subject. The math is not as bad as you'd think.
Just skip it and take something more advanced.
Most of the material is based off of lecture notes with problem sets sometimes involving complicated calculations, but exams had much easier problems.
Only take this course if Pesendorfer is teaching it. He and Uwe Reinhart are literally the best professors at Princeton.

Only take this course if you need to for Econ (or if you are considering graduate study in economics).  The grading is harsh and unpredictable and the lectures usually revolve around equations rather than economic concepts.  That having been said, Professor Pesendorfer is not a bad teacher, and you learn a lot about how to approach different microeconomic problems.
Pessendorfer is a strong lecturer and this course is more than manageable if you stay on top of the subject material. The course covers a lot, so stay sharp.
Stay on top of the powerpoints and pay attention in lecture or you will find yourself in trouble later.
Take it if professor Pesendorfer is teaching it! Also try and get into Rohit's precept if he's a TA.

Take it if you have to. If you're really good at math, take it because you'll probably enjoy it. And make sure you go to class and are up on the lectures. The problem sets and exams will be easy for you.
Take it next fall with Abreu
Take it with Pesendorfer for sure if he's teaching it.

Take it with Wolfgang. No, just because you don't have to take the lagrangian of non-differentiable functions (somehow), it doesn't make it less rigorous. He prioritizes conceptual over complicated math, and makes you really understand the concepts underneath the numbers.
Take it! It's worth it
Take it, go to lecture and pay attention in it. Don't make the mistake of relying on lecture slides, because him explaining it makes much more sense.
Take it.
Take the course if you need to. On the other hand, if you need an SA to fulfill and are a very quantitative person, this would be a good class to take.
Take this class with Pesendorfer if you have any interest in econ and a fairly strong math background.
Take this class with Pesendorfer! He's great, and the class is fun.
Take this class with Professor Pesendorfer, because he's really great.

The problem with this class is that the material is ridiculously boring; you will effectively be solving the same optimization problem all year. The highlight this year was a brief foray into some game theory topics, which was admittedly pretty neat.  Pesendorfer is a very nice guy, and gives really solid lectures, especially compared to what I have heard about past professors.  So, if you have to take it for the Finance certificate, take it with him.  If you're interested in economics...go elsewhere.  The only way this class could be challenging is if you have no idea of the math behind what's going on, and in that case a multivariable class would serve you better anyway.
This course will make you a better person.

This involves a lot of math. Work with others on the problem sets--focus on those and the notes. The textbook is not so useful, since it's mostly there as supplemental material for you to gain a better understanding of what's presented in class.
Would take this class if you need it for a certificate or departmental. great class.
do it only for the certificate.
go to office hours
interesting, quantitative, etcetc
its a good class
not bad
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 200 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Genetics of Human Populations
reviews: Light workload, interesting material.
Very interesting material.
prereqs: EEB 309, EEB 320, or MOL 342, or CHM 236/COS 236/MOL236/PHY236. Strong familiarity with genetics and molecular biology..
descrip: This advanced seminar will survey the evolutionary history of modern humans and the genetic basis of variation in our species through reading and discussion of classic and contemporary primary literature. Topics include the evolutionary origins of modern human populations, signatures of natural selection in the human genome, and approaches for discovering genetic variants that affect disease susceptibility and variation in normal traits. Significant emphasis will be placed on very recent advances made possible by the human genome project.

title: The Everglades Today and Tomorrow: Global Change and the Impact of Human Activities on the Biosphere
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Avoid taking this class with Luis Goncalves unless you are totally fine with having two days' notice to complete assignments worth 10 or 15% of your grade which take hours to complete.  Essentially, for an average Princeton student with a need for scheduling time commitments, avoid Luis Goncalves - he's a really nice guy but a really lackadaisical professor.
Definitely take this course, and make sure you keep up with all the work. It is easy to fall behind but truly worth it to stay along with the flow of the course.

I definitely recommend this course, especially if the student is interested in learning a new language.  The Portuguese department is the most accessible and friendliest department that I have encountered at Princeton.
I would advise other students to take this class if they were interested in Portuguese for fun--but only to continue on if they were serious about getting a certificate.
If you speak Spanish and want to learn Portuguese, this is a great course because it goes at a quick pace while helping students along the way.
Take it! It's fun and a great way to learn a third, fourth, fifth, etc. language.
act like you actually want to learn and even if your accent sucks which it probably will. still make an effor.
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature and Culture - Literature and Gastronomy in the Age of Globalization
reviews: Definitely take this class, MB is a very easy grader, and if you just make the effort to get to know her she will love you. She's a really interesting person, doesn't flaunt the fact that she has a PHD, etc. Definitely do the readings because participation counts for a lot, and it'll make the midterm exam much easier if you're just kept up the weekly work (which already isn't a lot).
It was fun and I learned and improved a lot. I would take it again!
It's a great course - the readings are enjoyable, and Professor Benjamin really engages with her students.
Take it!
Take it! We even ended with a food celebration feast at Campus Club!
Take this course if you want to read interesting literature and improve your French speaking and writing skills.
prereqs: A 200-level French course..
descrip: Students will first explore the cultural aspects and roots of French cuisine and its gastronomic art form, and then will study through close reading its translation into modern French literary texts. And finally, the course will consider how globalization has impacted the French national identity and how the French intelligentsia has responded to that impact. Course material will include sociological and historical primary and secondary sources, literary texts, as well as films by famous contemporary French directors.

title: Linguistic Universals and Language Diversity
descrip: The study of human language from the perspective of linguistic universals. This course will demonstrate that, contrary to initial impressions, languages of the world do not differ arbitrarily and without limit. All human languages share a common core (universals). We must explain why there are linguistic universals and how languages can differ (diversity).

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Definitely a great class to take if you need a LA or want to try something new at Princeton without worrying (too much) about a grade; do remember that you need to keep up with your assignments or your Dean's Date will be awful.
Don't miss out!

Everyone should take at least one creative writing class at Princeton. Poetry will help make academic writing more interesting to write and read. Shaughnessy is one of the best choices for a professor.
Great, relaxed course to take if you just want to learn/write poetry. I felt like I definitely improved in writing, and it was my least stressful class.
I would say take it, but take it knowing its limits.
If you want to write poetry, definitely take this class.
If you're interested in poetry and want to actively consider pursuing it, getting your work discussed is extremely helpful, and this class is a great way to do just that.
Just be prepared to really write, and try to put in your best effort.
Take it! It is great, even if you are a science major like me!

Take it! Professor Wheeler is extremely nice. Don't be afraid to have your work read by others, getting a variety of constructive critiques will help you grow as a poet. The class environment is generally relaxed, but also very enthusiastic.
Take it!!
Take this course if you can, it's great
Take this course, but don't take it lightly - you and your classmates will get the most out of it if all of you are prepared for and engaging in each class discussion.
Take this course. Or else.
Take this if you have significant experience in poetry. Might be more work than you expect.
YES-take it, great class!

You need to enjoy writing poetry to take this class. It is intended for students who are going to spend a lot of time and energy writing a strong poem each week, and who also will put thought into evaluating other students' work. Commenting and reading classmates' poems can seem tedious, but it will actually get you to read and examine your own poems more critically.
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Egyptian Colloquial Arabic
reviews: Colloquial is what it's all about- do it!
DO IT its a lot of fun and you will learn so much about how to actually speak to people across the Arab world, about Arab movies   culture, everything. Tarek is a blast.

I would definitely take this course if you ever have the chance.  Egyptian colloquial is one of the most commonly-used versions of Arabic colloquial.  The whole point of learning a language is to use it to speak, not to know it only for reading purposes.  As such, it is paramount to take a colloquial class in addition to your regular Fus'ha classes.  Professor Tarek is the best Arabic professor in the whole department.  Much better than Hebatolla (who is nice, and all, but cares more about making you like her so she can get good reviews in the department than about actually teaching you the language.) Professor Tarek is nice in a more real way...he will actually spend hours of his time outside of class just helping you learn how to speak better...he cares much more about you and your improvement than about whether or not he is liked in the NES department.  Professor Tarek is by far the best Arabic professor at Princeton.  Jump at the opportunity to take from him.  You will not regret it.  As long as you are willing to put in the effort, he will show you how to dramatically improve your Arabic.
If you don't think that the Arabic department teaches you how to speak the language and you want to learn, than this class is for you.
prereqs: A minimum of two years study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107) or NES permission..
descrip: An introduction to the spoken dialects of Egypt, particularly of Cairo. Students in this course are assumed to have a functional, working knowledge of classical Arabic, and the course will focus on developing the ability to use conversational language in common, everyday situations.

title: Introduction to Later Sufism (ca. AD 1200 to present)
reviews: I would strongly recommend this class for anyone with an interest in NES, South Asia, or religion.  The philosophy discussed in the class is also very interesting and very useful in understanding the Western philosophical tradition.
Not too difficult, often rewarding, and Professor Barry is a great experience.
Take this class. It will change the way you think about the world. I cannot recommend it enough.

This class will transform you, I guarantee it! I especially recommend the class for Muslims as it will provide you with a very different understanding of Islam that you probably were never exposed to growing up!
be ready to open your mind!
descrip: Popularized through translations of world famous poets like the 13th century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. The Spring session of this two-term course addresses the overwhelming influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (d. 1240 AD) on all subsequent higher Islamic mystical speculation and poetical literature - as far as India.

title: Health Psychology
reviews: A good course for people looking for a good course to PDF.
Don't take if you are pre-med.  It is very insulting to doctors.
Don't.
Easy course to take, but didn't get much out of it.
Good material, terrible delivery, could overall be better
I would definitely recommend taking the course. The professor is very nice, a good lecturer, and is available for help.
I would not recommend the class to students who are interested in health. I would only recommend it to students looking for an easy class.

I would recommend this class. It broadens your horizons and helps you see beyond academia/intellectual discussion about important "world affairs" that dominate most of Princeton interaction. It is really a class about living and the day to day events that affect our quality of life.

If you are interested in a different perspective on medicine that emphasizes the social, psychological parts of health in addition to the biological, take this course. it's not terrible difficult for non-psych majors because the professor kindly explains concepts that non-majors may not understand is very accessible. Don't be too worried about the multiple exams, but be prepared to be tested on very specific material at times (such as names of experimenters). This would be especially valuable for pre-med students who could stand to gain from a non-biological perspective to health.
Interesting enough, not too much work.
Low work-load and straightforward information. I'd take it again.
Low-key, low commitment class. Professor and TA are both very nice. Learn a lot without being stressed.
Participate in precepts and attend and listen to lectures.

Take it if you like psychology models. Keep in mind that this class is filled with premeds, so unless you want to be cutthroat like everyone else, it is hard to do well. Professor Brynildsen is one of the nicest professors though. She asked for feedback a third of the way through the course and actually changed the course format to better address the students' needs.
Take it!

Take this class because Professor Taga is great! It is also not difficult to do well, as long as you study hard and do all of the readings. Make sure to read the boxes in the textbook, as some test questions come from them.

Take this class if you are interested in health psychology or anything with health in general because there is such a wide range of topics to find interest in and the professor is great at teaching the material!
Take this course if you want to dabble a little bit in psych or are interested in medicine. You will learn a lot!
Take this course only if you are very interested in health and health psychology

The topic is definitely interesting, but I think there are other interesting courses that would be a better way to spend your credits at the moment.  Personally, I decided not to take Psy of Gender next semester, mostly because Professor Taga was teaching it, not because I don't like her - she seemed really nice and easy to talk to - but just because I don't want another textbook cookie-cutter class without much soul.
There are more interesting psych classes to take.

This is probably a good class to PDF. The lectures basically cover the same thing as the textbook and there are only a few questions on exams that are solely from the textbook. The lectures are not very engaging, but the material is pretty interesting.
Topics were interesting. Lectures not so much
Very interesting insight and perspectives into different aspects of health psychology. Also useful for premeds and anyone else interested in providing healthcare.
You will learn a lot of interesting material that you can apply to your own life in health psychology.
good
it was ok, but not great
sdf
prereqs: One prior psychology course..
descrip: The objectives of this course are to understand the psychosocial processes that influence health and health care delivery. Topics to be examined are the psychophysiological and sociocultural bases of health and illness; pain and healing; adaptation to chronic illness; stress; personality and illness; quality of life; death, dying, and grief; substance use; health promoting behaviors; patient adherence; physician-patient communication; health care; and medical ethics and utilization.

title: Tropical Biology
reviews: Definitely take it if you want to get field experience! The course won't be as structured as Princeton classes, but it's great because you're always out in the rain forest, pursuing a project you designed.

Put a lot of effort into deciding on your project before hand. It will help you later. I wish that I had gotten more feedback from the professor before I actually began my project. Also make sure you work with somebody. I thought I would be working with somebody else and it turned out she had her own ideas and I ended up by myself a lot. Do not do a lab intensive project. You miss out on a lot of stuff if you spend very little time in the field.
This course is a fair amount of work but is really good!  You will be surprised at how much you care about and are interested in insects after it!
This course is lots of fun!  Pick a project that doesn't involve having to learn to identify too many species ... the tropics are diverse.
Very good introduction to forest dynamics and insect-plant interactions
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester tropical biology program in Panama..
descrip: "Tropical Biology" is an intensive, three-week field course given at four sites in Panama, examining the origins, maintenance and major interactions among terrestrial plants and animals. The course provides the opportunity to appreciate (1) floral and faunal turnover among four rainforest sites (beta-diversity); and (2) floral and faunal turnover along vertical gradients, from ground to upper canopy, at two rainforest sites (vertical stratification). Students carry out individual projects at the sites. Fieldwork is supported by six orientation walks that introduce participants to common orders and families of plants and arthropods.

title: Mechanics of Fluids
reviews: Average course. You need to take it, and it's a HUGE improvement from 223/221 in the fall though. Decently interesting course material, class isn't to hard either,preceptors are pretty helpful. My only complaint was that lectures pretty much reiterated the book (common in courses with professors teaching their own book), so you need to only go to lectureor read the book really.
Good class.
I had to take it but I'm glad that I did. It was interesting and Lex is an awesome professor.
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn more about fluid behavior, if only to an introductory extent.

I'd imagine if you're taking this class, it's because you have to, but it's certainly not the worst required class in the MAE department sophomore year.  Read if you want to, go to lectures if you want to be engaged, and don't be afraid to go to office hours if you have questions.
Interesting course and not difficult.
It is a difficult course with a difficult curve.
It's a fine course. Not great.
It's a good course if you are interested in fluid mechanics

Overall it was a worthwhile class. The workload is very manageable. Though the professor is not super available the help from preceptors is enough to get through the class. Its a very good intro to Fluid Mechanics!
Take it!
The course was good overall.  Very interesting material and pretty easy relative to other MAE classes.

The instruction is very good and the material is very interesting. I would definitely recommend this course to, like solid mechanics and E&M, introduce you to a basic example of physics applied to complex systems.
he is a good professor but it is a hard course.  exams are hard but not impossible.
required.
prereqs: MAT 104 and MAT 202. MAT 202 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Introduction to the physical and analytical description of phenomena associated with the flow of fluids. Topics include the principles of conservation of mass, momentum and energy; lift and drag; open channel flow; dynamic similitude; laminar and turbulent flow.

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Mathematics in Engineering I
reviews: A good introduction to East Asian history as analyzed and seen through literary works, film, and other media, which also happens to be a pretty enjoyable EM.

Absolutely take it if you're an engineer and if Kostin is teaching it, especially if you don't think you're going to have a chance to take PDE in your undergrad.  He goes over the basics of ordinary and partial differential equations at a very approachable level.  Also, I find myself to be a little bit more of a theory person and thought I would be disappointed, but I wasn't.  There was enough course material to keep everyone on the theory/applications spectrum satisfied
As a 300-level math class, and as useful knowledge for engineers, I recommend this class.  Kostin is a very good professor, and while not perfect, I had a good time in his class.
Ask around for opinions on the professor listed. Your experience in the course will vary widely.

Be ready for an intense start. The problem sets are longer than most, so budget your time accordingly. Expect the unexpected, and brush up on your previous math concepts. Finally, the professor is more approachable than he seems.
Do it, but stay on top of the material.
Don't take it unless required.
Engineer? Do this one. Don't need to fulfill a requirement? Why are you even looking at this?

Engineers have to take it, math majors will probably think that it's too easy (it is a math departmental though) and physics majors have already learned all the stuff in the class. So easy GPA booster for math lovers I guess.
Even though it's a common engineering requirement, an interesting course in its own right.  Morton Kostin has a great sense of timing in his lectures, which makes them almost entertaining.
Felt lost during the year, then felt very confident studying for final, then got spanked by final

If you are looking for a rigorous treatment of the mathematics of differential equations, this is probably not the course for you. If, however, you just want practical ways to solve them, then take this course. The quality of the course will vary greatly depending on your instructor, but as long as Stone teaches in the Fall and Kostin teaches in the Spring, you'll be set. Kostin has a very slow-paced style of lecturing, which might turn off some people but might be helpful to others as well. His sense of humor is subtle but hilarious if you get it. On a side note, this is definitely the least I have ever worked for a math class. I kind of wish I had more practice with the material, but the workload is extremely light. Don't sweat the pop quizzes too much.
If you have any interest or need the course, take it with professor Kostin.

If you need to take DiffEq, I would recommend this over the Math department course, because if you're considering which one you should take, you should probably not take the Math version. This class will actually teach you how to solve differential equations (a necessary skill for Physics/engineering), whereas the Math equivalent will have more to do with proving theory.

If you're considering taking this unnecessarily because you think you might like it, I say go for it. I really enjoyed this class and the material. If you feel good about calculus and linear algebra, and want to go on with math, do it.
Koatin is amazing
Kostin isn't terribly engaging but has his quirks and can be pretty entertaining. Material isn't hard to grasp. The final is hard and there is not really a lot of material to use to prepare for it.
Make sure you come to all the lectures!
Make sure you do well in the final.
Only take if you have to.

Professor Mortin has a rather low voice, so at times it was hard to hear him. Attending lecture is recommended since the professor gives pop quizzes. Since he gave them at random times during lecture, people would be in suspense quite often. He seemed to enjoy keeping his students in suspense. Overall, the man seemed like a helpful and sweet man. Though he probably took pleasure in watching us freak out, he made the effort to ensure that we understood the material.

Start problem sets early and work with other people in groups if you get stuck. Always go to lecture because there are pop quizzes and because the lectures present the material in a much more understandable format than the textbook.

Take Diff Eq with Kostin. It will be your best decision as an engineer. Although he's not the most exciting lecturer, his problem sets are way more straightforward than other Diff Eq professor's, and the final exam is not terrible. The pop in-class quizzes are generously graded and a much better alternative to a midterm exam.
Take it if you have to.. Not sure if it's worth your time to learn differential equations if you never use it again.
Take notes, even if you are really tired, because when he says they are the primary source he isn't kidding.
Take this course, it focuses on problem solving with a dabbling of theory.
There are pop quizzes in this class, which is never fun. Kostin is surprisingly funny sometimes, but otherwise there is not too much excitement.
This class is doable, but not the most enjoyable.
This is an essential class to take if you are interested in pursuing math and engineering.  Prof. Kostin makes the class enjoyable and he keeps the material applicable and not too theoretical.

great course!!
not too hard, good background on diff-equ
kostin is a boss!
take if you are a good note-taker.
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or 204.
descrip: A treatment of the theory of differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve problems in this field.

title: General Chemistry II
reviews: A good course overall but I don't really know why you'd take it unless it's it to fulfill a prereq.
Always go to the professors' office hours, utilize study groups and McGraw. Study a lot and read the book, and attend lectures!
Attend lectures - they are more helpful than reading the textbook.  Do the practice problems they post right before exams.
Chemistry is a basic science that everyone should know something about, and this is an interesting way to learn about it!
DO the problem sets.
Do practice problems! They're very helpful.
Do the problem sets!
Do the problem sets.  For the final, study the electrochemistry information primarily.
Don't hesitate to ask questions and answer them both in lecture and precept. Stay on top of the readings.
Don't procrastinate on problem sets and go to the TA office hours.  They are not that well attended so you get one-on-one help from the TA's, who are all amazing.
Don't take it unless you have to. It's a lot of work, Bocarsly is a bad lecturer, and there is no curve.
G
Get in Maria's precept.
Get your problem sets done early and pay attention in lecture.  You will miss important things if you skip.
Go to lecture and stay on top of the reading. There are no tricks to doing well in this course.
Go to precept.
Go to the McGraw center for questions.
Good for both science majors and those interested in taking a science.
I don't see a need to take this coures unless it is required of you for some reason.

I needed this course for CBE, so I had no choice. I personally felt that it wasn't that hard - the concepts were straightforward for the most part - but a lot of times I got the feeling that it was just one big pain in the neck - not being able to decipher what was wanted in problem sets, not having any reference other than lecture notes to decipher crystal field theory, etc. Not hard, just frustrating.

I took CHM 207 in the fall, and seemed like much of the material covered in 202 was also covered in 207 (since it is supposed to be a continuation of 201, not 207).  Besides that, this class was very interesting and a nice complement to the fall course.
I would advise a future student to keep up with readings rather than catch up.  I would also suggest finding a good study group to meet with on a weekly basis.
I would advise students to take the course. It is challenging but good.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is important to keep up with the readings.
I would only recommend this class for people who need to fulfill either a premed requirement or some sort of distribution requirement.

I would recommend this class in terms of the content of what we learned. I think that someone who like chemistry should take this class, but beware it is harder than high school chemistry and CHM 201. I also would advice them to always go to precept if Professor Bocarsly is still the lecturer (as I'm sure they'll figure out).
I would say that it is a great class to take that you will enjoy if you do the readings and the homework.
I would tell another student to always keep up with the homework and to work with others and to regularly attend lectures.
I would tell the student to take good lecture notes and review over them so that you actually understand the point of the lecture at the end.
I wouldn't take this unless you love chemistry or if you have to go to medical school. It was extremely dull and the psets were near impossible once you got to the 2nd half of the course.
If you have had AP chemistry the course will be fairly easy and somewhat review

If you have to take this class for a requirement, take it. But compared to CHM 201 you will have to put in a lot more work to get the same or worse results. Attend lectures, but you will also need to attend additional review sessions/office hours.
If you like chemistry and/or are thinking of studying chemistry, I would highly recommend taking this course. I found it very interesting and well organized, and really enjoyed the course overall.
If you need this course for CHM, pre-med, or other pursuits take it. Otherwise, it's fairly dry and unnecessary.
If you want or need to take this course, join a study group or make your own immediately. The information starts off easy, but the moment of confusion comes unexpectedly quickly, so be prepared.
It is what it is: for most people, it's just a requirement for med school, chem major, what have you. It's well-taught, though, and not graded on a curve, which is good or bad for you depending.
It was not exactly a fun course but it was usually interesting and sometimes enjoyable and that's good enough if you're a premed and have to take the class.
It's a basic Gen Chem course. I don't think any who is taking is doing it not as a prerequisite to something else.

It's a wonderful course, much better than CHM 201. If you take CHM 207, you will be well prepared. It's easier than CHM 215, but you learn the basic nuts and bolts of general chemistry and it's the fun half of the year! It's a lot of hard work, but it is do-able. Enjoy it if you decide to take it.
It's an OK course, take it if you need it for a pre-requisite.
Its general chemistry if you have to take it take it. Otherwise I think there are better courses for one to take.
Keep up on the lectures and readings.
Keep up with the readings and go to precepts.
Lectures are frustrating, but the rest of the course is really just fine.
Make sure not to fall behind in reading and attend all lectures.
Make sure to read the chapters and see your teachers for help (esp. for acids/bases)
Make sure you know how to solve problem set questions. Go to extra help (McGraw, office hours etc)
Make sure you pay a lot of attention to the parts of lecture that aren't in the book or you'll find yourself extremely confused.
Make sure you study the materials as you go along.
Make sure you understand what comes up on the problem sets and practice problems - they will be just like the exams. Concentrate on the math.

Most of you will take this course because it is a requirement, so this isn't much of a choice. But if you took CHM 207 like I did and wanted to continue learning about general chemistry, go for this course!
Need to be on top of things, go to every lecture.
Only take it if its necessary definitely not for just a distribution requirement.
Only take this course if you have to or if you have a lot of time to dedicate to this material.
Pay attention in lectures! The book doesn't help too much.
Problem-based learning is the most effective. Only take it if you really need to, though.
Read text before class
Read the textbook before lecture because otherwise lectures will only confuse you more.
Read the textbook. Attend lecture. Go to precept, and above all else go to the McGraw review sessions.

Reading the textbook and paying attention in lectures will help! Also, attend class because Professor Bocarsly might give out vital information regarding the midterm or exam! And get to know Professor Bocarsly and Professor L'Esperance. They're really cool, especially when you see them out of class.
Should take.
Start studying for tests early. Only take this course if you have to.
Stay on top of things. Material isn't difficult, just don't fall behind.
Study groups are so helpful.  I feel that I did better in this class because of my study group and really working hard on the problem sets.
Study!
Study.  Read the textbook (or at least skim it).  Start problem sets at least a day or two before they're due; you'll be happy about it the night before when you're done.
Take advantage of McGraw. It is so helpful!
Take it because you have to. If you have AP Chemistry credit, don't take general chemistry. If not, you're stuck with it.

Take it if you are interested in chemistry or think you might be interested in it.
Go to office hours and seek help when you are struggling with something. 
There are so many resources for help available--office hours, review sessions, TAs, McGraw review sessions--that if you are willing to put in the effort, you will do well and come to love chemistry.
Take it if you are interested in science, not if you are fulfilling an ST requirement.

Take it if you have to. If you are interested in chemistry and/or passionate about it, this class shouldn't be that bad. But for those that are learning chemistry for the first time like me, it will take quite a bit of work.
Take it if you have to. No real reason to take a 7hr/week class otherwise.
Take it only if you have to
Take it. Don't be turned off by CHM 201; CHM 202 is much better.
Take only if interested or needed.
Take this class if you need a gen chemistry overview.  If you feel very strong in chemistry, I don't know if this necessary.
Take this class if you want to learn chemistry.  It is taught by good proffessors.
Take this course only if you need to for premed or departmentals

The course is good if you're willing to put in time before tests to really understand the material. Even though I didn't, it's helpful to read the textbook before going to lecture and keep up with all the readings, if possible.
The general information in this class is good to know, and the course itself isn't particularly hard. It is tedious, however, if you're not interested in the subject.
The professors in this course a phenomenal. There could not be a better general chemistry class.
This course is soo good!  The class isn't on a curve, so tests are incredibly fair.  Everybody in the staff for the course wants you to do well and they all do all they can to make sure you do.

Try to read the book before lectures. And really go to lectures because Professor surely puts in material from the lectures in the exams that are not actually covered in the book. The problem sets are easy, the exam is definitely harder than the problem sets. It is really a good course to have under your belt before moving on to higher Chem courses, unless you have had a very strong Chem training before.

Ummmm.... It's hard to judge what is going to be on the final exam. Therefore have alot of leadway before taking the exam. In other words try to make sure you already have at least 650 points before taking the exam.
Work hard. Do the work.
Work on the problem sets in groups
You probably have to for many reasons. It's not bad, some is really interesting. Dr. L'Esperance is really awesome. The nicest and most genuine teacher I've met here.
don't take it. take all of your pre med reqs somewhere else.
go to mcgraw review sessions...they were long, but really helped me to understand some concepts that would have taken a lot of guessing (inefficiency) otherwise.
it is a course that will definitely introduce you to some important concepts of chemistry. however, it will not convince you , or make you fall in love with chem.
its hard and boring only take if u have to

meet with your TA outside of precept. they are an excellent resource.  I don't think a recommendation really applies with this course, because everyone taking it is either pre-med or a potential science major who has to take it.
take good notes.
prereqs: This course is a continuation of CHM 201; also open to CHM 207 students. Calculus not required..
descrip: Continuation of 201. Principles of chemistry; introduction to chemical bonding and solid state structure; chemical kinetics, descriptive inorganic chemistry; laboratory manipulations, preparations, and analysis. Fulfills medical school entrance requirements in general chemistry and qualitative analysis. Three lectures, one class, one three-hour laboratory..

title: Mapping Knowledge
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Democratic Theory and Public Policy
descrip: We will examine policy-making in the contemporary American political system, focusing on two broad models--one emphasizing majoritarian aggregation of public preferences and the other emphasizing power, preference intensity, and bargaining. We will consider the normative foundations, logical coherence, and empirical veracity of each of these models and assess their utility as theories of democratic policy-making.

title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
reviews: Definitely not as bad as its rumored to be.  It might be the new set of professors though.  Lab time is very relaxed and even fun...often time you can even do work for other classes or start analyzing data while in class.  Do not be intimidated, but definitely ask older CHE's what experiments are the best/easiest and try to get those to do with your group.
Good luck :)

I would advise the student to stay on top of the work and make sure that they don't leave the data analysis for the last minute.  The course moves fast, especially after spring break, and so there is no time to fall behind.
Of course, this is a class that you have to take for CBE, but I would recommend these professors.

Of course, you have to take it as a ChemE. Just keep in mind that this is the closest you will get to independent experimental research experience in a course at Princeton, and try to get the most out of it.
Stay on top of deadlines and put a lot of effort into this course.
Talk to upperclassmen before taking this course- it is going to suck but you will get a lot out of it
The course is a lot of work but highly invaluable. You will put in a lot of time and effort and undergo a lot of stress, but you will come out feeling it was worth it.
This course will be the craziest thing you will experience. Take only 3 other courses while taking this, and pick your partner ASAP!!!!
You don't really have a choice, now do you? =P
You must must must choose a good partner.
take it and work hard.
prereqs: CHE 246/CBE 246 and CHE 341/CBE 341 or equivalents..
descrip: An intensive hands-on practice of engineering. Experimental work in the areas of separations, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, process dynamics and control, materials processing and characterization, chemical reactors. Development of written and oral technical communication skills.

title: Intermediate Hebrew II
reviews: Definitely a great course to take if you are looking to fulfill a language. I feel like I could easily carry on a Hebrew conversation after a semester of this class!
I greatly enjoyed this class, and I would recommend it to everyone.
esther rules
good course
prereqs: HEB 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Completion of two-year textbook, Ha-Yesod, and reading and discussion of selected additional texts (newspaper, stories, poems, etc.) Extensive practice in conversation, writing and reading and tasting Hebrew literature.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: Be on your A-game! You cannot skim by in this class because grammar and your participation DOES count!

Be prepared to make a short film in Spanish for your final project.  Write your discussion board posts in advance so you have time to edit them.  Enjoy the great films on display! Alberto is very kind, considerate, and a great teacher.
Get the book "Looking at movies" and skim through it before the end of the term. It would TOTALLY help you with the final movie project!
If you want to watch some great Spanish language films and practice conversation, great course.
Take this course! It's interesting and your spanish gets a lot better.
The course is amazing simply by the reading list and the professor is amazing. However, the success of the course is determined by how interested and dedicated the students are.

This class is great. Take it if you have any interest in Spanish, Latin Culture, or great films. Alberto is also an amazing teacher. There is a fair amount of work, but it is entirely doable. Just don't leave watching the movies until the last second!
prereqs: SPA 108 or SPA 207 in addition to instructor's permission. Please email Alberto Bruzos Moro (abruzos@princeton.edu)..
descrip: A course designed to improve oral and writing skills, while significantly increasing students' knowledge of cultural affairs in an ever changing Hispanic world. A significant amount of time will be dedicated to intensive debate on a wide variety of topics presented in films. Students interested in contemporary cinema may find this course especially enlightening. The grammar component of the course aims to ease the path to a more fluent communication in Spanish. The diversity of Hispanic culture is presented from the standpoint of a selected number of film directors.

title: Read Like an Egyptian II: Continuing Middle Egyptian
prereqs: Prerequisite COM 222, or equivalent..
descrip: A continuation of "Read Like an Egyptian" (COM 222, Fall '10), with extensive work on The Middle Egyptian verbal system. In addition to the standard work necessary in a classical language course, this course will explore further relations between Middle Egyptian and the cultures of the ancient Nile Valley. Students will read an ancient Egyptian classic, "The Tale of Shipwrecked Sailor."

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: This meets your governmental requirement, so take it, and make sure you have a record of it so that you won't have to take it again. Interesting topics at times.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Engineering Dynamics
reviews: Don't take it

It's like physics on steroids for engineers.  If you like understanding physical situations and how things move, you'll love this class.  It's hard going at first until you understand the intricacies of Kasdin's sometimes frustrating and pointlessly complicated notation, but eventually you understand why it has to be that way.  It's all about understanding things on a practical level.  Not easy, and sometimes things go against intuition, but a generally excellent class.
Learn how to write exactly as Kasdin does. If you can do that, you can do well in the course.
Start your problem sets over the weekend so you can go to tuesday precept and you don't have to scramble to get them in by Friday.
Take it!

This is BY FAR the best 200-course in the MAE department. Don't blow off this class because there's just so much to be learned. Kasdin's a great professor - his book/methods/notation/concepts are all clear, in order, and just plain interesting and there's always help if you need it. This was my favorite class sophomore year - enjoy it.
You have to take if you are in it.
its a lecture you will want to go to but not a class you should take unless you are an MAE
you learn very interesting physics and feel pretty confident after getting through it all. just BEWARE of Kasdin's book's notation
prereqs: MAT 201 and PHY 103 and MAE 223 or CEE 205. Freshmen may take the course with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Formulation and solution of equations governing the dynamic behavior of engineering systems. Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics. Two and three dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies. Motion relative to moving reference frames. Impulse-momentum and work-energy relations. Free and forced vibrations of mechanical systems. Introduction to dynamic analysis of mechanical devices and systems.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of ORF 509. Each student writes a report and presents research results. For doctoral students, the course must be completed one semester prior to taking the general examinations.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: N/A
Take it.
take it
descrip: oh, dear

title: The Just Society
