reviews: Don't take this class if you are not interested in political theory/reading what a bunch of men think society should be like (in very many words).
Good political theory course, not too difficult but readings are challenging. Could be improved by a bit more variety in the readings.

I think this course is good if you haven't read the stuff already and economic justice is interesting to you. But if there are more engaging lectures in your list options of I would definitely opt for those.
I would recommend it. It would be a good class to PDF because it was hard to gauge how well I was doing in the class until I got my grades on big assignments.

I would recommend the course because it provides a solid foundation for thinking about issues such as justice and inequality. I will also say two things:

1) Realize that this course is mostly theory, not application.  You will mostly discuss justice in the abstract, weighing the pros and cons of particular systems of justice proposed by philosphers such as John Locke, Karl Marx, J.S. Mill, Robert Nozick, John Rawls, etc.

2)Freshmen: It's possible to do well in this course, although it is much easier if you have some background in philsophy, or are at least used to constructing logical arguments.  I thought that my reasoning skills improved as the course progressed; the class definitely provides a lot of opportunity for growth.

I would strongly recommend students to take this course, both as an introduction to political theory, a way to elucidate their own ethical principles, and as an investigation into the principles of justice.
I would strongly recommend this course.
I would tell a student considering this course to take the course, read the readings, and to be ready to make arguments about the readings.

If you're familiar with the subject, and have already read a lot of Locke and Marx, the class might be rather repetitive. Even so, Professor Patten focuses more on interpretation than many other POL professors I've had; though the course description looks kind of generic and not too interesting, there's a lot to get out of the class, especially if you have Prof. Patten for precept.
If you're looking for a good political theory class, this is it.
Interesting course. It really presents the leading thinkers in economic philosophy and guides the debate while not forcing any conclusions on you.
It is a very good EM.

TAKE THIS COURSE. 
PROFESSOR PATTEN IS AN AMAZING LECTURE. 
he was the best lecturer i had that semester- I also had Prof. Flower for history, so that's saying something. Patten is interested in the stuff he teaches (cuz it's interesting), and it shows through in the lectures. The papers are pretty straightforward and basic. The Marx quiz is not as tough as you'd expect- just though-provoking. Regardless of my grade, this Oxford man knows what he's talking about, critically thinks justice through, and you'll like it.
Take only if you're interested in the topic and/or want a solid class to P/D/F
Take this course- enjoy theory.
There are better courses out there

This class is pretty important for students who are thinking about majoring in politics and political theory in particular. The thinkers covered here are among the most influential. It is not really necessary to have taken other POL courses before this one.
This is a good class to get a distribution requirement from.
This is a good overview of the major thinkers in political philosophy and property rights. If you have taken much political theory before, however, I would skip it.
Would recommend if you are interested in philosophy - even if you're not sure, it's a great way to test it out! Not too intense, but a fair amount of work. Keep up with the readings!
You should take this class if you are interested in learning a few different perspectives on economic justice.
do all the readings, they're worth it.  as lewis was quoted by professor patten:  the purpose of philosophy is to raise the cost of beliefs.
descrip: An introduction to theories of social justice and examination of their implications in areas of contemporary social and political controversy. The first half of the course introduces the problem of social justice and examines two classic positions, as articulated by John Locke (whose name is associated with liberalism, property, and capitalism) and Karl Marx (whose name is associated with the critique of capitalism). The second half of the course focuses on contemporary theories of justice. We will read authors such as John Rawls and Robert Nozick, and examine controversies over poverty, taxation, equal opportunity, and environmental justice.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Climate, Air Pollution, Toxics, and Water
prereqs: The course is required for students who wish to pursue the Environmental Studies certificate program; these students cannot enroll under the p/d/f option..
descrip: This course will focus on environmental consequences of human activities and their interactions with natural systems. Beginning with underlying principles, we will consider the social, political, economic, scientific and technical dimensions of four areas of environmental concern: the atmosphere (atmospheric pollution, its sources and prevention); climate (climate and climate variability; models and public policy); toxics in the environment (pollutants, remediation and solutions); and water resources (water-sheds, land use, climate effects, political issues).

title: Modeling Tools for Cell and Developmental Biology
descrip: Mathematical models of complex natural phenomena can organize large amounts of data, provide access to properties that are difficult or impossible to measure experimentally, and suggest new experimental tests of proposed regulatory mechanisms. Participants will demonstrate these ideas in the context of cell and developmental biology. Using a number of well-established experimental systems, such as dynamic instability of microtubules and circadian clocks, course introduces stochastic and deterministic models of reaction and diffusion processes and computational methods for their analysis.

title: Economic Development II
reviews: Professor Easterly has a specific style of development economics. This course is a good course for learning general lessons but he does not go into details. The classes of Professor Case were excellent and she managed to give both great general knowledge to know as researchers and also she gave useful tips for the details.
Recommend
prereqs: ECO 562.
descrip: Selected topics in the economic analysis of development beyond those covered in 562. Topics are selected from the theory and measurement of poverty and inequality; the relationship between growth and poverty; health and education in economic development; saving, growth, population, and development; commodity prices in economic development.

title: The Sociology of Crime and Punishment
reviews: If you are interested in the material, it's worth taking.  Skip it otherwise; it's not inherently an exceptional course.
If you are interested in the subject of crime, punishment, and American criminal justice policy, this is a fantastic class.

If you have any interest in criminology, sociology, or the criminal justice system more generally, definitely take this class. Professor Chancer is pretty good at leading discussions, very good at explaining the theories, and is extremely well connected.
If you love criminology or are even mildly curious about it, definitely take this course. The work load is reasonable and the material very interesting!

If you're interested in the subject matter, this is a great course! Professor Chancer doesn't assume that you have a sociological background and teaches from the most basic material and gradually  works the course into more specific areas of interest.
TAKE IT! Professor Chancer is so nice!
descrip: This course seeks to provide a sociological account of crime and punishment. Why do people commit crime? How should we respond to crime? How has crime policy changed over the past several decades? What are the consequences of recent crime policy? By reading classic and contemporary sociological research, policy analysis, and media coverage, we will explore the themes of crime and punishment in contemporary society.

title: Main Street, USA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Organic Chemistry II with Biological Emphasis
reviews: A decent amount of work and can be very hard if you don't keep up.

Although I know freshman who did very well in this class, I expect that I did not. I would not recommend this freshman year, and if you do, do your best to take other easier classes so you have enough time for it.

They give you more materials and resources than any other class - just make sure you have time to use them!!

Are you a premed/mol bio/chem major? Don't take this class in conjunction with other difficult courses (I took it with MAT 202 and COS 126). If you are not one of the above majors, why in the world do you want to take orgo?
Attend all the lectures, do all the problem sets, participate in precept, and most importantly, attend every review session!

Compared to other courses I've taken, I think this is one class that wants you to do as well as you can and will offer a plethora of resources to help you do it.  But ultimately, it's as much work as you're willing to put into it. DO practice papers! And do as many as you have time to do. Only consult the textbook when you don't understand something, but don't use it as the main guide - the lecture notes are the most important.
Difficult but interesting.
Do NOT take this class. Seriously. Take it over the summer if you're pre-med.

Do not take this course unless absolutely necessary. Way harder than first semester. DO NOT DOUBLE UP ON SCIENCES EITHER. This and mol bio is awful. Also, those students in one course but not the other will ruin the curves for you.
Do practice problems.
Don't fall behind!
Don't let yourself fall behind.  If you feel yourself starting to drift, get help IMMEDIATELY!

Don't take it if you don't have to.  It's not easy and it's pretty boring if you aren't interested in organic chemistry.  It was definitely a struggle and if I wasn't pre-med I would not have taken it.
Don't take it if you don't need to.  It's as simple as that.
Don't take it unless you have to. Do the practice tests

Don't take it unless you're very motivated and are willing to put a lot of time into it.  GRADING POLICY SUCKS and lends itself to procrastination/lack of motivation since you can drop an exam if you're doing well, then have your grade turned upside down by the final because other people who do well on the final and haven't done well all semester can steal your A's.  This system really needs to be changed.  (But not this semester since I need to do well on the final...)

Fellow athletes/non-cutthroat students: take over the summer, if you have to take it at all.  All of your classes, health and performance in non-academic fields will suffer as a result of just trying not to fail this course.
Go over practice exams and STUDY.
Go to lectures and precepts. Do the practice exams (conscientiously).
Go to reviews - they help a lot.

I assume if you're taking Orgo it's because you have to for some reason or another. Honestly I enjoyed Semmelhack's style; there's not THAT much "biological emphasis" (some sugar chemistry and proteins is about it), and his notes/practice exams are super helpful in preparing for exams.

I loved this course.  It has been my favorite course so far here at Princeton and I recommend anyone who likes chemistry to take it.  But, you must make sure to attend lecture and also complete all of the reading in the textbook.

I personally loved this course but I know that this won't be the case for many students. If you give organic chemistry the respect it deserves that I have no doubt you will find this course to be rewarding.

I would advise students taking this course to make sure to work on practice problems and not to hesitate to take advantage of helpful TAs or review sessions to completely undertstand the material. Yes, at (most)times the course may be frustrating, but everyone wants to see you succeed in this course, and you just have to be proactive to take advantage the help that's available!
I would advise the student to study for the exams by working through the old exams provided.
I would recommend the course to another student. I particularly enjoyed seeing the connections between biology and the mechanisms that we were learning in class.
I would tell students that if they can see past the competitiveness of this course, then I think they would really enjoy it.

If you are considering taking this course, you have to take it. If you have to take it, do yourself a huge favor and study the material ahead of time. Study the concepts before they are taught in class. It will make all of the time you have to spend on this class much more worth it.
If you love chem, go for it. Otherwise, good luck.

If you put in the time on orgo, it will absolutely pay off and will change the way you think about chemistry. Orgo can be much more than just a premed requirement, and can actually be quite enjoyable if you think of it as a puzzle.
If you're a science major, this is a great course to take.

If you're considering taking this class.. you pretty much have to anyways.

Work at it alot and learn the style of Semmelhack's exams.

If you're interested in biology, take this course over Sorensen's. Sorensen's course from what I could tell based off of friends focuses entirely on synthesis and spends a ton of time on the Diels-Alder reaction. You'll learn the same material in this class, and it'll be more of the same from first semester in terms of teaching and exams.

If you're willing to invest time in this course, it is definitely manageable (and you may even find yourself liking some of the material). For exams, I would recommend going over the lecture notes, reading Organic Chemistry as a Second Language II (as opposed to the Sorrell textbook), and completing all of the practice exams from previous years. I would also recommend going to the weekly McGraw review sessions, especially if they're held by Keith Reber (he's awesome!).
It is far too much work to have your GPA get destroyed. Even the people who have As in this class hate it.
It's not that hard!

It's pretty much a continuation of 303, so if you did well in 303 just keep doing what you did and if you did not do so well now's the chance to learn from your mistakes and improve. Lectures continue at the same quick pace and the textbook is still pretty useful (I even used it as a substitute for Semmelhack's lectures 2/3 of the time, and it worked pretty well). Lab will probably seem easier now due to the experience, but the lab reports just get longer and more tedious. The exams get harder as well, but this is probably just a reflection of the nature of the material (304 is all about mechanisms, so the latter end of 303 is a good foundation if you were solid with Sn1/Sn2/E1/E2 stuff). You get less than half the number of practice exams as you got in 303...which could be a good or bad thing depending on how you look at it. Overall, though, there isn't that much difference between 303 and 304 in terms of workload, pace, etc.
It's very demanding, but very satisfying by the end of the semester when it all comes together. Be prepared to put a lot of time into it.
Keep up with the lectures!
Less conceptual than first semester

Material is very interesting, but the whole "orgo" aspect and pre-med aspect of it makes it hard to enjoy. Keep up with the work and attend as many precepts / review sessions / etc. as possible to actually learn the material.
Not as bad a people say - don't be intimidated.
Only take it if you absolutely have to.
Recommended if you are interested in chemistry or molecular biology.

Review your notes after lecture by comparing them to the readings and do the problem sets. Also have a study group or somebody who has taken Orgo before, so you have people to talk to. Most importantly, don't procrastinate studying.
Study hard outside of class.
Study hard, do all the work, practice exams.
Super hard! Study!
Take it because you probably have to.
Take it seriously and do the work. The TAs and professors are fantastic but you have to work!
Take this course if you've already taken 303B. The problem sets don't count, Semmelhack is a great lecturer, and it is overall a very interesting course.
The course is very difficult.  I would not recommend anyone who is not interested in science to take this course.  For those who are, it could prove to be very intellectually stimulating.
The practice examinations are very helpful.

Very challenging, especially synthesis problems. Keep very good notes, and organize your notes according to mechanism, e.g. all the different ways you can make a N-C bond, different oxidation techniques and when they can be used, etc. Keep up with the problem sets and do all the practice tests and precept handouts, because problem-solving practice is the core of this class. If you put the time into it, you will learn a lot, and you can't really get by without putting the time in anyway. Not as much of an emphasis on memorization, but you do need to be familiar with a lot of different mechanisms to do well.
Very difficult course, but you learn a lot.

While a difficult class, this course is very rewarding. If you want to learn more about the biological applications of organic chemistry, I would definitely recommend this course. It is taught very well and memorization is not the focus.
You have to take it anyway...
it's tough, but if you learn the material it's fascinating
you get what you put into it
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303. Course is open to freshmen..
descrip: The concepts introduced in CHM 303 will be extended to the structures and reactions of more complex molecules, with an emphasis on how organic chemistry provides the framework for understanding molecular processes in biology. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry will be illustrated, as often as possible, with examples drawn from biological systems. Appropriate for chemistry and engineering majors, premedical students, and students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Critics of Modern America, 1880-1960
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or http://www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Special Topics in Dance History, Criticism, and Aesthetics - Choreography for the American Musical
reviews: Good, but only take this class if you have previous background in dance!

I would recommend this class to other students with a suggestion: Do the readings! It will serve you well in terms of participating in class and writing papers. Also, I would say having some dance experience would definitely be recommended. Some of the material is quite challenging. But there were some people who didn't have much experience and they got through it, so take it if you're genuinely interested in the material also, but just be aware that the material can be slightly difficult at times.
The dancing part and seeing the musicals for free is pretty cool

You definitely need prior dance training if you want to take this class - there's a lot of challenging stuff, but it's really fun and probably very helpful if you're thinking of going into musical theater later. If you're willing to put up with the ridiculous amount of writing, go for it!
descrip: This course examines the history of American musical theater dance through lecture/discussion and a studio component involving musical theater dance classes. The study traces the genre's evolution through a variety of venues including: spectacle, vaudeville, musicals and revues. A primary focus of the course is the period referred to as The Golden Age of the American musical (1943-1964). How choreographers emerging from newly formed modern and ballet companies changed the function of dance in musicals and exposed commercial audiences to cultural trends and social commentary through the language dance is a focus of the course.

title: Screenwriting Topics: Writing in Space (Greece)
prereqs: Application through the Creative Writing Program or Permission of Instructor. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Can the emotional fabric of a world, a space, or a country be adapted into a work for the screen? Can a cultural space be used as the source material in the same way that a literary text could be used to create a screenplay adaptation? Using Greece and Greek culture as a source of inspiration, students will explore their own approach of transposing a physical and metaphorical space into the fabric of a short film/screenplay. Traditional screen adaptations of memoirs, novels, and plays taking place in Greece will be used as filmic study-texts. An intermediate course in screenwriting technique, also open to beginners.

title: The Economics of Education
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 302 and MAT 102, or MAT 103.
descrip: This course will use economic concepts to analyze the relationship between education and economic performance, at both the individual and aggregate level. It will also use economic and statistical tools to evaluate various education policy options. These range from long-standing debates about class size to the controversy surrounding the No Child Left Behind legislation. To that end, the course will familiarize students with contemporary education institutions, enable students to apply economic and statistical tools to questions arising from these institutions, and enable students to evaluate education policy options.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews: A definite must for any Princeton student.
A good way to get acquainted with basic economic principals. This is not a course, however, really intended for students with a serious interst in economics. Very much an introductory course.
A great class everyone should take in order to be an informed citizen of the world.
A great class for absolutely anyone who is interested in macroeconomics.
A great overview of economics that every student should be familiar with.
A solid introduction to Macro. Definitely take it with Blinder.
Assigned readings should be done on a weekly basis if you want to do well.
Attend all lectures, each is very important and they build off of one another.
Attend lectures. It helps you understand the material so much better.
BUY THE BOOK! Especially if you don't have a basic understanding of econ. Especially since it's written by Blinder, whatever he says in class will correlate exactly with the book.
Be sure to do all the readings.
Blinder is a GREAT professor and I highly recommend him. The exams aren't impossible, but sitting through precept is. If you keep up with the readings, you don't need to ever attend precept.
Blinder is a coherent lecturer, though sometimes he can be rather simplistic.  Be sure to get a good preceptor- some of them are not the most skilled at teaching/explaining concepts.
Blinder is good, but if you can, skip out of macro and take a higher level micro course.
Continue to review throughout the semester rather than waiting until the end.

Definitely take ECO 100 before this class. I think 100 to 101 is the right order because micro is helpful for macro whereas I do not think this is true the other way around. Its not necessary but it certainly helped.
Definitely take Macroeconomics, if not only to get a better sense of the economy on a larger scale and what's going on in the world.
Definitely take this course.
Definitely take with Blinder.
Do all the readings.
Do not get Meixia Zhang as a preceptor. Alan Blinder is not all that's hyped up to be, lectures were quite dull and boring.  So if you're doing this just because Blinder's teaching it, think twice!
Do the reading and keep up with it. Do not forget to read the book AND the pequod packet readings.
Do the reading, go to lecture.
Do the readings
Do the readings before you do the problem sets! You will be able to do the problem sets so much faster.
Do the readings!
Do the readings! At the end of the semester it can get really daunting if you put all of it off -- don't! It's not too much to keep up with if you're conscientious about it from the beginning.

Do the readings, and go to McGraw. Possibly look into tutors because there is no guarantee that you will be able to understand your preceptor. The lectures are good, but you have to do so much more to do well. If you don't have any prior background in economics, and you are not mathematically inclined, the class will be a struggle no matter what you do. But it is extremely interesting and important.
Do the readings.
Do the readings. Go to lecture. If you don't fall behind the class is very manageable.

Do your reading early and ask questions. If you need a tutor early on, GET ONE. Most helpful thing ever. Make sure you understand you the material to begin with, AND:

Make sure you are confident in your arithmetic. I suck at it, and I paid dearly for it on the exam.
Do your research about preceptors and try and read the text book
Don't fall asleep in lecture and don't lose focus in lecture. If you follow and understand the concepts in lecture you'll do great.
Econ 101 isn't really a class you take for fun. But taught by Blinder it's interesting and you get a good grasp of the material.
Everybody should have at least somewhat of an understanding of the recent recession.  Therefore, I recommend taking this course even if you are not planning on being an economics major.
Excellent beginner's economics course.
For a basic understanding of economics, yes.
For both concentrators and non-concentrators, ECO 101 will inevitably be extremely interesting and useful due to its frequent references to current events.
Get help outside the course right away, especially if you have trouble gaining anything from precepts.  It's a good class though, take it!
Go to lectures, but you can get away with skipping precept if you do the readings. The problem sets are easy (but tedious) and the midterm was fine.
Good course.
Good knowledge to have and a good introduction to economics.
Great
Great class!
Great class.
Great course! I understand policy issues so much better.
I can't vouch for other professors, but Blinder was great and made lectures really interesting and relevant.  You'll have to read the textbook to really understand what he's talking about.
I definitely recommend other students to take this class. If definitely provides you with the basics of macroeconomics.
I feel that everyone should have some sort of background in macroeconomics which is why I personally took the course.
I learned so much about the recent economic recession and financing in general.  Everyone should have to take Macro with Blinder before they graduate!  He is an awesome lecturer.

I picked up this class as my fifth course because I thought it would be interesting.  Do not underestimate the amount of time needed for the class.  The class will go much better for you if you dedicate an appropriate amount of time to it, go to lecture, and do the readings.
I really enjoyed this course. It's a worthwhile course to take even if it means the only benefit you get is being able to understand newspaper articles much more clearly.
I recommend the course to anyone, regardless if they're interested in economics or not. It definitely helps widen your worldview.
I would advise them to go to as many lectures as you can and to go to precept often in order to learn basic concepts.
I would definitely recommend the course as Blinder was a great professor and the material is interesting.
I would have loved econ had I been any better at it; I must recommend because I do not regret pdfing it to attain that general knowledge that I strived for.
I would highly recommend this course as I feel the concepts learned in this class are useful and practical for a basic understanding of how our global world works.

I would highly recommend this course because it is both interesting and relevant.  Don't bother buying the main text unless you have a lot of problems understanding the material presented in lecture; it's cheaper to use the textbooks on reserve in the library.
I would only take this course if you are inherently interested in economics. Otherwise, take microeconomics, which seems to have less work
I would recommend this course for common knowledge and as a distribution requirement.

I would recommend this course if you're somewhat interested in econ.  It really helps in terms of understanding a lot of the things going on in the news today.  Lectures aren't incredibly interesting, but Blinder gives you all of the info.  Precept is boring and essentially optional because the problem sets are incredibly easy.
I would recommend this if you are interested in econ/want to gain an idea of how our economy works. Really helped me in understanding the financial crisis and what is meant by inflation/recession.
I would recommend to other students

I would say that macro is an important knowledge to know in life. For this I would recommend the course. But I would recommend to my friends that they check out books from the library on economics because their preceptors probably won't speak English well, and therefore, you can expect not to get any help from them.

I would say the course was solid. Theres nothing here that would deter you from taking the course if you are interested in it. If you like econ or are interested, 101 with Blinder is a good course that you will enjoy.

I would suggest that every freshman student be required to take this class. It has taught me so much about what is going on in the world today and showed me that economics is a far more dimensional topic than i had originally thought. the workload is 100 percent managable just dont fall behind on the reading.

I would tell them to do the readings and attend class because they are interesting, and I would recommend this course to anyone because it provides valuable, applicable information. If you work hard, you can do well.

I wouldn't take this class unless you're going to major in it and are dedicated to doing ALL of the weekly readings   article readings.  The course itself isn't too hard if you put in the time, but unless you are seriously considering a concentration in economics or a finance certificate, you will just feel disinterested in this class.

I'm amazed people can fail this course.  It's interesting, the professor's great, the workload is a little too light, but you can read deeper into things with a little effort.  Blinder kindly will stick around after EVERY lecture to go the extra mile with interested students.  He's the BEST!!!  Oh, and bring a super soaker water gun with you to class to spray the streakers - they're super annoying.
If Prof. Blinder is teaching - take it. You'll be glad you did. Make sure you do the readings!

If students are interested in Macroeconomics with a heavy emphasis on the U.S. economy, I would recommend this class, though the Macroeconomics course typically taught by Prof. Bogan in the fall semester seems to have been focused more on international economies in comparison if that is the student's area of interest.  Overall, the class is interesting and worth putting effort into.
If they want to learn about macro!
If you are interested in economics but don't have any background in it, this course will give you a good introduction.
If you are interested in economics, you need to take this class.
If you are not a liberal arts major, don't take it.
If you don't wish to pursue economics past this class, I would take it P/D/F.
If you dont like to read dont take this class
If you get a bad preceptor figure out a different one to go to, otherwise don't go. Work load is really easy though, you just have to study a lot for exams, unless you're PDFing.
If you have general interest in this sort of thing, then definitely! If you know nothing about econ this should be beneficial for your life indeed

If you want a general knowledge of macro this class is for you. And is typically taught by a high profile professor. Which is really cool. The problem sets are easy if tedious and the tests were really straightforward. If you study you will do well.
If you want to be able to read and understand today's newspapers....Take this course!!!
If you're considering becoming an Economics major, take this class.
If you're interested in macro, take it.  Professor Blinder is a good, clear lecturer (albeit not the most objective).  Make sure you do the readings, because he'll ask about them on tests.
Interesting and pretty easy to understand, valuable information for understanding the world.
Interesting course if your into economics.
It was a nice course that gave me an understanding of basic concepts, but could have been more stimulating.
It's a good class, take it if you're remotely interested in Econ or in understanding politics etc.
It's a good idea to read the textbook before lectures!  I would certainly recommend taking this class with Blinder; he does a great job of keeping lectures simple, organized, and relevant.
It's a good intro class, not excpetional.

It's a solid course. It's not much work. It's well taught and relevant to a complete understanding of the world. Be sure to read diversely because Professor Blinder gets a bit biased from time to time. I would recommend taking it though.
It's an average Princeton course.
It's an easy class to do well in because it's really straightforward. If you keep up with all assignments, which are very manageable, you can do very well.
It's pretty easy.
Its intro macroeconomics; you get what you signed up for, and if you take the class seriously, you will find it more fruitful than one might originally imagine.
Just take it. It's easy, it's informative, it takes out an SA.
Keep on top of the readings.
Keep up with readings, and make sure you understand the problem sets as you do them, instead of just doing them. Take this course.
Keep up with the material.
Keep up with the readings and attend as many lectures as possible.
Keep up with the readings.
Keep up with work and do well on problem sets.

Learning macroeconomics from Alan Blinder is a unique opportunity.  If you are interested in the material, take his class.  However, if you are not interested in economics, I wouldn't strongly recommend it.
Lectures are great, precepts are alright, the workload is not terrible. Macro teaches you a lot of useful life skills that will help you now and in the future.
Listen to Blinder and take good notes. Do the readings. It is a very interesting course, especially the information about the recent financial crisis.
Make sure to be careful of small mistakes on your problem sets; there are many places to mess up sometimes. Read lots before exams.
Make sure to read the textbook.
Make sure to stay caught up with the textbook reading - it will help understand lectures and finish the problem sets more quickly
Make sure you do the textbook readings and pay attention in lecture.
Make sure you keep a general understanding of what's happening or the dean's date paper will be confusing.

Need to take this just to understand what you hear in the news.
Neutral

Not a difficult course at all, a good experience and a chance to take a course with one of Princeton's most esteemed professors.
Not that much work, interesting material.
Read text at beginning of each week.
Shop preceptors, if your preceptor doesn't suite your learning style unofficially go to a different one.
Should be taken at some point in 1st 4 semesters, preferably 1st or 2nd
Stay on top of the readings.
Stay on top of the work load. It is not a lot but you will not gain as much from the lectures if you fall behind in the work outside the classroom.
TAKE IT
Take Eco 101 with Blinder, but PDF if you're not majoring in Econ
Take economics 100 before 101 - it is easier to learn basic economics concepts on a micro rather than a macro level.
Take if you're interested in econ, or if you want to understand what happened in the financial crisis, but don't expect to be excited to go to lecture or in any way about the class.

Take it even if you're not going to be an econ major. I'm definitely not, but still think the material consists of things that everyone should understand. Taking it pass/fail was just to lessen the stress for me, but I think I still would have gotten a good grade without it so don't worry about the difficulty level. It's very manageable.
Take it if you want to balance out your schedule (light workload) and are interested in the material.
Take it if you're interested.
Take it with Blinder!

Take it!

Take it, especially with Blinder!
Take it, it's not that hard if you do the practice exams.
Take it.  Not too difficult, but don't expect to be entertained 24/7.
Take it. Don't get behind on the readings, but don't be frightened of the material.
Take the class because it useful for general life.

Take the course if you are even slightly interested in the basic economic ideas behind current affairs. The most rewarding part of this course was being able to apply the concepts to understand current affairs immediately after learning them in lectures. The workload and the reading load are definitely manageable.
Take the course, avoid the precepts
Take this class when Blinder is the lecturer.  He is very good at explaining the history of the financial crisis of 2008.
Take this class, especially if Blinder is teaching it! It's not too much work, and Blinder is a fun and engaging lecturer.
Take this class.  It is interesting and you will be a better citizen for it.
Take this class. It will teach you all you need to know to navigate an economic world.
Take this course if you are seriously considering Economics.
The course is competitive. Make sure you do your readings.

The material in this course is good to know but this course is not one that you will look forward to going to. That said, it is not incredibly difficult so if you are interested in economics, taking it wouldn't be a bad idea.
The material is great!

The optimal benefits of this class probably come to those who (1) have some sort of background in economics or have taken Micro (Prof. Blinder used a lot of terms and concepts without clearly defining them first), and (2) have the time and inclination to keep up with the readings. The professor is a good lecturer, although during the more politicized chapters my friends and I had some doubts about his impartiality. Overall, the class is a good introduction to Macro if you're willing to put effort into learning. Also, if you're only planning to take one ECO class, I recommend starting with Micro instead of this.
They should definitely take the class. It's good to understand basic economic concepts.

This class is so important in terms of understanding what's happening in the world. I feel like it should almost be mandatory. It's not a ridiculous amount of work, but it is interesting and important

This course is a great introductory course to Macroeconomics. Professor Blinder is a great lecturer, though a bit dry at times. He is also one of the most knowledgeable people in the world on macroeconomic issues.
This course is a great overview of the economy and allows you to understand the topics covered in the news everyday
This is a class everyone at princeton should take.  If you are even reading these and considering it, take it.  Blinder is great
This is a course that every student should take, because the information is relevant outside of the course and is vital in understanding how the economy functions.
This is a good class. Not a terrific PDF option, but a great class if you're interested in the economy at all.
This is a good course taught by a good professor for someone looking for a basic introduction to economics.
This is a good intro economics course, but I feel like it's easier if you've taken micro already.
This is a good introductory course to macro economics. However, it is not the most exciting course.
This is an intro level course. Expect Intro level material, but Blinder makes up for that.
This is not an easy A.
To find a preceptor they can understand.
Very quality class, something you can't miss.
Wasn't a fan.
Worth taking
You should definitely take this class with Prof. Blinder.
after taking this course I can understand and discuss basic economic current events, which was exactly what I hoped to gain from this course
do the readings early.
highly recommend it!
keep up with the work
take it but check who the professor is first
take it esp if you have any interest in economics, but try to keep up with readings since some ideas tend to build on each other
take it only if you like it
take it.
take this course even if you are not interested in economics.
prereqs: ECO 101 is offered both terms and may be taken before or after (or simultaneously with) ECO 100..
descrip: Analysis of the operation of the national economy, with emphasis on the causes and consequences of recessions and booms, inflation and unemployment--and possible policy responses to each. Attention is also paid to the banking and financial systems, the financial crisis, and international influences on the U.S. economy.

title: U.S. Constitution and Foreign Policy
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: American Economic History
reviews: Anyone interested in economics or American history should absolutely take this course.
Definitely take this course if you have an interest in both econ and history, since it is a mix of both.
Eh...it's not the best, not the worst. I liked lecture well enough.
I would say make sure you do all the textbook readings.
I'd tell them to take it because it's an interesting class.
If you have an interest in American history take it. It is truly fantastic and presents a unique view on the subject matter

If you're not a huge fan of history, this course will be much tougher. Still, it's hard to find so a course that knocks so many requirements out if you're a WWS major. Also, definitely go in to talk with Bogan during office hours. Not just about the material, but about life. After performing poorly on the midterm due to personal matters, she lifted my spirits and taught me a thing or two about coping with life's problems. She is extremely warm, understanding, and fair.
Recommend it if you're very good with US history and are comfortable with finance-related fields. Otherwise, keep your distance.
Study the slides for exams.
Take this course!
take it, but make sure your comfortable giving a presentation in front of your precept
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. These are firm prerequisites, NOT co-requisites. This course counts towards WWS disciplinary perspectives requirement..
descrip: Modern economic theory is used to analyze growth and fluctuations in U.S. output from colonial times to the present. The course examines the role of labor markets, property rights in land and labor, financial institutions, transportation, innovation and other factors in economic growth. Before examining twentieth century fluctuations, a week is spent on business cycle theory. Then particular emphasis is placed on The Great Depression and its relationship to the recession of 2007-2009.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: Absolutely take this course.  It will teach you a lot and also keep you interested.
Good class to get a lot of new ideas from.
I give this course my highest recommendation. A diligent student of any background could take this class.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: Topics in Germanic Literatures - How German is it? Alexander Kluge's Germany
reviews: Alexander Kluge is a strange, strange author. But as is with most strange authors, you learn a lot more from them than conventional authors. I highly recommend you take this class. Your media literacy will greatly improve, even if you weren't like me and hadn't taken any film classes yet; your understanding of German culture will improve; and your written and spoken German will improve.

Anyone with a general interest in the literature and politics of post-World War II Germany - and related areas such as media theory - should enjoy and learn a great deal from this course. The same goes for anyone who likes to read original and stimulating literature; Kluge leaves ample room for interpretation to the reader and raises important questions of ethics, public culture, and media form in the process.
prereqs: GER 107.
descrip: Alexander Kluge, decorated with virtually every prize a writer, movie director and TV producer can receive in Germany, has always been a political author focused on the history and fate of Germany. His extensive and wide-ranging body of work can be considered as one vast library devoted to this topic. Drawing on this multi-media collection the seminar will read stories, films, television-programs and theoretical texts to develop a sense of just what Kluge's Germany looks like.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: "Don't be afraid of picking up new programs!"
Axel is a different kind of studio professor than you might be used to and that you might have again, and should be embraced for it.
Be comfortable and confident in your own ideas. Students should not expect too much guidance or handholding. It is important to be totally self directed.
Take a class with Axel, and ask him for feedback/desk crits whenever possible, but as a studio critic, one wishes for more variety and personality sometimes.
descrip: Part two of a two semester sequence in which fundamental design skills are taught in the context of the architect's wider responsibilities to society, culture and the environment. Students acquire a command of the techniques of design and representation through a series of specific architectural problems of increasing complexity. Both semesters are required for three-year M.Arch. students.

title: Introductory Physics II
reviews: Not a lot of help from teachers outside the classroom
A pretty good course. Avoid Haldane if you need someone to actually teach you material. Sondhi is an excellent teacher.
Be prepared to teach yourself the entire course.
Better than dying in 104.
Do all of the work.
Don't take it if you don't have to and make sure you have Prof. Sondhi as a preceptor otherwise it will be difficult to learn anything.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Go to Professor Sondhi's precepts and at least skim the book.
I only took this to satisfy a requirement, and wouldn't recommend it for anyone with general interest.

I really dislike the 'drop 3' policy. I wish they would let us make up at least the quizzes, if not also the clicker questions. The way the policy works, if you're absent for any reason, then that day's grades (clicker and/or quiz) automatically get dropped, for the first 3, and all of the others count. I found this inherently unfair to anyone (like me) who had to miss multiple classes, since I was not given the opportunity to even attempt the questions, while my classmates were able to do so. I really hope that the policy gets revised in the future.
I would recommend this course for anyone who needs to fulfill the premed requirements. It is harder than PHY 101, but if you put in the extra work then you should do well.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in physics.
I would recommend. There's weekly homework, quizzes, and clicker questions, but other than that it's pretty interesting and some cool demos.
I wouldn't take this class for fun. It just got on my nerves a lot. I wouldn't take it unless I had to.

If not considering MOL or PHY or an engineering concentration that requires it, or not premed, don't take it. Competitive premeds make it a cutthroat environment for grades and grade deflation does not make this situation any better.
If you are pre-med, you have to take it anyway. If you are not pre-med, don't take it. simple.
In my opinion (although a lot of other people don't share it), the second half of the PHY 101-102 sequence is much easier and better than the first! Definitely take it.

It would be foolish not to take PHY 102 if one took PHY 101, and PHY 102 is probably easier (at least it requires less work, especially in regards to the lab). If there's any reason to take PHY 102 it's because of the importance of the material, not because it's a good course.
It's a good class, but don't think it will be easy just since it's PHY102 and not PHY104.  It's a tough class, do lots of practice problems.

Join Prof. Shivaji's precept.  It is fantastic and will, aside from reading the book, be the only way you will learn the material.  Lectures are useless, but are mandated via graded "clicker questions."
Just keep working throughout the semester. Professor Sondhi's an extremely good lecturer.
Much better than PHY101.
Much of your work outside the class determines your grade. And many times the work you put in doesn't match your grades, which is frustrating. Once you finish this course you will be very happy.
Not bad.  probably wouldn't take it unless you absolutely had to though.  There are several more interesting lab classes out there.
Only take course if required.
Only take this course to fill the pre-med requirement.
Pay special attention to the reading in preparing for the clicker questions. The quizzes can be tough, but if you understand the week's materials you should be okay.
Please, if you do not need to take it, do not.

Read the book beforehand if you want to get the clicker questions. They actually count for a pretty good part of your grade. Quizzes are annoying. Material is pretty easy. Way less time consuming than PHY103.
Read the textbook and do a lot of practice everything.
Read the textbook and study really well for the weekly quizzes.
Read the textbook over the weekend so that you're ready for wileyplus and practice problems during the week.
Read the textbook. Do problems.
Take it if you have to, it's doable and much more manageable than PHY 103/104.
Take it if you're pre-med.
Teach yourself the material.
The class material is ok and it is also well-organized, but unless you need it to fulfill a requirement or are just interested in physics, I would avoid it.
The class was okay: the concepts are more abstract than the ones in PHY 101, so perhaps you'll have to spend more time learning them.
This course is a very good course. Take it if you are pre-med or need it for a science major. If you have taken AP Physics, you might get bored...go for a challenge and take 104 or 106.
This is a great introductory course for physics. Fairly manageable.
Typical Princeton Intro Pre-med class. Take it somewhere else if you can.
Unless they need it for the pre-med requirement, I would strongly recommend against this course. I was shocked that a course in such a prestigious department could be so poorly taught and organized.
Unless you must take this class for some reason, I would avoid it.
Unless you're a pre-med (in which case you might be better off taking the 103/104 sequence instead anyway).
While this course is often a requirement for many students, I strongly recommend that Princeton University drastically change the professors and model of this course.
dont necessarily take this course if u dont have to its alot of busy work, but the material is interesting.
its ok
prereqs: PHY 101.
descrip: This course presents an introduction to the fundamental laws of nature, especially optics, electricity/magnetism, nuclear and atomic theory. These are treated quantitatively with an emphasis on problem solving. The laboratory is intended to give students an opportunity to observe physical phenomena and to gain "hands-on" experience with apparatus and instruments.

title: Environmental Challenges and Sustainable Solutions
reviews: - This is a good science course to PDF. I filled my ST requirement and I enjoyed it a lot more than bridges - at least I learned something here, and had fun doing the labs.
GREAT PDF class bc there is not much outside the classroom work and assignments are not regular. Would be an AMAZING class for someone who was passionate about environmental studies.

I think that this class does provide an interesting opportunity to learn about the campus and its environmental impacts, as well as the chance to learn about some important environmental issues.  I would not recommend the course if you want to learn in detail about the science of these issues.

I think this would be a great course for anyone interested in Environmental studies.  I would also recommend this as an interesting class to non science majors who need an STL class that won't absolutely overwhelm them with intense science stuff.
Not much scientific inquiry, but the closeness of the research matter (campus) made the material somewhat interesting.

this class is a chill ST, but I kind of had a horrible time. I made some super cool friends, but Zerba's class is unstructured and really not that fun. And although it's advertised to have a community component it doesn't. Definitely not the best class.
descrip: Focuses on environmental challenges and sustainable solutions related to interrelationships between constructed and natural processes. Topic areas include resource conservation, sustainable practices, stormwater management, and habitat restoration. The format of the course is experiential learning with problem-solving research projects, lectures, and discussions. A central theme of the projects is to track the impact of land use and sustainable practices on the ecological balance of environments in and around Princeton's campus. Sample projects include: stream restoration; the health of Lake Carnegie; and the benefits of green roofs.

title: The Chemistry of Magic
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Formal Political Analysis I
descrip: An introduction to mathematical models of political processes. Course develops the analytical foundations for examining problems in collective choice. The technical development focuses on the logical structure of formal models as well as on their use to develop testable hypotheses. The presentation of technical apparatus is combined with a wide range of applications. Topics include models of majority rule, direct and representative democracy, political competition under various electoral systems, and political economy.

title: Epidemiology
prereqs: This is a required course for graduate students in the Health and Health Policy certificate program..
descrip: Course covers the basic concepts and methods of epidemiology and demonstrates how these can be applied to improve population health and reduce health inequities. Topics include: measuring the health of the population, understanding the causes of poor health, developing interventions for improving health, translating evidence into practice, and evaluating the impact of policies and programs. Key epidemiological concepts such as association, bias and confounding are covered, as well as the main epidemiological study designs.

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: BREATHE!
Definitely take this course!!!!!!
Definitely take this course.
Great class for seniors who need 6 classes or students interested in African dance. Be prepared to move every class. Participation matters.
I loved this course as a non-dancer and somebody who had never experienced African dance before.  I would totally recommend it to anybody interested.

If they are interested in more movement and the dance aspect i would say definitely take it but if they are interested in the academic elements of African american cultural expressions. I would say just read a book.
Make sure that you are engaged and come to every class.
Take it! It's an excellent course where you get to have a lot of fun without a heavy out-of-class workload.
Take the class for the dancing alone, because it's a lot of fun!
Take this course. It will definitely add to your list of enjoyable memories here at Princeton.
This class is very enjoyable. And there are not many times in your life where you will get to take a course like this
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: France, 1815 to the Present
descrip: The history of France in the 19th and 20th centuries appears a rapid and perplexing turnover of regimes and administrations. This course has two interrelated aims: (1) to account for France's peculiar political instability in terms of social struggles which were played out in one form or another in all European states, and thereby, (2) to set France's unique pattern of development in its European context. Topics will include: the Restoration and the legacy of the French Revolution; 1848 and Bonapartism; popular revolt in the fin de siecle and the triumph of the Third Republic, etc.

title: Advanced Statistics for Biology
prereqs: A course in basic statistics (e.g., MOL 355 or ORF 245) or a course in quantitative biology (e.g., ISC 236, MOL 410/510, MOL/COS 455, MOL/COS 551, MOL 515). A working knowledge of basic genetics and molecular biology..
descrip: Statistical methods for biology research, with a special focus on modern problems. Topics may include likelihood, Bayesian methods, bootstrap, EM algorithm, regularization, generalized additive models, principal components analysis, multiple hypothesis testing, causality, and graphical models. The statistical software R will be used to explore methods and anlyze biological data.

title: PhD Seminar: Research Design
descrip: This is a course in research design. We will discuss some issues in the philosophy of science, then analyze questions of conceptualization, proceeding to problems of descriptive inference, objectivity, and causal inference, including the role of causal mechanisms. The seminar will continue with analysis of how to avoid bias, then tackle issues of historical change. Students will present their own research designs and critique those of their colleagues. Emphasis will be on qualitative research, but the argument underlying the seminar is that the same basic principles of inference apply to qualitative and quantitative research, and that the

title: Topics in International Relations - Human Rights History and Practice
descrip: Examines human rights in modern international history and current debates in policy and practice. Explores the emergence and spread of human rights ideas, institutions, debates and activism from historical, philosophical, legal, and cultural perspectives. The goal is to set contemporary debates about human rights policy in a longer historical trajectory, to better inform considerations of policy options by state officials, NGOs and other actors. Class participants write a series of brief arguments and responses to weekly readings and a final paper exploring the historical roots and contemporary debates surrounding an important human rights pr

title: Imagining America
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Civil Liberties
reviews: Be ready to work a lot and do not fall behind on the reading.
Definitely take it if you are interested in American government and constitutional rights. Professor Whittington is an expert in the subject, and keeps the class interesting.
Definitely take this course if you're either majoring in Politics, or if you just have an interest in civil liberties in America.
Excellent EM or if you're interested in law-related issues.
Great POL class for anyone interested in law or American history.
Great course if you want to know more about our judicial system, the types of civil liberties and how they've changed over time, and generally more information about landmark court cases.
I was one of 4 freshman out of 60 students. I would recommend waiting at least until you're a sophomore to take it. It was not a good choice for me to take it as my first politics class ever!

I would have to strongly recommend against courses with Professor Whittington except in the case of students who share an exclusive interest in this very specific, legal framework as a way of understanding political issues.
I would not recommend this course.

If you are a political theory or American politics concentrator, or even someone interested in the general history of the political actions that shaped our country, I would definitely take this course.
It's a lot of reading, but very interesting material.
Pretty chill. Graded pretty strictly though.
See above
Take it if you're interested in the law.
Take it when Robbie George is teaching it. But if Whittington is still teaching it, then do read the focus cases for precept and don't worry so much about the other readings.

This course doesn't spend a lot of time at all on the modern era (and  Professor Whittington even tried to avoid talking about abortion in class), so if you're looking for a course on that, this is regrettably not it.  However, if you enjoyed Constitutional Interpretation, this should tick all of your boxes.

This is a pretty solid course to take. It's neither particularly difficult nor easy and it covers lots of interesting material. If you already have any familiarity with this material though, be prepared for frustration with your fellow students and the pace of the class.
Whether you've taken POL 315 or not, this course is great for anyone interested in the Constitution, American law, or the development of rights and liberties in the US.

unless prof. george goes back to teaching this course, i absolutely would not recommend it. the precepts were absolutely painful with the professor, and lectures were fairly tedious. the contemporaneous topics that we associate with civil liberties--i.e. detention cases, gay marriage, gender equality, etc.--were touched on extremely briefly while historical topics (i.e. the "post office controversies") were harped on for weeks on end.  so, so disappointing as my last politics course at princeton.
descrip: An exploration of how the United States has grappled with the limits on government power. The rights of individuals, and the justification for the use of force from the founding period to today. Topics include religious liberty, free speech, economic liberty, equality and personal autonomy, and security issues.

title: Visual Cognition: More than Meets the Eye
prereqs: PSY 255 (Cognitive Psychology) or instructor's permission..
descrip: Vision is the dominant sense in humans, and is central to our experience of the world: how we recognize friends, how we navigate campus, how we play sports, how we read, etc. Despite this importance, we take for granted how well vision works. While vision seems effortless, what we see is the product of sophisticated mental processes operating without our awareness. Visual cognition is the branch of cognitive psychology concerned with trying to understand how these processes work. The goal of this course is to provide an advanced introduction to visual cognition, including existing theoretical frameworks and cutting-edge research findings.

title: Cultural Systems - Modernist Classics of European Cinema
reviews: Get ready to watch some really difficult films and do some heavy reading, but expect to learn a lot and develop an appreciation for art films.

If you are interested in film or European cultural at all, TAKE THIS CLASS. It's fascinating and fun. Professor Kiss is incredibly knowledgeable, though a bit disorganized. But the material is completely worthwhile!
Take it if you're interested in film theory. If you just want to learn about the history of films, etc. I would recommend taking another class.
This course is a good idea to take if you enjoy film and would like to be able to understand and enjoy it even more.
descrip: The masterpieces examined in this course--that sometimes are also referred to as European art films--seem to resist interpretation to the extent that they often appear enigmatic or obscure. Close analysis and the historical and theoretical context of these challenging films will enable us to see them more clearly. We will discuss the cinematic ideas of Wajda, Antonioni, Bunuel, Bergman, Fellini, Chytilova, Fassbinder, and Tarkovsky among others.

title: Topics in 18th-Century Literature - Jane Austen in Context
reviews: Be prepared for lengthy novels and try to think out of the traditional conceptions of Austen.
Definitely.
Do the readings and go to lectures. If you do that you'll be fine
Hands-down, this is the course that I have enjoyed the most at Princeton. If you love Jane Austen, you will love this course. If you don't, you will learn to love her. Professor Johnson is a God.
I highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in Jane Austen. Claudia Johnson is an expert who teaches at a level everyone can understand!
I liked it!
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student!
I would recommend this course to anyone who enjoys reading and discussing literature. I would advise future students to attend the lectures and precepts.

If you are a Jane Austen fan, it is incredible. If you only like it or have read one or two of the books, its a little too much. I felt odd surrounded by women who LOVED Jane Austen when I only liked her.
If you like Austen, or are interested in reading her works, this is clearly the course for you. Go nuts.
If you like Jane Austen, you can't go wrong with this course.
If you love Jane Austen, you must take this course!
If you need an LA distribution requirement and like Jane Austen definitely take this course and consider taking it PDF (although this probably wasn't necessary).

Jane Austen is not beach-reading--you'll appreciate her much more when you think about her novels afterward. I would read each novel twice before writing about it. And have lots of fun close-reading! You'll be amazed at what you find.
Jane Austen is the shit. Claudia Johnson is also awesome. TAKE IT.
Keep up with the reading, engage in precept discussion, go to office hours to narrow down paper topic
Make sure you do the readings - it's not the same to learn about what happens without reading the actual material.
Make sure you're prepared for all the reading!
Professor Johnson is one of the foremost Austen scholars.  Please take advantage of this great opportunity.
Stay on top of your readings
TAKE IT!

TAKE IT! Even if you haven't read Austen before or have only read one or two of her novels, or even if you've read every single of her works, everyone has a chance to learn something from this course. Professor Johnson and the preceptors were all brilliant, so take the time to really engage with them and their lectures.
TAKE IT!!!!!
Take if you like Jane Austen, and if you will actually read all the books.
Take this class!  Claudia Johnson is amazing!
Take this class! Period.
Take this class. It was an amazing experience, and I loved every second of it.
Take this course, that's the only advice I can give.
The novels are awesome, and reading them is important to being able to understand what is being talked about in lecture.

The readings can seem like they are a lot. Take it only if you love Jane Austen. If you don't the readings can seem repetitive. However, if you do like this kind of reading, then by all means, this is an excellent course.
This course is a great way to read the complete works of one author, especially if you've read only Pride and Prejudice and want to get to know Jane Austen better.
descrip: Jane Austen is the darling of popular audiences and high culturists alike. The inventor of the modern novel and a pivotal, inspirational figure in English literary history, she is venerated or despised with peculiar intensity--for being a brilliant stylist or a provincial bore, a benign aunt or a nasty spinster, an instrument of tedious and oppresive normality or of dazzling and expansive fabulousness. We will test such views by studying all of Austen's novels, paying close attention to the context of 18th-century literature out of which she develops and contrasts her achievements to recent film adaptations.

title: Shakespeare II
reviews: If you like Shakespeare, do it.
Plays are not novels and are not poems. Make sure you want to grapple with the form and 16th/17th century language.
Take it.
Take the class. You will gain a whole new level of understanding for the Bard of Avon
descrip: A selection of Shakespeare's plays read in the context of the representation of violence on the Renaissance stage.

title: Stochastic Calculus
reviews: If you like rigorous probability and love taking limits very carefully, you should definitely take it from Prof. van Handel.
One of the best courses so far. Take it even if you (think you) already know stochastic calculus.
This is a math course, not an applications course. If you are willing to devote enough time to this class, in particular the problem sets, you will get a lot out of it.

This is a very hard class. There is a lot of work, and the material is also challenging conceptually. It assumes an excellent command of the ORF 526 material  - otherwise it will be a struggle. Prof. van Handel's lectures are very clear and thorough, but sometimes he goes too deep in the technical details and formalism. Same for the problem sets. It is possible to learn a great deal from the class, but you must invest time in it. Towards the end especially, two days per week need to be devoted to it in you want to be on top of the material.
Very good for technicalities, but few applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ORF 526.
descrip: An introduction to stochastic calculus based on Brownian motion.Topics include:construction of Brownian motion; martingales in continuous time; the Ito integral; localization; Ito calculus; stochastic differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; martingale representation; Feynman-Kac formula.

title: Analysis & Visualization of Large-Scale Genomic Data Sets
descrip: Introduces students to computational issues involved in analysis and display of large-scale biological data sets. Algorithms covered will include clustering and machine learning techniques for gene expression and proteomics data analysis, biological networks, joint learning from multiple data sources, and visualization issues for large-scale biological data sets. No prior knowledge of biology or bioinformatics is required; an introduction to bioinformatics and the nature of biological data will be provided. In depth knowledge of computer science is not required, but students should have some understanding of programming and computation.

title: Themes in Islamic History and Culture
descrip: This year the course will be a research seminar in which graduate students working on Islamic and Middle Eastern topics will present their research in written and oral form, receiving feedback relating both to the substance of their work and to the manner of its presentation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: The Power and Peril of Cycling Cells
descrip: Accurate control of cell cycle is essential for the formation and maintenance of a normal living organism. This course will study the molecular machinery that controls the cell cycle and the devastating consequence of its de-regulation that leads to cancer. We begin with a mechanistic examination of the cell cycle in bacteria, yeast, flies and mammals. We then consider cell cycle and cell size, and the cell cycle of stem cells. We will also discuss the oncogenic events that disrupt the normal cell cycle, the signaling pathways that activate uncontrolled cell proliferation, and the molecular therapeutics that target oncogenic pathways.

title: Policy Issues and Analysis of Nonprofits, NGOs, and Philanthropy
descrip: Examines policy issues at international, national and local levels. Provides groundwork on nonprofits, NGOs, and philanthropy that can be followed with specialized courses on management and program evaluation. Emphasis on understanding how philanthropy, nonprofit, and NGO sectors operate, their niche alongside private and public sectors, revenue sources, impact on society, and converse effects of society and its institutions; the policy making process. Explores impact of reliance on government or overseas support for Third World NGOs; faith-based service provisions: accountability and transparency; advocacy; and government regulations.

title: Systematic Ethics
descrip: A graduate seminar in ethics.

title: Quantum Mechanics II
reviews: EH, not too bad.
If you have the time and the guts, you won't regret taking this course. It really is time consuming though, and you can expect it to take up the majority of your semester.
If you really like quantum mechanics, take it.
Read up on you Lieb papers. Much better than QFT.
Take it only if you have to fullfil a requirement.
Take this course if you are interested in pure mathematical physics and many-body phyics.
Taught in a mathematical spirit.
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics, following PHY 505. After a brief review of some fundamental topics (e.g., hydrogen atom, perturbation theory, scattering theory) more advanced topics will be covered, including many-body theory, operator theory, coherent states, stability of matter and other Coulomb systems and the theory of the Bose gas.

title: Coexistence through Theater and Film
prereqs: Fluent speakers.
descrip: An advanced language and culture course in Hebrew. Students will develop further proficiency in all skills through discussions, oral presentations of authentic materials and media. The objective is to investigate how playwrights and filmmakers deal with socio-cultural issues of coexistence. In addition to reading the plays, students will watch the DVDs with the performances from the unique bilingual theater in Jaffa. Lab work will be also assigned.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - Stochastic Methods for Quantitative Finance
reviews: Great class to take if you have any interest in the material. The professor van Handel is very good at teaching.
Great course to take if you loved ORF 309, ORF 335 and wanted more! Like, how does stochastic calculus turn into the Black-Scholes formula anyways?
If you want to learn about stochastic calculus, this is the course you should take.

Take it! It's a good class to PDF if you a) want to learn something b) are willing to put a tiny bit of work into the concepts and c) don't want to screw yourself over on the (really really hard) final.
This course has many applications that are useful in many other courses and should definitely be taken.
This course is very good.  Take it!
Very interesting course without too much effort
van Handel is amazing. Take a class if he is offering one. Be prepared to think fairly rigorously.
prereqs: ORF 309 required.
descrip: This course is an introduction to stochastic calculus at the undergraduate level with applications to financial models. The emphasis is on computational and practical techniques. Topics include: Brownian motion; Ito's formula; stochastic differential equations; partial differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; stochastic control; simulation and finite difference numerical methods; implementation in Matlab.

title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Space
reviews: I definitely regretted taking this course; although the subject matter might be interesting, it requires you to be intelligent and have a background in analysis (including Fourier series).  The lectures did not help illustrate concepts or include examples; if you're not comfortable with such an approach, you might have a difficult time with this course.
If Ionescu is teaching it again, take it. Even if you don't like analysis.
If you really like Analysis, then this course will be enjoyable.
Keep up with reading.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or permission of instructor.
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Makeup and Ability of US Military Force
descrip: This course will examine US military capabilities and limitations throughout the spectrum of non-nuclear conflict. It includes a broad review of US military culture, structure, strategy, planning, readiness, decision making, force projection, employment and logistics. It also considers force enhancement through use of non-military US capabilities, allies and indigenous populations. The course provides helpful information and perspective for those engaged in national security planning and decision making.

title: Elementary Hindi II
reviews: Definitely take the course sequence - it was a friendly, comfortable, and relaxed environment in which we were able to come together as a class and really learn the intricacies of the language.  Mekhalaji is incredible and nice and funny, and I'm so glad she structured the class the way she did.
Do it!
Don't worry about vocabulary quite as much, but make sure to have a really firm grasp of grammar.

It is very easy to slack in your work and pick up later,but really you will end up just hurting yourself.  The coursework is not hard, but really doing it and putting in the effort will give you the most out of this course.
The class is interesting and the workload is very manageable.

This is not an easy class, but it's very enjoyable if you put the effort into it. It especially helps if you have an interest in South Asian culture since languages and cultures are often tied together.
prereqs: HIN 101 or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: Elementary Hindi 102 provides the second semester of training in spoken and written Hindi. Our primary objective is to continue to increase understanding, speaking, reading and writing Hindi. Classroom activities include comprehension, grammar exercises, role-plays, and conversation.
