Some attention to the cultural context of northern India. Depending on interest, Urdu script will also be taught.

title: Modern Memory
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: The Romantic Period - Three (Long) Romantic Verse Epics
descrip: An intensive reading of the greatest epics of the Romantic period--Wordsworth's Prelude (1798-1850) and Byron's Don Juan (1819-1824), E.B. Browning's Aurora Leigh (1856), works usually encountered in anthology selections. All cast long shadows across the 19th and 20th centuries and their force is felt in several genres: poetry, the novel, and literary criticism and theory, as a magnetic focus for principles, methods, and practices. Your acquaintance with Paradise Lost and the Romantic period will be helpful.

title: Imagining America
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Independent Study
prereqs: Students MUST fill out the Independent Research Proposal Project form signed by your advisor & the dept rep. Hand in to Tiffany Sirois in E-212 E-Quad during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and must result in a final paper.

title: Electronic Materials
reviews: A lot of work, but worth taking if you want to get a better understanding of electronic devices.

A very interesting course. Though a lot of time is spent explaining solar cell device fundamentals that a lot of EEs may have already seen before, the approach to the teaching of this material alone makes this course worthwhile.

Problem sets can be time-consuming and sometimes abstract, but generally are very good. The final project is a very worthwhile opportunity to explore your favourite solar cell topic!
If you want to build a solar cell, or just if you want to learn something useful, take this class.
If you've already taken an ELE "electronic devices" class, beware that this class assumes little/no knowledge of that material, and will re-teach all of it.

It is a good course. Non-electrical engineering can survive in it - as long as you're committed to paying attention and doing the problem sets. Better yet - make some electrical engineering friends when you take the course! They may make the ride less bumpy.
Read the current literature. It will help you for your final project.
Solar cells are recommended to be known, even we are not working on it.
Would strongly recommend for any student, ELE or not.
prereqs: A course in solid-state or semiconductor physics, or in solid-state chemistry..
descrip: Physics of solar cells and resulting material requirements. Absorption of light, pn junction theory and carrier transport, theory of carrier generation and recombination in the bulk and at interfaces, contacts, components of cell efficiency. Cell design, cell models and techniques for loss minimization, evaluation of cell and module performance. Application of physical principles to concentrator and thin film solar cells. Review of technologies, with focus on highly efficient silicon cells.

title: Inventing Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Generalized Regression Models
reviews: Course well structured, well taught, but be prepared to learn advanced Statistics from a very very theoretical point of view. But if you're OK with that, then you'll enjoy. 2 interesting problem sets + a final exam: problem sets are interesting, but the final exam is actually very hard and research-oriented (90% about the very last part of the course and more advanced than we learned). I recommend it if you want to learn a lot more about real statistics, very theoretically, without many exams but not easy at all.
Don't expect any connection with ORF524.

If you are doing research in theoretical statistics, this will probably be the best class you will ever take in Princeton. 
The lectures cover the main areas of research in statistics (GLM, High-Dimensional Statistics, Aggregation). The material is presented in a way that up to date methods and techniques are shown. Prof. Rigollet is a great lecturer and he also gives very good insight with regards to current research areas and how to approach problems in statistics.
The only annoying part of the class was the typos in the lecture notes/slides, but this was mainly due to the fact that the syllabus and the lectures notes of the class were changed massively this year. This shouldn't be an issue in the next school years.
If you want to learn how to proof error bounds on various regression models, that class should be useful for you.
Recommended. Warning: Very theoretical.

This class should be titled 'Statistical Learning Theory'. The topics covered are more interesting and modern than ORF 524, so I would recommend this class even if you do not like old-school parametric statistics. Also, the material is only loosely related to 524, and you can take this class with only a basic knowledge of probability. Having said that, you will appreciate the lectures much more if you have some background in statistics, machine learning or data mining. There is little homework, but the final is fairly long and complicated - in my year there was a problem with 12 sub-points... If you are interested in statistics, this is a nice class to take, but it's all very theoretical so it's  somewhat unlikely that it will spark a previously non-existing interest.
prereqs: ORF 524: Statistical Theory and Methods or instructor's approval..
descrip: A theoretical introduction to statistical learning problems related to regression and classification. Topics covered include generalized linear models, nonparametric estimation (splines, kernel smoothing), penalization (ridge, lasso), aggregation (adaptation, boosting), and Vapnik-Chervonenkis theory. Emphasis placed on deriving precise error bounds for the proposed estimators or classifiers.

title: System Design and Analysis
reviews: Car lab was a tremendously educational experience for me. It was also extremely difficult to get through, due to poor organization and communication. I would not advise a student to take it if Professor Dickinson and Victor are still in charge. However, if they are not, I would recommend it because it was a valuable experience and I learned a lot.
Carlab is hard but it's Extremely rewarding. Be ELE!
Choose a partner carefully, don't leave milestones for the last minute!!!
If you need to take this course, definitely take only 4 courses total, and minimize the number of Dean's Date assignments you have, since that's when the documentation for this course is due.
It is much improved from what I heard about the past.
Its a wonderful course. But do realize, it will be a lot of work and if you are not into designing a car (or robot) then you will probably end up hating it.

Please take it easy with the rest of your classes.  I don't say that just because it will be stressful to have a lot of work, but also you won't get the full experience of your other classes when you're in car lab.  Save hard classes for when you can completely devote yourself to them.
Radd is cool!
Takes too much time.  Shouldn't take unless it is required

This course could be interesting to students outside of the electrical engineering department, but it does require a lot of man hours in the lab, which may make it not worth it to a student considering the course out of intellectual curiosity.

Advice I would give to a student taking this course would be to pick a partner you're comfortable communicating with. A lab partner will be invaluable for bouncing ideas off of and for generally offering support when times get rough. Other advice I would give would be to help other teams as well when they have it rough; you may be able to help them this time and they may be able to help you later because it's difficult for one team to know how to do everything and not have to rely on any other team.
Unless you have to take this course, don't. If you do, get started as soon as you possibly can! Do not procrastinate!
prereqs: ELE 206 and ELE 301. Permission of instructor..
descrip: Comprehensive, laboratory-based course in electronic system design and analysis. Covers formal methods for the design and analysis of moderately complex real-world electronic systems. Course is centered around a semester-long design project involving a computer-controlled vehicle designed and constructed by teams of two students. Integrates microprocessors, communications, and control.

title: African American Literature: Origins to 1910
descrip: This introductory course focuses on texts from the mid-eighteenth century through the early 20th century; it will cover early texts such as poetry by Phillis Wheatley & Paul Laurence Dunbar; oratory by David Walker, Sojourner Truth; slave narratives by Frederick Douglass, Harriet Jacobs; spirituals; black theatre by Pauline Hopkins, Bert Williams; fiction by Charles Chesnutt, James Weldon Johnson; & non-fiction by W.E.B.DuBois, Anna Julia Cooper, Booker T. Washington. The course explores how black literature engages with the politics of cultural identity formation, notions of freedom, citizenship, and aesthetic forms.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic II
reviews: Definitely take it, just because it's intensive doesn't mean too much.
I definitely learned a lot in this course, even though there were times when the class or the length of assignments was frustrating.
I recommend this course to students with some exposure to Arabic (at least reading/writing) interested in learning Arabic in a community setting and willing to spend 2 hours a day on study.
I'd suggest other students to go to office hours as much as possible, because sh'e a great one on one instructor.
Take it! I've learned so much in so little time.

Take this class only if you're up for a very different experience from what you'd expect from a typical language class.

This class has given me a more integrated, fluid knowledge of the language than I would have gotten in the standard ARA 102 course.  I have a richer vocabulary than I would have had, and I know more grammar than I would have learned.  Additionally, diligence in this class is essential; as much as she is very dedicated to her work, Prof. Heba is not well-organized, and if the students don't stay on top of what is happening in the class, the class can sort of fall apart.

However, if you decide to take this course, you should be extremely open-minded.  Prof. Heba has a very unique way of teaching, often involving moving fluidly from one subject to another without any clear distinction as to which particular grammar topic she's discussing.  While I think this pays off in the end, by giving you an ability to integrate knowledge of one grammatical concept with another, it is quite difficult to follow initially.

Also, Prof. Heba often refers to linguistic theory external to what you need to know in order to learn Arabic during class.  She often tries to convince you that Arabic is a root for a variety of other languages by indicating similarities between words that are not systematically or clearly established.  While initially interesting, this theory distracts from allowing us to learn Arabic more than it helps, mostly because Prof. Heba's arguments for linguistic relationship are poorly substantiated.  While I find the theory interesting, when I'm in Arabic class, I want to learn how Arabic grammar works; I am not interested in watered-down versions of theories on how languages evolved.

Taking this track can be helpful because it allows you to skip 105, but I would not recommend it unless you are too advanced for 101 but not advanced enough for 105.  The instructor is very nice, but her teaching style doesn't work for everyone and she tends to ignore student participation, like speaking drills etc.

This course throws a lot of information at you at once and a good strategy is to pay attention and absorb everything you can and take good notes.  Though it may seem like Professor Heba is going off on an unrelated tangent, she is usually just talking about something you will learn in the future and once you get to that topic, you will be very happy that you took notes earlier.  Also, study the vocabulary and do the homework.  Practice writing will help you understand where you're going wrong.  Enjoy! Some people complain, but if you love Arabic and you want a professor who is caring beyond belief, you should take this class.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 103..
descrip: A continuation of 103. The second semester of a full-year language course designed specifically for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic. Graduate students who are primarily interested in learning to read Arabic are also welcome. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, as well as how to analyze grammar.

title: Intensive Intermediate German
reviews: 1025 is worth the effort and time if you can fit the 11am section into your schedule. 8:30 is probably rough.
Absolutely, absolutely take it; especially if it's taught by Professor Rankin
Be prepared for a lot of work, but it's a great course!
Best course I've taken at Princeton. Best. One. Learn German, love Germany, love yourself.

Definitely a great way to get a jump on the language requirement. Good language training. About an hour of homework every day, but less work overall than taking two courses. Overall a very rewarding course.
Definitely do it if you can manage the workload.

Definitely take it! I think this course is wonderful in every way - and by the end of it the progress you can make is unbelievable - so are the opportunities offered! I am definitely looking forward to Munich, as are the others!
Go for it--it's a step up from 101, but the workload isn't too bad, and you'll be really pleased with your German progress!

If you are on the fence about this or 102, and you think you will have the time to deal with a double course in the spring semester, take this course (especially, but not exclusively, if it's with Jamie Rankin).  I can't promise you that you'll be speaking like a native at the end of the semester, but the progress you will make in spoken (and written) German is pretty drastic - provided you put the time into reviewing vocab, grammar, etc. every day.  Very highly recommended.

If you are willing to commit significant time to learning the language (and if you genuinely want to learn the language and not just fulfill the requirement) I would definitely recommend that you take 1025.
If you ever wanted to learn German, this is the time and place to do it.  You probably won't find many better professors than Jamie and you'll be speaking easily before you even realize it.

If you're thinking--maybe I'll go for 102-5, definitely do it! It's the ideal course, and your work pays off. The teachers enable you to achieve your best, which is the best of what a Princeton education can be. I had a wonderful time this class and am very close with my classmates. We had a great time, and learned so much in such little time.
ONly take if if you're willing to make the commitment and put forth the effort. then it's totally worth it.
Take it if you have the time; don't bother if you aren't going to try.
Take it!
Take it, if you can wake up for an 8.30 class every morning, and will spend 2 hours everyday on homework.

Take it. If you are willing to commit to daily 1.5 hours of class, take it. You will not regret your decision -- the language instruction you will receive is stellar, and the professor is inspirational! If you are strongly opposed to waking up early in the mornings, nevertheless strongly consider this course if you are interested in learning the German language. It is completely worth the effort.
Take this if you have the time in your schedule. There were times when it was a lot of work but it was a great class and German is an awesome language to learn.
The German department is very organized and the fairness of the grading of the course was very refreshing.
This course is time intensive, but everything you put into it you get out twice over. Take this if you want to speak German.
prereqs: GER 101 and permission of instructor. Enrollment by invitation only, following an interview with the course instructor; interviews are normally offered to students in GER 101 attaining a grade of A or A-..
descrip: Intensive training in German, building on GER 101 and covering the acquisitional goals of two subsequent semesters: communicative proficiency in a wide range of syntax, mastery of discourse skills, and reading strategies sufficient to interpret and discuss contemporary German short stories, drama, and film. Intensive classroom participation required. Successful completion provides eligibility for GER 107 or, in exceptional cases, for 200 level courses. Participants are automatically eligible for the Princeton-in-Munich program (107-G), June, 2011.

title: Urbanization and Development
descrip: Examines the origins, types, and characteristics of cities in less developed countries and the ways in which patterns of urbanization interact with policies to promote economic growth and social equity. Readings and class discussions address three areas: a) a history of urbanization in the Third World; b) an analysis of contemporary urban systems, demographic patterns, and the social structure of large Third World cities; c) a review of the literature on urban dwellers with emphasis on the poor and their political and social outlooks.

title: The Making of the Modern African Diaspora
descrip: This course considers the political, cultural, social, and intellectual history of the modern African diaspora, from the collapse of the Atlantic slave system through the late 20th century. Focus is on the historical construction of the diaspora and the shifting relationships between the continent and African-descended people in the Americas, Europe, and other regions. The course also tracks the evolution of diaspora as an idea and analytical framework, particularly its intersections with African-American history, transnational/world history, and postcolonial studies.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: Anthropology of Language (Half-Term)
descrip: A brief introduction to the anthropology of language, focusing on examples from law and politics. Course begins with basic methods for analyzing language emerging from recent developments in anthropology, focusing particularly on tools for examining how language works in social contexts (e.g., language pragmatics, metapragmatics, linguistic ideology), then considers ethnographies of language in legal contexts which used these tools to give insights into the vital role of language in law. Students who have already done fieldwork may consider applying linguistic anthropological approaches to their own ethnographic materials. A six-week course.

title: Reading and Writing about the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term) - Molecular Sciences
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed at least one semester of graduate school..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars.

title: Seminar in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature - Madness and Modernity
descrip: This seminar will examine the development of the categories of norm and anomaly, law and accident, reason and unreason in the philosophical determination of man's relationship to the natural world and the definition of human egarements as challenge to self-knowledge and social order. We will study the specific relationship between madness and society, creativity and silence. We will read texts by Sade, Lautreamont, Nerval, E. A. Poe, Verne, Freud, and Antonin Artaud, and discuss films by Fritz Lang, Jean-Luc Godard and Ridley Scott.

title: Global Technology
prereqs: No prior knowledge of science and mathematics will be assumed to ensure that students in the humanities and social sciences can also participate in the program. ENROLLMENT IN THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN THE TROPICAL BIOLOGY PROGRAM IN KENYA..
descrip: An introduction to key ideas in science, technology, humanities, and social sciences that are relevant to global development. The course will highlight essential needs in the rural environment and consider how to develop environmentally-friendly scientific and technology solutions to satisfy these needs. The course will also examine the potential role of global technology in the development of rural and urban areas within the developing world. Morning lectures will be followed by field activities and group projects. The course will be taught at the Mpala Center as part of the Tropical Biology Program in Kenya.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - American Environmental History
reviews: Definitely take for certificate!
Do the reading and you'll get a lot out of the class!
Great class to take.
Take it, but be engaged
take it!
descrip: Explores the diverse connections between America's national development and natural environment. It examines how the U.S. originated, then expanded to cover a continental land mass, and the ways that expansion changed the nation. It analyzes how, why, and with what consequences major parts of the U.S. economy--for instance, farming, energy, services and government--have grown or in shrunk. It looks at how and with what results the U.S. has incorporated different ethnic and racial groups. It shows how, why, and with what outcomes it has historically globalized and conducted its foreign policy, and offers insights into current landscapes.

title: Physical Language: Knowing Through Movement
prereqs: This course is designed for people with a physical practice: dancers, athletes, martial artists, etc. Applicants should have at least one dance course or equivalent experience. Interview required; Please visit the Dance Program website for interview information..
descrip: This course is integrates a critical study of the sources and bounds of movement knowledge with the experience of bodily cognition and the development of physical agency. We will incorporate research in cognitive studies, neuroscience, and dance epistemology with experiences of multiple somatics modalities and functional anatomy to expose students to theories of embodied agency and ask what it means to 'know' in the body. We will focus on seeking physical knowledge to generate new movement languages and acquire efficient movement patterns within our bodies, our minds, and ourselves.

title: The Phaedra Project
prereqs: A relevant course in Theater, Dance, or Visual Arts. Please visit the Theater Program website for application information..
descrip: An interdisciplinary theater-making course focused on the development of Marina Carr's "Phaedra," in preparation for its world premiere at the McCarter Theater. A truly original and lyrically explosive adaptation of the ancient Greek myth, set in a fractured visual landscape, Carr's play uses a large cast, a non-linear structure, poetic language, and a variety of non-dialogic narrative technique (both film and live action), to tell her version of the tale in a thoroughly and bravely 21st century way.

title: Evil in Christian Thought and Practice
prereqs: While familiarity with the history of Christianity will help students get the most out of this class, there are no prerequisites..
descrip: This course is an examination of how theologians, preachers, and communities came to terms with evil in the world. Beyond a consideration of the theological abstraction of evil, however, this class will examine how certain individuals and groups came to be identified as the embodiment of evil--either the demonic agents of Satan or Antichrist himself--and persecuted as such. This course will cover period of Christian history from roughly 300 to 1600, and will focus on three groups in particular who came to be recognized as the personification of Christian ideas of evil: medieval heretics, the Jews, and witches.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Sociological Perspectives on Inequality
descrip: Course covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. We begin by reviewing major theories, constructs, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks 2 -6 focus on institutions that mediate the transmission and reproduction of inequality, including families, schools, neighborhoods, labor markets, and the criminal justice system.

title: Business Ethics and Modern Religious Thought
reviews: If you can, take it!
TAKE IT! And get to know Prof. Miller outside of class.
Take it. Do the readings. This class is the best EM you can take.
Take this course if you do not have to deal with independent work simultaneously.  Take this course if you think your education is not preparing you for "the real world"--this course can help!
Take this course regardless of your future plans or religious background. Professor Miller is incredible and he brings fascinating executives to class.

This course is interesting and really focuses on helping you frame your own thoughts and opinions on these issues. It's good to think about these situations before being in them! Also the CEOs who visit are really great.
Very practical course. Great professor. Great lessons learned. Everyone should take a class like this.
take it only if you like it! it requires going to classes and additional lectures.
descrip: The course objective is to learn basic ethics theory and develop practical tools for business ethics, with particular attention throughout the course to the role of religion and spirituality in ethical formation, frameworks, and decision making. This will be applied to contemporary business ethics case studies, and will include several guest CEO visitors.

title: Natural History of Mammals
reviews: A great course.
Make sure to stay on top of all of your work! Try to read some of the articles ahead of time (before the course starts), and be ready to work hard!
prereqs: EEB 211, and EEB 321. Permission of the instructor is required for non-EEB majors..
descrip: Introduction to concepts, methods, and material of comparative natural history, with African mammals as focal organisms. Perspectives include morphology, identification, evolution, ecology, behavior and conservation. Observations and experiments on a variety of species in different habitats and at a range of scales will provide insights into the adaptive value and underlying mechanistic function of mammalian adaptations. This course will be taught in Kenya at the Mpala Research Center and nearby field sites.

title: Structural Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering
prereqs: CEE 361 and MAE 305.
descrip: Analysis of forces and deformations in structures under dynamic loads. Idealization as discrete parameter systems. Single and multiple degrees of freedom. Response analysis under free vibration, harmonic, impulsive and random dynamic loads. Time and frequency domains. Earthquake phenomena from the engineering point of view. Seismic waves and power spectra. Measurement of strong ground motion. The concepts of response spectra, structural response to earthquakes, design criteria, and seismic safety.

title: The Muslim Mediterranean
descrip: Although the word "Mediterranean" evokes images of Italy and Spain, much, if not most, of the Mediterranean has been under some form of Muslim rule - whether Arab or Turkish - since the 7th century C.E. This course will explore the Muslim experience of, and impact on, the Mediterranean world from the medieval period through the 20th century.

title: Democracy and Ethnography in the United States
descrip: In this seminar, we explore connections among scientific, literary and cultural creativities through some of anthropology's classic innovations with the idea of culture. Our cases come from U.S. scholars during two formative periods in the discipline's and the nation's history, at both ends of the 20th century, when anthropologists and the public alike were distinctively aware of the democratic implications of the concept of culture, as well the stakes in its misuse, in relation to race. Thus, anthropologists' literary efforts to persuade and guard against misreading by scholars and the public are inseparable from their theoretical concerns.

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Actually do the grammar homework.  You'll be screwed come time to write the papers if you don't.
I really recommend this course to anyone wishing to continue in Spanish studies.
I would definitely recommend it. The instructor made it especially worthwhile. It is not too much work and there only a few essays, no projects, and no presentations.
It'll improve your written Spanish. It's not for everyone, though.
Keep up with the reading in the course packet.
Lower-end 300-level Spanish course (in terms of difficulty) but nonetheless rewarding - be sure to take it if you are interested in grammar and improving your writing skills!
Take it if you want to improve your grammar, but make sure you're more conscientious about making sure you know the rules clearly than I was.
Take it. It's like a writing seminar for Spanish. It will give you a good idea of how to write an academic paper in Spanish.
Take this course if you enjoy studying Spanish grammar. Also, it can be useful as a less literature-esque LA if you are looking to fulfill distribution requirements.
This is a good course to take to better your Spanish skills. You cannot be truly fluent unless you have a through understanding of the little things in Spanish grammar.
YES IF YOU LOVE SPANISH!
prereqs: SPA 207 and/or another 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission..
descrip: For advanced students of Spanish who want to expand their writing skills and improve their knowledge of grammatical structures which continue to pose challenges. Along with the study of grammar, this course aims at reaching higher levels of accuracy while expressing ideas and opinions in writing. Inspiration for written assignments to be drawn from literary works, journalistic writings and audiovisual materials. Combination of fairly intensive writing, reading and grammar based assignments.

title: Financial Crises
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 202 or equivalent..
descrip: In this course we will use economic theory and empirical evidence to study the causes of financial crises and the effectiveness of policy responses to these crises. Particular attention will be given to some of the major economic and financial crises in the past century and to the crisis that began in August 2007.

title: Game Theory
descrip: This course will provide a broad treatment of game theory and its applications, particularly in economics. Coverage will include such topics as: common knowledge and rationality, refinements of Nash equilibrium, auctions, bargaining, mechanism design, dynamic games, and reputation. This follows up on the introduction to game theory provided in the microeconomic sequence.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Political Economy of Latin America
descrip: This course looks at issues in political economy that are particularly salient in Latin America: establishment and preservation of stable democracy, populism, sovereign debt repayment, free trade agreements, income inequality, education, narcotics trafficking. In each area we look at what the theoretical literature in economics and politics says, look at some significant cases in Latin America, and discuss policy implications, both from the perspective of policymakers in Latin America, and of policymakers in the rest of the world. The subjects will be knit together by the underlying themes of economic development and sustainable democracy.

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: A lot harder than FRE 108!!!!
Be prepared to use other resources outside of class (language tables, talking to friends) to improve your language. The class on its own probably won't suffice.
Don't take this class unless you have AP credit or unless you are a native speaker.  It is a GPA destroyer

I think that if you are looking for a french class at Princeton, it is essential to find a native speaking teacher in order to get the most out of a language class. While there are certainly non-native speaking teachers that are equally capable, it has been in my experience that a course taught by a non-native will not help you continue to develop in that particular language.
I would advise another student to be proactive about preparing for the class discussions--thinking of questions to bring to the discussion beforehand and deliberately taking an active role.
I would recommend against taking. I would take a more interesting course in this place. Not due to the professor, just because of the nature of the course.

I would say be prepared to read a lot of French and to not learn very much more about grammar.  The content is good, but the grammar that is on the tests can be frustrating because you feel like you haven't really gone over much of it.
It is a good course to keep your French up, but it does involve quite a bit of work.
It's a hard course, but good.
Take it if you have strong interest in French as the workload gets especially heavy towards end of semester.
Take it, though note that it is more of a French literature course than a French language course.

Take it. Grammar exercises can be a pain, but readings are interesting and cover material that everyone should really know, but only extracts so not that intensive. Go to classes and participate if you want to enjoy the class.
This is a good class; do the readings and come to class with something to say.
This should not be your last french class. It is slow to begin with, but if you are lucky and get a good professor, persist and you will definitely enjoy it!
not a good course. dont take unless you are already good at speaking, writing, and dont need any help with grammar.
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: Archaic and Classical Greece
reviews: A good class even for non-classics majors.
A good course with reading you will want to do.
A good course, but you need to take lots of good notes to do well on the exams.
Amazing professor!
Do it.
Do not take this class if it's for your HA. Confusing names, disorganized dates, and so many quizzes and blackboard responses that you'll feel like you're in high school.
Excellent for both those who wish to fulfill the HA requirement and those who have a genuine interest in Classics.
Highly recommend if interested in ancient Greece at all.
I would strongly recommend this course.

I would tell them that this will be one of the most engaging classes they could take here! I was never really interested in Greek history before the class, but after listening to Prof. Flower's lectures and talking to him, I found out that I really enjoyed the material! I will definitely consider taking related classes throughout my time here at Princeton.
If another student had any interest in the classical world, then I would definitely recommend this class.
If you are mildly interested in ancient Greece, this is a great overview course for you. Go to lecture and you'll be fine. THIS CLASS IS SPARTAAAA!
If you keep up with the reading and go to lecture, you should do well. It's a solid class.
It's aight. Depends on the preceptor to some extent.
Spread out the readings and enjoy! Definitely a course worth taking for anyone. Also make ID lists of the readings as you go so the small details don't get forgotten.
Sure, I'd recommend it.  It was an interesting course, certainly, and generally it wasn't an overbearing amount of work.  If you're interested, then yes, I'd give it a shot.
Take it, but make sure to do all the reading and be sure to remember everything (dates included) while reading and reviewing lecture notes.
Take it.
Take it.  It's a good history to know.

Take this course, especially if you're interested in ancient history at all.  There are a lot of interesting topics to tackle.  Figure out an efficient way to do the primary source readings and take notes.  Go to the lectures - they are incredibly helpful.
There was a pop quiz which was infuriating, but the lectures are great and it's worth taking the class just for that.

This class is a lot of boring reading and memorizing a lot of pointless material. If you are looking for a PDF, it might not be too bad. If you are a history major looking for a preclassical class-- dont take this. Look for something in the history department.

This course is great- Flower's lectures are boss and that's all you really need to get a good grasp of Greek history. Towards the end, the readings get to be excessive so do the readings in the beginning while they're still at a minimum. The quizzes keep you on top of things so that's good. If you want a laid-back history course that you devote a lot of time to at the very end when you've gotta cram/ churn out a paper, but is still not too horrible..this is the course for you.
And now I know so damn much about Greece! It's really good.
take it, i enjoyed it and it is straightforward if you just do the work
descrip: The social, political, and cultural history of ancient Greece from ca.750 B.C. through the time of the Peloponnesian War (404 B.C.). Special attention is paid to the emergence of the distinctively Greek form of political organization, the city state, and to democracy, imperialism, social practices, and cultural developments. Emphasis is placed on study of the ancient sources, methods of source analysis, and historical reasoning.

title: How Not to Go to Africa: Alternative Voices on the (East) African Narrative
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Approaches to American History
reviews: A great course to introduce you to historical writing.  The material gets a little dense, so be prepared to do a lot of reading for every class.

I would not take this course. It almost turned me off of history and was not very engaging. If you are really interested in the way historians create history, then go for it. but otherwise i would take a different 300 level history course.
It's a good class to learn how to write for history, but it is not the most enjoyable.
Keep up with the reading and have questions prepared for precept.

Take it if you want to learn how to work with primary sources and write papers (and if you're willing to spend lots of time on the papers), but if that's not your focus another history class with more lectures and a more specific time period would probably be more interesting for you.
Take it if you're interested in the study of history as a discipline, not just history in general.
Take it! It is one of the best choices you can make, even if you are not set on being a History major.
Take this course no matter what discipline you're studying.  A must for history majors.
The course is demanding and challenging but rewarding. If you plan to pursue history research seriously in the future, take this course to learn important skills.

There is a lot of reading and you absolutely have to do it, but it's pretty interesting stuff. I learned a lot about history writing and would recommend this especially if you are thinking about becoming a history major.
This class was amazing and I strongly recommend it. If you are a history major, it is a must-take.
This class will inform you if you like studying primary documents, central to independent work in history.
Very worth taking if you have a real interest in history.  Would be insufferable if you were only lukewarm about history.
prereqs: First priority is given to Sophomores then Freshmen..
descrip: A useful introduction for potential history concentrators, particularly those interested in a course focused on the methodology and practice of writing history. Students will immerse themselves in documents from three critical historical events: the Salem witch trials, the Denmark Vesey slave insurrection conspiracy, and the Little Rock school integration crisis. We will stress Interpretation of documents, the framing of historical questions, and construction of historical explanations. Students must email History's Administrator (etta@princeton.edu) indicating which class they will attend before they are able to enroll in SCORE.

title: Fundamentals of Queueing Theory
reviews: At some points it's pretty challenge (brush up on your 309!) but the professor is so nice and approachable!

I would recommend this course for a departmental, because Professor Massey is a very dedicated professor. I would encourage students to go to lecture, even though the slides are so thorough. The class is small so Prof Massey knows when you don't attend, and he often helps with homework problems toward the end of class, sine we almost always finished 20 minutes early.
It's very 309-mathy but there are a so many different interesting applications of queueing theory (ie internet, airlines, telephones, restaurant servers, etc).

Take it. The problem sets and exams aren't too hard, and though Massey's lectures aren't spectacular, the slides are all-encompassing. 

Plus there are only 6 psets and 2 take-home exams, all of which are untimed/open note. They're slightly time consuming, but way less than the typical high-level ECO/ORF class.
This is a challenging but useful course that presents a general overview of queueing theory, with many possibilities for applications.
This is a great class if you liked orf 309 - this is its real continuation. Class is very chill, while interesting, recommend taking.
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental results of queueing theory. Topics covered include the classical traffic, offered load, loss and delay stochastic models for communication systems. Through concrete examples and motivations we discuss the theory of Markov chains, Poisson processes and Monte-Carlo simulation. Fundamental queueing results such as the Erlang blocking and delay formulae, Little's law and Lindley's equation are presented. Applications are drawn from communication network systems, inventory management, and optimal staffing.

title: Literature and Gender - Feminist Theory
descrip: This course will consider major statements of feminist thought, beginning with Mary Wollstonecraft and John Stuart Mill and moving quickly into the twentieth century. We will think about what "feminism" has meant at different historical moments, what makes it a radical political ideology, how it changed academic fields like literary study, history, and art history beginning in the 1970s, and what forms feminist scholarship takes now. We will also consider how feminist theory intersects with the study of sexuality, race, and religion.

title: Automatic Control Systems
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Students will develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems.

title: Language and Law
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Optimal Learning
reviews: As said above.
Excellent and interesting class.
Great class!  I learned a lot, and the material was very useful.
I would recommend that you be prepared for some programming. Most of the problem sets are not very demanding, but there are one or two that will be.
It's an elective, and it's not too bad.

It's an interesting topic, but I don't know if I could recommend taking it because I did not find the material interesting enough for a long enough duration to compensate for my annoyance with the problem sets/long run times.  I have heard that it does make 411 more interesting.
Knowing some 309 is helpful.
Taking 418 would be useful for knowing if you want to do something Optimal Learning related for your thesis.
Take this class -- you'll learn a lot about this field, without being too "math-y" of a class.
Take this course if you are not too concerned about a grade and have an interest in the material. It is definitely an interesting subject matter.
Take this only if you're hardcore OR. Oh, and be prepared to spend time digging through typos and notation.
The course is interesting. Better have some basic knowledge of MATLAB before taking this course.
This class is interesting and well-taught.
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309.
descrip: Optimal learning addresses the problem of collecting information that is used to estimate statistics or fit a model which is then used to make decisions. Of particular interest are sequential problems where decisions adapt to information as it is learned. The course will introduce students to a wide range of applications, demonstrate how to express the problem formally, and describe a variety of practical solution strategies.

title: Problems in 19th-Century French History
descrip: Readings in the politcal, social, and cultural history of nineteenth-century France are the focus of this course. Topics include: the First and Second Empires, reaction and revolution, liberalism, France overseas, art and religion, the coming of the Third Republic.

title: Beginner's French II
reviews: Be prepared to do a little bit of work every day!
Definitely take french if you are undecided about a language or are simply curious.
Do not cram - study a bit each day.
Do the homework incrementally
Good place to learn french.
Great department, and I feel I can get a lot done in French.
I found the overall experience to be enjoyable, if not a little bit painful to wake up at 9am every morning.

I had initially intended to join FRE 102/7 this semester, but it was only offered at a time that conflicted with a departmental requirement necessary to join my major. Consequently, I often felt under-stimulated in FRE102. Of course, this is in some ways a personal decision, yet I feel as if I would have benefited immensely from the option of enrolling in a slightly more advanced course.

I think this course is a much better option than the summer reading course Princeton offers.  This one is free and just gives you more time to learn the material so that you can actually feel confident in your abilities after taking it.

I would certainly recommend other students to take this course- it is extremely fulfilling to learn a new language. The only advice I have, is to work at it daily, and put two hours a day into it. Otherwise, it is difficult to benefit from all the course has to offer.
I would recommend that he or she has enough time to commit. That is the only way to take advantage of the opportunity.
I would strongly recommend, if Brian was the instructor. :)
If you are really interested in French this isn't a bad class. If you get a good instructor you'll be fine. If you want to learn French I wouldn't let this class stop you
If you do all the work, the course is extremely helpful. You get what you put into it.
If you want to improve your language, you need to do all the homework.
If you're interested, stick with it.  It's really not that hard, and if you put in a little effort you can get a lot out of it
It's hard to start a language as an upperclassman. It becomes steadily less fun as the year continues, but it's a great skill to have and worth investing in if that's what you want to do.
Keep up to date with all the homework, that is the most important thing in this course.
Si tu veux apprendre le francais, prends-le!
Stay on top of the homework- it's not a class that makes sense to cram for just like every other language course.
Study vocab and grammar.
Take it if you're interested in french. All there is to it
Take it!  But keep up with the work and study the grammer and vocab well for each test.  And keep your study sheets!
Take the course with Zakir. Great teacher.
This course was the one that students should take.
This is a great course, and Zakir is a great teacher.
You cannot learn to effectively speak a foreign language while living in the US, it is a great opportunity, however, to gain valuable grounding in the basics.

You get out what you put in.  Getting the professors (from what I hear) as opposed to grad students is definitely a plus, so if you can work your schedule that way it will definitely change the experience.
always go to class!
take french with Murielle, i've heard complaints from other people but never students of Murielle
prereqs: FRE 101 or Permission Of Instructor. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless FRE 102 is successfully completed..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to enable you to achieve intermediate communication proficiency in French. All four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing will be actively practiced in realistic communicative situations, through a variety of activities designed to help you strengthen newly acquired vocabulary and grammatical structures. You will learn to talk about events and people, construct narratives in French and develop reading and writing skills that will be a foundation for literacy in the target language. There is a wide use of authentic material from France and the Francophone world throughout the course.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Sound of Subversion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Asset Pricing II: Stochastic Calculus and Advanced Derivatives
reviews: Again, lots of very key subjects in finance explained here. Professor is good. Just be prepared to do a lot of difficult work.
Do not take it unless you absolutely have to
Good class for someone who wants to discover stochastic calculus. Might be a bit hard for someone who doesn't have any notions.
I hope you'll be able not to chose it.
If students want to learn very technical materials, then take this.  Otherwise, this is not that real-world useful.
If you already know stochastic calculus you'll learn nothing, so look for another class.
Take this!! No ORF 335 needed.
This course is very practical.
This course simply includes too much material without much thinking. It tries to teach measure theory, stochastic derivatives and financial pricing in 1 course which is impossible.
don't.
recommmend for students who want deeper understanding of stochastic calculus and financial engineering
descrip: Course covers the pricing and hedging of advanced derivatives, including topics such as exotic options, greeks, interest rate derivatives and credit derivatives, as well as covering the basics of stochastic calculus necessary for finance. Designed for Masters students.

title: Roads Not Taken: Some Critics of American Society, 1880-1960
reviews: I would absolutely recommend that any student take this course, with no qualifiers.
Take any course taught by Professor Ryan.  He is a joy to work with and a great resource on political philosophy.
You'll get nothing out of it if you don't do the readings. Given the structure, how well it  goes is also incredibly dependent on the other students.
descrip: Many commentators during the 1950s gave the impression that postwar liberal-democracy was the 'natural' state of the USA. This obscured the work of many interesting, non-mainstream critics of modern industrial America, ranging from insurrectionary socialists to melancholy conservatives, few of them writing from the academy, including novelists, journalists, and activists. The course aims to give students the chance to read these writers and decide for themselves whether they deserved to have more influence than they did, or perhaps even less.

title: Calculus
reviews: Buy the calculus lifesaver textbook.
Class is pointless. Watch Adrian Banner videos.
Go to the review sessions.  You will probably need to hear the material more than once to understand it.
Go to the reviews!

I everyone should probably become acquainted the material taught in this course (integration, series, imaginary numbers/polar co-ordinates, volumes of solids). It's not oppressively difficult; au contraire, the amount of weekly material is quite reasonable. Professor Frank, at least, was a very good instructor. There was also the opportunity to attend Tuesday evening review sessions to elucidate the material even further.
I strongly recommend this course. Especially after taking MAth 103. If you grasp the concept in 103, then this course will seem easy to you.
I took this class as a premed requirement, and I think that it helped me to solidify my basic understanding of calculus. The material is doable if you stay on top of your work.
I would recommend working on the problem sets early so you don't have to rush to do them Sunday night and I would recommend doing the online practice quizzes before taking the weekly quiz.
I would strongly recommend Professor Norin for any students who plan on taking MAT 104.
If you have to take a math course take this one.
If you like calculus this is a good course to take.
It's manageable and not too hard.  Definitely opens the doors for a lot of classes.
It's not as easy as you think it is.
Make sure you are in the right course.
Math is hard.
Take 103 first
Take it if you need the course, if you're mildly interested in math, this class is also a good choice.
This is a fine way to learn calculus, if you want or need to for whatever reason.
USE ADRIAN BANNER REVIEW SESSIONS.
Use outside resources if you don't understand what's going on in class.
Work is manageable and it is not too difficult to do well.
You will learn a lot from this course.
prereqs: MAT 102 or MAT 103. A basic knowledge of differential calculus (derivatives and how to compute them) is assumed. Students taking this course in the spring normally should have taken MAT 103 in the fall..
descrip: Main topics are Integration Techniques and infinite series.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - How to Write a Novel in Twelve Weeks (or at least make a start)
reviews: I saw this course in the catalog and immediately knew I had to take it. If you feel the same way, then go for it! You won't be disappointed.
Take it!!!!
prereqs: This course is limited to advanced writing students who have previously completed at least two 200 level writing courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: This advanced workshop will be devoted to the novel. What makes a novel? How do novels work? Most important, how do we write one? Participants will arrive with a novel in prospect (in other words, an idea) or even a novel already in progress, will produce a minimum of eight draft pages per week, and will have their novels-in-progress workshopped by the group. In addition we will read at least three canonical novels of the past century to see what we can learn about why they succeed. Each participant's goal will be as much of a rough draft as possible of his or her novel-in-progress.

title: Climate Change: Scientific Basis, Policy Implications
reviews: Easy science, interesting topic
Expect more science and less policy, so if you already know the science, the class can drag a bit early on.
Good course, well-taught.  First half is a lot of science, though, so if you're not into that you may not want to take it (though the science isn't too hard).
Great class, very informative, worth taking.
I would definitely take this class - it's intense, but great if you're interested in the material.
I would not recommend this course.

If you are at all interested in science or environmental policy, take this class.  Professor Oppenheimer is great.  The class is really interesting and you learn a ton from a dual perspective (science and policy) not present in most classes.
If you're interested in both the science and policy of climate change, you'll like this class. If not, you'll find large sections of the material boring.
Take a lower level course on climate change.
Take it!  Oppenheimer's great.
Take this class! It's a great class to learn from one of the brightest minds, and the leading expert in climate change! Prof Oppenheimer is everyone's favorite professor!

Take this course if you really do have an interest in both the policy and science aspects.

WWS students: the science kids will best you on the first problem sets and parts of the midterm, so work hard early in the course.
This class is excellent! Great professor, great preceptor, and great coursework. If you have any interest in climate change, make sure you take this course!
This course is absolutely crucial for students who are interested in environmental science, policy or poiltics
This is a topic that I think everyone should learn about, and it's a good class.
prereqs: MAT101-102 and either CHM 201-202 or PHY 101-102 or Permission of Instructor.
descrip: This course explores the causes and consequences of human-induced climate change, and the range of potential policy responses. By studying the natural climate system and how it is influenced by human perturbation, we will develop a quantitative understanding of how climate is expected to change in the future as greenhouse gases accumulate in the atmosphere. The course also examines scientific themes that should frame any public policy based on risk management, including irreversibility, uncertainty, and surprise. We will also examine the ways in which people, governments and other institutions are actually responding to climate change.

title: Statics of Structures
reviews: I strongly recommend this course because it is fun and not too difficult.
If you have any questions, be sure to ask Professor Glisic, because he would be more than happy to help you.
Pay attention in lectures and see Professor Glisic when you have trouble, he is more than willing to help!
Take this course, it is great, and I have already recommended it to many people
This is a great course in which you will learn a lot. Although it can definitely be challenging, it teaches you a lot about structural analysis.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Develops notions of internal forces and displacements, and instructs students how to design and analyze structures. Presents the fundamental principles of structural analysis, determination of internal forces, and deflections under the static load conditions, and introduces the bending theory of plane beams and the basic energy theorems. The theory of the first order will be developed for continuous girders, frames, arches, suspension bridges, and trusses, including both statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Basic principles for construction of influence lines and determination of extreme influences will be presented.

title: Advanced Problems in Photography
prereqs: VIS 211 or 212 or 313 or VIS 315 or VIS 316.
descrip: Student-initiated problems in photography will be explored in close working relationship with the instructor. Emphasis will be on integrating practice and critical thought.

title: On the Methodology of Architectural History
descrip: Seminar examines the varying attitudes of architectural historians towards the uses and abuses of historical concepts and the very nature of historical time, as opposed to a linear survey of the various histories of architecture. Issues discussed include historicism, anachronism, revival, "prehistory," and post-historie. Close reading of five architectural historians: Sigfried Gideion, Bruno Zevi, Reyner Banham, Manfredo Tafuri and Robin Evans, plus a number of collateral readings from psychoanalysis, intellectual history and critical theory.

title: Readings in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: A reading of selections of poetry and prose. Problems of narrative, poetics, and the like may be discussed according to the interests of the class.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - Inequalities
descrip: This seminar examines various types of human inequalities and considers several thought-provoking explanations for their occurrence. The focus is primarily conceptual and philosophical, although the discussions will include references to current instances of inequality and policies designed to alleviate them. The readings include both classics in political theory and more contemporary works.

title: Selected Topics in Theoretical High-Energy Physics - Strings, Black Holes and Gauge Theories
reviews: For those who plan to work in QFT or strings this course is definitely a must, whether you already know much about strings or just starting to learn.
I strongly advise to any high energy theorist to take this course.
Take this course, if you're interested in high energy theory.
descrip: Superstring effective actions, D-branes, black holes, gauge/string correspondence.

title: Investment Science
descrip: A survey of central topics in the area of financial engineering and multiperiod financial planning systems. Pricing methodologies integrated with financial planning models. Linking asset and liability strategies to maximize surplus-wealth over time. We model the enterprise as a multistage stochastic program with decision strategies.

title: Fairy Tales: The Brothers Grimm and Beyond
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: What do fairy tales do? More than children's entertainment, they instruct, amuse, warn, initiate, and enlighten. Throughout history, they have functioned to humanize and conquer the bestial and barbaric forces that terrorize us. They have also disguised social anxieties about gender and sex. The history and social function of fairy tales will be explored in the context of eighteenth- through twentieth-century Germany. Texts will include selections from the Grimms' Hausmarchen, as well as the literature of the Romantic, Weimar, and Post-War Periods. Readings in German and English. Discussion and written work in German.

title: Analysis in a Single Variable
reviews: As it is a prerequisite for most maths majors, I cannot recommend against or for this, but it is probably a good idea to ask for help/advice from others who have taken the course.
Be prepared for lots of work. Otherwise it is a really good class giving a nice base for further study of analysis.

Conway is the worst teacher that I've had at Princeton, even by math department standards. We finished the course material by midterm, then dawdled for the rest of the year. Problem sets were fair in the first half of the course, then became insane as our preceptor ran out of intermediate-difficulty material that he could assign due to the pace of the course. Grading is admittedly more lenient in the spring than fall, but you will get more out of taking this class in the fall.
That having been said, you can still learn a lot from taking this course. Reading Rudin is useful, but I found Elementary Analysis by Ross to be a better introductory text. Good luck!

If you are scientific major (math, Physics, engineering, Orfe) i would seriously recommend it. It is useful for future studies. If you are econ, it might be useful, but still you feel pain in certain situations, and the value added is only if you think of doing graduate studies, otherwise not.
If you take it with Prof. Sarnak or someone else, by all means, go ahead. Do yourself a favor, however, and never take it with Conway.

It's true that Conway's teaching style gets mixed reactions. Some people like it and some people don't. I liked it. If you're considering taking this class and you're not sure, you should at least try it!
Math majors: prerequisite, no advice. Econ, physics, cos majors: teaches how to do proofs, which is fundamental even if it's not your primary focus.
Problem sets take a lot of time, so get started early. Taking the course with Conway means it's easier than normal since he doesn't follow Rudin, but reading some other textbook might be helpful
Take the class. It not too difficult with John Conway as he does not cover much material and he goes over concepts many times.
descrip: The rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of a function and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Introduction to Chemical Instrumentation
reviews: Good intro to various analytical techniques but probably won't make you more proficient at actually analyzing NMR or other data.
I would tell a student to take this course, but I would also urge them to read as much material as possible for background information to try to further understand the material from class.
If you are doing organic synthesis, I recommend to take this class to broaden knowledge.
Might need to supplement course material with more hands on experience.
Take the course
This class is all about NMR and only about NMR. Forget about learning anything of any substance about any other technique. But if NMR is what you're interested in, then this course would be perfect!

This course is a great introduction to the subject material, but there is little practice working with the actual spectral analysis.  Instead, it is a more theoretical approach to the material.  I would recommend following along the lectures with the reading to learn the material throughout the semester.
This is a good course.  It is especially good if you are interested mainly in NMR.
Try to do as many spectral assignments as you can on your own to get a better sense of NOE and TOCSY/COSY experiments.
descrip: The application of instrumentation (chiefly spectrometers) to modern chemical and biochemical research, including medicinal chemistry will be covered. Primary emphasis will be on NMR methods, including data processing and spectrum analysis, but additional sections of the course will be devoted to mass spectrometry , X-ray diffraction, IR, UV, and EPR spectroscopy, as well as chiroptical techniques. The integrated nature of using various instrumental methods for identification and characterization of molecular structure and dynamics will be emphasized.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies - Contemporary Cuban Literature and Visual Culture
reviews: I would strongly recommend this course IF you are interested in the subject material.  I think a lot of Spanish students will be, given that Cuba is such an interesting country but if the topic does not interest you a lot it won't be as enjoyable because it is a very small class and everyone is expected to participate a lot.
Take it !
Take this course even if you are not particularly interested in Cuba. You will be more interested in pursuing Cuban culture once the course has ended.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: In this course we will read literature and essays, examine artwork, performances and blogs, and watch films produced in Cuba or the diaspora from the 1990s through the present. Themes include the economic crisis, publishing and new media, post-cubanidad, the Raul Castro era, and others. Authors, filmmakers and artists, some of whom will visit the class, include: Anton Arrufat, Tania Bruguera, Los Carpinteros, Victor Fowler, Abilio Estevez, Carlos Garaicoa, Pedro Juan Gutierrez, Fernandez Perez, Leonardo Padura Fuentes, Ena Lucia Portela, Antonio Jose Ponte, Reina Maria Rodriguez, Juan Carlos Tabio, Anna Lidia Vega Serova, Zoe Valdes.

title: Crime, Fiction, and Film
descrip: This course will explore representations of crime (mainly but not only murder) in a range of American and European texts and films. We will look at amateur and professional detectives, crime scenes, gangsters, methods of investigation, theories of the criminal mind, and what we might think of as the sociology of fictional crime. What is the nature of this persistent, international interest in wrongdoing on the page and on the screen? Even and especially on the part of people who have no interest in real-life crime. There may be just too many answers to this question, but that's not a bad reason for asking it.

title: Empire and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Literature and Environment
descrip: How is our understanding of nature and the environment conditioned by the ways in which writers have imagined it? This course examines how literature, especially that of 19th-century America, has laid down roots for our own attitudes towards the natural world. At a time when eco-criticism has been termed "the only ethical stance toward literature," we will explore what it means for readers--and writers--to be interested in geography, ecology, and biology; in questions of space, place, and region; in forms of life that are not human; and in the political and ethical stakes of such interests.

title: Acting and Directing in Musical Theater
reviews: Absolutely take this class! You will learn so much about musical theater, and from the legendary John Rando no less!
Always have things prepared for class so you can get the most out of the time.

Anyone even mildly interested in musical theater from the perspective of an actor, director or audience member will enjoy this class. Regardless of your level of training, John Rando will help you improve.  Take this class!
Attend all the classes, and expect to put 2-3 hours of work/week into your scenes outside of class.

Definitely take it if you have an interest in musical theater performance.  The class is also totally fine for people who act but want to improve their singing.  Try to rehearse during the week, not just the Sunday night before class.  Have tons of fun! You'll learn a lot from John.
Do lots of outside research and practice a lot even if you've just acquired the material!
I have already recommended it to several.
If you enjoy musical theatre performance and you want to work with a Broadway director, TAKE THE CLASS
If you like musical theatre at all, take this course!
PLEASE take this course. It is the most wonderful thing that has happened to me since I got here.
prereqs: THR 201, THR 301, THR 311, THR 366 or THR 411 or MUS 241 or significant experience in the musical form. Please visit the Theater Program Website for application information..
descrip: A practical, hands-on introduction to acting and directing in musical theater. The course will require students to prepare songs and scenes from selected musicals with an eye to how best to approach the particular challenges the scene presents.

title: The Geography of Art
descrip: The logic of the discipline points to world art history. This seminar will discuss the possibilities of a global history of art and architecture. Questions will be considered in relation to historiography and theory of the geography of art.

title: Blood, Sex, and Oil: The Caucasus
descrip: The Caucasus region has served as a contested borderland from time immemorial and has fascinated outsiders for nearly as long. It is today a tense and explosive region. This course surveys the history of the north and south Caucasus. It begins with an overview of the region's geography, peoples, and religions, and then examines in more detail the history of the Caucasus from the Russian conquest to the present day. Topics covered include ethnic and religious conflict and coexistence, Sovietization, the formation of national identities, and pipeline politics.

title: Seminar in Political Theory - Greece and Rome as Political Models
descrip: What political models do ancient Athens, Sparta, and Rome represent, and how have these models been interpreted and used in the subsequent history of political thought? Half of this course is devoted to understanding the political institutions of ancient Greece and Rome by reading major historical writers of the time such as Thucydides, Livy, and Plutarch, as well as modern scholars. The other half explores the significance of Greece and Rome for political theory, including case studies of authors such as Machiavelli, Rousseau, John Stuart Mill, and modern democratic theorists.

title: Light, Camera, Action
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Intermediate Japanese II
reviews: DEFINITELY DO IT! But be prepared for class five days a week and homework every day.
Definitely take it if you want to learn Japanese.
Devote a lot time and effort to this course and it will be fun, worthwhile, and rewarding

Go to office hours since extremely helpful.
Get hundreds on HW and Quizzes since those are points you should not be missing and points you need in light of the curve.
Prepare a lot before class, that way you get a lot more out of it. Really class is the time you should be practicing the language because there are virtually no Japanese students to speak with on this campus.
Great teachers! You will enjoy this course, but always attend all classes.
I would advise this class to anyone who might be interested in the Japanese language or culture.
I would recommend this course to any student not already in another language course.
If you have an interest in Japanese, the classes here are fairly good, except for excessive amounts of tedious homework.
It is a very good Japanese class, though the pace may be a bit frenetic and students will have to expect to do a lot of work.
ONLY DO THIS IF YOU REALLY WANT TO LEARN THE LANGUAGE/AND OR WANT TO DO WORK/SUMMER IN JAPAN!! Not worth the amount of busywork otherwise.
Practice kanji; you learn so many, so it is a good idea to refresh your memory periodically.
Senseis are funny and Japanese is a beautiful language.
Take it if you're going to be an AB and you need to take this to finish your language requirement.
prereqs: JPN 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The course aims at a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points covered in JPN 101, 102, and 105. It is also intended to give students advanced vocabulary and expressions through aural-oral drills, readings, and written exercises. Emphasis will increasingly be on reading, but oral work will still comprise fundamental aspect of the course.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Separations in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology
reviews: A manageable class. Make sure you get a lot of practice working problems. Go to office hours because the staff are really approachable. Find people to check problem sets with.
By far the best CBE core class I've taken yet. It is pretty simple conceptually, but the problem sets can keep you up late the night before.
Class is unavoidable for CBEs. Class is worth going to since it saves having to read the incredibly dry textbook in order to get the information for problem sets.
Consider taking it even if you're not a CBE student.
Do not take unless you absolutely have to.
Don't buy the second textbook (the small one). Just share with your friends, you barely use it.
Don't take it unless you need to for Chemical Engineering
Focus on the class notes.
Go to every single lecture and take good notes; take advantage of office hours for questions about homework and the material
I would recommend that students attend lecture and to go to office hours.
I wouldn't say not take the class if you are not a chemical engineering major but it seems like everyone taking it is one.

It's not too much work, but the problem sets can be annoying. It's not terribly difficult, but this year's midterm was much more difficult than previous years', so maybe it'll get harder in the coming years. It's required, so just buckle down and do it.
Read the book in addition to going to class!
Separations is an interesting course overall and a more straight-forward departmental for the ChemE's. Prof Link is a great guy, very approachable and willing to help.
Start problem sets early.
Study diligently every week.
Study the notes.

There is absolutely no reason to take this course for non-CBE majors. For CBEs, it's not too bad as long as you don't fall behind. The material isn't too challenging, just make sure to go to lecture because the textbook is useless
This class is pretty straightforward: just do the homework and prepare for your tests.  Good luck!
While it may seem easy at first, there are many tricks in separations.
Work with groups. Probably helps a bit later in the course to have taken MOL 215.
You'll only take it if it's required.  Go to class and start problem sets early.
dont take unless chemE
required class, not too bad
prereqs: CBE 245 or MAT 104 and permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course covers the theory and practice of separations technologies used in the chemical and biochemical industry. Both equilibrium and rate-based separations will be discussed including distillation and chromatography as the primary examples. The first two-thirds of the course will focus on traditional chemical separations while the remainder of the course will be devoted to bioseparations.

title: Topics in Labor Economics
reviews: I'd say the best way to learn things and appreciate the field is to do as much reading as you can.  It can be hard to stay motivated to do that since there are few reinforcing incentives, but I'd say it's worth it.
