Labor is the best!
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical literature and the relevant empirical methods and results in selected current research topics in labor economics.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Absolutely do not graduate without taking this course. Let me repeat: absolutely do NOT graduate without taking this course. Become a fifth year senior if you have to. This is something that can't be missed. It will prepare you for a lifelong career of success no matter what you do.
Great course.  Makes you think about yourself and your life.  Also, I would even suggest that it motivates you to go out and achieve your dreams
Highly recommend it.
I think that this is an excellent course for any student interested in learning how to start and grow a business.
I would highly recommend this class if Professor Zschau is teaching it. It will give you a new perspective on life as you are about to graduate (take it as a second semester senior if possible)
If you do not take this class before you graduate, you will regret it!
It can change your post-graduation plans and more.

Just don't hesitate: you won't regret it. Ed Zschau is a great teacher and a great person, he will give methods and approaches so useful, for entrepreneurship... and for so many other things. One of the most important courses I've ever attended.
Know that it's significant time commitment to prepare for classes every week, but it's a very educational and interesting class.
Must not be shy, based very much on class participation
Princeton's best course.
Professor Zschau is a great professor. This is a course that teaches you a lot about things nothing else at Princeton does, and does so in a way that nobody else at Princeton does.
Show up on time!! And catch the last lecture.
Take it!

Take it.  One of those classes you'll regret not taking, and personally the most important class I've taken during my time in Princeton.  It's not something that blows you away, but it helps you understand what you really want to do when you graduate because of all the lessons it gives.
Take this course and work hard, you will not regret it!
This class will change your perspective on Princeton and life going forward.  Take it!!
This is one of those legendary classes that you should take regardless of major, regardless of interest, regardless of other background... Zschau is the man.
YES!
definitely take it. Zschau is incredible.
do absolutely everything you can to take this class!
take this course. entrepreneurship is a way of life and not some business skill. ed zschau will change your life.
this was the best course i took in 4 years at princeton
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application. Applications are available at ACE-21in the E-Quad. All applications must be completed and returned by December 7, 2010..
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Topics in Recent and Contemporary Philosophy - Recent & Contemporary Philosophy
descrip: The class will cover contemporary issues in metaphysics.

title: Forensic Anthropology
descrip: An introduction to the techniques of analysis that biological anthropologists apply to forensic (legal) cases. Topics include: the ethical and moral considerations of international forensic efforts, recovery of bodies, analysis of life history, reconstruction of causes of death, and case studies where anthropologists have contributed significantly to solving forensic cases. Discussions will include the limitations of the application of DNA recovery to skeletal/mummified materials; various case studies including recovery of body parts from the World Trade Towers site; and uncovering gravesites in Bosnia and Iraq.

title: Food Security in the Middle East
descrip: The Middle East is the world's largest oil exporter but also has its highest food import dependency and water scarcity per capita. This is a strategic concern for Middle East policy makers, influencing decisions. The course analyzes how Middle East food security is affected by various factors such as tighter global food markets, a decline in domestic agriculture and population growth. It looks at the historic development of agricultural relations and their importance in development planning. Special attention is given to the 2008 world food crisis and international agro-investments of Arab Gulf countries to safeguard their food security.

title: Darwin in His Time and Ours
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Japanese Print
reviews: ART 425 is a great class!  Especially if you're less familiar with Asian art, Prof. Watsky makes the material very approachable and enjoyable.

I would strongly recommend this course to both undergraduate and graduate students as it addresses many important aspects of Japanese print such as physical qualities and condition of the print and teaches students how to really look at a print.

If you're interested in Japan, prints, or just art in general I think this class would be wonderful. I think also even with almost no art background it is a very approachable class-the context is provided through the reading.
This course is a great option for anyone who has even the slightest interest in Japanese art.
prereqs: At least one lower level course in art history or Japanese studies, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines Japanese woodblock prints from the 17th through the 19th century. We will consider the formal and technical aspects of prints, the varied subject matter, including the "floating world" of prostitution and theatre, the Japanese landscape and urban centers, and the links between literature and prints, especially the re-working of classical literary themes in popular prints. The seminar will emphasize the study of prints in the Princeton University Art Museum; students will also research Japanese prints at an art gallery in New York and recommend one to be purchased and added to the collection of the Museum.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Work and Love, Play and Politics in Spanish Cinema
reviews: Loureiro is an amazing and funny professor and I would recommend this course to everyone.
Professor Loureiro is great!
Take the class, watch every movie.
Take this course.  Professor Loureiro is incredibly knowledgeable about the material and it is truly a pleasure to listen to him.

This course takes up a substantial amount of time because you are expected to watch two films a week and write about them. However, it is a great introduction to Spanish film, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in the subject.
Try to watch the movies as early as possible.
Watch the movies! Though some are rather long, they are very interesting and necessary to participate in class discussion!

While definitely taxing in terms of workload, I never felt overwhelmed by all that I had to do for this course, and not having a final exam or paper was a huge help during reading period/finals.  It was enough of a time commitment to peak a significant interest in film but also not too much to where I completely burnt out on the material.
prereqs: At least one Spanish course above SPA 207 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will explore some of the most distinctive themes present in Spanish films over the last 40 years. The three main thematic units will be: the modernization of Spain since the 1960s (urban transformations; the changing face of love; new sexualities); old and new political orders (civil war, political repression, terrorism); playful worlds (thrilling boredom; the world is a stage).

title: Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: A challenging class for certain, but probably the best of the MOL core classes, especially given the winning Burdine/Coller duo.
A lot of memorization, but it's a pretty good class.

A pretty good class. Study hard for the exams; absolutely anything covered in lecture is fair game, so learn more than just the "molecules to know". Make sure you understand the concepts and experiments as well though; it is not just rote memorization.
Answer problem sets taking each question EXTREMELY literally - and be ready to ask for points back on a regular basis by providing sources for your answers that are rock solid.
Check your problem set answers with other students. The professors encourage it. Attend lecture and enjoy.

Consulting outside readings is helpful for understanding the significance of cell and developmental biology in research and the different techniques used to support current findings. The textbooks are good for facts, but they are not the only resources that you should use in the class.
Don't take it unless you need it.
Go to all the lectures and take notes. Making summaries of the lectures really helps.
Good, interesting (required!) class for the biologically inclined.

Great teaching, not impossibly difficult, but grading is competitive.  If you have an interest in cell or developmental biology, this is a fantastic course and you should definitely take it, but you will have to put time and work into it.
I would recommend this course for MOL majors, as it does cover many, many names and molecules that I have heard about but not understood details for.
I would take the class again for the material, assuming all the negative things would be resolved by next year.

If the professors were to consider restructuring the course appropriately, this would be an amazing course to take.  Neither of them is a bad teacher and they seem to really care, so I think this could be great.  As it stands, however, I'm ambivalent in regards to recommending it to other students.
It's a great course.  Very interesting.
Only if you have to.

Pay attention during lectures, take good notes, clarify any questions you have, and you won't need the textbooks to do well in the course.  If Laura Terry is still a preceptor, her posted notes on each lecture were a great help during exam preparation.  With her notes and your own, the lecture slides, and asking questions, you should have all that you need to get a good grade.
Put in the time and you'll get a lot out of it. And probably a good grade.
Study very hard because the tests are hard, but Coller and Burdine are great professors and this is a very interesting class. The only hard part is the curve.
Study!  Don't fall behind!  This class covers a lot of material in a short period of time, so you need to keep up with everything.
Take it if ya need to or have a special interest in the material.
Take it if you're interested in development - even if you're not a MOL major!

Take the course, for sure - it is really cool stuff.  But be prepared for a lot of information to get in your head - it is a good idea to review lecture material on a regular basis and ask questions from the TAs, who are really helpful!
Take this class only if you're genuinely interested developmental biology, a lot of complicated information is thrown at you. This class involves equal amounts of memorization and application.
The course is difficult, but the material is pretty interesting. I would recommend taking it to those with an interest in biology.

This course is very interesting, but be prepared to work hard. You will learn a lot about essential cellular and developmental processes. If you have a background in science research or a strong curiosity about science, this course is for you.

This is a regular departmental course in MOL...but the tests were too easy so the curve was weird I thought.

If Laura Terry is precepting, take it.
Unless you have to take it as a departmental, do not take this class.
Well, it's required... but I still feel like I learned a lot.
majors have to take it.

read the textbook before, or at least after, lecture; spend lots of time on the problem sets--it might not be necessary to spend 10 hours on the questions, but the process also helps you learn other related material
since you probably have to take the course, know that it is not as bad as when previous professors have taught it
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345 is required..
descrip: The mechanisms that underlie development of multicellular organisms, from C. elegans to humans, will be examined using biochemical, genetic and cell biological approaches. The course will investigate the roles that gene regulation, cell-cell communication, cell adhesion, cell motility, cell death, signal transduction and intracellular trafficking play in the commitment, differentiation and assembly of cells into specialized tissues.

title: Senior Project with Design
descrip: Similar to 440 with the principle difference that the team or group project must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior project with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Psychology of Thinking
prereqs: PSY 255 or PSY/PHI 237 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The aim of the course is to elucidate the main forms of human thinking, e.g. calculation, deduction, induction, creation, and association. The course will consider psychological theories of these processes and their experimental investigation.

title: Thesis Studio
reviews: Do It!
prereqs: One course is required for all M.Arch. students. Completion of Pre-Thesis Workshops is required for entry into Thesis Studio..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student. The student begins with a thesis statement outlining an area of study or a problem that has consequences for contemporary architectural production. Marking the transition between the academic and professional worlds, the thesis project is an opportunity for each student to define an individual position with regard to a specific aspect of architectural practice. As an integral part of the design process, it is intended that the thesis project will incorporate research, programming and site definition.

title: Black Power and Its Theology of Liberation
descrip: This course examines the various pieties of the Black Power Era. We chart the explicit and implicit utopian visions of the politics of the period that, at once, criticized established black religious institutions and articulated alternative ways of imagining salvation. We also explore the attempt by black theologians to translate the prophetic black church tradition into the idiom of black power. Our aim is to keep in view the significance of the Black Power era for understanding the changing role and place of black religion in black public life.

title: Ceramics Sculpture
reviews: Although time-consuming, this class is very fun, rewarding and beneficial.  I would strongly recommend taking it, although if you don't really like clay it's probably not for you.
I would recommend this course if you have an interest in the arts.
TAKE RISKS AND BE STRANGE. I found that taking intro sculpture before this course really allowed me to not feel limited with such a strong focus on one medium.
do put in the time, and there is a lot needed for this class, but you'll be prouder of the things you do.  Show up on time.
descrip: This course is course designed for students interested in learning the fundamentals of working with clay. A wide variety of hand building techniques will be taught, enabling students to make utilitarian vessels as well as sculptural forms. Students will learn about glazing and colored engobe application methods and how to operate electric and gas kilns. Studio work may be complemented by readings, field trips and slide presentations.

title: Art and Politics of the Russian Avant Garde
descrip: This course will investigate the complex inter-relationships between politics, ideology, and aesthetics, and consider whether it is only governments and the policies they make that have the power to coerce artistic production, or whether artists can shape politics and ideology as well. In short: What does it mean for art to be political? The primary historical focus will be on Russian art before, during, and after the Bolshevik revolution, but comparative geo-historical cases will also be considered.

title: Gender and Latin American States
descrip: This course examines the intersection of gender, power, and identity in various states in Mesoamerica. It explores states of different time periods and political movements (e.g., pre-Columbian, colonial, national and transnational state systems), bisecting traditional divides in prehistory and history. Rather than approach gender from an evolutionary perspective, readings and discussions focus on comparative analyses that both challenge monolithic perspectives of social power and underscore historical contingency in the constitution of gender.

title: Environmental Engineering Fundamentals II: Surface and Subsurface Processes
descrip: Second course in a two-part series focuses on surface and subsurface processes in environmental engineering and water resources. Topics addressed include the evapotranspiration and energy & water resources fluxes, physical hydrology of the surface and subsurface, and chemistry of water and pollution, which are discussed and analyzed through the use of governing equations and concepts of environmental chemistry and physical hydrology.

title: The Philosophy of Aristotle
descrip: An examination of metaphysical issues in Aristotle, starting from the work of his predecessors. Likely themes are treatments of the different senses of being, the different senses of unity, and different kinds of "one-many problem" in Plato, perhaps in other earlier philosophers (Eleatics, "sophists," Old Academics), and in Aristotle's critical examinations of Platonic and other Academic theories of eternally unchanging beings. We may also look at later Greek or Arabic interpretations of these themes in Aristotle.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Seminar. Modern Architecture
reviews: A wonderful class--Professor da Costa Meyer is great!
It was great, just be prepared for some not so arty readings.
When the professor asks to you give a brief presentation or write a term paper on a nineteenth century topic, be sure to stick with the given chronological and geographical parameters!
descrip: This seminar studies the radical forms of urban renewal that altered the city of Paris during the heyday of Impressionism. The often violent redistribution of social classes across the urban territory, creation of new forms of infrastructure, and transformation of the city into spectacle had a pronounced effect on citizens. Urban mobility, new forms of leisure and consumption, but also spatial segregation and class antagonisms all helped pave the way for new cultures and counter-cultures. We shall analyze how notions of identity were being forged and reinvented as traditional class and gender roles changed.

title: Evolution and the Behavior of the Sexes
reviews: A great introduction to the topic--I learned so much. A ton of work, though.
Absolutely take this. It will change your view of society and biology, and will be interesting even to non-science majors.
I highly recommend this class. But be prepared to fully engage the material because that's what it takes to learn understand everything.
I would advise other students to take this course.

If you like behavior but also like people - the first half is more animal based (woo eeb) and the second half more anthro - interesting but you definitely have to recognize that this was a crosslisted class - alot of different people from different majors but it makes the discussion more interesting
Not a bad course.
Really interesting course. Many, frequent writing assignments.
Take it if Kate and Catherine are teaching it. They made the class.
Take it! It'll blow your mind. Just be wary-- there definitely is quite a bit of work.

Take this class! It provides an intimate setting in which you can explore the topic of evolution of the sexes. It covers a wide variety of fascinating issues and allows you to form your own opinions about the current literature. The workload is very manageable.
Take this course if you have the time to invest in all of it.  If you're dealing with independent work, don't take it.
descrip: This course, designed to capitalize on diverse student backgrounds, will use principles of evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology to examine mating strategies and their effect on social systems. We will draw examples from vertebrates, with an emphasis on group-living mammals, particularly primates and elephants. Topics will include mate selection, ontogeny of sex differences, sexual diversity, social bonds and cooperation, and intersexual conflict.

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews: Definitely take this class if Professor Beliaev is teaching it.  This is the best math course I have taken at Princeton.  Professor Beliaev goes through the material fast (we finished the book in the first 9 weeks, then spent 3 weeks doing supplementary material), but he explains things well.  I really learned a great deal from this class.  It seems that Professor Aizenman often teaches this class as well.  Having had both professors (I had Aizenman for a different class) I can definitely say Beliaev is the better teacher, so try to take it with him if possible.

Great course. Beliaev is a great teacher, and the midterm and final are both take-home. I took this course after MAT 201/202 and MAE 305, so it was by far the most rigorous math course I'd taken yet, but I did fine just making sure to go to class and read book.

I recommend taking this class, it is easier than the Stein Sequence class but it's not boring.  And I think it's better to take in the spring than the fall b/c the fall teacher (Aizenmann) writes difficult in-class tests.

I would recommend this course to a more mathematically inclined student who wishes to study the applications of mathematics. If one seeks to go deeply into proof/rigor, the other complex analysis course would seem better suited.
It was an okay class.
Please take this class. Complex analysis is an incredibly elegant subject. The professor is great. Honestly one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton
Take the course, you'll love it!
prereqs: MAT 202 or MAT 204 or MAT 218, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Calculus of functions of one complex variable, power series expansions, residues, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Topics in the Renaissance - English Reformation Drama and Poetry
descrip: The Protestant Reformation drastically altered the shape of daily life and religious practice in England during the 16th century. In this course we will look carefully at English poems and plays in order to explore how such literary works shaped the character of devotional life during the English Reformation. Taking key theological concepts as points of departure--predestination, providence, faith, justification, the organization of the church, the life of Christ, and the relationship between church and state--we will investigate how literary works instruct readers and how they test the limits of religious tenets and institutions.

title: Radio Documentary: The Art of Narrative Journalism
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://: humanities.princeton.edu.
descrip: A good radio story does more than just convey information. It whispers in the listener's ear and lodges in the brain forever. Students in this audio storytelling course will combine precise writing, compelling interviews, sound, scene and narrative to create radio documentaries of broadcast caliber. Weekly readings and listening sessions will explore style, ethical issues, and innovative models of audio storytelling in the digital landscape.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Advanced)
descrip: Considers theories and evidence to explain processes of economic development; examines theories of economic growth, and the two-way links between development and poverty, inequality, social institutions, and the family. Policy debates on education, health, and social policy, and governmental and international aid are also covered.

title: Computer Networks
reviews: Decent CS course, but just decent and nothing more. If you have taken OS before, the course (or at least the programming part of the course) is going to seem fairly easy. If not and you had some trouble with 217, you might be overwhelmed by the assignments so start early and ask for help. If Freedman is teaching the course expect some oversimplified lectures, which give you a false sense of understanding the material. You will have to do a lot of reading and learning on your own because if you rely only on the lectures for exams you should expect to be under the curve. As for the TAs, if Prem is still a TA for the class make sure you go to his precept. He's great at explaining the material and answering any questions you might have (no matter how stupid they might seem) and always finds time to meet with you. All in all is you are looking for a good systems course, take OS.  If you are just looking for an easy systems course then take Intro to logic design. Take Networks only if you really want to learn (mainly on your own) something about networking.
Definitely worthwhile to take in the age of the Internet.
Glad I took it rather than compilers or info retrieval. Don't be afraid to take this if you haven't had OS. I found the lecture content interesting but didn't care for the programming assignments.
Good class for all COS majors to take.
Great class, make sure to attend lecture and precept, and start early on programming assignments.
If you are interested in Computer Networking, this is an excellent course. The assignments can take longer than you would expect, so make sure you start them as early as possible.
If you need a systems course, go for it!
If you're a COS major, TAKE THIS COURSE. It teaches you everything you need to add network functionality to your code, and provides some interesting insights into how networks work in general.
Interesting topics. Assignments probably not so much. Not bad if you really need another systems course.
It's tough but you learn a lot.

Professor Freedman is a dynamic, extremely knowledgeable teacher. He always solicited that we ask questions in class, and answered thoughtfully and completely. He picked the most important, interesting, and relevant topics in Networking, and presented them in the most clear, logical way aimed toward true teaching.
TAKE IT!  You come out of it really understanding how the internet works at every layer..  be ready to put super time into the assignments though.  My favorite course at princeton so far.
Take it after 333 or OS. You really need to have good programming skills. Either that, or be prepared to put a lot of time into the class.
Take it if you want to live in Friend for a few days.
Take it with friends or people who might have taken it before so that you can get help with debugging.
Take it.  Interesting material and projects, but not as hard as 318.
Take it. This stuff is important - essential to understand in CS nowadays - and very well presented.
Take this course. Freedman has great lectures and the subject is very relevant for CS students.
The course would be really hard if you have not done any c programming, as it is in my case. I spent lots of time trying to figure out things seems trivial to other students.
This class is interesting but unnecessarily difficult because of disorganization and vague assignments.
take it if you're interested in the material. i took it because it's just good to know, but in the end i don't think it was worth my time
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: This course studies computer networks and the services built on top of them. Topics include packet-switch and multi-access networks, routing and flow control, congestion control and quality-of-service, Internet protocols (IP, TCP, BGP), the client-server model and RPC, elements of distributed systems (naming, security, caching) and the design of network services (multimedia, file and web servers).

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: Sex and Gender in Anthropology (Half-Term)
descrip: This 6-week course for graduate students will focus on recent key theoretical and ethnographic texts on gender and sexuality. Recent research in clinical psychoanalytic, linguistics and rhetoric, and anthropology have opened up new ways of understanding attachment, gender identification, and cultural context in the shaping of sexuality. This course will explore this literature, with the primary concern the utility of these frames for ethnographic research.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - International Institutions and International Law
prereqs: Students wishing to enroll in the course must write a three-paragraph application of not more than 500 words. One paragraph should discuss the student's background educational and otherwise relevant to the issue of international institutions and law. The second paragraph should indicate what the student hopes to learn from the course, and the third paragraph should discuss any career aspirations relevant to the topic. Preference will be given to WWS students conditional on writing a coherent application but non WWS students are also encouraged to apply..
descrip: This course will focus on the continual tension between international law and international politics. It will examine the impact of this tension on issues of intervention and also on other issues of substantive importance, including environmental protection, trade, human rights, laws of war applicable to the "war on terror," and crimes of state. It will discuss recent developments affecting international institutions and recent changes in international law, such as the changing conception of "sovereignty."

title: Metals in Biology
reviews: Great course.

I wish this course were being taught next year. It was definetely a privelege to take and is one of the best courses I have taken while at Princeton University. If it is taught again in the future, then my only advise would be to take it and enjoy.
I would definitely recommend for others to take this course
If you are interested in both biology and chemistry, I strongly recommend this class.
It's a very good course. It is very helpful especially if you are interested in bioinorganic chemistry.
This course presents an interesting subject matter as described by one of the pioneer scientists in the field.  However, the assessments in this class are frustrating and opaque.
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 301/302 or CHM 303/304.
descrip: Life processes depend on over 25 elements whose bioinorganic chemistry is relevant to the environment (biogeochemical cycles), agriculture, and health. CHM 544 surveys the bioinorganic chemistry of the elements. In-depth coverage of key transition metal ions including manganese, iron, copper, and molybdenum focuses on redox roles in anaerobic and aerobic systems and metalloenzymes that activate small molecules and ions, including hydrogen, nitrogen, nitrate, nitric oxide, oxygen, superoxide, and hydrogen peroxide. Appreciation of the structure and reactivity of metalloenzyme systems is critical to understanding life at the molecular level.

title: Introductory Printmaking
reviews: Take it!
awesome--just plan ahead to finish assignments on time
descrip: This course introduces techniques of copper plate etching, and relief printing. Assignments focus on applications of various printmaking techniques, while encouraging independent development of subject matter. Critiques will occur throughout the term. Students are encouraged to draw regularly outside of class to cultivate themes and content applicable to their prints. Field trips to the University museum and the library's graphics collection will complement class work. Additional independent workshop hours required.

title: Animal Acts
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soviet Literature, 1917-1965
reviews: Take it if you have an interest. Take it if you've never really thought about it before. It's a great way to build your analytical skills.
You'll read some good books and they'll make enough of an impression that you'll want to talk about them.
descrip: The course surveys salient literary phenomena and developments in the period between the October Revolution and the end of Khrushchev's Thaw. We will examine works by avant-garde poets, proletarian writers, and by so-called "fellow-travelers" or "dissident" authors. The discussion of these representative texts will aim at a general understanding of Soviet culture of this period in its various currents and phases. Topics on which we will focus attention include: modernism and the fate of art; the Russian intelligentsia and the revolution; from modernist culture to Stalinism; the nature and method of socialist realism.

title: Low Power IC and System Design
descrip: Sources of power consumption; simulation power analysis, probabilistic power analysis; circuit and logic level power optimization; power analysis and optimization at the register-transfer, behavior and system levels; power management; software power estimation and optimization; hardware-software co-synthesis for low power.

title: Advanced Russian through History and Culture
prereqs: Permission of Instructor.
descrip: The course aims to improve students' proficiency in idiomatic Russian by using materials on historical and cultural topics. The materials cover Russian history from the days of Kievan Rus' to the post-Soviet era.

title: Topics in Development - Making Government Work in Fragile States
descrip: Reformers exist in many fragile states but few are able to produce sustained improvement in service delivery or in the operation of core government institutions. This course focuses on a set of governance traps that appear to subvert fragile state turnarounds and strategies for escaping these. It also addresses handling of principal-agent problems in remote areas. At a broader level, it engages participants in thinking about patterns of state formation in 21st century, focusing on scaling up of reform in urban centers. We use biography and case studies to spur thinking, plus theory drawn from economics and political science.

title: Advanced Physics (Electromagnetism)
reviews: As far as taking this class goes, I'd say take it if you're interested in learning about E&M at a conceptually deeper level than 104: this course actually shows how E and M are unified using special relativity, which was incredibly interesting. Try to have taken multivariable calculus before this class though, it'll help a lot in the earlier portions.
Dedicate a few hours a day to learning the material, try to stay a step ahead of the lectures, and the class should be fine. Tests are still very challenging, but I learned a lot in this class.
Go for it. There is some very interesting stuff in here that I don't think gets covered in 104.
Highly recommended for physics students.

I would strongly recommend this if you are a prospective physics major, or if you have a strong interest in physics. If you have not had a strong background in electromagnetism before, you will be in for a lot of work and self-study, and problem sets will be very difficult at first. It pays off in the end though.
I'd recommend it if you're interested in the subject
If you like physics and aren't afraid to spend long hours on problem sets, this course was very rewarding and interesting.
If you really like physics, you will learn a lot more exciting material in 106 than in 104. Like how magnetism can be explained by relativity!
If you're very interested in physics, and considering being a physics major take this course.
It's a pretty hard class. I took this without having done AP Physics and had to work quite a bit every week at it. There's a lot of material and it's hard to wrap your head around all of it.
Make sure to read the text book as you go along. The lectures are often not enough alone to fully grasp the material on the problem sets.
Obviously this is a prerequisite for physics concentrators, but nonetheless also a valuable if formidable challenge.
Only take if you're a Physics or Math major. Really.
Read the book. It is normally more important to the problems than the lectures.
Study hard and work with friends.
Take if you have an interest in EM and a decent background in multivariable/vector calculus
Take it if you like E&M.
Take it if you want to learn about E&M, or go on to do more courses in the physics department
Take it- the lectures sometimes aren't the best, but the material is interesting and Purcell is a good text.
Take it.
The course provides good information about electricity and magnetism in detail.  It is both interesting and a nice challenge.

There is really very little positive that I can say about this class.  Huse and Adam are both bad lecturers who like to write formulas and do long derivations on the board for an entire class instead of trying to explain anything at all.  Perhaps a better way to spend our time would be to have a precept session like in PHY 105 once a week.  The problems mostly consist of figuring out how to set up some integral and then doing it out in gory detail, possibly several times, often with ugly answers.  The labs mostly consist of sitting around analyzing errors, either that or sometimes there will be a physics problem in the lab, and then the lab consists mostly of sitting around trying to solve said problem since it usually counts for most of the lab grade for the week.

Purcell is a wonderful book, and a lot of the time the class boils down to just reading it before assignments and exams to figure out what the hell is going on.  Speaking of which, the midterm this year was decent and the final was complete murder, we haven't gotten the grades back but I don't doubt they will be horrific.

I have a passing interest in physics, but I am convinced that in order to enjoy taking this class, you must be very, VERY fascinated with understanding this material.  None of it comes easily at all, and too much of it devolves into learning unintuitive rules to be very inspiring at all.

This class is so much more reasonable than PHY 105. The class and problem sets and tests involve much more of you understanding the physics than being able to come up with some brilliant solution. All in all, completely reasonable and doable as a class. You will rely on calculus more a significant number of the problems. Some of the labs are legitimately awesome. There will be times you are annoyed and frustrated with this course, but all in all it is a good one.
This class starts off pretty easy if you've taken some kind of E&M before. Don't be fooled; it gets hard.

This course is as hard as PHY104, but it is difficult in the good way (ie, because you learn a ton) rather than in the tedious way (ie, iClicker and weekly quizzes. Regardless of whether you took 105, this course is the best option. This course is much easier than 105, yet somehow more educational
Unless you're a physics major, do not take this course. You need to come in with a passion for physics to really get anything out of it.
if you like/are good at physics, you should take this course. it's slightly easier than 105.
it is very hard, but through your own effort a lot can be learned
take it if you want
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105..
descrip: This course features the classical theory of electricity and magnetism, with emphasis on the unification of these forces through the special theory of relativity. While the subject matter is similar to that of PHY 104, the treatment is more sophisticated. The topics also include DC and AC circuits and the electromagnetic behavior of matter.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Senior standing is required for enrollment in this course..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers,subject to the consent of the faculty advisor.

title: Semiconductor Devices, ICs, and Micro-Fabrication
reviews:
if you are considering this class, don't.
if you need to take it for ELE, switch majors.
if it's this or death, go with death.
Don't take it unless you're ELE. It's not very interesting, and not very well taught.
Don't take it, ever.

Don't take this class unless you're serious about being an ELE. Clear the rest of your schedule to make space for this class- it will eat up your time near the end of the semester. I recommend taking no more than 2 other hard courses at the same time.
Maybe get a different text book if they keep chennming's one that is currently used.  Avoid until they restructure it if you can.

Not the best class. Start lab reports early. If you are ELE, don't drop just because of this class... everyone finds it difficult and you won't have to encounter this material again if you don't want to.
There are absolutely no redeeming qualities to this course, except that you feel kind of cool for making an IC (if you're into that).
This is an incredibly hard class, it often consumed entire days of my weekend and night labs consistently ran over into the night. do not take this course unless required.
Use the Neamen textbook.
prereqs: PHY 104. Pass/Fail not available to EE majors. Successful completion of ELE208 is a prerequisite for admission to senior independent work in the silicon device fabrication laboratory. PHY104 is a Pre- or Co-requisite. Elementary knowledge of circuits is required..
descrip: This course examines what is inside a microchip, how it works, and how it is made. Topics include semiconductor material structures and properties, pn junction, solar cells, metal-oxide-semiconductor (MOS) field-effect transistors (MOSFET's), bipolar transistors, and their circuit applications such as digital gates and analog amplifiers, as well as microfabrication technology for semiconductor devices and integrated circuits, such as photolithography, etching, evaporation, and other thin film processing. The course has a hands-on integrated circuit microfabrication lab to fabricate diodes, MOSFET's and circuits by students themselves.

title: Topics in Urban History - City, Region, Nation, Place
descrip: Course surveys the rich recent scholarship on the history of cities and their regions, which intersects with many disciplines?including geography, political science, visual studies, the built environment, planning, policy, and architecture--as well as with established historical fields of research in race, ethnicity, gender, class, and culture. Seminar covers evolution of the field from detailed community studies of the 1960s to recent interdisciplinary and national studies, addressing problems of place, social processes, and human experience. Students focus on methods, frameworks, and narrative strategies.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: Be prepared & don't fall behind
Damron is a great professor. His lecture are incredibly clear and he is very approachable.  Take it if he's ever teaching it (or anything else he is teaching).
Don't procrastinate and don't sleep in class.
Highly highly recommend taking any class by Michael Damron.  Seriously, he is probably one of the most organized and neat math instructors I will have.
I think it is better to take this class as the first math class if you are considering math major.

I would recommend this class for people that need (or want) linear algebra, that have strong math backgrounds and like a more theoretical and abstract approach. You don't need to have taken 215 as long as you have had some experience with writing proofs.
If you like math take it.

If you're a math major, you need this course. If you're not, it's proof-based, so only take it if you really want to? Damron's a great teacher though (and definitely really cool/fun), so his stories are even sometimes worth going to class.

Linear algebra is an area of fundamental importance in mathematics, and after learning it a lot of things in math and quantitative science start to make a lot more intuitive sense (e.g. least-square approximations or Fourier analysis.) This course is valuable in providing such a deeper understanding, although I feel it is not always taught as well as it could be.
Problem sets could sometimes take a lot of time. Make sure you start early.

Take Math 215 first, and when you take this make sure you ask yourself a couple of weeks in if you like abstract theory as much as you thought you did last semester. It is always possible to switch into 204.
Take it if you might seriously major in math. Otherwise there's probably no need too, and you would probably be doing yourself a disservice.
Take it under Dr Damron if possible, and go for his office hours.

Take it- you may think it's going very slow at the beginning, but half way into the semester it starts getting toward the difficulty of 215.  If you don't have any experience with proofs I'd suggest taking this before 215.
Take the class if you want to train your math skills.
Take this course only if you're not into computations. This is an abstract class aimed at preparing math majors for the department.
The course teaches important information and is interesting.  It is an excellent course and gives a good challenge.

Writing and reading a proof is not like doing a math problem. If you have only taken 20x courses prior to this, be aware that you will have to adapt to a style of teaching and learning that places much greater demands on your ability to reason things out for yourself. Having said that, this is a well-taught and valuable course, and the subject matter is very interesting.
descrip: Rigorous introduction to linear algebra and matrices, with emphasis on proofs rather than on applications.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Political Economy of Education Finance
descrip: Providing primary and secondary education absorbs over 20% of state and local government expenditures in the U.S. The magnitude of spending needs and the large disparities in economic capabilities across school districts create great challenges for financing public education. Financing schools has become an arena for debate not only about education but also about redistribution. Course studies the political, legal, and economic challenges involved in education finance and the diverse ways being attempted to cope with them.

title: Pirates, Privateers, and State Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Ideology - Politics of Memory and Human Rights in Global Latin America
reviews: Go in knowing that the language will be challenging and prepare one or two things you want to say in each class.  Then you'll get a lot out of it!

If you want to learn about Latin American politics and history in the second half of the twentieth century, take this course! You'll learn a lot about those two topics, as well as the representation of trauma/violence in art and literature.
Its really good.  Professor Draper is really kind and approachable and passionate about the subject.  I especially learned a lot about Argentina's past and its culture.
Participate, and read thoughtfully.
Yes take this course! Susana is a wonderful person. Wonderful professors make all the difference in any course. The readings and videos are also pretty cool!
this class is great if you're interested in how artists like photographers and writers react to human rights violations.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course explores recent cultural and artistic productions that deal with human rights and political violence issues in contemporary Latin America, focusing on the politics of memory behind representations of the past in the context of a "global" marketing of memory. By working with literature, testimony, film, photography, truth commissions, and processes of museification, it analyzes different modes of figuring the past as well as the areas that these languages leave aside when memory becomes the target of a "global market" and "trauma tourism."

title: Seminar in Special Problems in Chinese Painting - Song-Yuan Painting
descrip: Song-Yuan painting, 10th through 14th centuries. Focus on the rise of scholars' painting, the conditions for and timing of its emergence, the changing role of description in painting style, the persistence of earlier styles, historians' characterizations of change in Chinese painting history.

title: Spiritual Exercises: Classics of Christian Spirituality
descrip: This seminar will focus on several of the classic texts of Eastern and Western Christian (primarily Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox) spirituality and their authors. Topics will include the development of spiritual tradition and "schools" within specific historical and social contexts.

title: Financial Economics II
reviews: Good course
I would recommend that students be prepared for both a theoretical and an empirical introduction to corporate finance and financial intermediation.
descrip: Review of probability and stochastic processes, stochastic integrals, reduction to martingale gains from trade, change of variable (Ito's lemma, local time, generalized Ito's formula, Girsanov's theorem), stochastic differential equations, the Black-Scholes model, the term-structure of interest rates, equilibrium assest pricing, an introduction to the optimal control of diffusions and some applications.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Social Psychology
descrip: Introduction to graduate level social psychology for first year graduate students in psychology. This course will serve as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Tropical Ecology
reviews: Do all the suggested readings!
Have a blast!
descrip: This intensive three week field course takes place during January in a suitable tropical locality. Readings, discussions, and individual projects. The content and location are varied to suit the needs of the participants. Students provide their own travel funds.

title: History of Economic Thought
prereqs: ECO 100.
descrip: A survey of the history of economics, with an emphasis on the origins, nature, and course of leading economic ideas. This class aims to situate economic ideas in their historical context, thus providing a deeper understanding of economic life and theories of it. We critically appraise economic texts from Aristotle to 20th century writers, not solely out of antiquarian interest, but also for their insights into commercial society's foundational issues: the role of the state in the economy, the nature of human action and of the social good, and the social effects of property rights, prices, trade and the other defining attributes of markets.

title: Instrumentation and Performance
descrip: A study of the characteristics of individual instruments, including extended contemporary techniques and writing arrangements for chamber ensemble and for orchestra. Special attention is given to problems of combining voice and instruments. The arrangements written for this class are performed by the Composers' Ensemble at Princeton and the Princeton University Orchestra, and problems of performance involving notation, rehearsal, and conducting are dealt with.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: Certainly worth considering if interested in behavioural finance.
DO IT
Fair class. Some typos in the notes. Interesting topic. A bit too descriptive. Not enough models.
Take it!
should take it.
prereqs: Economics 562 recommended.
descrip: Traditional economics and finance typically use the simple "rational actor" model, where people perfectly maximize, and efficient financial markets. We will present models that are psychologically more realistic than this standard model. About 30% of the course will be devoted to economics, 70% to finance. Applications to economics will include decision theory, happiness, fairness, and neuroeconomics. Applications to finance will include theory and evidence on investor psychology, predictability of the stock market and other markets, limits to arbitrage, bubbles and crashes, experimental finance, and behavioral corporate finance

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: The senior thesis is an independent study for individual students. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Students develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Students develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Students submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Second Language Acquisition: Theory and Praxis
prereqs: Admission by application only, with preference given to German majors in the linguistics track and students in the Teacher Prep program who need certification for World Languages. Applications are available in the German Department (203 East Pyne). APPLICATION DEADLINE: applications must be in Dr. Rankin's office mailbox (208 East Pyne) by 5:00 PM, NOVEMBER 22, 2010. Students will be notified of their application status by Monday, November 29, 2010..
descrip: The course will introduce students to recent theories of second language acquisition (SLA) by way of critical reading and discussion; it will show how SLA theories manifest themselves in various teaching approaches by influencing instructional syllabi and classroom methodology; and it will provide an opportunity for course participants to apply the insights gained to a real pedagogical context. Each student in the class will be paired with a community member for weekly tutoring in ESL, so that the experience of teaching will inform (and be informed by) our discussions of SLA theory.

title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
reviews: Be very, very thorough in your explanations, even in problem sets. Do not treat your problem sets like those in other classes, because you need more explanation. In all sentence-based answers, be much more thorough with the treatment of the topic than you think you need to be, and give specific examples whenever possible (not just when you think it's applicable), or you will lose points for not including xyz.
Brush up on your chemistry knowledge before taking the class; keep up with the work; don't fall behind.

ChemE's considering sustainable energy? Do this. It's basically CBE245 and some separations, plus some less mathematical, more environmental stuff.

As for the rest of you, it's a moderate introductory class that covers an array of environmental issues. If you're interested in that, go for it. Be aware there's more than the average mathematical modeling involved.
Definitely attend lecture and take detailed notes and it will make homework and exams much easier.

Definitely take the course if you have an interest in actually helping the environment. Take very careful notes in lecture, as that tends to be what she cares the most about, and spend time on learning MATLAB.
Don't take this unless you have to.
I recommend not taking this course if you don't have to.
I spent a lot of time studying for this class. But I think that it is an appropriate introduction to a very versatile and varied field.
If nothing else, attend Bob Harris' lectures. They're legit
If there is a similar course out there, never ever take this course. The course has the potential to be very interesting, it is just heart breaking how it is ruined.
If you are interested in the topic, it is well worth taking.
If you're interested in environmental engineering then this is the best course for you to start with.
It is an easy course, especially if you already have some background in environmental engineering.  However it was not very enjoyable.
Only take this course if you need to. Go to class or find notes from someone because they are the only items relevant to the psets.
Take the class if you are interested in the environment. An excellent choice in general.
avoid taking this at all costs
don't take it!
prereqs: CHM 201 and MAT 104 (can be taken concurrently), or permission of the instructor.
descrip: The course introduces the students to the basic chemical and physical processes of relevance in environmental engineering. Mass and energy balance and transport concepts are introduced and the chemical principles governing reaction kinetics and phase partitioning are presented. We then turn our focus to the application of these principles in environmental engineering problems related to water and air pollution.

title: Readings in American History: World War I to the Present
reviews: Strongly recommended to anyone interested in 20th century American history, but also modern American politics.
Take it.
This is a great course. I highly recommend it. But, be prepared for a lot of reading and come to class ready to engage in a lively discussion.
descrip: Fourth in a sequence of core courses in United States history, this course is designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American history since World War I.

title: Biology of Coral Reefs
reviews: Bring a rash guard instead of a wet suit. Ask questions about what you can expect in the Pacific before deciding on your project. Don't try to look at too many things in your project because that will just make the work harder for you and you won't end up using all of the data.
Bring patience, anti-itch cream, lots of books, an underwater camera, and a rash guard.
I still strongly recommend the field semester in Panama. I only hope this course will be better managed in the future.
If you're going to Coiba, bring a full-body rash guard.  The jellyfish are bad and Pacala won't warn you about them.
Make sure you plan a project that can be conducted both on the Caribbean and the Pacific sides - some groups didn't and had trouble modifying their projects and writing up a unified report.

Take the course and read about coral reefs and possible projects before the actual course because while you are on the islands you won't have any opportunity to look at the previosu literature to design a project

This course is fun and you get to go to cool islands, but there may be jellyfish, which aren't fun. You won't learn much book knowledge or background knowledge, you'll mostly just be working on collecting data.

This course will kick your ass.  No days off, lots of bus travel, lots of bumpy boat rides, and more jellyfish than you will ever want to see in your entire life.  But you'll also get to see reefs in different stages of degradation.  The marine flora and fauna I got to observe in this class were awesome in the original sense of the word.  I feel like I saw privileged things that not every human being has access too.  For example, we swam in a school of over a million fish.  Do it!
To be prepared for a lot of trouble-shooting and adaptation of methods when doing fieldwork in the water.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: This field and lecture course provides an in-depth introduction to the biology of tropical coral reefs, with an emphasis on reef fish ecology and behavior. Each day begins with a lecture, followed by six to eight hours on the water, and ends with data analysis, reading and a discussion of recent papers. Students learn to identify fishes, corals and invertebrates, and learn a variety of field methods including underwater censusing, mapping, videotaping and the recording of inter-individual interactions. Each year group projects will vary depending on previous findings and the interests of the faculty.

title: Intelligence, National Security and the Constitutional Democracy
descrip: This course treats intelligence and constitutional issues essential to evaluate controversies in national security and civil liberties in a democracy. We examine tensions through history, statute, technology, public opinion, the media and current events. Can we implement effective security and not adversely impact our constitutional rights? What is the "correct" relationship between intelligence and law enforcement? Should information be shared and/or protected? Technology threatens or protects? Is post 9/11 reform on track? You decide if government is making the right choices "for the country and individuals" based on this critical material.

title: Constraint in Modern European Fiction & Poetry
descrip: A study of 20th century writing in European languages relying to some degree on the principle of constraint or 'strict form'. Queneau, Calvino, Mathews, Perec, Roubaud and other members of Oulipo will constitute the central focus, but depending on students' linguistic competences works by e.g., Harig, Kharms, Nabokov, Cortazar may be included. Attention will be focussed on underlying principles as well as on practice and product.

title: Directed Research
descrip: During the third semester, each student writes a research paper under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: The New Testament and Christian Origins
reviews: A good class, but Lance isnt teaching it again. I would caution Christians on taking it because it might be a little basic and frustrating.
But Dr. Jenott is leaving this year, so you probably won't have the same course.
Definitely take this course if you think it sounds interesting. Its the perfect amount of work and you'll get out of it as much as you put in to it.
Do all the readings and talk to the professor/preceptor outside class hours!!
Do the readings and go to the precepts, attendance is noted. Also to not be afraid to answer questions.

Do the readings and just enjoy them--don't read them as part of a class but as a book that has changed the lives of many but do not place faith before logic because for this reason I saw a lot of students get upset throughout the class.
Do whatever the hell you want.
Good course, interesting material.  You'll be at a bit of a disadvantage if you're not already super familiar with the bible, but nothing you can't make up by working.
Great class!

I would definitely tell students looking to fulfill an HA and with an interest in Christianity to take this class. As a Christian and having attended a Christian high school, taking this class was worthwhile, as I saw the Bible through a historical rather than religious perspective.
I would recommend that other students also make appointments with their preceptors to discuss the material further and do all of the readings, as they are an integral part of this course!
If you have an interest in religion, Christianity, church history, or the canonization of the Bible then this class would be a great fit.
If you're interested in the material, then sure
It's a good basis of New Testament knowledge, which is useful for living in Western society regardless of personal religious persuasion.
TAKE IT. It was great. The professor was super interesting and made things really easy to understand. Great precepts too.

Take it if you never have read the Bible! It's very enlightening. Also, for those who have, you get an interesting historical perspective. It is a class with a good amount of work so it is not too overwhelming.

Take it! Make sure to read the companion book (Harris)--it's really helpful. This course will help you in virtually any humanities class, just because the New Testament is so important the society we live in.
Take it! The course load is not extremely demanding and it's very interesting. Make sure to go to lecture, since most of the important material is discussed by the professor.
Take this class if you want a fairly easy class and are interested in learning a broad overview of the origins of Christianity and The New Testament.
Take this class! It's really interesting, and will give you a different perspective on the Bible.
Take this class. It was amazingly interesting
This course is very interesting and examines the bible in an intellectual way.
This is an excellent course.  Readings are not very long, and lectures are very engaging.
be open to everything you hear even if it is not in your personal belief
i recommend the class. as long as you stay on top of readings and review class notes you will do great.
descrip: This course introduces students to the various documents now collected together in the New Testament, the second section of the Christian Bible. The course's approach is historical, asking questions about the people who wrote the texts, the social and political circumstances in which they wrote, and what they hoped to achieve by writing. The goal is to critically examine the texts as historical witnesses to the earliest followers of Jesus and the development of what eventually became Christianity. Special emphasis is placed upon the diversity of perspectives represented in the collection.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching in secondary or elementary school (a minimum of 10 weeks for seniors, and 12 weeks for 9th semester and graduate students). Teaching is done under supervision of a master teacher and a program staff member who regularly observes and discusses the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and individualizing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: Studies in Later Persian Literature 1200 - 1800 A.D.
descrip: Course acquaints students with the literature of the second great classical language of Islam and its legacy of epics, chronicles, lyric poems, mystical writings and imaginative tales from the traditional Persian-speaking world - including not only from present-day Iran, Afghanistan and Tajikistan but also from Anatolia, Central Asia and the Indian sub-continent. Continuation of NES-539. Treats the literature from 1200 to 1800.

title: Senior Independent Work
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required. Students are expected to spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French
reviews: As someone who seriously considered not taking this class, SERIOUSLY do it. Florent is amazing and is the best professor I've ever had.  This is my favorite class at Princeton.  The work is manageable and it's absolutely worth it.  Plus, Florent's gorgeous so it's easy to stay focused ;)

I would not enter this course lightly. It is a lot of work if you don't enjoy French and aren't committed to learning it. For those who understand the demands, it is a wonderful class and you will really learn a lot.
If you are truly interested in learning French and you have the opportunity to, take this class! It is a lot of work, yes, but it is entirely worth it!
If you want a relatively intense, yet extremely rewarding language class, take a 1027 level course.  And if you can, take French 1027 avec Monsieur Masse. You won't regret it.
If you want to learn French and you don?t mind putting in A LOT of effort the first half of the semester, this is a class you should take, especially if Florence is teaching it!
If you want to practice your speech in the language, DO NOT take this class. If you want to learn many, many grammatical rules; sign up right now.
Input work in all areas of the language to get the msot out of it.
It's a great language class.
It's a lot of work, but worth every bit of it. Florent may seem a bit intimidating at first, but he is really a great teacher. If you can, take the class, the effort will pay off.
Participate in the class discussions as much as possible

Take it if you love French and want to major or pursue a certificate in French. The class takes a ton of time and effort, but if French is a big priority for you, as it was for me, then you won't want to be anywhere else.
Take it! But be prepared to do a lot of work.
Take it! This class will improve your French, give you a chance to go to Aix, meet a really cool Professor and form a close group with 14 other students.
Take this class, the professor is amazing and you'll definitely learn a lot of French.
prereqs: FRE 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: FRE 102-7 is an intensive double course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Focus will be on reading and listening comprehension, oral proficiency, grammatical accuracy, and the development of reading and writing skills. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to various Francophone cultures through readings, videos and films.

title: Mathematical Logic
descrip: Propositional and predicate calculus. Godel completeness theorem. Finitary methods. Godel incompleteness theorem.

title: Introduction to Atmospheric Science: Dynamic Meteorology
reviews: A decent amount of physics/vector knowledge is very helpful for this course. Be prepared to work with complicated equations.
If you want to develop a mathematically intensive understanding of synoptic-scale meteorlogical phenomena this is the class for you.

If you're interested in meteorology, I would recommend this course.  Not too much work, but you cover some interesting topics. I expect the format and content of the course will be changing somewhat, since this was the first time the course was being offered.
The course material was interesting and the class was not a lot of work, but lectures were spent mostly doing derivations, which got a bit boring at times.
prereqs: One 200-level math course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course provides the rigorous introduction to the moving atmosphere needed to understand Earth's weather and climate. The fundamental forces of the atmosphere (pressure gradient, gravity, and Coriolis) and conservation laws (mass, momentum, energy) will be developed. Approximations relevant to Earth's large-scale circulation and regional-scale extreme events will be discussed. Important consequences of atmospheric turbulence will also be covered. Throughout, connections between dynamical equations and atmospheric observations will be strongly emphasized.

title: International Relations
reviews: A great course to better understand the workings of international politics.
Although it is a lot of reading, the actually written assignments are not terrible and you get a good sense of seeing things from another perspective.
Although its lots of reading, really an interesting class. Moravcsik is so smart and interesting, and brings in huge name people (like he isn't one himself) to hit on relevant topics.
Be careful about which preceptor you choose. It makes a big difference.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading, and keep up with the material and precept terms/discussion questions in order to get the best experience out of the course
Be prepared to spend 10-15 hours a week on readings and movies. The material is extremely interesting, but the workload is double that of any other POL course. Professor Moravcsik is excellent.
DO IT! You have to embrace the readings, but it's so worth it.
Definitely take this class!  Even if you aren't going to be a politics major it teaches you a lot about the way the world works.
Do all of the readings.
Do the readings and take notes as you go. Always answer the precept discussion questions in advance and fill in the key terms as the semester progresses so that you are not scrambling for the final.
Don't get lazy with the readings!
Good course for a distribution. Interesting first half if you're into theory.

Great course if you are interest in IR and are willing to focus on this course. Papers were graded harshly and got cold-called in precept on the 200  pages of reading a week. Lots of time, but a very helpful class.

Great course if you are interested in International Relations. It opened up so many doors for me for the future in terms of the many topics relating to International Relations. Definitely take this course!

I think this is a great class for any underclassperson, regardless of whether they want to study politics or public policy. It covers a wide range of subjects and will help clarify the kind of subjects one likes, such as history, political theory, or contemporary policy choices. I think I personally could have gotten more out of an upper level class, but at this point I feel I have a good base from which to think about IR.
I would definitely recommend this course. It's very informative and you will learn a lot.
I would highly recommend this class as a good intro to international relations.  There is a strong focus on theory as a lens.

I would highly recommend this course to other students, ONLY if Moravcsik is teaching because the other professor is not that good. The material is interesting and lectures are awesome. I really wish I had been able to take better advantage of the course.
I would recommend taking this course. Do the readings if you have time, but if you do not make sure you understand the general argument of each article.
I would recommend this course though would tell students that it does require a fair amount of work.

I would recommend this course, but you should realize that there is a lot of reading. Be sure to have enough time to devote to doing the reading. It gave me a great understanding of the political theories, which are a great way to understand the historical events and predict future events of countries. It's a great introduction to the Politics department.
I would say that students should be prepared to do lots of reading. Although not every reading is necessary, they do make the course more fulfilling.
If you can handle the work, take it

If you have the chance to take this course with Prof. Moravcsik, and have even a slight interest in the subject matter, do so!  He is an extremely capable lecturer, in stark contrast to the smattering of guest lecturers who gave presentations throughout the year.
If you're interested at all in politics, take this course! It is wonderful in and of itself to introduce you to a mix of political theory and IR.
Interesting course. Be prepared for a lot of material, some of which veers off course into odd theory and history.
It is a very interesting class, but beware of the huge reading load.
It's a good class. There's a LOT OF READING though, so if that is not up your alley then stay away
It's a lot of work, however I highly recommend taking the class if you're even remotely interested in IR and politics.
It's a lot of work. Don't take it in combination with hard courses and don't take it if you aren't prepared to sacrifice a lot of sleep for it.

It's a lot of work. The readings are insufferable. Moravcsik is great but the preceptors vary a lot. The grading can be semi-arbitrary and annoying. That was a lot of negativity but honestly i'd still take the class. It's quite rewarding.
Keep up with the readings!
Only take if you have lots of time for readings and a deep interest in the history of IR.
Prof. Moravcsik is great, take it P/D/F if you just want to hear him lecture.
Schedule a precept late in the week so you can tell before then which readings you need to do based on the lectures, otherwise you'll end up feeling like you're wasting time.

Start a dialogue with your preceptor early, as there seemed to be a large variety in what each preceptor required of his or her students.  There is a lot of reading, and you do actually have to read all of it, but I found having a study group outside of precept very helpful.  Do not take this class if you are not interested in the material.
TAKE THIS CLASS. Its definitely one of the better courses offered at Princeton, especially in the Spring by Moravcsik.
Take if you are willing to put in the work and read. You will gain a lot from this class if you put in effort.
Take it
Take it if you enjoy politics.
Take it!  But know that the reading is dense... and take notes of the readings as you go!
Take it! Really interesting material, just a lot of reading.
Take it.
Take this class. Professor Moravcsik is great, but always be prepared.

The course isn't the best but you just have to get through it if you want to pursue issues in this field. The Prof. is generally unavailable but the preceptors are pretty good. Some interesting topics are dealt with which could make the class worthwhile.
There is a lot of reading but its okay

Try to keep a list of each of the articles read for each week with a few sentences about their main ideas, to guide your studying and ability to make connections between different articles from one week to the next.
Unless you have time to do 250 pages of reading a week, do not take this class.
Very interesting material, offering lenses to analyze relevant and contemporary events in international relations.
While there is a fairly heavy reading load throughout the course, it will give you an excellent introduction to international relations, and will deepen your understanding of current affairs.
With this professor this was a very good class.
get ready to WORK
descrip: This course is an introduction to the causes and nature of international conflict and cooperation. We critically examine various theories of international politics by drawing on examples from various historical eras as well as across security and economic affairs. Topics include the causes of war, the pursuit of economic prosperity, the sources of international order and its breakdown, and the rise of challenges to national sovereignty.

title: Princeton Atelier - The Big Picture: Mural Arts in Philadelphia and Trenton
