prereqs: Students with interest or experience in any of the following areas of study or practice are encouraged to apply: arts and cultural policy, political and social activism, social entrepreneurship, community work, art history, visual arts, public art. Course is by application. Please see the Princeton Atelier course webpage for deadline information and online application. For more information, please contact Prof. Stacy Wolf swolf@princeton.edu or Ellen Goellner goellner@princeton.edu..
descrip: Students will collaborate with Jane Golden, Director of the Philadelphia Mural Arts Program, along with muralists Shira Walinsky and David Guinn and with local community members on a new mural project in Trenton. Students will study the history of mural art, formal issues of design and formal functions of place in public art. The course will explore how the mural process has been a powerful tool for social change and investigate how identity, perception and power shift when communities are part of creating and writing their own histories through murals and other public art. Students will help paint the final mural design in Trenton.

title: Politics of Inequality and Redistribution (Half-Term)
descrip: Study of policy preferences, differential rates of political participation, voting behavior, legislative process, political communication, urban politics and role of race in US political life are central to study of inequality in politics. Though the American case will feature prominently, we will approach issues from a comparative perspective. Thus the course provides introduction to comparative study of welfare states and political economy of advanced industrial countries, including regulation of labor markets and relationship between wage inequality, income distribution and policy preferences for redistribution and social protection.

title: Inquisition, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in German Intellectual History - Benjamin's Baudelaire: Toward a Theory of Modernity
descrip: In the course of the 1930's, the figure of Charles Baudelaire emerged as the central organizing motif in Walter Benjamin's attempt to develop a comprehensive theory of urban capitalist modernity. The seminar will trace the development of this theory from the mid-1920's (Origin of German Trauerspiel; Benjamin's intensive engagement with the European avantgarde movements) through 1940, concentrating on the finished texts that emanated from the great complex of the Arcades Project. Particular attention will be paid to the exchanges between Benjamin and his friends Siegfried Kracauer and Theodor Adorno.

title: History of the Apocalypse, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Special Topics in Informations Sciences and Systems - Optimization of Communication Systems
reviews:
It is worthy to take it. 

But Prof Chiang also offers a similar course for undergrad. If you are interested in the topic, it may be better to take that one. Usually undergrad courses are more fun than grad ones.
The course has really good material, but you must be ready to do a lot of extra reading and put in some hours into assignments.

This course covers both theory and applications of optimization. Students that have an exclusive interest in one or the other may not like it. If you have mixed interests like I did, this is a good course for you.
descrip: Study how problems in point-to-point and networked communication systems can be formulated and solved as optimization, covering both classic results and current research. Introduce the methodologies of linear program, convex optimization, Lagrange duality, and study their theoretical properties and computational algorithms. Sample application topics: information-theoretic and queuing-theoretic problems, coding and equalization, antenna beamforming, network resource allocation and utility maximization, theory of network architecture, wireless network power control, Medium Access Control schemes, IP routing, TCP congestion control.

title: An Introduction to Black Women's Studies
descrip: An interdisciplinary introduction to the study of women of African descent in the United States, 1830 to the present, through sociology, history, law, religion, and film. This course discusses black women's identity as reflected in community, stereotype, and individuality.

title: Tonal Syntax
reviews: 205/206, I think, is more helpful for composers as they provide the bare bones of counterpoint and the structure of simple pieces.
Definitely take this course with Burnham.. You'll learn a lot about music
It's a good grounding in music theory.  Take it.
Take it if you have to or if you are dying to.  Don't let it stop you from a certificate or a major (it's not burdensome), but I wouldn't do it for fun.
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: MUS 206 begins by making relevant connections between the modal counterpoint of the 16th century (studied in MUS 205) and tonality as it evolved in the 18th century. Fundamental tonal concepts will then be explored in later music including Chopin and Brahms.

title: Moses and Jesus in the Islamic Tradition
descrip: The course will focus on the changing representations of the prophets Musa (Moses) and `Isa (Jesus) within the Islamic tradition. Course materials include readings in translation from the Qur'an, hadith, Sufi poetry, the popular "Tales of the Prophets" as well as modern Islamic texts on social justice, and novels. We will examine the ways in which these prophets, while recognized by Muslims as foundational figures in Christianity and Judaism, played and continue to play a prominent role, as monotheistic prophets and as religious examplars, in many diverse aspects of Islamic thought and practice.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Intro. to Science, Technology and Environmental Policy
descrip: Designed to improve students' skill, confidence and judgment in use of science in policy applications. Using case studies, real-world examples, and in-class exercises, in the areas of atmospheric and energy policy, the emphasis is on preparing both non-scientists and scientists to use, understand, and critique science in environmental policy applications. Exercises are scaled to the student's background.

title: Japan Anthropology in Historical Perspective
descrip: The course considers Japan studies in the context of theories of capitalism, personhood, democracy, gender, and modernity. We will be discussing issues of fieldwork as method and "area" as a unit of analysis. We will also consider the place of Japan in American social thought.

title: Sociology of Sports
reviews: Definitely take if SOC major interested in athletics.
Definitely take this course
TAKE IT!  Professor Kornblum is wonderful!
This course can be really great if you and your fellow classmates make the most of it.
take it if you love sports and can write about them
descrip: The course will focus on sports and athletes in American communities (not limited to communities in the U.S.), and including sports on the college campus. Students will be asked to write about their own experiences with athletics and to compare them to examples drawn from outstanding first-hand accounts of sports in different community settings. Readings, films, and class discussions will afford opportunities to appreciate the individual and social benefits of participation in athletics, as well as the risks and value distortions that competitive sports may entail.

title: Computational Methods in Plasma Physics
reviews: If you want to do computational work in plasma physics, this course will be very useful.
prereqs: Graduate students and seniors only..
descrip: Analysis of methods for the numerical solution of the partial differential equations of plasma physics, including those of elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic, and eigenvalue type. Topics include finite difference, finite element, spectral, particle-in-cell, Monte Carlo, moving grid, and multiple-time-scale techniques, applied to the problems of plasma equilibrium, transport and stability. Basic parallel programming concepts are discussed.

title: General Plasma Physics II
reviews: If you want to know more about plasma physics, this is the course that you must take.
Useful if wanting to do any research related to tokamaks especially
descrip: Introduction to Plasma Physics at the Graduate level. Principles and applications of magnetohydrodynamic and kinetic theory are discussed. These principles are fundamental to Plasma Science, and the illustrative applications are relevant to current magnetic fusion research and plasma astrophysics.

title: Socialist Realism
descrip: The course will examine the historical formation and existence of Soviet socialist realism as a method of representation, theoretical platform, and cultural reality. Apart from prominent critical statements and secondary scholarly literature, it will consider a number of works from the fields of Soviet literature, art, and cinema. It will seek to understand socialist realism both in the broader context of European modernism and in the native Soviet context of social transformations, political prerogataives, and ideological sanctions. Lectures and discussions in English, readings in both English and Russian.

title: Tragic Drama
reviews: If you're a classics major, take this! You would be remiss if you failed to take a class on tragedy during your time here, and Ford is a great professor.
Take it!  Greek tragedy is amazing to study in the original language, and Professor Ford is fun to have since he's passionate about the material.
This is a great class, and Prof. Ford is a great teacher - just be warned that he is not organized and his grading is highly suspect; moreover, he seems to think grades are not a big deal.
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A close reading of one Greek tragedy, with supplementary readings (in English and Greek) illustrating the genre and its context.

title: Environmental Microbiology
reviews: A challenging but very interesting course. Get started on the research paper early and your reading-period-self with thank you. Same goes for the presentations - doing those during an all-nighter is possible, but not fun. Seek help on the study questions, because the wording is not always clear. Bess is always available and ready to help, so don't be afraid to seek her out. If you have any interest in the environment or biogeochemical cycles, this is a great class to take.
Anyone who cares about the environment should take this class.
I absolutely advice to take the class to students interested in biogeochemical cycles.
It is a very good class for environmental microbiology but very demanding.
It's a really useful class for anyone interested in general biology, evolutionary biology, and the geosciences. Bess is a wonderful professor and I really learned a lot from her.

Not the flashiest course, don't be tricked, this is a very worthwhile course if you put in the work and time (which you will have to). Bess is one of the nicest Professors on campus, and is always super easy to meet up with to discuss difficulties. The course does a lot of its teaching in non-obvious ways. Lecture is only part of the picture, and much of what you learn will be through the presentations, problem sets, and papers. The time commitment can be on the larger end, but only if you plan poorly and leave everything until the last minute. Very interesting course, and very useful to any aspiring scientists.

This is a interesting and engaging course.  If you're not going to be interested and engaged, I wouldn't take it, however, as it is small and full of people for whom this kind of work is central to what they do.  Don't let the thermo or other potentially intimidating physical sciences aspects scare you off.  It's very well taught and Bess doesn't let things go over your head.
prereqs: One 300-level course in chemistry or biology, or instructor's permission..
descrip: The study of microbial biogeochemistry and microbial ecology. Beginning with the physical/chemical characteristics and constraints of microbial metabolism, we will investigate the role of bacteria in elemental cycles, in soil, sediment and marine and freshwater communities, in bioremediation and chemical transformations.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: Depends on who's teaching, but great class overall.  Our professor had lots of quant work in the problem sets, so watch out (he's visiting though).

I would strongly recommend that other students take this course because it was super interesting.  Due to the financial and economics models, I would probably only recommend it to economics majors or people with some exposure to economics models.
If you're interested in behavioral economics, this is a good course to take to learn it.

This is a wonderful course! Professor Pouget presented a good combination of models and empirical evidence, and even had us play several games during class! However, since Professor Pouget only taught it for this semester, I can't say whether this course will be as great next time.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 required. ECO 310 and ECO 362 recommended..
descrip: Traditional finance typically considers that financial markets are efficient because investors are rational and maximize their expected utility from consumption. This course departs from this view and discusses how inefficiencies arise due to psychology and limits to arbitrage. The psychology of investors shapes their preferences and may impair their judgment. Whether these psychological factors have an impact on financial markets ultimately depends on arbitrageurs' ability to fight against mispricings. These issues will be covered through lectures and class games and will allow discussions about cognitive illusions and speculative bubbles.

title: Southeast Asian Islams
descrip: Seminar explores topics ranging from the Islamization of Insular Southeast Asia, the development of Muslim polities, reactions to colonialism, and transnational critiques of everyday praxis. It evaluates the role of indigenous informants in creating the body of knowledge about Islam in Southeast Asia among scholars, and looks at how that knowledge informs our present day discourse on the region and its relations with the rest of the Muslim World.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: Feel free to experiment and explore to your ability level. In fact, you will probably do better in the course if you do.
I would strong suggest you take this class if you want to explore dance and movement.
If you have any interest in creative dance, take this course!
Let loose
Take this course! It's really fun and it's a break from a "normal" class. It's a really good stress relief and it helps clear your mind.

absolutely take it, especially while aynsley is the instructor. you can come from absolutely no dance background and it's fine because every movement is stripped raw and you concentrate on feelings and getting to know your own body (not technique)
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing, and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and the cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as politics, identity, history, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: Molecular Evolutionary Genetics
reviews: If you are interested in the topic, take this class.
It is a tough course demanding a lot of time, but I learned a lot.
This class will not be offered next year.  But since Prof. Landweber will be teaching Evolutionary Bio, I would not recommend taking that class.
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, or any upper level MOL course..
descrip: How and where did life evolve? On Earth or Mars or elsewhere? This course will discuss the evolution of the molecules that sustain life (DNA, RNA and proteins) at both the micro and macro evolutionary levels. We will explore the role of these molecules in the origin and continued evolution of life. Topics include the origin of eukaryotes and organelles, the evolution of development, comparative genomics, molecular population genetics, and human evolution.

title: 20th Century Non-Conformist Russian Theatre
descrip: One is aware of Konstantin Stanislavsky's importance to Hollywood and Broadway's indebtedness to Mikhail Chekhov, but how well are we aware of the diversity of the tradition that sustained them? The present course offers a survey of 20th c. Russian non-conformist theater and drama (Mikhail Bulgakov, Daniil Kharms, Mikhail Kuzmin, Evgeny Zamiatin) as well as its theoretical foundation. A performance component is an integral part of this course.

title: International Trade
reviews: If you can afford an econ class and you are not a econ major, take this class.
This is a great course to take - it introduces you to very useful and interesting knowledge about international trade.
prereqs: MAT 103 and ECO 300 or 310..
descrip: This course analyzes the causes and consequences of international trade and investment. We investigate why nations trade, what they trade, and who gains from this trade. We then analyze the motives for countries or organizations to restrict or regulate international trade and study the effects of such policies on economic welfare. Topics covered will include the effects of trade on economic growth and wage inequality, multinationals and foreign direct investment, international trade agreements and current trade policy disputes.

title: Latin: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: Definitely take.
It seems like just the right amount of work - not too fast, not to slow. I would recommend it over 101/102.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to the Latin language: LAT 103 covers the material of LAT 101-102 in a shorter time through increased class time and drills. Students completing the course will be prepared to take LAT 105.

title: Global History (1850s - Present)
reviews: Don't feel intimidated by the professor or the class, simply because you are unfamiliar with the topic. Prof. Kotkin is very open and eager to help you learn!
descrip: This seminar offers a history of global interactions roughly since the 1850s, combining an analytical framework with an overarching narrative. It singles out geopolitics, political economy, empire, networks and exchange, warfare and welfare, and oil. Key themes include the Anglo-German antagonism, the U.S.-Japan clash, the rise and fall of global communism, the German story and the European Union, the fall and rise of China, and America's global predominance and partnerships.

title: Mapping Knowledge
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Electromagnetism
reviews: Don't take 5 courses when you take this.  It's a lot of work, but worthwhile.
If you have any interest in the subject matter, it is a great course.
If you're a physics major, you have to take it. Electrodynamics is also unique for being a very well-developed theory that seems to fit together very well---quite different from quantum mechanics.
Interesting material.
It's good with Professor Meyers' lectures, but I don't like worrying about the grade.
Take it
Take it if you have to.
Take it take it take it take it!!!
Take it, but MANAGE your time!! It is crucial to do well this semester, and easy to fall back on not reading the text but just doing the problem sets through sifting through the book.
Take this course if you want to go beyond 106 kind of material.
Take this only if you need to; it really is a lot of work.
The content is a bit overwhelming. Too much to learn, not too difficult conceptually.

This is definitely the best physics course I have taken at Princeton so far.  If you are a physics major, you have to take it, but don't worry.  You'll like it.  I also recommend it to any other science majors.  The subject area is extremely elegant and the course is well taught.  The course is primarily intended for juniors but is definitely accessible to sophomores who want to get ahead.
Very difficult, only take if you have to.
Work hard, attend lecture office hours and problem sessions and while you still aren't guaranteed to do well you will have gained a lot of knowledge.
You can't be serious about physics and not take a serious EM course like this.  I'm not sure that there would be terribly much appeal for non-majors.
You don't have a choice if you're a physics major. At least it isn't much work.
You have to take this course if you are a physics major. If you are not, Professor Meyers is an excellent instructor for the class, but it would be a lot harder with many other instructors.
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Electromagnetic theory based on Maxwell's equations. Electrostatics, including boundary valve problems, dielectrics, and energy considerations leading to the Maxwell stress tensor. Magnetostatics and simple magnetic materials. Electromagnetic waves, retarded potentials and radiation. Familiarity with vector calculus is assumed.

title: Afghanistan and the Great Powers, 1747-2001
reviews: Absolutely take this class. If you want to understand what is really going on in the region, you need to take this class.
Barry is a genius. He just gets up there and weaves a story. Highly recommended.
Be ready to discipline yourself to do the readings by your own.
Classic Princeton course!  Don't miss out taking it!
Don't take this class if you're anal about structure. You have to be willing to go with the flow because (while brilliant) Professor Barry is very unorganized.
Don't take this class just because you hear its "an easy A", because (1) that's not guaranteed and (2) the whole point of taking a class is to learn something (or so one would think...)
Don't think twice -- it's a rare treat.
Go to lecture, keep up with the readings, go to office hours, and consult Professor Barry before choosing a final paper topic.

I recommend this course for students interested in the Near East, India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Russia, Britain, international relations, and/or history. It gives such detail about Afghan history and such broader context for regional and even European history.
I would absolutely recommend that anyone the least bit interested in Afghanistan take this class.
I would definitely take this course and attend every lecture and do as many of the readings as possible because it is so information rich and interesting.
I would say take this course. It will open your eyes to the Middle East and give you so much insight into its history and answer why everyone has always been so interested in Afghanistan.

If you have even a passing interest in Afghanistan you should take this class. Barry is a wealth of knowledge having spent over 30 years living and working in the country. He's also very approachable and willing to meet with students to discuss papers, life, etc.
If you have the slightest interest in Afghanistan, this course should be mandatory.
If you need structure don't take this course. If you just want to listen to an extraordinarily passionate and knowledgeable man, take this course.
If you want to get the most of the course, do the readings even though they are not required.
Michael Barry is one of the best professors at Princeton, and this class is living proof of that. You'd be losing out if you graduated without having taken this course, or something else with him.
Not a lot of work and very interesting lectures. Definitely take a course with Professor Barry!

Professor Barry is excellent.  He is an encyclopedia of knowledge about Afghanistan, and some of his stories regarding his actual experiences in Afghanistan are truly amazing.  The class is very easy-just one midterm paper that is not graded and a 10 page final.  I am considering majoring in NES after taking this class.  Coming into Princeton, I was not considering majoring in NES at all.
TAKE THIS COURSE. It will without a doubt open your eyes about the challenges facing the Afghan nation, and the nearly insurmountable challenges we face there.
Take it and actually pay attention to prof barry
Take it!  Not all the readings are necessary, and the Pequods are incredibly expensive... Just scan readings from the library copies.
Take it! It is fantastic
Take it. You will learn a lot about Afghanistan which is such an important part of our current events.
Take this class
Take this course because Michael Barry is the f-ing man, and also because the workload is totally manageable if you're a senior simultaneously trying to write your thesis.
Take this course if you have a passing interest in South Asia, the US military, history, the Middle East, or if you want a great class from a great professor.
This class is amazing.
This course is great - don't miss out on taking it! The papers are straightforward and the lectures are illuminating!
Would recommend as an easy class in which reading is not required and there is a midterm and final paper as the only thing asked of the student.
he is the best!
descrip: The course traces the great powers' struggle for control over the Middle East, as it affected Afghanistan. It begins with an introduction to the social and ethnic background, touching on the rise of the tribal Afghan kingdom in the 18th century. It will then focus on the rivalries between Russia and Britain in the 19th century ("the Great Game"), and on those between the Soviet Union and the US in the 20th. We will conclude by studying Washington's support in the 1980's for Islamist groups fighting the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, its consequences, and the Taliban movement into the 21st century.

title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
reviews: A great survey of an important current issue. Worth taking.
Always make sure to read the primary source documents and films as they are often the subject of class discussions.
Great course, but be prepared to work.

I think it's a great course. Prof. Schayegh is extremely knowledgeable on this topic and explains things very clearly and interestingly; whenever there's a question about pretty much anything, answers are forthcoming and abundant. The material is wide-ranging, covering all sorts of aspects of the history of the conflict. It's just basically great.
If you want to take an NES class take this one.

If you're interested in the conflict currently, this course doesn't have a lot to say explicitly about recent events in the region, but it provides a great, thorough grounding in the historical roots of the conflict.
Take it, but realize that, although you'll have a great understanding of the conflict up to 1973, it won't really prepare you to debate about Israeli-Arab current events.

This course has a relatively heavy reading load, and the readings are really fundamental to gaining a better understanding of the subtleties of the issues discussed. This is a great class for anyone who has any sort of general interest in the Arab-Israeli conflict.
descrip: This course studies the history of the Arab-Israeli conflict up to 1967. Due to its contentious theme, it stresses historiographic problems and primary sources; also, it looks at Israeli and Palestinian societies as much as at the conflict between them. Questions include the ideological vs. practical roots of, and religious/secular elements in, Zionism and Palestinian nationalism; politico-economic links between the two societies; breaks in their social and/or ethnic composition; the effects of collective traumas and warfare on socio-political structures and gender; and the role of foreign powers and regional states.

title: Graphic Design
reviews: A fantastic course with a fantastic professor. Highly recommended.

BEWARE: This is the study of typography, not exactly you're modern definition of graphic design.  I found this out the hard way ? but stuck with it and gained a lot of insight I would have never expected.

I'd recommend this class only to those who already have some knowledge about graphic design -- that it's not merely about making pretty things in Photoshop -- and are aware that the class focuses solely on typography.

If you have any interest at all in graphic design and/or typography, take this course. The format is so interesting and original.  The entire course is so well-thought out and, well, just, cool. It also offers some nice variety to the schedule of most Princeton students.
Make sure you understand it's about typography, not general graphic design - i.e. you won't be using Photoshop. If you're into that, go for it!
Take it! It's great and informative and fun!
Take it, but go with the flow for it might not develop as you expect it to.

Take this class! You should know this, though: The work level really depends on who is teaching it. I took this course after reading all of the evaluations from students who took it with Reinfurt. Apparently the outside-of-class time for his class is very minimal, so if that's what you're looking for, try to take it with him. I took it with Alice, and discovered that the assignments were soooo time-intensive! However, Alice is SUPER EXCELLENT! She knows so much! I recommend her whole-heartedly. Also, I heard that Reinfurt's class was very much a typography class. While Alice's class is still pretty much just about typefaces, we don't spend a huuuuuge time in the typeshop, and we use InDesign to make very relevant projects. Really, the reason why the graphic design courses are really typography based is the same reason the intro photo courses are in film and black and white--to strip you from the high-tech stuff so you understand the basics before moving on. And Alice's assignments didn't feel super typographical, just really cool. Oh, and A LOT of architecture upperclassmen/grad students take this course, so that was fun. I didn't know much about the department before.
Very helpful for seniors specifically because it compliments thesis well, time-wise and skill-wise
its not a graphic design course its a course on typography.
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.

title: Calculus
reviews: Do practice problems on your own to get a better grasp of the material.
Do practice problems.
Go to office hours! And don't be afraid to ask questions in class.
I would say be that this class is a good calculus course if you are willing to teach yourself at times by reading the textbook. Be prepared to not be able to rely solely/mostly on your notes.
If you need math credit MAT 102 is a good class to take-not as hard as MAT 104
descrip: Continuation of MAT 101. Review of differentiation. Applications of the derivative. Intro to Integration.

title: Ethnographic Tradition (Half-Term)
descrip: First in a sequence of four modules designed to train graduate students in ethnographic methods. This class introduces students to classical and contemporary works of ethnography that exemplify the contributions this method has made to sociological theory. Weekly readings are drawn from texts on topics such as the social ecology of the city, the study of the self, race and ethnicity, organizational ethnography, disasters, and social movements. Students who select to do original research papers over the course of the entire sequence begin their preparation in this class.

title: Sex and Ethics
prereqs: One course in Philosophy or Political Theory.
descrip: An examination of the moral principles governing sexual activity. Questions to be addressed include: What is consent, and why is it morally significant? Is sex between consenting adults always permissible, and if not, why not? Are there good reasons for prohibiting prostitution and pornography? Is non-procreative sex morally wrong? Is there such a thing as sexual perversion? Why is marriage morally important? Is polygamy morally objectionable? Should we use the law to enforce controversial principles of sexual morality? Everyone has opinions about these matters. The aim of the course is to subject those opinions to scrutiny.

title: Mathematical Physics
descrip: TBA

title: Problems in Early Ottoman History
descrip: The seminar is a study of the origins and development of the Ottoman state. The emphasis is on the characteristic features of its cultural, economic, and social life, as they were developed in the eastern Balkans. By retracing the establishment of Ottoman rule in Northern Greece it will examine the nature of Ottoman Administrative practices in the 14th and 15th centuries.

title: Molecular Spectroscopy
descrip: A survey of atomic and molecular energy levels and the Hamiltonians that describe them. The interaction of radiation with matter, including multiphoton effects and nano-optics. Examples include electronic and nuclear spectroscopy of molecules and crystals, electron spin resonance, microwave spectroscopy, and the uses of lasers in modern spectroscopic research.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term)
prereqs: Course open only to graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed sufficient research to begin writing an article for publication..
descrip: Writing workshop for students who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One three-hour seminar.

title: Neuroimmunology: Immune Molecules in Normal Brain Function and Neuropathology
reviews: Absolutely recommend for MOL upperclassmen looking to learn more about the field!

I really enjoyed this course. Very good for enhancing your presentation skills. Prof B is very accessible and wants to help students learn so don't feel intimidated if you're not an MOL expert. For those who do not have a strong molecular background but want to develop an appreciation, definitely take this course. And if you're interested in learning about the really cool (and in some cases not) things our body does, this is excellent!

I would strongly recommend this class, but really only if you have a background in MOL or at least reading science papers. Even as a MOL senior, I still often struggle to decipher all these journal articles. But if you're interested in science and thinking like a scientist (especially a neuroscientist) then definitely add this one to your wish-list.
If you don't know how to read biology papers, the class might be overwhelming in the beginning, but you will know how to read primary literature by the end of the class.

It is a challenging course, not because it has a lot of work, but because it involves a lot of thinking and criticizing what seems to be perfectly fine papers. It will train you to think like a true scientist. and boulanger... is awesome!
Recommended if you have any interest in the subject
Take it to learn and develop skills for critiquing papers and for future research you may conduct yourself!
The open discussion is great. I feel like I'm in high school again and can really ask questions.
This is an excellent course. Even if you don't have a very strong science background you should definitely take it.
don't be intimidated by the name of the course, I have very little neuroscience background and was able to keep up
prereqs: MOL 214 / EEB 214 (Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology); MOL 340 (Molecular and Cellular Immunology) and MOL 348 (Cell and Developmental Biology) would provide additional useful background, and may be taken concurrently..
descrip: In this course, we will explore the diverse and complex interactions between the brain and the immune system from the perspective of current, cutting-edge research papers. In particular, we will focus on the molecular mechanisms of these interactions and their role in brain development and function as well as their potential contributions to specific neurological disorders, including autism. In the process, students will learn to read, critically evaluate, and explain in presentations the content of articles from the primary literature.

title: Material Effects
descrip: The potential of computer generated form is inexhaustible - this surplus of potential form will be regarded as a provocative to develop new synthetics, rigid and flexible composites and new hybrids of traditional building materials which may provide a context for a new architectural discourse. Working with algorithm, diagram and ideas of self-organization and non-linear sequence, this course explores the production of new materials (and their effects) within the context of the ecological and econimic systems to which they relate.

title: Topics in Physical Chemistry - Fundamental Problems in Materials Physics
prereqs: Prerequisites: Graduate-level courses in both statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics..
descrip: Fundamental microscopic understanding of the structure and bulk properties of liquids, glasses, quasicrystals and crystals, colloids and polymers. Classical statistical mechanics;sphere packing problems;local density fluctuations and classification of crystals, quasicrystals and disordered atomic systems;covering and quantizer problems as ground-state problems;inverse statistical mechanical problems;electronic ground-state problems (density functional theory, ab initio molecular dynamics, quantum Monte Carlo);quantum statistical mechanics and path integrals;linear response theory;Langevin and Fokker Planck equations;Non-Markovian processes.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation II
reviews: A class to take if you wish to really continue to studying the language or obtain a certificate.
If you like Russian, then do it...
Prepare to be disappointed. If you're serious about learning the language, then do immersion programs and get materials to practice on your own.
Take it! Keep up your Russian!!
should take it if interested in Russian
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 207. Translation and discussion of the literary texts ( 20th-century poetry) and the poets' biographies; review of selected grammar topics; work with a movie "Window to Paris".

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: This class and Mr Rahm's unique process is worthwhile for any arch. student.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Beginner's Spanish II
reviews: Bookhammer makes learning Spanish very fun

Definitely put in work with practicing with the workbook and reading the book itself or you WILL fall behind and get bad scores on the exams. You need to put in the minutes of exxtra work in addition to going to lecture, and you will really succeed. It is what you put into it. Spanish at Pinceton is not a piece of cake, but definitely doable with hard work. By the end of the year, I was amazingly better in my spanish speaking, reading, writing and overall undertanding. I'd say, take it!
Definitely take the course. It's a lot of indepenedt work and practice but if you attend and engage in classes and put in just a little work outside you will be successful.
Do it if you must.
Do the homework.

Do the workbook as it's assigned, not all at once at the end. Go over your compositions and situations with her before you turn them in--it's a lot more effective and will help you do better on it. Study hard for the exams. Use props and do a bit of acting in the situation skits--they show extra effort, and you'll get a better grade. It's also just more fun that way.
Do your homework every night.
Don't have Rina Ramos.
Don't take beginner's languages at Princeton unless you have to.
Get a tutor early
Great class, great teacher
I definitely recommend this course for interest as well as filling the language requirement.
I found that going to office hours was a lot more useful for me than the lectures. That one on one time truly helped.

I strongly recommend this course if you like learning new languages and want to learn how to speak fluently in Spanish. I would also recommend it especially if you have to fulfill the foreign language requirement. It will be easy for you if you have already taken Spanish in high school and even if you have never taken a Spanish class, if you put in some effort, you can get an easy A.
I would advise them to do all the homework even if it is not required and study the book because this is where you will receive clarification.

I would definitely reccomment taking this course if your interested in learning spanish.  The course isn't too much of a burden.  It's what you put into it basically.  If you try hard and come to class prepared, you will definitely get a worthwhile experience out of it.
I would recommend this instructor.
I would tell them that the course is difficult and very time consuming but as long as you put in the effort and time you will be fine.
If you get the right teacher, especially Kevin Bookhamer, you'll have a blast.  Try hard to get him if you want Spanish.  If you don't, you'll regret it.
If you want to learn spanish this is really your only option, but if you are good at languages it will probably be fun for you so take it.
It's a fun, low key class.
Keep up with the grammer and keep on top of the assignments because the tests are challenging

Make sure you get a good teacher. Be warned that you may end up in a class with people who aren't at the same level as you as this can determine the pace of the class for you personally. Review grammar THOROUGHLY before coming to class so you don't end up asking stupid questions and wasting time.
Make sure you get one of the sections that does not meet on the other side of campus as all your other classes.
Only take it if you have to for a language requirement.

People only take this class cause they have to, its not really a choice, but overall you do learn more spanish. Know that the intro levels are usually filled with people who have had years of spanish classes.
Prof. Bookhamer is very good in explaining the concepts. Even if you have already passed your language requirement Spanish is worth taking.
Put effort into it and you WILL learn spanish
Ruth was a good teacher and made a required class pretty enjoyable.
Similar to 101, but fewer tests and more writing. Pretty much what you expect for 102.
Spanish is a great language to take, even if only for satisfying a distribution requirement. The Spanish Department at Princeton is incredibly, so this class would certainly be worthwhile.
Spanish is great!
Study every night.
Take as distributional requirement.
Take it if its at your level.
Take it seriously. Don't slack off on your work and you'll do fine.
Take this professor!
The textbook is a really helpful tool for studying.

This course is required to receive credit for SPA 102, so I do not think much convincing is necessary. But it builds upon grammar and greatly improves your ability to converse in Spanish, which is the ultimate goal when taking any language.
This course requires work to be put in each day. It is quite time consuming, and the course is fast-paced so it's important to keep up.
This is a good course. Very helpful in understanding spanish fully.
Very useful and interesting course. Keep up on the workbook because the there are tests and presentations every week. It is a very engaging course and requires a lot of commitment.
do all assignments and attend all classes
great class. take it.
i recommend finding another instructor
prereqs: {SPA 101. No credit given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102.}.
descrip: The development of Spanish communication skills in listening comprehension, speaking, reading, writing and Hispanic culture appreciation. Language instruction complemented with audiovisual materials.

title: French Senior Seminar
reviews: To start readings early.
prereqs: For senior concentrators in the Department of French and Italian only..
descrip: This course is designed to provide a formal environment for French senior concentrators to refine their command of literature, culture, and thought, as well as to foster their writing skills. In addition, the seminar helps prepare students for the department's final comprehensive examination. Major texts from the French and francophone traditions will be studied weekly, and, in addition to being discussed, will serve as bases for writing workshops. An important part of the seminar will also be dedicated to the art of translation.

title: The Western Way of War
reviews: Amazing class
Attend lectures and be engaged.
Do the readings.

Do your reading over the weekend and then write your response early. Most of the readings are dense, sometimes they don't make sense. Talk to your preceptor about overall themes, too, because everything can get confusing.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture, skim the longer readings.

Go to lecture. They are phenomenal. Professor Centeno puts a lot of effort into making them better than your average lecture, and if you take good notes, that is all you will need to write the papers so the lectures benefit you in more ways than one.
Got to precept and lecture
Great class to PDF, interesting material, but can be a lot of work at times.
Great class.  Very interesting.
Great course. Centeno is amazing.
I enjoyed the class and Prof Centeno is a great lecturer.  If you're not a confident writer, don't take it.  But it's worthwhile.

I thought this class was one of the better ones I took at Princeton. Very engaging and great modern and important topic. Go to class, do the readings, and engage with your preceptor/Professor Centeno.

I would definitely encourage people to take this course if they are committed to the subject. Since computers weren't allowed to take notes on, going to every lecture was very important (since you couldn't have anyone send you missed notes).
I would recommend it
I would recommend this course without hesitation to anyone at Princeton.
If Professor Centeno is teaching this, take it.  If he's not, take whatever course that he is teaching.
If you are interested at all in war, take this course. If you're looking for a fairly easy class thats pretty interesting, this is it.

If you have any interest in the social phenomenon that is war, TAKE THIS CLASS. Be prepared for some of the best lectures you will receive ever, this is what I imagined when deciding to come to Princeton.
If you have any interest in war or sociology, or even if you don't, I'd highly recommend it! Not terribly time consuming, as you can put in the amount of time that you want to some extent.
If you're considering taking this course, do it!
Interesting course, really good lecturer, although lectures were in the morning I never had trouble staying awake, the course is not too hard either and it is an HA, unlike most SOC classes.
It worked as the 'fun' class, it's reputation is pretty accurate.
Make sure that you give yourself a lot of time to think about the essays before you write them.
Not much work if you're PDFing, interesting subject.
TAKE THIS COURSE

Take it!

Take it, go to lectures, pay attention, enjoy it.

Take the class. I really enjoyed it, and don't be intimidated by all of the reading. However, this does not mean you don't have to do anything for the class. You still have to put in a lot of time for reading.
Take the course if you truly are interested in war because if you are only somewhat interested perhaps the course isn't for you.
Take the course!  It really is what people make it to be, and however much you want to put in is however much you'll get out of it.
Take the course. It was very enlightening and interesting.
Take this course and do the readings!
Take this course or anything by Centeno. He's great.

Take this course! And make sure you try to get into Prof Centeno's precept -- it'll make the course awesome. One of the best SOC courses I've taken - but good for people who aren't that into SOC also.
Take this course! But you can't, because Centeno isn't doing it anymore.
Take this if you want an easy course with manageable work and good lectures.
The reading list is very long, but the course is very interesting. Centeno is amazing.
This is a great class to take if you're curious about sociology, and it's also a great opportunity to take a class with a fantastic lecturer.
This is a great class, but be prepared to do a lot of reading.
Very good.
Very interesting.  One of the best ways to fill an HA
best class ever although the exams can be annoying
go to all the lectures, don't fall behind on the readings
its an interesting class but papers are hard
my favorite class of all time. all time.
take it. do the readings. go to lecture.  lecture classes like this are why you came to princeton.
would recommend strongly
descrip: A historical and analytical overview of war focusing on the origins and consequences of organized violence, the experience of battle, the creation and behavior of warriors, and the future of such conflicts.

title: Readings in Modern Korean: The Voices of Change
reviews: I definitely recommend it if you want to work in Korea in the future, or if you are fine with speaking with other students but wish to improve your language skills. Also, you will probably never be able to present or write in Korean if you miss this chance. I really loved this course. However, if you do not speak Korean regularly and do not feel comfortable reading, writing, or speaking in Korean (aka if you do not use Korea with friends/parents), it might be hard to keep up with the class.
I highly recommend this class to whoever wants to bring their Korean language skill to another level.

I would strongly recommend this course to students who are more or less fluent in the language but have not had much exposure to it on a deeper level and do not feel very confident about their reading and writing skills. The course really helps enhance your ability in the language as well as your knowledge of the Korean culture, history, and literature. Overall, I feel like students could walk out of the class feeling much more confident in the language and interested in many of the subjects discussed in class.

If you're fluent in Korean and interested in learning more about the Korean culture, but unsure of taking this class because your Korean's not perfect- don't let the high level scare you. The instructor is willing to help you whatever stage you're at, as long as you're genuine about learning and willing to put in the effort to improve.
If you're serious about your Korean, this class will do you wonders.
Take it! Take it if you are fluent and comfortable talking and writing in Korean and would like an opportunity to read korean fiction.
it's perfect if you have a good grasp of the language but a poor grasp of everything else.
prereqs: KOR 402 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course is designed: to advance students' literacy skills to the Superior level (near native-like); to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, history and literature; and to further develop their critical thinking through reading and writing in Korean. Focusing on change in the Korean language in relation to history, society, and culture, the course covers a wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues through various media resources as well as documents written in Middle Korean, literary short stories and poems, traditional and modern.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Modern Brazilian Literature and Culture
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A study of 20th- and 21st-century literature, with the aim of discussing the blooming of new narrative and poetic forms in Brazil. Works by Mario de Andrade, Oswald de Andrade, Manuel Bandeira, Graciliano Ramos, Joao Cabral de Melo Neto, Clarice Lispector, Luiz Ruffato, Adriana Lisboa.

title: Introduction to Graph Theory
reviews: As a CS major, this class was way skewed towards the mathematical approach to things. This isn't necessarily bad, it's just that there are a lot of existence proofs and important intermediate theorems which made the class not really my cup of tea.
Attend lecture, etc
Definitely take it if you're considering it.

Do not, under any circumstances, take this course.

The lectures were too fast, and jumped around many different topics instead of sticking with one for more than one week.

The entirety of the material is theorems and proofs--which I normally like, but in this case, they were wholly uninteresting.  Absolutely no time was devoted to applications (which is surprising given the widespread use of graph theory in computer science), making everything we learned seem pretty useless.

Professor Seymour was an okay lecturer--he was well-prepared and very knowledgeable about the material.

It was great that he stopped every so often to ask something like "why is this true?" or "how should we start proving this?"
However, this bonus to his teaching quality was offset by the fact that most of the time, the same one or students (who pretty much already knew the course material) would answer the questions, so the professor would just move on, assuming everyone else knew it.

He often went to fast, and was not good at answering questions.  He had no conception of the material's difficulty, and no particular regard for the students who were struggling with it.

The problem sets were very long and difficult, and pretty much impossible to do without extra help from the TAs.

It would have been much better to have problems which more closely follow the material from that week's lectures, and which are more doable.

Don't expect it to be very applied. Quite theoretical (all theorems and proofs), and rather challenging problem sets at times. 

Be prepared to spend at least 15 hours a week on the class.
Find people to work on the problem sets with.
Great class. Would recommend if you like math, but must be prepared for difficulty.

Great course- Seymour is an awesome lecturer, and the problem sets usually aren't ridiculously hard.  Math majors tend to have a leg up on COS majors in this class since they have more experience with proofs.
I would definitely recommend this course. It is a thought-provoking introduction to an interesting field.

I'm a computer science major and took this for the first theory departmental. Came in with absolutely no math/theoretical computer science background and, after hard work, it was fine! Coming out of lecture, I was always pretty confused, but if you go through the material afterwards it usually not to bad to figure what was covered. Try to find a few people to work on the homeworks with, start early, and reach out to the preceptors as much as possible if you're stuck. It's doable!

If you are good at theoretical math, this might be for you. The medians on the homeworks were always around 90 to 98 percent. I probably wouldn't take this for the sole reason of COS theory requirement.

If you are looking for a highly-theoretical abstract course on graph theory with very little exposure to algorithms and other applied topics, then this class is for you. Otherwise, with weekly time-consuming problem sets, I found it very difficult to engage myself.

If you are not a math major and you care a lot about your grades, do not take this course. The curve will be insane (at some point an 87% was reportedly a C+)... If you are COS major who thinks there will be any CS in this course, there won't be. If you're ok with both of the above and you want to learn about an really interesting (though potentially challenging) subject and discover what pure math really is, by all means take this course. I certainly can appreciate having taken it and feel that it was in many ways a positive experience. Just don't say I didn't warn you.
If you aren't a math major, don't take it.  Non-math majors will get lots of points off for minor proof style mistakes.  Don't. do. it.

If you're a math major, the course will be really easy at first.  But the problem sets will get interesting pretty quickly and Seymour moves pretty fast.  Work with other people on the problem sets and go to office hours.  Seymour always goes over the homework in class, which is a bit annoying, but means that you'll always know the best solution to the problem.  Overall, I'd definitely recommend it.

It's an interesting course worth taking. A couple of caveats: things might change if the professor changes; and it's really much more of a math course than a COS course--expect to spend a lot of effort writing proofs.
It's both a COS theory course and an introduction to a fun branch of mathematics taught by one of the best graph theorists in the world.  Can't go wrong.
More work than you expect. Go to office hours and get a study group.  Take good notes in lecture.
Not really interesting; I wouldn't recommend it. I was super interested going into the course but I just found it extremely boring.
One of very few combinatorics classes here, take it if you're interested.
Please enjoy the class. Just pay attention in class and try to answer professor's questions and you can enjoy the beauty of graph theory.

Professor Seymour is a good teacher and is very important in this field. Graph theory is very applicable to many fields, especially COS. Although this class isn't applied in nature, you'll get a great handle on techniques like induction that are useful in math, COS, and other fields.

Professor Seymour's lectures were excellent! His explanations were clear and it became obvious that he is an expert in graph theory. The course was not as hard as most other 300 level math courses, but the problem sets were by no means easy either.
TAKE IT!!!
Take good notes. Not a bad MAT/COS course for your theory, but not very COS at all.
Take it unless you already know it.
Take it, but know what you're getting yourself into - this class is very much in the style of a math class.  It seemed like a lot of the non-math students who took the class dropped it.
Take it.
Take it. It is very entertaining, while challenging at the same time.

Take the course if you are interested, but unless you are sure you can score full points on problem sets of rigorous math proofs, prepare for a lower grade than you'd expect for the amount of work you put in.

Take this class if you're interested in getting an interesting overview of graph theory, or if you want to take a mathematics course with a slightly lighter workload. If you're a COS major taking this for a requirement, find some friends to do the work with. It will make it a lot easier and a lot more enjoyable.
Take this course! It's great!

The graders are very picky and Seymour wastes a lot of time in lecture (coming in late, slowly handing out homework, spending half of class reviewing the homework).  This is ok as an easy 300 level math/cos class, but I would recommend something else more interesting.

The lectures are very, very good, Seymour is excellent at explaining all of this clearly and keeping people involved and giving ideas.  One of the problems is the grading of the problem sets, which can get a little ridiculously strict since most people do quite well, and so small errors determine a lot of the grades.  There's no midterm, so that can be nice if the problem set grading doesn't bother you, since they end up counting for a lot of the grade (along with the pretty long final).

This class is great, and I would recommend it to anyone who is at all interested in pure math. There is almost no prerequisite mathematical knowledge, which makes it very accessible. Professor Seymour is a fantastic professor.
This is an awesome course. Take it!
Work with other students, from the start.
prereqs: MAT 202 or MAT 204 or MAT 217 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will cover the fundamental theorems and algorithms of graph theory. The main topics are: connectivity, matching, graph coloring, planarity, the four-color theorem, extremal problems, network flows, and related algorithms.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
descrip: Course examines interactions between states and citizens since Latin American independence with an additional consideration of the region's integration into global economic and political systems.

title: Claims and Evidence in Policy Research
descrip: Students will learn such basics of policy research as formulating researchable questions, designing studies, and using empirical evidence to evaluate claims. Students will examine substantive problems and both qualitative and quantitative research approaches, through critical reading of social science research, review of WWS senior theses, and examples drawn from the professor's experience conducting policy research with the World Bank. The course will also cover such practical aspects of research as ethics and regulations concerning human subjects, use of library and reference search tools, resources for acquiring and presenting data.

title: National Security Policy
descrip: This course will focus on the State Department's Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review, the strategic plan for the department. It will review the recommendations of the most recent QDDR, and consider how best to implement its recommendations, including: how best to organize and deploy new bureaus on Conflict and Stabilization Operations and on Energy Resources; how best to integrate a development focus on women and girls; how best to utilize private partnerships; how a new Under Secretary for Civilian Security, Democracy and Human Rights can best partner with the Defense Department in countries such as Afghanistan, Sudan and Mexico.

title: Politics and Modernization
descrip: An examination of alternative theoretical approaches to modernization, including interpretations of both the historical transformation of the western states and the efforts under way in the contemporary Third World.

title: Earth Chemistry: The Major Realms of the Planet
prereqs: CHM 201, or equivalent; MAT 103, or equivalent..
descrip: The chemical composition of the major realms of the planet: core, mantle, continents, ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. Topics include the synthesis of the chemical elements in stars, the origin of the solar system and Earth, and the chemical differentiation of Earth's core, mantle, crust, ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. Also explores the global cycles of carbon, nitrogen, and other biologically important elements, their interactions with the geosphere, and their evolution through time.

title: Seminar in 19th-Century Photography - Inventing Photography
descrip: Just as there was initially no one process that was identified as what we call "photoography" today, there was no one moment of "invention" or clear idea of what making pictures with light might accomplish. At a time when it has become fashionable to speak of the "death of photography," this seminar returns to the earliest experiments with light, silver salts, and cameras between 1789 and 1848 in order to reconsider what photography was, why it embodied the ideals of "modernity," and how it can be located within practices ranging from drawing, printmaking, magic, optical amusements, art, natural philosophy, and industrial production.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: Literature and the Arts
reviews: Don't be dissuaded by the large amount of reading for the HUM sequence! The readings are fascinating, the professors are amazing, and you'll come out of this course well versed in the Western canon.

I would recommend this strongly to anyone willing to do ridiculous amounts of reading every week.  It's definitely defined my freshman year, and the knowledge I've gained from these works will stick with me the rest of my life.  I'm hoping to have time this summer to reread everything we've read this year, though that might be on the unrealistic side.  Basically, it's been a fantastic experience that has been 100% worth the hours and all-nighters.

If you can read and be interested in 400 pages a week of the most  important literature ever written, take the course. It's not right for everyone, but it *can* be right for almost anyone, and it's a great intellectual experience.
If you have the energy and the drive, take it.  It'll be the best course you can possibly take your freshman year.
If you like reading the Western canon and tons of reading, take this course!
If you like reading.
If you want to learn a ton of information about the history of Western civilization and culture, sharpen your analytical skills, and grow as a person, then take this course. If not, then don't.

If you want to read the great Western books with students and professors as enthusiastic about them as you are, take this course. The most important factor in my enjoyment of the course was how thoroughly I was able to read each book and thus how well I was prepared for the precepts. Thus to be fully satisfied with this course you need as much time as possible to spend with the amazing texts.

Keep up with the reading, start papers early and work hard on them. Don't be discouraged by a few initial low grades as they will improve. Talk with the professors outside of class; they are awesome people.
Love to read, and just read the works in your free time as a way to procrastinate doing the unfun work like problem sets and the like.
Please see other course evaluation for comments.
Read what you can. Don't stress too much about what you can't. The enjoyment of this course depends on your personal interests and approach.
STRONGLY RECOMMEND. But be wary and ready.
TAKE IT!!!  It will be the best decision you ever made.
Take HUM if you're down for the challenge.
Take it. Go to office hours.

Take this course if you want to gain enormous knowledge of Western Civ, but only if you are willing to work hard, do all the reading, and participate in precept. If you aren't the class can become hell.

The HUM sequence is so much more than just a class, or even four classes: it's truly an experience, and definitely one of the most rewarding and inspiring at this university. Don't miss out on it. Take second semester. The professors are incomparably awesome, and you get to form really close friendships with your classmates. And the works we read... I mean, just look at the syllabus. Yeah. Just do it?it's an exhilarating ride.

This is not the course for everyone; it is difficult, but the caliber of the professors and other students is unmatched. My advice would be to do the reading and take advantage of the opportunity to interact with such inspiring, enthusiastic, and passionate individuals.

What you get from this course is what you put into it. If you don't do the readings, and most of the time it is difficult to complete them all, discussions will not be as interesting or meaningful for you. The most rewarding precepts will be those for which you have done the reading and prepared questions or concepts which you find intriguing. Otherwise the course will feel pointless. If you are not willing to commit to the amount of time required to do the readings, do not take this class. Also do not take this course simply for the sake of it being an application-based course.
prereqs: Students who have not completed HUM 216-217 should submit an application (see the Humanities Council website) with a letter describing their interest in taking 218-219 and their background in classical, biblical and medieval studies. Deadline is December 6 for notification by December 10..
descrip: This team-taught double credit course is the second half of an intensive four-course, interdisciplinary introduction to Western culture that includes history, religion, philosophy, literature and the arts. It examines European texts, works of art and music from the Renaissance to the modern period. Readings and discussions are complemented by films, concerts, museum visits and special events. Although most students will have already taken 216 - 217, it is possible for students to join at this point if they have a strong background in antiquity and the Middle Ages.

title: The Civilization of the High Middle Ages
reviews: Even if you don't have an interest in the middle ages Professor Jansen's lectures will make you love it! Definitely take this class!
I would strongly recommend this course.
It's not too terrible, but you should actually enjoy the subject. I wouldn't take it for an HA requirement.
STay on top of the readings, attend lectures. you'll learn stuff and it's not difficult.
Very knowledgeable professor who is genuinely interesting in her subject.
descrip: This course offers a survey of later medieval Europe (11th - 14th centuries), a period well known for its soaring gothic cathedrals, the culture of chivalry, church and state power struggles, the crusades and the emergence of the inquisition. These are among the topics we will examine as manifestations of the political, economic, social and religious transformations that shaped Europe during this formative period. Prominent themes include: authority and power, encounters and expansion, city and countryside, women and gender, ecclesiastical institutions and religious practice.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social scientific methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: Topics in the Culture of Cities - Spanish, Latin American, and Latino Nueva York
reviews: Arcadio is that avuncular professor you always wished you had at Princeton. If you're lucky enough for him to teach any more courses at Princeton, you shouldn't miss your opportunity.
Do it! Take the class, read the readings, participate in discussion, enjoy!
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT. You'll love it.
TAKE THIS COURSE!  The professor is great, the material was fabulous, and the work is not very heavy.
THIS course may seem like a lot of work but it is definitely worth the challenge. This course was the BEST!!! will definitely miss this class and the professor.
Take this course if it's offered again.
Take this course. One of my favorite courses at Princeton.
This is a great course with a great professor and I think everyone would benefit from taking it.

This is an incredible course that enables you to learn about a different history of New York, with a particular emphasis on the influence of Latin America and the Caribbean on the United States, and vice versa, along with gaining a deeper understanding about the presence of immigrants during the post-WWII era.
prereqs: Course taught in English with readings and papers in English. However, Spanish concentrators and certificate candidates are required to write papers in Spanish. Some reading knowledge of Spanish preferred..
descrip: An exploration of the ways in which Spaniards, Latin Americans, and Latinos have imagined and experienced New York. How and why did Nueva York become a diaspora city for "hispanos"? Themes include: Caribbean and Latin American migrations and the shaping of new identities; the growth of "barrios"; the city between empires and the legacy of 1898; the role of art, literature and music in the creation of cultural memories; political and cultural debates in the city from the Mexican Revolution through the Spanish Civil War; race, Afro-Latinos and responses to racism.

title: Politics in India
descrip: India is on the move. Sixty years after attaining its independence, India's growing economic and military power has begun to attract the world's attention. But in its quest to become the next great power, India must also surmount enormous political, cultural and social hurdles in order become a stable, well-ordered democracy. This course aims to understand both these aspects of modern democratic India -- its promise and its challenges. It will examine a number of topics including democracy, federalism, religion, caste, foreign policy, and economic reform and development.

title: A History of the World since 1300
reviews: I'm somewhat impartial on a recommendation here.
If this course is offered your year, TAKE IT!  It's great and you'll learn a lot!

It was a very easy and interesting class. They don't require much reading, and the articles are always well chosen.  If you want to do well, the professors and preceptors are also very available to talk.  So do the work, because it's not much, and you'll be golden.

It's not a walk-in-the-park easy class like you might expect; there are better classes to fulfill a distribution requirement.  If you genuinely want to learn about the subject?  Go for it, you'll probably love it.

Much more demanding (in terms of grading at least) than other lower-level History classes, but material is really cool and Professors are great lecturers. So would recommend taking it, just not as an "easy" fourth/fifth class.
Pay attention in lecture, they are the key to doing well in this class.

Put the extra time in to do the readings and you will find the course quite intriguing.  If you don't have that kind of time, at the very least attend lecture.  They do an excellent job of keeping lecture interesting and informative.
Take it.
Take this course if you want a good understanding of world history.
This class is a good history class, especially for students who do not want to read a lot.
This is the best course I have taken at Princeton. Kotkin and Adelman have great senses of humor and are excellent lecturers.
Very broad, (as suggested by the title), and sometimes wished we could have taken more time to discuss certain topics. Good class to fulfill requirements, and great professors.
Very interesting world history class that I strongly recommend.
Worth taking for the lectures, but only as a departmental. You could just as well buy the textbook and read it on your own.
depends if you like very broad courses
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the history of the modern world, this course traces the global processes that connected regions with each other from the time of Genghis Khan to the present. The major themes of the course include the environmental impact of human development, the role of wars and empires in shaping world power, and the transformations of global trade, finance and migration.

title: Twice-Told Tales
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: Already commented on other evaluation.
Evaluated under ISC 233.
Even if your GPA takes a hit (like mine has), do take this course. The material in the spring is worth all the pain!
I say recommend because it is not for everyone, but for those it suits, it is a great experience.
If you're in this far and are still interested, you might as well go all the way. The payoff for this semester is much greater than that of last semester.
Lots of work, but worth it
N/a, see 233
See 233 evaluation.
See 233.
See evaluation for 233.
See response for ISC 233.
With the caveat that you study very hard from the very beginning and also are already proficient in advanced math, with preferably some programming background again.  It is a unique experience.
don't be scared
read ahead. Read professors' notes, not so much textbooks!!
see ISC 233
see other evaluation
take ISC!!!!
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year-long 4 course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across 4 departments with the following faculty involved in teaching the course: W. Bialek, C. Callan, J. Shaevitz (PHY); D. Botstein (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); E. Carter (MAE).

title: Topics in Geometry - CR Geometry
descrip: CR Geometry (a continuation from Fall 2010)

title: Energy Conversion and the Environment: Transportation Applications
reviews:
Don't miss lectures as they're extremely useful in making the most out of what is being taught and understanding the lecture notes provided. 

Not a light course but totally worth it.
Don't take this course unless you have to! Lectures are really difficult to follow and there is no text if you get lost.

I would tell you to take the class but Prof. Dryer is retiring...
I can only hope that the course will be as well taught in the future as it has been for the last 25 years.

Prof. Dryer is very serious about the subject matter and is very engaging in his lectures.  He is very informed in the field and conveys it thoroughly that the work in it is very important.  I'm probably going to receive a C in this class, but it is indubitably one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton.
Sorry kiddos, should have taken it with Dryer when you had the chance.

This is one of my favorite courses in Mechanical engineering.  The material is really interesting and has countless real world applications. Prof. Dreyer is retiring after this year and I don't know who is going to teach it, but it will probably be a very differnt course from what it was this year.
material is important but I did not like the course. so I am neutral
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or equivalent, or by permission of instructor..
