descrip: This course will develop an overview of energy utilization in and environmental impacts of current and future propulsion systems for ground, air, and space propulsion applications. Principles of advanced internal combustion, electric hybrid, and fuel cell energy conversion systems for ground transportation will be introduced. Relevant thermodynamics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and combustion fundamentals will be stressed, and performance properties of power plants, control of air pollutant emissions, and minimization of resource-to application carbon emissions will be explored.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Political Economy of Global Energy
descrip: Economic growth requires constantly growing use of energy, the Middle East plays a vital role as exporters of hydrocarbons to the rest of the world. The course will cover: 1) Global energy demand and supply scenarios and the role of the Middle East; 2) The functioning of the global oil market and the potential role of major oil exporters; 3) The resource curse, economic diversification and the experience of the Gulf countries; 4) Oil, accountability and conflicts; 5) The global gas market and the role of Qatar; 6) Rational use of energy, renewable energy sources and nuclear energy.

title: Problems in Early Christian Music - Medieval Western Chant and Liturgy
descrip: Seminar provides an introduction to medieval Western chant and liturgy and a practical introduction to the study of medieval liturgical manuscripts. Course familiarizes students with major research questions, tools and methods that are useful for the study of history, religion, and art history as well as for musicology. Course focuses on the abbey of Cluny and its influence in the central Middle Ages, as an example of the liturgical implications of monastic reform.

title: Politics of the Middle East
descrip: This course offers students an overview of modern Middle Eastern politics. The course will first provide a historical analysis outlining the conditions that shape the formation and consolidation of authoritarian rule in modern Middle Eastern states. We will examine the political economy of the region, Islamic politics, state-society relations, wars, and other topics as probable explanatory variables to authoritarian persistence. Through case studies, the course will also focus on the impact of authoritarian rule on the political economy, civil societies, and opposition movements in the region.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
reviews: Anyone interested in LA history should take this course, esp. history majors.
Be careful of the first two weeks because they can be hard, but after that the class is really great!
DO IT! this is a great overview. You get a good foundation of the region, and a special emphasis on connections to today is provided.

If you are interested in Latin American history this is a class you must take. It gives students great background knowledge on the region as well as good insights as to why Latin America faces the circumstances and challenges that it is facing at the moment.
If you have any interest in Latin American History, take this class. You will not regret it.
If you're interested in Latin American history. This is the course for you!

If you're interested in learning the material, you'll get a LOT out of this course. If you're not, you can just cruise by with minimal work. The lectures are fascinating but intense--Prof. Karl speaks kind of formally and quickly! The 1810-1850 period is definitely more boring than the later stuff, so it gets better as the months pass. The assignments aren't that demanding. The students who take this course vary a lot--some concentrators, some freshmen, etc.--but it doesn't feel very competitive.
Take it if actually interested in modern Latin American History, or else it won't be interesting.
There are plenty of readings, but the class is well worth the effort.

This is a great class if you have the time to commit to it. Interesting material and a lot of it. Not the best for PDFing, as I did, because there is a TON of reading and you'll be sort of lost if you don't do it.
there are better history classes out there if you just want an HA, but latin america was interesting so was an ok class. not great though.
descrip: This course surveys the main themes of Latin American History from independence to the present. The main focus is on the interaction between states and citizens, social relations, and economic development.

title: Truth of Memoir, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Clash of Civilizations? Perceptions of East and West from Medieval Period to the Contemporary World
descrip: Among the most pressing issues of our time is the perceived divide between the Islamic "East" and the European and American "West." As this course explores, the meeting of Islamicate and western civilizations has a long, complicated history. We shall examine the roots of this tension and the ways in which the two perceived one another from the Middle Ages to modernity through classic works of literature and art. The seminar will further examine the historical development of the East-West divide and the relationship between religion and culture in the formation of identity.

title: Research Methods in Demography
reviews: Be prepared to study the material from the lectures alone, as there is too much information to understand having seen it only one time.
It's a lot of work and very tough, but great.
One might consider lack of maths bakcground a problem for taking this class, but that is not so actually.
Take it. The course builds wonderful intuition for how to use straightforward math to understanding populations, and builds good foundations for next steps in research.
This course is a excellent introduction to demographic methods.
This is a great course, and studying for it will foster teamwork and also increase thinking outside the box
This is a very well-designed course that provides solid instruction in applied methods.  Definitely worth taking.
prereqs: ECO 571 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Source materials used in the study of population; standard procedures for the measurement of fertility, mortality, natural increase, migration, and nuptiality; and uses of model life tables and stable population analysis and other techniques of estimation when faced with inaccurate or incomplete data are studied.

title: Topics in German Culture and Society - The Culture of Acoustic Media
reviews: I think Professor Hanrahan is going back to Columbia after this semester, so I don't think this section is applicable, but I would recommend his class in a heartbeat.  I would also take another class with him for sure.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent..
descrip: A survey of artworks and artifacts made for acoustic media--phonograph, radio, tape and digital recording--from the 1900s to the present day. Listening to recordings of radio plays, documentaries, avant-garde sound works and propaganda broadcasts, we will address formal and technical question--language and sound, performance and medium, liveness and recording, orality and textuality--while paying close attention to the political and cultural contexts from which texts emerge.

title: Repsonsible Conduct in Research
reviews: You have no choice, and it really is in your interest to ask a lot of questions since you'll get feedback from other students who have been in similar situations.
descrip: This course will cover the essential topics of what constitutes responsible conduct in research.

title: Secrets and Confessions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: When Cows Go Crazy: The Inextricable Links between Human and Animal Health
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: The Scientific Revolution
descrip: This is an interdisciplinary seminar on issues surrounding observation and experiment in early-modern science. Among issues discussed are new conceptions of natural history, the development of the telescope and the controversies over its first uses, the relations between experiment and reason, and the founding of the Royal Society. Figures discussed may include Bacon, Galileo, Descartes, Boyle, and Hobbes. We will also discuss some contemporary critical literature from history of science, sociology of science, and the philosophy of science on observation and experiment.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: A lot of material to cover!   Find early on the balance between book readings and reviewing lectures.  You have to be active in seeking help from the TAs and professors.
Don't take it unless you need to.
For the lab portion, I wish we were warned to have had prior experience with statistics and computer coding.  That would have been helpful.
I found this more interesting than NEU 258.  There is a lot of overlap between this class and PSY 255.

If you are going to take the lab, be prepared to do much more work for the same amount of credit. It's a poor system and rather unfair. 3 hours and reports that take days vs the precepts' one reading a week and ten minute quizzes. Also, it doesnt make sense to have a participation grade in a 100 ppl lecture- in labs and precepts fine, but to grade 5% participation based on Piazzza is annoying. It's possible people just don't have questions and understand the material and they basically get penalized for this.
NEU259 is a great course but was too heavily based on class participation.
Not a bad course.
Solid neuro class.
Take it if you are prepared to work hard for it.
The content is interesting, but I would not recommend it if it is not a required class. Because the instructor and the grad students were new this year, they will probably improve in future years.

The professor is not a very good lecturer and the book is pretty badly-written. However, the materials is still very interesting regardless. The most interesting lectures were the ones by guest lecturers.

This class is a good way to test how interested you are in neuroscience, and, especially since the teachers and TAs are all very serious about making this a good experience, I think the course will only improve from here.

This course was much better than 258 but would be a challenge if I hadn't taken 258.  I wish they would combine 258 and this course so that 258 had less brute memorization and more of 259's conceptual understanding.
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention and selective perception, systems for short- and long-term memory, language, cerebral lateralization, motor control, executive functions of the frontal lobe, cognitive development and plasticity. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed.

title: Conservation Biology
reviews: Do the readings.
If you're interested in conservation biology definitely take it -  but not typical EEB class.
It's really interesting, brings together a number of fields along with biology, and the final project is actually fun, but still a significant amount of work.  Precepts were not always stimulating.
Lots of individual work, projects.
Take it - it's not too difficult and will teach you to look at conservation in a new way.
Take this class even if you're not interested about conservation.  If anyone can convince you that conservation is important, it's Professor Sterling.
The class is generally interesting and offers many great case studies. The precepts and lectures are somewhat irrelevant and not entirely needed for the papers.
There are better EEB courses. If you are type A and like specifically outlines syllabi, or knowing what is going on at all times, do not take this course. Otherwise, it was ok.
Unless there is a different professor, do not take this course.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: An in-depth exposure to topics in conservation biology emphasizing the application of scientific concepts to our understanding of the problems that threaten endangered species and ecosystems. Topics include island biogeography, population genetics and viability, landscape ecology, reserve design, and endangered species recovery. To a lesser degree, this course will address some of the political, economic, and cultural aspects of conservation.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Be sure you want to do it; it takes a lot of work.
If you want to improve your Chinese, take this. You will have to work at it, but the reward is great if you do all of the readings and know what is going on on the tests.
If you're still interested in Chinese by this point, this is a good class to take.
Make sure that you are willing to dedicate the time to preparation, but if you enjoy the language it is definitely worth it.
See who the lead teacher is, then decide. Jia isn't very fun as a lead. Chiang lao shi is awesome, though.
Take Chinese! It's a lot of work but you learn really quickly.
Take it. However, be prepared to keep up. There is (light to moderate) homework due every day, and it's easy to fall behind.
This is one of the strongest language programs at Princeton and if you're willing to put in the time, you can learn Chinese very well.
do the homework and exercise everyday.
prereqs: CHI 303 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of CHI 303, designed to improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of newspaper essays and commentaries.

title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Parasites and Infectious Diseases
reviews: Again, aside from the organizational issues, this was a great course, with a lot of interesting material presented.
Go to lecture. They are great! Start the term project early.
This class may be at times a bit difficult if you absolutely hate math, but it wasn't too bad.  I am still amazed by what I learned, and I hope to be able to study these issues further in the future.
prereqs: Prerequisite: 210 or 211; one year of calculus; 321.
descrip: An introduction to the biology of viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, worms, arthropods, and parasitic plants. The major emphasis will be on the parasites of animals and plants, with further study of the epidemiology of infectious diseases in human populations. Studies of AIDS, anthrax, and worms, and their role in human history will be complemented by ecological and evolutionary studies of mistletoe, measles, myxomatosis, and communities of parasitic helminths. The course focuses strongly on policy implications, particularly for the dynamics and control of emerging infectious diseases of humans and animals.

title: Introduction to Critical Theory - Dialectic and Difference
descrip: Through a comparative focus on the concepts of dialectics and difference, we will read some of the formative theoretical, critical and philosophical works which continue to ground interdisciplinary critical theory today. Focal works by Lukacs, Freud, Heidegger, Adorno, Derrida, de Man, Arendt, and Benjamin are included among the texts we read.

title: International Political Economy
reviews: Course was helpful given my interest.
Do it! No econ background is needed because Professor Campello does a great job grounding the class in just the very basics. Due to this, the class may seem a bit slow for econ majors, though.
Great class for anyone interested in politics, international relations, and/or economics.
Great professor
I wouldn't recommend taking this course until it is restructured by the professor.
If you have any interest in how states and markets interact on the global stage, take this course. The professor is engaging, and the material is very exciting.
If you want to understand the economics that underlie most of what goes on politically in the world, take this class. Simple as that.
Not math based so you don't need an econ background.

Take this course if you are interested in international political economy, but don't want to take a quantitative course.  Although the course description doesn't say this, a basic understanding of economics is vital.
This class is much better than I hear it used to be. Professor Campello is really great.
This class is very interesting, but it involves a lot of weekly reading. If you keep up with the readings, however, the midterm exam, course essay, and final take-home exam are not difficult.
This is a class that everyone needs to take given the recent worldwide financial troubles.
This is a great course to take, it is thought provoking and intellectually stimulating.
You definitely learn a lot about international finance. So take if you are interested in that. It isn't the easiest course, but you don't need to kill yourself over the work.
class material is good. DO NOT CHOOSE CAMPELLO AS PRECEPTOR!!! - She is biased, mean and Horrible! Class assignments are overly hard and graded very differently by the TA and the Professor.
do the readings and print out the lecture slides before lecture rather than making notes just during lecture.
take it if you are interested in the topic
descrip: This course explores the following questions: who wins and who loses from globalization of trade and finance? Who sets the rules under which the game of international capitalism is played? How powerful are international organizations like the WTO or the IMF, nation-states, or NGOs? These issues are explored with reference to economic and political theories, history and contemporary events.

title: Psychology for Policy Analysis and Implementation
descrip: Course covers basic concepts and experimental findings of psychology that contribute to an understanding of the effects of policy on human behavior and well-being; and psychological factors that affect the formulation, communication, and execution of policy. Topics include a descriptive analysis of boundedly rational judgment and decision making, a consideration of social motives and attitudes, and an introduction to the ways in which agents influence and negotiate with one another, including an examination of the psychological roots of conflict.

title: Modern Fiction
reviews: Be sure to read all the books... it really helps, and they are definitely worth it!!!
Definitely consider taking it! Even if not an English major, still really great and the readings are a lot of fun. It does take a while to read a novel a week, however, so be prepared.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone with the time to read through all of the novels. Ulysses is a bit of a struggle, but if you can pace yourself properly and attend lecture it should not be too bad.
If you like to read and discuss literature, this is a great class1
If you're interested in this kind of literature, definitely take this class.
It's a lot of reading, but if you're willing to keep up. Quite worth it.
Make sure to go to lecture because you could feel lost otherwise.
Take it if you want to learn about this period. If you know you hate modern work, don't take it.
Take this class if you're looking to read some terrific books, and don't worry if you haven't had past experience in English courses.
Take this class! It's really great! Especially if you want to get a sense of the narration of the modernist movement in the English language.

The literature you will read in this course is amazing.  The professor is very engaging and is always willing to meet with you outside of class in preparation for essays and after essays to explain her comments.  It's a great class!
This is a great class with an amazing reading list, and DiBattista is an amazing lecturer. Keep up with the readings (especially Ulysses) and you'll find it really enjoyable.
You should definitely try to take a class with Maria DiBattista!  The lectures are excellent, though you have to be prepared to just not know your grade.
Your best shot at Ulysses.
good class, lots of reading.
descrip: The Modern movement in English fiction, from Conrad and Joyce to the present.

title: Organizations: Management, Bureaucracy, and Work
descrip: Sociology 342 surveys management theory and practice since the late nineteenth century. How did entrepreneurs first decide to let strangers run their enterprises? How do today's managers motivate workers who expect job fulfillment? We review the key dilemmas managers have faced, with the goal of understanding why modern organizations have such different sorts of management practices and cultures, and also why business trends seem to come and go.

title: Structural Design
reviews: You have to take it, its a requirement.
great course! Great instructor
descrip: Introduction to the design of building structures of steel, timber and reinforced concrete.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Better to take if you have a strong background in MAE-related material.

Dear student, if you already have a degree in Math or Applied Math, it's fine to take this class. Be advised that if you studied Physics or Engineering before coming to Princeton, this class is not teaching anything to you since it's assuming that you already know everything.
Moreover, do not dare talk to prof Holmes. He is surely going to answer in a very bad way.
Don't be cheap; buy Hildebrand.
If you REALLY REALLY enjoy pure mathematics and the fine details relating to it, then this is a good course and is enjoyable.
If you are not a mechanical and aerospace student, then the applications of the theory presented in this course may be challenging to conceptually understand.

If you're looking for an applied engineering math course, this is not it. Make friends with people who have completed high level math courses before this and who are willing to help you fill in the gaps, or you will not do well. The only people I know that did well in this class or MAE 501 are people who came in with a master's degree and already learned this material previously.
Print out the notes and follow along with a highlighter - don't distract yourself by taking your own, because subject matter moves quickly.

This course is very useful for students who need to be familiar with advanced engineering mathematics. It covered important topics and my advice for students taking the course is to keep up with the problem sets and lectures as it helps to understand the concepts better in class.
When Philip Holmes says: "Don't overwhelm with detail," don't listen to him. He will take off points if you don't give detail.
this class is as the prof describe it some tapas of math tools so if needed it is a good starting
descrip: A complementary presentation of theory, analytical methods, and numerical methods. The objective is to impart a set of capabilities commonly used in the research areas represented in the Department and more broadly in engineering and the physical and biological sciences. Standard computational packages will be made available in the courses, and assignments will be designed to use them. Topics will include Complex variables, PDE, Fourier and Laplace Transforms, and a brief introduction to numerical methods.

title: Energy and Empire
descrip: The seminar examines social, political, and cultural arrangements generated by different energy sources. Moving in the first part of the course from the rise of Islam in Arabia, via the Dutch Golden Age, to colonial India, we explore various polities sustained by different driving forces. We then examine the multifaceted history of fossil fuels, from the adoption of coal to the shift to oil, and the political ramifications of such transitions. As we prepare for another shift, away from depleting fossil fuels and back to some of the energy sources that carbon-based energy supplanted, this history is timelier than ever.

title: Physical Optics
reviews: In 2011 the class had only three students, so it became an informal discussion-based class. Professor Fleischer is quite brilliant and a good teacher, so it's worth taking if you have an interest in optics. Much of the lecture was spent on cutting-edge research and tangential but very cool topics.
prereqs: PHY 104 or ELE 351..
descrip: This course presents an introduction to wave dynamics and imaging. Topics include geometrical and Fourier optics, diffraction, microscopy, photography and holography. Modern methods to beat the diffraction limit, including near-field and computational imagining, will be discussed.

title: Creative Non-Fiction
reviews: An amazing class. If you get the chance to take Creative Non-Fiction, I would definitely do it. You will learn a lot about what it means to write well and get closer to finding your own unique voice. It was a privilege to get taught by John McPhee.
By far the best course I've ever taken in my life. John is an amazing human being and a wonderful professor.
Do not EVER give up the chance to take this course should you be offered it.
If you get in, take it.  It can be tedious at times because the seminar is long.  But I learned a lot, you meet awesome people, and McPhee really is brilliant.
If you make the cut, you should take this course.
If you take this course, take it very seriously; it's a rare and invaluable opportunity
Take it, take it, take it! Best class I've taken so far, and most I've learned in a class so far.

This is a once-in-a-lifetime course. Take it. Aside from the things you'll learn and risks you'll take in writing, you'll also enter the ranks of past McPhee students, which include David Remnick, Richard Preston, and other greats.
prereqs: For the writing sample, submit whatever you consider to be your best work from any source. Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu.
descrip: This is a course in factual writing and what has become known as literary nonfiction, emphasizing writing assignments and including several reading assignments from the work of John McPhee and others. Enrollment is limited to 16 second-year students, by application only.

title: fMRI Decoding: Reading Minds Using Brain Scans
prereqs: All students should have prior knowledge of computer programming (e.g., COS 126). Prior experience with Matlab is extremely useful but not strictly necessary. Additionally, students should EITHER have prior experience with fMRI research and cognitive neuroscience (e.g., from a course like PSY 259 or PSY 416) OR they should have prior experience with pattern classification and data mining methods (from a course like COS 402 or COS 424). Students who are unsure whether they have appropriate background for the course should contact the professors..
descrip: How can we decode what people are thinking by looking at their brain scans? Over the past several years, researchers have started to address this question by applying sophisticated pattern-classification algorithms to patterns of functional MRI data, with the goal of decoding the information that is represented in the subject's brain at a particular point in time. In lectures, students will learn about cutting-edge techniques for finding meaningful patterns in large, noisy datasets; in weekly computer labs, students will use these techniques to gain insight into fMRI datasets.

title: Electronic Commerce
reviews: Compared to other ORF department classes, this class is much easier. The type of programming you learn is also very useful.
Final project was a lot of work but fun to work on.
If you're into computers, this is a great course to take.
Pretty fun class
There are better ORFE courses that can be taken to satisfy the departmental.
Very random class, whatever you expect will be demolished.

You definitely must experience Professor Kornhauser's style once. I can almost guarantee that you won't have a professor here apart from Prof K who sends you articles from tech blogs to read -- if you're a tech lover like me, that's really refreshing and fun. And then you come to class, and instead of looking at the slides (which we sometimes did), of course we talk about those articles! You basically come to class, and Prof K talks about whatever topic's hot that day, and you get to discuss various issues related to it. Once in a while, you'll have a formal lecture based off of slides. This is one of the funnest and most flexible ways of teaching a class (even if unintentional). If you take this course, take it for the professor. The material is widely applicable too - esp in web programming - but you don't really dive deep into anything, simply because you can't. The same TA won't be there next year but he was great. The final project is manageable - just start early and make sure it gets Prof K's seal of approval.
BTW - softball game   BBQ at the professor's house at the end of final presentations = WIN
prereqs: COS 126 or ORF 201 or equivalent.
descrip: Electronic commerce is broadly defined as the buying and selling of goods using electronic transaction processing technologies. Some of great expectations of this technology are beginning to be realized. We will study the success, failures and challenges. We will focus on the technlogies themselves as well as various economic and financial issues associated with their use.

title: Irreversible Processes in Plasmas
reviews: Consider it a challenge, and budget lots of time for the problem sets.
descrip: Introduction to theory of fluctuations and transport in plasma. Origins of irreversibility. Random walks, Brownian motion, and diffusion; Langevin and Fokker-Planck theory. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; test-particle superposition principle. Statistical closure problem. Derivation of kinetic equations from BBGKY hierarchy and Klimontovich formalism; properties of plasma collision operators. Classical transport coefficients in magnetized plasmas; Onsager symmetry. Introduction to plasma turbulence, including quasilinear theory. Applications to current problems in plasma research.

title: The History of American Capitalism
reviews: A good amount of reading but it is all interesting.

Definitely take this course. It is great. There is no need to understand any kind of technical economics or anything. It is actually a very good history course. As a history major, this is one of the best history courses I have taken here. The exams are very fair and they are very fairly graded. Just the right amount of reading and lectures were absolutely amazing.
I would highly recommend this course if you are interested in the history of capitalism.
I've already recommended this class to at least a dozen of my closest friends.
If interested in the history of capitalism in American, take this course.  It is extremely interesting and not very difficult.
If you are interested in the material, take it.
Keep up on the reading. You don't necessarily need it for the exams, but it is really really interesting.
Pick readings carefully. Really think about what essays you want to write and do research on it, but remember to look at lectures as well.
Really engaging, not super hard, and very relevant. If the topic at all interests you, I would really recommend you take the class.
Take it
Take it-do the readings even when you can get by without- they add to the value of the course exponentially
Take it.
Take the Course!
Take this course

Take this course -- one of the best I've taken here.  
The reading leans towards primary sources, with secondary sources used to tie things together.  Lectures are some of the best I've had at Princeton.  Subject material is extremely interesting.  
Be aware that it is an intellectual history course, not a course in economic history per se, so the approach is different.  Some knowledge of basic economics is helpful, but no expertise is necessary.
Take this course but make sure to attend lecture since a lot gets said thats not otherwise available
This course is quite focused in its discussion of American history but it is certainly interesting.  Take this course if you have an interest in American capitalism.
This course is very interesting and the workload is what you make of it. If you really like the subject matter, it is a great course and you will enjoy it as I did. I strongly recommend this class.
This is an incredible course. Pay attention. It's all material that you can bring up in conversation to make yourself look good.
Work hard and you will enjoy it.
excellent course, favorite at princeton
excellent course, would highly recommend
if you are interested in the topic take the course
prereqs: No prior course work in economics is either required or assumed..
descrip: This course offers a broad overview of American capitalism from colonial times up to the present. It introduces students to the economic transformation of America from a rural colonial outpost of the British Empire to the largest industrially developed economic power in the world. The course will consider the political, social, geographical, legal, moral, environmental, technological, and cultural dimensions of economic life--all together attempting to provide a total picture of the historical characteristics and dynamics of American capitalism.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: CHI 306 is challenging and time-consuming but if you want to learn the language well, you should definitely take it!

CHI 306 is hardly a trivial class; you?ll need to invest a huge amount of time and energy in the weekly quizzes and assignments, and the benefit you derive is very dependent on how much effort you expend. However, if you?re really interested in bringing your Mandarin to the next level, there is no better context in which to do so.
For those who want to learn Chinese, this is a must-take.
If you are willing to work hard, take this! You will enjoy it. Preview material.
If you want to really learn Chinese, and are not afraid of a huge workload, this class can't be beat.
It's hard and a lot of work, but you learn a lot.
Language classes really aren't that bad.
Take it! Don't be intimidated - it's definitely not bad at all in terms of the amount of work. And you learn a lot.

Take this class if you're going to devote to it the time that it deserves and requires. Your Chinese will definitely improve, but it definitely demands a daily commitment and lots of studying for the weekly tests.

Take this if you're serious about Chinese, because to get even an A- requires a lot of work. If you don't plan on using Chinese in your future, don't take the course because it will probably sink your GPA. But if you do end up taking CHI 306, your chinese is going to improve by an amazing amount.
Very useful class, workload also not too bad.
it's got a tough curve, take it only if you want to challenge yourself.
prereqs: CHI 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 305, designed to further improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of essays published in contemporary Chinese newspapers and magazines.

title: Topics in International Relations - Intelligence and Foreign Policy
descrip: Focuses on the role played by intelligence communities in the formation of national security policy. Explores the functions and goals; practices, problems & challenges of national intelligence, using case studies to evaluate the use of intelligence in critical episodes in history.

title: Physical Principles of Electronic Devices
reviews: Don't take it!

I would advise students to keep up with the course readings and to try and complete them before lectures so as to be able to get the most from lectures. I would also encourage students to ask for help with the material as discussions with the instructors or other classmates are very helpful to developing an understanding with some of the harder course material.
It's a lot of work, but it's worth it if you're interested in the topic
prereqs: (PHY 103 or PHY 105) and (PHY 104 or PHY 106).
descrip: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles that govern the operation of modern solid state and optoelectronic devices. The emphasis is on fundamentals rather than applications. The major portion of the course will be devoted to quantum mechanics and statistical physics with examples from solid state and materials physics and quantum electronics. This provides the basic background needed to understand the physics of device operations and also prepares the student for more advanced courses in solid state and quantum electronics (such as ELE 441, 442 and 453). For more details, see Undergraduate Announcement.

title: Studies in Religion and Philosophy - Augustine and Political Augustinianisms
descrip: Recent developments in political theory, theology, and the study of late antiquity have led to revived interest in Augustine's ethics and politics within the broader context of his vision of Christian life. This interdisciplinary seminar examines these developments through close reading of primary texts, including Confessions, City of God, and other major treatises, but also some very revealing sermons and letters. Attention is paid to "classical" interpretations and a variety of contemporary authors who lay claim to Augustine and/or wrestle with his legacy for their constructive purposes.

title: Advanced Spanish
reviews: A good course to take.
Come prepared to class every day and do a little bit of work every night.
DO IT!
Definitely take this course because it will make you near-fluent in the Spanish language. It is not a daunting amount of work, but enough to increase your language ability.
Do it if you gotta.
Do the homework on time and participate in class to work on your listening and speaking.
Do the homework! Give yourself time to do the papers and to look over them. The first draft grade does count.
Do the work and show up to class.
Do the work.  You have to take the course and it's not too hard if you do the work.

Do your homework on time and participate in class discussion. If you do you will get the most out of the course.  Also read the chapters for homework, don't just look at the vocab and grammar section.
Don't take it at 9:00 AM.
For students who are looking to complete their language requirement and learn a great deal about Spanish culture in the bargain, this course is an excellent choice!
Hard to get good grades, but interesting.
I can't speak for other professors, but Prof. Moscardo is wonderful. I would definitely recommend the class if she is teaching it.
I have told my friends to be wary about what professor they get if they take SPA 108.
I would definitely recommend Professor Suoto-Portas to any student enrolling in SPA 108. She is always open to questions via email or one-on-one time.
I would definitely recommend this course for students looking to develop  a strong foundation for upper level spanish courses.
I would recommend choosing Paloma as your instructor if you are taking SPA108
I would recommend other students create study groups where they can practice their spanish speaking abilities outside of the classroom.

I would recommend this course with the caveat that (if you really do want to improve your Spanish) you will be taking the class along with many students who simply want to fulfill their requirement. This makes for a less than satisfactory learning environment, and the grammar that you learn is too advanced for many of these students, which slows down the class. 

That being said, the class was quite enjoyable and it is what you make it. If you put in a bit more work on your papers and readings, you will reap the rewards!
I would say that if you are taking 108, Paloma is a great teacher and very engaging.
I would say try not to take it id you don't have to, but I don't like language as much as other subjects so I'm a bit biased.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student considering taking it.
I would take it!
I would take this class if you are looking to continue your study of Spanish.
I would tell them to try to do their work ahead of time.

I'm going to miss this class. It's the perfect way to fulfill the language proficiency requirement and be ready for more advanced topics in the Spanish department. Try to take class with Professor Moscardo-Valles if possible--she's a wonderful person and a brilliant educator.
IF SENORA PALOMA IS TEACHING IT, TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
If necessary.
If you have the ability to go straight into 105 or 108, it is absolutely worth it
If you're interested in Medicine and learning Spanish, take this course
It's a good class to finish your language requirement.
It's not difficult material at all, and if I had to choose again, I'd take the course (but make sure I have all my homework done and attendance taken care of).
Its a pretty good course, but I'm not sure I would have taken it if I didn't have to. If you work hard, you'll do fine.
Make sure that you come to class prepared. So during a grammar week, make sure you have looked it over in the Repaso. And participate in class.
Make sure you keep up with the material regularly - it's easy to fall behind.
Maria is awesome and it's a good course to take.

Medical Spanish with Paloma is the BEST! She is awesome. She is the most fantastic professor I've had. She was so cool, funny and fun, but also taught very well and was very organized and fair when it came to tests and compositions. She went through a lot personally second semester and didn't let it affect the quality of the class. I am really going to miss her.
Most students will probably find themselves in a position where they have to take this class; I would tell them not to worry, especially if they are fortunate enough to get a good teacher.
Obviously, you have to take this course to fulfill the requirement, so Maria is a good choice as a professor. It's not the most entertaining course, but it does help improve your skills.
Only take if needed.
Only take it if it is a requirement.
Practice speaking and participate a lot in class
Solid class, a good requirement.
Study
Take if you are in the spanish sequence.
Take it if you want to learn Spanish or to fulfill the language requirement, but it probably won't blow your mind
Take it.
Take it. Your Spanish will improve considerably. Also, don't spend too much time trying to be creative on the essays - you'll lose a lot of points for grammar mistakes.
Take spanish only if you have to or are distinctly interested in the subject.
Take the course with Prof Moscardo! As long as you keep up, you are fine.
Take this class to complete the requirement since it meets three days a week instead of five
This course is very interesting because of the way it is designed to concentrate on health topics. Paloma is also very nice. If you have to take SPA 108, you should take this class.
This course offers a good review of a lot of grammar points, basically solidifying what I learned in high school Spanish.
This is a fun spanish course!
Tomala. Se?ora Souto-Portas es una maestra fantastica y intenta muy dura para ayudar a sus estudiantes.
Try to get Paloma as a teacher.
Yes.
You have to take it
good class
prereqs: Prerequisites include SPA 105 and/or satisfactory score on the placement test, or permission of Instructor. Offered both semesters..
descrip: An intensive course designed to prepare students to enter 200 level courses, with an emphasis on reading, oral and written proficiency. The course is aimed at developing advanced syntactical and lexical competence which it addresses through frequent rewrites of compositions, oral presentations, discussions of contemporary Spanish literary texts, music and film. (Please see note under "Other Information.")

title: Introduction to Music
reviews: A good course to take no matter what.
A good intro to music history class. Be warned, though, that it's not just "clapping for credit." Definitely more difficult than I thought it would be.
A solid LA distribution. The second half of the course is much better than the first.
Attend lecture, if not you won't do well.

Be sure to attend lecture and take copious (but organized) notes. It won't hurt you too badly to fall a few weeks behind, but don't try to learn the whole semester in the days before the final or half of the semester in the days before the midterm.
Definitely take it if you are interested, but it is not as easy as you might think.
Definitely take this class and go to lectures!

Definitely take this course if Prof. Morrison is teaching it - it is really well-run, and you feel like a much more educated person afterwards - a person who is able to talk about and enjoy music intellectually.
Definitely take this course, even if you have no music background. Morrison is a great lecturer. Just study a lot for the midterm and final, because the curve is pretty tough. GREAT TO PDF.
Definitely worth taking if you are interested in learning about the history of Western Music--great lectures and interesting listening.
Do not take unless you are already somewhat familiar with musical terms
Do the readings and listening when they're assigned, not right before the test.

Don't take it unless you're interested in the history of music (which most people who know music are, in which case you probably don't need to take the course because you will already know it).  Don't PDF it out of general interest or anything...definitely study hard and take the grade, not worth PDFing.
Don't take. Sounds interesting, but the exams are hard and the homework is tedious. Other LA's are much more interesting.
For those who want to learn about music history, this is very good course.
Fun and exciting way to learn a little bit about music. Grading is tough.
Fun to take. But there's a lot of memorizing involved.
Go to the lectures--they are what define the course.
Good course to take if you want an easy LA with almost no work.  Try to get in Ireri Chavez Barcenas's precept.
Good for PDF.

Good intro music history class. Be forewarned, however, that you spend lots of time memorizing seemingly tedious things like dates. In general, however, it's worth it and you are exposed to many different musical styles.

Good, fun course to take. You learn the basics of music history. There is a fair amount of memorization so you should stay on top of the listenings and go to lecture (which you should want to anyway because Professor Morrison is a very good lecturer).
Great for filling LA requirement. Workload not heavy at all.
Hard to get a good grade due to grade inflation.  Most people in the class play an instrument or already know music in some way.

Helps to have at least a little musical background to understand concepts or at least have a good enough ear to pick things up.

Thats because it will make it much easier to memorize everything since you will know what is going on.

If you have Morrison, record lectures since he goes fast and all test questions come from lecture.
I feel a little more appreciative of music I once did not appreciate at all.
I highly recommend taking this class
I would advice them to just have fun with the course. The course definitely requires work but at the same time, it is one of the more enjoyable ones that I have taken during my time at Princeton.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. It is interesting material, and the lectures are great.

I would definitely recommend this class to every student. I would advise them to attend all lectures. I think one can pass the exam without them, but I also think that they are a wonderful added  experience for any Princeton career.
I would recommend against PDFing this course, as I originally considered doing.  You must memorize quite a bit of material, though it's not too tedious.  The lectures are overall excellent.
I would recommend this class if they are interested in music history.
If it seems interesting to you, take it for sure. Just don't think you can blow it off and do well. If you give it a bit of focus you should thrive and enjoy it.
If you are interested in music, you should definitely take this class.

If you are like me and don't want to do a ton of reading for your LA, take this class.  It really teaches you a lot.  However, this isn't really "clapping for credit" anymore; you will have to do some work, especially when exam time rolls around.
If you don't have a background in classical music, be prepared to cram - even if you do all the readings and come to class engaged.

If you have any kind of musical background, this should be a breeze.  If not, I definitely don't recommend it unless you're sure you're going to pdf.  There are a ton of people at Princeton who know music and you'll be way behind all semester.

If you like music it is a good course to take, but don't think it is easy.  There is a lot of material to cover.  Definitely put the time in to learn to songs during the semester instead of cramming a couple days before.  Professor Morrison is fun to listen to, but be ready to write down everything he says because it could be on the exam.

If you think you are going to have an easy time with MUS 103 because you play an instrument, guess again. Basically if you want an A, you need to go to every lecture, take good notes, and have a good ear.
It's a great course! The lectures are amazing! It's especially good for PDF-ing purposes!
It's a very entertaining course. Don't take it P/D/F. It's quite easy and if you even the most basic interest in Western classical music, you'll find yourself doing the work just for pure enjoyment.
It's not as easy as you think to do well in this course.

It's very introductory, so if you want a fleeting glance at music history this will get you acquainted with the big names. If you're a prospective music major, I would eschew this class in favor of the 105 and 106 series, which I'm told is far more intensive but also more useful.
Lectures are important.  Be sure to jot down Simon Morrison's flowery descriptions and interpretations of important musical pieces.
MUS 103 can be a fun course, but I do not recommend taking the course for a grade, since it appears difficult to get a decent mark.
Morrison is amazing. Everyone should take it. Save it for senior spring.
PDF it if you're just not interested !
Perfect PDF. You definitely need to put in some time to study for the midterm and the final, but other than that, you can pretty much just go to lectures and enjoy the material stress-free.
Start listening to the music a couple weeks before the tests.  Don't try and learn all the songs in a few days leading up to them.
TAKE IT - no regrets.
Take it - its great stuff to know and fun to study.
Take it if you're interested in music and music history.  Definitely not my favorite class at Princeton.
Take it! It's a great course! Be ready to memorize, but it's great!
Take it.

Take this class if you have even the slightest interest in music. You will walk away feeling like you have at least grasped the basics of how to listen to music and music history.  Its different than other courses on campus because your homework is to listen to music, which makes this course fun and refreshing.
Take this class. It's a lot of fun and you will get a broad survey of music history and composition. The course load is not very heavy and the material is very interesting.
The class is good but is a lot more challenging that you may think. It provides a good perspective of musical history, so for those who don't have such knowledge, this would be a good course to take.
The course is not as easy, nor as interesting as I thought it would be.
The more you put into it, the more you get out of it.

There's no question this is an easy LA, but it's not quite as simple as clapping for credit. You will have to do quite a lot of memorization and learn a thing or two about the major cultural shifts in Western thought over the past millenium. That being said, the things you learn add value to your life in teaching you about the importance and influences on music, something most of us never think about.

This class does not deserve its reputation for being "easy" if you are trying to get an A. You will have to put time in to do the listenings at the very least. Tests are very comprehensive and require a lot of preparation.

This course has a reputation for being easy but it is not. If you are good at memorizing take this course because you will probably be good at it. If you are looking of an LA I would go for an english class.

This is a fun class to take for an LA if you need one.  It really isn't as easy as you might think, although it seems to depend a great deal on what preceptor you have and how much work they assign/how they go about grading it, if at all.  The exams aren't very hard, although there's a lot of memorization of dates of pieces and composers' births and deaths for no apparent reason.  The best part is Simon Morrison's lectures, he makes everything very engaging and actually gives wonderfully interesting background stories about the composers and so forth.  It's a bit disheartening to see people get up after the 50 minutes when he's in the middle of talking, but if you stick around you'll hear some neat information from a very much prominent musicologist.  The lectures themselves are presented impeccably; he has a certain style and flair to his public speaking that most professors here lack completely.  Overall, a very fun class if you put in a reasonable amount of work and go to the lectures and precepts.
This is a surface-grazing intro course for anyone who needs a mildly interesting, but not too involved PDF class.
This is a very interesting music survey course.  It's a good course to fulfill an LA.
Totally indifferent.
You'll have the memorize dates for the exams. Other than that annoyance, this class covers musical history in the west and does some basic terminology.
be ready to do well on the midterm, it is harder than expected
don't neglect lectures!
good class. wish I had more time to study for the final. hope i passed...
great course! must take for pton students.
keep up with lectures
more of a history class than a music class
take it
take the class--little work, learn a lot, fun
this course is interesting, but it does have some work
why not?
descrip: Music 103 is an introduction to Western Art Music (works from 1100 to the present). The course defines the basic elements of music - pitch, rhythm, melody, harmony, and form - and the historically significant styles and genres of composition. Emphasis is placed on significant premiere performances, music and politics, and music and the other arts (film, dance, literature).

title: Ethics and Public Policy
reviews: A great ethics class to take if you enjoy thinking about current events!
A great introduction to political theory and its application to policy challenges. I've heard that Professor Macedo is even better.
A great politics/ wws class, no other way to describe it
Apparently Steven Macedo was a very good professor. I would advise against taking the course if Keith Shaw is teaching it.
Course is a great way to get an EM distribution, but is probably not one of the more interesting WWS courses.
Definitely take this one.
Great course, especially if Shaw is lecturing.
Great course. Surprisingly manageable workload. Challenging and stimulating material. Take this course.
I think this is a great course. Having friends to study with will make it even better so you can share notes and go over the terms for exams and discuss papers.
If you enjoyed Intro. to Moral Philosophy you'll enjoy this class. The reading list is very interesting and we discuss some very relevant ethical topics.
If you need it for Woodrow Wilson, or are interested in political philosophy, take it. But if you are just looking for an ethics class, take another course.

Interesting, not too hard EM

Good for WWS too
It's a great course to learn about ethics and their application to public policy. I am not an ethics kind of person and it was interesting to reconsider policies and individual actions.
Split the readings with other people in your class.
TAKE IT!
Take it if you're interested in Philosophy and Ethics and Politics. Be careful though because WWS is competitive.
Take it, but there are better WWS classes i Think.
Take the course, especially if you are interested in the readings. I don't think it would be good as a simple distribution requirement-filler.
Take this class if you need an EM or if you are interested in public policy.
Take this class, you won't regret it. It's better than PHI 202! Look out for classes under Prof Keith Shaw
Take this if you are even slightly interest in how ethics can inform policy choices!
Take this if you need an EM course. Otherwise take it only if you are truly interested in political philosophy.
This class definitely teaches you many important and fascinating topics. I recommend that anyone interested in ethical issues take it
This class was very interesting and not an overwhelming amount of work. Lectures an readings went together nicely.

This is a fun class. Interesting readings and topics. If you want more philosophy/more legit precepts, go take an actual political philosophy course so that your brain will be happier. Otherwise, this course is fine.
This is a great EM to take, especially if you can't wait two years for Peter Singer to teach again.
Work on paper drafts and talk about your ideas with preceptors before writing the final draft.
you have to work for the class. don't slack off if you are pdf
descrip: This course examines major moral controversies in public life and differing conceptions of justice and the common good. It seeks to help students develop the skills required for thinking and writing about the ethical considerations that ought to shape public institutions, guide public authorities, and inform popular expectations. The course will focus on issues that are particularly challenging for advanced, pluralist democracies like the USA, such as justice in war, ecological stability, surveillance and privacy, markets and distributive justice, and the place, if any, or religious arguments in politics.

title: Relativism
prereqs: One philosophy course or permission of instructor..
descrip: The course will explore various kinds of relativism: cultural relativism about beliefs concerning matters of fact; conceptual relativism, deriving from claims about the existence of distinct and, perhaps, incompatible conceptual schemes; something called "epistemic relativism"; and moral relativism of various kinds. We will look for the common structure of the various relativisms--if there is one--and explore whether relativism in any of these domains is plausible.

title: Mathematical Methods of Physics
descrip: Mathematical methods and terminology which are essential for modern theoretical physics. These include some of the traditional techniques of mathematical analysis, but also more modern tools such as group theory and differential geometry. Mathematical theories are not treated as ends in themselves; the goal is to show how mathematical tools are developed to solve physical problems.

title: Archaeology Seminar
reviews: Great if interested in archaeology, even if it's not your major.  Be ready to discuss, discuss, discuss!
I would definitely recommend this course.
It's a good class, nice, fair professor. If you do the work and participate it should be fine.
It's a pretty cool class.
Take it.. It's wonderful
Take this class.  Even if you have no intention of going into archeology it is worth it.
prereqs: None.
descrip: Required for concentrators specializing in archaeology. Aims to introduce students to the methods and thinking of archaeologists and prehistorians, so that they will be at home in fields where archaeology supplies the evidence they study. Topics include the concept of prehistory (the idea that part of human history is not recorded in writing); ethnographic analogy and the interpretation of material remains; relating material culture to texts (e.g. a Mesopotamian site to the cuneiform texts found there, or Jericho to the Bible); schemes of cultural development (the definition of "civilization"); and how to read an excavation report.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Sophomores and Juniors only.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Recent Developments in Financial Regulation: International Dimensions
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Aqueous Chemistry
prereqs: Intro to CHM 201-202 or background in GEO 363 or GEO 418 or instructors permission..
descrip: This course focuses on selected topics in aqueous chemistry of the natural systems, including: chemistry of inorganic and organic species in aqueous solutions- hydration, hydrolysis, coordination chemistry of metal-ligand complexes, chemical equilibria in fresh and saline water; mineral dissolution and alteration, recrystallization and evolution of secondary phases, dissolution kinetics; nucleation and precipitation of minerals, biological control in mineral precipitation, precipitation kinetics; electron transfer in aquatic systems, redox equilibria and kinetics; chemistry of water-solid/air interfaces.

title: Reception of the Classical Tradition
descrip: Course examines the ways in which philosophers and imaginative writers, historians and philologists, artists and antiquaries, interpreted ancient texts and objects, from ca. 1400 to 1850.

title: Levantine Colloquial Arabic
reviews: Don't forget to study vocabulary independently.  The course vocabulary is fairly narrowly tailored to the movies.
It's a nice break from grammar and will help you understand different ways of speaking while at the same time improving your MSA.
Take it. Watch the movies not only to boost your colloquial skills but also to greatly expand your knowledge of the situations in the Middle East.
This is a quite easy class which introduces one to the Levantine dialect and the many cultures of the Levant. Definitely a good course to take if you have done at least two years of Arabic.
descrip: An introduction to spoken Levantine dialect. Materials in the course are designed to promote functional usage of the language, stressing the vocabulary and grammar of conversation as used in daily life in the Levant, particularly Palestine, Jordan, and Lebanon.

title: Topics in the Cultural Expression of Protest and Dissent in Spain - Culture and Memory of the Spanish Civil War
prereqs: At least one SPA 200-level course (two 200-level SPA courses advisable) or instructor's permission.
descrip: An examination of the narrative, poetry, film, songs, photography and graphic art generated by Spaniards and foreigners about the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939) in the seventy years since the war was fought. This cultural production will be examined in the context of the political and ideological reasons that explain the international attraction the war generated. Among the works examined: poems by Neruda; Picasso's Guernica (it was the first war in which aviation played a significant role); documentaries (The Spanish Earth, Mourir a Madrid); and photographs by Robert Capa (the Spanish Civil War consecrated the nascent art of photojournalism).

title: Beginner's Russian II
reviews: Great class!

I'd definitely recommend Russian to any student considering picking up a new language - from what I've been able to tell, my classmates and I have been much more pleased than most other first-year language students (in French, Spanish, etc.).  I've absolutely loved it.
If you have any interest in studying Russian, absolutely take this course.
Know the material from 101 very well! Everything is cumulative, and if you're still struggling with things from the last semester, you're  going to struggle in this semester as well.
Russian is a difficult language, but if you want to learn it, Princeton's Russian language program is excellent.
Stas is a really good instructor.  Russian is not an easy language.  You must put in more effort than just enough to get by.  If you do the work, it is very exciting to be able to learn the language.
Stas is awesome! Actually, everyone in the department is awesome! This class is a large time commitment but it is definitely worth the work.
Take it - teachers are great, the class is fun, and Russian will always be useful for many things, but be prepared to work hard! It's a pretty consistent daily challenge!
Take it! Russian is a hard language and grade deflation definitely exists in this class, but Stas does a great job with presenting the richness of the language.

Take this course if you are at all interested in Russian, or even to fulfill the language requirement if you're up for a challenge.  The course is generally pretty demanding, especially on a day-to-day and week-to-week basis, but it is very rewarding in the end!

Take this course!! It has been the best experience of my time here at Princeton, academically speaking, and it has stimulated my curiosity in so many ways. This is far more than just a language class.

The course was generally effective as an extension of RUS 101. In my case, I feel that my greatest advances have been in reading and speaking, as that is what exercises and tests/quizzes tend to reinforce. There was a greater (compared to RUS 101) but still relatively small emphasis on listening and reading authentic material, but hopefully that will come naturally at higher levels of language study.
This is a great language course; it is also demanding. I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves learning languages and wants to start Russian.

Well, if you took RUS 101, you kind of have to take RUS 102. Nevertheless, this course is amazing as well, and actually runs at a more reasonable pace than RUS 101 (four chapters instead of six). Some material in this course is not in the textbook, so do your best to listen in class and ask questions. Aspect is a tad tough to deal with, but it is doable with a bit of dedication. Be warned: GRADE DEFLATION SUCKS IN THIS COURSE! Our curve for last semester was as follows: A: 99-100, A- : 95-98, B : 91-94, etc. If this happens again, band together and do something about it. You should not have to make the choice between your GPA and the Russian language.
prereqs: RUS 101 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The objective of RUS 102 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian: basic training in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending the Russian language in a cultural context.

title: O.P.R. Seminars
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Digital Signal Processing
reviews: If you enjoyed ELE301, this is a good course to take.
It's a good entrance course for the students who are interested in signal processing
descrip: The lectures will cover: (1) Basic principles of digital signal processing. (2) Design of digital filters. (3) Fourier analysis and the fast Fourier transform. (4) Roundoff errors in digital signal processing. (5) Applications of digital signal processing.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Tiffany Sirois in E-212..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Special Topics in Public Affairs - The Economics of the Welfare State
descrip: All advanced countries have extensive "welfare state" programs that provide insurance against economic losses, support people with low incomes, etc.. But these programs vary widely in extent from the relatively small US welfare state, to the larger welfare states of much of Europe, to the generous programs of Scandinavia. At the same time, there is heated controversy about the effects of such programs. This course surveys welfare state programs, including health care systems, across various countries, analyzes the debates over their economic effects, and looks at the political economy of reform in the US and countries such as France.

title: Independent Project I
descrip: A one-semester research project under the supervision of a faculty member. The topic is developed by the student and faculty supervisor. Course culminates in a final report in the style of a research paper. Post generals students that have not already taken that course may take this course, however, they must take it with a faculty member other than their research advisor on a different research topic. P/D/F for Ph.D. candidates, graded for MSE and MEng candidates.

title: Viscous Flows and Boundary Layers
reviews: Certainly worth it
Course gives a very thorough explanation of fluid mechanics
Course is a decent amount of work, but it is absolutely worth taking.
If you get behind on the homeworks, you will not catch up.
Large workload.
Long homework sets and hard final exam.
N/A
Set aside a lot of time for the homework.
Take the course, you will have an excellent teacher to learn from!
the course is a bit math heavy, but it's still really worth taking the course.
very fundamental course in fluids, no need for a backround,
descrip: An introduction to the mechanics of viscous flows. The kinematics and dynamics of viscous flows. Some solutions of the Navier Stokes equations. The behavior of vorticity. The boundary layer approximation. The laminar boundary layer with and without pressure gradient. Separation. Compressible laminar boundary layers. Introduction to instability and transition. Introduction to turbulence.

title: Colonial North America
reviews: Colonial North America is an interesting period in history. This course does a good job of providing an overview and correcting many of the misconceptions we learned in other history classes. The work load isn't too bad, although there is a fairly substantial amount of reading.
Great Course Overall, I recommend it to those looking to learn about the often overlooked colonial period.
Great class.  I would take it again.
Professor Warren is an engaging lecturer, and the course material is really interesting.
Recommended. Prof. Warren is really great. The course has really interesting material, it's definitely not the colonial history of your high school.

Take it if you're interested in the subject, as told from a multiplicity of viewpoints. This is one of my least favorite parts of American history, so I didn't find the subject particularly fascinating, but Professor Warren does a good job and is very fair, so the course itself was fine.
Take this class!  Lectures and readings are very interesting and will perhaps open your eyes to historical perspectives you hadn't considered before...
descrip: An introduction to the history of colonial North America. We will study the processes set in motion by the collision of Indian, European, and African cultures during the first two centuries of colonization. The course considers the impact of climate change, pandemics, revivals, and imperial wars; the limits of the Atlantic world; migration and rapid cultural change; the rise of slavery and racial thinking; gender and sexuality; contending religious and magical systems; and trade and pre-revolutionary political strife during this turbulent period of American history.

title: Nonlinear and Mixed-Integer Optimization: Fundamentals and Applications
descrip: Topics in convex analysis; unconstrained and constrained nonlinear optimization; duality theory; mixed-integer linear optimization; mixed-integer nonlinear optimization; modeling issues in process synthesis; and process synthesis applications in energy recovery, separations, reactors, and flowsheets.

title: Poptimism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Analysis of Buildings
prereqs: ARC 203 and ARC 204; Preference given to architectural concentrators and graduate students.
descrip: Investigating the rich interplay between form, space, skin, structure, material assembly, performance and representation, this course seeks to develop creative and productive approaches for analyzing very recent buildings.The past decade has witnessed the realization of a wealth of buildings, which has been documented in over-sized books, design blogs, and glossy magazines but not carefully dissected with inventive analytical tools. This analysis will be positioned within the context of the history of building analysis, and buildings key to that history.

title: The New Wave on Film
prereqs: 200-level FRE course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The dark. The screen. The projector. The light in the dark. The music. The getaway car. The starlet. The director. The French New Wave. A course on how to read films through the revolutionary cinema of French New Wave directors Francois Truffaut, Robert Bresson, Jacques Demy and Jean-Luc Godard, and close contemporaries Alain Resnais and Agnes Varda. We will also look at the films that inspired them, their call to aesthetic irreverence, and the Auteur theory at the heart of their theory and practice of filmmaking.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Nice and chill class, Prof. Williams is really nice and famous, you should take it if interested in translations/poetry.
Translation is fun.
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Developmental Psychology
reviews: A fun, not too difficult class. Time consuming with the nursery school observations. Lots of exams/papers, so plan ahead because they sneak up.
A relatively easy class with interesting subject matter, though some of it is common sense.
An "easy" class in the sense that all the material is stuff you know from being a human.
Definitely do the reading cause you'll learn a lot of interesting stuff.
Definitely take it! If you read the book and attend lectures, you'll get a good grade!
Do it! You learn a lot and won't feel overwhelmed. Plus, watching children during the observation is adorable!
Don't take it unless you need an EC to graduate.
Expect to memorize a lot of fluffy theories.
Extremely time consuming, but interesting material.
For students just looking for an EC I would not recommend this course. I believe there are more interesting courses that you can pursue.
Go to lecture!
Good filler class for EC. There are a lot of exams and papers but they're all pretty easy and not much work.
Good for a PDF class, but a little more written work/time commitment to work than might be preferred for a PDF.
Good for if you need an EC
I would advise taking the course.
I would advise to go to lecture and to read  the textbook.

I would definitely reccommend taking this for your EC requirement.  It's not difficult to do well in the course so you don't have to PDF it.  The material is interesting and I was happy with my decision to take it.
I would definitely recommend it to another student. Especially if Peter is your preceptor.
I would recommend this if you're interested in human development or just looking for a not-too-difficult but fun psychology course in general.
I would recommend to this course to someone who is looking for a relatively easy course with minor commitment that is still pretty interesting.
I would say if you're interested in the development of cognition in humans, definitely take this class! A lot of interesting concepts are covered.

I would strongly recommend this course to other students if they are planning on majoring in psychology or if they have a general interest in psychology. In this course, we learn about several things that have applications in our everyday lives, and thus, students learn many useful things in this course.
I would take the course. You will learn a lot.
I would tell them to go to lectures because a lot of the test material is from lectures, and also to make notecards on the book definitions to prepare yourself for tests.

I you are interested in psychology and why people of different ages act the way they do, take this course.  It provides a good overview on concepts learned throughout life and was not too heavy on assignments and readings.
If students like children, they should take this course. Part of the course requirement includes visiting a nursery school, and this experience is quite rewarding.

If you are interested in psychology and kids/babies, definitely take this course. Every lecture is very interesting, and the course is not hard at all as long as you attend every lecture (as tests are based on lectures and textbook reading) and read each chapter. Also, Professor Brynildsen is VERY nice, friendly, and approachable.
If you want to take it, do so for the observations and papers which make it an interesting course.  Otherwise it's pretty boring.
If you've already taken Intro to Psych or AP Psych, then a lot of the topics are review.
Interesting, not too difficult. It also overlaps with other psychology courses quite a bit, so it's a good way to get an easy departmental in a non-boring class.
It is a easy course to succeed in, but a little a dry. I would suggest doing all the reading in order to succeed on tests if it is taught in the same way next year.
It's interesting if you like psychology and children.
Lecture may seem unimportant, but lecture notes helped me a lot with studying for exams.
Lectures can be a bit dry but the child observation segment is a fun experience. Not my first choice to fill a 200-level psych req but if you're interested, why not.
Make sure to do all the readings.

Make sure to read the textbook and take notes in lecture, as questions come from both lecture material not covered in the textbook and textbook material not covered in the lecture. If you want to do really well on the tests, also read the boxes in the textbook that take a closer look at a study. There is usually one question per test from one of the boxes.
Not unless you really want to learn about this specific topic.
Only take this class if someone else is teaching it.
TAKE IT!
Take it - it's not too much work and what you learn is totally applicable to real life. Plus, you get to observe cute kids :)
Take it!
Take it! It's fun, and not too difficult. Especially if you are at all interested in psychology or science.
Take this class!!!!
