The class is just filled with knowledge that everyone one should just know. Very practical life class.

The course is completely based on memorization, and if you find yourself enjoying the material - which I believe is likely - then the memorization becomes substantially easier. If you're at all interested, definitely consider taking this course, you learn a lot about human nature through lectures (through psych studies). It's easy to like. The papers can be annoying, though. Definitely take notes about your visits to the preschool for your second paper, and for your first paper, try to at least research the articles early on, so you only have to read and summarize once it comes time to actually write.

The work's not difficult, and the material's fairly interesting, especially if you don't know anything about psychology at all (but even if you do). Do the experiments early to get them out of the way. And do the child observations - although sometimes they involve a lot of early-morning walking, this is probably the heart of the course and the most rewarding experience.
This course is very interesting and a great was to fulfill your EC requirement

This is a good intro class for psych, and you'll see how psychology works. There is not much to the material of this class except memorization. I thought it required a lot of outside work (observations, study requirements) for what I got out of it.
This is a great course!
easier, more interesting EC than most of the others
go to class.
i liked this course! there are just a lot of hidden (required) hours. be prepared
listen in class and do the readings!
sure, go for it if you think you'll like it!
take it its a nice course
descrip: A survey of human development emphasizing the nature of children's minds and experience, developmental change, and the relation between child and adult mentation. How do children at different periods in development think, feel, and experience the world around them? Students will be actively involved in preschool settings.

title: Morals, Markets, and Health
descrip: This seminar examines ethical issues that lie at the intersection of markets and health. Examples include paternalism and the ban on trans fats, access to essential drugs and the justifications for intellectual property rights, and the morality of markets in body parts and reproductive labor. Readings will be drawn from philosophers such as Debra Satz, Peter Singer, Robert Nozick, Elizabeth Anderson, Ronald Dworkin, and Frances Kamm. The purpose of the course is to provoke critical thinking about normative issues in public policy.

title: Atmospheric Thermodynamics and Convection
descrip: Thermodynamics of water-air systems. Overview of atmospheric energy sources and sinks. Planetary boundary layers. Closure theories for atmospheric turbulence. Cumulus convection. Interactions between cumulus convection and large-scale atmospheric flows. Cloud-convection-radiation interactions and their role in the climate system.

title: The Early Modern Print
descrip: This course surveys the history of print in Europe from ca. 1400-1700. It attends to the distinctive techniques and material processes that have been involved in printmaking over the centuries, as well as the myriad cultural and formal developments that the efflorescence of print wrought. Artists to be studied include Durer, Raimondi, Rembrandt, Lucas van Leyden, and others. Students will meet in the printroom of the Princeton University Art Museum bi-weekly, where they will work with objects from the collection.

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: Consider the professor teaching the course, because that plays a major role.
Do not bother unless you think you are going to potentially be a psych major. General interest people -- BEWARE>
Do not take this course if the same teacher is teaching it.

Don't blow off studying for the lab tests, midterm, or final. They're the major sources of your grades in this class, and honestly, they're not bad at all if you study thoroughly--especially because most people don't. They say that questions come from the class notes, and they definitely do and you need to have attended class to answer them, but the majority of them come from the textbook and a solid knowledge of the textbook will work fine. I suggest keeping up with the readings each week just because it's a lot to catch up on at the end of the semester, but it's not necessary to be on top of it at all times. Really put time and effort into the three hours that you're in lab--what you get out of it really depends upon how much you put into it, and you can really learn a lot.
Don't take it if you are just trying to get a distribution requirement out of the way, genuinely enjoy the course!
Don't take it in the spring.
Don't take it with Professor Avena.  The subject material, however, is interesting, as are the labs.
Don't take this class with this professor.
I recommend it and to look at the powerpoints before the exams.

I would definitely recommend this course! Especially for those looking for an ST, you get a taste of lab work and science without having to worry about being out of your depth in scientific knowledge! The lectures and readings were relevant and interesting and the labs were always fun. Overall, a very good class for somebody who is trying to decide if they're interested in psychology or even for just getting an ST out of the way!
I would not recommend this lecturer to another student.
I would recommend going to lecture.
I would recommend that students look over the slides that the professor posts every week and outline lightly the book but review all lecture notes. Sparknotes Pscyhology is good resource as well.
I would recommend this course.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone either slightly interested in psychology or looking for an ST course. It was one of my favorite classes this year.
I would tell friends to take the course. It isn't particularly hard, is a good ST, you learn interesting things, and is largely enjoyable and educational.
I'd probably wait to take it with Oppenheimer in the fall, but it was fine. Not horrible, not great.
If you are interested at all in psychology, take this course.  It has fun and engaging labs and great course material surveying the field.

If you have taken AP Psychology and are looking for a more in depth understanding of Psychology, this is the course for you. AP Psych gives you a foundation of knowledge that puts you at a bit of an advantage in terms of memorizing terms and their meanings.

If you have to take this course as a prereq, I would recommend it. However, out of general interest, I would recommend taking the many other courses out there that are more engaging/thought provoking. I have heard great things about more specific psych classes, so one of those might be a better bet than this general introduction.
If you need to take this course in the spring semester, do it, but if you can, take it in the fall semester with Professor Oppenheimer.
It isn't PDFable, so if you're thinking of slacking and using it for an ST, go elsewhere. The workload is actually fairly heavy.
It's a fairly easy class on a weekly basis, although the midterm was deceptively difficult.
Keep up with your readings.
Prepare to memorize a lot.
Pretty good ST ? not an easy class per se but the labs and lab reports are pretty easy. Very interesting class by and of itself.
Read the textbook. It is OK to miss a few lectures. Pay special attention to whatever is presented in class and not in the textbook.
Study for this specifically. The tests were way more specific than the lectures.
Take good notes during the lectures, because those are the most important sources of material for the exams.
Take it.  If only to see if you enjoy the material, because the overall field is very interesting.  The class itself may not be the best indicator of how the rest of the department goes, though.
There may be easier STs to take; however, Psych is a good subject to have under your belt.
They should definitely take the class.
This class is great. I recommend it.

This course is NOT PDF. Just to clarify - people think it is, and then they take the midterm and freak out. With that said, it is a good course and you should take it. But don't expect to try it for fun and then PDF it. Not happening. Do it to learn Psychology.

This course provides a great overview of the various subfields in psychology; should you decide to take this course, pay special attention to the lectures, from which the focus of the examinations are derived. Although labs can be long (3 hours), they are great reinforcers of the material in the lecture and sometimes the presentation and group experiments are even fun.
This is a great intro course for Psych and any science. I would highly recommend it.
This is interesting if you're interested in psychology and I think it's helpful to any discipline, but make sure you keep up with the readings so you can remain engaged in the lecture.
This lecturer was not good, but the course is good.
Very fair and interesting course

Very good course. If you need an STL distribution requirement, take this course. The work is straightforward and the material is interesting and engaging. If you have a general interest in psychology, this is best survey course Princeton has to offer. I would definitely recommend this course to freshman.
Very interesting material and a good class for everyone to take
Well, PSY 101 could be a good course. Talk to people about the professor you would have, though, since it could make or break the course.
a very good introduction to psychology that will help orient your interests.
very interesting class
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a pre-requisite for majoring in psychology and can also serve as one of the two lab courses used to satisfy the natural science requirement.

title: Advanced Arabic II
reviews: Hisham is great.  But be prepared for a lack of organization.  There was no syllabus at the beginning of the semester and we got our homework assignments only a day before they were due.  It is a lot of work, but you'll have impressive grammar skills by the end.  And beware--grading is a bit arbitrary.
If you want to learn Arabic grammar in a serious way, he is your guy
Take it! And take it seriously!
Take this class! Professor Hisham does give a lot of homework, but he is a great teacher and is extremely helpful.
This course will give a lot of practice in reading.
prereqs: ARA 301 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Modern Standard Arabic language acquisition through reading, listening, writing, and speaking with emphasis on grammar, exposure to philology, and utilization of translation from and into Arabic, supplemented by readings from literary figures and modern media.

title: Twice-Told Tales
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Algebraic Geometry
descrip: TBA

title: Low Dimensional Topology
descrip: Course focuses on the interplay between group theory, geometry and topology (a continuation from Fall 2010).

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: History of Modern Mexico
descrip: The course studies Mexico between two historic defeats: that of the mid-nineteenth century, when it lost half of its territory to the U.S., and that of the single-party regime of the PRI at the polls in 2000, after over 70 years of uneasy rule. Civil war followed one of these events; the outcome of the other is still in dispute. How can we explain Mexico's transition from the richest colony in the Americas to a nation with unresolved social, economic, and political struggles? What have been the causes of internal tension and how have different groups sought to solve them? Why have the drug cartels gained so much ground?

title: Globalization and Development
descrip: A treatment of international political economy, designed to provide students with a theoretical and critical understanding of the interaction between globalization and development. Examines international patterns of trade, debt, aid, investment, and migration, as well as the impacts of these processes on economic and political development. Attention is also devoted to analyzing the role of multilateral institutions, such as the IMF, World Bank, and WTO, in mediating these impacts and promoting development. Course has a particular focus on less developed nations, and inquires into the normative issues of global justice.

title: Pro-Sem in Chinese & Japanese Studies
descrip: General seminar dealing with the problems and possibilities of research peculiar to the fields of East Asian Studies. This year, the topic is Classical Chinese Philology.

title: History of Anthropological Theory
reviews: A course you must take if your priority is to learn theory.  You will definitely learn so much.
Anthro majors should try to take this course with Davis, even if it means taking the course early or late!
Awesome class.
It's a requirement, so you have to take it. I would encourage some pipeline of feedback to Professor Davis early on.
It's required for anthro students. Make sure you read and try to really read deep into the text.
Pay attention to the arguments the professor makes in class, and then reproduce them in your paper.
Simple: if you want to walk out of class starry-eyed and excited about anthropology, take this course.
Take it with Prof. Davis, she's really good!
Take your time with the papers, and go in to talk to Davis.
This is a fantastic course.  The lectures are very helpful!  Be concise in your writing.
this class is a summary of material that you've probably already read for any 300 level anthro or sociology course
to take it with professor davis!
prereqs: ANT 201 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to fundamental theories and debates in social/cultural anthropology. We will examine the national and colonial origins of anthropology, considering how western encounters with non-western peoples in the 19th-20th centuries opened questions about human kinship, history, economy, religion, language, sexuality, and personhood that continue to shape the horizons of our thought today. We will study this inheritance critically, exploring the changing concepts, methods, and ethics of anthropological research and writing, and evaluate their bearing on questions of power, justice, and identity in the present.

title: Beginner's Italian II
reviews: A very laid back course. If you are bored of spanish of french, this is a course that fit you well. The teachers are really great and understanding. This course moves at a steady pace, that ensures that you understand the concepts and develop as a strong speaker of the language.
Be prepared to participate, do the homework, go over the material five minutes before the start of the class.
Definitely take it if you are looking to take a fairly easy language class.
Do not be afraid of being in a small class.  For me, it was a good experience.
Do the homework that's about the grammar review, print out the packets because being on Google translate on your computer is stupid
I would certainly recommend this class to any freshman on the Italian path.
If you want to learn italian, this is your class.

Italian is a fun, easy language and the professors are great people. The assignments were very lax and the readings and films were interesting. HOWEVER, be prepared to take classes with athletes who couldn't give a flying sour apple about participating, which makes the class less enjoyable in the end.
Italian is awesome and the teachers are great! Take the course!
Keep up with the material.
Take Italian!
Take it if you need a language, and even if you don't.
Take it! You learn a lot in just a year, and it's very fun.
Take this course if you like Italian
Take this only if there is no way to get out of fulfilling the language requirement.
This course is great to get a solid understanding of the basics of Italian and all the instructors are great. Definitely take it.
Too hard don't take it.
italian is a great language to take at princeton
italian is better than the other languages....but still don't take it if you passed out like i did.
take it if you like languages or if you have to take a language
take italian even if you havent taken it in the past
take this course, it is not easy like many who first take italian believe it will be but there are many good teachers in the department
prereqs: ITA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Further study of Italian grammar and syntax with increased emphasis on vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Skills in speaking and writing (as well as understanding) modern Italian will also be further developed. Some aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Computational Finance in C++
reviews: Be prepared to work really hard if you have no programming experience at all.

Don't Do It! The course wastes tremendous amounts of time and just makes you angry. If you are looking for a job, and taking many other classes, or just want to enjoy life, this class is not one to take. 
If you already know C   very well, know finance very well, and can already put the two together, you may be able to do well if you ignore the lectures completely and can successfully interpret and catch the errors in the assignments. However, that seems to make taking the course completely unnecessary. So, if you know what you are doing, don't bother. And if you do not know what you are doing, you will not learn it here. Well, you may be able to learn something but it will be minimal relative to the amount of time and energy you put in, and you will never really be sure if what you learned is correct.
Some students complained that they could not understand some maths. So I suggest students to take asset pricing II or some other prerequisite courses first before taking this course.
The material is interesting and certainly important in your job later, so make sure you learn it, but avoid Maxim Bichuch at all costs.
You would need some basic C   language and some stochastic calculus background.
unless student has strong c   experience and phd level math, this course will be very tough
prereqs: Night class in Excel & VBA; Night class in Introduction to C++; Senior enrollment by Instructor permission only--must contact instructor PRIOR to signing up.
descrip: The intent of this course is to introduce the student to the technical and algorithmic aspects of a wide spectrum of computer applications currently used in the financial industry, and to prepare the student for the development of new applications. The student will be introduced to C++, the weekly homework will involve writing C++ code, and the final project will also involve programming in the same environment.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Automated Software Verification: Software Model Checking
reviews: Before you do each assignment, make sure you get the idea about the whole project.
Don't.
I think this is a good course for people that want an overview of how to build formal methods tools.

Some background in formal verification might be helpful, although not necessary to understand the subject matters. It is definitely recommended for first/second year graduate students looking to work in the area of verification.
Thorough presentation of modern software validation techniques, recommended for students interested in formal methods.
descrip: This course covers contemporary automated verification techniques for software. The focus is on the underlying techniques and algorithms rather than on using verification tools. The course is divided into two main parts: One covering model checking for finite state models (e.g., manual abstractions or UML state-charts), and a second part that shows how these techniques can be applied to infinite state programs by means of abstraction.

title: Sociology of Religion
descrip: This course examines the classical foundations of the sociology of religion and the different theoretical traditions within this field. The course then turns its attention to contemporary applications of these analytical approaches, focusing on the significance of religion in present-day politics, family life, race, economic development, and immigration.

title: Automatic Control Systems
reviews: A great course. Prof. Rowley is amazing, and labs aren't too bad.

A time-consuming but very rewarding course. Prof. Rowley's lectures for this course were among the best I've had at Princeton. Rowley is the one to go to if you don't understand something; he's incredibly knowledgeable and great at explanations. If you're an MAE, you should look forward to it.

Absolutely take it.  Prof. Rowley is an incredible lecturer, and the subject matter is very interesting.  Some of the problemsets can be a little long, but it's truly fascinating to be able to take any physical systems, and manipulate its physical properties through control (rather than say, changing the mechanics of the system itself)

Take it.
Definitely go to lecture: Prof. Rowley really makes the material clear.
Definitely take it with the lab (though I think all MAE students have to), go to the lectures, and start the problem sets early.
Go to lectures that's where you'll learn all the material. P-sets will confuse you, so don't be afraid to ask for help from a friend, professor or TA.
Great MAE course!
I enjoyed it.
I would definitely suggest taking this class, regardless of background. The technical material is not that hard and is taught very well.
TAKE IT.
The only reason to take this class is if you are an engineer but even though it is a requirement it is an interesting subject and Prof. Rowley is great!
This is a great class. The problem sets are pretty involved and take a lot of work, but it is definitely worth it.
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor. Course not open to Freshmen. Non-concentrators and graduate students need approval of instructor to enroll in this course..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.

title: Topics in Algebra - The Most Interesting Simple Groups
descrip: This course will be a discussion about the most interesting simple groups. More details provided at the first class.

title: Advanced Topics in Learning & Memory: Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms
prereqs: PSY 258 and 259 or the equivalent..
descrip: Seminar designed to expose students to current research on the cellular and molecular bases of learning and memory, providing an up-to-date analysis of what is, and is not, known about the neurobiology of learning and memory. We begin with a review of the model systems used to study learning and memory, including an analysis of the translational validity of certain model systems. We then deal with different forms of plasticity (synaptic and structural) as they pertain to learning and memory during development and adulthood. Finally, we apply some of these findings to evaluate the current status of research on aging and Alzheimer's.

title: Molecular and Cellular Immunology
reviews: A lot of fun for a glimpse of medical school.
Definitely take this course. Great blend of premed and MOL. Lecturer and preceptor are equally awesome. Material is very interesting and the case studies are a great supplement.
Good for MOL majors, especially pre-meds. Manageable workload; study hard for the quizzes. The professor is changing, so this may not apply.
Good intro to immunology.
Great course to get a sense of the why behind a lot of medicine, but you could probably learn as much from the text book as you could from a semester in this class.
I recommend taking this course.

It is a good class, the lectures are good, the precepts are interesting, the instructors are good and very nice.  But hear this: there is so much material in this course, make sure that you do the reading before the lecture on the material, and don't fall behind.  I will repeat, THERE IS SO MUCH MATERIAL TO KNOW that it can easily sweep over you, and you won't notice how much you don't know and/or remember until the tests.  Do the reading, keep up with it, go to lecture, be attentive.  It will help a lot and make your life come test time a lot easier.
Skip it and just save it for med school.
Take it if you want to know about our immune system - not to be taken lightly.
Take the course if you are interested in immunology or need another distribution. Overall a solid course.
The subject is interesting, but expect to memorize a lot of details.
Try to stay up to date with the lecture material so you are not scrambling when the quizzes and exams come around.
take the class if you're interested in immunology
prereqs: MOL 214.
descrip: A broad survey of the field of immunology and the mammalian immune system. The cellular and molecular basis of innate and acquired immunity will be discussed in detail. The course will provide frequent exemplars drawn from human biology in health and disease.

title: Advanced Sculpture
reviews: This class takes work but is really fun. If you like building stuff, and want to have an awesome, quirky, & laid-back professor you should definitely take a class with Joe. You will learn a lot about contemporary sculpture and how to talk about it.
prereqs: VIS 203/204, or VIS 221/222, or VIS 231/232, or VIS 331/332 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Through field research and studio work, this course will interrogate the "negative" idea of contemporary sculpture. Where bright lines still exist to delineate paintings and photographs and video from each other, contemporary sculpture is tacitly defined as everything else, as anything that is "not painting", "not photography", or "not film". This course will approach sculpture positively and revel in the persistent allure of all things massive, from freestanding letterforms and roadside attractions to panic rooms and regional cuisine. Of all the visual arts, only sculpture can address our existence in the material world on its own terms.

title: American Politics
reviews: Attend the lectures.
Definitely take this course if you plan on living in America! It is essential that we understand as much as we can about our political system.
Do it.
Don't take this unless you never took an American politics/government class in high school - otherwise it will waste your time.
Especially for internationals.
Even if you think you know a lot about American politics already, this course is a must for understanding current events and taking part in American government.
Great lecturer, mostly interesting material, easy if you have any background in Government or Politics
Great professor and very relevant topic. Take it!
I think you should take this course if you want an overview of American Politics.
I would say to take the course if you are interested in the material.  I am glad that I learned what I did in the class.
I would tell them to get ready to learn alllll about the Congress.
If you are interested in politics, you should take this class.
If you have an interest in politics take the class.
If you have an interest in politics, then I would definitely recommend this class with Frymer. I had a good time in it.
If you haven't taken American politics before, it's worth it. If you took AP Gov in high school, don't bother.
If you know a lot about government and politics this will not be new to you, but take it anyway because there are some basic things you still might not know.
If you know that we have three branches of government, don't take this course. If you don't, find a better professor who will actually give you a rich and meaningful understanding of the material.
If you'd like a basic introduction to how this wonderful nation operates internally, take this course.
If you're familiar with American politics from AP Government already, this will be a lot of review. But the readings and Professor Frymer's lectures still makes it a worthwhile course.

If you've taken AP Government or otherwise have a strong background knowledge of, you'll be bored at times, though there was some new stuff. Incidentally, it felt a lot like a high school class - not necessarily in a bad way, but just the mix of people/format/topics.

If you've taken a reasonable amount of interest in what has gone on in the U.S. during your lifetime, you already know at least 75% of what's covered in this course.  So if you're looking to gain a deeper understanding of American politics, then this course probably isn't for you.  But if you're keen on getting your distribution requirement with a relatively light workload, then this is probably your best bet.
It's a good SA to take, and there is often room to explore your own interests given a choice of which readings to write with.
Make sure you do the readings. Come to lectures, they are amazing! Precepts are also very good.
Professor Frymer is very good lecturer. If you keep up with the readings, you should do well in the class.
Take it

Take it if you don't know much about American politics. Or even if you just want a refresher. It covers the basics (Constitution, branches of government, etc) but also provides readings that help you understand the significance of things beyond just their definition. Frymer is easy-to-listen-to and his exams are very fair.
Take it!
This is a good course if you want to learn the basics of American politics.
This is a good course, but make sure you are ready for a very different experience, as the precepts and papers can have little discussion and be confusing, respectively.
This is a great course if you are looking to take politics.
do the readings

don't take it.  complicated, befuddled, confusing.  even though the professor is good at presenting the material, there's so much of it and each subject is touched upon so lightly, that it's hard to remember everything well enough to be able speak intelligently about it in the midterm and final...which are basically the only two things that determine your grade...unfortunately.  it would probably be better to take a more in-depth American politics course.  That way you might actually learn a lot about one aspect, instead of almost nothing about a lot of aspects.
i liked this course a lot.  minimal work if you wanted to, but very interesting.
pretty fun class, not too hard
reading intensive - less set material
take it! go to lecture
take it, it's a good intro class.
descrip: An introduction to the national institutions and political processes of American government and democratic representation. Topics include the Constitution, the American political tradition, public opinion, interest groups and social movements, political institutions, civil rights, civil liberties, and matters of public policy.

title: Topics in Brazilian Cultural and Social History - Music and Literature in Brazil
reviews: Do the reading, speak up in class discussions, and let a particular work or musical artist spark a passion for your own research in addition to the classwork.

Don't think twice about it.  The course is a marvelous history of Brazil's relationship with music that will not only expose you to a wealth of incredible artists but also revolutionize your understanding of the palavra cantada.  And Prof. Meira Monteiro is unmissable.
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission.
descrip: What happens when music and literature meet? How does a literary project convert itself into music? And what if music itself turns into literature? We will address these and other issues in order to answer the question posed by literary critic and musician Jose Miguel Wisnik: how does it happen that in Brazil a popular singer like Caetano Veloso can be the most profound critic of its major writer, Guimaraes Rosa? And what if that criticism is nothing but a song? From the act of listening to music to the close reading of literature, we will try to understand why Brazil is so often identified as a richly "musical" country.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: History, Philosophy, and Religion
reviews: Be prepared to not have enough time to always finish everything and learn how to still do well regardless
HUM is a great class, but be prepared for the work level; anyone who is not ends up dropping out.

HUM will give you access to the foundations of Western civilization while making you develop as a reader, writer and thinker. It is very challenging, as the reading list is extensive and students are held to a high standard, yet the education you will receive is definitely worth it if you are willing to put in the time and effort.
I would advise any student thinking of studying the humanities to take this course and I would advise her to do all she could to make the most of it.
I would advise them to take this course even if they have only remote interest in the Humanities--even if it's a lot of work, it will form your foundation for life.
If you have even the slightest inclination toward taking this course, do it.  It changed my life.
If you like reading and don't mind the 400 pages a week, take it!
Just do it. It's fantastic.
Please see my evaluation of HUM 218.
See HUM 218.
See evaluation for HUM 218
TAKE IT.
Take it if you know how to value learning over grades.
Take it. Yes, it is hard to keep up with everything, but it is well worth it.

Take this course if you want to gain enormous knowledge of Western Civ, but only if you are willing to work hard, do all the reading, and participate in precept. If you aren't the class can become Hell.
Take this course!!!! See HUM 218 evaluation
YES YES YES YES YES YES YES
prereqs: See HUM 218.
descrip: In combination with 218, this is the second half of a year-long interdisciplinary sequence exploring Western culture from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Students must register for both HUM 218 and HUM 219, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for 219 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 218. There are no separate meeting times for 219.

title: Modernism and Modernity - Globalization and Art
descrip: Combining globalization theory with comparative observation of the arts (visual, literature, music, cinema, theatre), seminar explores emergence of multiple global "art worlds" in recent history. Terms of phenomenology and communication theory aid in discussing concept. Institutions/structures examined include: museums, orchestras, artist networks, performances, exhibitions, educational structures and careers, cities as centers of art worlds and their relation towards peripheries. A guiding interest: the interrelation of homogeneity and diversity, examined through a systematic comparison of processes in the different arts.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: A ton of work if your not majoring in COS. Really gives you an understanding of how your system works.
Be prepared for long assignments
Definitely take this class! You'll get a lot out of this class per unit time that you spend working on the assignments.
Do the programming assignments. Start early. Seek help. You will need it.
Don't let people tell you it's hard. I took 126, then 226, and then this. It's not conceptually difficult, but the programming assignments do take a long time.

Finish assignments several days before they're due during the second half of the semester.  That is the best way to ensure that you have enough time to complete the last programming assignment, which is a doozy to say the least.
Follow the readings consistently, definitely attend lecture as much as possible, and whenever this is not possible, be sure to consult the lecture slides the day of. And start the assignments early.
For anyone interested in computer science or applying computer science to another field, this course gives you a very strong background.
Good course to take.
Great class if you are interested in being a COS major or persuing the certificate. Be warned, however, that it is very time consuming.
Hard course but rewarding -- be prepared to work
Huge time commitment but super interesting!
I P/D/F this class.  It is incredibly hard but you learn a lot.
I think anyone who is interested in computer science should take this course. It requires a lot of time, especially for the assignments, so make sure that schedule enough time to get your work done.
IF you have any interest in systems programing, take it.
If you are interested in COS, this is a must-take class. It's amazing. If you're not interested in COS, take this class no matter what, because you will immediately get interested.

In terms of workload and time-commitment, COS 217 is probably the equivalent of at least 1.5 Princeton courses, so it?s definitely not something to take on lightly. However, it was also by far one of the most rewarding and well-taught classes I?ve taken here so far, and I heartily recommend it to anyone who is interested in learning how computers work on a deeper level.

Leave at least one weekend open to do the assignments.  You don't know how long debugging's going to take, and it's very helpful to be able to work late into the night for as long as you have to, to fix that one elusive bug.

No prior knowledge of C or Assembly is required, and there is no need to buy any of the textbooks.  Lecture slides are online and precept handouts teach you all you need to know about the details of the language.
Provides great insight into the workings of the computer at a low-level. Beware that the problem sets take a considerable amount of time, but it's definitely worth it.
Recommend only if you are willing to put in the work.
STAY on top of assignments...and don't forget to study for the exam (REALLY HARD)
So much fun!!! The assignments are tough but so satisfying once you've finished them!
Take it if you love computer science; otherwise, you're in for a long semester.
Take it if you're at all interesting in systems programming. Of course take it if you're a COS major.

Take this class!! It is currently my best class at Princeton so far! I personally recommend taking COS 226 first; 217 assignments are conceptually simple, but can get annoying in implementing so just make sure you have good programming experience. Also, I highly recommend taking this with ELE 206! They complement each other well: COS 217 work down from high level programming to registers, whereas ELE 206 help build up the fundamentals up to registers. 
Once you take this class, just make sure to start assignments early, and you will literally love this class!

Take this course!  It is challenging and time-consuming, but I learned an enormous amount and after both the assignments and the exams felt really satisfied that I had done well and achieved something. If you thought TOY in 126 was super-cool, or are interested in how things work in the computer when you compile a program or run a command, definitely check this course out.

This is a very very well-done course.  Lectures, precepts, assignments, and exams are all put together with care. Professor Rexford was a particularly amazing lecturer, but I have heard that all the ones for 217 are good. Chris Moretti, the head preceptor this semester, was almost always at his computer, ready to answer questions on the Piazzza discussion board. He also was very good at explaining the material.

The assignments are challenging and time-consuming, especially in the second half of the semester as you move to assembly (which is horrible to debug). Take the course with friends; there are two partner assignments near the end and having study buddies for the midterm and final is really useful.

I did not take 226 before taking this course and never felt like I needed anything from that class that other people knew.  The two cover very different topics.

Start early on assignments (like every COS course). But actually. Especially the last one. I didn't, and I saw a lot of pretty sunrises before Dean's Date. Don't do that.  The Dean's Date assignment takes perhaps 4x as long as the one before it.  

Some advise to consider: Don't program in a room alone.  Obviously you must be very careful of the course policies when talking to friends and classmates, but a few people all staring at screens and complaining about hats/PuTTy makes a late night coding a lot more bearable.  Go to the COS lab TA's if you're confused on things. Go to the ACM's Code@Night to get food for those late night coding sessions and hear a junior or senior explain conceptually what in the world a double pointe

Take this course:
- if you're going for a COS major/certificate (duh)
- if you really, really like low-level programming and don't mind spending a lot of time debugging.

That's it, really. It's fantastically taught (especially if Chris Moretti is your preceptor) but even fantastic classes won't save you from a huge workload.

This course is probably too much work for anyone with a casual interest in systems programming to consider taking, but as a required course it is still very interesting and you will learn a ton of information. Go to precepts!
This is a good course for people who aren't necessarily interested in computer science specifically. It will help improve your programming style and problem-solving capabilities. And it's fun.

This is an amazing course. If you have any interest at all in low level programming or generally how computers work beyond COS 126, this course provides a fascinating look at the topic. However, while the projects aren't particularly difficult, they do require a large time commitment.
definitely take it if you're interested in cos and want to learn more about how everything works, and leave yourself plenty of time to do programs if you're not that fast as coding/debugging
dont take it unless you have to because it is really difficult and not useful unless you are a cos major or doing something cos-like.
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended), or ORF 201, or score of 5 on the AP Computer Science Exam..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: Liberation Ecology: Politics and Policy in the Creation of a Just, Green Economy
descrip: This course explores how the United States might help birth a just, green economy--one characterized by less poverty and less pollution, more opportunity and less inequity. This course examines the political challenges inherent in achieving the policy goals that would allow a just, green economy to flourish. It encourages students to develop their own critiques and to imagine new paths forward. Students will be encouraged to imagine, design and present their own strategies for a renewed ecological politics in the U.S.

title: The Economics of Uncertainty
reviews: Essential for anyone wishing to do grad studies.

Hard to say; I like the underlying material but I'm not sold on the course.  Also, Professor Morris said he wants to change the course significantly in the future; however, I think his changes will make the course worse, rather than better.
I think he's changing the entire nature of the course for next year. Less math and more discursive (read: easier). So I can't really advise.
If you are an econ major, take it for sure.
One of the tougher ECO classes math-wise.
One of the worst classes i've ever taken.
Take this class if you are interested in an analytical way of thinking about situations in life. You'll find it very interesting.
don't.
prereqs: ECO 310, ECO 202 or equivalent knowledge of probability theory..
descrip: This is an advanced microeconomic theory course. Using the concepts and mathematical techniques developed in ECO 310, the following topics are studied: [1] Theories of choice under uncertainty. [2] Risk aversion and applications to insurance and portfolio choice. [3] Equilibrium under uncertainty with applications to financial markets. [4] Asymmetric information: moral hazard and adverse selection. [5] Applications to the design of incentives, contracts, contests, and auctions. Concepts in game theory are developed as needed.

title: Experimental Physics Seminar
reviews: Take if you are self-motivated and have a good idea of what you want to do with your time there. It is basically a do-it-yourself class. You set out to do a physics experiment and you just ask the teachers for help getting the materials and setting up.
This class is a lot of fun especially if you take it with a friend and you're both interested in physics and excited to work together on an experiment.
Very fun. Not that much until the last week of school, when you have to finish your experiment. Don't leave everything to the last  minute. Only use a circuit if you have previous experience.
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent.
descrip: The seminar introduces students to techniques in modern experimental physics in a laboratory setting. In the first half of the course, students are introduced to analog electronics, data acquisition and control, vacuum technology, optics and lasers, cryogenics and other techniques. In the second half of the course, students working in small groups propose and perform an experiment.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two-200 level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Between Resistance and Collaboration: The Second World War in Europe
reviews: Awesome, fairly easy history course. Professor Gross is a rock star.
Do it.
Do the reading and be nice to Marcelline.
Good class, not too much work. Enjoyable subject matter.
Great course -- not too difficult, and incredibly interesting.

I would definitely recommend this to other students because even if they do not know much about history, it allows them an interesting view on World War II that they wouldn't have gotten in an ordinary AP history course.

I would recommend taking this class.  Professor Gross is such a sweet, lovable person who has interesting ideas about WWII (we read reading that mentioned him).  It is not too much work and I learned new things.
I would recommend this class to any history major or anyone interested in WWII
If you are interested in war and WWII in particular, take it, no doubt!
If you are willing to do the reading and are interested in the second world war, this is an excellent class to take.
It's a good course if you are interested in WWII history.

It's a great PDF class. The lectures are awful - Jan Gross constantly goes on tangents so I never knew what he was talking about. Besides that, it's not much work. The readings are interesting. The film reviews aren't so bad and there are tests instead of papers for the midterm and final.

Its a cool class, and not that hard especially if you read and go to lecture. If you pay attention and even do half the work, you'll be just fine. Plus, its legitimately really interesting. I would definitely take it, even if you're not in history. If you do all the reading, its a lot. But, you don't have to do it all if you want to do well.
Light workload interesting material=take

Most of the readings are very interesting. The lectures, less so, but it's a good course overall. Be advised that resistance material actually only covers about two weeks of the course, at most. And there is more Holocaust material involved than you might expect.
Not only was the material in this course fascinating, but it was presented in such a way that made us question our own stance in the twenty-first century as a result of all that we'd learned about.
Readings make it worth it.
Really interesting material, not too much work - take it.
Take it.
Take this no matter what your major (if you have an interest in the topic)
The films and many of the primary texts were interesting.  Grading seemed slightly arbitrary.
This is a good course whether you are in the history department or just generally interested.
Very good, I would recommend this to someone with a general interest in WWII.
Would not recommend unless you have a strong interest in East Europe during WW2.
it's ok
descrip: In the broader context of conflict between fascism, communism, and liberal democracy, we shall examine various patterns and methods of occupation, collaboration, and resistance during World War II in Western and Eastern Europe. The Holocaust of European Jewry and the technology of terror will be discussed. We will try to ascertain how elites and different social strata were affected by the impact of war and occupation. Students will be asked to read historical studies as well as personal narratives by eyewitnesses and participants.

title: Introduction to Differential Equations
reviews:
If you want to learn ordinary and partial differential equations in the span of one semester without going at a breakneck speed, this course is a great choice.

Professor E was a well-prepared, effective lecturer.  It was great that he wasn't afraid to go slower when the material was more difficult, and was very receptive to questions and comments.

There was, however, a discrepancy between some of the lectures and the homework, and the material covered in the additional "workshops."  Better notation and a more structured presenting of the material would have been much-appreciated.

The problem sets were usually too short and too difficult.  For most of them, it was impossible to do them without extra help from the professor.
It would have been better to have more problems, and have them be do-able without extra help.

The material is very fun to work with, and has tons of applications to physics and engineering.  We focused on a variety of these applications in class.

Take this course instead of MAE 305, you will not regret it as long as you have a moderate level of mathematical maturity. I took this course after having taken mostly engineering math classes and was shocked at the elegance and accessibility of the material. With brilliant and friendly profs Phil Trinh and Weinan E both teaching a small class, this was the best class I have taken at Princeton.

This is a really great class on differential equations. It's a mixture of theory and computation. Way more interesting than what I've heard is done in MAE 305, so take this class if you want a more stimulating, probably more challenging class. Again, really great.
descrip: An intro to differential equations. Both applications and fundamental theory will be discussed. Basic second order differential equations (including the wave, heat and Poisson equations); separation of variables and solution by Fourier series and Fourier integrals; boundary value problem and Green's function; variational methods; normal mode analysis and perturbation methods; nonlinear first order (Hamilton-Jacobi) equations and method of characteristics; reaction-diffusion equations; in addition, application of these equations and methods to e.g. finance and control. Necessary background material in ODEs will be covered.

title: Politics in Africa
reviews: A good course for people interested in African issues. There's something for everyone in this course whether its political economy, sociology, or current events.
Attend lectures as much as possible; focus on themes and general terms

Definitely take the course if you have an interest in Africa. You will learn a ton of relevant facts about the state of Africa covering a broad range of topics. Furthermore, the quality of instruction you receive on papers is extremely beneficial for you developing your writing skills.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in African politics. You will come away learning a lot, but not be overwhelmed by the amount of work.
Do the reading and write as much notes as possible : it will be very helpful later in the course.
I would recommend taking this course!! I learned so much. Attend class everyday would be my recommendation.
If you are at all interested in African studies or are curious about development in Africa, you should take this class.

If you are generally interested in Africa, this is a great broad look at its development and challenges with a fantastic professor. Just be prepared for a lot of reading. If you are new to the field, do not be intimidated by all the political science, econ, and woody woo majors; Professor Widner makes the material very accessible to politics novices.
If you have an interest in Africa and politics this is a great course to take.
If you want to take a good politics class at Princeton, this is definitely one of them. Challenging and interesting readings, a good lecturer, and a fair final exam.
If you're interested in Africa, this is a great course!  I probably wouldn't recommend this as an easy SA, but it has definitely been one of my favorite courses at Princeton!
It was an OK class.

Split up the readings with other students - there's a ton of material to cover and all of it is important and interesting. Ask Professor Widner or any of the preceptors if you need help. They're very approachable.
Take it!
Take this class if you are well-versed in Africa or in politics.

Take this class if you want a general overview of some of the political challenges facing Africa. Be prepared to read a lot (I think it is worthwhile to do the reading, go to lecture, and you will come out of it with some solid foundation in political science thinking and African themes. It is rather broad, be warned.

Take this course if you have any interest in Africa or development in general.  However, I wouldn't suggest taking this as a freshmen - as a junior in the politics department I felt like I did well in this course only because I had some background in politics and economics.
The course material is so interesting, and the professor delivers it really well. However, be prepared for all the reading and the intense papers (3).
The politics often gets in the way of the the Africa, but if you're interested in Africa, it's one of your better options.
There are other classes on Africa that are more interesting, like LIeberman's class, but Widner is an expert in the field and you still get a lot out of the class.
This is really interesting and a lot of fun.
Those interested in the topic should certainly take it. It is the only real African politics course that Princeton offers
prereqs: No previous knowledge of Africa is required..
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the study of African politics. The lectures and readings briefly review the social and historical context of contemporary political life. They then profile the changes of the early post-Independence period, the authoritarian turn of the 1970s and 80s, the second liberation of the 1990s, and problems of war, state-building, and development. Although the lectures trace a narrative, each also introduces a major analytical debate and an important policy problem. Broadly comparative with some special attention to selected countries.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: Brilliant course, particularly due to the lecturer
prereqs: FIN 501, FIN 522.
descrip: Course examines the concept of risk and its mitigation, and how the ideas can be applied in the practice of risk management for financial and non-financial companies. The basic toolkit draws on economics, probability theory and statistics, and they are integrated with more advanced concepts drawn from portfolio choice, derivative securities and dynamic hedging. Overall aim of the course is to demonstrate how the main concepts have practical applications.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Easiest course to get an A  in at Princeton, except for maybe the other Billington course.
I highly recommend this course, to everyone, engineers and non-engineers. It will enlighten you and give you a completely new preception of structures.
I would strongly recommend this class, although I believe CEE students who have taken CEE205 or 312 have an advantage in terms of calculations and problem sets.
It's an easy course and worthwhile if you're interested in architecture and/or civil engineering.
It's definitely an easy ST if you are an AB because the math is basic high school math.
Pay attention during lecture and you will remember the information better than you think.
Take this course no matter who you are, it's well worth it.
Take this course! If you're an engineer it will change the way you see your field. If you're not it will change the ways to look at our built world. A must!

Take this course! Not because it's "an easy A", but just because it's very interesting. Even if you never thought you would be interested in buildings, just try it. It is a great way to get an ST out of the way and learn something you might never have the chance to learn again.
Take this.
The A-section of this course is interesting, but it is not a "gut" class!

This class is okay. It was the first civil engineering class that I took here so it was something new and different for me, but the subject material was relatively interesting. The lectures can be boring, but I liked the assignments.
This class is pretty easy. Lectures are sort of interesting and the weekly work is minimal.
This is a good class to take if you want to learn more about famous structures. It has a reasonable amount of work though.
Very easy course if you attend lecture, which are actually interesting.  Readings are not necessary at all.  Problem sets and exams were very easy.
for a PDF this class requires a lot of 'busy' work. overall though, very interesting.
great!
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through critical analysis of major works students are introduced to the methods of evaluating structures as an art form. Students study the works and ideas of individual structural artists through their elementary calculations, their builder's mentality and their aesthetic imagination. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities.

title: Philosophical Logic
reviews: Be courageous.
Be prepared to do proofs and think mathematically. Very good course if this is what you want.

I strongly recommend taking the course, either towards a satisfaction of a logic requirement or for a general interest in the subject. More specifically, for those with less (or no) background in logic, I would suggest not to despair at the outset, and to seek the professor's help at first (which is fortunately always available). One gets comfortable with the material fairly quickly, at which point a genuine interest in the subject matter may well develop.
It is a great class to take if you have any mathematical background at all!
Unless you like logic for its own sake or need the credit, you will find much of it too difficult and tedious to be worth your while.
prereqs: PHI 201 or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to non-classical formal logics: temporal, modal, conditional, relevantistic, intuitionistic.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Theories of Psychotherapy
reviews: I would recommend this class, especially for people who are interested in clinical psychology.

Take this class if you are interested in clinical psychology, especially if you want to go to graduate school. Professor Comer is a fair grader but the paper assignments are difficult to complete in within the page limit. Overall, a worthwhile class for people interested in the applications of psychology.

This class was very interesting and not particularly hard. Don't miss any classes, pay attention and you'll do fine. For a 300 level class it isn't too much work, probably an hour or two a week for the reading.
This course really give you a solid understanding of psychotherapies, I strongly recommend it if you are interested in psychotherapy.
prereqs: PSY 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course will examine the different theories, models, techniques, and settings that comprise the practice of clinical psychology in general, and psychotherapy in particular.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
reviews: A good class on an interesting topic that will definitely increase your understanding and appreciation of modern art.
Don't take if you don't know what collage or abstraction is.
Don't take it unless you like to look at art philosophically.
I did not enjoy this course.
Interesting class and accessible to non-concentrators.

Its worth taking if you are at all interested in contemporary art. I learnt a lot from it, and got a clear idea of what areas I am interested in studying in greater depth. Doing all the readings and going to the lectures is really important.
PDF it.
Sit in the front row so you can hear Professor Lang

TAKE THIS CLASS.  This was one of the most interesting courses I took in Princeton, and while the memorization of the flash cards got tedious, the readings were always interesting and precepts were always engaging.
Take it with a different professor
This course is very interesting, but if you haven't taken another art history course before then it can be a bit overwhelming, especially at the beginning.
This is worthwhile for anyone to take if they are interested in art at all, even just recreationally. It will, at the very least, help you understand museums better and make them more enjoyable.
take it!
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of postwar art--abstract-expressionist, pop, minimalist, conceptual, process and performance, site-specific, etc. Special attention to crucial figures (e.g., Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Robert Smithson) and problems (e.g., "the neo-avant-garde", popular culture, feminist theory, political controversies, "postmodernism").

title: Problems in Near Eastern Jewish History
prereqs: Knowledge of Arabic required. Students lacking Arabic should speak with Instructor for possible exception..
descrip: The topic this year is the Dhimma, the status of Jews and other non-Muslims in medieval Islam. In addition to reading secondary literature, we will read and discuss primary sources in class.

title: The Russian Short Story
prereqs: SLA 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course traces the development of the Russian short story from the 1830's to the present. The entire course is conducted in Russian and special emphasis is placed on active use of the language.

title: From the Bronze Age to the Plastic Age: A Histor of Chemistry through Experimental Discovery
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Computing and Imaging in Architecture
reviews: Fundamental to my understanding of architecture, and extremely worthwhile. Might not be for some people, but it was extremely engaging, interesting, and pratical.  Opens up a new way of seeing the rest of your course work.  However, the school needs to set up a render farm.
Miles is a great instrcutor and very helpful.
descrip: This course on digital media infrastructure will explore breaking technologies of fabrication, modeling and design based on production pipelines pioneered by the film and gaming industries--pipelines we will author in CATIA, McNeel's Rhino/Grasshopper, and Bentley's Generative Components. A series of formal experiments will be carried out each culminating in the fabrication of rapid prototypes using the CNC mill and the InVision 3D printer, explicitly challenging conventional modes of practice and seeking insight into new forms of organization, techniques and operative procedures.

title: Modern Classical Dynamics
reviews: A must take for undergraduates interested in theoretical physics.
A tough course, but definitely covers many nice, modern topics.
Every physics major should take this to follow from PHY 205/207.
Take at least one course with Polyakov.
Take it if you want to learn a lot and have fun in a laid back course.
descrip: Discussion of the most beautiful and important parts of classical dynamics: variational principles, ergodicity and chaos, fluid dynamics of vortices, shock waves and solitons as well as the theories of developed turbulence.

title: South African History, 1497 to the Present
reviews: Do the readings and go to lecture

Keep up with the readings. They're boring, but you'll have to do them at some point. Also, don't get hung up on the details of the readings. They focus on insignificant figures and the general idea is all you need.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject matter. It will not be worthwhile if you do not want to really learn about Southern Africa.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available to History concentrators.
descrip: South Africa's past and present were and are closely intertwined with those of its neighbors, including Angola, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique. South Africa's industrial expansion, for example, relied on thousands of migrant laborers from its neighbors. The course will highlight a variety of themes, including the rise and fall of African empires (Great Zimbabwe and the Zulu kingdom), the effects of European colonization and the repression caused by the Apartheid system. The focus will also be on the dramatic 1994 transition of South Africa to a multiracial democratic society led by Nelson Mandela.

title: International Trade Policy
descrip: Evaluates arguments for and against protection and adjustment assistance and considers topics chosen from the following: non-tariff barriers, dumping, embargo threats and trade warfare, and the political economy of trade policy formation. Special attention is given to trade problems of the less-developed countries, including North-South trade relations and commodity price stabilization. Prerequisite: 511c.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
reviews: A must for micro theory.
Everything you need to know about information economics in strategic and competitive environment.

Good graduate background on finance and information economics theory.

Take Scheinkman's half only if you must for the departmental requirement.

Morris is excellent worth taking.
Great course, in particular the part on information economics.

I feel the course is an excellent continuation to the first semester of microeconomics. I would recommend students in the course read the additional readings provided to help gain better intuition for the subject matter covered in the course.
If you want to do any kind of graduate work in economics, politics or public policy you should probably take this course.
If you want to do economics you should take it. Both professors have great lectures and the material is essential for economics.
Not so hard and definitely worth the effort if you are serious about graduate school in economics.
Only take if you plan to go to grad school in econ.
This course is fundamental to theoretical economics, and introduces very important topics.
descrip: This course is the second term of a 2 term sequence in Microeconomics.

title: Seminar in Jazz Composition
reviews: Don't get on Tony's bad side. Try to do the journals week by week as it is a pain to do them at the end.
If you are interested in developing your voice as a jazz composer this class is worth taking. It is also a good class to take to fulfill requirements for the jazz studies certificate.
If you want to begin to think more seriously about jazz composition, this course is worth considering as a starting point.

If you want to do a lot of composing, take this class, but be ready to tolerate Professor Branker's antics - he is not an easy person to work with. If however you feel that you have enough self discipline to compose on your own, there is really no reason to take this course.
Take the course, but beware; the work can sneak up on you.
prereqs: Music 311 or Music 312 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An advanced course in jazz composition that emphasizes the process of creation. Students will be expected to develop original works utilizing a variety of compositional approaches, including: creating in collaboration, improvisation as a compositional strategy, as well as, non-musical techniques that will be translated into some form of musical representation.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Conditional Cash Transfer Programs
descrip: This course will cover the following: 1) Conditional cash transfers (CCTs): conceptual issues and basic facts; 2) an introduction to impact evaluation; 3) the impact of CCTs on poverty, inequality, labor force participation, and within-household decision-making; 4) the impact of CCTs on health, nutrition, and schooling outcomes; 5) opening the black box of CCTs: design issues; and 6) the role of CCTs in a social protection system.

title: Modernity and China (I): Power and Life
descrip: Chinese modernity is addressed using different approaches and issues, while focusing on one set of issues each time. This term, course examines how a certain way of governing became the threshold of modernity. The inspiration and limits of the framework of governmentality and biopower, in particular, are seen through cases such as famine prevention, famine relief and the failure to do so, and through the interaction of different modes of power in Maoist socialism and post-Mao China.

title: The Making of Modern France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from 1789 to the Present
reviews: Do the readings and participate in class

I would certainly recommend it. A girl working at labyrinth strongly recommended it to me, and said it was the best class she'd ever taken. I don't agree with that (not to be insulting) but I certainly liked the class very much and will miss it next semester.
Take it! You'll actually learn a lot.
Take this course if you are comfortable participating in class.
take this course or other courses with Professeur Blix!
prereqs: Prerequisites: 107, 108, or equivalent. 207 recommended as a co-requisite..
descrip: This course examines the major historical and cultural developments that have shaped France since the Revolution. By studying a series of classic texts (from Balzac to Beckett), important films, paintings, and essays, we will undertake an interdisciplinary tour through two centuries of French cultural history, addressing issues such as nationhood, colonialism, democracy, and consumer society. The focus will be on the relations between artistic renovation, social change, and historical events.

title: Walmart Nation
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Computational Neuroscience and Computing Networks
descrip: An Introduction to the biophysics of nerve cells and synapses, the mathematical description of neural networks, and how neurons represent information. Course will survey computational modeling and data analysis methods for neuroscience and will parallel some topics from 549, but from a computational perspective. Topics will include representation of visual informaion, spatial navigation, short-term memory, and decision-making. Two 90 minute lectures, one laboratory. Lectures in common with MOL 437. Graduate students will carry out and write up an in-depth semester-long project. Prerequisite: 410, or elementary knowledge of linear algebra, di

title: The Anthropology of Development
descrip: Why do development projects fail? This course examines why well-meaning development experts get it wrong. It looks closely at what anthropologists mean by culture and why most development experts fail to attend to the cultural forces that hold communities together. By examining development projects from South Asia to the United States, students learn the relevance of exchange relations, genealogies, power, religion, and indigenous law. This semester the class will be designing a marketplace.

title: Advanced Mineralogy
descrip: A survey of the structure and crystal chemistry of major rock-forming minerals. Topics include: crystallography, physical properties of minerals, mineral thermodynamics, lattice dynamics, phase transformations, elasticity and defects.

title: Polymers
reviews: Do it.
If you are interested in polymers, and either have not taken any polymer courses or are looking for a review of basic principles, this course is a good choice.
If you have any interest in polymers at all, by all means take this course.
If you're terrible at organic chemistry (like me), avoid this course. If you love chemistry, embrace it.
It's a great course about one of the more important topics in chemical engineering. There is a lot of important knowledge to be gained in this class.

Like the rest of the courses in the CBE Department, Polymers was a well taught yet difficult course.  I would recommend this class to all CBE majors, as it fulfills departmental elective requirements.
Probably one of your strongest choices for a CBE higher level class. The professor is extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and effective, and the information is often very interesting.

Pros: It counts as a chemistry, material science and upper CBE class. It has no finals.
Cons: The problem sets take a lot of time. The material is interesting, but hard. There are easier classes out there.
Take this course. Not too difficult but material is interesting and applicable to a lot of different fields.
prereqs: Prerequisite courses CHM 301 or 303 and MAT 104 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Broad introduction to polymer science and technology, including polymer chemistry (major synthetic routes to polymers), polymer physics (solution and melt behavior, solid-state morphology and properties), and polymer engineering (overview of reaction engineering and melt processing methods).

title: Biophysical Chemistry II
prereqs: Some background in chemistry and familiarity with basic biochemical terms is assumed, but there are no specific prerequisites..
descrip: Broad introduction to major contemporary techniques used to study structures, functions, and interactions of biological macromolecules, including quantitative theory of molecular interactions. Aims to convey to students with diverse backgrounds and interests the utility of various experimental methods for solving molecular problems. Emphasis is on applications, practical aspects, and experimental design, and on strengths and limitations of individual methods and complementarities among them.

title: Topics in Financial Economics
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical and empirical methods and results in selected research topics in financial economics. Topics vary from year to year reflecting current developments and the instructor's interests.

title: Topics in Ecology - Biodiversity: Origins and Maintenance
descrip: The causes of global patterns in plant and animal diversity remain a topic of debate just as when Wallace and Darwin defined the issue. This seminar seeks a new synthetic understanding of the topic via critical reviews of major papers on (1) macro-evolutionary patterns of species formation and loss as documented in the paleontological literature, (2) the causes and dynamics of speciation, (3) geographic (including latitudinal) patterns in species diversity, (4) allometric scaling of body size, abundance, productivity, etc. and diversity, and (5) analytical theories of interspecific interactions and species persistence/coexistence.

title: Chemical Kinetics
reviews: Definitely a course to take for the physical chem requirement
I highly recommend it. The literature discussions are extremely useful for those students who aim to understand scientific literature and publish on their own.

It is a fun course and not too difficult. Don't skip the readings though, no matter how tempting. Easily 50% of the subject matter was taught through the reading and discussing of journal papers. If you skip them, you'll miss out on a lot of knowledge.
It is a good course for a student majoring in physical chemistry.
Take the course
The course is an excellent way to brush up on kinetics and their application to a wide variety of chemistry fields.
This class has way more reading than expected, but it was pretty interesting, the homeworks helped further my understanding of the subject material, and it was overall not so bad!

This class is very accessible for undergraduates with a basic understanding of quantum mechanics and thermodynamics and makes a great first grad course for someone interested in physical chemistry theory. Literature discussions also teach you how to read papers and perform experiments like few other classes.
This course is much less work than most other p-chem courses I have taken, but is also very informative. A decent trade-off, I think.
This is a course that requires a decent amount of time, but, if you keep up with the work, you get a lot out of it and his grading is fair.

While there were a few aspects of this course that could have been improved, overall this was a good class that enhanced my knowledge of the subject area.  Reading the textbook after lecture was especially helpful in learning the material, as well as for figuring out the problem sets.
get the textbook by Steinfeld, Francisco and Hase
descrip: A survey of chemical kinetics. Kinetic measurements and experimental methods, reaction rate theory, molecular dynamics experiment and theory will be discussed. Both gas phase and condensed phase kinetic studies will be considered.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: A good background course that will enhance knowledge and appreciation of music... but don't be fooled by the 106 label, as it's quite a large time commitment both inside (5 hours a week) and outside of class.
A good course, but be diligent with the assignments and studying the theoretical ideas.  Unless you've studied the material before.
Better than many people give it credit for.
Don't take it unless you have a music background (in theory), otherwise you will be confused and frustrated.
Don't take it unless you have to for the certificate program.

Even if you are not interested in the certificate, I would recommend this class if you love music and would like to understand it more. If you liked MUS 105, definitely continue with 106, but be aware that 106 is more work than 105, since it builds upon the more basic concepts of the fall course.
Excellent overview of theory.
Following MUS 105, this course really completes a nice overview of music history and theory - I feel like I can comfortably pursue the other courses now int he department.
I strongly recommend it if you are seriously considering music or if music is one of your passions and you don't mind having to compose for homework assignments
