I would not recommend this course to anyone who did not take music theory in high school. You definitely need a lot of prior knowledge to take this course. Knowing how to play the piano is also extremely helpful but not entirely necessary as long as you know how to use music composition programs.
If you are interested in music and can read it, take this course.
If you are seriously interested in music, take it.
If you have any interest in music, especially music theory, take this course.  The information you learn in this course is so valuable and all-encompassing, and I enjoyed every lecture I went to.
If you like music theory and are a well versed classical musician, this course might appeal to you if not even be easy for you.

If you love music and are interested in unwrapping the technical aspects of what makes a piece or a technique "work," and if you are intrigued by taking an often quantitative approach to this work, then at least shop the course. It's a lot of work--2 lectures, 2 precepts, 1 ear training lab/week, as well as homework assignments that can often take several hours--but you will learn more theory than you thought possible, and the knowledge you acquire will help your playing as well. Having a background in piano helps IMMENSELY in completing composition assignments, and often deepens understanding of material presented in lecture. I can't stress this enough--if you have the opportunity, take piano lessons before starting the course!

If you want to understand Western music, take this class. You won't get all of the details, but you will better understand the narrative of how we got to where we are today. If you are both creative and strong at musical analysis, you will do well.
It takes a lot of time, but you'll learn a lot also. I've already recommended to on of my friends.
MUS 105/106 is rigorous and will take up lots of your time, but I think it is worth it.

MUS 106 is a fairly challenging course, so I would advise a student to take a bit of caution. If the student has just finished 105 and found it to be relatively easy (or easier), then he or she ought to take 106. But if 105 is a challenge, I think they should reconsider.
Only take it if it's a requirement, don't take it if you just want a fun music course
Start composition assignments as soon as you get them - they take a while. And don't get behind, or good luck catching up. Also, try to do some score analysis on your own time - I wish I had.
Start problem sets early -- compositions do take some time (for most people). Go to lectures.
Take it if you want in depth music theory training.
Take it, you won't regret it.
Take this class if you're interested in music theory and/or if you want to do the performance certificate. It's worth it.
Take this course! Not only will it give you a solid foundation in music theory, but it will forever change the way you think about music theory/history itself!
The course is a lot of work, but worth it if you're generally interested in composing.

This class was pretty good. Go to the lectures, because they're the best part. I would also suggest doing the assignments with a time limit, all of the time, so you can practice what you'll be tested on (speed-composition and speed-analysis). You'll also get them done faster, which is a plus. If you're not interested in music, don't take the class, but if you are, then this is a good way to get started.
Tread carefully.  For music majors/certificate students only.
WTF ANNE HEGE

While a fascinating lecturer, Prof. Tymoczko is an extremely tough grader and a difficult personality, and he teaches his own (often far-fetched) theories rather than those of more respected music theorists. Definitely steer clear of his precept--and if music isn't your #1 priority here at Princeton, steer clear of this course.

You have to be willing to put in the work in learning the more recent romantic and 20th century styles, but the music is interesting and the assignments not too hard--the exams are the only things to worry about, but overall it is a good music theory course.
unless you need it, dont take it.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of the instructor. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-level theory work, and should be taken by any freshman considering majoring in music, entering the Certificate Program, or taking upper-level music courses..
descrip: A continuation of MUS 105, with an emphasis on the harmonic and formal principals of Western classical music. We will focus on modulation, chromatic harmony, and form, continuing to study and compose music in classical and other styles.

title: Secularism in Muslim Central Asia and the Middle East
descrip: The rise of revivalist and radical religious movements in Muslim societies understandably has spurred interest in the politics of Islam. Yet Muslims have also had extensive experience with secular politics. Central Asia and the Middle East in the 20th century saw secularization projects that fundamentally transformed Muslim societies and left legacies that will persist long into the 21st century. Drawing on the disciplines of history, religious studies, anthropology, and political science, this course explores how Central Asian and Middle Eastern Muslims embraced and rejected, assimilated and resisted, constructed and negotiated secularism.

title: Infection: Biology, Burden, Policy
reviews: Ask questions in lectures and precepts.
Definitely take it! Be prepared to learn a lot/work hard.
Definitely take! Love Profs. Mahmoud and Shenk! They are great and it is an incredible experience to take a class with them.
Find out who the preceptors are in advance.
Go to class!  You'll learn a lot!  Also ask for help with your presentation.  The preceptors and professors are full of information and really helpful!
I would recommend a seminar instead if you want the policy side, and a class like virology, immunology, or the new microbiology class if you want the biology side.
If the course doesn't have precepts, definitely take it.

If you're interested in infectious diseases, this a good overview course. The workload is not terrible, but be prepared to put in many hours to prepare your group presentation. The professors are nationally recognized scholars in the field of infectious disease so, if for no other reason, take the course for the chance to interact with them. They also have connections with other well-known infectious disease scholars and often bring them into class to speak.  The entire first section of the course is lecture, while the second half is all student presentations -- which is a nice variety, though the student presentations can vary depending on the quality of their presentations in a way that the professor presentations did not (because they were always excellent). The class is accessible to non-science majors, for sure, but be prepared for a few intense science students who will ask some very detailed questions that you might not fully understand.
Interesting and easy.
Not much work, interesting subject material (especially when the professors lecture in the first half of the course).
Take it if you are willing to interpret material independently and put up with the TAs not being very knowledgable about the field.
Take this class.

The class content was very interesting and I enjoyed learning about infectious diseases.  I feel like this class is especially useful for GHP students.  However, the grading and precepts brought down the class.
prereqs: MOL101, MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine fundamental determinants of human microbe interaction at the biological and ecological aspects. The focus will be on major global infectious diseases, their burden of illness, and policy challenges for adequate prevention and control. Each infectious agent will be discussed in terms of its mechanism of pathogenesis, disease progression, epidemiology, as well as strategies for its control. Specific emphasis will be placed on the public health aspects of each disease.

title: Topics in International Relations - US Diplomacy & the Other Middle East
descrip: Seminar examines the political, social, economic and strategic dynamics within "The Other Middle East": the members of the Gulf Cooperation Council and their primary neighbors, Iraq, Iran, Yemen and India. Course explores the context and complexities of the regional actors, how recent US policies have affected these states and the impact of the Iraq War on the region and on US influence and options. Topics include the role of religion, the growth of knowledge-based globalized economies, public diplomacy; the history of Saudi-Iranian relations, and the rise of regional actors, particularly Iran and India.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: I would not necessarily recommend this class unless you have to take it for teacher prep. the discussions are completely student led and sometimes you get bored with hearing the same students give their opinions.
Participate in lecture
Really great for those in the Teacher Prep program as it looks at education from a psychological perspective.
This was the worst, most boring, most poorly structured/taught class I've encountered at Princeton. Even if you love education, you won't like this course. It's awful.
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Others may enroll with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: The Great Russian Novel and Beyond: Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Others
reviews: Be sure you have a lot of time to read.
Definitely take it, but keep up with all the readings!!
I'd recommend to anyone interested in Russian literature.
If you want to read some of the best books ever written, this is a class to take.
If you're looking for an LA or just want to read fabulous books or have even a passing interest, this was a really good course. Professor Chances gives great lectures and the books are amazing.
Maybe read the lengthy novels beforehand (Ana Karenina, Brothers Karamazov)
One of my favorite classes at Princeton - do the readings! They're worth it!
Take it. It's a great class. If you're curious about Russian Literature, it's a great excuse to read a lot of books.

Take this class if you want to engage with interesting material, have an amazing professor, and become a more intellectual person. If you don't like to read, then this probably isn't a good class for you, though...
This is a very interesting course that will definitely extend your general knowledge, but be advised that the readings are very long.
prereqs: Curiosity. Knowledge of Russian not required. Open to first-year students..
descrip: An examination of significant trends in Russian literature from the 2nd half of the 19th century to the Russian Revolution and a bit beyond. The course focuses on many masterpieces of 19th & 20th-century Russian literature. The works (mostly novels) are considered from a stylistic point of view and in the context of Russian historical and cultural developments. The course also focuses on questions of values and on the eternal "big questions" of life that are raised in the literature. Authors read include Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bely, Nabokov, and Kharms.

title: Elementary Turkish II
reviews: Definitely take it. Turkey's rising in the world, Professor Gilson is an amazing instructor, and the language is linguistically fascinating.  What's there not to like?

Turkish has always been an important language for our country, and it is only becoming more important. It's applicability is wider than Arabic, and it takes less time to learn than Chinese. Plus, it's a pretty cool culture. What else could you want out of a language?
You will learn a lot, but be prepared to spend a lot of time doing homework.  This class is a huge commitment.
prereqs: TUR 101 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Familiarity with all grammatical aspects of Modern Turkish. Reading text of moderate difficulty; developing communicative skills: ability to comprehend and engage in daily discourse; ability to write short compositions.

title: Cognitive Psychology
reviews: Be prepared to read some boring concepts as well as some interesting ones.

Content-light, memorization-based course. All exams and quizzes are multiple choice. Both read the book and attend class. Doing both, you'll spend maybe 3.5 hours a week total on the course (3 of those are lecture and precept). Almost too easy (the curve will prove to be quite harsh).
I'd say take it if you have an interest in the subject. It's a good 5th class since the workload is pretty light, and can be very interesting and fun if you want it to be. And it's good for an EC!
If you miss lecture, you can't just make it up by reading because he mentions specific experiments in the lecture and doesn't provide notes.
If you take this class, try to get Adam Moore as your preceptor.
Osherson can be a little dry, but the material is very interesting. Quizzes and tests are pretty easy.
P/D/F it until Osherson decides to release his lecture slides.
PSY 255 is a great course that I would definitely recommend.
Take if you want an easy class. You have to do the readings, but they aren't that bad. Material is pretty boring, however.
Take the course!! It's very interesting and not extremely challenging. Readings are short and somewhat easy. And evaluations are multiple choice and fair.
Take this class as a PDF for an EC, but not much else
Take this if you know you're already interested in Psychology. You learn a lot of cool things, but it might not be the best Psych class to take if you're trying to see what the discipline is like.

The course was sort of a joke. If you're serious about getting good grades, you will be frustrated by the constant multiple-choice and the very random, specific questions that are asked. If you're not super into psychology, you'll learn some stuff, though.

The lectures are 10am which some people find very early- so actually sleep the night before because the material covered in lecture is extremely interesting AND included on every weekly quiz plus the midterm and final. Read a chapter a week- it's easy to stay on top of.

This course had a very manageable workload - there were no weekly written assignments, just precept quizzes with 6-8 multiple choice questions.  Other than that, it's only the hour-long midterm and ~2 hour final.

This is a really interesting, well-taught class.  The book is well-written; read it.  There are weekly precept quizzes, which are usually ~10 multiple choice questions.  Review your lecture notes, do the reading on time, and do the online lab and you will be fine.  Be aware that all testing was multiple choice.
This was a great class, not any busy work, just learn the material and do the readings. Lectures are interesting and professor Osherson is great.
Very chill class. As long as you do the reading assignments and attend lectures you should have no problems.
You definitely need to go to lecture since Prof. Osherson often mentions specific studies that may show up on a test (also, he doesn't post lecture slides).
descrip: The course will survey the major themes and experimental findings of Cognitive Psychology. We will address the question of how scientists probe the nature and underlying structure of human thought. Topics covered include attention, perception, imagery, memory, language, thinking, decision making, and cognitive neuroscience.

title: Readings in Modern Korean History
descrip: A survey of major issues and debates in the historiography of modern Korea. Course introduces the major English language works on modern Korean history. Topics include: "opening" of Korea, Japanese colonialism, space of liberation, the Korean war, issues of gender and labor, and U.S.-Korean relations. No previous knowledge of Korean history or language is necessary, but basic knowledge of twentieth century East Asian history is expected.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Society, Politics, and Culture in Germany, 1890-1945
reviews: Definitely take it-- it was always interesting and fun (I swear).  I feel like my German really improved, and I learned a lot of interesting things about the "infamous" time, despite feeling like it had already been beaten in over the years.... As far as advice goes-- do the readings because they're great and it helps class discussion a ton if everyone spent a little time preparing some thoughts.
I would definitely take this class.  The professor is great and very helpful if you ever need help.  You will learn a lot from a variety of sources about German history.
If you love German this course will be great and you'll enjoy it. If you are trying to juggle courses that don't permit you to devote the time necessary to learning a language, you might reconsider.
Start papers early, so that you have time to thoroughly proofread them.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: This course offers discussions of historical documents and literary texts from the first half of the twentieth century: essays and speeches, poems and prose, films and sound recordings. These are examined within a broad historical context, encompassing the Kaiserreich and the First World War, the Weimar Republic and the rise of National Socialism. Through a series of assignments based on this material, we will work on written and spoken German, with particular emphasis on questions of style, precision, and nuance.

title: Public Finance
reviews: A good low-stress course with little surprises.
A very good introductory course for the topic.

About as difficult as ECO 100, but with a focus on public finance topics such as taxation, insurance and expenditures on public goods. There was nothing particularly difficult about the class, although this might make the curve tough if you're trying to get an A. A great option if you're looking to PDF a moderately interesting ECO class, since only about half the homeworks are required and the exams are easy enough that you can get close to an A with 2-3 hours of studying tops.
Great, easy course; attend lectures and read the textbook!
I would probably tell them not to take it.  There are much more interesting economics classes at Princeton.

If Andrew Shephard is teaching this course, stay far away.  He's the worst professor I've ever had in the ECO department, hands down.  He mumbled his way during lectures, and often rushed through them without focusing on the important points.  He also was extremely afraid of students, as evidenced by his awkwardness during office hours and his unwillingness to direct his gaze towards them during lectures.  The problem sets were unreasonably long and difficult - I took ECO311 and ECO363 in conjunction with this class this semester, both of which are recognized as being much difficult classes than ECO341, and yet I spent three times as much time working on 1 ECO341 problem set per week than I did working on both of those classes *combined.*  The material isn't that interesting either, unless *sorta* learning about Medicare and Social Security from a highly theoretical yet unrealistic point of view is the type of things that floats your boat.  Future versions of this class might be better, depending on the professor.  However, if you're looking to be intellectually stimulated, I strongly recommend looking elsewhere.
It's an interesting course especially if you're interested in policy. Even if you're not an Economic major, it's a do-able course.
It's okay.
Not the most interesting course
Take advantage of the clear lecture slides and the very informal and engaged professor.
Take it if it's with Andrew Shephard (or if Rosen comes back).
Take the class if you want to learn more about the public finance system in the United States. Might not be applicable in other countries.

The class was not that difficult and is good for the finance program and for understanding the reasons for government involvement. I'm sure the class will get better as the professor gets more experienced.
This course should be named public economics, not public finance.  Be sure you read the course description before signing up-FINANCE topics like municipal bonds will not be covered.
Very standard course. Make sure to go to lectures and precepts to get the problem set questions down.
Yea, not bad. Pretty interesting.
do NOT take this class unless you absolutely have to.
prereqs: ECO 100. A working knowledge of calculus is required for this course..
descrip: The main goal is to learn to think analytically about government policy problems.

title: Backstage Dramas: Survival Strategies in the American Theater
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy
reviews: A good, easy way to get the EC requirement out of the way.
A very good course to take either for distribution requirement or general interest.
Awesome
Consider taking it if you have an interest in Philosophy. It's interesting.

Definitely take this course, regardless of your major; PDF it if you're stretched for time and need to blow off or delay a paper or two to manage time. Very useful to see the early days of logical discourse, and how some seemingly contemporary issues and problems have really been a part of society since antiquity.

Do not take this class if you're just looking to clear an EC, unless you are extremely interested in ancient greek philosophy. Readings are dense and take time to make sense of on your own, and even after you do, the ideas covered are nothing revolutionary. Find another EC to take.
Don't take it, you won't learn anything in enough detail to care about it or think critically.
Don't take this course unless you really like exploring very technical facets of Greek philosophy.
Give it a shot, why not!
Go to precept, it is very helpful. If you have a general interest in philosophy but don't plan in majoring in it, then I recommend this class.
Good EC. Very good readings. make sure you get a good preceptor, like Tom Miller or Richard Hutchins. Definitely avoid Mor Segev.
Great EC class
Great introduction and easy to follow
Great introduction to philosophy, and a fun way to consistently work on your writing in an interesting way.

Great way to fulfill an EC requirement. Also a great course to take if you have any interest at all in philosophy. Workload is minimal and I found what work there was (readings and short papers) to be engaging and conducive to the overall course.
Harsh grades, especially if Tom is preceptor. But, the course is worth taking.

I am a science major and I took this course primarily as a distribution requirement, but I found the material interesting and the workload minimal. Take it if the idea of ancient philosophy interests you remotely.

I highly recommend this course. The workload was fairly light. Prof. Lorenz gives very clear lectures, and he likes to repeat the important points. Writing the essays basically involved being able to say back the important points that were covered in lecture. The material was pretty interesting - those old Greek guys back in the B.C. times had some really funny ideas. Even as an engineer who is pretty distrustful of humanities, I felt like everything made sense and stood up to rigor. Prof. Lorenz was very knowledgable and can present material and answer questions in an easily understood manner.
I would definitely recommend taking this class.  It isn't too much work and the material is very interesting if you're willing to open up your mind a little.
I would highly recommend this class.
I would highly recommend this course to get a start on classics and get a feel for what a lot of it is about.
I would recommend doing the readings and going to lecture, because then the material is much easier to understand.

I would say if they have a desire to try it, they definitely should. However, I would look for a preceptor other than the one that I had. Most of my friends in this class had different ones and enjoyed the material more. Also, they did better and put in MUCH less time than I did. It is also a great PDF if one wants to learn philosophical concepts without worrying about the subjectivity of grades.

I would strongly recommend this course, for a distribution requirement, or just out of general interest. Ancient philosophy could easily become a dense and seemingly-irrelevant topic, but Professor Lorenz taught even the most archaic philosophers in a clear and easily accessible way.
If you are interested in Plato's and Aristotle's written works, the lectures and precepts in this course are extremely valuable as a first introduction to the material.
If you are interested in ancient philosophy, definitely take this course. It can be a bit slow and boring at times and the essays are challenging.

If you don't have any background in philosophy, this is a great place to start. Prof Lorenz is meticulous in his explanations and offers a lot of helpful insight into Plato, Aristotle, Heraclitus, the Atomists, and others. A useful course for humanists and scientists alike.
It's a pretty easy class.
Its a course where you can learn stuff in general, provided you do your readings.
Lots of written work, so be prepared fo rthat. If you have taken philosophy courses in the past, be prepared to be bored as Lorenz will attempt to clarify everything for the non-philosophy students.
None.
Pretty easy and interesting, make sure you go to precept!
Recommended to anyone.
Stick through the fragmentary authors - it's worth it to get to Plato and Aristotle!
TAKE IT!
Take it for an easy EC!
Take it if you're interested in philosophy. You won't regret it.
Take it to fulfill EC, it is fairly easy and not much work, and you can pdf it, so no stress at all. But certainly it is not the most exciting class.
Take it! If you have the slightest bit of interest in ancient philosophers!
Take it! It's a great EC, the assignments are short, and the final is only a 1000-words - plus everyone should have a basic knowledge of  Socrates/Plato/Aristotle and their contributions.
Take it.
Take it. It's interesting, not impossible, and is great for an EC.
Take it. You don't even have to go to the lectures most of the time. But it's important you keep up on the readings.
Take the class just to do the readings--they're wonderful. And a simply way to get rid of a distribution requirement

Take this class if you like philosophy. Some science or math people will have little patience for the presocratic theories about the universe being water etc but it is a necessary grounding to understand later thought.

Take this course if you have a specific interest in ancient philosophy, but don't expect it to be a good, general introduction to philosophy.  As someone who simply wanted to fulfill my EC requirement and get a taste of philosophy, I wish I had taken something like moral philosophy or something of that nature that would be more relevant to everyday life.  That being said, it is not difficult and requires very little work.
Take this course if you need an EC, it's really interesting and pretty well-taught, all round.
The class has some important material to learn, but it honestly does not present it in a way that you could not get from just reading the material by yourself.

The readings were more interesting than I had expected them to be. It's very well explained and taught. I enjoyed writing the papers for it. I took for a pdf though, it might be hard to get an A in the class
This is a relatively easy way to get an EC out of the way, but unless you're really interested in ancient philosophy, the class moves slow at times and the material can be dense.

This is an excellent course that will familiarize you with the ancient philosophers. The most important thing is to do the readings and attend precept; in my experience, lecture is not essential but it is helpful.
To take it for sure. Having no background in PHI, I was able to keep up and contribute.
Yes
You'll learn about the foundations of thought and realize why it's so utterly wrong to take the ancient masters for granted.
decent pdf, but i dont feel like i learned all that much even though im averaging a b
do it.
good course for gaining an overview of the ancient classical philosophers.
great way to fill EC
lots of work, generally good.
descrip: This course discusses the ideas and arguments of major ancient Greek philosophers and thereby introduces students to the history and continued relevance of the first centuries of western philosophy. Topics include the rise of cosmological speculation, the beginnings of philosophical ethics, Plato's moral theory and epistemology, Aristotle's philosophy of nature, metaphysics and ethics. The course ends with a survey of philosophical activity in the Hellenistic period.

title: Intermediate Korean II
reviews: A's are hard to come by.
Don't slack off. Quizzes get harder and harder as time goes on.
If you are at all interested in learning Korean, the Korean classes here are great.  The classes are fun, the teachers are awesome, and you cover a lot of material.
If you are interested in Korean you should definitely keep taking this class.
If you've taken the previous course (105), take it!
Take the class if you want to learn more Korean! The work load is extremely reasonable and the lectures are very clear.
prereqs: KOR 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 105. Continued development of four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) in Korean. Complex grammatical structures and irregularities will be taught while the basics are reviewed. Idiomatic expressions will be introduced; journals will be kept for writing practice.

title: Selected Topics in Logic
descrip: This course covers areas of current interest in mathematical logic.

title: Introductory Playwriting
reviews: If you have an interest in writing or any aspect of theater - acting, directing, or just reading plays - you should take this class. Professor Sandberg is excellent and the class is a lot of fun. One of my favorite classes.
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it!
Take it! It's wonderful.
Take this course if you have any sort of interest in writing plays. The instructor is great, the classmates will be great, and, I assure you, you will learn.
descrip: This is a workshop in the fundamentals of writing plays. Emphasis will be on solving problems of structure, dramatic action, and character. Attention will also be given to innerlife, language, atmosphere on stage, creating living dialogue, and examining the sources to be used in writing, etc.

title: Infrastructure and Design: Design and Disaster
prereqs: CEE 262 - Structures and the Urban Environment..
descrip: This seminar is an effort to use design tools as a way to gain understanding of how physical infrastructure affects and can influence social organization and ideologies. The course will survey the general topics and specific case studies to develop an understanding of the contexts and forms of civil works and infrastructures.

title: French and American Crisscrosses in Contemporary Poetry
prereqs: Some knowledge of French is desirable, but not required..
descrip: This course explores French and American poets reading each others' works from 1970 on: from Emmanuel Hocquard's discovery of Charles Reznikoff, to Norma Cole's translations of Anne Portugal. Students will become acquainted with the French and American poets currently grouped around small publishing houses and centers for Franco-American exchange in both countries. They will develop their own tastes for the poetry created in this multi-faceted milieu: for the "mechanical lyricism" of Pierre Alferi, for Hocquard's "reverse elegies," for Lyn Hejinian's "rhythm of cognition."

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Global Environmental Governance
descrip: Examines intl law & governance in the context of environmental problems. Considers the need for regulation under conditions of scientific uncertainty in issues such as climate change, bovine growth hormones, GMOs, fisheries management, biodiversity conservation, ozone depletion. Explores the efficacy of diverse regulatory approaches, mechanisms for scientific advice to policymakers & participation by business firms, NGOs. Considers intersections between environmental regulation (both domestic and international) with trade, investment, & multilateral development, aid programs.

title: Arabs in the Americas: Middle Eastern Migrants in the US and Latin America
prereqs: Freshman may take the course with instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will examine the history of an often forgotten component of the great waves of migration to the Americas: Arabic-speaking migrants from present-day Lebanon and Syria who scattered through the US and Latin America. Using sources ranging from historical scholarship to memoirs, congressional reports and press articles, we'll consider the social, economic, political, and legal histories of the Middle Eastern men and women who settled in places as varied as Brooklyn and Buenos Aires. Crossing the lines between US, Latin American, and Middle Eastern history, we'll embark on a fascinating journey on the trail of these forgotten migrants.

title: Ancient Greek: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: Definitely take this class if it is being taught by Wildberg. He really wants the students to learn the material and he's also really cool.
Greek is really hard. Be warned that turbo will consume your life. But if you make it out alive, it's pretty cool to be able to read ancient texts.
I would recommend it, provided he knew it would be a lot of work and a lot of forms and things to handle in a very brief time.

If you want to learn Greek fast, and are inspired, and are prepared to test the limits of your memorization skills, then take this course. If you are ambivalent about learning Greek, or don't like constant studying, then you might want to take CLG 101 instead.
If you're up to the work (Professor Wildberg described the course as harder than orgo [well first he said "ergo"]) and you have an interest then this is an amazing course.
Take it; be prepared for substantial amounts of memorization and a time commitment.

This is a good class, but it really is only suitable for students who have a solid grounding in general grammatical concepts, i.e. who have already studied another foreign language (preferably Latin) for some time
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to Greek grammar. It covers in one semester material usually done in the standard two-semester introductory sequence (CLG 101/102). Students who complete this course and then take CLG 105 in the fall will be able to complete the usual three semesters' sequence in two and can fulfill the language requirement by taking only one additional course, typically CLG 108. This course aims at providing a reading knowledge of Classical Greek, quickly.

title: Muslim South Asia
descrip: Religious, cultural, and political developments in South Asia, home to nearly a third of the world's Muslim population, have long exerted considerable influence on the greater Muslim world. This seminar is concerned with religio-political thought and movements in Muslim South Asia from the 18th century to the present. Topics include: Sufism; the impact of colonialism on Islamic thought and institutions; evolving Islamist trends from late colonial times to the present; and debates on Islamic law and the position of women in India and Pakistan.

title: Seminar in Observational Astrophysics - Seminar in Observational Astrophysics
reviews: Any time you can take a course on telescopes from two of the originators of SDSS, it's a good idea!
Definitely recommend if it is on a topic you enjoy and want to know more about. The class is a friendly and informal environment, perfect for improving your presentation skills in.
Jim and Jill are both retiring and will not teach again. But if they change their mind, this is a very good class. Highly recommended.
This was a very useful seminar. It taught us on observational techniques in astronomy. It is a very important class even if you are planning to do theory.
Use the seminars as an opportunity to expand the depth and breadth of your knowledge on the given topic. The exposure to these ideas is very valuable.
Whether you work in observation area or not, this course will give you a lot of new information.
descrip: Students will prepare and deliver presentations and lead discussion about topics of current interest in observational astrophysics and techniques. The topic for this academic year will be instrumentation and the upcoming large astronomical projects.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: A fine PDF class, but I didn't get much out of it.  The lectures are okay, but they move very slowly. Much of the information is repeated over and over again, which makes attending 100% of the lectures seem entirely necessary.
Definitely take this class!!! Professor Mann and Professor Monge are excellent teachers.  Not taking this class during your time at Princeton would be a mistake.

Definitely take this, especially if you are a science/engineer looking for a requirement. Mann is an amazing lecturer and cares deeply about his students. He's also a leading anthropologist in his field--what could be better?

Easy EC, interesting material. You can probably pass with minimal work, but if you want to get a lot out of this course you'll need to immerse yourself in the material and talk to the professors outside of class or precept because most students didn't really care.
Excellent class. Definitely take it if you can.
GO TO LECTURE!  It's worth it!

Go to every lecture and take GREAT notes since that's the only place you'll be able to learn the material.

If he uses specific examples, make sure you use them as well on exams/papers.

Take if you're interested in human evolution or ANT since it really is a decent course in that subject area.

Good if you're looking for a easy P/D/F. Pretty interesting subject matter, and Mann is an endearing professor. Plus, a better understanding of our evolutionary history is never a bad thing. If you're taking this course for a grade, I would maybe reconsider (the average for the midterm was surprisingly low).
I'd take it again in a heartbeat. Fantastic class.
If you are looking for something with a light workload and interesting lectures this fits the bill, but feels a little inflated--not that much substance.
If you're not in this course, you're missing out on an amazing experience. Take it!
Take it as an easy EC senior spring.

Take it for an easy EC. P/D/Fing would would great--little work and almost no likelihood of failing.  If you take it for a grade though, there are a lot of people in the class, so the curve may be unforgiving.
Take it!
Take it! don't worry too much about the reading, and go to lecture!
Take this class for the EEB credit as well. The fossil report does not take too much time, and I would say that it was one of the best parts of this class.
Take this class if you have any interest in the subject matter.
Take this course, especially senior spring, and PDF it.
This class is very interesting and the instructors are all highly engaging.
Very little work, but you will not learn much. Good course to PDF
only if you PDF
pretty fun, alan mann is really nice and a good lecturer, but the exams were pretty ahrd because the questions were very open ended and the grading was a little tough
recommend for EC requirement- PDF it!
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications.

title: Introductory Photography
reviews: Art is very subjective--and time consuming.
It is a time commitment that works in a different way than a reading/paper or problem set driven class.
It's a lot of time and work in the dark room and outside of class. Would probably recommend you do it in an otherwise easy semester so you can take full advantage of what it can teach you.
Take it if you want to learn about the fundamentals of REAL photography.  But be warned that there is a pretty major time commitment, especially if you are unused to studio classes

Take this class if you are bored by the monotony of papers and problem sets. Fun, creative class. Gest was a great prof. Be prepared to put in time in the darkroom, but I really looked forward to a the work for this class.

This class was the most enjoyable course I've taken at Princeton but also the most time-consuming. Literally. It is a great course to take Senior spring if you only have two classes because the work is pretty fun and a great break from thesis/other classes.  I wouldn't recommend this class Junior year simply because I don't think I would have had the time to finish all the work on top of a full course load and multiple JPs.  If you think you might be really into Photo, try to get into this Freshman or Sophomore year (which is hard to do, I wasn't able to).

Great course though.. Just don't think it's easy and won't take up a minimum of 8-12 hours/week.
This is deceptively time-consuming; I spent several all-nighters in the darkroom
don't process your photo the night before class. It's way to stressful
take it if you are interested in photography, you will get a lot out of the class.
takes up more time than you would expect.  i had ben gest as my professor.  i felt like i learned a lot about the techniques of photography but not much more.
the field trip is kind of annoying but you if have any interest in photography its a must take!

this is a great class if you want to learn more about photography. People tell horror stories about all the time outside class, but it's a seminar, and it's fun time if you actually like photography (and not that much)
this is a great class.
descrip: An introduction to the processes of photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of light-sensitive material, camera, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of the medium in relation to both student work and the work of guest photographers.

title: Water Quality Modeling and Analysis
reviews: The workload is very low.  The project is very open ended and has been very interesting to me, though that will depend on what topic one chooses.
descrip: The course explores construction and solution of water-quality models for transport and transformation of pollutants in surface runoff, streams, lakes, estuaries, and groundwaters; and the basic principles of water quality modeling. It reviews existing models and the utility and appropriateness of various modeling techniques for analysis and prediction.

title: Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology
reviews: A decent class, but not great. Prof. Ju is not a very good teacher and relies entirely on powerpoint. But on the plus side, it isn't too hard.
I would say if you're very interested in rockets, take it. But if only moderately interested, consider another course.
It's not too much work, and if you want to learn about rockets, it is not terrible. It is not, however, very interesting or exciting.

While "Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology" might sound very exciting, this course is definitely not exciting. Prof. Ju is not a very good lecturer. He lectures off PowerPoint slides. They're not particularly well-made and he goes really fast. That said, the expectation for the learning you have to do is pretty low. All of the assignments are short and not too difficult, and neither are the exams. Half of it is memorizing facts ("Name three methods for cooling a rocket engine and nozzle. What are the merits and dismerits of solid rockets?" ) and the other half of it is a very limited pool of simple calculations and derivations. This both makes you feel like you didn't learn all that much, as well as making it a very easy course. Take it if it's relevant to your interests, but don't have very high expectations for it.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222.
descrip: The study of principles, flight envelopes, and engine designs of rocket and ram/scramjet propulsion systems. Topics include jet propulsion theory, space mission maneuver, combustion control, and system components of chemical and non-chemical rockets (nuclear and electrical propulsion), gas turbine, ramjet, and scramjet engines. Characteristics, optimal flight envelopes, and technical challenges of combined propulsion systems will be analyzed.

title: Remaking American Studies
descrip: This seminar is an experiment that engages its members in two questions: What should every student know about a mysterious and impossible subject of study, America? And second, how best to go about approaching and formulating (even as we interrogate) this knowledge? The seminar offers an opportunity to think about what American Studies is today as a set of practices. It considers conceptions of nationhood, as well as changing notions of individualism, identity, subjecthood, race, and class. It confronts the problem of interdisciplinarity in humanistic study. It also takes seriously the internationalization of "America".

title: Refugees, Immigrants, and Social Justice
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

classes.bldg: Carl A Fields Ctr for Equality

title: Middle English Religious Literature - Piers Plowman and its Forms: The B and C Versions
descrip: This course examines the two longer versions of William Langland's great and enigmatic poem, a poem that draws from a host of traditional discourses--theology, law, politics, philosophy, economics--and whose politics are putatively traditional. Yet it was also a revolutionary text: Langland has been called an author "in advance of himself." We will examine this aporia by considering literary form and philosophical form; revision, publication, and canonicity; theories of medieval narrative and normativity; heterodoxy and "reformation"; authority and authorial identity.

title: Race, Drugs, and Drug Policy in America
reviews: A HUGE AMOUNT OF READING. Great lectures and really interesting material so its definitely worthwhile if you are interested in the subject. Id recommend PDFing

A great course, especially if you want something fun, engaging and interesting to fill your schedule. Also, I really appreciated the course's social/cultural approach to history (very few classes in the department seem to take a similar approach).
A wonderful class!  Absolutely take it.  Some people complain the lectures are disorganized, but you just have to pay attention in class.  And the papers are so much fun to write!
Be prepared for a lot of readings and at times, difficult to follow lectures.
Be prepared for an extremely demanding reading load, but otherwise a fair, engaging, and comprehensive course.

Be prepared to deal with lots of readings and confusing slides!! But what you gain in knowledge is certainly fascinating. I know there are other students who enjoyed the course much more than I did, so I think it's a matter of interest.
Be ready for a ton of reading.
Consider taking it if the professor changes or the amount of reading is no longer at 300 pages a week.
Cool Class!
DEFINITELY TAKE IT!!!! So so so interesting :)
Definitely take this course if you are interesting in the topic.

Don't bother doing anything more than skimming the readings, convince Wailoo to post his ridiculous power points as .ppt files and not pdf's, so you can actually read that paragraph thats hiding under that picture of Harry Anslinger.
Don't take it.

I strongly recommend this course for any student in the history department or any student thinking about majoring in history. I do not recommend this course for students simply looking for a HA requirement because the amount of work and deep analysis expected is challenging, especially for younger students. Don't let the title of drugs fool you, it is not a course where you can slack! Going to lectures is a must and finishing the readings as much as possible is also a must, if you do this, then you will be well prepared for the assignments and learn some extremely interesting facts along the way!

I think it's a good (not great) course because it isn't exactly what you expect. I expected to discuss race and drug policy more. We mostly just discussed drugs, random facts about them, and the people associated with them rather than anything particularly interesting.
I would definitely recommend this course to everyone, but you have to be willing to do a lot of reading each week, and put in a lot of effort into the two papers and the final exam.
I would recommend this course.
I would strongly recommend for history majors and other students in need of an HA that are interested in "alternative" historical studies.
If you are really interested in the subject, then definitely take it.  Its a lot of work but it is worth it if you are really interested.

If you are strongly interested in the subject material, you'll like the class. It's interesting material, certainly. However, I did not love the format of the class. That being said, I'm much more used to seminars, rather than larger lecture classes that rely heavily on slides.
Interesting for overall view of drug history. Great for initiating superficial discussion of the topics, but there was very little look into the deeper aspects of drugs and ethnicity.
Interesting, well presented course, just be prepared to do the reading and don't take if you plan on skipping lecture (lecture attendance is indirectly taken and factored into final grade)
It's an interesting subject, but it's a lot of reading.  Only take it if you  have a lot of time to devote to the reading.
Its an interesting class with a lot of reading you could probably get away with not doing.
Its not really AAS.
Keep up with the reading and take good notes otherwise by the time the final comes you will have to do a lot more work.
Learn to deal with the slides; and start your second paper early.
No comment

One of my favorite courses at Princeton. A strong, very eye-opening course that should appeal to students in a wide variety of disciplines (politics, public policy, history, sociology, etc.). Although it is quite a bit of work (two papers and a final exam), if you can reasonably fit it in your schedule, do try to take it!
Only take it if there is not something else you would prefer to take. It was a nice supplement to my schedule, but I don't feel like I got that much out of it.
Shop the course and see if you like Professor Wailoo's lecture style. Be aware that the second paper will be graded much more harshly than the first.
Stay engaged and try to go to lecture.
Super interesting! Definitely take it. It's a lot of work but you get a lot out of it!
TAKE NOTES ON WHAT WAILOO SAYS!
Take it!
Take this class! A lot of work (two papers and a final exam that requires a lot of memorization) but you will learn a lot about the history of drugs and drug policy!
Take this class! Do the reading, it is worth it, go to lecture, they cover different material from readings/take different approaches. This class is amazing!

Take this course if you're interested in race, drugs, and policy!! But be warned, there is a lot of reading. More than it says in the course description. (But I think it's worth it...just learn how to skim).
The course is really interesting and you learn a lot. It is a lot of reading, though, and Wailoo's slides are a bit unorganized. Make sure you pay attention.

The final exam is huge. My advice: make a huge timeline of each drug and controversy, think in terms of themes, and remember legislation. it may seem like a daunting task, but so necessary. it helped me beast the exam. get with a study group. there is no way to do it alone. GREAT CLASS

This class requires a lot of reading. Take if you are interested in the history of drugs or medicine. Start your papers early and get your preceptors' comments.The course tries to address a lot of drugs that span a large amount of time, which can be frustrating for students. Professor Wailoo is an expert in the field of history of medicine (which is clear in the lecture) but the course can try to be tackling too much at once. Readings and lectures do not correspond. Expect on spending alot of time on this course if you decide to take it.

This was one of the most amazing history course (or course, in general) I have EVER taken.  I usually hate history and took this history course as my HA, as this seemed the most interesting.  However, I completely loved the course; the professor and precepters were fantastic.  If this is not enough of an incentive, the material is most fascinating within itself!

Understand that there is a lot of reading, more accurately 200-250 or more. Study every week and keep a clear timeline so that you can keep the general trends clear in your head. What I found to be most important in this class and the way it was run was not the specific legislation or dates, but rather the overarching trends -- how our perceptions of drugs change, or remain the same, over time.

Unless you are already very interested and knowledgeable on this topic (like you're writing your thesis on it or something), I think this class might feel frustrating.  If you have no interest, you will easily be lost to the disorganization; if you have some interest, I am afraid you might be disappointed.
You should take it!
keep up with the reading
lectures can be a waste of time and hard to follow
descrip: From "Chinese opium" to Oxycontin, and from cocaine and "crack" to BiDil, drug controversies reflect enduring debates about the role of medicine, the law, the policing of ethnic identity, and racial difference. This course explores the history of controversial substances (prescription medicines, over-the-counter products, black market substances, psychoactive drugs), and how, from cigarettes to alcohol and opium, they become vehicles for heated debates over immigration, identity, cultural and biological difference, criminal character, the line between legality and illegality, and the boundaries of the normal and the pathological.

title: Life in a Nuclear Armed World
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Science and Gender
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Economics of Health and Health Care
reviews: A lot of people take it b/c Reinhardt is teaching it, but overall only take it if you're looking for a more relaxed course.
Absolutely take this course. It will give you a good sense of the health economics.

As I have told other students before, "If Uwe Reinhardt is teaching, ART 106: Watching Paint Dry, I'd take it!"

If Reinhardt is teaching a class, TAKE IT!
Brush up on elementary economic concepts in your free time.
Definitely take it.  Reinhardt is great.  The class is particularly relevant in the U.S. right now, which makes it even better.
Do not take this class if you want to learn any economics. It is mostly just learning facts about healthcare.
Don't take it unless you have a specific interest in the healthcare field.  Lectures are pointless and the material isn't as interesting as I thought it would be.
Great introduction to the health-care sector. Not much mathematical background needed, as this course is meant for non-econ students as well as for econ majors.

Heath and health care is an interesting subject, but it seemed like the goal of this class was to make me feel like an idiot. The professor is knowledgeable, but arrogant and attempts to impress you with his knowledge of the subject rather than teach you any of the material. Problem sets are difficult, time-consuming, and require mastery of microeconomic theory, finance, and statistics to complete well. This was one of the most challenging courses I took at Princeton, but one where I was constantly fighting to keep my head above water rather than being empowered to succeed.
I really enjoyed this class!
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in health economics or economics. As a pre-med economics major, I am extremely glad that this course was offered.
I'm on the fence about this one. It was a good lecture series, just not a great class.

It's not a bad course if you need an econ class.  But if you're not an econ major be prepared to do extra reading on the side or rely on your econ friends to explain some of the economic concepts in the problem sets.
Take it. It's fun and very informative.
Take this class if you're really interested in learning about healthcare, not if you want an easy Economics class.
Take this course.  If you're American, take this course.
Take this if Prof. Reinhardt is teaching.
This is a course on health economics. Not the health care system. Do not expect to learn much about insurance or managed care.
This is a great course and will be relatively easy for non-econ majors. Not too much math is involved at all.
Unless he reworks the course to work with a large audience, I recommend you find another departmental (for econ majors).
take it!
work hard if you take it
prereqs: ECO 100 or ECO 200 or equivalent..
descrip: This course explores aspects of health systems primarily through the prism of micro-economic theory and analysis. It will be structured around a well-known textbook on the subject. Students successfully completing the course should have a better understanding of this complex system which now absorbs 17% of GDP and will soon claim a fifth.

title: Modern Dance: Beginning/Intermediate Technique and Choreography
reviews: A great course to take whether or not you have dance experience. If you don't, it can open up a new world, if only for a semester, or maybe for life. It's also a lot of fun. Why not?
Fun but lots of work too.  Be open-minded and analytical.
Give yourself a good amount of time to do composition assignments; you'll want to do something that you personally enjoyed to make and perform!

If you have never taken a dance course but really want to and feel up to the task of choreographing short pieces every week, then I suggest this course. Sometimes the material in technique is repetitive but that is balanced by the fast-paced work in the choreography class. It's just nice to take a course where you're doing something different than sitting and taking notes the whole time. Tina and Susan are both very friendly and encouraging.
Make sure you are willing to contribute all the class time
prereqs: PREREQUISITE: DAN 219, equivalent previous training, or instructor's permission. Interview Information: THERE IS NO APPLICATION FOR THIS COURSE. In order to assure correct placement, interested students must attend an open interview which will be held Wednesday, November 10th & 17th from 1:30 to 2:00pm in Room 209 at 185 Nassau Street..
descrip: Dance technique and choreography for beginning and intermediate levels. Technique class will emphasize placement and the increase of movement efficiency through proper alignment. Students will also explore dancing to different rhythms, tempos and styles of music while emphasizing weight of the body and its relationship to space and gravity. In choreography class students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's overarching impact and content.

title: Contemporary Critical Theories - Psychoanalytic Approaches to Siblings, Groups, and Gender
descrip: Psychoanalytical approach to the place of siblings in the formation of the social group and its gendering.

title: Introduction to Media Theory
reviews: Do the readings and really participate

If you are looking for a class to fulfill a distribution requirement, this isn't a bad option -- only two assignments in the year. But be prepared to have no idea what's going on during class. I think you'll find a lot of people in the same boat.

The only way this class is interesting is if you are engaged.  Try not to fall into the laptop-distraction trap!!  It can be somewhat confusing though, and if you zone out for a little while it's easy to get lost.
Yes
descrip: Through careful readings of a wide range of media theoretical texts from the late 19th to early 21st century, this seminar will trace the development of critical reflection on technologies and media ranging from the printing press to photography, from gramophones to radio technologies, from pre-cinematic optical devices to film and television, and from telephony and typewriters to cyberspace. Topics include the relationship between representation and technology, the historicity of perception, the interplay of aesthetics, technology and politics, and the transformation of notions of imagination, literacy, communication, reality and truth.

title: Reading and Writing about the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term) - Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in quantitative fields such as economics, science, and engineering who have completed at least one semester of graduate school..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars.

title: Molecular Biology of Eukaryotes
descrip: Discussion of gene structure and organization, chromatin and chromosome structures, mechanisms of replication, gene expression and regulation in eukaryotic cells. Emphasis will be placed on unique features of eukaryotic systems with examples from higher and lower eukaryotes.

title: Advanced Painting
reviews: Take it!
prereqs: VIS 203, 204 or instructor permission..
descrip: A studio course focused on advanced problems in painting practice, including pictorial structure in abstraction and representation, color in relationship to space and light, working process, and materials. This course, although structured, encourages development of independent work. Group critiques will be conducted. Students gain awareness of historical models as well as contemporary art, as they build and analyze the relationship between student work and contemporary painting culture.

title: African-American Literature - Race and Property
descrip: In this course we will read works of fiction, cultural history and critical race theory that explore the relationship between property ownership and citizenship rights. We will also consider texts that question the role of property in the constitution of racialized identities.

title: Themes in Islamic Law and Jurisprudence
descrip: Selected topics in Islamic law and jurisprudence. The topics vary from year to year, but the course normally includes reading of fatwas and selected Islamic legal texts in Arabic.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: A student should be interested in the topic so that the course will be useful.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially those who are considering become involved in education.
I would recommend it.
Necessary if you want to be a teacher-- great class, great readings, great instruction. Definitely worth your time and effort.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of teaching, with an emphasis on matching instruction to learner characteristics and needs. Students also become familiar with the organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Students perform 18 hours of site-based field experience. Students attend two seminar meetings and a weekly evening laboratory session.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: DO NOT UNDERESTIMATE THE MIDTERM. DESPITE HOW EASY THE MATERIAL SEEMS TO BE THIS IS PRINCETON AND THEY FIND WAYS OF MAKING IT DIFFICULT!
Do all the homework and extr problems: it will help in preparing for exams
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take unless you absolutely have to, even if you were always a "math" person before you came to Princeton.
For a course that is a prereq for many other classes, the students don't have much choice. I would advise Princeton and the Math Department to choose their lecturers more wisely.
Go to class and keep up with the material
Go to office hours and review sessions if you can.
Good fundamentals for future work in mathematics and science.
I think this class is OK, but take 215.

I would recommend reaching is section before lecture so if you have problems during class you can easily ask questions on what you dont understand instead of finding out later that you dont understand.
I would recommend this class to any students who haven't taken multivariate calculus before.
I would recommend this course because it offers practical mathematics that are useful in a variety of fields and are still not based entirely on proof or theory.

I would strongly recommend against taking this if you're only interested in the finance certificate or being an econ major.  Take MAT 200 instead.  This class kills your GPA, is poorly taught, and requires a ton of outside work and learning.  Most of the material covered in this class is not necessary for the math-track econ classes, and the material that is is covered in sufficient detail in MAT 200.
I would take this class if you have a good teacher.
If you are interested in math and intrigued by calculus, then take this course. It takes work, but if you like it, then it's worth it.
If you like math, take it.
If you liked math in high school, this class is great. It's like BC but 3D so its familiar and also new. Knowing physics would definitely help.

It's a great class. Make sure you have a good instructor, do your homework, and make sure you don't fall behind - it's hard to catch up since it's a really fast class. It's greatly rewarding, and a lot of fun, if you enjoy calculus.
It's not like anyone takes this class for fun.

Its the kind of course that you should take if you need to take Multivariable calculus, or have a general interest in higher-level math. It is very well taught, and the ideas and concepts presented are readily applicable to science courses and economics classes.
Keep up with the work on a weekly basis.
MAT 201 is a difficult class and requires work.  If you enjoy a challenge and are willing to commit time to learning the material you will like it.
MAT201 was interesting and culminated in a strong understanding of calculus in several variables.
Math is essential
Meh. It's all right. A fine required class, and maybe enjoyable if you just like math, too, but it's no pushover.
Most people have to take it anyways, I would just tell them to study hard and its not that bad.
Not too bad if you have to take it.  Definitely find an instructor you can understand.
Only take it if you need to.
Practice with more difficult questions.
Read the chapter and/or watch Adrian Banner's videos before going to class.

Read the textbook. Go to class. Make sure you know the underlying principles which govern the steps you are taking.
Only take this course if you have Luc as your professor. Watch Adrian Banner videos.
Stay on top of reading the textbook, go to office hours and study groups, and do extra problems.
Students taking this course should go to class, take good notes, and use the resources available to them (especially the practice exams and quizzes).

Study every week, go to office hours if you cannot do the homework, go to the review sessions! I didn't do really well but I also didn't take advantage of all the help offered, so really, I cannot complain. 

Yet, only take the course if you need it! Unless you are really into math, as a hobby...
Take it if you need it as a departmental, or if you really enjoy math. 201 really shouldn't be taken "for fun."

Take it if you want to learn more multi; cannot comment on how it compares with 200 and 203. I should've discovered Adrian Banner's recorded review sessions (which, if you're taking 201 in the fall, might be real live review sessions) much, much sooner.
Take it.
Take only if necessary, or if really like learning math.
Take this course if it is required, or if you have a strong interest in and affinity for math.
Take this course if you're interested but keep up with the material!
The Adrian Banner videos serve as a valuable source of review! It might be best to watch one weekly. The review sessions did not help as much, since they weren't structured.

The content of this course is really good stuff - solid, real calculus (not like those series from MAT 104) - but it's also pretty conceptual and it takes awhile to hammer in those concepts. Which you don't really have, since the class just keeps moving forward. If you're considering it, I think this is one of those courses where it would be really good to keep up, but if you're like me and you couldn't, it's still possible to learn it all at the end of the semester....
The course is definitely challenging and should not be taken lately, but if your interested in Math i suggest take it.
The course is hard. Take it only if you have to.
This class is good to take if you are interested.

This class is pretty time consuming in that it demands a lot of studying outside of the p-sets and class.  The tests are hard and if you do not have to take this class, I would not suggest taking it for fun.
This course is certainly not easy, but it is worthwhile for its applications to sciences and engineering. Take it if it is required for your major.
This course is doable, and presents essential knowledge of you are interested in the higher maths.
This course may be challenging at times but is a worthwhile introduction to multivariable calculus. Overall, the workload is manageable and professors are very willing to help.

This course presents information that is necessary for many engineering and science courses of study, so it is quite useful, but make sure you get a good preceptor.  Mine was good, but I've heard that others are much more difficult to understand.  Take good notes in case the textbook explains something badly, and go out of your way to do practice problems if you can make time.  The best way to get used to and understand this material is guided practice (by answers or with a teacher/tutor's help).  Start the homework early and go to office hours.  I wish I had done so more often.

This is a challenging course. Go to lectures, office hours, review sessions, and watch the Banner review videos. And do practice problems. Beware that it gets harder as it goes along. If you're deciding between this and 203, consider your reasons for wanting to learn math and if you think getting a bit more theoretical grounding is worth the increased time commitment.
challenging, but not too hard.  a good level math course for people experienced in math but not taking it for other subjects
don't take unless necessary, even if you think youre good at math
if you are interested in concepts either being covered in physics or are interested in applications of integrals, the class will be more engaging
it's tough!
stay on track
study for the quizzes
prereqs: MAT 104 or permission of instructor. Two terms of advanced placement may be substituted for the MAT 104 prerequisite with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in 3-space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes' theorem.

title: Sociological Studies of Inequality(Half -Term)
descrip: This segment of the JDP seminar covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. Course begins by reviewing major theories, constructs, measures, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks two through six focus on institutions that are expected to produce (and reproduce) inequalities, including families, neighborhoods, schools, labor markets, and penal policy.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Making Networks Work
descrip: This course will focus on the most recent literature on organizational, cybernetic, and biological networks and what the implications are for actually using networks to accomplish specific functions ? how to lead, host, orchestrate, or manage them in ways that exploit their full value.

title: Problems in Ancient History - Ancient and Medieval Numismatics
descrip: A seminar covering the basic methodology of numismatics, including die, hoard and archaeological analysis. The Western coinage tradition will be covered, from its origins in the Greco-Persian world through classical and Hellenistic Greek coinage, Roman imperial and provincial issues, the coinages of Byzantium, the Islamic world and medieval and renaissance Europe. Students will research and report on problems involving coinages related to their own areas of specialization. Open to undergraduates by permission of the instructor.

title: Shades of Passing
prereqs: Juniors and Seniors only.
descrip: This course studies the trope of passing in 20th century American literary and cinematic narratives in an effort to re-examine the crisis of identity that both produces and confounds acts of passing. We will examine how American novelists and filmmakers have portrayed and responded to this social phenomenon, not as merely a social performance but as a profound intersubjective process embedded within history, law, and culture. We will focus on narratives of passing across axes of difference, invoking questions such as: To what extent does the act of passing reinforce or unhinge seemingly natural categories of race, gender, and sexuality?

title: Advanced Social Statistics
descrip: Thorough examination of linear regression from a data analytic point of view. Sociological applications are strongly emphasized. Topics include: (a) a review of the linear model; (b) regression diagnostics for outliers and collinearity; (c) smoothers; (d) robust regression; and (e) resampling methods. Students taking the course should have completed an introductory course in probability and statistics.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Government Activity
descrip: Analyzes government involvement in "market failures"; externalities (corrective tolls for congestion, environmental damage); "natural" monopolies (infrastructure- telecommunication, electricity-regulation and pricing); efficiency and equity aspects of excise and income taxes; and alternative social security structures and reform proposals in the U.S. and other countries. Prerequisite: 511c.

title: Contemporary Literary Theory
reviews: Attend lectures- they really clarify the readings.
Cadava is incredibly good but the readings for this course are very hard.
Definitely take this course if you get the chance - Professor Cadava is perhaps one of the most insightful lecturers at Princeton.

Do the readings and come to class! The texts are difficult but part of the learning comes from struggling with these texts and simply accepting that they are tough! And the struggle is worth the effort in the end.

Excellent course for understanding the relation between literary theory and contemporary issues. Readings are some of the most difficult I have encountered, but well worth the time. It is also possible to skim the readings and still get a pretty good idea of them in class.
Hard course, but you shouldn't leave college without it.
I would advise other students to take the course but not necessarily feel obligated to attend lectures.

I would take this course if you are looking for a different way of looking at contemporary political and cultural events, or if you are looking for a basic grounding in literary theory. Be warned that the readings, while short, are often very dense, but you will get better at reading this type of writing as the semester progresses. Professor Cadava is excellent, so by all means take it if he is teaching it, even if they repeat the large seminar format.
It's exhausting trying to keep up with this class.

Only if you like reading difficult texts. But really, they're worth it. Once you've read this stuff, you can write about it for any Humanities paper and the paper instantly becomes better. Well, maybe not, but I certainly know it's helped my writing.
Recommend if it's a seminar.
Take it! You'll learn to think differently.
Take it.
Take this class only if you really like theory.

This is a spectacular introduction to literary theory, of interest to students of literature, philosophy, and politics, alike. Professor Cadava is brilliant and one of the nicest faculty members at Princeton. The course has the power to change how you look at the world. I highly recommend it!
Worth taking for Cadava's brilliant lectures.
Worthwhile.
a delicious class.
descrip: An intensive survey of the most important terms in contemporary theory and their role in recent cultural and political debates. Each week will take up a new critical term, examining both its history and its current usages. Terms might include: language, ideology, performativity, sexuality, ethics, media, trauma, AIDS, globalization, and war.

title: Interdisciplinary Research - Disciplines as Moral Orders
descrip: Just as cross-cultural comparisons enable critical sociocultural analysis, cross-disciplinary juxtapositions help to expose and disorient unexamined assumptions about knowledges: particularly the conventional distinction between epistemological and ethical discourse. Readings and discussion consider disciplines as moral orders and disciplinary communities as historically contingent yet intellectually compelling contexts for meaning-making.
