While this Anthropology-of-Knowledges approach may be familiar in science studies, the seminar focuses on the social sciences (e.g., psychology, sociology) and humanities (e.g., history, journalism).

title: Elementary Japanese II
reviews: Be sure you have time to practice daily. It is a difficult language, but the instructors are excellent and make the class very enjoyable.
I recommend this class only if you have the time and motivation to put the work in. You can't just skate by in this class and expect to do well.
If you are interested in Japanese... Take it!
If you are interested in learning Japanese, this is a nice match.

If you are prepared to do a lot of work and devote a lot of time to learning the language, this is a great class. The professors are very kind and approachable. The lectures and drill sections, while sometimes stressful, are all very helpful. If you stay on top of the work, it is incredibly rewarding.
It's a fantastic program, and an absolutely fascinating language.
It's very work-intensive, so be prepared for a lot of day-to-day work.

JPN102 was a very interesting course and built on JPN101 very well. Integration of topics regarding Japanese culture provided the knowledge in addition to the language proficiency that would be necessary when visiting Japan.

Japanese is a great language to explore & learn not just to be able to read haiku, understand anime and movies, but also to be able to talk to wonderful people of the Country of the Rising Sun. Don't forget that foreign language acquisition hones clear thinking. Japanese at Princeton is the course to take as it's intensive (5 days a week which is perfect for language class), interesting and full of different activities throughout the semester: speech contest, language tables, origami & calligraphy practice, compositions, etc.
Just be prepared to invest the necessary time. It's a great class.
Take it if you want to learn elementary Japanese.
Take it if you're interested, it is a considerably big commitment though, both in terms of time and effort.
Take it.
Take it. Practice speaking with your classmates.
Take this course. Japanese is fun and rewarding, but you need time and commitment. The teachers are the best.

Taking this course really depends on how strong your interest in Japanese is, as it is a quite challenging course.  Take it if you have a strong interest in the Japanese language and Japanese culture.
The pace, workload, and difficulty of this class was significantly higher than first semester, so be prepared for that. Truly a great class, highly recommended.
There's a lot more kanji in this class than in 101 - study it and study it EARLY. In general, this is definitely a step up from 101 and should be treated as such.
This is one of the best language course here I think.

Wonderful instructors will help you to learn difficult material while keeping you entertained throughout the entire course.
Be prepared for a lot of work, though. You will have to study for this class on a daily basis. Also be advised that you will have to work even harder if you have never studied Japanese or another East Asian language before (for example, learning Chinese characters can be daunting).
You have to take this after 101, but I would even if you didn't have to :)
make sure you have a strong interest in the culture/language. the work won't be worth the work otherwise. you have to make yourself review past kanji/grammer on your own
take it!
prereqs: JPN 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of JPN 101, which emphasizes the basic four skills to achieve survival proficiency level.

title: Mid-Infrared Technologies for Health and the Environment
reviews: I would encourage taking this course, as it does a very good job of giving students practice for giving quality talks in from of an audience.
It's still not a easy or straighforward course for a non-native speaker student when compared to native speaker student.

Professors clearly don't interact with undergrads much, and think it's ok to be late to most lectures, extend class arbitrarily, and have ridiculous expectations for their students. Didn't learn much either.
Take this class if you're interested in anything related to MIRTHE, you'll enjoy it.

This course is quite time consuming, but I don't really feel you learn a vast amount. You will really only benefit from this course if you currently  or considering in the future working for a MIRTHE research group.
descrip: This course is designed to give Juniors, Seniors, and interested graduate students a comprehensive and interdisciplinary introduction into mid-infrared sensing, its applications, and its technological foundations. Topics include: materials, light sources, lasers and detectors for the mid-infrared; spectroscopy and sensing; sensing systems and sensor networks. It addresses such important issues as global warming, policy making, engineering solutions to global challenges, environmental sensing, breath analysis and health applications, and sensing in homeland security.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
reviews: Easier than other ChemE classes, and more interesting.
Obviously this is pretty much just for CBEs, and they have to take it, but I enjoyed the class, and I would strongly recommend taking something that Nelson is teaching.
Prof. Nelson is great. She makes the course a lot better and more interesting than what it could be.
Students do not have a choice in taking this course or not, so I cannot really give them any advice for whether or not to take it.
The course is a very good introduction to reactors. I wouldn't take it unless you need it as a requirement, but it's certainly one of the better departmental classes.
Write down everything on the board.
take it and work hard.
prereqs: CHE 341/CBE 341..
descrip: Introduction to chemical reaction engineering and reactor design in chemical and biological processes. Concepts of chemical kinetics for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. Coupled transport and chemical/biological rate processes.

title: Introduction to Painting and Book Illumination of the Islamic World
descrip: A survey of painting and book illustration in the Islamic world between the 8th and the 20th centuries. Topics may include thematic subjects, styles and schools, as well as intensive discussions of some masters. Visits to museums are planned.

title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - The Historical Avant-garde
reviews: If you like history even just a little bit, take this course or any course JLC teaches.

The subject matter is very specific to a time and place in history. Nonetheless the material and diverse knowledge of Professor Cohen make it appealing and open to anyone interested in architectural methodology and criticism.
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students only.
descrip: The seminar frames the saga of the Russian avant-garde in a broad historical perspective. Lectures will present the main issues typical of Russian architecture production, against the background of 20th century history. During the second part of the class, students will analyze specific designs, buildings or discourses, in echo to the issues introduced in the lecture, with particular attention to Western reception and discussion, from Bruno Taut, Le Corbusier, Erich Mendelsohn, Hannes Meyer and Frank Lloyd Wright to Aldo Rossi, Anatole Kopp, Manfredo Tafuri, and Rem Koolhaas.
